title: Janet Gaynor Will Bow On Broadway in Maude
description: Janet Gaynor, who won an Academy Award in 1929, retired from the movies in 1939 and has acted in only a single play, will star in Harold and Maude on Broadway. Her part, that of an 80yearold woman who has a relationship with a 19yearold boy, was to have been done by Glynis Johns. In an apparently amicable separation, however, Miss Johns left the cast, and last weekend Miss Gaynor agreed to replace her. The play will open on Jan. 28.

title: Riviera Furnishings Of Aga Khan Sold
description: MONTE CARLO, FRENCH RIVIERA

title: Gunpowder Plant Blast In Alabama Hurts Eight
description: BESSEMER, Ala., Oct. 31 (AP) Eight persons were injured tonight in an explosion and fire at the Hercules Powder Company plant in this Birmingham suburb. The authorities evacuated the area in the event of another explosion, the Birmingham police said.

title: 9 Displaced L.I. Families Picket Exxon Over Expenses We Have No Place to Go
description: EAST MEADOW, L.I., Oct. 31  The last of 25 families who were forced from their homes and into a motel 10 months ago after fumes from leaking Exxongasoline storage tanks at a neighborhood station made their homes uninhabitable, picketed the station today to protest the oil company's refusal to continue paying for their food and lodging.

title: Interest Rates Lifted In Germany Liquidity Added to System German Central Bank Lifts Key Interest Rates
description: PARIS, Oct. 31  The West German central bank increased key interest rates today for the fourth time this year, in a move apparently opposed by the Government, which fears the action may damage the dollar and undermine the Federal Reserve Board's antiinflation policy.

title: Dance: Steve Paxton's Improvisations
description: QUESTIONS, questions. Tuesday night's performance by Steve Paxton and David Moss at Camera Mart/Stage One prompted lots of questions. And those questions sprouted other questions. What happened?

title: REGULATION IS URGED FOR FUNERAL HOMES; Consumers and Six in House Fight Move to Bar F.T.C. Proposal
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31  Consumers and Congressmen who support efforts to ,regulate the funeral industry rallied today to head off a proposed Congressional action that would force the Federal Trade Commission to drop its plans to enforce rules for the industry.

title: Jet Engine Fails on Alaska Flight
description: SEATTLE, Oct. 31 (AP)  An engine failed on a Northwest Airlines DC10 bound for Fairbanks, Alaska, forcing the plane to return to Seattle, the Federal Aviation Administration reported yesterday. An F.A.A. officer said he was told by airtraffic controllers that the plane made a safe return after one of its three engines had to be shut down because of a minor problem. A Northwest operations official refused to give any further information.

title: Casino Stocks Off as Market Retreats
description: With weakness showing in gambling, computer and energy issues, the stock market yesterday gave back a good part of the strong advance it made on Tuesday.

title: 74 Die in a DC10 Crash in Mexico As Pilot Lands on Closed Runway; 74 Die in Mexico City Jetliner Crash; United Press International
description: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 31  A Western Airlines DC10 on a flight from Los Angeles crashed on landing at the Mexico City airport shortly before dawn today, killing 71 of the 90 people on board and at least three people on the ground.

title: Solomon Sees Peril In Yen Fall Intervening Heavily in Market
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31  Anthony M. Solomon, Treasury Under Secretary for Monetary Affairs, said today that the decline in the value of the Japanese yen was not fully justified by fundamental factors and posed a threat of disruption to the world trading system.

title: David Hicks: Design Globetrotter
description: RCENTLY David Hicks, the celebrated London interior decorator, stepped off the Concorde in New York to spend two days with friends before taking off for Japan. At the same time, his new book, David Hicks Living With

title: Ravitch Tells Senators He'll Forgo M.T.A. Pay
description: ALBANY, Oct. 31  Governor Carey's candidate to head the Metropolitan Transportation Authority told a State Senate hearing today that he did not intended to draw a salary. The M.T.A. board can set a salary as high as $80.000 for the Chairman.

title: Edward F. Carey, 74, Investigator Of French Connection, Is Dead; Took New Rochelle Post
description: Edward F. Carey, retired Commissioner of Police for New Rochelle and a former deputy chief inspector for the New York City Police Department, died Tuesday at the New Rochelle Medical Center. He was 74 years old and lived in New Rochelle.

title: A Welcome Remedy for Stagnant Justice
description: In New York and several other cities in the state, justice is not so much done as postponed. In the five boroughs, the backlog of civil cases has risen 83 percent to 26,659 over the past four years. The number of cases that have been awaiting trial 15 months or longer has almost tripled; there are now nearly 10,000 of them. It is hard to overestimate the poisonous effect of such stagnation on people's lives and their respect for law. New Yorkers should be grateful that someone has now undertaken to flush the system clean.

title: Albany Legislators Nearing Accord On Financing for New Amex Home
description: ALBANY, Oct. 31  Negotiators were close to agreement tonight on a measure to finance a new headquarters for the American Stock Exchange as the State Legislature prepared to return tomorrow for a special session on this and a variety of energy matters.

title: Celtics Embarrass Nets, 11679, as Bird Dazzles the Crowd; Bird Flies High; The New York Times/ Larry C. Morris
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Oct. 31  It was a night when ghosts and goblins, witches and skeletons walked the streets. It was an evening for haunted houses, mysterious happenings and eerie, inexplicable sensations.

title: Opera: Viennese Perform Ponnelle's Figaro Dexter to Remain in Met Opera's Troika
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31Mozart's Le Nozze di Figaro had its world premiere in Vienna in 1786, and was cordially but not rapturously received. It remained for Prague totake this marvelous opera to its bosom. But Le Nozze di Figaro remains indissolubly tied to Vienna, and last night the Vienna State Opera presented it as the third production in its series at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts. Richard Strauss's Ariadne auf Naxos, the last of the operas that the company has brought to Washington, will be performed next Tuesday.

title: Harasser Shot by IRT Passenger
description: Twice threatened by a man with knife, a middleaged subway passenger suddenly drew a gun and opened fire yesterday afternoon and gravely wounded his alleged harasser, the transit police said.

title: Heating Oil Supply Surges in Week
description: Supplies of distillate fuels, which include heating oil, surged again last week, rising by 6.1 million barrels to 245.4 million, according to the weekly report released yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

title: The Region Byrne Defends use Of Copter by Family
description: TRENTON  An aide to Governor Byrne yesterday defended the use of a state helicopter to fly the Governor's daughter Susan from Princeton to Atlantic City to meet Willie Mays Tuesday.

title: MarkNote Sale Set
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP)  The first of two recently announced sales of United States debt securities denominated in West German marks will be held next Monday and Tuesday, the Treasury Department said today. The offering will involve notes totaling up to two billion German marks, or about $1.1 billion, with interest rates to be announced next Monday. The agency said the notes, available only to German residents, would have maturities of 2.5 years and 3.5 years and would be allocated between them at its discretion.

title: Obituary 5 No Title
description: Deaths

title: Islanders Scoring
description: FIRST PERIOD  1, Vancouver, G?? 3 (Gradin, Linbgren), 6:48. 2, Islanders, Howatt 1 (Merrick, Lorimer), 11:13. Penalties  Mclihargey,?? Van, 3:14; J. Potvin, Is!, 5:28; PoneIIi, 1st,. 13:31; Vancouver, (bench minor served by Sedibauer) 19:29.

title: Books of The Times Claims of Greatness
description: THOUGH one hadn't an inkling of it from reading her The Female Eunuch when it appeared a decade ago, Germaine Greer turns out to be sufficiently versed in the history of Western paint

title: E.P.A. Confirms View Of Westway as a Peril To Quality of City Air Confidence Is Expressed
description: The Federal Environmental Protection Agency said yesterday that new data on air quality and traffic flow presented by proponents of the Westway had not altered its oppostion to the highway because the agency believed the highway would be a major source of air pollution.

title: Joan Mondale Opens Arts Program for Gifted Inner CityYoungsters
description: The New York Times /John Sotomayor

title: Nuclear Report's Call for Reforms Wins Bipartisan Praise in Congress; But There Is Little Agreement About the Remedies Industry Relieved Moratorium Was Not Urged One of the major recommendations of
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31  The President's Commission on the Accident at Three Mile Island won bipartisan support in Congress today for its central conclusion that fundamental changes are required if the risks of nuclear power are to be kept within tolerable limits.

title: Louisiana Vote Totals Bring a Switch in Runoff; Cautious Campaign
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 31 (UPI) Major changes in voting returns today put the chairman of the Public Service Commission, Louis Lambert, in the Dec. 8 runoff for Governor against Representative Dave C. Treen, a Republican.

title: Obituary 3  No Title
description: Deaths

title: McCall Expected To Take Position At U.N. Mission Harlem State Senator Due to Be a Liaison Delegate
description: ALBANY, Oct. 31  President Carter is expected to name State Senator H. Carl McCall, a Manhattan Democrat who represents the West Side and Harlem, to be delegate to the United Nations, according to officials here and in Washington.

title: New Bond Issues
Seoul Assassins Reportedly Tried To Draw Army's Chief Into Plot; Seoul Assassins Reportedly Tried to Persuade Army Chief to Join Conspiracy After Killings; Continued From Page A1
description: SEOUL, Oct. 31  Kim Jae Kyu, the head of the Korean Central Intelligence Agency who allegedly killed President Park Chung Hee of South Korea last Friday, attempted to draw the Army Chief of Staff, Gen. Chung Seung Hwa, into the plot after the assassination, according to Korean and Western sources here.

title: Obituary 6  No Title
description: Deaths

title: China Buys 42d St. Motel For Office and Residence Bringing Business to New York China Purchases a Motel on 42d St.
description: The Chinese Government purchased a 20story motel overlooking the Hudson River yesterday and before nightfall workers began tidying the premises in preparation for officials who will be spending their first night in the new quarters.

title: Minorities Influence Will Rise Next Week In Houston's Election; Houston Vote To Widen Role For Minorities; Continued From Page A1
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 31 During Houston's quartercentury rise to national stature as the country's fifthlargest city, its spectacular expansion has essentially been managed  or mismanaged. say a growing army of critics  by a network of businessmen and developers. From their downtown skyscrapers, and from City Hall that is both literally and figuratively in the skyscrapers shadows, they have followed a policy of minimal taxes, minimal services and minimal control over growth and development.

title: Brooklyn Murder Indictment
description: A Brooklyn man was arraigned yesterday on an indictment charging that he murdered a 63yearold woman in the BedfordStuyvesant section during breakin at her home. The suspect, Ronald Pinckney, 23 years old, of 300 Putnam Avenue, is accused of killing Ruth Priscu of 431 Putnam Avenue on April 5.

title: A Wood Stove Spirit At the White House; A Wood Stove Spirit at the White House; Continued From Page C1
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 On a trip to Iowa in May, President Carter casually dropped the word that he would install a woodburning stove at the White House before winter  a remark that conjured heartwarming images of the First Family gathered around a blackened, antique potbellied monster, all to save heating oil.

title: Topics Hoarding Facts, Releasing Vegetables Revisionism Revisited Tomato Surprise
description: Since revisionist is one of the dirtier words in Henry Kissinger's vocabulary, it is amusing to observe the latest controversy about how the former Secretary of State revised his memoirs to deal with a conspicuous critic of his Cambodian policies. This particular sport has required a careful comparison of Mr. Kissinger's edited galley proofs with the published book, and clocking the changes against the relentless charges of a British journalist, William Shawcross.

title: Around the Nation; U.S. Seeks Dismissal of Suit Brought Over Atomic Tests
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 31 (AP)  The Federal Government, in response to lawsuit filed by 442 residents of three Western states, said yesterday that there was no evidence that fallout from nuclear testing had caused death or illness for those living downwind from the test site in Nevada.

title: 3 Factions in Japan Premier's Party Join to Oust Him
description: TOKYO, Oct. 31  The split in Japan's governing party deepened today as the leaders of three factions opposing the continuation of Masayoshi Ohira as Prime Minister agreed to coordinate their efforts to force him out.

title: Martinelli Faces a Battle For 4th Term in Yonkers Largely Ceremonial Post
description: YONKERS, Oct. 31 For the first time since he was elected Mayor six years ago, Angelo R. Martinelli is engaged in tough battle for reelection.

title: The U.N. Today; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
Miss Miller Wed to W. D. Zabel
description: Deborah M. Miller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fred M. Miller of Reading, Pa., was married yesterday to William D. Zabel, son of Mrs. Louis J. Zabel of Sioux Falls, S.D., and the late Mr. Zabel. Surrogate Millard L. Midonick of New York County performed the ceremony in his chambers.

title: $100,000 Prize Given To Diabetes Specialist For Clinical Research; Clinical Research Stressed
description: Dr. Jesse Roth, an expert in the biology of insulin action, was named yesterday as the first winner of a new $100,000 annual prize for outstanding achievements in clinical research.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Treasury Notes Yield 10.75% Key Rates
description: The Treasury sold 10year notes yesterday at a record yield of 10.75 percent as investors and dealers became less enthusiastic about buying new Government securities than they were Tuesday, when threeandahalfyear year notes were auctioned.

title: C.A.B. Awards Airline Routes
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP)  The Civil Aeronautics Board gave Eastern Air Lines permission today to fly between Albuquerque, N.M., and DallasFort Worth. It also awarded Trans

title: Thomson Joins Presidential Race
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP)  Former Gov. Meldrim Thomson Jr. of New Hampshire, a leader of the country's staunch conservatives, announced today that he was running for President on a thirdparty ticket because none of the Republican contenders were acceptable.

title: Gold Futures Fluctuation
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (Reuters) The Commodity Futures Trading Commission said today that it had approved a request by the Chicago Board of Trade for a permanent expansion of the daily pricefluctuation limit for gold futures to $25 per troy ounce. The board had temporarily expanded the limit on Oct. 1.

title: Home Beat; Original Tiles Handmade to Order
description: BRENDA BERTIN studied art and textile design, as well as working as an editor, before moving to Iran with her husband, a physicist, in 1976. The Bertins also traveled widely in Italy and France. Tile country is how Mrs.

title: Legislator and 3 Coal Officials Indicted in Alabama; Another Defendant Replies
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 31 (AP)  A Federal grand jury has returned a 19count indictment naming seven persons, including a state legislator and three officials of the state's largest coal mining company, on charges of racketeering and extortion, according to a United States Attorney.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Judge Curbs Forced Medication In Treatment of Mental Patients Freedom to Decide Right of Communication
description: BOSTON, Oct. 31 (UPI)  Federal District Judge Joseph L. Tauro has ruled that a mental patient has the right to refuse tranquilizing medication unless he is likely to become violent. The judge called such forced medication an affront to human dignity.

title: Synthetic Fuel Bill Unites Foes; Development Opposed Altogether
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31  An odd coalition of environmentalists and conservative business interests announced today a campaign to defeat President Carter's proposal for an energy security corporation designed to develop and produce synthetic fuel in volume.

title: 2 Senators Soften Proposed Changes for Arms Treaty; McGovern Looks to Future Cuts
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31  Two Democratic Senators whose support for the strategic arms limitation treaty with the Soviet Union had seemed doubtful proposed milder changes today than had been expected. As a result, they were regarded as leaning toward approval.

title: Sports Today; BASKETBALL
description: Knicks vs. Utah Jazz, at Salt Lake City. (Television  Channel 9, 9:30 P.M.)

title: VANCE HOPES SEOUL WILL EASE CONTROLS; He Looks to Widening of Political Process in Korea  Departs Today for Park's Funeral
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31  Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said today that the United States hoped the new South Korean leaders would promote political growth and that he was prepared to discuss their political course with them.

title: Design Notebook; In an exhibit and a book, lost mansions live.
description: THAT noise we hear when we go skimming through one of our more prosperous countrysides is the knell of the very big private house. It is a sad sound, and many things contribute to it.

title: Obituary 4 No Title
description: Deaths

title: Two Lotteries Hit 728 Hard Way Together
description: The winning number yesterday in the Connecticut and New Jersey lotteries was 728. The odds against its happening were 999 to 1, the same as for any number drawn in either lottery.

title: Sifting for Lessons of the Crash Robert Lekachman The lessons to be drawn from the searing experiance of the stock mar ket collapse in the United States and the global Depression that ensued are still unclear so years after the crash. Interviews with come of the world's leading economists, including many who have shaped have postDepression economic thought, show that each reads into the ?? of the Great Depression his own vision of economic reality.
description: The 59yearold teacher of economics at the City University of New York is the author of The Age of Keynes, an evaluation of the economics that grew out of the 1930's. He is an articulate critic from the left of current establishment economics.

title: Concert: Sequoia String Quartet
description: THE Sequoia String Quartet, heard last Saturday afternoon at the Metropolitan Museum, is a sevenyearold Californiabased ensemble that won the Naumburg Chamber Music award in 1976.

title: Making a Fireplace More EnergyEfficient; Screens
description: GETTING the fireplace ready for winter involves more than just sweeping the chimney in this year of exorbitant fuel costs. Homeowners and tenants who pay their own heating bills might even decide they can't afford the pleasures of a fireplace, which wastes far more heat than it produces if energysaving measures are not taken.

title: Hundreds Are Rescued After Blizzard in West
description: CAMPO, Colo., Oct. 31 (AP)  Rescuers plowed through deep snowdrifts today picking up hundreds of people stranded by a blizzard that battered eastern Colorado and the Oklahoma Panhandle with 12 inches of snow and winds up to 90 miles an hour. Two persons were found dead in a car.

title: Bronx Boy Finds 2 Slain at Home
description: An 8yearold Bronx boy climbed down a fire escape and through a window to enter his locked apartment yesterday morning and discovered the bodies of his mother and uncle, who had been bound, gagged and stabbed to death.

title: Golden Profits From Drab Ore Golden Profits Found In LowerGrade Ore The New York Times/Nov. 1, 1979
description: TUCSON, Ariz.  A modern gold mine is not a neatly tunneled cave with glittering veins ready to be chipped from the walls. Instead, it is an open pit where bulldozers shove around tons of unimoressivelooking rock. Until recently the traces of recoverable gold were so scanty that it was not worth crushing and chemically treating the ore. But today the price of gold is more than $380 an ounce, and this has transformed the business of gold mining.

title: Nations Cup Won By U.S.; Prince Philip Heads Group; Exceptions Are Made; Buddy Brown Replaced; Henry the Hawk Wins
description: The United States Equestrian Team won the Nations Cup, the most important event of the week for international riders, at the National Horse Show last night. The victory led to some comments by Coach Bert de Nemethy on how it was achieved.

title: Nov. 4 Declared Will Rogers Day
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP)  The House and Senate adopted a resolution today designating Nov. 4 as a day to honor the memory of Will Rogers. That day will be the 100th anniversary of the birth of the humorist.

title: SOUTH AFRICA BLAST MAY HAVE BEEN BOLT; Some Scientists Now Believe That the Nuclear Detonation Was Super Flash of Lightning
description: A superbolt, which is a lightning flash so powerful that it can release as much energy as a small nuclear weapon, may account for what was orignally thought to be a nuclear detonation near South Africa last month, some scientists now believe.

title: U.S. Senate Confirms 4 For Jersey Court Posts
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate voted yesterday to confirm four new Federal court judges in New Jersey, including Anne Elise Thompson, who will become both the first black and the first woman to serve on the Federal bench in the state. She is currently the Mercer County Prosecutor and previously served as a Municipal Court judge in Trenton.

title: Korea After Park
description: For the third time since 1948, South Koreans have the chance to lay the foundations of a durable, essentially democratic state. This time, with luck and the right kind of American encouragement, the cement may set. Even before the murder of President Park Chum Hee. it was apparent that his oneman rule was obsolete in a nation that his economic policies had transformed. While economic power was diffused, political power was not. The system he created courted the violent end that not even his ring of bodyguards could prevent.

title: Home Improvement; How to repair sticking doors without planing.
description: ALTHOUGH doors sometimes start to stick or rub because the wood has swelled, when an inside door sticks, more often than not wood swelling is not the cause. In most cases, the trouble is due to hinge screws that have worked loose, or to hinges that are improperly mounted. It is only after these possibilities have been eliminated that the homeowner should think about trimming some wood off the edges of the door by planing or sanding.

title: Saving One City Hospital
description: The Jewish Hospital and Medical Center of Brooklyn has been saved from collapse again. The nearly bankrupt institution has been rescued repeatedly by state subsidies but lately Albany's patience has worn thin. So now state and local leaders have persuaded a reluctant Carter Administration to join the rescue. The President's advisers, apparently, did not want him blamed for the demise of a hospital with ties to blacks, Hispanics and Jews in a key political state.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Allied Artists industries has elected to its board Ralph J. Lomma, president of Lomma Enterprises Inc.

title: Idyllic British Valley Unites Against CoalMine Plan; A Test Case for Britain; Opponents Seek More Proof
description: BELVOIR, England, Oct. 31  For eight centuries, the crenellated towers of Belvoir Castle have stood guard over the gentle green pastures and croplands of valley here in central England, an oasis of calm 110 miles north of London.

title: Nuclear Report Mixed, Power Industry Finds Nuclear Report Analyzed Continued From Page D1
description: The nuclear power industry expressed relief yesterday that the Kemeny commission's report on Three Mile Island had stopped short of urging a moratorium on the licensing of nuclear plants, but analysts foresaw substantial and expensive licensing delays as inevitable.

title: Dividends
description: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 31, 1979

title: Brown to Announce Presidential Candidacy Nov. 8
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31  Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California will formally announce his Presidential candidacy on Nov. 8, the day after Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts announces in Boston.

title: Judge Fines British Extremist
description: KINGSTON, England, Oct. 31 (AP) Martin Webster, organizer and strategist of Britain's white supremacist National Front. was elven a suspended sentence and fined the equivalent of $320 yesterday for publishing material inciting racial hatred. The charges against Mr. Webster stemmed from articles he had written in the front's newspaper concerning the number of crimes committed by nonwhites.

title: A Perfectionist Does It All Himself; A Perfectionist Does All the Work Himself; The New York Times/Robert Levin
description: UNTIL three years ago, Parker Zaner Bloser had never built anything larger than an architectural model. But he needed a place to live and simply decided to do it all himself. I had literally never wielded a hammer, said Mr. Bloser who, nonplussed his first day on the renovation, went out to buy the best hammer and saw I could find.

title: GOING OUT Guide Kabuki Dancer to Tell of Life
description: PERSPECTIVES Starting tonight at 8 o'clock, the public is invited to three lectures on postmodernism as related to architecture, art and literature, with scholars and critics as guest speakers at the School of Visual Arts,

title: Factory Orders Up 3.9% in September
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP)  New orders for the nation's factories rose 3.9 percent in September to $148.2 billion, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Terese Lasser, Started Group to Aid Women After Cancer Surgery
description: Terese Lasser, founder and former national coordinator of the Reach for Recovery program of the American Cancer Society, died of a heart ailment Tuesday at Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco, N.Y. Mrs. Lasser, who was

title: Cabaret: Dardanelle's Act
description: SINCE Dardanelle, the singer, pianist and sometime vibraharpist, came out of two decades of retirement in 1976, she has been heard in a succession of restaurants where her singing and playing were subordinate to the serving and eating of food. But at Reno Sweeney, where she is appearing this weekend and next with George Duvivier, bassist, she has finally found a place where she can appear as an act.

title: Radio Music
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Sonata for Guitar in E, Soler; Rondo in G, Vorisek; Thousand and One Nights Waltz, J. Strauss Jr., Serenade No. 7, MozartKreisler; Galliards from Lachrimae, Dowland.

title: Corporate Earnings; Corporate Sales and Earnings Reports
description: The company is controlled bv General Motors Corp.

title: 5 Ships Carrying Relief Supplies Said to Arrive in Cambodian Port
description: BANGKOK, Thailand Oct. 31 (Reuters)  Five ships, including three from the Soviet Union, have arrived with food and medicine at the Cambodian port of Kompong Som, relief sources in Bangkok said today.

title: LOUIS STEINBERG
description: Louis Steinberg, former district counsel of the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service in New York, died Saturday at Mount Sinai Hospital at the age of 75. He lived in Manhattan.

title: 14 Are Reported Killed In 3 Salvadoran Clashes
description: SAN SALVADOR, Oct. 31 (AP)  Authorities reported that 14 persons were killed in three clashes today and a businessman was kidnapped.

title: Bethlehem Net Up 15.6% Southern Company
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's secondlargest steel company, reported yesterday that the cutting of losses at its shipyard at Sparrows Point, Md., and higher earnings from interest and dividends helped its earnings to rise by 15.6 percent in the third quarter.

title: Letters Birds and Windows
description: Emperor's New Clothes

title: Market Place Loctite's Hunt for a Merger
description: THE Loctite Corporation, a manufacturer of industrial glues, told shareholders recently that preliminary merger discussions were under way and the shares have been trading at higher levels ever since.

title: GARDENING; In Winter Sun, A Windowsill Herb Garden
description: HERBS do not rank among the world's exquisite houseplants. Nor are they particularly easy to grow indoors in the winter. But if you own a sunny windowsill and are willing to invest the time and effort required, they are yours to use and enjoy.

title: In Soviet Bloc, Path From Farm to the City Is Narrowing; Shortages and Bureaucracy; Prague Closing Its Doors; Long Wait for Apartment; Litte Change in Labour Force; Governments Express Confidence; Profits a Measure of Success
description: BUDAPEST  Across Eastern Europe, the six Communist allies of the Soviet Union are struggling to cope with declining economies and a continuing disappearance of opportunities for their people to move from countryside to city or from one field of work to another.

title: Birmingham Victor Elated and Determined; Finds Progress in Vote
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 31  Since last night, Richard Arrington has spoken twice with President Carter, and Senator Edward M. Kennedy has called four times trying to get through. The Senator's nephew. Robert F. Kennedy Jr., dropped by for a chat yesterday, and Gov. Fob James of Alabama called up this morning to say there's no feeling quite like winning an election.

title: Bridge: Brazilians Felt the Pressure Of Play Before Home Fans Bid One Level Too High
description: Competing in your home town in front of your own fans is a mixed blessing, as the Brazilians found out recently in the world team championship in Rio de Janeiro.

title: Vincent DeSimone, 61; Jersey Detectives Chief
description: Vincent J. DeSimone Jr., chief of detectives in Passaic County, N.J., died of cancer Tuesday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Paterson, N.J., at the age of 61. He lived in Hawthorne. N.J.

title: Battle Looming Over Ryan
description: Nolan Ryan, the most glamorous name in tomorrow's baseball freeagent draft, could become the objective of the first bidding battle between George Steinbrenner, the principal owner of the Yankees, and John Mc

title: TV: Issues of Accuracy Miss Shange
description: TWO relatively short items of interest can be found today at relatively odd hours. At 10 this morning, CBS's monthly Magazine feature's a report questioning the veracity of a widely acclaimed documentary. At midnight,

title: MGM Results Off 16.8% in Quarter Uniroyal American Standard
description: MetroGoldwynMayer Inc. reported yesterday that it had a 16.8 percent decline in earnings for the three months ended Aug. 31 but a 24.9 percent jump in profits for the full fiscal year.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I have a cedar closet that had real cedar wood installed on the walls and ceiling about 25 years ago. It has dried out and no longer has any aroma so I would like to give it a coat of cedar oil. Can you tell me if this oil is available, or if there is anything else should do? V. K., Queens.

title: Private Funds Help Park To Get More Loving Care Private Money Helping to Maintain Madison Square Park Neglect Blamed, Not Vandals Company Is Excited Major Improvements Sought The New York Times/Fred R. Conrad
description: It began unobtrusively, early on the morning of Sept. 1, when two men in work clothes began raking the leaves and pruning the hedges in Madison Square Park.

title: The Ups and Downs of BestSellerdom; More Competition Seen; Basis of Lists
description: Life for a book on the bestseller lists in today's marketplace is more volatile than ever. Some books manage to hang on, week after week; others seesaw; some take months to climb; others jump almost to the top the week they are published. All this is a change from the recent past, when the list was more stable.

title: Farm Goods' Prices Fall
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP)Prices that farmers get for raw products fell 2 percent in October, including a sharp drop in the prices of meat animals, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE Outsider to Head Zayre Women's Unit Plotting Texaco Strategy
description: The Zayre Corporation, the big New Englandbased discounter, has shaken up the management of its faltering Hit or Miss chain, which features offprice branded women's apparel, and has appointed an outsider as the new head man. Stanley H. Rutstein, the 38yearold former president of the United States Shoe Company and before that president of U.S. Shoe's Casual Corner retail group, has been named president of Commonwealth Trading Inc., the Zayre subsidary that operates the Hit or Miss chain.

title: Miller Suggests Fed Moved Too Quickly Uncertainty on Third Step
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31  Secretary of the Treasury G. William Miller suggested today that the Federal Reserve might have moved too quickly in changing the way in which the nation's money supply is managed.

title: Shipping/Mails; Outgoing
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Leases Still Hard to Read, State Panel Says The Most Outrageous Form
description: Most of the apartment leases used in New York City violate the state's plain language requirement, a consumer agency charged yesterday. And it asserted that the few leases that did conform to the requirement forced tenants to surrender almost every right given to them under state law.

title: About Moses Park Set for a Winter of Content in Nature's Solitude
description: ISLIP, L.I.  Robert Moses State Park, at Fire Island's western tip, looks, at October's end, as picturepretty and perky as it did when multitudes were trampling its sands last summer.

description: Citibank should not raise its minimum interest rate on corporate loans tomorrow even though its formula is likely to call for an increase in the prime rate, the chairman of the House Banking Committee said yesterday in a telegram to Walter B. Wriston, chairman of New York's largest bank.

title: CARTER ASKS ACTION TO SPUR TECHNOLOGY; Calls for Loosening of Regulatory and Antitrust Constraints Carter Urges Action by U.S. on Lag in Technology; Hundreds of Contributors; Continued From Page A1
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31  In what he called an effort to loosen the stifling constraints imposed on industry by government, President Carter today proposed revisions in patent. antitrust and regulatory policies and other measures to reverse a widely perceived lag in the capacity of American business to exploit technological innovation.

title: Theater: Dying Out By Peter Handke Fading Business
description: NEW HAVEN THE uses and the limits of language  the contrast between what we say and what we doare essential elements in the theater of Peter Handke. In They Are Dying Out, a tantalizing new play of ideas at the Yale Repertory Theater,

title: JUSTICES HEAR PLEA ON KISSINGER PAPERS; ExSecretary of State Argues That Data on Phone Conversations Should Not Be Disclosed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31  Henry A. Kissinger's attorney tried to persuade the Supreme Court today to shield from public disclosure transcripts of telephone conversations that Mr. Kissinger conducted from his White House and State Department offices.

title: CORRECTION
description: Two articles in Metropolitan Report yesterday, about the trial of Anthony M. Scotto, appeared inconsistent because they omitted details of the New York State election law. The law prohibits a candidate for state or local office, or any of the candidate's aides, from accepting cash contributions over $100. All individual contributions of $100 or more must be reported to the Board of Elections. Additionally, Section 14120 of the law forbids the concealment of the name of a campaign donor. Misdemeanor charges can be brought against anyone who accepts a cash political payment of over $100; anyone who accepts a payment of more than $100 and conceals the name of the contributor, and anyone who gives more than $100 and allows his name to be hidden. The issue is discussed further in an article on page B10.

title: 55 M.P.H. Period.
description: SHERMAN OAKS, Calif.  To ease, or perhaps to solve, our energy problem requires only one simple piece of legislation: No one shall manufacture, import or sell any (earthbound) motor vehicle able to exceed a maximum speed of 55 miles per hour, ambulances, police cars and railroad trains excepted.

title: Notes on People Kleindienst Joins Law Firm in His Native Arizona
description: It's back to his native Arizona for Richard G. Kleindienst, an Attorney General during the Nixon Administration. Mr. Kleindienst, who has been in law practice in Washington, will today join the Tucson firm of Lesher, Kimble and Rucker.

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE; Adhesive Kits Help In Storage

description: Joseph P. Anderson, former executive director of the National Association of Social Workers in New York, died Sunday at a nursing home in Stamford, Conn., at the age of 72. He lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Islanders and Canucks Play to 22 Deadlock; Black Hawks 0, Sabres 0

description: In a prelude to upcoming municipal labor negotiations, union leaders accused Mayor Koch yesterday of inflaming city employees by talking about possible layoffs. They also insisted that substantial pay increases were a necessity.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP)  Four out of 99 pharmacies checked by inspectors of the Food and Drug Administration were still selling an infant formula recalled nearly three months ago because of a serious lack of the essential nutrient chloride, the agency said today.

description: COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 31 (AP)  Gov. Richard W. Riley today ordered a 50 percent reduction over two years in the amount of lowlevel nuclear waste buried in South Carolina. The nation's two other dump sites have already been shut.

description: A Manhattan jewelry store owner was killed and one of three robbers was seriously wounded during a holdup attempt yesterday, the police said.

title: Plane Is Briefly Hijacked And Ordered to Tijuana
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 31 (UPI)  A man pretending to have a bomb hijacked jetliner last night on a flight from Los Angeles to San Diego. The plane landed in Tijuana, where Mexican agents arrested the hijacker, and returned to the United States safely, landing at San Diego only 36 minutes behind schedule.

title: News Summary International
description: THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 1, 1979

title: Education Board Examining Ways Of Pruning Its Budget $45 Million Opposition to Cuts
description: A majority of the sevenmember Board of Education yesterday opposed a plan to end free travel and cutrate fares for 135,500 gradeschool children.

title: Hawks Hand 76ers First Loss of Season; Bucks 110, Lakers 106
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 31 (AP)  Eddie Johnson scored 4 of his 18 points in the final 42 seconds tonight as the Atlanta Hawks snapped the Philaelphia 76ers seasonopening streak of eight triumphs with a 10297 victory. The 76ers had been the National Basketball Association's only undefeated team.

title: Koch and the Control Board His Plea to Pressure 2 Agencies to Curb Spending Would Involve Major Policy Change by Monitors
description: By his own admission, Mayor Koch broke with past practice two weeks ago when he asked the Financial Control Board to intervene directly in pressuring the Board of Education and the Health and Hospitals Corporation to curb theirspending and avoid budget deficits this year.

title: Hollywood Warm To Carey's Wooing Theater Owners' Group Meets Hovhannes Symphony To Have Premiere Jan. 17
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Oct. 31Governor Carey returned home to New York today after a oneday trip to Hollywood. His journey to the West was an attempt to entice film makers into making their movies in New York. He promised them that his newly created State Office for Motion Picture and Television Development, with its yearly budget of $300,000, will even get you a hotel room in New York City.

title: Suit Challenges Steelworkers Ban On Outside Aid in Union Elections; Alleged Purpose of Rule
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31  Ed Sadlowski Jr., the maverick union leader who was defeated in 1977 in his bid for leadership of the United Steelworkers of America, filed a suit against the union today, charging that it had adopted an illegal and unconstitutional rule in prohibiting candidates for major union offices from accepting any money or services from nonunion members.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yesterday's Weather at National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration/UPI

title: CONFEREES APPROVE $29.9 BILLION DEFICIT IN BUDGET FOR 1980; GAP RISES $2 BILLION ABOVE 79 House Side Accepts More Military Spending  Senators Agree to Widen Social Outlays; Formal Limit on Spending; Conferees Approve a 1980 Budget; Trim of Only $700 Million; GENERAL GIAP IN ALGERIA TO MARK REVOLUTION: Vo Nguyen Giap, Vietnamese war hero, in Algiers as celebration of country's 25th anniversary began. General Giap may meet with Zbigniew Brzezinski. Page A10.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31  House and Senate conferees ended a long struggle today and settled on a compromise Federal budget of $547.6 billion for the fiscal year 1980. The budget projects a deficit of $29.9 billion, about $2 billion greater than the deficit for the fiscal year that ended last month.

title: Film: 'Natural Enemies':A Bit of Gloom
description: HAL HOLBROOK plays Paul Steward, the central character in "Natural Enemies," as a man without lips. His face stays frozen in a grouchy grimace while a voice-over drones on about his miserable situation. He's tired of his wife. He's sick of his children. He's thinking of shooting them all this very evening, after dinner. Will he or won't he? The film, which supposedly spans one day but feels like years, has long since dissipated its suspense by the time the moment of truth arrives. The characters seem to have talked one another to death long ago."Natural Enemies," which opens today at Cinema 2, was written and directed by Jeff Kanew, who has had a long career making movie trailers and commercials, a line of work that would seemingly require some verve. There's none in evidence here; instead, he imbues the film with a static, self-congratulatory gloom. All too soon, it becomes unmistakable that Mr. Kanew is not about to let anything brighten Paul Steward's day, and the mood turns into one of painful repetition.The film's only real surprise comes when Paul visits a brothel, where five decorous prostitutes listen to yet another dreary chapter of his story. He has already been glimpsed on the commuter train, making the obvious complaints, and in his office, gazing sadly at his pretty secretary, and enough would seem to be enough. But Paul leaves the brothel and heads back to his office, because his day isn't over yet  in fact, it's only lunchtime. Only lunchtime!"Natural Enemies," which is adapted from a novel by Julius Horwitz, is full of material that must surely read better than it plays. "No one can really understand what happens between a man and his wife  we communicate silently, like cockroaches have for 50 million years . . .," Paul intones. At another point, he speaks fondly of his early days with Miriam (Louise Fletcher), in a cold-water flat, when they patronized "an Italian restaurant where they knew us by our first names. We'd get extra meat sauce just by asking for it." The cast, which also includes Jos Ferrer, Viveca Lindfors and Patricia Elliott, delivers such lines with a uniform bleakness. They sound less like they've been directed than sedated.

title: Jewish Women Discuss Impact Of Feminism; Jewish Women and Feminism; Continued From Page Cl
description: THERE was piety in the prayers of the women who started one day's session by reading the Torah and there was poetry in the words of the writer Cynthia Ozick, who closed it with a literary epilogue. But for the most part the tone of the conference on 'The Jewish Woman in a Changing Society, sponsored by the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies Commission on Synagogue Relations, was pragmatic.

title: Preserving and Repairing Your Silver
description: EVEN those born with silver spoons in their mouths will someday need their flatware refinished. For, while gold and platinum appear eternal, silver does not withstand the test of time. Air and usage tarnish it.

title: Study Proposes Way to Help Private Colleges Survive 80's; Low Standards a Target
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 31  A way to force weak public colleges and universities to close to assure the survival of private institutions will be proposed by a blueribbon panel concluding a twoyear study of higher education.

title: EARNINGS Socal Profit Up 110.2% In Quarter Business Abroad Cited for Jump
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 31 (AP)The Standard Oil Company of California, the nation's fourthlargest oil company, said today that its profits rose 110.2 percent in the third quarter from the yearearlier level, continuing the trend of hefty profit increases for the nation's big oil companies.

title: In Matters of Design, the Dialectic Applied
description: EVERY time I go to Cambridge, I discover that I have been taking for granted something that other people are talking and thinking about with all their might. This time was houses.

title: Atomic Panel Depicts Information Conflict; Conflicting Reports Cited
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31  Minutes before President Carter arrived at the site of the nuclear accident at Three Mile Island last April 1, a member of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission and three staff members assembled at the Harrisburg, Pa., airport to greet the President.

title: Vance to Take Part in Cambodia Aid Talks at U.N.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31  Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance announced today that he would represent the United States at a special conference on aid for starving Cambodians called by Secretary General Kurt Waldhelm of the United Nations for Monday in New York.

title: Mortgage Action Delayed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP)  The House Ways and Means Committee voted today, 18 to 13, to postpone action for at least a week on a bill that would ban the use of taxexempt bonds for financing purchases of singlefamily homes. The bill would replace city and statesubsidized mortgage programs with tax incentives to encourage savings account deposits.

title: Britain Countering U.S. Antitrust Laws Economic Imperialism Cited Bill Rejects Punitive Damages U.S. Investigations Criticized
description: LONDON, Oct. 31  In a sharp response to alleged overreaching by American regulators, the Government introduced a wideranging bill today designed to protect British companies. The legislation could, in some cases, result in the attachment here of United States assets.

title: Music: Maazel Leads Clevelanders York Players to Present Grass Harp on Nov. 16
description: WHEN symphony orchestras go on tour, programming sometimes becomes a problem. Straight orchestral concerts, even excellently performed ones with instrumental soloists, do not invariably fill halls and draw the public's attention. So, in recent seasons, a common solution has been either to put on large chunks of opera in concert version or to engage an opera singer, preferrably a soprano of inter national rank, to lead the bill. Unfortunately, this dilutes the purpose of touring, which is to place the orchestra itself on display and improve its reputation.

title: ESSAY Fighting The Sloom Overriding pressure to reduce taxes
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31  In the midst of a sloom  an inflationary boom that makes us feel we're in slump  three schools of economic thought are clustering about three of the leading candidates.

title: Surprise Meeting On Chrysler White House Said to Back Substantial Aid Surprise Meeting On Chrysler
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 31 The two top executives of the United Automobile Workers made a surprise trip from here to Washington this afternoon at the request of the Carter Administration for Cabinetlevel discussions at the White House on the fate of the troubled Chrysler Corporation. According to a union source in attendance at the meeting, the officials told the union leaders that the Administration would be recommending substantial aid for the No. 3 auto maker.

title: ABROAD AT HOME The Energy Disaster: III
description: BOSTON, Oct. 31  Anyone who thinks this country is serious on the subject of energy should consider three recent Washington events:

title: Questions in Mexico Crash; No DC10 Faults Are Blamed, but Safety Experts Are Likely to Examine Airport and Interior of Jet
description: Inevitably, when word was flashed from Mexico City yesterday that a DC10 jumbo jet had crashed, aviation specialists were quick to ask: Was there something wrong with the plane?

title: French Minister's Suicide Note Accuses 2 Officials; Collusion Is Charged in Note
description: PARIS, Oct. 31 (AP)  Labor Minister Robert Boulin, implicated in a Riviera real estate scandal, said collusion by a blackmailer, an ambitious judge and a Justice Minister preoccupied with his career were responsible for the cloud of suspicion that drove him to suicide.

title: Appeals Court Says Using Office For Personal Gain Is Not Bribery
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) A Federal appeals court ruled today that Government officials can be convicted under Federal bribery laws only if they take money to influence official decisions.

title: Man Shot and Stabbed Ina Halloween Prank
description: A 32yearold Queens man was hospitalized in critical condition last night after being shot and stabbed during an attack that police said may have started as a Halloween prank.

title: Scotto Denies Knowing Political Gifts Were Illegal; Scotto Denies Wittingly Giving Illicit Campaign Donations; Anthony M. Scotto, center, with his wife, Marion, and James LaRossa, his lawyer, outside court. Mr. Scotto continued to testify in his own defense.

title: Talking Business Housing in '80: Drop Foreseen
description: George H. Weyerhaeuser is president and chief executive officer of the Weyerhaeuser Company, one of the Big Three in the paper industry, ranking behind the International Paper Company and the GeorgiaPacific Corporation in sales. It has the nation's largest timber holdings, is a leading supplier of building products and a major force in the building of family houses. Seven of its subsidiary companies are in the business of buying land, preparing it for development and subcontracting with local builders to put up the houses.

title: Hers
description: WHILE living in Los Angeles, I did what everyone there was doing: going through changes, having breakthroughs, getting next to, into and be- hind things. Some friends laid out $175 to get into Transcendental Meditation. Others, for the same money, got heavily into Erno Laszlo. I did both; moisturizer was my mantra.

title: Teddy on CBS Sunday
description: CBSTV has set a new date to broadcast a news documentary on Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, in order to keep it exempt from the equal time law for political broadcasts. Originally scheduled for Wednesday, the telecast has been moved to Sunday night at 10 o'clock, where it will preempt Trapper John, M.D.

title: Advertising; Chanel Gets New President
description: CHANEL INC. is losing a Catherine and getting a Catherine. After eight years Catherine Deneuve is out as spokesman for its Chanel No. 5 fragrance and after 23 years working on the account at Norman, Craig & Kummel, Catherine D'Alessio is joining privately held Chanel as president. That will be Nov. 26.

title: Sound
description: FROM the looks of it, audio definitely seems to be shrinking, and the latest evidence that less can be more comes in the trim shape of the most compact receiver ever designed. With its space proportions (16 by 13 inches in width and depth, and a mere 3 inches in height) the Onkyo X20 is billed as a midisize component by coy copywriters. But it packs even more performance per cubic inch than the separate minis heading the current trend toward smallness.

title: Paul Kinsie, 86, ExInvestigator For Unit Fighting Spread of V.D.
description: Paul Michael Kinsie, a retired staff investigator for the American Social Health Association, a voluntary group that fights the spread of venereal disease, died yesterday at his Manhattan residence. He was 86 years old.

title: Mets Trade Hebner For 2 Tiger Players; Mets Hebner Sent to Tigers For 2 Players; Continued From Page B11
description: The New York Mets unloaded more of last season's illfated new offense yesterday when they traded Richie Hebner to the Detroit Tigers for Phil Mankowski and Jerry Morales, who might not even make the team next year.

title: BusinessLoan Details Found to Be No Secret; Position Disputed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct 31  While most owners of small businesses assume that their banking remains a matter between them and their bankers, in reality every bank in the country routinely discloses that information to any credit grantor who asks, according to a recent study.

It said the dividend would be payable on Dec. 10 to shareholders of record as of Nov. 9. Last week the company reported thirdquarter profits of $1.14 billion, its highest for any quarter.

description: ALGIERS, Oct. 31 Zbigniew Brzezinski , President Carter's national security adviser, said today that he had come here to tell Algeria, on behalf of President Carter, that the United States favored a political solution of the AlgerianMoroccan struggle over Western Sahara, but that Washington would not stand by and see a military solution imposed on Morocco.

title: Senate Rejects Savings Change
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) The Senate, on a voice vote, agreed to remove language from a major banking bill that would have directed banks and savings institutions to reduce from $10,000 to $1,000 the minimum size of highearning moneymarket certificates of deposit. Faced with defeat of the lower minimum, Senator William

title: 2 Airliners Vanish in Andes: Could It Be Hijacking?
description: QUITO, Ecuador, Oct. 28  Saeta Airlines Flight 11, a fourengine Vickers Viscount with 59 passengers aboard, left Quito Aug. 15, 1976, on its 45minute morning flight to the mountain city of Cuenca. Midway in the trip the pilot made his routine call to the Ambato Relay Station. Soon after, the plane disappeared without a trace.

title: 1,700 Floridians Flee Break of Dike
description: INDIANTOWN, Fla., Oct. 31 (AP)  A concrete and earthen reservoir wall collapsed today, unleashing a 12foothigh wall of water that quickly flooded a 20mile stretch in two counties. About 1,700 people were evacuated. officials said.

description: WIENER WERKSTATTE designs are back on sale in a Fifth Avenue store after an absence of almost 50 years. The Years of the Wiener Werksttte, a collection that returns these wares to shoppers in a large exhibition, opens tomorrow on the eighth loor of Lord & Taylor and remains through Dec. 9.

title: Guns Become Sales Weapon For New Cars Dismayed by Discount Price
description: ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 31  Automobile salesmen have resorted to a variety of hardsell techniques to stimulate sales over the years, but dealers in Ithaca may have been the first to use guns.

title: World News Briefs; Kurdish Insurgents Retake Iranian Mountain Town
description: MEHABAD, Iran, Oct. 31 (Reuters) About 1,000 guerrillas loyal to the Kurdish Democratic Party were back in control of this mountain city today, six weeks after being ousted by Government forces.

title: Settlement in Chemical Dispute
description: LANSING, Mich., Oct. 31 (AP)  A $15 million settlement between the state and the Hooker Chemical Company has been approved by Judge Michael Harrison of Ingham County Circuit Court. Hooker will wend the money to clean un its 880 acre plant site near Montague. Nearly a million cubic yards of toxic chemicals are buried or stored in leaking barrels at the site. Some chemicals have seeped into groundwater and nearby White Lake.

title: Bahrain, the Gulf's GuineaPig Society
description: At first glance, the managers of the little island state of Bahrain, in the Persian Gulf, do not appear nervous. The Emir, Sheik Isa bin Sulman alKhalifa, sits cherubic and unruffled in his majlis (reception room) listening to his subjects petitions. He seems unperturbed by the demand of highranking Iranian Ayatollahs for Iran to annex Bahrain and for the Emir to stop his alleged persecution of Shiites, who constitute twothirds of Bahrain's population of 300,000. A high official apologizes for being late, but he had few disturbances to attend to; never mind, and the talk turns to improving the physical fitness of Bahraini youths. At a luncheon, a group of the

title: Experts Differ on Source Of Currency Unrest Rates Expected to Stabilize Cooper Warns of World Recession
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31  The sharp increases in the price of oil over the last five years and the breakdown of fixed exchange rates in the early 1970's were the two main causes of shortterm instability in the foreignexchange markets, Richard Cooper, Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, said today.

title: Resorts Net Rose On Property Sale
description: Resorts International Inc., which operates a casinohotel in Atlantic City, reported yesterday that an extraordinary sale of property lifted thirdquarter income 64.6 percent.

title: George's New Yankee Troika Takes Over; Sports of The Times
description: In occasional moments of modesty, George Steinbrenner will preface one of his Yankee theories by saying, I may not know much about baseball, but. . . And then he will issue a directive. But say this for the Yankees principal owner, principal judge and principal jury: He may not know much about baseball, but he now is more experienced in his role than the general manager and the dugout manager are in theirs. Gene Michael is a rookie general manager. Dick Howser is a rookie dugout manager. For seven years George Steinbrenner had to respect the judgment of the older heads in the Yankee troikas. But of all those experienced baseball people, Cedric Tallis and Billy Martin were the last to depart. He may not know much about baseball, but one way or another George M. Steinbrenner 3d has finally rearranged the Yankees so that he is the old head now.

title: BL Ltd. Employees Back Cuts Vote for Plan to Save Car Maker
description: LONDON, Nov. 1 BL Ltd., the only large Britishowned car producer, has won from its work force a ringing endorsement of the cutbacks it says it needs to survive: the cutting of some 25,000 workers and the closing or partial closing of 13 plants. Among the casualties is to be the MG snorts car.

title: Publishing: Patrick White
description: ALTHOUGH he is seldom heard from between books and has a reputation for being reclusive, the Australian novelist, Patrick White, who won the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1973, has not been idle.

description: May belongs to the poets. Lovers are partial to June. September inspires songs. Joy and giving mark December. But who cares about November? Lots of people.

title: India Seeking to Calm Ethnic Hostility in Northeast Challenge to Illegal Aliens
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 1 Deputy Prime Minister Y.B. Chavan today began a mission to the northeast of India, where outbreaks of rage against outsiders and separatist agitation are intensifying. Mr. Chavan is heading a Government delegation mat seeks to study, and hopes to ease, unrest that has been flaring in the five states and two territories forming a wedge between Bangladesh, Burma and China.

title: L.I.R.R. Mutes Its Call To Back Transit Bonds
description: The Long Island Rail Road withdrew its loudspeaker announcements urging commuters to support the state's transportation bond issue yesterday following a complaint by the head of a consumer group opposed to the measure.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE Founder's Son to Head Storer Broadcasting
description: The Storer Broadcasting Company, in a management reorganization related to its planned 5250 million expansion into cable television in the next few years, yesterday named Peter Storer, son of the founder and 25year veteran of the Storer organization, as chief executive officer and vice chairman of the company. Mr. Storer, who is 51 years old, is currently president and chief operating officer.

title: Strauss Assaying FullTime Work On Carter Effort Might Leave Mideast Post No Decision Is Made
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1  Robert S. Strauss, President Carter's special Middle East negotiator and a key political adviser, raised the possibility today that because of political demands on his time he might have to give up his diplomatic assignment to devote himself completely to the reelection campaign.

title: Screen: 'Promises In the Dark' Opens:Illness as Disaster
description: AS anyone who has ever enjoyed a disaster movie knows, fatal accidents and freaks of nature don't necessarily ennoble their victims. In "Earthquake," when Ava Gardner is swept away in a sewer never to be seen again, we don't weep and wail and gnash our teeth. "Good riddance to bad rubbish," we say, knowing that she is simply a function of the plot.The point of a disaster movie is not its people but its spectacle. We are perfectly aware that when "Earthquake" was conceived, the producers began with the idea for a film about a cataclysmic event and more or less worked backward, filling in the story with characters much as one might furnish a basement playroom.In disaster movies as well as in caper movies and most murder mysteries  certainly in the kind written by Agatha Christie  people are important only in terms of events. In other movies we ask for a little bit more. It's this little bit more that is missing from Jerome Hellman's "Promises in the Dark," a sort of small-scale disaster movie, the disaster in this case being the terminal cancer faced by a pretty, 17-year-old West Hartford girl named Buffy Koenig (Kathleen Beller). The movie opens today at Cinema I.Though "Promises in the Dark" means to be about the gallant Buffy, about her distraught, middle-class parents (Ned Beatty and Susan Clark) and especially about Buffy's spunky doctor, Alexandra Kendall (Marsha Mason), it's so blandly written, directed and acted that it has the peculiar effect of exploiting the spectacle of Buffy's illness and short-changing the real hardships of the human condition, including the fight against cancer. It's the sort of movie that says, by indirection, that if Buffy hadn't had the rotten luck to get sick, there would have been no point in feeling concern for her.Because "Promises in the Dark" has been furnished with stereotypes instead of individuals, it is neither inspiring nor depressing but coyly morbid. Though it pretends to celebrate human courage, it is actually merchandizing it as another kind of earthquake.As if aware that he was creating characters who have passed through a state of extreme ordinariness into banality, Loring Mandel attempts to tone up his screenplay with what in mystery stories would be identified as red herrings.Miss Mason's doctor, whose only function is to diagnose the illness and treat the patient, is presented as a woman who has a lonely private life into which a little sun falls in the shape of a handsome, available male doctor. That may well be true, but the time spent on this subplot has the effect of padding. Buffy and her boyfriend (Paul Clemens) talk about reading, specifically "Catch 22" and "The Golden Bough," which, being of an art and an intellect far removed from the movie's, make the characters seem even emptier than they are.Miss Beller has the worst of it, being required to smile bravely when a real first-rate tantrum, or some other form of identifiable despair, would be in order. Little by little, we watch her disintegrate. First her leg is amputated. In the course of chemotherapy, her hair falls out. She wears a wig she calls "Harry." The circles under her eyes darken, the general pallor increases. When someone upbraids her for being gloomy, she says, very gently, "Forgive me. I never died before."The other performances are no better or worse than the material.At the end of the movie, when "Promises in the Dark" raises the question of whether or not patients should be kept on life-support systems after everything else has failed, you might suspect  accurately, I think  that the film itself has been on its own life-support system for far longer than is necessary."Promises in the Dark," which has been rated PG ("parental guidance suggested"), is about a subject that might well be disturbing for small children.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Thursday, Nov. 1, 1979

title: Wriston Reacts On Rate Policy
description: The chairman of Citibank warned key member of Congress yesterday that it was threatening the stability of the dollar to criticize interestrate increases by the nation's commercial banks.

title: Utility at 3 Mile Island Is Ordered To Prove Its Right to Keep License Request for Rate Increase
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1  The Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission today ordered the Metropolitan Edison Company, operator of the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant, to show why its license to sell electric power should not be revoked.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE Friday COMEDY PREMIERE ON L.I.
description: The PAF Playhouse in Huntington, L.I., opens its new season tonight with Good Evening, Ladies and Gentlemen, a comedy by Michael Barrie and Jim Mulholland. The play concerns the frantic efforts of six bigtime television writers to put together a comedy routine under deadline pressure. For the authors, who used to write for The Tonight Show, this is a first play, and PAF is presenting the world premiere. Performances tonight at 8:30; tomorrow at 2 and 8:30 P.M.; Sunday at 2 and 7:30 P.M. Tickets range from $5.95 to $9.95. By car from New York City, take the Long Island Expressway to Exit 49; follow route 110 north to Second Street, turn right and drive three blocks to the theater. Information: (516) 2718282.

title: Coop City Foreclosure Delayed
description: New York City has postponed foreclosure action against Coop City, the huge Bronx housing complex that owes $30 million in delinquent real estate taxes.

title: Treasury Sale Cuts Gold Price CURRENCY MARKETS Sale Cuts Gold Price
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 The Treasury sold 1,250,000 ounces of gold today to 11 successful bidders at an average price of $372.30, down from the average price of $377.78 an ounce at the Treasury's last sale, on Sept. 19.

title: COMPANY NEWS I. B. M. Announces New Text System KLM Earnings Fall By 39.6% in Quarter
description: DETROIT, Nov. 1 (AP)  The Ford Motor Company said today that would put about 10,300 more workers on temporary layoff next week and that would suspend passengercar production at two plants starting Monday to help dealers balance inventories.

title: Art: Countdown Toward Infinity
description: ROMAN OPALKA has been counting for 14 years. Not all the time, of course  just when he paints. Or perhaps it's the other way around, he paints as he counts. Anyway, in his fourth show at the John Weber Gallery, 420 West Broadway, Mr. Opalka shows seven identically sized gray canvases on which numbers from 2601104 to 2828874 have been inscribed in white, together with 15 drawings running from 2834989 to 2881886. There may or may not be significance in the absence of numbers 2828875 to 2834988. A tape of Mr. Opalka counting in his native Polish accompanies the display.

title: Art: Benign Shapes By Seymour Lipton
description: THIS is the 75th anniversary year of the Jewish Museum, and the first of its celebrations is a retrospective exhibition of sculpture and drawings by Seymour Lipton, which runs through Jan. 20.

title: Obituary 8 No Title
description: Deaths

title: Yanks Trade Chambliss, Beattie; 12 Players Exchanged In 2 Deals
description: The New York Yankees moved into their postBilly Martin era yesterday by unveiling their new general manager and manager, and they promptly announced two sweeping trades involving 12 players in which they lost Chris Chambliss but gained Ruppert Jones.

title: Stage: Cristofer's Ice Radio Hour Matinee
description: IN his Pulitzer Prizewinning drama, The Shadow Box, Michael Cristofer dealt compassionately with death and dying. In Ice, which will run through Sunday at the Manhattan Theater Club, he is concerned with bleak survival, death in life: two lonely men and a woman in an isolated cabin in the Alaska wilderness.

title: Mondale Charges Kennedy Lacks Issues for Campaign HatchetRole Eschewed
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1  Vice President Mondale contended today that Senator Edward M. Kennedy has moved closer to President Carter's positions on inflation and defense spending in recent weeks and has no issuebased rationale for running for President.

title: 2 G.I.'s Die in Korean Air Crash
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 1 (UPI) Two American soldiers died today when their helicopter crashed on a training flight north of Seoul, a United States Army spokesman said.

title: EXREPRESENTATIVE SEEKS MAYOR'S POST Former Congressman Fraser and 4 Others Run in Minneapolis  Election on Tuesday
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 1  With no major issues, the mayoral campaign here has been a lackluster one, and next Tuesday's election stacks up as more symbolic than substantive.

title: Nunn Again Demands Arms Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1  Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat, has repeated his threat to vote against the arms treaty with the Soviet Union unless President Carter makes a public commitment to press for increases in military spending of at least 5 percent a year.

title: Mail Backup Expected To Delay U.S. Checks
description: A continuing backlog of mail at the computerized Morgan Station post office in New York City is expected to delay the delivery of Social Security checks to 1.8 million residents of the New York metropolitan area, the Government reported yesterday.

title: A Time to Vote Yes
description: Constitutional Amendment One on next Tuesday's New York ballot would strengthen the Job Development Authority, a state agency that does constructive if littlerecognized work. It deserves a Yes vote. So do the other two amendments on the ballot.

title: Money Supply Declines By $1.3 Billion in Week Money Supply Declines By $1.3 Billion in Week
description: The Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday a $1.3 billion decline in the nation's money supply for the financial week that ended Oct. 24 and announced revisions totaling $1.1 billion in previously announced figures.

title: Bolivia AT A GLANCE Geography
description: Since 1884, when it lost its coastal territory to Chile, Bolivia has been landlocked in the heart of South America. With 424,160 square miles, it is the continent's fifth biggest nation in size. It lies entirely within the tropics but differences in elevation  as low as 300 feet along the Brazilian border and more than 21,000 feet in the peaks of the Andes  produce a great variety of climatic conditions. The highland Altiplano, a flat, dry and chilly expanse, houses most of the population. The Oriente, a largely undeveloped region east of the Andes, makes up about threequarters of the country's area.

title: Screen: 'Running,' Winning and Losing:Marathon Mania
description: MICHAEL ANDROPOLIS (Michael Douglas) is so afraid of losing that he drops out of everything before the final test. When we first see him, arising one summer morning in a squalid Manhattan furnished room, he has already dropped out of medical school, law school and his marriage of 14 years. There's only one thing he feels he does well  marathon running. Michael's goal: to make the United States running team and compete at the Montreal Olympics."Running," which opens today at the Cinerama 2 and other theaters, is an earnest though not particularly affecting movie about Michael's attempts to come to terms with himself, his ex-wife Janet (Susan Anspach), his two young daughters and his dreams of himself as a champion runner. Steve Hilliard Stern, whose other movies I have not seen, both wrote and directed the film.The chief problem with the screenplay is that although we are told by everyone, including Michael, that he is a loser, it's clear from everything we see that he is a winner as well as a hero. He responds to life in the way that all right-thinking people in the audience know they should respond. He is properly bored with his job as a shoe salesman. He is properly impatient with the red tape at the unemployment office. He is properly skeptical of the Babbit-like, get-up-and-go businessman who hopes to marry Janet. On top of all that, Michael still loves Janet, deeply and unselfishly, which is the way she loves him."Running" isn't even very suspenseful when Michael is running in competition. Since it's established that he is an excellent marathon man, we know that he'll make the Olympic team. Though there may be some doubt whether he'll win a gold medal, there's no doubt that, whatever the outcome, he will have proven himself to himself.I suppose the continuing appeal of movies like "Running" and "Rocky" is that though they seem to be about losing, with concern for losers, they're really about nothing but winning. When one can lose in the way of a Rocky or of a Michael in "Running," one has actually won, which is a most comforting way to look at the whole process of losing. These movies have no patience with real, dyed-in-the-wool losers, with people who fail badly, who persist in blaming others for their own shortcomings, who never learn by their own mistakes and who, when the chips are down, lie and cheat and behave, in general, with cowardly heart.On the strength of "The China Syndrome," Mr. Douglas could well be on his way to becoming one of our best young leading actors. He's a performer of power and intensity, though he has little to do in "Running" except run and occasionally look winded. Miss Anspach, one of the pleasures of Paul Mazursky's "Blume in Love," has a nothing role. Mostly she just stands by and admires Michael's guts. This may be why she tends to embroider the performance with a succession of tiny but busy smiles, tears, gulps and grimaces. She acts as if she were running for this year's All-American Sandy Dennis award."Running," which has been rated PG ("parental guidance suggested"), includes some mildly vulgar language.

title: Textron, Pioneer Conglomerate, Elects New Chief Executive
description: The board of directors of Textron Inc., a pioneer in the conglomerate movement in the 1960's, announced yesterday that Robert P. Straetz has been elected chairman and chief executive officer .

title: SeychellesCloses a Newspaper, Accusing It of Sensationalism
description: VICTORIA, Seychelles, Nov. 1 (Reuters)  The Government has closed the largest local weekly newspaper, Weekend Life, the state radio station said today.

title: Steel Survey Finds A Coke Shortage
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 1 (AP) The American steel industry faces a critical shortage of coke, a key ingredient in steelmaking, and a growing dependence on imports of the fuel, Fordham University says.

title: Chrysler Omits Another Payout
description: The Chrysler Corporation announced yesterday that it would not pay a dividend on its preferred shares in the fourth quarter and said it was considering issuing additional preferred stock in the near future. The board also said no dividend would be paid on common shares.

title: Mrs. Lloyd Serving On Familiar Court; Changes Practice Habits
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 1 The emotional roller coaster that has been carrying Chris Evert Lloyd through the peaks and valleys of tournament tennis since her marriage last April will make a brief but important stop in her bailiwick tomorrow.

title: Notes on PeopleRussian Dressing
description: A glide over to the Sky Rink on West 33d Street yesterday turned up Oleg Protopopov and his wife, Lyudmila Belousova, the Soviet figure skaters who defected in late September. On Tuesday, the Protopopovs were officially granted asylum in Switzerland, but the money they will bank will be earned in this country.

title: Matching Taxes To Federal Law On State Ballot Voters to Weigh Extension of Income Tax Procedure
description: The same simplification that permits New York State income taxes to conform with Federal patterns  thereby easing taxpayers paperwork  would be extended to other state taxes under a proposal on next Tuesday's ballot.

title: Our Seasoned Man in Seoul William Henry Gleysteen Jr.
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1  With Washington vitally concerned about the latest twists and turns in South Korea, there has been a sense of satisfaction in the State Department during the oast week that the United States

title: Britain Offers Bill to Sell Airline Stake B.P. Offer Terms Set
description: LONDON, Nov. 1 (Reuters) The British Government introduced a civil aviation bill in Parliament today that provides for the sale to the public of a substantial interest in stateowned British Airways.

title: Obituary 1 No Title
description: JOHN HAITCH

title: Scotto Says He Gave Official 2 Tickets That Cost $ 1,000 Questions About an Envelope The New York Times/ Marilyn Church
description: Anthony M. Scotto testified at his Federal trial in Manhattan yesterday that he had given tickets costing at least $1,000 for a political fundraising affair to a former New York City Commissioner, but he denied having given him any money.

title: Books: Tales of Updike
description: WHAT would today's fiction do without divorce? Some. times it seems that, except for divorce, men and women in books would simply muddle their way toward old age and death.

title: Cut RatePhone Calls Laid to Night Operator
description: An entrepreneur who allegedly thrived by offering cutrate overseas telephone connections has been arrested and charged with cheating the New York Telephone Company of an estimated $1 million in long distance charges over four years.

title: Ladd Films to Star Midler and Newman; Moved From Columbia; Business of Relationships Symbolism of White Oak Tree
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 1  A filmed Bette Midler concert and a thriller starring Paul Newman as a priest who attempts to thwart an assassination are the first two movie projects to be set up by Hollywood's newest major film production company.
