title: About Real Estate Why Condominium Ownership Is Gaining New Support
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 30  Here in the citadel of conversions of rental apartment buildings into condominiums, a strong case is made in support of the view that the future of unsubsidized multifamily housing in the United States lies in apartment ownership by the user, rather than rentals.

title: Ballet Theater and Union Break Off Contract Talks
description: Talks between the American Ballet Theater and the American Guild of Musical Artists, the union representing the dancers of the company, aimed at resolving the issues of a new union contract. have broken off.

title: Koch's Hospital Plan Is Criticized in Study By a U.S. Rights Unit
description: The Office for Civil Rights of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare has concluded that racial minorities would be disproportionately affected by Mayor Koch's plan for cutbacks at some municipal hospitals.

title: Israeli Cabinet, in a Heated Session, Puts Off Showdown on Settlements Talk of CrisisDismissed
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 1  Israel's Cabinet sidestepped a confrontation today between moderates and rightwingers over the future of Jewish settlement in the West Bank of the Jordan, postponing decision on an overall settlement plan.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK; MANHATTAN; BRONX; BRONX (Cont'd) BROOKLYN; STATEN ISLAND; QUEENS; LONG ISLAND; LONG ISLAND (Cont'd); ROCKLAND; WESTCHESTER; FAIRFIELD
description: Below 42d Street

title: Quebec Outlines Role as a Nation
description: QUEBEC, Nov. 1  The Quebec government presented its final proposal today for a sovereign province linked economically with the rest of Canada.

title: PARK ASSASSINATION: PART OF FAILED COUP Investigators in South Korea Say Intelligence Chief Was Trying to Take Over the Country
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 1 The assassination of President Park Chung Hee last Friday was the first stage in an attempted coup that failed, according to sources close to the investigation here today.

title: Life Term for $1 Theft and Rape
description: A 25yearold man was sentenced to life in prison yesterday for raping a woman and robbing her of ;1, according to District Attorney Mario Merola of the Bronx.

title: Theodore S. Steingut Weds Susan Brotman
description: Susan Brotman and Theodore Seth Steingut were married yesterday evening by Rabbi Benjamin Kreitman at the Columbus Club in New York.

title: Bob Abplanalp Wants the Mets; Sports of The Times
description: The New York Mets are for sale and Robert H. Abplanalp hopes to buy them.

title: 2 Die in Nashville as Light Plane Crashes Into Lake Near Airport
description: NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 1 (AP) private turboprop aircraft crashed into lake as fog hung over the Metropolitan Nashville Airport tonight. At least two people were killed, officials said.

title: Anne Meyers Ready To Sign With Gems
description: Anne Meyers, the only woman ever signed to a National Basketball Association contract, has agreed to a multiyear contract with the New Jersey Gems of the Women's Basketball League.

title: Bulk of Belmont Estate Goes Into Special Fund
description: Eleanor Robson Belmont, the wealthy socialite and patron of the arts who died Oct. 25, left the bulk of her estate to a fund in her name, according to a will filed yesterday in Surrogate's Court in Manhattan.

title: MEXICO CRASH STUDY FOCUSES ON RUNWAY Indication Is That Lighting Was On by Error on Closed Strip Where  the Airliner Went Down
description: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 1  American and Mexican experts investigating the crash of a DC10 here yesterday tried today to establish whether the plane landed on a runway closed for repairs because approach lights had mistakenly been switched on.

title: Strict School Promotion Plan Unveiled Plan Is a Response to Criticism
description: A proposed promotion policy that would be based on academic achievement could bar nearly a third of the city's eighthgrade pupils from high school.

title: A Day for Bringing Fossils to Museum
description: If you have any old skeletons rattling around your closet, now is the time to haul them out.

title: Barry I. Roberts Weds Patricia Heller in Jersey
description: The marriage of Patricia Dee Heller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph L. Heller of Englewood Cliffs, N.J., to Barry I. Roberts, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy Roberts of West Orange, N.J., took place yesterday at the Tammy Brook Country Club in Cresskill, N.J. Rabbi Barry Friedman of Livingston, N.J., performed the ceremony.

title: Bridge: Artificial Bidding Pays Off With Care and Hard Work
description: The growing popularity of team games in recent years has encouraged many clubs to include such contests in their programs.

title: Cooper Completes Sale to Schering
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., Nov. 1 (Reuters)  Cooper Laboratories Inc. said today that it had completed the sale of the major portion of the assets of its internal medicine business to a subsidiary of Schering A.G. Berlin/ Bergkamen for $90 million in cash.

title: House Panel Releases a List of Sites Used in States to Dump Chemicals; Importance Stressed
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1  A House investigation subcommittee today released a list of 3,383 sites where chemical wastes had been dumped, but it declined, at least for the present, to identify the chemicals by name.

title: Dance: Bella Lewitzky
description: THE Bella Lewitzky Dance Company from Los Angeles has performed in various parts of the East and in Europe since it made its New York debut in 1971. Yet this troupe headed by a California moderndance pioneer is rarely seen in New York City.

title: A Place Called Brooklyn
description: Lost somewhere in America's social memory is the origin of all the putdown jokes about Brooklyn. Where were you born? the Army doctor asks the soldier. Soldier: Brooklyn. Doctor: Any other defects? Even Brooklynites, when they go to Manhattan, say, I'm going to the city, as if Brooklyn were out in the tulies, as they call the sticks in California.

title: Obituary 2 No Title
description: MINTO CATO

title: Discount Rate Raised in Japan
description: TOKYO, Nov. 1  The Bank of Japan announced today that it would raise its official discount rate by 1 percent to 6.25 percent tomorrow in an effort to curb inflation.

title: West Side Gets a Taste Of Gilbert and Sullivan
description: There is no end to productions of the Gilbert and Sullivan light operas, a situation that makes a great many people happy. For many years this city has had the benefit of yearround performances by the Light Opera of Manhattan (L.O.O.M.) and annual stagings by the Village Light Opera Group, Blue Hill Troupe and Barnard College. In the last few years, a new organization has established itself on the scene, the New York Gilbert & Sullivan Players. They opened their current season last night at Symphony Space, Broadway and 95th Street, with performances of H.M.S. Pinafore and Trial by Jury, a double bill that will be repeated tonight at 8, tomorrow at 2 and 8 P.M. and on Sunday at 2 and 7 P.M.

title: Dow Rises by 4.44 Superior Oil Adds 41
description: Specialsituation issues were strong performers on Wall Street yesterday as the stock market registered a modest advance in continued light trading.

title: New Law Says Lease Must Tell Tenants of Their Rights
description: Residents of the 850,000 rentstabilized apartments in New York City must be informed by their landlords of tenants basic rights under the city's Rent Stabilization Law, according to the terms of a City Council bill signed into law by Mayor Koch yesterday.

title: Savings Spur In Tax Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1  Three members of the taxwriting committees of Congress introduced legislation today that would provide tax incentives meant to encourage savings.

title: An Autumn Tour Of Central Park
description: The wroughtiron Vanderbilt gates on Fifth Avenue at 105th Street will open to the splendors of Central Park in autumn at 10 tomorrow morning when Henry Hope Reed, the park's curator, will conduct the last walking tour of his domain this season. Everyone is invited and the cost is $1.

title: Japanese Governing Party Is Expected to Choose Its Leader Today Series of Inconclusive Meetings
description: TOKYO, Friday, Nov. 2  Liberal Democratic members of Parliament are expected to choose today between Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira and his predecessor, Takeo Fukuda, as the leader of their party who will also be the party's candidate for prime minister.

title: The U.N. Today GENERAL ASSEMBLY
Reforming Drug Laws
description: In September, the Senate quietly passed the most basic overhaul of law relating to the regulation of new pharmaceutical drugs in 41 years. It is now the House's responsibility to determine if the longawaited reform of the drug laws will become a reality. What the House does will affect the health and pocketbook of every American and millions of foreigners. House hearings begin soon.

title: HARVESTER'S PLANTS SHUT IN EIGHT STATES 35,000 Members of Union Go Out as Talks on New Contract Fail
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 1 (AP)  Thirtyfive thousand members of the United Automobile Workers struck the International Harvester Company today, shutting down operations in eight states.

title: Officer in Westchester Is Slain While Serving A Notice for Eviction Phone Call to Police Station
description: HASTINGSONHUDSON, N.Y., Nov. 1  A Westchester County policeman was shot six times and killed today when he served a courtordered eviction notice on a resident of this suburban village.

title: Music: Baroque Opera
description: NEWELL JENKINS and his Clarion Concerts opened their season in Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night with a concert performance of Agostino Steffani's La liberta contents. It was the third opera by this relatively obscure composer that they have given here. This one certainly justified their interest in reviving his music.

title: Sports Today; BASKETBALL
description: Nets vs. Indiana Pacers, at Rutgers Athletic Center, Piscataway, N.J., 8 P.M. (Radio WVNJ, 8 P.M.)

title: State Senate Approves Plan For Emergency Heating Aid Several Appointments Approved
description: ALBANY, Nov. 1  The State Senate voted tonight to accept a plan to give emergency heating fuel aid to homeowners earning up to twice the poverty level, or $13,400 a year for a family of four. Governor Carey was considering a veto of the measure on financial grounds.

title: Screen: Rock Drama From a Who Album:Mods and Rockers
description: THE results of my (highly) informal survey about "Quadrophenia" have been tabulated. They show that most moviegoers think this is either a concert film or a rock opera, or that the title refers to a quadrophonic sound track. Not true. This is a dramatic film, one that's gritty and ragged and sometimes quite beautiful. It happens to incorporate rock songs, and to be saddled with a silly title. Though it's by no means a movie for everyone, "Quadrophenia" is something very special. It demands  and deserves  some special allowances."Quadrophenia," which opens today at the Paramount and other theaters, is set in England in 1964, and populated by Mods and Rockers, warring bands of teen-agers who speak with such thick accents that American audiences may find their conversation indecipherable. For this and other reasons, the film  which is a hit in England  hasn't traveled well.But its foreignness has perverse advantages, helping to recast situations that might seem commonplace in an American end-of-adolescence movie, and making them just remote enough to seem fresh. A gifted new director, Franc Roddam, lends the film a clarity of emotion that keeps it from becoming too confusing.The story is derived very, very loosely from an album by the Who. This album was an ambitious undertaking: it described a teen-age boy, Jimmy, who was so acutely sensitive to social pressures that he developed the four-way schizophrenia of the title. Jimmy's condition was illustrated, rather than described, by four separate melodies  one associated with each member of the Who  that eventually merged into one transcendent theme. The specific ending of the album called for Jimmy to swim out to sea and scale an enormous rock. Unfortunately for the current film, which does some floundering at the finale, Ken Russell borrowed that scene for "Tommy" several years ago.But "Quadrophenia," as directed and co-written by Mr. Roddam, is perhaps too raw to have culminated with pie-in-the-sky. Jimmy, played by a wonderfully avid-looking actor named Phil Daniels, is a cheerful, unexceptional fellow, by no means the Who's hypersensitive hero. He is seen squabbling with his parents, partying with his Mod friends, working at a mailroom job that's both dead-end and dull. These episodes, which are carried by the boisterous enthusiasm of an excellent cast, combine to form a slice-of-life movie that feels tremendously authentic in its sentiments as well as its details.The Mods-and-Rockers aspect of the story might seem to date the material. But Mr. Roddam is as concerned with the general experience of adolescence as he is with these particular groups of people. And he is able, in recreating the seaside riots between these rival gangs, to capture a fierce, dizzying excitement that epitomizes a kind of youthful extreme. Jimmy, who is so electrified by his new identity as a Mod that he makes a quick, thrilling sexual conquest while the fighting is going on, may never again feel so fully at the height of his powers. "Quadrophenia" fills the moment with equal elements of regret and celebration.In a barely memorable shot at the beginning of the story, Jimmy is seen to be walking away from a cliff  a cliff from which, at the end of the movie, he appears to jump to his death. This disastrous attempt at a flashback damages the movie, which finally seems to be concerned with nothing more morbid than the end of this boy's flaming youth. The last minutes of the film are further weakened by some last-minute interjections of the Who's music, which has until now figured into the story more delicately.Images of the group, up until this point, have been ghostly and unbiquitous. Their records play in party scenes; their posters and photographs decorate walls; Jimmy watches the band on television while his parents complain. Jimmy himself looks considerably like the Who's Pete Townshend, and he has the gawkiness that Mr. Townshend has made such memorable use of in the course of his career.When Jimmy, in one of the film's most stunning set-pieces, dives into a crowd of dancers at a seaside resort, as much to vent his frustration as to attract attention, the spirit resembles that of an early Who concert  the kind that concluded with Mr. Townshend's furiously smashing his guitar.Among the fine supporting performances in "Quadrophenia," on a par with Mr. Daniels's superb Jimmy, is Raymond Winstone's Kevin, an old school friend Jimmy runs into in a public bath. When they put their clothes on, Jimmy realizes that his friend has become a Rocker; later, they share a conversation about how important it is to join the right group so you won't be like everybody else. Leslie Ash is suitably heartbreaking and heartless as the most popular of the female Mods, and the actors playing Jimmy's closest friends are affecting, too. The movie includes a hilarious turn by the Ace, the prettiest and surliest blond Mod, who turns out to be a bellhop on the side. The Ace is played by Sting, who is lead singer of a widely praised new band, the Police.

title: 2 Top Quarterbacks Head Group of ScholarAthletes
description: Paul McDonald of Southern California and Steadman Shealy of Alabama, quarterbacks on teams ranked in the top four, were among 11 college seniors named yesterday to receive scholarathlete awards from the National Football Foundation and Hall of Fame.

title: 44 on FreeAgent Draft List; AMERICAN LEAGUE; NATIONAL LEAGUE
description: Baseball will hold its fourth freeagent draft today at the Plaza Hotel, with 44 players eligible to be selected. Up to 13 teams may claim negotiation rights to a player, and the team from which he declared himself a free agent will retain those rights. If a player is picked by fewer than two clubs, he will be free to negotiate with all teams. The Toronto Blue Jays will select first and the other 27 teams will choose in reverse order of their 1979 wonlost records. Following is a list of eligible players:

title: Algeria Shows Off New Weaponry On 25th Anniversary of Revolution Brzezinski Visit Pleases Algiers
description: ALGIERS, Nov. 1  Algeria celebrated the 25th anniversary of the start of its revolution against France today, staging a threehour parade to pay tribute to the poorly equipped guerrillas who fought for eight years. The parade showed a tough and modern military force.

title: New, Not Ole, Miss.
description: WASHINGTON  The Eastern perception of Deep South politics is reminiscent of a dog chasing its tail: unable to catch up with reality. Take, for example, recent coverage of the Mississippi gubernatorial campaign by the East Coast news media.

title: The Pop Life New and old cross tracks on Who album.
description: POLYDOR has released a twodisk sound track of Quadrophenia, the British film based on the previously unperformed rock opera by the Who, which opened today in New York (a review appears on page C6). Sound track is in quotation marks because in this case the film might be more accurately referred to as the sight track of the Who's music. The band's 1973 double album of the same title was, after all, the original inspiration for this project.

title: Mamie Eisenhower Dies in Sleep At 82 in Hospital in Washington Burial in Abilene, Kan. Mamie Eisenhower Dies in Sleep at 82 in Army Hospital in Washington Feeling of Contentment Moves Were Frequent Encouraged Reelection Bid Silent on Summersby Matter Moved to Washington Survived by 4 Grandchildren United Press International
description: Mamie Eisenhower, the widow of Dwight D. Eisenhower, 34th President of the United States, died peacefully in her sleep early yesterday at the Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington.

title: Lost Da Vinci Mural Believed Discovered Lost da Vinci Mural Believed Discovered
description: After centuries of speculation on the part of art scholars and five years of onthespot detective work in Florence by university researchers, important clues have been found that may lead to a major art discovery.

title: Settlement By Cities Service Co. Consent Accord On Prices Signed
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1  The Energy Department today announced the signing of a consent agreement with the Cities Service Company in which the company agrees either to make cash payments or to forgo price increases totaling $220 million. The settiement ends department complaints that the company had made a series of overcharges for oil that totaled almost $300 million.

title: The Cycle of Investor Strategies The Great Crash The Legacy of 1929 Last of a series. Randy Jones
description: If the devastating stock market crash of 1929 taught investors anything, it was to beware of speculation. But the lessons of history are quickly forgotten, and the urge to make a killing whether in stocks or in real estate  is hard to suppress.

title: Art People Titled crowd at the Met.
description: AS of 6 o'clock next Wednesday evening, there will be enough English lords and ladies in the Metropolitan Museum of Art to float a production of one of Shakespeare's histories. They will be here for the presentation of this year's Mitchell Prize for art history. As lords and ladies go, these are of recent creation. Lord Annan, vice chancellor of London University, was raised to the peerage in 1965. Lord Weidenfeld, most Americans favorite English publisher, was annobled in 1976. So was Lord Vaizey, the social scientist, whose wife is art critic of The Sunday Times in London end general adminstrator of the Mitchell Prize. These are not titles that go back to the days of the Bayeux Tapestry, therefore, but when it comes to intellectual illumination they stand for high wattage. In any case, people love lords. George Weidenfeld has a roster of titled authors that stretches from here to Shea Stadium, and altogether the English end of the Mitchell Prize has a great deal of style.

title: Dance: Muna Tseng
description: MUNA TSENG is an exquisite dancer and there were exquisite moments in Wednesday night's concert by Muna Tseng and Dancers at the Theater of the Riverside Church. Miss Tseng's love of whimsy was particularly evident in her new Moonbeams, which, set to a taped collage of music and speech, explored childhood fantasies.

title: Kings Top Rangers By 42; Slumping Rangers Lose To Kings by 42 on Coast
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Nov. 1  The realization that they had not won in their last three games followed the New York Rangers to the West Coast.

title: EARNINGS General Dynamics Profit Climbs 25.9% in Quarter
description: The General Dynamics Corporation, the nation's largest defense contractor, yesterday reported a 25.9 percent increase in the thirdquarter profits on a 27 percent sales rise.

title: News Summary International Energy National Metropolitan
description: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 2, 1979

title: Second SocietyGrows in East Europe Social Mobility Has Diminished
description: BUDAPEST  On Garay Terrace in the heart of this Hungarian capital, small knots of people gather in the morning around poorly dressed and unshaven men who furtively display shopping bags containing cheap rings, trinkets, cigarettes and embroidered blouses.

title: U.S. Budget Cutting: Putting Genie Back in Bottle; News Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1  Last Monday the Senate was considering a bill that would place a strict limit on Federal funds that help poor children in foster care. Liberal lobbyists, upset by the plan, desperately tried to find a senator tosponsor an amendment to remove the cap.

title: 68 Legislators Urge U.S.Soviet Airlift for Cambodia Led White House Delegation Joint Responsibilities Suggested
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1  A bipartisan group of 68 members of the House of Representatives appealed to President Carter today to try to set up a joint airlift with the Soviet Union to relieve mass starvation in Cambodia.

title: Television TOP WEEKEND FILMS
description: Morning

title: Drive Is Begun To Free Streets Of Monte Game Drive Is Begun to Free Streets of the Dealers Of ThreeCard Monte The New York Times/Paul Hosefros
description: The police and midtown business groups moved yesterday against the swiftdealing threecard monte operators who make an art of separating the unwary from their money. But the operators, perhaps having got word of the maneuver, disappeared from midtown streets.

title: For Children Puppets in the Park National Horse Show KidsDrama Workshop Film Song and Stories Plays Puppets and Magic
description: GULLIVER, by the Cottage Marionette Theater, Saturday at noon and 2:30 P.M., in the Swedish Cottape In Central Park, Central Park West and 81st Street. Free. Reservations: 9889093.

title: Around the Nation Judge Halts Enforcement Of Illinois Abortion Law
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 1 (AP)  A Federal district judge has temporarily halted the enforcement of a new state abortion law just one day after the General Assembly overrode a veto by Gov. James R. Thompson Jr.

title: CARTER URGES PLAN TO BACK $1.5 BILLION IN CHRYSLER LOANS GUARANTEE A RECORD Doubling of Aid Envisioned for Company Linked to Worsening Plight $1.5 Billion Chrysler Aid Backed
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1  The Carter Administration proposed today that the Government provide $1.5 billion in loan guarantees for the Chrysler Corporation.

title: Crop Exports Set Record
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (UPI)  The value of United States agricultural exports totaled $32 billion in the fiscal year 1979, 17 percent higher than last year and a record for the 10th straight year, Secretary of Agriculture Bob Bergland said today.

title: Greece and France Join Met in Show Of Aegean Art Aegean Art In Show At the Met
description: THE very names  Olympia, Delphi, Rhodes, Samos  exercise a magic spell, and so news of a loan exhibition of ancient art from the museums in these and other Greek locales is bound to excite particularly high expectations. Lest itbe thought, therefore, that yet another blockbuster is upon us in the show called Greek Art of the Aegean Islands, which opened yesterday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, it should be said straightaway that this exhibition, though it contains a great many objects of rare beauty and historic interest, is something less than an epochal event.

title: Kennedy Changedby Accident Kennedy Wins Union's Backing
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (UPI)  Senator Edward M. Kennedy said today that the death of Mary Jo Kopechne in his car at Chappaquiddick Island 10 years ago changed his life more than the assassinations of his brothers John and Robert.

title: Spring Showings Open on a Civilized Note; Wear With Confidence
description: Halston fired the opening salvo in the New York series of fashion shows for spring 1980 this week. His approach was civilized. From his aerie high in the Olympic Tower on Fifth Avenue, his audience of press people and store buyers saw pretty girls parade down the long runway in pretty, dresses to pleasant background music. There were no minis (I don't really care for them much right now) or the other eccentricities with which the European readytowear collections abound.

title: Auctions A big week for art sales.
description: THE art world is gearing up for week of spectacular auctions of paintings, sculpture and drawings that should keep dealers and collectors going at a sizzling pace from Monday evening through the afternoon of Saturday, Nov. 10. The sales open on a high note Monday night at at Sotheby Parke Bernet, Madison Avenue at 76th Street, with the dispersal of the William N. Copley collection, described as the most important group of Surrealist art works ever in a public sale. Mr. Copley, the painter, assembled many of the selections when he ran an art gallery in the 1940's in Los Angeles and numbered among his friends Max Ernst, Rene Magritte, Man Ray and Marcel Duchamp. The top lots in the sale are three works by Ernst (estimated to sell for up to $800,000, $250,000 and $200,000); a Joan Mire (up to $250,000) ; Man Ray's painting of a pair of giant red lips over a landscape (up to $250,000); an Yves Tanguy (up to $200,000), and three Magrittes (one up to $180,000 and the others up to $200,000). The second session of this sale will take place Tuesday at 2 P.M. and includes additional works by these and other artists.

title: Puissance to Wrong Number; Wrong Number, Ridden By Vaillancourt, Is Victor
description: Wrong Number, a veritable neophyte in the field at 6 years of age, soared over a wall of 7 feet 1 inches to win the puissance class at the National Horse Show last night. His rider then promptly predicted the horse would break the world indoor record.

title: Guide to the Wide Whirl of Folk Dancing Partners Not Required
description: It is no wonder that in New York, this melting pot of immigrants, every weekend during every season of the year and in almost every community, there are groups of people, young and old, kicking out their feet, twirling their skirts and tapping their toes to the traditional tunes and rhythms of their own and their neighbors ancestors

title: American Conference Teams' Records Suggest Dominant Theory; Local Teams
description: American Conference teams won all six games last week from National Conference opponents for the first time since the National Football League took on its present format 10 seasons ago. The A.F.C. leads the interconference competition this year, 219, with 22 games remaining.

title: Jets 11 Wounded Feel Like Outcasts; 2 Falls Down Stairs
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 1 They used to be called the Jets Swimming Team when Mark Lomas was their leader several years ago. Now they are just the injured Jets, the ones who cannot play and who feel uncomfortable surrounded by their healthy teammates.

title: Shock Past, Seoul Goes About Its Business Few Deviate From Routine
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 1 Sandwiched between a black Mercedes and a Rekord Royale, Ku Tae Duk sat on wooden box, his back to the brick wall of a Viennese pastry shop, and repaired shoes.

title: U.S., Fearing a Spread Of Vietnam Invasion, Speeds Arms to Thais
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1  The senior spokesman for the Defense Department said today that the United States was concerned that the Vietnamese invasion of Cambodia might spread to other countries, and has accelerated deliveries of weapons to Thailand, which borders Cambodia.

title: Letters; An Eyewitness Recalls the 1948 Arab Exodus
description: To the Editor:

title: Dianetic Sect Said to Spy on A.M.A. Criticized Over Dianetics
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP)  Leaders of the Church of Scientology thought of the American Medical Association and the National Institute of Mental Health as enemies and infiltrated the medical association to discredit it, according to documents made public today.

title: Market Place YearEnd TaxSwap Guidelines
description: EVERY year about this time, investors begin to worry about establishing capital gains and losses, and tax swaps become commonplace.

title: James Buckley Weighs Senate Bid
description: James L. Buckley, the former ConservativeRepublican United States Senator from New York, said yesterday that he would decide soon whether to seek the Republican nomination for United States Senator from Connecticut.

title: Why to Vote in New Jersey
description: Early Presidential campaigning seems to have drowned out the candidates seeking the 80 seats in the next New Jersey Legislature. When asked who was running in next Tuesday's Assembly election, one voter replied: Carter, Kennedy and Reagan.

title: COMMODITIES U.S. Gold Auction Spurs Steep Decline in Prices Potentially Bullish Development
description: By The Associated Press

title: CREDIT MARKETS Treasury Bonds Yield 10.44% Bonds Carry 1O% Coupon
description: The Treasury sold 30year bonds yesterday at an average yield of 10.44 percent, the highest rate the Government has ever accepted on such longterm securities.

title: An Ontario Stable Pays $200,000 for Harness Filly
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 1 (AP) Delmegan, a filly by Super BowlDelmonica, was sold today for $200,000 to the Armstrong Brothers Stable of Brampton, Ontario, the top price on the final day of the 45th annual Standardbred Horse Sales.

title: TORIES INVOKE CURB ON PUBLIC,SPENDING British Government Will Restrain Social Services in an Effort to Counteract Inflation Some Modest Cuts, Some Increases Gasps From the Labor Side Lower Cost to Taxpayers
description: LONDON, Nov. 1  Declaring that high public spending was a main cause of British economic problems, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Cabinet specified today how it would reduce government spending.

title: Producer Prices Rise 1% in Month Rate Is Lower But No Relief Is in Prospect Producer Prices Rise 1% in Month Energy Goods Increases The New York Times/Nov. 2. 1979
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1  The Government reported today that its Producer Price Index, which measures the prices of goods at wholesale but which anticipates retail trends, had risen by 1 percent last month, indicating that little inflation relief was in sight.

title: Digest BUSINESS Digest Companies
description: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 2, 1979

title: Restaurants West Side bargain and East Side pub.
description: WITH food prices soaring upward almost by the minute, there is some cause for celebration when a restaurant offers pleasantly prepared and interesting main courses such as Thaistyle rabbit sauted in soy sauce with ginger and mushrooms, pork chops sauted with onion in hoi sin sauce, and a crisp, buttery stuffed chicken cutlet for $5.95, complete with rice or potatoes and wellcooked vegetables. Not all creations at the 10monthold International Forest and Sea Restaurant at 83d Street and Amsterdam Avenue live up to those three dishes, but it is nevertheless possible to put together a satisfying and entertaining meal here for $10 or even a little less. The Thai owners offer food that is basically Continental with Oriental accents and overtones, a combination that works better in some instances than in others.

title: Hawks' Magnuson Retires, Will Be Assistant Coach
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 1 (AP)  Keith Magnuson, Chicago Black Hawk defenseman who led the National Hockey League in penalty minutes during his first two seasons, announced his retirement as a player today. He will become an assistant coach with the club.

title: Wake Forest Gains Top 20 in Football
description: Wake Forest, the most surprising team in majorcollege football, moved into 18th place in this week's computer ranking, after 4238 triumph over Auburn last Saturday. It was the Deacons first appearance in The New York Times's top 20.

title: WASHINGTON Fritz Mondale's Blitz
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1  In this phonywar phase of the Presidential election, Vice President Mondale has the hardest job of all. He is by general agreement one of the most decent and certainly one of the most liberal leaders of the Democratic Party, but he has been assigned the task of cutting up his old liberal ally, Senator Kennedy, in an effort to rescue and reelect President Carter and himself.

title: World News Briefs A Leading Iranian Ayatollah Is Wounded by Gunmen
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 1 (Reuters) Gunmen today shot and seriously wounded Ayatollah Qazi Tabatabai, the chief clergyman of Tabriz, a spokesman for the governor said.

title: Casals Body to Be Sent To His Catalonian Village
description: The body of Pablo Casals, who died in October 1973 at the age of 96 and was buried in Puerto Rico, will be returned next Thursday to Spain.

title: TV Weekend Four Family Dramas, MacArthurand Jaws
description: THE networks are gearing up for their ratings sweeps, the periodic binge of counter programming that scatters expensive productions in a frenzy of the public be damned scheduling. Meanwhile, some impressive moments of unusual substance can be found in a 90minute documentary made by two independent video makers  John Reilly and Julie Gustafson.

title: Korea's Generals Said to Agree to Scrap Constitution Powers Were Formidable A 3Month Freeze Power Brokers Seem Doomed Show of Solidarity
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 1  Senior army generals meeting in secret here this week have informally decided to scrap the Constitution that was the legal foundation of President Park Chung Hee's power, according to sources close to the military today.

title: Leader of Tiny Pacific Nation Sues a Newspaper Giant One Subscriber on Nauru
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 1  The Gannett Company Inc., the nation's largest newspaper chain, and Hammer DeRoburt, president of Nauru, the richest little island and smallest republic in the world, are squaring off in Federal District Court in Honolulu, where their multimilliondollar libel suit will be tried.

title: White House Still Chooses Aiello
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1  The White House has decided to go ahead with the appointment of Stephen R. Aiello, president of the New York City Board of Education, as a special assistant to President Carter, Representative Mario Biaggi said today.

title: Senate Backs Checking Interest
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1, (Reuters)  The Senate tonight passed, on a vote of 76 to 9, a bill that would continued to allow interest on money held in checking accounts, or negotiable order of withdrawal (NOW) accounts.

title: GiantsCowboys Game a Tilt of Opposites; Looking Back Instead of Forward
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 1  One team has missed the playoffs once in 13 seasons; the other has not been to the playoffs since 1963.

title: Baker Joins Campaign for Presidential Nomination Few Political Negatives
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., the Senate Republican leader, formally declared his Presidential candidacy today, saying he was the man to start the nation on a new generation of confidence.

title: The City Boy, 14, Accused Of 2 Rape Attempts
description: A 14yearold Manhattan high school student was arrested yesterday and charged with trying to rape two women and with sexual abuse and weapons possession. He is believed to be responsible for 18 sex attacks last month on female joggers in Riverside Park near Columbia University.

title: Obituary 3 No Title
description: Deaths

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A dispatch by The Associated Press from Birmingham, Ala., printed in The Times yesterday, incorrectly reported that a Federal indictment had accused two former Alabama state senators, Joe Fine and Eddie Hubert Gilmore, and state Representative Jack Biddle of accepting prostitutes from an Alabama coal company. The indictment charged that the Drummond Coal Company had provided prostitutes for unidentified state legislators, but not for Mr. Fine, Mr. Gilmore or Mr. Biddle. Those defendants were charged only with having accepted gifts, money, airplane trips and football tickets.

title: A Guide to the Wide Whirl Of Folk Dancing in the Region
description: The New York Times/Funk C. Dougherty

title: Cambodia Impasse: Political and Human Needs in Conflict News Analysis Talks Under Way for Months FullScale Aid Effort Opposed
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 1  The Cambodian Government has not only rejected a proposal by three American Senators to receive food for its starving people by road from Thailand. but alsocontinues to delay open and full acceptance of a relief program by two international agencies that are acting in effect on behalf of the Western world.

title: Advertising Direct Mail: A Sounding By Gallup UN Plaza: New Monthly Free for the Affluent Campus Media Exposure To Be Surveyed Next Year People
description: DIRECT mail advertising, junk mail to its detractors, is already probably the most precise kind of advertising, because both the form and the content of the messages and their target audiences can be thoroughly researched and refined before a major effort is made.

title: Kennedy Forces Lagging Badly in Iowa Carter Team Is Well Ahead
description: DES MOINES, Nov. 1  In the awkward transition from a draft movement to an authentic Presidential campaign, the forces backing Senator Edward M. Kennedy are now stalled and temporarily a bit demoralized in the state that the Senator himself called the first real battleground with President Carter in 1980.

title: Visa Traveler's Checks Put on Sale
description: A major Chicago bank and a tiny New York bank became the first institutions in the world to issue Visa traveler's checks yesterday. They were the First National Bank of Chicago, the nation's ninth largest bank, with assets of $28 billion, and the Golden Pacific National Bank of New York, with assets of $24 million.

title: Growth Problems for 115 Infants Linked to Recalled Baby Formula
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (UPI)  As many as 115 infants around the country may have suffered growth problems by consuming a sincerecalled baby formula, with the longrange impact on their health not yet known, Federal health officials said today.

title: Freighter Hits Tanker Off Texas, Spilling Oil 31 Are Believed Dead Freighter Rams Tanker Off Texas Oil Spills and 31 Are Feared Dead
description: GALVESTON, Tex., Nov. 1  A Liberian tanker carrying 16.8 million gallons of crude oil was rammed amidships early this morning by a freighter in choppy seas about five miles south of this Gulf Coast port. Both ships burst into flames and the tanker was sinking.

title: New Face: Bob Gunton Getting Inside the Skin of a Dictator A National Legend Tribute to a Mentor
description: WHEN Bob Gunton, who plays Juan D. Pern in Evita, heard he was being considered for a part in that show, the 33yearold actor thought that it must be the role of Che the battleclad guerrilla who moves through the musical reminding the audience of the villainy and greed of Peronism.

title: Slayer of F.B.I. Agent Gets Life
description: CLEVELAND, Nov. 1 (AP)  Melvin Bay Guyon, 20 years old, was found guilty today of firstdegree murder and sentenced to life imprisonment for the Aug.9 slaying of a Federal Bureau of Investigation agent, Johnnie L. Oliver, in an innercity apartment. A jury of six men and six women returned the verdict before United States District Judge John M. Manos after deliberations for three days.

title: Loosening the Belt a Little Tighter
description: In the present atmosphere of confusion about America's economic problems, we could understand a Government policy aimed at cooling off inflation with economic restraint. Or we could understand a policy of stimulus, to promote growth and productivity. Whatwe cannot understand is the present tendency to try both at once. Congress, the Federal Reserve Board and the President act as if they agree on economic strategy. In fact they are pointing toward policies so inconsistent as to do further serious damage.

title: U.S. Made Money On Lockheed Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP)  If history is any guide, taxpayers could reap tens of millions of dollars of profit from the Carter Administration's proposed loan guarantees for the Chrysler Corporation.

title: Obituary 7 No Title
description: Deaths

title: Puerto Rican Leaders Sense Improvements in Relationship With Koch But Now He Was Subdued
description: Within days of the August shakeup that cost Herman Badillo his job as a New York City Deputy Mayor, a small group of his friends and sometime critics called at his City Hall office for a meeting. The atmosphere was one of concern.

title: At the Movies; Star of 10 declares her independence.
description: I warned Orion not to fool around with me, but they didn't believe me, Bo Derek was saying the other day. She was referring to the company that made 10, in which she plays the title role, the unreachable summit of beauty on a scale of 1 to 10.

title: Obituary 4 No Title
description: Deaths

title: Studio 54 Owners Reported Ready To Plead Guilty to Evading Taxes Maximum FiveYear Term
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1  Two of the owners of the Studio 54 discothque in New York City are expected to plead guilty in Federal District Court in Manhattan tomorrow to two counts of tax evasion, Justice Department officials said today.

title: 3 Con Ed Plants Being Converted For Use of Coal Work Begun Before Permit for Change From Oil Con Edison Converting 3 Plants Before Getting Approval for Coal
description: Without waiting for approval by state and city environmental agencies, the Consolidated Edison Company has started work on a $150 million project to convert three of its oilburning electric power plants in Queens and Staten Island to coalburning capability. The plan is bitterly opposed by environmentalists and some community leaders.

title: Books of The Times
description: WHAT are we to make of Max Reinhardt, those of us born too late ever to have seen any of his stage productions? How do we assess a genius of the theater whose only artifact is a movie, the 1935 Hollywood version of A Midsummer Night's Dream, which introduced Mickey Rooney and Olivia de Havilland to the American public? This Viennese character actor and ham, this selfeducated upstart, virtually invented the cult of the director and, certainly from his staging of Gorky's The Lower Depths in 1902 to the premiere of Der Rosenkavalier in 1911, revolutionized the theater of Berlin and all of Europe.

title: Rules for AlternateSide Parking Now Under Review, Steisel Says
description: Sanitation Commissioner Norman Steisel acknowledged yesterday that New York City regulations for alternateside parking were under review, but he said that if any changes were adopted, they would not take place for at least 18 months.

title: Music: Polish Chopinist The Program
description: KRYSTIAN ZIMERMAN made his first New York appearance last night preceded by a big reputation and by a handful of records. With the New York Philharmonic conducted by Zubin Mehta he played Chopin's F minor concerto. It was not an unexpected choice. Mr. Zimerman, 23 years old, is a Pole and won the Chopin Competition in 1975. He already has recorded the E minor Concerto.

title: Events and Openings Friday Films
description: PROMISES IN THE DARK, directed by Jerome Hellman; starring Marsha Mason and Ned Beatty, at the Cinema I Theater.

title: Astros Sweeten the Pot And Sign Cruz for 5 Years
description: By adding one year and a little more money to the deal, the Houston Astros reached agreement with Jose Cruz yesterday and snatched him out of today's freeagent draft.

title: Rose Crawley Andre Is Married
description: The marriage of Rose Crawley Andre to Howard Pratt Johnson took place yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard W. Deehan of Montclair, N.J.

title: Stage: Jewish Repertory Revives Molnar's Liliom Lexington Ave. Encore
description: LILIOM, a play by the Hungarian playwright Ferenc Molnar, has had success on Broadway since the early 1920's and it was made into a musical, Carousel, by Rodgers and Hammerstein. Now it is being revived by the Jewish Repertory Theater on East 14th Street.

title: A Turning Point For Murray Louis Inspiration in a Park
description: Murray Louis was in a good mood. He had had an old leg injury checked by his orthopedist earlier that day and all was well. Just look at those knees, they're the most beautiful knees I've ever seen, Mr. Louis said, looking down proudly at a pair of knees that have bent and stretched through a good 30 years of plies. That afternoon, too, the dancer and choreographer had just finished reading through the final draft of his book, Inside Dance, a collection of 20 essays to be published by St. Martin's Press in August 1980, with a preface by Rudolf Nureyev and a foreword by the choreographer Alwin Nikolais, Mr. Louis's longtime associate. And later that week the Murray Louis Dance Company was scheduled to open the new Masters of American Dance series at City Center, with a new solo for Mr. Louis to be given its New York premiere tonight, a solo that marks changing point in Mr. Louis's long career in modern dance.

title: The Region 2 Westchester Men Held in Kidnapping
description: WHITE PLAINS  Two Port Chester, N.Y., men were arrested yesterday on charges that they kidnapped a man and a woman at gunpoint last week in a Stamford, Conn., hotel parking lot and then drove them to Mount Vernon, where they allegedly robbed them and raped the woman, according to the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Bunker Ramo Corporation, Oak Brook, Ill., a manufacturer of electronic components and equipment, fabrics and data electronic systems, has elected Duane L. Burnham to the new position of executive vice president.

title: Firestone Reaches PayRule Accord
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (UPI) The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, the nation's secondlargest tire manufacturer, has reached agreement with the Administration that allows it to pay wages in excess of the standard of the Council on Wage and Price Stability.

title: Top Pacers Vie At Roosevelt; Sherry's Twister Third
description: WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 1  Some of the top 2yearold pacers in the East started the threeround Silver Spoon Series tonight, with Nanseroan and Philabuster capturing divisions at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: Zhang Suchu, Witness to 30 Years of China History; I Have Great News Husband Did Manual Labor
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I.  She called him Uncle Zhou and his wife Mama Deng. That was Zhou Enlai, Prime Minister of China until his death three years ago, and his wife Deng Yingchao. These are only two of the great personages who have passed through Zhang Suchu's house in the past 30 years. She has been a witness to history.

title: Accord Reached in 4Month Strike For Higher Pay at Green Bus Lines
description: A tentative agreement in the fourmonth strike against Green Bus Lines Inc., which serves 100,000 daily riders in Queens, was announced last night by a state mediator.

title: Judge Backs Confidentiality Between Adult and Parent Appeal Being Decided
description: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 1  In what apparently was the first ruling of its kind, a Westchester County judge has held that a parent cannot be forced to testify against his child, even if the child is an adult.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yesterday's Weather at 1 P.M.: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration/UPI

title: Harry Nickles, 70, Dies An ExEditor at Holiday
description: Harry G. Nickles, retired senior staff editor of Holiday magazine, died Monday at his home in Bucks County, Pa. He was 70 years old.

title: Disposal Sites of States For Chemical Wastes
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1  The following is a statebystate list of the chemicalwaste disposal sites identified for the House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations:

title: Appeals Court Says Using Office For Personal Gain Is Not Bribery
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP)  A Federal appeals court ruled Wednesday that Government officials could be convicted under Federal bribery laws only if they took money to influence official decisions.

title: Retail Sales Gains Slowed in October Sears Up Only 0.2% Penney 1.5% Higher
description: Sales gains of the nation's largest retailers were generally smaller last month than yeartoyear increases achieved earlier in 1979, according to reports released by the retailers yesterday. The results reconfirmed the slowdown in consumer buying that first became evident in the late spring.

title: Milwaukee Rail Partly Closed
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 1 (UPI)  More than half of the Milwaukee Road's track system was closed today in an effort to restore the bankrupt railroad to profitability.

title: Hard Times at Sparrows Point Sparrows Point Wrestles With Shipyard Slump Bethlehem Sends Work The New York Times /George Tames
description: SPARROWS POINT, Maryland  It was the best of times. The Arco Prudhoe Bay, keel laid in 1969, delivered December 1971; the Arco Sag River, keel laid May of 1971, delivered May of 1972, the American Independence, keel laid January 1976 and delivered November 1977, noted George S. Hamilton, general manager of the shipyard of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, in looking over the records of the big ships built by the yard. But that was the last of the big oil tankers, he said, and now it is the worst of times.

title: W. Conant Brewer, 83, Founder Of Container Shipping Concern
description: W. Conant Brewer, founder of the Brewer Shipping and Tidal Companies, died Wednesday at his home in New York City. He was 83 years old.

title: Florida Dam Rupture Leaves Many Stranded
description: OKEECHOBEE, Fla., Nov. 1 (UPI)  Flood waters from a ruptured power company dam began receding today, but hundreds of residents, many of them angry, were told they could not return to their inundated homes for days.

title: Importers Win TV Duty Cut
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) American importers of television sets made by 10 major Japanese companies have won a reduction in the customs duties charged on sets imported before July 1973, the United States Customs Service announced today.

title: The New Bork Times College Football Rankings
World Gold
Scotto's Counsel Assured Carey He Wouldn't Be Made Bad Guy
description: In negotiations that led to Governor Carey's appearance as a character witness for Anthony M. Scotto, the Governor was assured by the Scotto defense that he would not be made to look like the bad guy, Carey aides said yesterday.

title: Nuclear Experts Called to Capital After Report Suggests New Hazard Potentially Significant Problem 52 NUCLEAR EXPERTS CALLED TO CAPITAL Continued From Page A 1
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 The Government, acting on the basis of a study by the staff of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, has summoned more than 50 nuclear fuel experts to an emergency meeting that began today. The study suggestedthat the emergency corecooling systems of virtually all the nation's nuclear reactors might not function as expected in an accident involving a loss of coolant.

title: Broadway Pinter's Betrayal,a tale of infidelity, to arrive Jan. 5
description: THERE have been lamentations sung over the straight play; the straight play is supposed to be dead, and better left to Joseph Papp, say, than to anyone on Broadway. But that was past, and now is now, and the season will be alive with straight plays. One of them is Betrayal. Theplay by Harold Pinter will open at the Trafalgar Theater on Jan. 5 and will star Blythe Danner, Raul Julia and Roy Scheider. They make up a more than interesting cast, and they are listed here alphabetically because that is the way they will be listed in the credits. Agents and lawyers strain mightily over settling things like that; it gives them something to do.

title: Help for Detroit's County Gains With Vote Accord Talks Irk County Officials
description: DETROIT, Nov. 1  Gov. William G. Milliken of Michigan and Mayor Coleman A. Young of Detroit have reached an agreement on a way to reorganize the government of Wayne County, opening the way for state aid to help the county out of its financial crisis.

title: Economic Scene Flawed Data Not Uncommon
description: WHERE is the recession? Economists were certain that they saw it in the second quarter of this year, when gross national product, that mulligan stew of hard and soft data, seasonal adjustment factors, price deflators and synthetic concepts alleged to represent the total output of goods and services of the national economy, declined at an annual rate of 2.3 percent. But then in the third quarter, real G.N.P. went up 2.4 percent, and the recession wasn't there.

title: Knicks Top Jazz; Knight, Cartwright Excel; Injury to Maravich Hurts Cavaliers 127, Pistons 125 Knicks Box Score
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 1 (AP) Bill Cartwright and Toby Knight scored 31 points each as the New York Knicks broke open a tight game early in the fourth quarter and defeated the Utah Jazz, 134118, in a National Basketball Association game tonight.

title: Obituary 5 No Title
description: Deaths

title: Journalist Who Reports a Fraud In Jersey Indicted as Participant Defendant Wrote 9 Articles
description: TRENTON, Nov. 1  A journalist who wrote a series of articles alleging the existence of a $45 million state unemployment insurance fraud scheme involving department officials was indicted by a state grand jury on charges of participating in a similar scheme.

title: China Drops Controls On Many Retail Prices To Spur Competition City Workers Get a Raise
description: PEKING, Nov. 1 (Reuters)  China removing price controls on thousands of products to spur competition and improve economic performance.

title: Spirited Race for Governor Nears End in Kentucky Viewed as Kennedy Backer Reach For the Stars
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 1  Because there are only three gubernatorial elections throughout the country in this prePresidential election year, to say that Kentucky has the most exciting and most politically consequential of the three is to understate the drama of this campaign.

title: Retired Police Officer Kills Wife And Then Turns Gun on Himself
description: A retired New York City police officer who had served on the force for 23 years shot and killed his wife yesterday and then turned the gun on himself, the police reported.

title: Radio Music Talk Events/Sports
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Deux marches et un Intermede, Poulenc; Nocturne in A flat No. 2, Chopin; Rondo for Flute and Orchestra in D (K.184), Mozart; Khovanschina, Prelude, Mussorgsky; Mazurka No. 15, Chopin; Caprices, Paganini.

title: Shipping/Mails; Incoming
description: ARRIVING TOMORROW, Nov. 3

title: IN THE NATION A Tale Of Two Cities
description: Federal judges in two cities delivered this week a double blow to the widely doubted idea that the law in this country acts equitably to protect the weak as well as the strong, the Door as well as the rich.

title: Jersey Democrats Expected to Retain Assembly Grip Help From Out of State
description: TRENTON, Oct. 31  Democrats are expected to retain control of the New Jersey State Assembly in next Tuesday's elections, despite a heavily financed Republican campaign effort.

title: A Jazz Horn of Plenty Spills Into Halls and Clubs A Jazz Horn of Plenty Spills Into Concert Halls and Clubs Ballads of the 20's Exploratory Guitarist Singers From the Big Bands
description: JAZZ is sweeping through New York this weekend with a splendid fall lineup of groups ranging from big bands to quintets, quartets and trios, with singers, pianists and guitarists galore, and styles covering a span from early blues and swing to the latest experimentalists. There's something for everybody.

title: Financial and Political Urgency Called Impetus to Chrysler Aid Interest Shown by Mondale
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1  A rapidly deteriorating financial situation at the Chrysler Corporation, combined with mounting political pressures on President Carter, led to the Administration's surprise endorsement today of a rescue package twice as big as it had originally contemplated, according to officials involved in helping Chrysler.

title: 3 Promoted at Buffalo News
description: BUFFALO, Nov. 1 (AP)  The Buffalo Evening News has promoted three editors following the retirement yesterday of Elwood M. Wardlow as managing editor for administration. Murray B. Light, who had been managing editor for news, was named editor, a new post, and vice president. Foster L. Spencer, assistant managing editor, was named managing editor, and Edward L. Cuddihy, was promoted from city editor to assistant managing editor, but will continue to run the city desk.

title: Shah's New York Doctors Said to Be Giving Iran Data on His Illness Reports Supplied Periodically Shah Treated for 30 Years Tumor Found In 1949 Treated by French Doctors
description: Doctors attending the deposed Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi of Iran at CornellNew York Hospital here have informally supplied medical details about his illness to doctors representing the current regime in Iran, according to a senior United States Government official who asked not to be identified.

title: New Construction Up for September
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) New construction in September rose 1.5 percent after a slight decline the month before, the Commerce Department said today.

title: 13% Part in Building On E. 52d Street Cost Scotto $26 to Acquire
description: A luxury apartment building near Sutton Place  far removed from the Brooklyn waterfront  has become one of the mystery elements in the trial of AnthonyM. Scotto, the International Longshoremen's Association leader.

title: Green Building on Earlier Setbacks In Bid for Philadelphia Mayoralty Marston and Police Support Promises to Blacks Labor Leader's Strength
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 2  In 1971, says Peter J. Camiel, then the head of the Democratic City Committee in Philadelphia, William J. Green came before a subcommittee screening potential nominees for Mayor of Philadelphia. He blew his stack, played the individual game, said he didn't need our support, Mr. Camiel says.

title: Visa Bids for TravelersCash; Check Venture Marks Entry in Tough Field
description: The day before yesterday, John Mallen became the first person in the world to buy a Visa traveler's check. At about 9:30 Thursday morning he appeared at the Golden Pacific National Bank in New York's Chinatown and bought five $20 checks.

title: Blacks Plan Convention to Prepare A Platform for Presidential Rivals 1972 Convention Recalled Memphis Vote Awaited
description: A national political gathering of blacks from a variety of fields is being planned for February to put pressure on both the Democratic and Republican candidates for President to support issues of concern to blacks.

title: Hua Tours a Biitish Dairy Farm And Chats With Townspeople; A Display of Farming Knowledge; Normal British Peasant's House?
description: BRIGHTWELLCUMSOTWELL, England, Nov. 2  Prime Minister Hua Guofeng of China, on the last full day of his visit to Britain, exuberantly toured a dairy farm this morning in the green hills of Oxfordshire. west of London.

title: Gretzky, Oilers Stop Islanders Bobby Hull in N.H.L. Return
description: EDMONTON, Alberta, Nov. 2 (UPI) Wayne Gretzky scored two goals and assisted on another tonight to power the Edmonton Oilers to a 75 triumph over the New York Islanders.

title: One Way to Appoint 2 With Single Post Open
description: ALBANY, Nov. 2  The Legislature resolved a squabble today over whether to name a Republican or Democratic to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. It expanded the size of the board to 14 from 13 and named them both.

title: Braun Discloses Talks on Merger
description: C.F. Braun & Company, a West Coast engineering concern long considered to be a takeover target, disclosed yesterday that it had begun formal merger discussions with an unidentified buyer on what it termed an amicable basis.

title: Oil Clouds Outlook on Payments Chance of U.S. Deficit Increased By Price Surge
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2  Rising world oil prices and the likelihood of further increases in coming months have raised the significant prospect of a deficit next year in the balance of payments, according to Administration and private economists.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 19.

title: Corporate Sales and Earnings Reports
description: For periods as shown.(N) Indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: New Typhoon Gathering Speed
description: TOKYO, Nov. 2 (UPI)  A new typhoon called Vera was spotted moving northwest in the Pacific near the Caroline Islands, weathermen said today. Vera was upgraded from a tropical lowpressure system as its center reached speeds of 45 miles an hour, the Tokyo Meteorological Agency said.

title: Thriving Irish Losing Inferiority Feelings The The Talk of Dublin Conversation With the Mayor
description: DUBLIN  The reports from Chicago that Princess Margaret used the term pigs in talking about the Irish were frontpage news in this land of ingrained sensitivity to what the British think. But reading the accounts and discussing them, a good many Irish people were pleasantly surprised to discover that their reaction to the alleged slur, which Princess Margaret denies having made, is amusement, not indignation.

title: Whole and the Lame Cross Paths at Cambodian Border Soldiers Urge Child to Go Disciplined in Leaders' Presence Parents Died of Hunger
description: KHLONG KHAI THUEN, Thailand, Nov. 1  Twoway traffic moves on the trail between here and the Cambodian border, on the other side of a huge crag that juts out of the low jungle landscape.

title: KENNEDY CAMPAIGNS ON NUCLEAR SAFETY In West Virginia, He Attacks Carter for Uncertain Course on Issue and Overall Leadership
description: CHARLESTON, W.Va., Nov. 2  Senator Edward M. Kennedy raised nuclear power as a campaign issue tonight, challenging President Carter to move forcefully on nuclear safety and renewing his own call for a moratorium on construction of nuclear power plants until safety problems are resolved.

title: Dividends
description: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 2, 1979

title: Groups Backing and Opposing Gun Curbs Gearing Up for Political Campaign in 1980 Violent Crime on Rise
description: While Senator Edward M. Kennedy has been preparing to announce his Presidential candidacy on Nov. 7, the political arm of the National Rifle Association has been asking gun owners around the country to join in helping to defeat the Massachusetts Democrat because of his role in sponsoring guncontrol legislation.

title: Bronx Gets Charlotte Street Project  a Movie Set Rubble Is Shipped In Bronx Gets Charlotte  Project a Film Set Planning Board Consulted The New York Times/Carl T. Gossett
description: A major construction effort of the kind Charlotte Street has been unable to obtain in real life is proceeding, in the unreal world of the movies, on one of the most barren sites in the Bronx.

title: 2 Die on U.S. Copter in Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Saturday, Nov.3 (AP)  A United States Army helicopter crashed yesterday on a training mission near Tongduchon, nine miles north of Seoul, and the two crewmen were killed, an Army spokesman announced today. Their names were withheld.

title: Import Ruling Challenged
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (UPI) Florida vegetable growers are seeking a Federal court injunction to overturn a rejection of their claims that Mexican vegetables are being sold below market value in the United States, their attorney said today. The growers charged in a lawsuit filed late Thursday that the Treasury Department went beyond the law and regulations in this week's temporary decision.

title: Protectionism in E.E.C. Reflected in Lamb War
description: PARIS, Nov. 2  Lamb chops ought to be as much as 30 percent cheaper in Paris right now. But they are not, because the nine members of the supposedly freetrading European Economic Community do not trade as freely with each other as they are obligated to.

title: Greek Nickel Mine Blast Kills 4
description: ATHENS, Nov. 2 (UPI)  An explosion today at the Larco nickel mining works at Larymna in central Greece killed 4 workers and injured 16, a company spokesman said. Initial reports indicated that a butane gas bottle might have been the cause of the blast, the spokesman said.

title: Pacific Bell Seeks Rate Increase
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 2  The Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company, which has been ordered to refund $341 million to its customers and reduce rates by $80 million a year, asked the California Public Utilities Commission yesterday for a rate increase of nearly 10 percent.

title: ATOM UNIT REVERSES ASSESSMENT OF RISK Staff Experts Say New Data Show No Hazard in Cooling Systems Atom Unit Reverses Assessment Of Reactor Cooling System Risks
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2  Staff experts of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, which began emergency meetings yesterday with nuclear fuel experts on an apparent new problem with nuclear reactor cooling systems, said today that there was no cause for concern.

title: A South Africa Paradox
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  South Africa's recent political evolution presents a complex paradox. Some blacks seem to have won significant economic and social gains, but recent reforms bypass impoverished rural residents, the majority of South Africa's black population of 20 million.

title: Agency Urges End To Mortgage Lid
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation announced yesterday that it had sent a letter to Governor Carey asking that New York State remove its ceiling on mortgage interest rates.

title: Chief of Social Security Resigning After a Year
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2  After only 13 months on the job, Stanford G. Ross announced today that he was resigning as Commissioner of Social Security to form a law partnership in Washington with his old friend Joseph A. Califano Jr.

title: Elections Won by Textile Union At 2 Southern J.P. Stevens Plants Union Rejects Vote Challenge
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 2  In the last four weeks, the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union has won two bargaining elections at Southern plants of J.P. Stevens & Company, the textile corporation that has long resisted unionization of its employees.

title: COMPANY NEWS House and Senate Clear Railroad Loan; G.M. Seeks to Buy Isuzu Motor Engines IDS Realty Agrees To Boothe Takeover 3 Airlines Report Passenger Increases American Financial In Tender Offer
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP)  Both houses of Congress gave quick approval today to a multimilliondollar loan program designed to get freight trains rolling again on Milwaukee Road's western lines.

title: CocaCola's Subsidiary in Brazil Joins the Guarana Generation; A Showcase for the Future Capturing Coke's Trademark
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  CocaCola of Brazil, already the leader in the world's fifthlargest softdrink market, is bidding for a larger share with a sprightly advertising and marketing campaign to introduce its new guarana soda called Tai.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: INTO SPACE Eeyore's Books for Children, Manhattan's only store dealing exclusively in publications for young readers, attracts children of all ages with its shelves of several thousand titles in many categories, friendly, familystyle atmosphere and special events involving readers and authors. The store (3620634), named for an animal character in Winnie the Pooh, is at 2252 Broadway, between 80th and 81st Streets.

title: Securities Analyst, 45, Slain in His Apartment
description: Manuel Thomas Correia, a 45yearold securities analyst, was found dead in his apartment at 9 West 64th Street Thursday morning, his wrists and ankles bound.

title: Strike Paralyzes Cities in Bolivia Rights Restricted Congress Defies Military, Backing Ousted Leader Continued From Page 1
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Nov. 2  Bolivia's cities were paralyzed today by a general strike called to protest the military takeover of the country yesterday, and the new rulers declared a state of siege.

title: Africans in New York: A Lively Visit A Trip to a Family Care Center
description: The best way to show African women what concerns American black women, the leaders of a major women's organization decided, was to immerse them in the classrooms, hospitals and conference rooms where things happen that most affect them and their families. So eight prominent women from Senegal and Togo were recently taken on a tour of New York that ranged from the Bronx to the Ford Foundation to what for most was their first visit to Harlem, in an exchange program sponsored by the National Council of Negro Women.

title: U.S. Judge Rejects IndiansPlea to Bar Tellico Dam
description: KNOXVILLE, Term., Nov. 2 (UPI) A Federal district judge, ruling that the Tellico Dam did not infringe on the constitutional rights of the Cherokee Indians, dismissed the Indians lawsuit today and denied an injunction seeking to halt completion of the project.

title: The Grind To Be A Grad
description: BROOKLINE, Mass. Unlike the parents of my students, I find myself more annoyed than comfortable with the direction that education has taken in the last few years. I have no argument with basic skills, except to note that they are far more complex than is usually thought. What bothers me is that the Age of Competence is inspired by a vision of learning as shortsighted as the vision that inspired the Age of Relevance. In fact, the question What is relevant?, once the unstated determinant of course content, hasn't been buried or discarded; it has merely grown a prepositional phrase, and now reads, What is relevant to success?

title: Jets Save Last Move for Walker Going With the Best
description: The demand in pro football for an expert snapper was underlined yesterday when the Jets used up their nexttolast free move from the injuredreserve list to activate a rookie center, Ed McGlasson. Coach Walt Michaels is going to save that last move for Wesley Walker.

title: Few Monte Game Dealers Return to Street
description: Only a couple of threecard monte dealers were seen plying their trade in Times Square yesterday afternoon, a day after the announcement of a drive against such curbside gambling operators had cleared the streets of them.

title: A Triumph of Social Engineering
description: A favorite sport in recent years among both conservatives and liberals has been to debunk the Great Society programs of the 1960's as costly, overblown social engineering. One such program was Operation Head Start. According to critics, compensatory education programs for preschoolers from poor families offer only meager benefits  and even these disappear once the children enter elementary school.

title: Pop: 2 Eckstines, Billy and Gina
description: Billy Eckstine is introducing a revamped nightclub and a new aspect of his long career this week, through tomorrow, at the Grand Finale II, 210 West 70th Street. The Grand Finale II is a redecorated, enlarged version of the unnumbered Grand Finale, which in the mid1970's was an active part of the New York cabaret circuit. Mr. Eckstine, along with Steve Anthony and Sage, an energetic singing and dancing trio, are the first performers under the new regime,

title: How Not to Vote for Judges
description: Here's a quiz for New York voters: Which candidate for judge are you planning to vote for on Tuesday? Do you know why? Can you recall the name of the last judge you voted for?

title: Kissinger Gave F.B.I. Information As Teacher in 1950's, Memo Says F.B.I. Has No Comment
description: Henry A. Kissinger, while teaching at Harvard University in 1953, volunteered his aid to the Federal Bureau of Investigation and supplied information touching on a seminar he was conducting.

title: BankAccount Rate Bill Draws Praise and Fire; End of Rate Limits Key Provisions of Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP)  A Senatepassed bill that would allow unlimited interest to be paid on checking and savings accounts is drawing both praise and criticism.

title: Music: Tokyo Quartet's Franck
description: The Tokyo Quartet's concert Thursday night at the Metropolitan Museum of Art was considerably better after the intermission than before it, and there are several possible reasons for that difference.

title: 'I Told the Truth,' Scotto Says on Stand; Scotto Relterates Testimony
description: Anthony M. Scotto declared on the witness stand yesterday that he had told the truth when he said he had received political contributions, not payoffs, from two waterfront businessmen.

title: Dr. Blanche Pesky, 72 Authority on Childhood
description: Dr. Blanche Persky, a professor emeritus of New York University and an authority on early childhood education, died yesterday at her home in Sarasota, Fla. She was 72 years old.

title: U.S. Secretary of Defense Plans Visit to China in January for Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (Reuters) Defense Secretary Harold Brown will visit China from Jan. 6 to 13 for talks with that country's leaders, the Pentagon announced today.

title: For AvantGarde in Men's Fashion, Stress Is on OldTime Quality
description: In the 1960's, it was called the peacock revolution. Otherwise sensible men ran around in fat ties, love beads and battered blue jeans. When they dressed up, they wore Nehru suits or turtlenecks with dinner jackets.

title: U.N. Appeals for $251 Million
description: GENEVA, Nov. 2  The United Nations Children's Fund and the International Committee of the Red Cross appealed today for $251 million for their 12month program of aid for Cambodia.

title: Obituary 1 No Title
description: ALSTONTheresa, on November 2, 1979. Beloved wife of Clyde M. Devoted mother of Christine, Cynthia and Claudia. Loving grandmother of Andrea. Dear sister of Catherine Hofmann. Friends may call at Frank E.Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. on Saturday and Sunday from 2.5 and 79PM. Funeral Mass Church of SLIgnatius Loyola, Park Ave. and 84 St. on Monday at 10AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: BUSINESS Digest; The Economy Companies Washington Markets Today's Columns
description: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 3, 1979

title: Army to Seek Subjects Who May Face Risks From Chemical Tests
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP)  The Army announced today that it would try to find soldiers and former soldiers who were subjects of its tests of drugs or chemicalbiological agents and who may be subject to risk of continuing injury.

title: BRITISH PRESS PLAN ON RHODESIA VOTING Carrington Outlines Final Version of Proposal for New Elections and Asks Rebel Approval
description: LONDON, Nov. 2  Britain today outlined what it said was the final version of its plan for new elections in Zimbabwe Rhodesia, and implored the Patriotic Front guerrillas to accept it by Monday.

title: Catholic Clergy Reject the Idea Of Voting Bloc
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (UPI)  The nation's Roman Catholic bishops will speak out on a broad range of issues, including abortion, in the 1980 election campaigns, even though the church rejects the idea of religious voting blocs, they announced today.

title: News Summary International National Metropolitan
description: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 3, 1979

title: Concert: Japanese Music
description: One thinks of the Japanese as expressing the universe by the simplest of means, a brush stroke on paper, a rock in the middle of a swirl of sand, the 17 syllables of a haiku, the plucking of the koto's silk strings. The Music From

title: Mrs. Lloyd Gives U.S. 10 Lead Advice From the Captain Point of Contention
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. Nov. 2 For a while today, Chris Evert Lloyd seemed distracted  a failing that she says has plagued her tennis since her marriage last spring. But she found her concentration midway through the first set, overcame a twogame deficit and defeated Sue Barker, 75, 62, in the opening match of the 51st Wightman Cup.

title: 2 From Massachusetts Will Run Kennedy Campaign in New York Target is March 25 Primary
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy, who is scheduled to announce his Presidential candidacy officially next Wednesday, has already designated two Massachusetts Democrats to head his campaign in New York.

title: Your Money On Choosing Money Funds
description: AS inflation and interest rates continue to soar, moneymarket funds, which are approaching $40 billion in total assets, continue to prosper.

title: 9 Students Injured as School Bus Collides With Truck in Colorado
description: MONTROSE, Colo., Nov. 2 (UPI) Nine students were injured, two of them seriously, when a pickup truck and a school bus carrying 50 school children collided at an intersection four miles north of Olathe, Colo., the state police said today.

title: COMMODITIES Futures Prices Mixed In Precious Metals Sugar Rally Continues
description: Gold futures rose moderately in inconclusive trading yesterday, while sugar futures set highs for the season amid strong speculative interest.

title: Theodore Jacqueney, 36, Editor Who Aided Human Rights Unit
description: Theodore Jacqueney, associate editor of Worldview magazine, died Wednesday at his home in West New York, N.J., of gunshot wound that was apparently selfinflicted, the police said. He was 36 years old.

title: Obituary 2 No Title
description: GREEFFErnest C.F., 84, of Ouogue, Long Island, New York, on October 31, 1979, survived by his wife, Katharine T.Greett, their son, Ernest T.Greeff and daughter, Nancy G. (Mrs.John M.)Sartorius, 2 grandchildren Douglas H.Greeff and David C.Greeft, a brother Herbert B. Green and a sister Helen G. (Mrs. Roswell E.)Fisher. A memorial service will be held at the Church of the Atonement, Main St., Ouogue,L.I., N.Y. on Saturday, November 3, 1979 at 11 o'clock A.M. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Williams College Alumni Fund, Williamstown, Massachusetts, for the Class of 1917, or to Quogue Library, Quogue,N.Y.

title: Four Die of Food Poisoning In a Jersey Mental Hospital coverUp Is Denidd
