description: MARLBORO, N.J., Nov. 2  Four elderly mental patients at the Marlboro Psychiatric Hospital died on Monday and Tuesday, apparently of food poisoning, and 131 were made ill, according to the executive director of the staterun hospitai.

title: Freed British Currency: Little Gain for Wall St.; Freed British Currency: Little Gain for Wall St.
description: LONDON, Nov. 2  Britain's decision to lift virtually all its foreignexchange controls means more money for Wall Street, but not very much and not very soon.

title: It's Really Up to Mexico
description: DOUGLAS, Ariz.  The illegalalien problem is Mexico's problem. The solution rests squarely upon its Government.

title: U.S. Cuts Off Assistance to Bolivia In Reaction to Takeover by Military
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2  The United States announced today that it was suspending military and economic assistance to Bolivia in response to yesterday's military takeover from the country's first civilian Government in more than a decade.

title: Methodists Rule A Homosexual May Stay Pastor Manhattan Minister Wins in Highest Church Court Homosexual Pastor Retains Post
description: The highest court of the United Methodist Church has ruled that an avowed homosexual, the Rev. Paul Abels, may remain as pastor of the Washington Square Church in New York City.

title: The Poison Organism And How It Can Kill
description: Food poisoning is always a hazard to the elderly, especially those who are in hospitals or other institutions.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yesterday's Weather at I P.M.: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration/UPI

title: Miss Chesimard Flees Jersey Prison, Helped By 3 Armed Visitors Miss Chesimard Escapes in Jersey Continued From Page 1
description: CLINTON, N.J., Nov. 2  Joanne Chesimard, a leader of a militant black group who was serving a life term for the 1973 slaying of a state trooper, escaped from a state women's prison here this afternoon with the help of three armed men.

title: Zoe Fontana, 68, Noted Italian Clothing Designer
description: Zoe Fontana, one of three sisters who were known as the SoreIl Fontana during the heyday of the Italian couture, died of cancer Wednesday at her home in Rome. She was 68 gears old.

title: Bad News From Bolivia
description: An ambitious Bolivian colonel has this week compromised the most promising South American political trend in a generation. Coupprone Bolivia was the obvious weak link in the emerging Andean democratic chain. On Thursday, President Walter Guevara Arze's threemonthold civilian administration fell to rebel soldiers led by Col. Alberto Natusch Busch. Because the coup was opposed by most political parties and Unions and by some of the military, a chance remains to undo part of the damage. The United States and other democratic nations in the hemisphere can help.

title: Dance: A Premiere of Murray Louis's Afternoon
description: There are times when a poorly planned program gives a less favorable Impression of a choreographer than he deserves. One could say this was true Thursday night when the Murray Louis Dance Company opened the new Masters of American Dance series that will run through February at the City Center55th Street Theater.

description: By The Associated Press

description: The Amway Corporation, the company that sells soap and free enterprise from household to household, is still going strong despite its long and wellpublicized squabbles with the Federal Trade Commission.

title: Knicks Rally to Defeat Kings Technical Against Coach
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 2 (AP)Michael Ray Richardson sank a free throw with four seconds left to give the Knicks the lead and then stole the ball to preserve It as New York rallied to beat the Kansas City Kings, 112111, in National Basketball Association action tonight.

title: Koreans Pay Final Tribute to Park at State Funeral
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Saturday, Nov.3  Thousands of Koreans lined the fogshrouded streets of Seoul this morning to pay their final respects to President Park Chung Hee as the body of the 61yearold leader was transported to the national cemetery for burial next to his wife.

title: Swiss Raise Discount Rate to 2%
description: GENEVA, Nov. 2  The Swiss National Bank raised its discount rate to 2 percent today from the 1 percent level at which it had stood for nearly two years. The bank also announced that it was cutting to 2.5 percent from 10 percent the quarterly negative interest, or tax, imposed on the large Swissfranc deposits of nonresident foreigners. The bank said that in raising the discount rate, at which it lends funds to banks, it was following the recent rises in Swiss commercial interest rates and in foreign interest rates.

title: Rate Improves in New York City Labor Force Is Smaller City Rate Not Adjusted Definition Is Challenged
description: The unemployment rate for New York City decreased from 9.5 percent in September to 8 percent in October, the Regional Commissioner of Labor Statistics announced yesterday.

title: Jakarta Shaken by 3 Tremors
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 2 (UPI) Three earth tremors shook Jakarta tonight but no damage or injuries were reported. The tremors occurred in a space of five minutes, jarring highrise buildings in the center of the capital.

title: In Vienna, Das KnowHow Spiel
description: Mornings I shave to the concluding bars of the usual nonstop allnight program  nothing but rock, pop, country, and blues, a swathe of solid Americana from Sinatra to Elvis to Patti Smith. WNEW, New York? Not a bit. Station Oesterreich 3 of Radio Austria. But don't understand Oesterreich 3's obsession too quickly. It is part of an ambiguity I could not escape during my recent stay in Vienna. I had come to study Europe's past and kept stumbling over a wrinkle in its present: The. Americanization of Europe continues breakneck on the surface. Underneath, the process may have come to a milestone of a stop.

title: Books of The Times On Being Special A Story to Envy The Lore of Old Men

title: World News Briefs Security Council Condemns South Africa of Aggression
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 2 (Reuters)  The Security Couricil tonight strongly condemned South Africa for aggression against Angola and called on it to cease all such acts immediately.

title: New Chief Spokesman Named at Justice Dept.
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP)  Robert M. Smith, a lawyer from the San Francisco area, has been named chief spokesman of the Justice Department, Attorney General Benjamin R. CPAletti announced yesterday.

Mrs. Mead was a member of Pilot International and was president of several local chapters. Memorial services will de held at Faith United Church, Tamarac, Fla., on Sunday, Nov. 4, 1979, at 1:30 PM.

title: Lawyers Watching the Scotto Trial Admire Tactics Used by Both Sides; Both Lawyers Well Prepared Lawyers' Moves Explained
description: Every day for weeks now, lawyers with time to spare from other cases have slipped into the seventhfloor room in the United States Courthouse at Foley Square to watch the trial of Anthony M. Scotto, the labor leader accused of taking illegal payoffs.

title: CREDIT MARKETS 15% Prime Becomes General
description: The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company and a number of large regional banks raised their prime lending rates yesterday by onequarter of a percentage point to 15 percent. The prime of most major banks now stands at the record 15 percent level.

title: Hong Kong Authorities Rescue Almost 100 Chinese Immigrants
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 2 (Reuters)  Almost 100 Chinese were rescued from three sinking boats today by police and British Royal Navy vessels combating an invasion of illegal immigrants from the Chinese mainland.

title: A Teletrack for Sports Betting?; Sports of The Times; Extending to Other Sports; Fantasy Tower in Nevada
description: By halftime, the odds on the football game have changed drastically. The favorite is now the underdog, and gamblers watching the action on a 50foothigh screen in the indoor comfort of the Telestadium are studying the new pointspread. Some of them already have begun lining up at the betting windows to place fresh wagers.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article in The Times yesterday misstated Quebec government sovereignty proposal concerning currency and exchange rates. Under the proposal, currency would be issued and exchange rates set by a joint QuebecCandadian monetary authority on which Canada would have a dominant voice because of its economic weight.

title: Music: Berg's Lyric Suite's
description: One of the most gripping musical mystery stories of this century has been unfolding during the last three years. It was discovered in 1978 that Alban Berg's Lyric Suite, which he published as a work for string quartet, existed in another, suppressed, version that dramatized the composer's hopeless love affair with a married woman, Hanna FuchsRobettin. The most outstanding feature of this secret version is the sixth and last movement, the Largo desolato, into which is woven a vocal part whose text is a Stefan George translation of Baudelaire's De Profundis Clamavi, from Fleurs du mal. To have such revelations made about so pivotal a 20thcentury work is roughly as stimulating as learning, say, that Beethoven's last string quartets were based, word for note, on Dante's La vita nuova.

title: Injustice in Two Cities
description: Federal judges in Houston and Philadelphia have just shown, on the same sad day, how courts can hand down judgments that are technically correct yet seem to allow police departments to trample citizens rights.

title: Carter Going to Pennsylvania
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP)  President Carter will visit Philadelphia and Harrisburg, Pa., Nov. 13, Jody Powell, the White House press secretary, said today. He said that Mr. Carter would hold a town meeting in Philadelphia and then attend the state Democrats! JeffersonJackson Day dinner in Harrisburg. He will return to the White House after the dinner.

title: The City; 2 Studio 54 Owners Admit Tax Evasion Wrong Man Shot By Officer in Holdup State Guard Held In Shooting at Bar Drug Program Audit
description: Steven Rubell and Ian Schrager, two of the Studio 54 discothque's three owners, pleaded guilty yesterday to Federal charges of evading personal and corporate income taxes. They face up to 10 years in prison and a $20,000 fine each when they are sentenced on Jan. 18.

description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., Nov. 2  During the summer of 1978, Columbia UniverMty's crosscountry team set a goal to win the 1979 team title in the Heptagonal Games Association championships.

description: VIENNA, Nov. 2 (Reuters)  Six chimpanzees and four lions died in a fire at Vienna's Safari Park last night.

title: Nets Conquer Pacers by 11593 Natt Has a Fine Game
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Nov. 2 It was difficult to imagine the New Jersey Nets sinking to any lower depths than they had in a 37point loss to the Boston Celtics last Wednesday night. Little, short of forfeiting their game tonight against the Indiana Pacers could have made for a more dismal encore.

description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Nov. 2 (AP)Oklahoma voters face the problem next Tuesday of trying to determine whether they will be unwittingly voting themselves a tax increase by passing a proposition aimed at cutting their taxes.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2  Without objection from the White House, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee adopted a declaration today that President Carter may not ratify the strategic arms treaty until he has assured the Senate that Soviet troops in Cuba are not engaged in a combat role.

description: In the intricate horseshow world of conformation, puissance and equitation, the basic method of jumping assumes a pleasing simplicity. The obstacles are there, and horse and rider must make clean leaps over them. No hoofs, hands or bits about it.

description: Juries in Manhattan and the Bronx awarded damages totaling more than $7.8 million in medical malpractice cases yesterday to two Bronx children. They suffered brain damage and were left retarded as a result of admittedly negligent treatment in New York City hospitals.

description: SEOUL, South Korea, Saturday, Nov. 3  Kim Dae Jung, who spent years in prison for his opposition to the late President Park Chung Hee, broke an unofficial moratorium on political activity yesterday by calling for the direct election of a new President and pointedly urged the United States to keep the South Korean military out of the succession process.

description: As cars carrying commuters home for the weekend made their way through the traffic below, a maintenance crew, having finished its workday on the suspension cables over the Manhattan Bridge, slowly worked its way up one of the cables toward the tower on the Brooklyn side of the bridge.

title: AMERICAN EXCHANGE WINS STATE BACKING TO BUILD NEW HOME $53 MILLION PLAN IS APPROVED In Special Session, the Legislature Also Passes Package of Bills on Energy Conservation Amex Deal Called Blackmail $2.57 Million Yearly Rent Home for American Exchange Is Voted Talks With New York Exchange The New York Times/Gary Gold
description: ALBANY, Nov. 2  The State Legislature approved a plan today to build a new $53 million home for the American Stock Exchange at Battery Park City in lower Manhattan. The approval came one year to the day after the board of the stock exchange voted to abandon a search for a new headquarters in New Jersey or Connecticut after receiving assurances that new headquarters would be financed for it in New York City.

description: CONCORD, N.H., Nov. 2  Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., on his first cam= paign swing as a declared Presidential candidate, visited New England today, calling for a stronger military and promising a newbrand of leadership.

title: France's Top Criminal Is Trapped and Killed By 80 Paris Policemen
description: PARIS, Nov. 2 (AP)  Jacques Mesrine, a murderer, robber and kidnapper listed as France's mostwanted criminal, was killed today in a barrage of police gunfire that wounded his mistress. Two grenades were found beside the fugitive.

title: Tribune Posts Higher Results
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 2 (AP)  The Tribune Company, the Chicagobased owner of The Daily News and WPIXTV in New York, yesterday reported record net income and revenues for the third quarter and first nine months. The privately owned Tribune Company is also the parent company of The Chicago Tribune.

description: The wait was supposed to end today for John F. Kennedy High. Two months after every other football team in the Public Schools Athletic League had opened the season, the Bronx school was scheduled to play its first regularseason contest yesterday. And then the rains came.

title: F.B.I. TO AID SEARCH FOR MISS CHESIMARD
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation late yesterday joined the search for Joanne Chesimard, the black militant leader freed from a New Jersey state women's prison Friday afternoon by three men who smuggled handguns into the facility in a carefully timed and executed escape plot.

title: Miss Alcott Golf Victor
description: HANAYASHIKI, Japan, Nov. 3 (AP)  A finalround 67, the lowest score of the 54hole tournament, enabled Amy Alcott to come from three strokes off the pace and win a $125,000 golf tournament,today, the last leg of the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour for 1979.

title: For November, Leatherman and Other Views of Past
description: AS falling leaves remind people of the passing of another season, several events and exhibitions around the county offer reminders of times deeper in the past.

title: U.S. Tops Britain In Tennis
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 3  A determined Tracy Austin evened a personal score against Virginia Wade today and helped the United States win the Wightman Cup for the 41st time. The 40 score in matches makes tomorrow's three concluding matches academic.

title: Oxfam Takes Only One Side The Side of The Hungry
description: OXFORD, England  Thirtyseven years ago, a small group of idealists met in this university town to discuss the plight of children starving in Nazioccupied Greece. Calling themselves the Oxford Committee for Famine Relief (later shortened to Oxfam) they collected $50,000 for food which they channeled through the Greek Red Cross. The campaign was controversial, and the British Government finally ordered it halted until the end of the war, to avoid indirectly helping the German Army.

title: WEST GERMAN ARMY ACCUSED ON MORALE
description: BONN, Nov. 3  The West German Army, widely considered the most capable and efficient in Europe, is described in a new report to the Defense Ministry as increasingly bureaucratic, lacking in soul and divorced from the soldiers in its ranks.

title: Big Ranger Deal: How Players Got News
description: DENVER, Nov. 3  In the van that bumped across Manhattan's West 14th Street in the October darkness, Mike McEwen of the Rangers was talking about being someone else's property. Someone owned him, he said, and he knew that but he didn't care.

title: Graz, an Old Imperial Town in the Green Heart of Austria
description: Austria's secondlargest city, Graz, calls itself the Town of Hidden Beauty for what lies within its nearly 1,000 historically preserved medieval homes and 90 arcaded courtyards. But Graz itself is a hidden treasure second to none: an imperial city blessed and then bypassed by history, fashion and tourism. With a population of 250,000 (onesixth of Vienna's), Graz has seven Gothic churches, an equal number of plague columns thanking Jesus for sparing the survivors and an inner city so well sealed off to autos that it must be explored on foot.

title: Fighting the Chill By Force of Will
description: THE chill and snow arrived in southern Connecticut very early this fall. Too early. The oil delivery truck slipped into our driveway at 7 A.M., two days after the temperatures dipped to 35 degrees.

description: The stock market moved ahead last week as the Dow Jones industrial average rose 9.64 points to 818.94.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE

The first of a series of Conversations on Art, led by Janet Saleh Dickson, curator of education, is to be held at 10:30 A.M. Saturday in the Sculpture Hall, and will deal with how museum functions.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: THE Parks Department in Hartford seems right up there with the oil companies when it comes to price increases fit for a sheik. Some golf fees at the two city courses will be going up a cool 1,150 percent. And if that's staggering, consider that the super increase will affect only the elderly.

description: BOSTON, Nov. 3 (AP)  Black and white members of the New England Patriots yesterday went into the classrooms to talk with high school students and teach them a lesson in getting along with each other.

title: Homer of Braves Signs 3Year Pact, Ends Dispute
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 3 (AP)  The Atlanta Braves announced today that Bob Horner, their third baseman, has signed a threeyear contract with the National League team, completing negotiations that started during the season.

title: PILOT ERROR IS SEEN IN MEXICO JET CRASH
description: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 3 (UPI)  Pilot error and not improper lighting of runways apparently was responsible for the fatal crash of a Western Airlines DC10 jet at the Mexico City airport, a high official of the United States Federal Aviation Administration in Mexico said today.

title: In the Year of the Child, Series Is Not for the Kids
description: ON a midJuly evening less than four months ago, Bowie Kuhn stood at home plate in the Kingdome prior to the AllStar Game in Seattle and decreed the contest to follow be dedicated to America's youth in this Year of the Child. After all, said the commissioner, baseball belongs to the children. Apparently the ABC network and Howard Cosell do not subscribe to Kuhn's public declaration, and judging by subsequent events, neither does Kuhn himself.

title: Youthful Knicks Rising
description: Most National Basketball Association general managers and coaches do not care to have the fans voting for the AllStar teams. They feel the fans treat it like a popularity contest.

title: Philippine Rebels Hijack Boat
description: MANILA, Nov. 3 (UPI)  Moslem rebels have hijacked a boat in the southern Philippines and have demanded an undisclosed ransom for six hostages, the military announced today. It was the second such hijacking by the insurgents in a week.

title: On Language
description: Not long ago, I advertised for perverse rules of grammar, along the lines of Remember to never split an infinitive and The passive voice should never be used.

title: Chamber: Premiere of Schuller's Octet
description: Add Gunther Schuller to the list of composers in flight from yesterday's avantgarde. title: Germans Find Old British Bomb
description: BREMEN, West Germany, Nov. 3 (Reuters)  About 3,000 people were evacuated from their homes today while bombdisposal experts defused a British World War II bomb found on a Bremen industrial site, the police said.

title: SelfDefense Against Crime Is Growing in France
description: PARIS, Nov. 3  Three years ago Lionel Legras got fed up. He owns an auto repair shop in Barbuise, near Carcassonne in the south of France, that had been burglarized 11 times and no one had been caught.

title: Best Sellers
description: This Week

title: Dining Out With Boris in Katmandu
description: Boris Lissanevitch, a colorful Russianborn restaurateur and hotel keeper who helped bring tourism to Katmandu 27 years ago, has opened a new restaurant in the Nepalese capital.

title: Racial Issue Clouds Sale of Roslyn Church
description: ROSLYN HEIGHTS SOME people say the Roslyn United Methodists reneged on selling their church to the Assembly Prayer Baptists for financial reasons; others say was because the Baptists are black.

title: New Brunswick Tomorrow: It Won't Happen Overnight
description: LEST New Brunswick be mistaken for another city, readers of this newspaper deserve the full story about the dynamic process of economic, physical and social revitalization now going on in that cornmunity.

title: Tomato Wars: Mexico Wins One
description: In a move that could at once bolster United StatesMexican relations and keep winter food prices down, the Treasury Department ruled last week that Mexico was not, as charged, selling tomatoes and other produce in this country at unfairly low prices.

title: Digital Recording Techniques Are Already Being Widely Used in Pop Music
description: LOS ANGELES  Digital records, the first radical change in the basic method of sound recording since the advent of the electrical process in 1925, have begun to appear in the marketplace, albeit in a notyetpure form. And unlike most previous highfidelity innovations, which have been pioneered by audiophiles and Classicalmusic lovers, digital recording is already being used extensively in Los Angeles, which boasts the greatest concentration of sophisticated popmusic studios in the world.

title: PILGRIMAGE TO THE COUNTRY OF NIGHT
description: The beginning, the end: AlI the world's roads, all the outcries of mankind, lead to this haunted place unlike any other. Here is the kingdom of night. where God'sface is hidden and a flaming sky becomes an accursed graveyard for a vanished people.

title: Rebecca Westover Married to Banker
description: Rebecca Lynn Westover, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Charles Barry Westover of Erie, Pa., and James Joseph McAndrews Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. McAndrews of Madison, Conn., were married yesterday. The Rev. Robert Goodill performed the ceremony in St. Luke's Roman Catholic Church in Erie.

title: MUSIC  From Philharmonia To Preservation Hall
description: FOR most regional orchestras, attempting a purely symphonic program one without an audienceattracting soloist  could be boxoffice suicide. We will see what happens when the Greenwich Philharmonia tries it at its next pair of concerts, but our hunch is that the audience will come and be satisfied as usual.

title: Midwood Surfaces as a Victor
description: Midwood had two things that held up against the rain yesterday. Astroturf and a superb defense.

title: Local Leaders Stump for India Premier Candidates
description: MADRAS, India, Oct. 27 With parliamentary elections still two months away, the question of whether to support Indira Gandhi or Jagjivan Ram is still distant to the voters in much of India. But for the 20 million voters in the maverick southern state of Tamil Nadu, of which Madras is the capital, a fierce debate has started on who will be prime minister.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Traditionally Election Day is last call for planting bulbs. . . . Speed up any planting projects so roots have a start before cold weather. . . . Established plantings should not be winter mulched: it is much too early. . . . Keepafter leaves; if there are too many, put them through a chipper before composting for quicker breakdown by spring. . . . All patio tubs pots, planters and window boxes should be cleaned and moved into storage.

title: Food
description: Shanks, whether they be beef, veal or pork, have a tenderness, a gelatinous texture that makes them, to some palates, far superior to the more luxurious cuts of meat such as tenderloins, fillets and the like. Shanks, too, are exceptionally easy to cook. Otherthan an occasional basting, they require little attention once they are placed in the oven. The flavors of these three recipes for shank dishes are all influenced by herbs basil, mint and parsley  and offer a delightful change of pace in winter dining.

title: Notre Dame Outlasts Navy, 140
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 3 (AP) Vagas Ferguson scored from the 3yard line in the fourth quarter to secure Notre Dame's hardfought 140 victory over Navy today.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Birgit Nilsson will be singing at the Metropolitan Opera tonight  but not in opera. The great soprano has returned to the United States, and the occasion is being honoredwith a gala benefit concert. Miss Nilsson will, of course, sing Wagner, but also on the program is thefinal scene from Strauss's Salome. Who will ever forget the concert version of Salome that she sang some years ago with Georg Solti and the Chicago Symphony? It was one of the great performances of the generation.

title: Tillie Mehler, 83, Leader In Jewish Charities, Dies
description: Tillie H. Mehler, a New York City resident long active in Jewish charitable organizations, died yesterday at her home in Manhattan after a long illness. She was 83 years old.

title: DINING OUT A Taste of Italy in Blairstown; **Alfonso's Spring Valley Inn
description: ONE would expect to find a new Italian restaurant in an easily accessible and densely populated area. But Alfonso's Spring Valley Inn, which opened only six months ago, is tucked away on a quiet country road in Blairstown.

title: Tracing the Roots Of Choral Music
description: Choral singing is an integral part of our modemday concert life, rooted deeply in the congregational singing of the Protestant Reformation. But although Luther was an especially fervent proponent of the bonds between God and song, he was hardly the firstreligious leader to countenance and encourage music as part of religious ceremony.

title: ANTIQUES In Flemington, A Touch of Glass
description: FLEMINGTON LOUIS IORIO, who will be 100 years old on Nov. 22, has lived to see the brilliant stonecut glass he made at the turn of the century become highly prized. In his lifetime, Mr. Iorio has turned out a vast number of pieces, using 4,600 patterns. Abouthalf were of his own design, and many are listed in catalogues simply as Iorio.

title: CAPITAL REPORT
description: TWO of New Jersey's top labor leaders are engaged in what may develop into a knockdown and dragout battle for the presidency of the State A.F.L.C.I.O., an association of labor unions with strong political influence.

title: A Person Used to Work Cannot Go Around Idle
description: The following article was written by Shlomo Fleshier, an 87yearold patient at the Workmen's Circle Home for the Aged in Elizabeth, and appeared in the mimeographed Workmen's Circle Home News, which is distributed to patients and their relatives. It is used by permission of Mr. Fleshier and the Workmen's Circle. Gertrude Dubrovsky translated it from the Yiddish.

title: A Businessman Who Planned for Future Needs
description: THOMAS ARMOUR was the first and, until a few years ago, the only black nursinghome administrator in New Jersey. Now two of his sisters are also licensed as administrators and work for him.

title: Nuclear Power Debated at State P.T.A.
description: EAST HARTFORD WHEN they mentioned Scholastic Aptitude Tests, I thought it would be an issue that should be presented to the public, said NancyCiarleglio, explaining how the Connecticut ParentTeacher Association, to the surprise of most members, got involved at its annual convention last weekend in a debate on nuclear power.

title: Sunday Observer The Plumbers of Wampum
description: By October's end the last of the Gucci classes who infest the historic old island of Wampum all summer have picked up their yachts and gone South, and a strange peace settles over the ancient whaling port of Wampumburg as the hardy islanders button down for another historic old winter.

title: Man Sets Token Booth Afire, but Holdup Is Foiled
description: A holdup man poured gasoline into the change slot of an IRT token booth In the Bronx early yesterday morning, set it afire and then fled emptyhanded as flames flared harmlessly over the face of the booth.

title: Compensation Law
description: TRENTON IN THE coming year, about 275,000 New Jersey workers will be injured on the job or develop jobrelated disabilities that will prevent them from working for a time or cause them considerable pain and discomfort. Some will be killed in accidents and some will die from their injuries.

title: Anne Bailey Plans Bridal on March 15
description: Mr. and Mrs. Francis W. Bailey of Fairfield, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anne Gilbert Bailey, to Maurice Jackson Hoover 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hoover Jr. of Darien, Conn.

title: Far Away From It All In the Dry Tortugas
description: The taxi driver dropped us off at the edge of Key West at a small gray dock stenciled InterIsland Air. There was no one in sight, raising one more doubt about whether we my wife, Julie, our 5yearold daughter, Kelly, and I  should ever have planned a winter camping trip on Garden Key, in the isolated chain of seven tiny islands called the Dry Tortugas.

title: Music: AvantGarde Solo By Curran at the Kitchen
description: Alvin Curran's solo concert Wednesday at the Kitchen, the second of two consecutive evenings there, was not only very alluring, but it also amounted to almost a textbook study in how socalled minimalism can grow into something rich and complex.

title: Italian Wine Growers Hope Crop Improves Image
description: MERCANTALE, Italy, Oct. 29  The harvest is over in the Chianti region. This morning at the Castello di Gabbiano, the last cartload of black grapes were tossed into a stainless steel trough and caught by a rotating spiral, disappearing into the big cylindrical press.

title: Owen Evans Is Fianc Of Patricia Ellen Stack
description: Mr. and Mrs. William J. Stack of Riverdale, the Bronx, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Ellen Stack, to Owen James Evans, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic J. Evans of Sydney, Australia.

title: TV VIEW
description: Tonight on national public television, there will be a 90minute documentary called Home (it can be seen on Channel 13 at 10 P.M.). Produced by Julie Gustafson and John Reilly over 16 months, the program presents four families struggling to define important events in their own lives at a time when institutions appear to be taking over the responsibilities of thetraditional family. The Birth of a Child segment shows couple who choose to go to an outofhospital maternity center where midwives are as important as the doctor. Growing Old is about a 94yearold woman trying to adjust to life in a nursing home. Marriage features a black man and woman, both in their 30's, deciding to give their relationship the symbol of a formal marriage. And Death of a Parent is constructed around the efforts of a son to have his terminallyill mother die comfortably at home instead of at a hospital or nursing home. Each segment, combining cinmavrit techniques with unobtrusive questions from the producers, is beautifully realized. The cumulative effect extremely moving.

title: FILM VIEW
description: The rise of no other civilization on earth has been as thoroughly documented as that of this country. By a coincidence of history, America approached the peak of its power at a time when there were cameras everywhere, ready to record virtually everything  thefantasies and obsessions, which became our fiction films, as well as the events, public and private, which are the stuff of motion picture journalism. The amount of filmed material is now so vast that it's virtually impossible to comprehend, which is why, perhaps, most cinematic attempts to make sense of our film heritage have always been rather superficial.

title: The City Has a Long Way to Go On Fiscal Problems, G.A.O. Says
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2  The General Accounting Office said today in a formal report that New York City still has a long way to go in dealing with its financial problems, but it modified some of the harsher criticism that it had made in the report's first draft.

title: Seesaw in Madison
description: MADISON PAUL BARRY should act more often. Usually directing plays for the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival at Drew University  and now guiding his own paces and pauses in the festival's revival of Two for the Seesaw  he is sensitive player who makes the most of his silences.

title: Uneasily, Congress Takes A Back Seat on Economy
description: WASHINGTON  To most outward appearances, the Federal Government's economic policy is mostly in the hands of Paul A. Volcker, the chairman of the Federal Reserve.

title: Trekking Through the Outback
description: Adventuretravel enthusiasts are being given an opportunity to follow in the footsteps of an expedition that made the first exploration across the Australian continent from south to north 119 years ago. They can doso this winter  during Australia's summer  by riding in fourwheeldrive vans on a series of 16day safaris through the Outback organized by a Melbourne company.

title: Garden City Improvement Not Enough
description: Last season, Garden City suffered its most humiliating defeat when it bowed to Bethpage, 560. Yesterday, the schools met again, and Garden City stayed close but failed to gain its revenge and also lost its first game of the season.

title: R. P. Casey Fianc Of Jane E. Ferelle
description: Mr. and Mrs. Conrad Ferelle of Muttontown and Westhampton Beach, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jane Elizabeth Ferelle, to Robert Peter Casey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Casey of Woodside, Oueens.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: Recent Openings Cuchulain, the Warrior King

title: Yanks Go For May, Watson
description: Acting with blitzlike speed at the end of a whirlwind week, the New York Yankees zeroed in on Bob Watson and Rudy May yesterday and, sources familiar with their efforts said, seemed convinced they would sign both free agents.

title: Urbanism
description: BiggerBetterBusier was once the ethic of the nation, reflecting the frontier conviction that growth was intrinsically good. Today that clich is seldom heard, and then only sotto voce and with qualifications. Communities by the hundreds from coast to coast have adopted growth controls, and more are constantly doing so.

title: For Recovered Alcoholics, the Job's the Thing
description: Sue is a 45yearold former switchboard operator from the Bronx who was fired from her job in 1973 because of alcoholism. During her drinking years, she said, she consumed a quart of Scotch and four quarts of beer a day and tried to commit suicide twice. withoverdoses of drugs that she called ups, downs and Valiums.

title: Mailbox: Lessons of Hockey's Violence
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Notes
description: A massive cleanup operation is continuing in the Caribbean where islands that were battered by Hurricanes David and Frederic are attempting to repair all the damage in time for the start of their winter tourist season next month.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: I too, like Mel Rabinowitz, was a temporary commuter of the L.I.R.R., although I commuted for eight weeks, rather than one day [After One Ride, I Love the L.I.R.R., Opinion Page, Oct. 14]. Mr. Rabinowitz was very lucky that his train came in on time and that he got a seat. However, he did not go in on the rushhour trains, but those later on, and in returning home, he left earlier than most.

title: Louisiana Conviction for Murder Is Rejected Over Insanity Issue
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 3 (AP)  The State Supreme Court has reversed the conviction of Carlos R. Poree on murder charges stemming from a shooting rampage here on Nov. 7, 1977, that left one person dead and nine others wounded.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Business Editor:

title: British Group Seeking To Revise Track Rules
description: LONDON, Nov. 3 (AP)  The British Amateur Athletic Association called today for an urgent revision of its rules after reports that fourfigure payments were being made to track and field stars.

title: Weicker vs. Moffett on Oil Prices
description: REPRESENTATIVE Anthony Toby Moffett has offered to serve as the whipping boy of Senator Lowell P. Welcker Jr., if that will help the maverick Connecticut Republican score points within his own party.

title: Proposition 1 Decision Is Near
description: AFTER three years of discussion, study and debate  and many weeks of intensive campaigning by both sides County Proposition County Proposition 1 has finally come down to the wire.

title: Beauty SHOPPING AROUND FOR SHAMPOOS
description: The question of which shampoo to use is the one that I am asked most frequently, says New York hairdresser Suga. Every head of hair reacts differently to different shampoos, so I can never give a client a specific answer. Whatever feels best,smells best, gives the most shine and manageability is the one that's right for you.

title: Pack Struggles to Regain Glory
description: GREEN BAY, Wis., Nov. 3  Yes, Bart Starr admits, We are suffering now. And when the Green Bay Packers suffer, not merely a team is involved.

title: Mayoral Races Heat Up at End
description: WHITE PLAINS THE mayoral campaigns in the county's three biggest cities have heated up in the last few weeks, with the incumbent Mayors of Yonkers and Mount Vernon engaged in difficult battles for reelection and the candidates in New Rochelle involved in a race that political observers say is a tossup.

title: A New Home For the Amex?
description: For years the American Stock exchange, resentful of the heavy city tax burden on securities transactions, has been making noises about moving away from New York. Perhaps evenlonger, the developers of a huge 91acre plot of landfill nearby, off Battery Park, have been trying to find financing to build a multiuse development there called Battery Park City. Last week there were government attempts to help resolve the problems of both.

title: Members of Moon Church Attend Leading Colleges
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  Thirtyeight members of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon's Unification Church are attending leading divinity and graduate schools in the United States as the church attempts to develop its own educators for the next generation.

title: The Drug Game Threatens International Amateur Sport
description: THE defection of a former East German world recordholder in swimming and the recent suspensions of seven Eastern European women track and field athletes for anabolic steroid violations are the latest examples the highpowered drug game that threatens international sport.

title: 76ers 120, Pacers 114
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 3 (UPI) Julius Erving scored 33 points to lead the Philadelphia 76ers to a 120114 doubleovertime victory over the Indiana Pacers tonight.

title: GARDENING The Apple's Evolution: From Eden to Now
description: IF Eve did indeed tempt Adam with an apple, is it any wonder that he gave in to such enticement?

title: VIOLENT CRIMES UP IN JERSEY SUBURBS
description: MATAWAN, N.J.  A report by the Federal Bureau of Investigation of an increase in crime nationally comes as no surprise to western Monmouth County. In the last year, there has been a crime explosion here, as in hundreds of New Jersey suburbs  much of it committed by juveniles, according to police officials.

title: GO P. INTEREST STIRS MAYOR RACE IN UTAH
description: SALT LAKE. CITY, Nov. 1 Salt Lake City would seem, on the face of it, an unlikely spot for the Republican National Committee to invest time, money and staff in trying to defeat a Mayor who is, after all, relatively unknown outside the state.

title: Backgammon:
description: Often in backgammon the advantage changes hands suddenly. Indeed, every backgammon player can recall situations in which a sound game plan was destroyedby a single unfortunate roll. Such disasters, however, can sometimes be averted by foresight and skillful play.

title: Irving Shapiro's Heir Apparent
description: WILMINGTON, Del.  When Edward G. Jefferson was about to receive his doctorate degree from the University of London, a recruiter from Du Pont offered him a job in the United States. I thought it might be a valuable experience, so I decided I'd come over for a year or two, recalled Mr. Jefferson in a recent interview.

title: Dredging Delayed At Moriches Inlet
description: WORK on a Federal dredging project at Moriches Inlet that has broad support in South Shore communities has been put off because of delays in drawing up a plan to remove sand that has piled up dangerous shoals in the navigational channel.

title: N.F.L. Gypsies Wait by Phone
description: Jack Deloplaine's Pittsburgh telephone number is on file in the personnel departments of every National Football League team. Why? Because Deloplaine is a usable running back, good on the special kick teams, and someone who has played for the winning side in a Super Bowl game.

title: Israeli Archeologists Race Air Base Construction Crews in Negev
description: IN THE NEGEV, Israel  It was a small formation of stones, a crude rectangle high on a ridge in the empty desert. No one had touched them since the Bronze Age. They had lain for thousands of years undisturbed except by incessant wind and the drift of dusty sand.

title: Justice Dept. Organizes Unit on Hazardous Wastes
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3  The Justice Department has created a new unit to handle prosecutions involving hazardous wastes, and its recently appointed chief said the department would seek to legally compel major chemical companies to pay for cleanup operations.

title: Births
description: BERNSTEIN

title: Editors Choice
description: CANNIBALS AND MISSIONARIES, by Mary McCarthy. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $10.95.) A plane filled with liberals and art collectors, on their way to the Shah's Iran for their particular purposes, is hijacked by terror ists: a novelistsocial critic assesses the temper of our times.

title: A CETA Official Defends Graduates
description: BUSINESS and industry in Connecticut undoubtedly face problems in the recruiting and hiring of skilled and semiskilled personnel, but I cannot let the remarks on that subject by Fred T. Allen, president and chairman of Pitney Bowes, go unchallenged.

title: A Normal Year
description: IKE an everswelling mob of Americans, write short stories. Like an even vaster mob, I seldom read them. And my greason is typical: they're short.

title: ON THE ISLE
description: Today

title: G.S. Mittendorf 2d Weds Sarah Rentschler
description: Sarah Yorke Rentschler of New York, daughter of Mrs. George W. Thompson of Batavia, Ill., and William H. Rentschler of Lake Forest, Ill., was married yesterday afternoon to George.

title: A Lesson From Nuns May Pay Off in China
description: ALFRED J. ROACH can sum up his philosophy of life in a few words: Nothing in the world can take the place of persistence. He has these words framed and hanging in his office of T.I.I. Industries in Lindenhurst, and no matter what he is talking about, he seems to come back to this thought.

title: Radio
description: Today: Leading Events

title: Janet Lindholm Married to Peter Lebovitz
description: Janet Louise Lindholm and Peter Michael Lebovitz were married yesterday by the Rev. Winthrop E. Stone in the. First Congregational Church in Madison, Conn.

title: BAKER: THE COOL CANDIDATE
description: A cold Feb. 12 in Springfield, Ill. The nation's highestranking elected Republican official is standing in Lincoln's Tomb patiently enduring endless tributes to his party's most famous leader. Finally. after all the dignitarieshave been introduced and each has carried a plastic wreath to the front of the sleek marble catafalque, Howard Henry Baker Jr. steps to the microphone. Trying as he does to give every word the ring of instant history, he invokes the memory of Lincoln. He was a great custodian of the heritage of his forefathers and we are his legatees, says Senator Baker in confident, honeyed tones.

title: Politics and Jobs: Chrysler Corporation's $1.5 Billion Bailout
description: The Carter Administration, weighing the political dangers of massive unemployment in the wake of a bankrupt Chrysler Corporation, decided last week to support a $1.5 billion Federal loan guarantee for the nation's thirdlargest auto producer.

title: Martha Jane Wakeman Affianced to Robert Proctor 3d
description: Mr. and Mrs. Norman B. WakeMan of Darien, Conn., and San Antonio have announced the engagment of their daughter, Martha Jane Wakeman of Florence, to Dr. Robert Emmet Proctor 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Proctor of Los Angeles.

title: Kennedy, at Rally in Buffalo, Asks Carter to Get Tough on Oil Tax Bill
description: BUFFALO, Nov. 3  Senator Edward M. Kennedy, broadening his attacks on Administration policies, called on President Carter today to threaten to veto any windfall profits tax bill and to reimpose oil price controls unless the tax captured at least half of the new revenues resulting from decontrol.

title: Nets Beaten by Hawks, 110107
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 3  Rich Kelley sat on a locker room bench looking more like the loser in a 15round fight than survivor of the New Jersey Nets 110107 loss to the Atlanta Hawks tonight. A handful of ice, packed in a plastic bag, rested against the rightcorner of his mouth. His hair, still damp, was matted around the areas where he had received over a dozen stitches at halftime.

title: POLITICS
description: WHEN President Carter came to New Jersey late last month, his reception by the state's Democrats was notable for its restraint.

title: 66Nation Study Points to a Surge In BombGrade Nuclear Materials
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3  An enormous expansion in the number of nuclear power plants in the industrialized and developing countries in the next 20 years will result in a dramatic, unavoidable increase in available supplies of bombgrade nuclear material, according to a report by an international study group.

title: Developers Think It's Time for the Supermalls
description: THE era of vast covered shopping malls  with several major department stores, large numbers of specialty stores and such special Saturday diversions as karate exhibitions or crafts displays  seems about to arrive in Connecticut.

title: Rutgers Upsets Vols
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 3 (AP) Ed McMichael threw a 37yard touchdown pass to David Dorn and Kennan Startzell booted two secondhalf field goals as Rutgers came from behind to upset Tennessee, 137. today.

title: SHOP TALK A Mall Within a Mall
description: BAY SHORE CAPTREE CORNERS is a distinctive minimall within the larger South Shore mall on Sunrise Highway. It is set aside in a section of the mall sequestered from the main area of clothing and shoe stores. The concept alone isinteresting because it gives shoppers a break from the larger mall, providing a place to eat or just sit down and relax. It also houses the most interesting specialty shops in the complex.

title: Politics Charged In Pinelands Plan
description: TOMS RIVER CAMPAIGN contributions in two suthern New Jersey legislative races came from companies that may have benefited from the state's program of pinelands preservation, according to official campaignfinancing lists on file in Trenton.

title: Boat Donations Becoming Sporting Notion
description: The harbors and coves in the region should be nearly barren in another two weeks as boatyards shift into high gear in hauling craft out of the waters for the winter.

title: Democrats on Board Facing a Tough Reelection Battle
description: TWO years ago, the last time the Board of Legislators faced an election, hopes were high among Democrats that they could reverse a 9to8 Republican majority and take control of the county's top legislative body. The Democrats lost a seat, however, and this year they appear to be in danger of losing even more.

title: Around the Nation
description: ERWIN, Tenn., Nov. 3 (AP) A 45day inventory has failed to turn up at least 19.8 pounds of weaponsgrade uranium that cannot be accounted for at a nuclear fuel plant in East Tennessee, according to officials.

title: The World
description: A colleague in Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party once described Masayoshi Ohira as a man who had a knack for avoiding controversy. If that was accurate then, Mr. Ohira has changed. Because he has declined to do what critics have urged him to dostep aside as Prime Minister because of the Liberal Democrats poor showing in last month's elections  the party that has ruled Japan since 1955 was without a leader last week.

title: STAMPS
description: Within the span of a week two events that had a profound impact on the spirit of the American people and, more so, the men who took part in these events, are being recalled with expressions of philatelic tribute.

title: The Frontier Style Clings To the Police In Houston
description: HOUSTON  For nearly three years, no single issue has more bedeviled and divided Houston than the conduct of its police department. Once again, the force is the most controversial topic in town, and, with municipal elections on Tuesday that will give the city's minorities a new influence in city government, the hottest political issue as well.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The Brasher doubloon is widely thought of as the world's most valuable coin because of the recent midsummer auction during which one of the seven known examples brought a record price of $430,000. Knowledgeablenumismatists say this is a misconception, because that record only takes into account coins sold at public auction.

title: CHESS
description: There are only two things to do about a sharp, heavily analyzed variation  either come to the board prepared with an innovation that forces the game in your favor, or divert the play into a quiet positional one with the hope of outplaying the opponent in a fairly level middle game.

title: Layoffs Imminent at Big Massachusetts Shipyard
description: QUINCY, Mass., Nov. 27 (AP)  The Hardcastles have put off plans for children; Dave Nadeau says his wife is looking for work, and the Merreys face the prospect of replacing two paychecks.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: TOWNSEND MUNSON

title: Authors' Queries
description: For a history of the B'nal B'rith Hillel Foundations on American and foreign campuses, I would appreciate hearing from any persons whose experiences, memorabilia or involvement (personal or tangential) might enrich the content of the book in preparation.

title: Bomb Kills Farmhand in Portugal In Area Marked by Land Disputes
description: EVORA, Portugal, Nov. 3 (Reuters)A farm worker was killed today when a bomb exploded near Evora, in the Alentejo wheat belt, the police said. It was the first death in a series of bombings in southcentral Portugal.

title: Bergen Catholic Routs Kearny to Stay Unbeaten
description: Steve Pacicco and Mike Amatrula rushed for two touchdowns each yesterday to pace unbeaten Bergen Catholic (701), one of New Jersey's top teams, to a 328 victory over Kearny at Kearny.

title: Hypertension Plan
description: Asixyear campaign to persuade the public that high blood pressure is a treatable condition is having results in Westchester, according to Dr. Marvin Moser, a White Plains cardiologist who is a consultant to a national education program on hypertension.

title: Group of Boat Owners To Run Basin as City Acts to Oust Operator
description: Calling the corporate operator of the 79th Street marina an absentee slumlord that had allowed the boat basin to deteriorate and had absolutely refused to make critical repairs, Parks Commissioner Gordon J. Davis moved this weekend to terminate the operator's concession agreement.

title: The Region
description: For a smart politician, Gov. Hugh L. Carey certainly seems to have been left out in the cold on the question of heating fuel. Last week, after the first day of the special legislative session he had called to deal with the matter, the Governor was faced with a distasteful choice between vetoing a bill to give heating aid to middleincome homeowners or signing it and seeing his budget endangered.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Elizabeth Dugdale To Be Wed Dec. 15
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward W. McGill of New York have announced the engagement of Mrs. McGill's daughter, Elizabeth Anne Dugdale, to Forrest R. Old Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Old of Grosse Pointe. Mich.. and Naples. Fla. Thecouple plan to be married Dec. 15 by the Rev. Dr. William Sloane Coffin in Christ Chapel of the Riverside Church.

title: Death and Taxes
description: ROMANS is a little town in the Dauphin province of southern France. In 1580, its annual carnival exploded into a tax revolt, which was repressed with the slaughter of over a thousand people. Emmanuel LeRoy Ladurie's new book is about two evertopical subjects: tax revolt and carnival.

title: Merchant Marine Finally Wins
description: The United States Merchant Marine Academy routed New York Tech, 287, yesterday at Kings Point, L.I., to snap its seasonlong losing streak at eight Rames.BETHLEHEM, Pa., Nov. 3 (AP) Dave Darro recovered an enemy fumble and Bruce Rarig blocked a punt, helping Lehigh defeat C.W. Post today, 170.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yesterday's Weather at 1 P.M.: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration/UPI

title: The Next Three Mile Island
description: Who can forget the apprehension that gripped the nation as the events at Three Mile Island unfolded last March? At movie theaters around the country, The China Syndrome was depicting a neardisaster at nuclear plant. Then. suddenly, it came to life.

title: Insect Man's Life: Web of Queries
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 3 (AP)  The requests that Charles A. Triplehorn receives for insect identifications range from trivial to some involving high economic stakes. One request provided the key to solving a murder.

title: Fashion DRESSING  UP EASE
description: Dressing up for going out can involve anything from a simple switch of sweater or blouse for a meal around the corner to an allstopspulledout effort for a grand soiree.

title: Irvington Streak Is Halted at 16
description: Westchester County's longest winning streak was ended at 16 yesterday as Byram Hills upset Irvington by 2115. With the game tied, 77, after the first quarter, Byram Hills went ahead to stay when Scott Sipple hit Richie Doetsch with a 39yard touchdownpass. Doetsch also scored on an 85yard kickoff return and Bob Minicus had a 70yard run for the Bobcats. Irvington's touchdowns came on a 40yard run by Colby Collier and a quarterback sneak by Greg Gizzi.

title: Pater $ familias
description: I am a 30yearold writer and editor, and my earnings this year will be about $30.000. Not bad, you say.

title: 2 Years More for Vista Approved by Conferees
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP)  House and Senate negotiators have agreed to keep the Volunteers in Service to America going for two more years. But they did not say how much money there would be.

title: New U.S. Parking Rule Makes Employees Pay
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (UPI)  Federal employees are now required to pay half the commercial rate for parking spaces t hat many used to get free.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Newburgh Revives Victorian Homes
description: NEWBURGH, N.Y.  When Brian Thompson first visited here about four years ago, he could not believe his eyes. In the middle of slums he saw what was to him an incredible stock of some of the finest Victorian houses in the U.S.A. They were cheap, and he started buying.

title: Study Reports Average Doctor In U.S. Worked 50.3 Hours in 78
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 3 (AP)  The American Medical Association's Profile of Medical Practice, 1979, reports that most doctors work longer than the standard 40hour work week.

title: Houston Topples T. C. U.
description: FORT WORTH, Nov. 3 (AP)  Houston used the passing of Delrick Brown and the running of Terald Clark to score two fourthquarter touchdowns gain a 2110 Southwest Conference victory over Texas Christian today.

title: Senior Group Fights for Housing Status
description: ABUSLOAD of senior citizens from Norwalk and Stamford plan to travel to Hartford tomorrow to try to avert action by the Connecticut Commission on Human Rights and Opportunities that they fear could end their special status as tenants in the condominium apartments in which they live.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS Australia and the U.S.
description: SYDNEY, Australia  For most of its history, Australia has been haunted by fears of invasion  that its open spaces and, more recently, its great mineral wealth, would one day prove irresistible to a determined outsider.In the last century, these fears fixated on the Chinese, Russians and Germans; in this, on the Japanese.

title: Economic Impact of Chrysler On State
description: WASHINGTON, D.C. CONNECTICUT has a $129 million stake in whether the troubled Chrysler Corporation survives.

title: PEGASUS SATELLITE SPLASHES IN OCEAN
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (UPI)  The United States Pegasus 2 satellite made fiery reentry into the Earth's atmosphere today and splashed down harmlessly into the trackless midAtlantic Ocean, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced.

title: Denise Durling Is Betrothed To Mark Winslow Biedron
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Carlton C. Durling of Whitehouse and Montoloking, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Denise Terry Durling, to Mark WinslowBiedron, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Biedron of Watchung, N.J., and Mantoloking.

title: The Region
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I.  Building a bridge across Long Island Sound is an idea that refuses to die, thanks to a group of Long Island business and labor leaders who feel the Island is a dead end and that building a bridge would be casting a lifeline to the mainland.

title: MERITAWARD PLAN BEGINS IN NEW YORK
description: Ward Attendant Jones, a quick and efficient worker at a state hospital, never fails to have a kind word for his patients and coworkers. His colleague, Ward Attendant Smith, rarely gets her work done on time and has a dour disposition.

title: News Summary
description: SUNDAY, NOVEMBER 4, 1979

title: HOME CLINIC Saving WaterHeating Energy
description: SINCE water heaters are second only to home heating systems as the largest user of energy in most homes in this area, anything that can be done to cut down on the energy a water heater consumes is usually worth looking into. There areactually three steps that can be taken to lower the cost of providing hot water:

title: Dispute Threatens Pinelands Program
description: WASHINGTON THE Federalstatelocal plan approved by Congress last year to protect South Jersey's vast Pine Barrens as a national reserve of wilderness, forests, bogs and pure waterways risks being mired in bitter dispute over which comes first: regulation or planning?

title: Garage Casts a Shadow on Renewal
description: GLEN COVE SHEETS of water spill cleanly and brightly over the futuristic stainless steel fountain in the heart of this city's pleasant new shopping plaza, but merchants and customers in the small boutiques and restaurants are expressing concern that the center's ambiance is being overshadowed by an unpopular municipal parking garage. The massive newly constructed cementparking facility has become a symbol of discontent in this North Shore community, which is in the midst of a struggle to complete the renewal of its downtown area in anelection year marked by inflation, recession and public resistance to government spending.

title: Connecticut /This Week
description: BRIDGEPORT  On Location in Vermont: paintings by Sandra Carron, Joyce Gilbert, Susan Sharp, Florence Zolan, through Nov. 15, Jewish Community Center, 4200 Park Ave., daily except Saturday 9 A.M. to 10 P.M., Friday to 4 P.M. Reception today 2 to 4.3726567.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: The sounds of Renaissance Italy will fill Reisinger Auditorium at Sarah Lawrence College in Bronxville today at 4 P.M. The school's quartetinresidence, known as Music for A While, willperform instrumental and vocal works from the Ars Nova period on their recorders, krummhorns, rebecs, violas da gambas and other early instruments.

title: His Town Hails 100th Birthday Of Will Rogers
description: CLAREMORE, Okla., Nov. 2  The famous face is all over town these days. The leathery complexion, the drooping forelock, the broad grin, the crinkles at the corners of eyes that are sometimes quizzical, sometimes teasing, sometimes just plain merry. You almost expect him to say it once more.

title: Rhodesian Rebels Assail British Plan but Stay at Talks
description: LONDON, Nov. 3  The Zimbabwe Rhodesian guerrilla leaders, straining to keep the eightweekold conference here from collapsing, said today that there was still a lot to talk about with Britain, and they urged that the negotiations on new elections continue.

title: NAZIHUNTING IS THEIR LIFE
description: On Dec. 7, 1973, a French lawyer named Serge Klarsfeld arrived in cold, snowy Cologne from his home in Paris. Near the great Gothic cathedral in the center of town, Klarsfeld stood and watched a parked car belonging to Kurt Lischka. For years, Lischka had led an uneventful life as a businessman. In1940, he had been the young Gestapo chief of this city. A year later, he had been promoted to be Gestapo chief of Paris and deputy chief of all France. He had been central to the deportation of more than 73,000 Jews to Auschwitz and other killing centers. [Elie Wiesel']s account of his return to Auschwitz and other death camps appears on page 36.] Among these deportees was Klarsfeld's father, Arno, who, late one night in 1943, had been taken from the family apartment in Nice by Gestapo agents while 6yearold Serge, his sister and mother huddled in terror behind a secret wall.

title: Other Ideas &
description: Britannia is surrendering some of its rule over the airwaves. Last week, as part of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's economy program, the Government announced its longdreaded plan for cutbacks in the world services of the British Broadcasting Corporation, regarded in many nations where local news service is nonexistent or corrupt as the veritable voice of integrity, civility and truth. European services in French, Italian, Greek, Turkish and Spanish will go; so will Burmese and Maltese programs. More than 100 members of Parliament of all parties have signed a petition against B.B.C. service reductions, but since the Government's spending plans for next year will be presented in a single package, there is little chance that Parliamentary opposition, however intense, can stop them.

title: Food PriceIncrease Lag to Cut Jan. 1 Rise in Food Stamp Benefits
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP)  Because food prices have not been increasing as sharply in recent months as they did earlier in the year, lowincome families will get only a small increase in food stamp benefits Jan. 1, new figures from the Agriculture Department indicate.

title: After the Last Hurrahs, Local Voters Will Choose
description: FROM Greenwich to Griswold and from Stamford to Stonington, election campaigns for control of the town and city halls across Connecticut  contests dominated by local issues and personality clasheswere in their final stages this weekend.

title: New Grenada Chief Reports Plot Involving Landings on the Island
description: BRIDGETOWN, Barbados, Nov. 3 (Reuters)  The new revolutionary Government on the island of Grenada was reported today to have uncovered a plot to overthrow the Government, and it placed its security forces on full alert.

title: The $101 Million Coop Conversion
description: A Chicagobased company that specializes in condominium conversions has submitted plans to convert a 40story East Side apartment house to cooperative ownership, but some tenants contend that the prices are unreasonable and the building needs repairs.

title: A Winter Roundup Of Discount Fares
description: As travelers begin planning for winter vacations, they will find fewer bargains on fares, but there still will be tempting ways to make dollars go farther.

title: DINING OUT Two Spots Best Suited for Lunch
description: THERE are restaurants that are far better at lunch than at dinner, and conversely. That one reason this reviewer visits each restaurant at least twice and at both lunch and dinner. Not only does a restaurant look different at different times of day, but often the staff is different, the food is different and so are the prices. Even the clientele changes.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: No one knows exactly how to measure innovation, but every President since Herbert Hoover has commissioned a study on why there isn't more of it in the United States. Last week President Carter announced a rather modest program to free technological innovation in American business from what he called the stifling constraints of Government policies.

title: REFUGEES FROM LAOS TELL OF GAS ATTACK
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3  Refugees from Laos have told United States officials that Vietnamese or Laotian Communist forces used deadly gas in air attacks to crush resistance to Communist rule by the Hmong mountain people of Laos.

title: Princeton Ponders The Urge to Merge
description: PRINCETON VOTERS in this college town will end months of fierce civic debate Tuesday when, for the fourth time since 1953, they will decide whether there will be one Princeton or two.

title: A Search Aircraft Finds No Trace Of Missing Ship Off South Africa
description: CAPE TOWN, Nov. 3 (Reuters)  A South African reconnaissance aircraft crisscrossed 1,000 square miles of sea off the Cape of Good Hope today in a vain search for the missing Norwegian ore carrier Berge Vanga and its 40member crew.

title: Partaking of a Rich Past in the Old Spanish City of Ronda
description: The approach to Ronda from Seville is deceiving. The vegetables and cereals in swatches of green, beige and ochre, the thatched peasant huts fenced in cactus, the occasional hacienda planted in the hill like a white shell in obsidian sand  these strike too domestic a note.

title: A Warning on Geese
description: BRIGATINE WILDLIFE specialists are warning that the occasional feeding of migratory and resident geese by New Jersey residents is dangerous and threatnes the birds winter survival.

title: What If You Ran Chrysler?; The Strategies Of Some Top Executives
description: WASHINGTON  The Chrysler Corporation, whose expected $1 billion loss this year would be by far the worst in American corporate history, won Administration backing last week for $1.5 billion in Federal loan guarantees. See Highlights, page 19.

title: Events Today
description: Lexington Avenue Festival: Antiques, food, arts and crafts, entertainment; 11 A.M. to dusk; Lexington Avenue from 23d to 34th Street. (Proceeds to benef It meal programs for the elderly.)

title: SPORTS CrossCountry: Running Without Traffic Lights
description: NEW CANAAN RUNNING has been gaining so rapidly on the popularity charts that it may even challenge television. There is only one way to watch TV, but there are all kinds of ways to run  and all but one of them are well known.

title: Maureen Waxon Is Engaged
description: The engagement of Maureen Frances Waxon of Rockville Centre, L.I., to Barry Stuart Zisman of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Zisman of Hallandale, Fla., has been announced bythe future bride's father, Albert Bru mond of Sun City, Ariz. The wedding is planned for Dec. 30. Mrs. Waxon, daughter also of the late Margaret Brumond, is facilities coordinator with Grumman Allied Industries Inc., in Garden City, L.I. Her fianc is the general counsel of that concern, a subsidiary of the Grumman Corporation. Mrs. Waxon's marriage ended in divorce, as did Mr. Zisman's.

title: Two New Shows Take Aim at TeenAge Viewers
description: You never see anything on television where children are not made to simply look cute or are not made fun of, Dr. Lee Salk, the child psychologist, said recently. I would like to make adults more respectful of children. I want to show thatthey have something to say about important things  they're just never asked.

title: Dance: Bowyer and JoAnn Bruggeman
description: It isn't every dance concert that ends with its audience boogeying on down the aisle. But then every concert isn't Bowyer and Bruggeman. With their blend of highenergy physical humor and telling satire on dance manners,Bob Bowyer and JoAnn Bruggeman would probably look as right on Saturday Night Live and the nightclub circuit as in the concert hall. And they looked pretty good on the stage of Camera Mart/Stage One last Sunday, where they appeared as part of the Dance Umbrella festival in a program dedicated to the late Joyce Trisler.

title: College Heads Fear for Quality as Costs Are Cut
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 2  The rising costs of operation that are resulting in everhigher tuitions at colleges and universities are causing growing anxiety among the presidents of the institutions, who are worried about how to maintain quality while cutting corners.

title: Headliners
description: Clyde Barrow is gone, John Dillinger is gone, and now Jacques Mesrine has joined them. Last week, France's Public Enemy No. 1, a robber and selfprofessed murderer who repeatedly cheeked the police with daring public appearances since his escape from prison 18 months ago, was ambushed by about 80 officers on the northern outskirts of Paris and machinegunned to death in an oldfashioned hail of bullets.

title: WASHINGTON Moscow's Deaf Ear
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3  Two points need to be made about the inexpressible tragedy of the Cambodian people. First, that the present threat to the very existence of that nation is being caused by a conflict between two Communist regimes. And second, thatthe Soviet Union has not only refused to use its influence to stop the carnage, but won't even cooperate with the civilized nations to save the Cambodian children.

title: MUSIC Not for Royalty Only
description: BACH'S A Musical Offering was intended for the private delectation of Frederic the Great, but the whole Westchester community is cordially invited to partake of the same at the Manhattanville College campus, which is turning into an arts festival all day today. Unless you're reading this with very early morning coffee, you have probably already missed the 9:30 A.M. workshop on Improvising in a Changing World, but there are a number of others to follow, along with displays of music scores and books, an afterlunch playin of rarelyheard music and, at 3 P.M., a composer's forum, with Lucas Foss. Wilma Machover, the pianist, Michael Rudiakov, the cellist, Antonia Lavanne, the soprano, and a number of other Manhattanville faculty and student performers will be heard during the day.For further information and driving directions to the Purchase campus, call the college at 9469600.

title: Taxes: Reform Takes a Breather
description: WASHINGTON AT 10 A.M. Wednesday, Treasury Secretary G. William Miller scheduled to present to the Ways and Means Committee the Carter Administration's disapproving views of a tax that mostAmericans have never heard of, and that most Democratic politicians have regarded as so far beyond political decency that it would be suicidal to support it.

title: Demand for Wood
description: ELWOOD HOYT is not a newcomer to the wood business. His grandfather established the Eastern Fuel Corporation in Hamden, Conn., in 1868. Years laterhis father ran the business for decades, before turning it over to him. Which is not to say that the youngest Mr. Hoyt followed in their footsteps. Things have changed for wood sellers in the last three generations.

title: The Met's Booming Basso
description: If one were asked to describe the looks, demeanor and bearing of a typical operatic bass, the image that would emerge would undoubtedly correspond to that of Germanborn Kurt Moll, whose imposing presence and high artistry have been in notable evidence this season at the Metropolitan Opera.

title: Dance: Bella Lewitzky Offers Three Premieres
description: Bella Lewitzky must love the challenge of putting dances together. All three New York premieres offered Friday at the Bella Lewitzky Dance Company's Dance Umbrella programat Camera Mart/ Stage One were methodical explorations of movement problems. And Miss Lewitzky took obvious delight in solving the problems she set herself.

title: Alligators in Louisiana Bringing Record Prices
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 3 (UPI) Hunters in 12 south Louisiana parishes caught more than 16,000 alligators in onemonth season and the hides are drawing record prices, a state Wildlife and Fisheries Department official says.

title: Lynn Reiss Plans Marriage on Dec.
description: The engagement of Lynn Ruth Reiss, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Lawshe Reiss of Dublin, N.H., to Lute Armstrong Quintrell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Armstrong Quintrell of GatesMills, Ohio, has been announced by me bridetobe's parents. The wedding is planned for Dec. 1 in the Union Congregational Church in Peterborough, N.H.

title: Two Window Greenhouses
description: Gail White and Betsy Keeler are two imaginative gardeners. They own window greenhouses, but each has found a different way to plant it.

title: Rabbi Defends Son Sentenced in College Drug Sale
description: NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Nov. 3 (AP)  Rabbi Joseph Goldman of Long Branch, N.J., has specialized in counseling youth. Last week he watched as a judge sentenced his 19yearold son to one year in jail for selling cocaine to undercover agents.

title: Trouble in Finding Alcoholic Women
description: THE treatment of women suffering from alcoholism is receiving new emphasis in Westchester County, but one of the biggest problems often can be finding the women involved.

title: Katherine Ellis Wed to an Editor
description: Katherine deSaulles Ellis, daughter of F. Henry Ellis Jr. of Brookline, Mass., and Mrs. Watson Ellis of Dedham, Mass., was married yesterday afternoon to Robert Karl Manoff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard K. Manoff ofNew York and Klosters, Switzerland. Associate Justice Arnold L. Fein of the Appellate Court, performed the ceremony at The Players.

title: Newspaper Celebrates Hastings' 100th
description: HASTINGSONHUDSON AN oldfashioned newspaper, The Hastings Centennial Chronicle, went on sale here today. The oneshot, 20page tabloid contains no advertising and has a major story entitled, Babe Ruth Comes to Hastings.

title: Voters in Coast County to DecideOn Solar Village at Old Air Base
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif., Nov. 3 (UPI) Marin County voters are to decide next week whether to transform an old Air Force base into a civilian airport or create a futuristic residential community powered almost entirely by solar energy.

title: Adrienne Neufeld Betrothed
description: Mrs. Harold Neufeld of Edgewater, N.J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Adrienne Merrill Neufeld, to Dr. Kenneth Paul Maykow of Hackensack, N.J., son of Mrs. JackRich of Riverdale, the Bronx, and the late Benjamin Maykow. The future bride is the daughter also of the late Mr. Neufeld. A wedding is planned in the spring.

title: Soviet Balks Ginzburg's Kin on Adopted Son's Visa
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 3  Aleksandr Ginzburg was freed from a Soviet prison six months ago and flown to the United States in a MoscowWashington exchange of five dissidents for two convicted Soviet spies.

title: Cowboys to Test Giants' Mettle
description: PHIL SIMMS used to think it was pretty exciting at the pep rallies before his Southern High School team played Fairdell in its big game every year in Louisville. And he said it didn't matter at Morehead State what the season record was when it came time to light the bonfires before the traditional finale against East Kentucky.

title: Lessons in the Law: TShirts! Superstar Profs!
description: After spending $15,000 or so on three years of law school, a new lawyer is not yet finished paying for his education. There's another $450 to go for a bar review course, a specialized review that helps him prepare for the bar examination of the state where he hopes to work.

title: Egypt Explains Its Policy On Palestinians to China
description: CAIRO, Nov. 3 (UPI)  Egypt told a visiting Chinese official today that it regarded the projected autonomy for the Palestinians in Israelioccupied Arab lands as a stepping stone to statehood.

title: TaxRelief Trial Due
description: NEW BRUNSWICK WITHIN the next two weeks, Judge Herman L. Breitkopf will schedule a trial in Superior Court to determine whether New Brunswick should be forced to grant a tax abatement voted by the City Council. The abatement would allow the construction of 126 units of low and moderateincome housing.

title: POLITICS A Key Convention Post for Mrs. Grasso
description: HARTFORD EVERYONE can agree on rhetoric and words when you get to a thing like the platform. But when you're talking about credentials  credentials mean coldstiff votes, and that's real power.

title: Iron Horse Disliked by Students Is Rusting in a Georgia Pasture
description: ATHENS, Ga., Nov. 3 (AP)  The University of Georgia students pranced like pagans destroying an idol, carrying torches and chanting, Burn the horse! Burn the horse!  They piled mattresses beneath the figure and set a fire, but they could not destroy the Iron Horse.

title: Manila Gambling Ship Burns
description: MANILA, Nov. 3 (UPI)  A fire shot through the decks of a floating casino gambling ship here today, driving more than 200 people from the vessel. One person was treated for minor burns.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: Vision, like beauty, is in the eye of the beholder. It can probably be safely said that few have beheld vision in New Jersey. That does not mean that this quality is lacking; it is just not the perceived hallmark of the state.
