New Yorkers, in particular,think of New Jersey in terms of a doublefare taxi ride through a surreal Refineryland on the way to Newark Airport; others think of it as an equally surreal Casinoland on the ocean, or Developerland on the Palisades. Princeton, or Short Hills, or Long Branch, seem very far away.

title: Salvadoran Rebels Say They Hold Bishop Who Supports New Junta
description: SAN SALVADOR, Nov. 3 (AP)  Leftists holding 27 hostages in two Government buildings said today that one of them was a Roman Catholic bishop being detained in a separate location as a guarantee that the Government would not attack them.

title: Other Regional Events; Waste Not Wanted; Buckley Redux?; Chesimard Escapes; Food Poisoning
description: New Jersey's industrial complex annually churns out billions of tons of goods and more than 5 million tons of bads hazardous wastes. Last week, a state advisory commission said the disposal problem had grown too large for any existing public or private operation to handle and recommended creation of a new state agency to tackle it. The agency should have power to override local objections to the placement of waste disposal facilities, if necessary. The commission also said the state should consider establishing a waste exchange. Wastes from one industry may be of value to other industries as raw materials. it said.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Joanne DuBosque, Lars Magnus Guy Plan Spring Bridal
description: Joanne Hutchinson DuBosque, an administrative assistant at the Eye Research Institute of the Retina Foundation in Boston, and Lars Magnus Guy, an area director for the American Cancer Society in Boston, plan to be married next spring.

title: Marino Passes Sink Syracuse
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 3  Dan Marino, a freshman quarterback making his first start for Pittsburgh, tossed two short touchdown passes and was assisted by a strong defense today as Pitt scored a 2821 victory over Syracuse and its oneman gang, Bill Hurley.

title: Music of Time First By Nose at Aqueduct
description: Rokeby Stable'sMusic of Time, who last season did not earn a penny in three starts and who gained his first 1979 victory only two months ago, captured the $108,700 Stuyvestant Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday in a tight threehorse finish.

title: Leslie A. Carr Wed to Stephen Zakrzewski
description: The marriage of Leslie Anne Carr, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Francis Willard Carr of Jersey City, to Stephen Zakrzewski, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Zakrzewski of Nutley, N.J.. took place yesterday in JerseyCity. The Rev. Walter Carlson performed the ceremony in St. Paul's Episcopal Church, of which the bride's father is the rector.

title: Three Novels
description: ETWEEN the song of noble Hiawatha and popular legends of the ferocity of Geronimo, the American Indian has been trapped in mythologies that have either ignored or justified his fate. Whether shown to be gentle and trustworthy or savage and treacherous, the Indian of stories, poems and filmsserve his victor's will; good or bad, the mythical redman is supposed to be entertaining. Feathered and painted, he is silhouetted against rosecolored mesas or pictured gliding eternally down silent streams.

title: Music Math No Charm For Doomed Animals
description: KOTKA, Finland, Nov. 3 (Reuters)  Young musicians have been barred from rehearsing in a laboratory at slaughterhouse here because their music lowered the quality of the meat, the newspaper Uusi Suomi reported today.

title: Music Notes: Composer As Painter
description: Many contemporary composers are accused of writing music for the eye rather than for the ear. This may or may not be a just accusation, but if you want to see some visually striking scores  claims might bemade that they are works of pictorial art  go to see the exhibition that opens on Thursday at the Drawing Center, 137 Greene Street.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Nancy Drew. The Hardy Boys. There's hardly an American now alive who hasn't at some time had the fun of following those teenagers as they tracked down clues in the pursuit of justice. This week, after half a century of life in hardcovers, the sleuths are moving into paperback, in three new volumes published by Simon & Schuster's Wanderer Books. They're priced at $1.95 each.

title: WESTCHESTER HOUSING How to Unload Family Treasures
description: YOU can't take it with you when you die, and you may not even be able to take it to your next abode  so what do you do with it? John Markham, a Westchester appraiser, asked rhetorically at a Briarcliff adulteducation class called Antiques And Collecting.

title: Scientists Say Close Encounters With Alien Beings Are Unlikely
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., Nov. 3  Technologically advanced civilizations are so rare that mankind's may be the only one in its galaxy, most of the 30 scientists who attended a meeting on the subject have agreed. Therefore, they said, it is futile to expect any close encounters of any kind with alien beings.

title: Paperback Best Sellers
description: Massmarket paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computerprocessed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: American Airlines Averts Strike
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., Nov. 3 (AP) Local 541 of the Transportation Workers Union and American Airlines reached a tentative agreement early today, averting a strike, although pickets walked in front of some of the airline's terminals for about three hours.

title: ART VIEW
description: Something has clearly happened in our relation to Realism. And I say our relation because it matters little whether we like or dislike the various kinds of art that are nowadays subsumed under this increasingly mysterious rubric. Both the friends and the foes of this still inadequately explained development in our artistic life are more or less in the same boat  at sea, as it were, and lacking any sort of reliable intellectual compass to guide them.

title: Proposition 1 's Might Prove Confusing to Voters Tuesday
description: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 2  Is there danger that on Election Day some voters may get their Proposition l's mixed up?

title: State Weighs Agent Orange Bill
description: TRENTON SOME time this month, the State Legislature is expected to take final action on a measure that has come to be known as the Agent Orange Victims Act, although the word victims is expected to be deleted from the name.

title: Politic Statements
description: T the office of Senator Edward M. Kennedy in Washington and at his publisher's office in New York it is said that Our Day and Generation, a collection of Kennedy remarks with a title derived from a speech by the late Senator Daniel Webster of Massachusetts, never was intended, and still is not intended to be a campaign book. SenatorKennedy's press spokesman in Washington, Thomas Southwick, understands and says he regrets that it going to be read as a campaign book because it is published at a time when the Senator is edging toward declared candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination and for election in 1980. Sure, Mr. Southwick says, people are going to read it that way and they are going to be disappointed. If it was Intended to be a campaign book, we'd have withdrawn it from circulation.

title: Columbia Booters Win
description: Barry Nix, a sophomore fullback, scored on a direct free kick with minute 31 seconds to play yesterday to give Columbia a 10 Ivy League soccer victory over Dartmouth at Baker Field.

title: Baby Chewed by Dog Dies
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 3 (UPI)  A 2weekold boy whose legs were chewed off by the family dachshund died today, leaving the family to decide whether to destroy their pet of six years. Christopher Johnson died at Children's Hospital, where he had remained in critical condi tion since he was attacked on Halloween while his mother slept in a nearby room. The baby had had an upset stomach and his mother, Linda K. Johnson, apparently was exhausted after staying up with him for two days, according to the police, who ruled out parental negligence. The dog was described by neighbors and friends as wellbehaved.

title: Thomas F. Vassallo And Miss Steinman Plan June Wedding
description: The engagement of Kemberley Lynne Steinman to Thomas Frank Vassallo, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Charles Vassallo of Chesapeake, Va., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. AlfredDonald Steinman Jr., of Centerport, L.I., and Wickford, R.I. The wedding is planned for June.

title: Carey Signs Measure To Provide Assistance With Heating Oil Bills
description: ALBANY, Nov. 3 (AP)  Governor Carey today signed a measure intended to help families in all income groups arrange for loans of up to $1,000 to help with their rising fuel bills this winter.

title: Patricia Orsini Wed In Jersey to Banker
description: The Wyckoff (N.J.) Reformed Church was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Patricia Orsini, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Orsini of Wyckoff, to Wolfgang Platzer of Frankfurt, West Germany, son. ofDr. and Mrs. Wilfried Platzer of Vienna. The Rev. Douglas C. Smith performed the ceremony, and the Rev. David Bach assisted.

title: Favorite Conservative
description: ITH his 70th birthday behind him and his doomed race for the Presidency 15 years in the past, Senator Barry M. Goldwater has acquired something of the statesman's air. To hisearlier identity as a man who talked first and thought later, Senator Goldwater has added, since the Watergate years, a reputation as everyone's favorite conservative, astraight shooter whose ideas you might question but whose character you would never doubt. In the last days of Richard M. Nixon's term, when the Republicans in Congress wanted to convince the President that he had to quit, they chose Barry Goldwater, symbol of probity, to convey their message.

title: Mary Craven Wed To Allan R. Kelly
description: Mary Leslie Craven, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donovan Craven of Bedford, N.Y., was married there yesterday in St. Matthew's Episcopal Church to Allan Rowan Kelly, son of Dr. and Mrs. Gordon Brooks Kelly of Fort Worth. The Rev. Daniel F. Miner performed the ceremony.

title: Filming Mozart's Don Giovanni
description: It rained on the day that the cast of Don Giovanni was scheduled to begin filming on location in Vicenza, a town in northern Italy near Venice. And the rain continued for a week, leaving the eight singers andtheir director, Joseph Losey, wondering what to do. It was impossible to work on outdoor scenes and the interiors were not yet ready to be shot. Rather than submit stoically to natural disaster, Mr. Losey devised a daily routine of rehearsal activities that he now feels contributed positively to the finished product. During that week, he says, we all got to know each other very well, breaking through my fears and those of the singers  most of them had never faced a camera before and had never directed an opera.

title: Rhodesia Reports Killing About 60 in Zambia Raids
description: SALISBURY, Zimbabwe Rhodesia, Nov. 3 (Reuters)  Troops of the Zimbabwe Rhodesian Government have killed about 60 Rhodesian guerrillas and three Zambian civilians in raids into Zambia, military headquarters said today.

title: Bill to Protect Retarded Gains
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP)  The Senate Judiciary Committee has approved legislation authorizing the Justice Department to go to court to protect the rights of persons in institutions for the mentally retarded. The 12to4 vote was taken by a poll of the members after discussion of the bill at a meeting earlier in the week.

title: BEHIND THE BEST SELLERS
description: I'm really just an ordinary housewife, Kathleen E. Woodiwiss was saying in a soft, shy voice from her home in rural Minnesota. I enjoy cooking and cleaning, my family and my home. Right now my husband is remodeling one of the bathrooms.

title: Venezuelan ExPresident Is Criticized in Scandal
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 3  A former President has been accused by the ethics committee of his own political party of taking part in a multimilliondollar scandal.

title: Huge Crowd Mourns Park at Funeral Rite in Seoul
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 3  President Park Chung Hee of South Korea was buried in a hilltop grave at the National Cemetery today after a state funeral and procession lasting nearly six hours.

title: THE NEW MOMA: MIXING ART WITH REAL ESTATE
description: When the Museum of Modern Art put up its first building in 1939  its fourth home, but the first structure erected specifically for the museum's own use  it knew precisely what it wanted. Architects Edward Durell Stone and Philip Goodwin produced a stark, boxy structure of the International style,which stood out among the brownstones of West 53d Street like a revolutionary at a ladies tea party. It was a crisp, sharp structure, gleaming where theneighboring buildings were somber, hardedged where the rest of the block was soft. It was a perfect proclamation of a new age: an architectural container absolutely suited to the provocative paintings it contained.

title: They Still Call It Saloon Singing
description: The success of Bobby Short during the past decade has encouraged an increase in the number of performers who might be characterized as saloon singers. Despite the ratherchic atmosphere in which Mr. Short usually works  his permanent base is the Hotel Carlyle  he still refers to himself as a saloon singer and those who have followed in his footsteps inevitably carry the label with them.

title: Fantastic Lessing
description: DORIS LESSING'S new novel has this in common with its predecessors: it forces us to think about first and last things, about what we are, how we got that way and where we aregoing. It forces us to look into the depths of the apocalyptic tide washing round us.

title: CITY SEEKS TO HIRE MORE PROFESSIONALS
description: You'd work at our headquarters in Flushing Meadow, one of the loveliest parts of New York City, the chief of the Parks Department's division of design and construction told 85 young engineers yesterday.

title: Auto Complaint Panels Will Adopt New Policies
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (UPI)  New procedures to help consumers quickly resolve complaints about faulty cars have been announced by the Government and automobile dealers.

title: A 120Pound Woman Saves Injured Trucker
description: ESSEX, Conn., Nov. 3 (UPI) A 120pound woman saved the life of an injured truck driver yesterday by dragging him up a steep highway embankment moments before his oil truck burst into flames.

title: You Can Bet Your Life
description: IF AN epidemic swept across New Jersey, driving its victims to alcoholism, a life of crime and, eventually, to suicide, the forces of government would join quickly with the medical, scientific and academic communities to develop an antidote.

title: Zoning Controls on Discos Planned
description: The city is about to get in step, but not on the bandwagon, with the disco beat. It is writing regulations for discotheques, which are not now covered in the zoning laws.

title: A Lesson in Walking the Picket Line
description: THE chartered bus waited in the faculty parking area. I boarded it and took a seat beside a librarian. Others followed. We cheered one particular professor as he stepped inside; his administrative job was recently abolished. returning him to faculty status. We all wondered how many of us might be bumped back to the unemployment line.

title: FOUR SHOT TO DEATH AT ANTIKLAN MARCH
description: Two carloads of whites opened fire yesterday on demonstrators opposing the Ku Klux Klan in Greensboro, N.C., killing four persons and wounding eight. The police arrested 12 men they said were associated with the Klan and charged with murder.

title: Not So Fast on Chrysler
description: The route to Federal aid for the Chrysler Corporation is now greased. With President Carter signed on, there is little chance that Congress will be able to resist the opportunity to win friends and votes by guaranteeing loans for the beleaguered auto giant.

title: Giaimo's Maverick Fight Against Federal Fuel Aid
description: WASHINGTON, D.C. REPRESENTATIVE Robert N. Giaimo stands virtually alone among New England officials in his opposition to any kind of Federal program to help poor people pay for heating oil this winter.

title: Kaufman Gives His Reflections On Court Work
description: Marking 30 years on the Federal bench, Irving R. Kaufman, chief judge of the Second Circuit Court of Appeals, has handed down a compendium of reflections on selected topics, ranging from philospophy to the quality of lawyers.

title: Armstrong Hurt in Mugging
description: ST. LOUIS, Nov. 3 (UPI)  Henry Armstrong, the only boxer to have held three world titles at one time, said today that a beating by muggers was more brutal than anything he had experienced in the ring. The 66yearold Hammering Henry was attacked in a street Oct. 27 and suffered multiple injuries. He said he expected to be released from Central Medical Center Monday.

title: West Bank's College Calm Again As Arabs Catch Up After Rioting
description: BIR ZEIT, IsraeliOccupied West Bank  For the moment tension appears to have eased between the Israeli military authorities and Palestinian students and faculty at Bir Zeit University. The Arabschool was ordered closed for two months in the spring and summer after demonstrations and clashes in which a student was wounded by a Jewish settler's gunfire.

title: Author's Query
description: For a collection of the selected letters of the late South Carolina writerphilosopherhumanitarian James McBride Dabbs (18961970), I would appreciate receiving copies of the originals, which will be reproduced promptly and returned to the owner.

title: Concert: Cantilena Chamber Players in New Work
description: The Cantilena Chamber Players presented the first of three concerts at the Guggenheim Museum last Sunday afternoon. The series is sponsored by the Helena Rubinstein Foundation, whichalso allows the group funds to commission works for itself. On this occasion, the new composition was Tzvi Avni's Beyond the Curtain, which received its New York premiere.

title: Louise Parent Will Be Bride Of John Casaly
description: The engagement of Louise Marie Parent to John Paul Casaly has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Stephen A. Flynn of Wilton, Conn., stepfather and mother of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Casaly of Natick. Mass.

title: A Year To Go
description: WASHINGTONThere is so a Republican Presidential race, even if the Democrats are getting the headlines. But it is being conducted with a civility unfamiliar to those who recall the raucousness of the party's Kansas City convention in 1976, and without the micrometers once used for measuring ideological purity.

title: Clemson, With 3 Interceptions, Surprises Wake Forest by 310
description: CLEMSON, S.C., Nov. 3 (AP) Clemson's veteran defense intercepted three Wake Forest passes  one was returned 17 yards by Jeff Davis for a touchdown  as the Tigers upset the Deacons, 310, in an Atlantic Coast Conference game today.

title: 50 Treated as Fumes Spread
description: NASHVILLE, Nov. 3 (UPI)  About 50 people were treated at hospitals for an illness caused by the release from a 55gallon drum of a chemical used to give natural gas its distinct odor, officials said. The drum, filled wih ethyl mercaptan, was ripped open by a forklift last night. releasing toxic fumes that spread over a onemile industrial and residential area, said Mike Caudill of the State Civil Defense. The chemical will cause nausea, dizziness and headaches, but it's not deadly, he said. Ethyl mercaptan is added to natural gas, which is ordinarily odorless, to make gas leaks easily detectable.

title: Badillo Criticizes Carter And Endorses Kennedy
description: Former Deputy Mayor Herman Badillo, expressing bitter disappointment at what he said was President Carter's failure to honor commitments to poor people and to racial minorities, endorsed Senator Edward M. Kennedy for the Democratic Presidential nomination yesterday.

title: ART
description: WAYNE ART labeled minimal seems austere, perhaps uneventful and maybe a little lackluster. Although there is an extraordinary amount of monotony in minimal art, it nevertheless has created a lot of excitement in the last two decades. And although its detractors predicted its instantaneous demise, it has weathered its opposition and continues to flourish as an unabashedly direct and unequivocally candid art form that appeals on both sensual and intellectual levels.

title: GARDENING The Apple's Evolution: From Eden to Now
description: IF Eve did indeed tempt Adam with an apple, is it any wonder that he gave in to such enticement?

title: Kennedy Presses Iowa Campaign
description: AMES, Iowa, Nov. 3 (UPI)  A lastminute change of strategy by Senator Edward M. Kennedy's campaign advisers transformed a Democratic Party fundraising event into a political battlefield today.

title: Ralph Jules Frantz Is Dead at 77; Herald Tribune Editor 30 Years
description: Ralph Jules Frantz, for more than 30 years an editor with The New York Herald Tribune, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Fair Lawn, N.J., two days after his 77th birthday.

title: The Nation
description: On occasion, no news is good news. But on the occasion of last week's economic reports, the news was plain no good. It was perplexing for economists trying to puzzle out whether a deep recession is imminent and disappointing for President Carter and for Federal Reserve Board chairman Paul A. Volcker, who was under growing fire for potentially exacerbating such a slump, possibly by mistake.

title: LETTERS TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR For Faculty Members, a Time to Ponder
description: MIDDLETOWN FACULTY members at Wesleyan University continue to grapple with the issues that gave rise to a proposal for them to join a labor union, even though the move to unionize was defeated by four votes last month.

title: Suffolk Airport Blocked Anew
description: WESTHAMPTON BEACH THE opponents of a plan to use the Suffolk County Airport at Westhampton Beach as a jetport have succeeded in their yearlong effort to have an environmental impact study made before DC8's and 707 cargo jets can land at the countyowned facility.

title: Social Security Changes Studied
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP)  An independent panel studying the Social Security system will recommend that husbands and wives split their earnings credits evenly if they get a divorce, Stanford G. Ross, Social Security Commissioner, told a House Ways and Means subcommittee this week.

title: Brown Conquers Harvard
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I. Nov. 3  Having saved something for a rainy day, Brown waited until the third quarter today before scoring three touchdowns within five minutes and overcoming Harvard, 2314.

title: IN THE NATION Delivering The Coal
description: Some nuclear industry analysts expect the Kemeny Commission's critical report to cause further delays in the licensing of new reactors. But the industry as a whole is clearly relieved that the commission did not order a moratorium on nuclear power plantconstruction  which can only mean that the power companies hope to start building reactors again as soon as possible.

title: Fission Was a Mark Of Kemeny Inquiry On 3 Mile Island
description: WASHINGTON  The jury of 12 Americans considered the testimony of more than 150 witnesses. They examined thousands of pages of evidence. Their final deliberations consumed days of intense, sometimes angry, debate. Last week, the members of the jury  which included a Washington laborleader, a California nuclear engineer, a Texas corporate executive and a New York journalism professor  handed down a unanimous verdict: Nuclear energy is inherently dangerous. It has been poorly regulated. But if fundamental changes occur in the way reactors are built, operated and regulated, the risks of can be kept within tolerable limits.

title: Modest Welfare Reforms Given a Chance This Time
description: WASHINGTON  Welfare reform remains one of the great, unfulfilled dreams of the last two decades in Washington. Lyndon Johnson, Richard Nixon and Jimmy Carter have all proposed farreaching schemes for comprehensive changes. Their plans now lie in unmarked graves on Capitol Hill, caught between a withering liberalconservative crossfire.

title: HOME CLINIC Saving WaterHeating Energy
description: SINCE water heaters are second only to home heating systems as the largest user of energy in most homes in this area, anything that can be done to cut down on the energy a water heater consumes is usually worth looking into. There are actually three steps that can be taken to lower the cost of providing hot water:

title: Cable Car Line to Reopen
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 3 (AP)  One of the city's three cable car lines will be back in service Monday for the first time in six weeks. The California Street line will be restored to service, but the two

title: Monet and Mayhem
description: RT is long, and life is short  so the adage goes. In this long, racy art thriller, the briefer lives (of victims and villains alike) all come to violent ends. One character is drugged and has his wrists slashed in a tepid bath; another is dumped into the Thames; three are ren##dered human ##vegetables bysome new chemical substance; one is electrocuted; another leaps or is pushed to his death from a penthouse apartment; several have their throats.cut or ?? shot to death with snubnosed revolvers or .44 Magnums. Rather an awesome total  somewhat more impressive than the final scenes of Hamlet.

title: Budd Lake Castle
description: BUDD LAKE DRIVING west on Route 46 in Morris County, one eventually comes upon Budd Lake, at the far end of which stands a castle, of all things. No, it's not a vision, but the Pax Amicus Castle Theater, which is opening officially today.

title: Canadian Freedom of Information Bill Is Praised
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 3 After years of complaints of official secrecy, representatives of political and civil rights groups as well as the press say they are pleased that Prime Minister Joe Clark has proposed Canada's first freedom of information legislation in the House of Commons.

title: Film: 'Arthur Miller on Home Ground':The Cast
description: "Arthur Miller on Home Ground" takes a reasonably pleasant and picturesque look at the playwright, who has been filmed and interviewed by Harry Rasky, also responsible for "Homage to Chagall." Mr. Miller is visited at his farm, and viewed repeatedly as he strolls through the streets of New York City, where he grew up. "I love this city," Mr. Miller says, several times. Each time he says it, Mr. Rasky provides the same kinds of generalized shots of the skyline. It is possible to feel, after a while, that one is getting at least as well acquainted with the Chrysler Building as with Mr. Miller. The less said about Mr. Rasky's visual ingenuity, the better.The film includes excerpts from movie and television productions of some of Mr. Miller's works, timed to the author's comments on each piece; his observations about the ways "Death of a Salesman" continues to affect audiences are particularly acute. There are also clips from "A View From the Bridge" (Mr. Rasky provides footage of the Brooklyn Navy Yard) and "The Crucible" (shots of primitive-looking New England dwellings in the snow). Mr. Rasky has also filmed new material to illustrate a story of Mr. Miller's, and one soliloquy from "The Price," although neither snippet is much of a success.Mr. Miller, whose manner is affable and whose remarks are consistently interesting, discusses his childhood, his career, his travels and, very briefly, his perception of Marilyn Monroe. Mr. Rasky, who near the end of the film asks Mr. Miller if he personally has indeed paid A Price, keeps most of his questions mercifully brief.The atmosphere of the interviews is businesslike-bordering-on-friendly, which means that when the camera wanders in for a close look at Mr. Miller's art collection late in the film, the intimacy and curiosity come as a mild surprise. The rest of the documentary seems a lot less actively involved with its subject. The film, which is interesting but not particularly insightful or informative, doesn't have the substance of an inquiry, or an explanation. It's the work of a good listener.

title: Mistakes Help Lynbrook
description: Undefeated Lynbrook capitalized on mistakes to beat Carey, 127, and boost its Conference III wonlosttied record to 501. Carey fell to 33.

title: Diagnosing Health Care
description: ALBANY  The debate on national health policy has become increasingly muddled in light of new statistics that seem to indicate that Americans health is better than ever.

title: BEYOND THE AVANTGARDE
description: For the sizable number of people who are nowadays devoted to modernist arteager to look at and make it part of their lives, if not actually to produce it or study it or buy and sell it  it is very hard to imagine a time when there were no museums concerned even to show it. Today an abundant number of museums show nothing else. Yet it was only 50 years ago that the Museum of Modern Art, the first and the greatest of our art museums to be devoted exclusively to this field, was founded in New York. This turned out to be a more fateful and farreaching event  for museums, for art and for our entire culture  than anyone could have known at the time. It marked the first official step in the institutionalization of modernism, a movement that owed its very existence and a good deal of its spiritual lan to its role in upsetting the institutional view of art, to overturning revered conventions and taking a profoundly adversary attitude toward established cultural values.

title: Mary B. Noyes, a Radiology Instructor, Married to Dr. Eric Cunningham Martin
description: Mary Bright Noyes and Dr. Eric Cunningham Martin were married yesterday in the First Church of Christ, Congregational, in Farmington, Conn. The Rev. Richard Bauer, the minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Growing U.N. Expands
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y.  Like a homeowner trying to meet the needs of a growing family, Clayton C. Timbrell said the other day, the United Nations found it necessary to make some improvements  $14 million worth, in fact.

title: ART New Moods Out of the Past Lichtenstein Uses Mirrors
description: PORT WASHINGTON IF an old technique is employed in the creation of an art work, we have a misguided tendency not to regard the work as modernist, as if technique were our principal index of judgment in such matters. But the newest and freshest kinds of art can be created out of the most timehonored techniques. In fact, some of the most revered modernists reached their loftiest accomplishments by means of expression that have been with us for years.

title: Caretaker Couple Killed by a Fire In a Jersey Country Club Building
description: Two people were killed early yesterday in a fire at the Roxiticus Country Club in Mendham, N.J., that destroyed the large turnofthecentury Gothic clubhouse, the borough police said.

title: Wanted: Lvng Prtnr
description: WHILE scanning a local newspaper some months ago, my eyes skipped quickly over summer's slim pickings to the column headed Personals.

title: Dance: Murray Louis Performs Five Haikus
description: It was indeed a stronger bill that the Murray Louis Dance Company presented Friday night after a weak opening program in its current season at the City Center. The highlight was the company premiere of Mr. Louis's Figura, while the novelty was the American premiere of his Five Haikus. Glances and an excerpt from Go 6 filled out the evening.

title: Connors and Borg Reach Toyko Final
description: TOKYO, Nov. 3 (AP)  Jimmy Connors struggled in the first set, faltered in the second set, then rallied against Vitas Gerulaitis today to gain the final of the $300,000 World Super Tennis Tournament.

title: Coast Jury Checks Medical Service
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 3 (AP) county grandjury has begun investigating the alleged siphoning of more than $8 million from the state health program by a medical company and a doctor who, according to state investigators, owns controlling interest in the company.

title: OffDuty City Correction Officer Is Stabbed to Death in the Bronx
description: An offduty New York City correction officer was stabbed to death last night during an argument on a Bronx street, the police said.

title: Order Reversed Against Reporter Jailed Over SourceIdentity Issue
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 3 (AP)  A suburban reporter's fight to withhold the identity of a news source succeeded yesterday when a Federal appeals court overturned a contempt citation that put her in jail on Tuesday.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: FOR more than 25 years, before his death last month, Roy R. Silver covered Long Island news for The New York Times. Besides being a special person and a dedicated newsman, said Andrew Geddes, director of the Nassau Library System, he was a lifelong friend of libraries.

title: I. R. A. Bomb Expert, Long Wanted by Irish, Seized in Philadelphia
description: A man arrested in Philadelpha five days ago as an illegal alien was identified yesterday through fingerprints from Ireland as a fugitive explosives expert of the Irish Republican Army wanted for questioning in the 1976 bomb slayings of the British Ambassador to Ireland and an Irish policeman.

title: Care of the Aged: Avoiding a Break With the Patterns
description: THE Pinerest Nursing Home in Paramus advertises itself as specially designed and built to provide dignified, efficient nursing care to the discriminating guest in refined luxury.

title: Music: Gelber Is Pianist With the Clevelanders
description: The Cleveland Orchestra appeared on the Great Performers at Lincoln Center series in Avery Fisher Hall on Friday night. The program was rather austerely limited to two works, the First Piano Concerto of Brahms, with Bruno Leonardo Gelber as soloist, andBartok's Concerto for Orchestra. Lorin Maazel conducted, and the playing was anything but austere.

title: Young Women of Good Cheer
description: EASTCHESTER ANYONE bored or embarrassed by school spirit would have squirmed in his seat last week at Eastchester High School.

title: ANTIQUES
description: Fifty years ago, Paris was an international stage for artists, writers, choreographers, jazz musicians and designers. And out of this provocative period between the wars came the most elegant and luxurious aspects of what we now call the Art Deco style, a mode that transformed all expressions of the decorative arts.

title: Oregon Turkey Growers in Drive Against Fear Birds Are Tainted
description: McMINNVILLE, Ore., Nov. 3 (AP)Oregon turkey growers are starting a nationwide campaign to keep their birds the centerpieces of Thanksgiving dinner tables this year.

title: ExTeammates Sink Rangers
description: DENVER, Nov. 3  John Davidson remembered a preseason phone call from a worried young female hockey fan. If Pat Hickey's injured eye did not heal, she said, she was going to jump out of a window. When Hickey was traded last week, Davidson wondered how many 14yearold hockey fans were on window ledges.

title: MAINE REPUBLICANS, IN INFORMAL BALLOT, GIVE BUSH A VICTORY
description: PORTLAND, Me., Nov. 3  George Bush, the former Director of Central Intelligence, stormed into New England today and upset Senator Howard H. Baker Jr.'s apparently wellprepared effort to score the first victory of his Presidential campaign.

title: Concert: Chamber Symphony
description: Hearing the New York Philharmonic play Beethoven's Fourth Symphony is not necessarily an event. Hearing the Y Chamber Symphony play it under Gerard Schwarz, as it did Oct. 27 and 28 at the 92d Street Y, assuredly is. Partly,the difference is the gain in detail and impact when a Beethoven symphony is performed in a 900seat hall, rather than Fisher or Carnegie. But the main reason Mr. Schwarz's performance overwhelmed was the amazing enthusiasm, virtuosity and seriousness of purpose of the 40member Y orchestra itself, now in its third season and, judging from Sunday's performance, better than ever.

title: Brynn T. Wellman Betrothed to Paul Raymond Raupagh
description: Bryan Thomas Wellman and Paul Raymond Raupagh plan to be married Dec. 22 in Ann Arbor, Mich. Their engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Jerome Wellman of Scarsdale, N.Y., parents of the prospective bride.

title: The Many Mishaps of Manufacturers Hanover
description: Despite widespread acclaim for the quality of its management, the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company seems particularly adept at getting egg on its face.

title: Nuclear Sub to Become A National Monument
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP)  Edward Hidalgo, the Secretary of the Navy, has decided that the Nautilus, the world's first nuclearpowered submarine, will become a national monument and will be moored at the Washington Navy Yard.

title: Traveler's Bookshelf
description: Few travelers actually court disaster, but three who have done so  all, as it happens, women  have lived to tell the tale in three new books. Each one makes diverting reading for vicarious adventurers.

title: Ruth Chalked Up Runs
description: Babe Ruth scored 150 runs or more in one season six times for the New York Yankees.

title: GARDENING The Apple's Evolution: From Eden to Now
description: IF Eve did indeed tempt Adam with an apple, is it any wonder that he gave in to such enticement?

title: A Big Game for the Giants
description: For a team with a 45 wonlost record, it might seem strange to say that such a team has a Big Game with the Dallas Cowboys today, especially when that team is the Giants but it is a Big Game.

title: Parley Recalls Freedom Summer
description: JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 3 (AP) Many of the students do not remember those days, but for older Mississippi residents the Freedom Summer conference bringing back memories of 1964, when the civil rights movement was at its peak and volunteers poured into the state to register black voters.

title: G.S.A. and Archives Are Criticized Over Loss in Fire of Historic Film
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (UPI)  A House committee said today that mismanagement by the General Services Administration and the National Archives had contributed to the destruction of 12.5 million feet of historic newsreel film in a fire last year.

title: New Senator Is Chosen As Head of Ethics Unit
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (UPI) Senator Howell Heflin, Democrat of Alabama, has become the first senator in 70 years to be named chairman of a standing Senate committee while serving in his first year in office.

title: Ombudsman's Office Works for the Elderly
description: In 1974, in response to reports of abuses in nursinghome patient care and in financial dealings involving Federal and state reimbursements, New Jersey and other states undertook investigations of longterm care of the elderly.

title: Knight Patterson to Be Married
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jere Westcott Patterson of New York and Southampton, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Knight Patterson, to Gilbert Simrall Meem Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Meem of Bluefield, W. Va.

title: Cars Banned From Part of Rome
description: ROME, Nov. 2 (Reuters)  The center of Rome, where some of the worst traffic jams in Europe occur, will be closed indefinitely to private cars beginning Monday in an effort to lessen pollution, the City Council announced today. About 16 miles of roads between Piazza Venezia and Piazza del Popolo will be cordoned off by 260 traffic directors.

title: Carole L. Weidman Is Married
description: Carole L. Weidman, an assistant state attorney general, and Dr. Lawrence Enisman, a resident surgeon at St. Vincent's Hospital, were married yesterday by Rabbi Irwin Isaacson at the Bayside (Queens) Jewish Center. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Weidman of Bayside. Dr. Enisman is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Abe Enisman of Rego Park, Queens.

title: Record October Flows Recorded For the Mississippi and the Ohio
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP)  The Mississippi and Ohio rivers recorded record high water flows in October, according to the United States Geological Survey.

title: Crete Excavations Reveal Drama Played in Face of an Earthquake
description: ATHENS, Nov. 3  Excavations on the southern Mediterranean island of Crete have revealed, along with rare artifacts, a religious drama played out in a Minoan temple 3,500 years ago in an advanced culture's last hour.

title: Italian Octuplet Goes Home
description: NAPLES, Nov. 3 (AP)  One of two surviving octuplets born here Aug. 16 to Pasqualina Chianese was released from the hospital yesterday. Doctors said the girl, Silvania, was in excellent health. Her sister, Anna, remains in the hospital but doctors say they hope she can go home at the end of this month. The six others died within two weeks of birth, which was nearly two months premature.

title: Peter Kiewit, 79, Builder in West; Public Works Created an Empire
description: Peter Kiewit, a Nebraska construction executive whose $400 million dollar empire was amassed through building of tunnels, dams, highways and other public works projects that, critics charged, sometimes dragged far behind schedule at exorbitant costs to taxpayers, died Friday in Omaha. He was 79 years old.

title: DINING OUT From Hunan to Canton to Sichuan; *Woks
description: WOKS is a new Chinese magnet on the outskirts of Huntington. The place is a hub of activity, especially on Sunday evenings, a popular time for families to share a Chinese meal.

title: Design THE PIONEER OF STREAMLINING
description: When Raymond Loewy and the century were young, the look of life was different. Everyday objects were bulky, colors were dowdy and machines bristled with ungainly protuberances.

title: Mrs. Thatcher Plans China Visit
description: LONDON, Nov 3 (Reuters)  Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has accepted an invitation to visit China and hopes to go next year, her office said today. Mrs. Thatcher was invited last night at a dinner given for her at the Chinese Embassy here by Chairman Hua Guofeng, who is on a sixday visit to Britain. She will be the first British Prime Minister to visit China while in office.

title: ART Rediscovering an Impressionist
description: NEW LONDON ESTABLISHED in 1899, the Old Lyme Art Colony did not always present an Impressionist front, nor were all the major American Impressionists associated with it. But from 1903, when ChildeHassam began summering there, to just after World War I, locale and movement were almost synonymous. Indeed, some authorities have compared Old Lyme to that enclave of French Impressionism, Giverny.

title: Candidate's Van Is Damaged
description: SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Nov. 3 (UPI)  A van used by Mayor Frank Duci's reelection campaign caught fire today, few days after his workers had received threat that the vehicle would be bombed. Mr. Duci, a Republican, said part of campaign sign had been stuffed between the van's motor and gas tank. The slim caught fire as campaign workers were driving the vehicle to Mr. Duci's home. The fire was doused and no one was injured, the Mayor said, adding that he believed the incident was more than just prank.

title: China Assails Freedom Posters
description: PEKING, Nov. 3 (Reuters)  The official Chinese press today denounced posters put up on walls by activists demanding democracy. A critical editorial was printed in both The People's Daily and The China Youth Daily. Facts show that such posters are apt to be used by those who have ulterior motives to create confusion in production, work and society at large, it complained, charging that the posters were the work of a small group of anarchists.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: JACK'S BOOK, by Barry Gifford and Lawrence Lee. (Penguin, $4.50.) Thisvolume, described as an oral??biography of Jack Kerouac (192269), author of On the Road (Penguin, $2.95), is, in a sense, also a chapter in the history of the Beat Generation. The authors have loosely woven together interviews with Kerouac's friends and acquaintances  William S. Burroughs, Gregory Corso, Allen Ginsberg, Gore Vidal and others less well known  to capture the spirit of a vital, messy time in our recent past.

title: Hawaii Strike Talks Recessed as Garbage Piles Up
description: HONOLULU, Nov. 3 (AP)  With garbage piled in the streets and the state's public schools still closed, negotiators went home to bed today after a marathon bargaining session aimed at ending twoweekold strike by public workers.

title: What's Doing in NEW HAVEN
description: INGENUITY  Speak of New Haven, and you think of Yale. But New Haven is by no means solely a center of learning. Here Yankee ingenuity and drive served not only the pursuit of knowledge, but also industry, and came up with such products as the New Haven clock, the Winchester rifle, Sargent tools and locks, Gilbert's toys (notably the enduring Erector set). Here Eli Whitney manufactured his cotton gin, and in 1812 led the way to mass production by turning out rifles with interchangeable parts. Here, too, Charles Goodyear invented vulcanized rubber. Out of this wealth of culture and industry has come a lively cornmunity with many interests and attractions. While historically New Haven leople have boarded the train for time on the town in New York, now more and more New Yorkers take the train to New Haven. They come for preBoadway plays, and art exhibits, to visit libraries and museums, to stroll the Green and the college quads, and, in fall, for football.

title: U.S. F14 Falls in Mediterranean During Joint Exercise With Spain
description: ALMERIA, Spain, Nov. 3 (AP)  An F14 fighter from the aircraft carrier Nimitz crashed into the Mediterranean today during United StatesSpanish exercises, military officials reported. Two crewmen are missing, they added, and a search is under way.

title: U.S. and Equatorial Guinea Agree To Restore Relations Cut in 1976
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (Reuters) The United States and Equatorial Guinea are restoring diplomatic relations, which were severed during the dictatorial rule of Nguema Biyoto Masie, who was ousted in August, the State Department said today.

title: Growth in Rural Regions Brings Rapid Crime Rise
description: HILLSBORO, Mo., Nov. 2  For the past few years, crime in rural areas and outward suburbs across the nation has been rising faster than in the cities. Jefferson County  667 square miles of open space, villages, small houses and mobile homes south of St. Louis  is part of the pattern.

title: That's My Little Brother on the Court and Everybody's Cheering
description: SITTING high up in the bleachers, I watch 10 kids run up and down the polished hardwood floor. A lanky kid sinks a layup, and North Plainfield's No. 25 takes it out of bounds. Thecheerleaders are on their feet, chanting, We want a basket, we want a basket, as No. 25 glides effortlessly down the court. He leaves the man guarding him waving his hands. He lofts a high arcing jump shot from the top of the key, the ball swishes through the hoop, and I stand up and cheer.

title: Herbs Supplement Therapies in Tibet
description: LHASA, Tibet  A new hospital in Lhasa is combining Western medical techniques with the art of Tibetan herbal medicine practiced for more than 1,000 years.

title: Flea Market Meets
description: MINEOLA FLEA markets are regarded as source of bargains for many consumers but to merchants with permanent locations on the main streets of Long Island they are about as popular as the bubonic plague.

title: Exploring the Other Hawaii
description: Hawaii is still the Pacific paradise it has always been and it is still an ideal place to spend a winter vacation. But in the 20 years since the islands became the 50th state, the boom in tourism has transformed Honolulu, the capital, from the slumbrous tropical seaport of preWorld War II days into a bustling metropolis where the din of traffic among the stark skyscrapers drowns out the soothing throb of the nearby surf.

title: CAMERA
description: Flash photography has come a long way in the past couple of decades, with the most dramatic change being the way that flashcubes and flashbulbs have been largely supplanted by compact, very efficient electronic flashunits that are now so widely available from dozens of different manufacturers.

title: Marla Brenden Bride of Horace F. Garfield
description: Marla Sue Brenden, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marlyn Odin Brenden of Eau Claire, Wis., was married yesterday evening to Horace Fuller Garfield, son of Mrs. Douglas Sutherland Dodge of Sheffield and Cuttvhunk Island. Mass.formerly of New York, and John Newell Garfield of Chicago. The Rev. Marlyn Close performed the ceremony in the First Congregational Church in Eau Claire.

title: No Spring In Valley
description: Clarkstown South defeated Spring Valley, 140, yesterday. Larry Mitchie opened the scoring with a 37yard runand Rich Barletta, South's leading scorer, ran 5 yards for the other touchdown. Jim Gillick added both extra points.

title: Music: Debuts in Review
description: Guitar ensembles are a rarely encountered species, partly because little music of significance has been composed for them. The Buffalo Guitar Quartet finessed that most obvious difficulty in its New York debut concert last Sunday night at Carnegie Hall. All 15 pieces on the program were transcriptions, most of them the work of Jeremy Sparks, a member of the group.

title: William Fugazy And Friends
description: Photographs crowd the walls of William D. Fugazy's small but comfortable Madison Avenue office, showing him playing golf and attending sporting events and parties with the likes of Frank Sinatra, Jackie Gleason, former President Gerald R. Ford, New York Yankees owner George Steinbrenner and Terence Cardinal Cooke.

title: JERSEY BOND ISSUES ARE FAVORED TO WIN
description: TRENTON Nov. 3  Two major bond proposals a $475 million issue for transportation projects and a $95 million issue for new construction and improvements at state colleges  seem likely to win voter approval Tuesday, according to New Jersey state officials and other backers of the bonds.

title: Missing Free Agent
description: Baseball's fourth annual flesh market opened a little after 11 A.M. in the Terrace Room of the Plaza with crystal chandeliers overhead, a frieze of wellfed angels simpering down from one wall and a few fans looking on from a balcony.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: FOR the last tour summers, the blind have been able to enjoy the solitude and tranquillity of the tall stands of trees on the shore of the Oradell Reservoir by strolling along a nature trail especially created for them. The reservoir is in the Bergen County town of Haworth.

title: Barbara Allen Vagliano Is Bride of John Fielding
description: Barbara Allen Vagliano and John Fielding were married yesterday afternoon in Norfolk, Conn., at the home of the bride's father, Alexander Vagliano. Justice of the Peace Hugh Robinson of Norfolk performed the ceremony.

title: The Greeks Have a Word For It and It's Independence
description: ATHENS  Shortly after a Greek shipyard began servicing Soviet supply ships attached to Moscow's Mediterranean fleet last month, Prime Minister Constantine Caramanlis toured Western Europe explaining how he reconciled this hospitality with Greece's obligations as a member of the North Atlantic TreatyOrganization. Next week, in Peking, Mr. Caramanlis will continue his explanations, to Chinese leaders who have been exhorting Europeans to keep their guard up against Soviet hegemony.

title: Gas Plants Protested in Medford
description: MEDFORD RESIDENTS of Peconic Avenue In Medford have been pressing for a new Brookhaven Town ordinance governing the location of bottled and liquefied naturalgas plants since a fire last summer at a nearby propane company that caused 800 people to temporarily evacuate their homes.

title: Topics Censors
description: Sensitive about their reputation for repression, Argentina's military rulers last month tried to make humanrights hay over the release of publisher Jacobo Timerman, who had been detained without charges for 29 months. They had little reason to boast. After a court ruled that continued detention of Mr. Timerman would be illegal, the generals expelled him from the country and then called the episode a show of their respect for the rule of law. Others suggested that their real motive was to try to influence the pending report of the InterAmerican Human Rights Commission. But whatever their motives, Mr. Timerman would at least be free, or so it seemed.

title: Officer Guilty in Sinking of Cutter
description: YORKTOWN, Va., Nov. 3 (AP)  A jury of Coast Guard officers today found Chief Warrant Officer Donald K. Robinson guilty on a reduced charge of dereliction of duty in the collision that sank his cutter and killed 11 men.

title: THIS WEEK IN SPORTS
description: BASKETBALL

title: Food Spice Shops Offer a Taste of the Exotic
description: IF you have a recipe calling for juniper berries, lemon grass, green cardamom seeds or fenugreek, there are places on the Island where you can find them all, plus hundreds more herbs and spices, both everyday and exotic. Shops in Roslyn,Amityville and Bridgehampton specialize not only in culinary herbs and spices, but in those used for medicinal and cosmetic purposes, essential oils, coffees, teas and miscellaneous products and equipment.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: BRYAN HARMON, an Ossining resident, first heard about the Neighborhood Watch Program when Stephen B. Acunto, director of the crimeprevention unit of what was then the Sheriff's Department, came to the Burke Rehabilitation Center, where I was a volunteer, and spoke about the idea, he said.

title: A Boy's Death: Case Becomes War of Nerves
description: SIX months after the killing of a 13yearold Smithtown boy touched off charges that the Suffolk County police had bungled the investigation, the police have made no arrests and, instead, appear to be engaged in a war of nerves with four suspects and their lawyers.

title: Bloomsbury Late Blooms
description: MORE than one reader of modern literature has suggested recently that there be a moratorium on things Bloomsbury; some confess to having tired of essays on Virginia Woolf's novels, and there may even be a stray person who tired of the novels themselves. But nobody shows any signs of doing anything about this state of affairs, and until nonBloomsbury novelists such as Arnold Bennett (Riceyman Steps), wyndham Lewis ( The Revenge for Love) and Ford Madox Ford (Parade's End has only just now been reprinted) are available in inexpensive editions, younger readers at least will think that the modern English novel is all D. H. Lawrence and Virginia Woolf. Everyone agrees that Mrs. Dalloway and To the Lighthouse are wonderfully original books that keep their freshness upon repeated rereadings. But are there any other Woolf novels that continue to feel essential? Does anyone really look forward to reading through The Waves again?

title: Kush Wins a Round In Ouster Struggle
description: PHOENIX, Nov. 3 (AP)  Arizona State's suspended football coach, Frank Kush, filed a $40 million suit yesterday, then said he would await developments as the school scheduled a hearing that the state's attorney general said should have preceded his suspension. The suit charged conspiracy, defamation, dueprocess violations and interference with his coaching contract.

title: 6355 Score Sets N.C.A.A. Mark
description: DAVIDSON, N.C., Nov. 3 (AP)  Al Sorrells completed three scoring passes and ran for two touchdowns as Furman edged Davidson, 6355, in the highestscoring football game since the National Collegiate Athletic Association began keeping records in 1937.

title: INVESTING One Way to Profit From Fallen Bonds
description: For investors, the crash of the bond market this month has one significant redeeming quality in addition to high yields. The steep break in bond prices has produced an opportunity to reduce capitalgains taxes without sacrificing income. It's done with a Wall Street sleight of hand known as the bondswap.

title: The Cover
description: The pictures on the cover are from the collection of the Museum of Modern Art. Left to right: (top row) The Persistence of Memory, Salvador Dali, 1931; The Battleship Potemkin, directed by Sergei Eisenstoin, 1925; Composition in White, Black and Red, Pier Mondrian, 1936; Birthday, Marc Chagall 1915; Girl Before a Mirror, Pablo Picasso, 1932; (second row) Drowning Girl, Roy Lichtenstein, 1963; Muscular Dynamism, Umberto Boccioni, 1913; The Palace at 4 A.M., Alberto Giacometti, 193233; Jane Avril. H. de ToulouseLautrec, 1893; The Sleeping Gypsy, Henri Rousseau, 1897; (third row) Kiesler, Robert Rauschenberg, 1966; Woman at the Piano. Elie Nadelman, c. 1917; Dance, Henri Matisse, 1909; Elegy to the Spanish Republic. 54, Robert Motherwell, 195761; Mountain, Table, Anchors, Navel, Jean Arp, 1925; (fourth row) Dance Hall, Brassai, 1932; ModIesko, Soprano Singer, Kees van Dongen, 1908; Three Women, Fernand Leger, 1921; Relief Construction. Joan Miro, 1930; The Breakfast Room, Pierre Bonnard, c. 193031; (fifth row) HideandSeek, Pavel Tchelitchew. 194042; Mother and Sister of the Artist, Edouard Vuillard, c. 1893; Marilyn from Ten Marilyns. Andy Warhol, 1967; Bicycle Wheel, Marcel Duchamp. 1951; Visa, Stuart Davis, 1951; (bottom row) Bus Driver, George Segal, 1962; The Engineer Heartfleld, George Grosz, 1920; Target With Four Faces. Jasper Johns, 1955; Floating Figure, Gaston Lachaise, 1927; At the Milliners. Edgar Degas, c. 1882; Arm chair. Gerrit Rietveid 1917.

title: Festive Japanese Holiday Unmarred by Political Crisis
description: TOKYO, Nov. 3  A festive Japan celebrated Culture Day, a national holiday, today, but the country was mired in one of its most serious political crises since World War II as a result of a challenge to Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira by the man who preceded him in office.

title: CARDENING The Apple's Evolution: From Eden to Now
description: IF Eve did indeed tempt Adam with an apple, is it any wonder that he gave in to such enticement?

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Fritz Mueller of the Central Park Track Club found his home course a perfect setting yesterday as he won the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union's 50mile run in the meet record time of 5 hours 14 minutes 54 seconds.

title: Brussels Comes of Age
description: BRUSSELS  Earlier this year, the West German Government decided to impose a noise level standard on power mowers, a move that would have practically foreclosed the German market to imports.

title: California Accountant Cleared
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 3 (UPI)  A judge has dismissed grand theft and conspiracy charges against Leonard Harris of Los Angeles, an accountant accused in the transfer of nearly $1 million into the bank account of a bookkeeper. The bookkeeper, Arne Ristol of West Covina, Calif., was acquitted three months ago by a jury of similar charges stemming from the mistaken transfer of $927,288 into his bank account.

title: Carter Goes North For a Chat Over The Back Fence
description: OTTAWA  Canadians love to tell tales that purport to show the ignorance and indifference that unenlightened residents of the United States traditionally display toward their fellow North Americans. However, this indifference is tempered, some Canadians believe, when it comes to energy resources, which the United States wants and Canada has.

title: Hungarian Clerics Visiting U.S.; One Faults Pope on Ecumenism
description: The first Hungarian interfaith clerical group to visit the United States in 30 years arrived in New York City last week, with one of the seven leaders voicing mild disappointment in Pope John Paul II regarding ecumenical relations.

title: Alice Marbach To Be a Bride
description: Alice Wells Marbach, a reference librarian, will be married next June to Gavin Worcester Watson, a systems analyst with the Bankers Trust Company. Their engagement has been announced by the future bride's parents,Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Marbach of Toms River, N.J. Mr. Watson is a son of Richard B. Watson of Darien, Conn., and the late Anne Worcester Watson.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: Auditions for string, wind and percussion musicians interested in joining a new orchestra will be held from 1 to 4 P.M. at the Newark campus of Rutgers University. Those interested are asked to go to Room 107 of Bradley Hall at 392 High Street.

title: Margaret Bowen Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ledyard Stevens Bowen Jr. of Danvers, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Bowen, to David W. Cybart, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Cybart Jr. of Shelton, Conn. A wedding is planned in June.

title: Westchester Medical Center Opens a $2.5 Million Burn Care Facility
description: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 3  The Westchester County Medical Center opened a $2.5 million burn unit this week, with facilities to treat 10 severely burned patients at one time as well as for teaching and research.

title: BRIDGE
description: The World Championship in Rio de Janeiro last month offered an opportunity for some lesserknown teams to match their skills against some of the world's greatest players. The Italiansand the Americans, who had won bunches of world titles on earlier occasions, duly reached the finals, but had plenty of trouble handling the representatives of the other zones.

title: Devotee Of Beauty
description: IN Being Bernard Berenson, Meryle Secrest sets out to tell the truth, once and for all, about one of the most curious and contradictory of human beings. She is not alone in that ambition  Ernest Samuels long study of Berenson's beginnings .Bernerd Berenson: The Making of a Connoisseur, came out earlier this year and is very good indeed; but what she has in mind is a portrait for the general reader, rather than a biography that would follow Berenson line for line, hour by hour and picture by picture.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: State and local roads throughout New Jersey are deteriorated, antiquated, congested and unsafe. As a result, our club members and motorists are paying for the consequences every day in terms of traffic delays, wasted gasoline and unnecessary wear and tear on their automobiles.

title: Rock: Tom Waits Comes Back
description: Tom Waits was back in New York Friday night for a soldout concert at the Beacon Theater. During the past year or so, while Mr. Waits kept a low profile, Rickie Lee Jones made a considerable commercial splash and won widespread critical adulation as wellwith an album and a performing style that owed much to his idiosyncratic manner, but he didn't seem worried. He was still strutting, growling, reciting, and more or less singing in front of a superb, sympathetically atmospheric fourman band.

title: Among Israel's Cabinet, the Political Right Is Also Might
description: JERUSALEM  Political events move so quickly in Israel that anyone who happens to walk into the spacious office of the Speaker of Parliament, Yitzhak Shamir, on the hour, is likely to find the grayhaired gentleman bent over the transistor radio he keeps in his desk, listening to the latest news. Mr. Shamir spent many years in the upper ranks of Israeli intelligence, and he obviously appreciates the value of information, which is often broadcast before it is on an official's desk.

title: SpecialInterest Funding: A Sensitive Issue for Congress
description: WASHINGTON, D.C. OF Connecticut's six members of the House of Representatives, Robert N. Giaimo of North Haven and William R. Cotter of Hartford received the most money in campaign contributions from special interest groups for the last election.

title: Panel Finds Private Pay Outpacing U.S. Salaries
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP)  A Presidential panel has reported that that the salaries of Federal whitecollar workers are lagging behind pay scales in private empIoyment.

title: Employment Group Prods Carter On Aid for Disadvantaged Youth
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP)  A national commission has urged President Carter to expand job programs for the nation's disadvantaged young people to combat stubbornly high unemployment rates. in a report presented to the President Thursday, Eli Ginzberg, chairman of the National Commission for Employment Policy, said: Most youth make the transition from school to work without serious problems. But youth from lowincome families and communities, particularly members of minority groups, often face severe, longterm barriers to jobs.

title: Mythic Objects
description: IN the long title essay of this book of varied reflections and observations, Roland Barflies writes lovingly about one of the world's most celebrated structures: Just as there is no Parisian glance which is not compelled to encounter it, there is no fantasy which fails, sooner or later, to acknowledge its form and to be nourished by it ... [its] sole mythic function is to join ... base and summit, or again, heaven and earth. The Eiffel Tower, he goes on, must escapereason. The first condition of this victorious flight is that [it] be an utterly useless monument. And then he plays with all the possibilities of the tower, following its shifting reality  an object when we look at it, it becomes a lookout in its turn when we visit it  and fixing its connection to time: to look down on Paris from it is infallibly to imagine a history.

title: Eve Carson Fiance Of George Webster
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Albert Carson of St. Joseph, Mich., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Eve Elizabeth Carson, to George Steven Webster of Indianapolis, son of Mr. and Mrs. George A. Webster of Glen Ridge, N.J. A January wedding is planned.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: Why are there no new choreographers? When season after season falls to produce a new genius, when dance companies throughout the world seek to satisfy an insatiable demand for novelty by offering mediocrity in the name premieres, when hastily assembled worksinprogressmasqueraue as completed works, when revivals of the classics and the notsoclassic in ballet and modern dance camouflage a creative bankruptcy, this question is asked with repeated urgency. Yet, it is being asked in a century that has produced the largest number of great choreographers in history, at a time when the greatest of them all rank with or tower over the giants of the other arts, and at the apogee of dance's popularity.

title: Give Me Your Vigorous, Your Rich And Those Who Know the Loopholes
description: WE AGREED, in a moment of undaunted expectations, that, when his immigration problems were settled, we would take the boat to the Statue of Liberty and drink champagne.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: It is all too easy to look at the photographs of John Gutmann, at Castelli Graphics, 4 East 77d Street, until Thursday, through the eyes of better known photographers of a younger generation: Robert Frank, Diane Arbus, Lee Friedlander, Mark Cohen, and so on. Or, asthe jargon would have it, to say that he anticipates these photographers. He did, like these photographers, turn his camera onto the streets and people of everyday America, in a way that was highly selective and idiosyncratic, and he did it in the 1930's, when the others were still school children.

title: Data General's Misstep
description: WESTBORO, Mass.  Two years ago, Edson D. deCastro, president of the Data General Corporation, was saying that his greatest problem was to manage rampant growth of the minicomputer company. Those were the heady days of 40 to 50 percent annual gains in sales and earnings, with no end in sight.

title: 101 Shot Meadowlands Victor
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 3  Any time they need two starting gates for a race at the Meadowlands, it is a good bet there are no worldbeaters in the field

title: Mrs. Eisenhower Quietly Buried At General's Memorial in Kansas
description: ABILENE, Kan., Nov. 3 (AP) Mamie Doud Eisenhower was buried today beside her husband, Dwight D. Eisenhower, the 34th President of the United States, in this small Kansas town where his long road to glory began.

title: Ignatowicz Shows Union Colors
description: Mark Ignatowicz scored on three short touchdown bursts and kicked five extra points yesterday as oncebeaten Union cruised to its sixth victory, 3515, over Elizabeth at Union. Ignatowicz, a 190pound senior fullback, scored twiceon 2yard runs in the first period, capping successive drives of 62 and yards, respectively. The second score was set up by Tim Kopec's blocked punt.

title: Sanyo Music Center Wins Jump at Garden
description: Harvey Smith, one of the most experienced and successful riders in Europe, has been having his difficulties since arriving for the fail indoor horseshow circut two weeks ago.

title: Italy's Musuems to Raise Fees
description: ROME, Nov. 3 (AP)  Admission fees to Italian museums, art galleries and archeological sites will be raised to $1.20 under a bill drafted by the Minister of Culture. The fees now range from the equivalent of 12 cent up to 60 cents.

title: Animadversions &
description: SINCE becoming editor, five years ago, of The American Scholar, the quarterly published by Phi Beta Kappa, Joseph Epstein.has been contributing a lifeandletters column to its pages. Fourteen of these columns are collected in Familiar Territory, together with a brief preface in which the author places them in the tradition of the familiar essay  a long and distinguished tradition, going back to Addison and Steele In England and even further back to Montaiane in France.

title: MODERN SOVIET ARMS ON WAY TO DAMASCUS
description: DAMASCUS, Syria  Relations between Syria and the Soviet Union, which turned chilly earlier this year, have been improved by Moscow's apparent willingness to send more uptodate military eouipment.

title: Author's Query
description: For a biography of Robert ??ley (18891945), the ??1st and actor, I would ap??te any letters, manu??, anecdotes,. reminis?? or memorabilia of his ?? career.

title: Rise Reported in Deaths Of Young on Highways
description: GENEVA, Nov. 3  There has been a general increase in deaths from motorvehicle accidents, but the increase is disproportionately high in the 1524 age group, the World Health Organization reports.

title: Shows and Events
description: Tuesday and Wednesday  Annual Antiques Show at the Ogden Memorial Presbyterian Church, Main and Elmwood Streets, Chatham. Thirty dealers. Admission: $1.25. Hours: Tuesday, 11 A.M.9 P.M.; Wednesday, 11 A.M.6 P.M. For information, call (201) 6358921.

title: Major News
description: After last week's critical assessment by a Presidential panel, and a big Wall Street demonstration protesting nuclear investment, all the atomic power industry needed was another attack of migraine.

title: Death and Continuity
description: SEX is out and death is in. To judge from the rash of books on dying, the symposia on death, the academic allure of thanatology, there Is more interest in the emergency ward than in the bedroom. Sensationalism accounts for some of this, but the dedication of genuine care is also part of it. The bearing ofdeath upon life has not, until recently, been fully considered; and Robert Jay Litton is surely correct when he argues thatpsychoanalytic theory has been especially remiss in its attempt to manage man's awareness of death.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: It was only a sketch, but to the detectives looking for 7yearold Etan Patz was a second beginning. It depicted man seen talking to a boy in SoHo on May 25, the day Etan disappeared.

title: Television This Week
description: OF SPECIAL INTEREST

title: He's the Thorn in SCM Corp.
description: N. Norman Muller is a major stockholder and board chairman of a private company whose main holdings are Petrocelli Clothes, a nationally sold line of men's apparel, and a South African diamond mine. Then last March, he bought 3 percent of the SCM Corporation.

title: NEW JERSEY HOUSING Mortgages: Guide for the Perplexed
description: WHEN asked the other day to comment on the current condition of the mortgage market, one mortgage banker replied: Are you going to put black border around the article?

title: Late TV Listings
description: 11:00 A.M. (Channel 4). Newscenter Forum: Onehour preelection special.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: Edited by Ann Thwaite and Ronald Hayman.

title: Recital: David Jolley Plays French Horn
description: The Concert Artists Guild Award Concerts began rather in an unorthodox fashion this season with a recital last Tuesday night in Carnegie Recital Hall by David Jolley, who plays the French horn. A graduate of the Juilliard School, he has appeared here withnumerous ensembles, including Music from Marlboro, but this was his debut as a soloist.

title: Votes in Congress
description: 1. Amendment to provide adoption eligibility for recipients of supplemental security income, to delete the means test for adoption assistance and to provide full Medicaid coverage for adopted children with special needs up to age 18, passed, 60 to 25, Oct. 29.

title: Zombies and Other Spooks
description: ERE are two spook novels that go to unusually inventive lengths to bring their Gothic trappings up to date. Although the characters inhabit what can only be described as haunted houses, the novels show that the modern world is what really gets them into trouble.

title: Wendy Gail Netkin Married To Dr. Jesse M. Cohen on L.I.
description: Wendy Gail Netkin and Dr. Jesse M. Cohen were married yesterday at Temple Beth Sholom in Lawrence, L.I. The bridegroom's father, Cantor Robert L. Cohen of the Conservative Synagogue of Fifth Avenue in New York, performed the ceremony.

title: Group Opposes Some Plans for Regulatory Change
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3  After a long incubation period, the regulatory overhaul proposed by the Administration and various legislators have begun to show signs of motion.

title: On N.F.L. Road With the Gypsies
description: Jack Deloplaine, running back, 510, 205, 25 years old, Pittsburgh Steelers. Drafted by Pittsburgh, sixth round, 1976. Played 25 games with Steelers, 197677. Cut 8/27/78, signed by Redskins 8/29/78. Cut 9/12/78, resigned by Steelers 10/12/78. Played 10 games. Cut 8/20/79, signed by Bears 9/5/79. Cut 10/ 18/79, resigned by Steelers 10/ 25/79. Cut 11/3/79.

title: Atom Agency Moving To Halt New Reactors Pending Safety Study
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP)  The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has decided against licensing any new atomic power plants until it thoroughly examines recommendations made after studies of the Three Mile Island accident, officials said today.

title: July '7879 Survey Shows Blacks Gained 2% in Elective Positions
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (UPI)  The number of black elected officials in the United States last year rose by 104, or 2 percent, the smallest increase of the decade, the Joint Center for Political Studies has reported.

title: HUA ARRIVES IN ROME ON LAST LEG OF TOUR
description: ROME, Nov. 3  Prime Minister Hua Guofeng of China arrived in Rome today for the last leg of a European tour that has also taken him to France, West Germany and Britain.

title: HONE CLINIC Saving WaterHeating Energy
description: SINCE water heaters are second only to home heating systems as the largest user of energy in most homes in this area, anything that can be done to cut down on the energy a water heater consumes is usually worth looking into. There are actually three steps that can be taken to lower the cost of providing hot water:

title: Senate Delays Nominee to Get E.P.A. Waste Rules
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3  To back its demand that the Federal Environmental Protection Agency move swiftly to prepare regulations on hazardous wastes, a Senate committee is delaying the nomination of the man the agency has designated to administer such regulations.

title: ANTIQUES Country Furnishings From Two Centuries
description: SOUTHPORT THIS picturesque harbor town will be the site next Friday and Saturday of one of Connecticut's prettiest autumn shows when the 12th annual Southport Antiques Show is held at the Congregational Church in the village center. The emphasis of the show is on 18th and 19thcentury country furniture, both painted and polished, and the accessories with which homes of those periods were decorated.

title: Pennsylvania Investigates Illness That Beavers May Have Caused
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 3 (AP)Pennsylvania, plagued by a variety of unusual health hazards in recent years, is contending with yet another menace, this one possibly caused by beavers.

title: Unknown Faulkner
description: THIS is a daunting enterprise: 677 pages of unpublished or previously uncollected works of short fiction by William Faulkner, along with Interesting notes that tell of the circuitous, tireless creation of the Faulkner canon. They tell, also, of the need for money along the way, the need that turns visions into submitted manuscripts, pieces of paper chugging alongto the eyes of George P. Lorimer at The Saturday Evening Post, to the desk at Collier's and to the editorial scrutiny of other magazines.

title: Unwanted Newspapers  a Burning Issue
description: AFAIR number of newspapers and magazines come into my house, most of them wanted and delivered in a manner that wouldn't offend me. The ones that were never wanted, and nonethelessappear with the inexorability of the seasons, taxes and death, are those infernal news sheets that arrive unsolicited, via unsummoned newsboys, and are wrapped in those cellophane envelopes that not only defy biogradability but also defy all of my efforts to halt their delivery.

title: Boys Will Be Spies
description: ROBERT LINDSEY, Los Angeles bureau chief for The New York Times, has written an absolutely smashing reallife spy story. It isn't a thriller, though; it is a tragedy  a puzzling, troubling, irrational allAmerican tragedy in which idealism is tangled with greed. And because California and the Central Intelligence Agency are involved, there is also a strong undercurrent of farce.

title: Bellport Achievement: First Winning Season
description: In four years of varsity football, Bellport has never had a winning season. Until this year. Yesterday, the Clippers defeated Riverhead, 380, in a Suffolk Conference III game for their fifth victory against two losses. Riverhead is on the other side of the coin, suffering its seventh straieht loss.

title: NAVARRESE DEBATE ROLE AMONG BASQUES
description: PAMPLONA, Spain  In the highly combustible Basque region, the province of Navarre could be the tinderbox. On Oct. 25 voters in the neighboring provinces of Guipuzcoa, Alava and Vizcaya approved the formation of a new Basque government, which will begin to assume control over education, broadcasting, some taxes and the police.

title: Mia Farrow: I'm Bored With Vulnerable Women
description: BOSTON Heaven help the working mother. Mia Farrow slumps wearily in a chair as four of her six children hang on her lap, and Ray the haircutter driesher pageboy.
