Attorneys on both sides say that it could become one of the most farreaching and complex discrimination suits to go to trial since Congress outlawed discrimination by race or sex in 1964.

title: Warmer Climate Feared As Coal Burning Rises
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 The National Academy of Sciences has sent the White House a report reiterating concern in the scientific, community that the continued burning of fossil fuels, particularly coal, will raise the temperature of the earth's atmosphere and lead to severe climatic changes worldwide.

title: Doing Satan's Work in Iran
description: In the zealous eyes of Ayatollah Khomeini, America is the great satan and Great Britain its evil ally. But it is the Ayatollah himself who is doing the devil's work by inciting and condoning the student invasion of the American and British Embassies in Teheran. This is not just a diplomatic affront; it is declaration of war on diplomacy itself, on usages and traditions honored by all nations, however old or new, of whatever belief. The immunities given a ruler's emissaries were respected by the kings of Persia during wars with Greece and by the Ayatollah's spiritual ancestors during the Crusades.

title: Taxes
description: PARENTS who set up a shortterm trust to build a fund for a child's education can save on income taxes, but there are pitfalls to beware of. Such an arrangement is commonly known as a Clifford trust, after George B. Clifford Jr. of Minneapolis, who pioneered the concept of shortterm trusts.

title: Walton Case Is Challenged
description: The National Basketball Players Association challenged yesterday the compensation awarded the Portland Trail Blazers for the signing of Bill Walton by the San Diego Clippers. Telford Taylor, the courtappointed special master, will hear the challenge.

title: San Francisco Cable Car Line Resumes Service With a Clang
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov.5 (UPI)  That familiar clang resounded off Nob Hill again today as limited cable car service resumed  to the delight of tourists, merchants and Mayor Dianne Feinstein.

title: U.S. Mark Notes To Yield 8.58.55%
description: FRANKFURT, Nov. 5 (AP) The United States will pay interest of 8.5 and 8.55 percent on its sale tomorrow of securities denominated in West German marks, it was announced today.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: OPEC Widens Trade Surplus
description: GENEVA, Nov. 5  In 1979, members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries should double the $41 billion to which their favorable trade balance shrank last year, according to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

title: Around the Nation
description: PETROS, Tenn., Nov. 5 (AP)  James Earl Ray, imprisoned for the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., tried to escape from Brushy Mountain State Penitentiary today but was sighted crawling on his belly outside the walls and was captured, officials said.

title: Chrysler Secures Credit For Unit
description: DETROIT, Nov. 5 (AP)  The Chrysler Corporation said today that it had secured a $930 million line of credit through 195 banks for its financing unit, the Chrysler Financial Corporation.

title: F.C.C. Is Petitioned Not to Deregulate The Radio Industry
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5  The American Civil Liberties Union and several organizations claiming a public interest in broadcasting petitioned the Federal Communications Commission today to withdraw its proposals to lift regulations from the radio industry.

title: Bridge:
description: Novels with a bridge theme tend to fall into two groups. Some are by writers with a little knowledge of bridge, and in this category the most successful effort is surely Agatha Christie's Cards on the Table.

title: Prominent Pay Respects To Mamie Eisenhower
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP)  Rosalynn Carter, former President and Mrs. Richard M. Nixon and a gathering of generals and politicians from the past paid their last respects today to Mamie Eisenhower.

title: Army Says Fort Totten Will  Stay in Operation
description: Fort Totten on Long Island Sound in Queens will remain open, as will eight scattered housing sites under its command in southern New York and northern New Jersey, the Army announced yesterday.

title: Welsh Nationalists, Rebuffed, Fight Fiercely for Their Language
description: BETTWSYCOED, Wales, Nov. 1  It has been a bad year for the Welsh Nationalist Party, Plaid Cymru. A proposal for devolution, or limited home rule, was humiliatingly defeated in a referendum, and in the general election the party lost one of its three seats in the House of Cornmons as its share of the vote dipped from 11.5 Percent to 7.6.

title: Ousted Turk Is Backed by Party
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 5 Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit won an overwhelming vote of confidence tonight from his Republican People's Party despite a crushing defeat in congressional elections last month that is forcing him from office.

title: J. J. (Jackie) Farrell, 83, Yankees Publicity Aide
description: John Joseph (Jackie) Farrell, a former sportswriter and sports editor who worked in the public relations department for the New York Yankees from 1943 until his retirement in 1970, died on Saturday at a nursing home in Passaic, N.J. He was 83 years old.

title: Jersey Aide Defends Secrecy on Outbreak of Illness at Marlboro Hospital
description: MARLBORO, N.J., Nov. 5 An official of the State Human Services Department told a joint legislative committee today that the outbreak of illness in which four persons died and more than 130 others became ill at a state mental hospital here was kept secret for five days because no one knew exactly what had happened.

title: Movie: Losey Brings Mozart's 'Don Giovanni' to the Screen:Philanderer Bar None
description: LIKE the legitimate theater and ballet, opera depends on two important agreements with its audience  (1) that its audience remain fixed, stationary and not go wandering around on the stage, poking its nose into the faces of the performers, seeking their bad angles and the zippers in costumes of an earlier age, and (2) that the audience understand (and derive increased pleasure from the understanding) that it's sharing the time span of the performance. At the end of the ideal evening, both the audience and the performers should be equally exhilarated, equally exhausted.It's no coincidence that the two most successful attempts to film a piece of classic theater and an opera have both gone to great length to recall for the motion-picture audience these truisms. I'm thinking, of course, of Laurence Olivier's "Henry V," which guided the movie audience to the play via a reconstruction of a Globe Theater production, and Ingmar Bergman's "The Magic Flute," which also began as a recording of a theatrical production and never for a moment pretended to be anything more than an extension of that production.Both "Henry V" and "The Magic Flute" are complete movies and both maintain the theatrical disciplines without which the original material flies into hundreds of bits and pieces of artifice alien to the movie screen.In filming Mozart's "Don Giovanni," Joseph Losey, who is nothing if not a film maker of style and intellectual resources ("The Servant," "Accident," "The Assassination of Trotsky," among other things), has sought other cinematic means to preserve the acknowledged theatricality of this most lyrical, wittiest, grandest of Mozart's grand operas. Though he has faithfully stuck to the score and to the Da Ponte libretto and has cast it all too fearlessly with singers who have fine voices (and who look like opera singers), Mr. Losey has attempted to find his own equivalent to the disciplines (limitations) of the living theater, not in a soundstage but in lovely real-life landscapes and in and around one of the most handsome houses ever built, the 16th-century Palladio villa near Vicenza in northern Italy. Unfortunately, it doesn't work.This "Don Giovanni," which opens today at the Paris Theater, is marvelous to listen to, even when a singer has difficulty lip-syncing his own voice, and it's pretty to look at, but it may well be utter confusion to anyone who doesn't know the score, or the story of literature's most fearless, most heroic philanderer.It could also reinforce all of the old stereotypes  I think of the Marx Brothers' "A Night at the Opera"  about opera's being nothing more than a bunch of overaged, overweight people running around and fretting at great volume about minor matters that are never made clear. This is not a "Don Giovanni" to make converts. It sings to the already committed.The most obvious difficulty is the singers themselves, among whom only Kiri Te Kanawa as Donna Elvira, the spurned woman who haunts Don Giovanni's desperate life; Edda Moser as Donna Anna, one of the few women the Don fails to seduce, and Jose Van Dam as the frequently distraught servant, Leporello, look and act in a fashion that doesn't make their close-ups embarrassing to watch.The others sing well enough but are extremely odd pictorially. As the Don, Ruggero Raimondi has the necessary weight in his voice but otherwise lacks any evident charm or passion. The camera is especially unkind to Teresa Berganza (Zerlina), Kenneth Riegel (Don Ottavio) and Malcolm King (Masetto). John Macurdy, as the Commendatore, has the easiest time of it, supposedly being made of stone.Still I suspect that none of this would have mattered much if Mr. Losey's overall conception had been successful and evoked a movie world in which we believed. What we have, though, is an essentially urban, highly artificial melodrama played out, for the most part, in the wide open spaces in and around that Palladio villa. People stride purposefully across lawns, in full sunlight, singing their hearts out but headed in no special direction. The entire cast appears to live in that one great house. Nobody ever stands politely still and sings. They're always moving, and if they aren't moving, the camera is. Sometimes a daytime scene comes between two scenes that are set on the same night. Another problem is that the singers who play Elvira and Anna, both beautiful women, look so much alike that we sometimes wonder which is which.Then, too, there are directorial touches to make any "Don" aficionado cringe, such as an exchange between the Don and Leporello in the Don's bedroom, with the Don on one side of the bed, Leporello on the other, and, between them, the well-tanned rump of the Don's conquest of the night before. From what we can see of this woman's perfectly sculptured form, she looks as if the Don had picked her up on the Lido and she probably can't sing a note.The movie is framed not by music but by the sounds of lapping waves and a quotaation from the Italian Marxist Grimasci, designed, I suppose, to give significance to the Don's story that Mozart and Da Ponte failed to make evident. Mr. Losey also adds a nonspeaking character in the shape of the Valet in Black (Eric Adjani), a sort of spooky supernumerary who turns up from time to time to clear away props and to hand the Don his mandolin. Instead of fitting into the decor, he rivets attention, being the spitting image of Isabelle Adjani, to whom, I assume, he is related.Though Mr. Losey jazzes up many other scenes, the climactic confrontation between the Don and the Commendatore is surprisingly tepid visually. I've seen better descents into hell at our own Metropolitan Opera and in any number of Hammer horror pictures.Mr. Losey and his associates haven't destroyed "Don Giovanni," but then they haven't illuminated it either. Their film is a busy, disorienting spectacle, superbly sung (and available on a CBS Masterworks recording).

title: 3 Pelt Koch With Eggs at Meeting; He Helps Seize 2 and Files Charges
description: Mayor Koch was struck in the eye and pelted with eggs yesterday morning by two men and a woman who raced up to the stage of the New York Hilton Hotel as he was rising to welcome 3,500 visitors at a convention of the American Public Health Association.

title: U.S. REJECTS DEMAND OF STUDENTS IN IRAN TO SEND SHAH BACK
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5  The United States rejected today the demand of Iranian students that the deposed Shah be turned over to Iran as the price for the release of the 60 Americans being held in the embassy in Teheran.

title: Finley Denies A's Sale
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 5 (UPI)  Charlie Finley, the Oakland A's owner, and a club spokesman denied today that the sale of the American League team and its transfer to Denver might be completed by the end of the month.

title: Listening Hard at Sperry Corp.
description: TROY, Mich.  At the Sperry Vickers division, another daylong excursion into the far reaches of good listening is drawing to a close.

title: CBSTV, After Mobil Ad, Sticks by Profits Report
description: A dispute has arisen between the Mobil Oil Corporation and CBS Television over the network's reporting of Mobil's recent earnings.

title: Kucinich in Uphill Battle For 2d Term in Cleveland
description: CLEVELAND, Nov. 5 If anything clear about Cleveland's tangled politics this year, it is the choice facing the city's voters in the mayoral race tomorrow.

title: Turkey's No Sick Man
description: The Sick Man of Europe  unfortunately, the news media love to describe situations with cliches and to fit current events into stereotypes. The sickman image, evoking the 19thcentury Ottoman Empire, is being used to characterize the current state of affairs in Turkey.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Joe Altobelli, dismissed last summer as manager of the San Francisco Giants, is expected to be named this afternoon the manager of the Columbus Clippers of the International League. The Clippers, who won both the regularseason championship and the playoffs last season, are the Triple A farm club of the New York Yankees.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: TV: The Great Tragedy of Cambodia
description: CONSIDERED by most observers to be one of the great tragedies of human history, Cambodia is proving a difficult subject for television to cover. On the one hand, there is too little, as American crews have limited access to the country. On the other, there is too much, as the few films that are available provide scenes of devastating horror. Shot after shot of emaciated bodies and tortured souls tend to leave viewers numb, however sympathetic they may be.

title: Mrs. King Captures Final In Stockholm, 63, 67, 75
description: STOCKHOLM, Nov. 5 (UPI)  Billie Jean King recovered in the final set to win the $40,000 Stockholm open tennis tournament today with a 63, 67, 75 victory over Betty Stove of the Netherlands.

title: BUSINESS
description: The Economy

title: Export Surge Cuts Deficit in Payments
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (UPI)  Despite a 29 percent rise in oil imports, the United States trade deficit on a balanceofpayments basis narrowed to $6.96 billion in the third quarter, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Rates on Treasury bills declined for the second consecutive week yesterday, as the Government began a week of heavy shortterm financing activity.

title: EDUCATION
description: THERE are no warning labels, no ingredients listed on the package, no guarantees. You can't squeeze it first, testdrive it or return it later for a moneyback refund. Nevertheless, a postsecondary education is being increasingly viewed as a consumer purchase, an expensive investment requiring caution on the part of the shopper and candor on the part of the provider.

title: RANDALL JENSEN
description: ELLENVILLE, N.Y., Nov. 5 (AP) Randall Jensen, the son of Jim Jensen, an anchorman for WCBSTV in New York City, was killed in a hang glider accident near here in Ulster County yesterday afternoon. Mr.Jensen was 26 years old and lived at 501 East 87th Street in Manhattan.

title: Poll Finds Reagan Keeping Lead; More Democrats Back Kennedy
description: Despite hardfought fall campaigning from Iowa to Florida by six other candidates, Ronald Reagan, the former Governor of California, maintains a strong lead over the Republican field for the 1980 Presidential nomination, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: Rams Sent Seahawks Into Shock
description: The team statistics tested credulity. At Seattle on Sunday the Seahawks, an offensivestyled team that had averaged 22 points and 350 yards a game, were shut out by the Los Angeles Rams, 240.

title: World News Briefs
description: DUBLIN, Nov. 5 (AP)  The trial of two men chargedwith the murder of Earl Mountbatten of Burma opened here today with the prosecution saying that the men planted the bomb that blew up the earl's boat.

title: Scholars Confront the Decline of Technology's Image
description: ANN ARBOR,MICH.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Cadbury Schweppes U.S.A., a subsidiary of Cadbury Schweppes Ltd., has elected to its board Richard A.R. Pinkham, president of Alden Ray Enterprises Inc., a consulting and communications company.

title: Freer Gallery Acquires Major Chinese Calligraphy
description: WASHINGTON Nov. 5  The Smith sonian's Freer Gallery of Art has acquired a major collection of Chinese calligraphy of outstanding quality, according to S. Dillion Ripley, secretary of the Smithsonian.

title: Danes Freeze Wages and Prices To Try to Ease Payments Deficit
description: COPENHAGEN, Nov. 5 (AP)  The new Danish Government imposed a freeze on wages and prices for the rest of the year. Prime Minister Anker Joergensen, a Socialist who formed a minority Government after slight gains in the general election Oct. 23, said the freeze was the first step in reshaping the economy to eliminate a perennial balanceofpayments deficit.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Theater: Jitters Finds Humor in Staging a Drama
description: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 4  Offstage, actors can blame incompetent playwrights, dogmatic directors and unknowing critics, but when they are on stage, they are largely at the mercy of themselves and their fellow actors. Actors can be very vulnerable and very funny people, as demonstrated in David French's delightful new backstage comedy, Jitters, now playing at the Long Wharf Theater's intimate Stage II. This is an insider's affectionate tribute to the theater as a flawed way of life.

title: The Dance: Marta Renzi
description: MARTA RENZI, who graduated from Hampshire College in Massachusetts in 1975, is typical of the young postTwyla Tharp choreographers now seen increasingly in New York. Unlike many in this group, however, she is a highly skilled craftsman who promises to be of considerable interest when she finds her own voice.

title: Inside White House, a New Tone Emerges
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5  The pale morning sun streamed through the tall windows behind Jimmy Carter as Vice President Mondale and the President's top advisers filed into the Oval Office and arranged their chairs in a rough semicircle in front of the huge desk. The President, wearing his familiar gray cardigan over a shirt and tie, set down a gold pen and looked expectantly at Hamilton Jordan, his chief of staff.

title: United Departures To Be Cut by 13%
description: United Airlines, the nation's largest air carrier, announced that it would reduce the number of scheduled departures by 13 percent next year.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: BOLIVIA TROOPS FIRE ON COUP PROTESTERS
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Nov. 5  Bolivian troops opened fire today on demonstrators supporting a general strike against the military regime that ousted civilian rule here last week. At least two demonstrators were reported to have been killed and many wounded.

title: HIGH COURT ON COAST;CLEARED BY INQUIRY
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 5. The investigation of charges of political manipulation in the release of the California Supreme Court's opinions ended today with the announcement that no charges of misconduct would be filed.

title: Light Vote Expected Today Throughout Tristate Region
description: Election officials predicted a low turnout for today in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut for largely municipal elections that are, in effect, the lull before next year's Presidential election and primaries.

title: A1 Capp, Creator of Li1 Abner, Is Dead at 70
description: Al Capp, who squeezed a universe of satire into a world of comedy and made light of his creation by calling it a comic strip, died yesterday at Mount Auburn Hospital in Cambridge, Mass., after a lone illness. He was 70 years old.

title: Stage: Yiddish Revival
description: REBECCA  The Rabbi's Daughter, the Yiddish show that opened at Town Hall on Sunday, is a sparkling old wine in a new bottle, a vintage 1920's, maybe 1930's, Yiddish Second Avenue musical from the days when the street was known as Knish Alley and Yiddish theater reigned supreme on it.

title: Borg and Alexander In China Exhibition
description: CANTON, China, Nov. 5 (UPI) Bjorn Borg and John Alexander brought worldclass tennis to China today, drawing oohs and aahs from nearly 6,000 spectators.

title: Q &
description: Q.What proportion of the free oxygen in the atmosphere is produced by algae and other marine organisms?

title: 2 Slayings Point to a War By Gangs in Chinatown
description: Two young men who were executed in Chinatown on Sunday night were the apparent victims of a new gang war now being fought for control of extortion rackets and other criminal activities there, the police said yesterday.

title: 14 Denied Bond in Slayings of Foes of Klan at Rally
description: GREENSBORO, N.C., Nov. 5  Fourteen Ku Klux Klansmen, one of them also a regional commander of the American Nazi Party, sang America and Onward Christian Soldiers in their holding cell in this shocked Southern city this morning and then filed quietly into a state courtroom to hear charges of murder against them.

title: Associated Press
description: OILERS BEAT DOLPHINS IN MIAMI, 96: Tim Wilson of the Oilers being upended as he carried the ball last night in Orange Bowl. Houston used three field goals by Toni Fritsch to triumph, while Uwe von Schamann had two field goals for Miami.

title: Acid Rain: An Increasing Threat
description: TORONTO

title: About Education
description: ONLY time will tell how Sesame Street does over the long haul; value of novelty can subside, the television critic Jack Gould wrote in The New York Times in an otherwise glowing review in 1969. The new program became the immediate favorite of millions of children and parents, but its deliberate borrowing from the then popular, unorthodox LaughIn and the Beatles shocked conservative educators.

title: On Solidarity Day, Blacks Say We Are Still Slaves
description: Carrying banners and flags calling for selfdetermination and human rights, hundreds of blacks marched through the streets of Harlem and the East Side to Dag Hammarskjold Plaza yesterday in observance of Black Solidarity Day.

title: Stage: A Weill Cabaret
description: IT may well have been one of the longest preBroadway runs, the dozen years that Martha Schlamme and Alvin Epstein have been doing A Kurt Weill Cabaret on college campuses, in nightclubs, in New York and outoftown.

title: Ruling on Oil Drilling Leases Is Due Today
description: BOSTON, Nov. 5  The United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit here today put off until 9:30 tomorrow morning a decision whether to halt the sale of oil and gas exploration leases on the rich Georges Bank fishing grounds near Cape Cod. The sale is scheduled to begin at 10 A.M. tomorrow.

title: Science Library
description: Too many Americans, these authors contend, believe that the answer to all of life's problems can be found in a pill. Aided and abetted by prescriptionhappy physicians, promotions by pharmaceutical companies, lax Federal watchdog and their own impatience and naivet, millions of Americans have become hooked on legal drugs.

title: Air Radio Operators Are Ordered Back to Work by Court in Canada
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 5 (Reuters)  A court ordered about 600 striking Canadian air radio operators back to work today, saying their jobs were essential to public safety.

title: Poll Shows Doubts Over Energy Shortage
description: More than half the respondents in the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll said they thought the energy shortage had been fabricated. Roughly one fourth said that, if given a choice of ways to deal with the higher earnings the oil companies, they would favor that the Government take over the in dustry.

title: Market Place
description: THE Tesoro Petroleum Corporation, which has been doing unusually well lately, is being favored by some investors who anticipate even better news in connection with Tesoro's troubled 37 percent equity interest in Commonwealth Oil.

title: Stocks Off in Slowest Day Since Jan.2
description: Several takeover issues moved lower yesterday as stock prices generally declined amid the slowest trading since the opening session of 1979.

title: Carter Routs Kennedy In an Iowa Straw Poll; Receives 71% of Vote
description: DES MOINES, Nov. 5 (UPI)  President Carter crushed Senator Edward M. Kennedy in a Democratic Party straw poll over the weekend, gainingearly impetus in the drive for support in Iowa's Jan. 21 precinct caucuses.

title: Manila and 2 U.S. Bases Bracing As Typhoon Hits Central Islands
description: MANILA, Nov. 5 (UPI)  Typhoon Vera struck the coconutproducing central Philippines today with peak winds of 137 miles an hour, prompting Manila and outlying areas to take precautions.

title: Advertising
description: JOHN BLAIR MARKETING was reponsible for that couponcrammed sixpage insert in Sunday papers in the New York area, but there's nothing new about that. The subsidiary of John Blair & Company has been into such inserts since 1975, for individual advertisers and for groups of advertisers. Manufacturers, especially those in packaged goods, have long been enamored of centsoff coupons, probably the secondbest way to encourage product trial.

title: EARNINGS
description: The Boeing Company, which controls about 60 percent of the commercial jet market, reported a record thirdquarter profit increase of 43.2 percent yesterday.

title: The Region
description: STAMFORD, Conn.  The United States Air Force has joined a case involving the theft of a car because a briefcase containing classified documents, designed to blow up if opened improperly, was still missing although the car has been recovered.

title: At the Whitney, A Vanderbilt Carries on Tradition
description: Her grandmother grew up in a palatial French Renaissance chateau at 57th Street and Fifth Avenue in New York, spending summers at The Breakers, the famous 70room Newport mansion on 12 acres overlooking the Atlantic Ocean. She crossed that ocean as casually as most of her countrymen might go across town, and was as familiar with the capitals of Europe as other children are with their own neighborhoods. But then, she was Gertrude Vanderbilt, the daughter of Cornelius, the richest man in the United States.

title: Friends of Seven Basques Report Spain to Try Them for Terrorism
description: MADRID, Nov. 5 (AP)  The Spanish Government will try seven Basque guerrillas on terrorism charges in Pamplona on Nov. 26, friends of the men report. They said the prosecution would ask for 40year sentences for three of the men and lesser terms for the other four.

title: Vote to Bar Bank Ties A Surprise
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5  The unexpected Senate approval of a sixmonth moratorium on foreign purchases of American commercial banks has both pleased and surprised the banking community.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the list of elections and candidates that appeared in the Metropolitan Report yesterday, some major contests in Nassau and Suffolk were omitted. Those contests and candidates appear on Page B7.

title: Railroad Denied Loan Guarantee
description: The Transportation Department has refused to approve a $231 million loan guarantee for the Chicago & Northwestern Railroad to build a coal line in Wyoming.

title: Hong Kong Tennis Opens As DuPre Defeats Turpin
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 5 (AP)  Pat DuPre, seeded second, beat Mark Turpin of the United States, 60, 16, 61, today in the opening round of the $75,000 Hong Kong tennis classic.

title: March Primary and Oil Aid Bills Among Those Signed in Albany
description: A bill setting March 25 for next year's Presidential primary was signed by Governor Carey yesterday, along with several other measures passed during last week's special session of the Legislature.

title: Egypt and Israel Resolving Oil Dispute, Sadat Says
description: CAIRO, Nov. 5  President Anwar elSadat said today that the dispute over how much Israel should pay for Egyptian oil was being resolved and would not delay the return of the Sinai oilfields to Egyptian sovereignty later this month.

title: A Rejection of $50,000 Is Reported
description: The director of Mario M. Cuomo's unsuccessful 1977 mayoral campaign has told the United States Attorney that he turned down a $50,000 cash contribution made on behalf of Anthony M. Scotto.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5  The Mobil Oil Corporation has agreed to pay $18.5 million in natural gas refunds and to pay the Government a civil penalty of $500,000, the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission announced today.

title: Blacks Expected to Make Gains In Election in Mississippi Today
description: JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 5  When the union won a vote to organize his tent factory, Mayor Hermit Jones of nearby Canton shut the plant down and converted into a segregated academy.

title: Bid to Buy 39% of Film Giant Stalls
description: A $190 million move by Jerry Perenchio, a West Coast television and movie producer, to purchase a 39 percent interest in Columbia Pictures Industries apparently fizzled yesterday.

title: N.B.A. Seeks a Way Out of Olympic Rules
description: The National Basketball Association's competition committee will meet today in Salt Lake City to try to devise a plan that would allow players drafted by the league in 1980 to maintain their amateur standing for the Moscow Olympics that year.

title: About New York
description: It was the night of The Game, and the play, ranging from torpor to tension, was more or less going the way it had gone on other nights of The Game for more than 40 years. The Game is an everyother Friday night session of pennyante poker and its longevity is tribute to the tenacity of New Yorkers who maintain habits of association even though they have moved from one neighborhood into another, got married, reared children and grown older  stages of life that more often than not dictate a change of friends.

title: Judge Says Rent Limits Also Apply to Garages
description: A judge has ruled that rent increases in an apartment garage are subject to the same limits as increases for apartments there, even if the garage and the building have different owners.

title: Corporate Sales and Earnings Reports
description: For periods as shown.(N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Books of The Times
description: By grace of the nonpareil translator Gregory Rabassa and the good offices of Harper & Row, we are brought now  after No One Writes to the Colonel and Other Stories, Leaf Storm and Other Stories and Innocent Erendira and Other Stories  to the very suburbs of a masterpiece. From Gabriel Garcia Mrquez's In Evil Hour, we can see his One Hundred Years of Solitude, a city of mirrors in the middle of the most intricate labyrinths of blood. The prospect dizzies.

title: First Foreign Bond Issue In 40 Years Set in Britain
description: LONDON, Nov. 5  Underwriters set the terms today for the first foreign bond issue aimed at British investors in 40 years, a deal many think will lead to a large amount of new securities business for London, at some cost to New York.

title: Jersey Senator Said to Have $1 Million in Swiss Bank
description: NEWARK, Nov. 5  State Senator David J. Friedland and his father, Jacob, have a coded Swiss Bank account containing more than $1 million, the United States Attorney's office contended today at the arraignment of the two on extortion charges in Federal District Court here.

title: Want a Party? Pick a Slogan
description: It's easy to have a party in New Jersey. If you are against lawyers, you can form the Down With Lawyers Party. If you feel truly independent, form the Uncommitted and Unbossed Party.

title: Pistols and the Presidency
description: More than 6,000 Americans have been killed by handguns this year. The power of the gun lobby makes it politically impossible, however, to pass serious controls over the 50 million pistols now in private hands. That is why Senator Kennedy has introduced a modest piece of legislation that would at least help control the manufacture and sale of still more handguns. Political rivalries notwithstanding, we urge President Carter to lend his support to the Kennedy bill.

title: The City.
description: Two Queens teenagers pleaded guilty yesterday to murdering two token clerks by setting their booth afire Jan. 16.

title: For One Jury, the Trial Is in the Waiting
description: Seven people stood nervously in a semicircle around the desk of the New York County Clerk in lower Manhattan. All had waited nearly two hours for a chance to explain why they should be excused from jury duty.

title: No Checking Was Done On Chesimard Visitors
description: The bogus names and addresses on a prison visitors list used by three gunmen to gain entry to a New Jersey prison and help Joanne Chesimard escape last Friday were not verified when the black militant leader, considered a high security risk by penal officials, provided them, the state's Corrections Department disclosed yesterday.

title: British Wholesale Prices
description: LONDON, Nov. 5 (AP)  The prices that producers received for manufactured goods in Britain rose 1 percent in October, putting them 14.9 percent higher than in October 1978, the Department of Industry reported today.

title: Election Day Choices
description: The polls in New York will be open today from A.M. to 9 P.M. There are few dramatic candidate contests but some significant issues. These include proposition to let the state borrow $500 million to improve mass transit, rail and highway facilities. In Connecticut, where mayors will be elected in major cities,

title: 4Year TaxCut Plan To Buoy the Economy Is Outlined by Baker
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., sketching an outline of his economic program as a Presidential candidate, called today for a fouryear plan of tax cuts to stimulate investment and higher productivity and inject noninflationary growth back into the American economy.

title: Theater: Rice and Beans
description: THE setting for Hector Quintern's domestic comedy Rice and Beans whose remaining performances will be given at Intar from Thursday through next Sunday, is Havana just before the Castro revolution. But it could just as well have been Brooklyn, Harlem, or India for that matter. Its theme  that of a workingclass mother obsessively ambitious for her children  must be as common a theatrical idea as can be found.

title: Beatha
description: MOSESBERNARDThe membership of East Midwood Jewish Center mourns the passing of our esteemed member Bernard Moses, beloved husband of Golda. We extend our heartfelt sympathy & condolences to the bereaved family.

title: Embassy Security Poses New Problem for the U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5  America's embassies are largely unprepared to face unexpected violent mob action directed against them in countries where local governments are too weak, or unwilling, to effectively defend the embassy.

title: Science Watch
description: Scientists have long been puzzled by a strange trait of locusts  the kind that sometimes grow in such vast numbers as to constitute cropendangering plagues.

description: His wife was at the hairdresser's last Thursday when Chris Chambliss got the phone call from Cedric Tallis of the Yankees front office. But when Audrey Chambliss returned to their home in Upper Saddle River, N.J., she realized from the look on her husband's face that something had happened. Something bad.

title: 9th Marine in Fire Dies
description: SAN ANTONIO, Nov. 5(AP)  A severely burned United States marine has died at Brooke Army Medical Center here, raising the death toll to nine in a freak fire last month during a typhoon at a Japanese base, officials announced today. They identified the latest victim as Lance Cpl. Orlando E. Sandoval, 20 years old, of Pueblo, Col. More than 70 young marines were burned last month when Typhoon Tip damaged a rubber fuel tank, sending 5,000 gallons of burning gasoline into a marine barracks area.

title: IN THE NATION
description: A leading Western diplomat wondered in private conversation last week whether it might not be time for the United States to lead an invasion of generosity into starving Cambodia.

description: VIRGINIA BEACH, Va., Nov. 5 (AP) The Navy said today that the prototype for its F18 Hornet fighter jet was damaged over the weekend when part of its landing gear collapsed after the plane landed at the Oceana Naval Air Station. A Navy spokesman said that the McDonnell Douglas jet, with Lieut. Comdr. Dick

title: From Federal Agencies, Gift Bargains of Books, Maps, Prints and Posters
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 It may not give you a gallon of heating oil, or a tax rebate, or even a Christmas goose, but if you're looking for inexpensive and original Christmas gifts, the Federal Government is no Scrooge.

title: F.Y.I
description: Al Zuckerman, a New York literary agent, once tried to interest a publisher in a book about life at a Hindu commune, written by a young, woman who had lived at one. Zuckerman thought he had the book sold.

title: Threat of Bid for Pennsy
description: The Reliance Group, a diversified financial services conglomerate that is also the largest single shareholder of the reorganized Penn Central Company, notified the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday that it might seek control of Penn Central if the former railroad company proceeds with a stock swap to acquire Marathon Manufacturing.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Further signs of unrest in Iran, rising oil prices and a somewhat stronger dollar provided the backdrop for trading in precious metals yesterday. Trading is expected to be slow today because of the Election Day bank closings. But all major futures markets will be open.

description: HARTFORD  We have not quit  we ain't hardly begun, said Edward J. Stockton, Connecticut's Commissioner of Economic Development.

title: Supreme Court to Rule on Oil Spills; Could Fifth Amendment Block Fines?
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5  The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the constitutional protection against selfincrimination could be invoked by persons required under the Federal Clean Water Act to pay for cleaning up oil spills.

title: Pope Pledges to Tell Cardinals of Vatican Finances
description: ROME, Nov. 5 Pope John Paul II opened an unusual meeting of 120 Roman Catholic cardinals today with a pledge to consult them regularly and fully on important church decisions.

title: Clothing Workers Union Is Struck By 121 Members of a Staff Union
description: The Clothing and Textile Workers of America, a 500,000member affiliate of the A.F.L.C.I.O., was struck yesterday as a minority of an independent union representing its staff objected to a new contract.

title: G.M. Declares Dividend of $1.50
description: DETROIT, Nov. 5  Directors of the General Motors Corporation, which reported a 95.9 percent decline in net income in the third quarter, today declared a yearend dividend of $1.50 payable Dec. 10 to stockholders of record Nov. 15. This compared with $2.50 paid to shareholders in last year's fourth quarter.

title: Chrysler Aid Issue: Growing US. Role
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5  In announcing the Carter Administration's support for $1.5 billion in Federal loan guarantees to help save the Chrysler Corporation, G. William Miller, Secretary of the Treasury, called the Chrysler crisis a unique situation, and reiterated the Administration's basic philosophical opposition to Government financial intervention in the private sector.

Everybody seemed to be there, from Joseph Fuchs and Itzhak Perlman down to every orchestra violinist in town who had a free night, and every young violinist out of Juilliard, Curtis or wherever.

title: U.S. Confident on Decision
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5  American officials said today that they were confident that the Western allies would agree to the deployment of the new missiles. At the same time, they said there was growing support for coupling the decision with the withdrawal of up to 1,000 existing missiles from Western Europe.

title: Cambodians Protest at the U.N.
description: Cambodian exiles wearing black armbands stood silently with bowed heads outside the United Nations enclave yesterday to dramatize the plight of their starving countrymen and then joined in appealing to the world community to rush emergency food relief to Cambodia.

title: Tragedy on the Fringe
description: There was a photograph in The Times Sunday showing five white men in Greensboro, N.C., lifting rifles and shotguns from a car. They looked like deer hunters on a cool November day. But what went on in that town last Saturday was not deer hunting. Some Klansmen and Nazis, members of the violent fringe, killed five people. The victims were from another fringe, the Marxist left. They were members of the Communist Workers Party U.S.A. and they believed that provoking violence from the Klan might promote socialist revolution. Their slogan was Death to the Klan. It would have been hard, on the basis only of such rhetorical violence, for the police to deny them a parade permit. Yet by allowing them to march, the police created a special responsibility to keep the peace. Not only did the police not take any special precautions; they actually withdrew from the scene. Their excuse was that the marchers did not want protection. But society and the law demand protection in such circumstances. Once the permit was issued, the police should have been on hand, whether they were wanted or not. They might have saved lives.

title: MCA Net Drops 11.6% in Quarter
description: MCA Inc. yesterday reported that its thirdquarter net income fell 11.6 percent to $41 million, or $1.75 a share, from $46.4 million, or $2 a share, in the comparable three months last year.

title: Fields's Snap Key to Jet Attack
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 5  It turns out that the man the Jets miss more than Wesley Walker, the glamorous wide receiver, is Joe Fields, who olavs the bluecollar position of center.

title: KOREAN REPORT SAYS PARK KILLED IN COUP
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Tuesday, Nov. 6  An official report on the assassination of President Park Chung Hee prepared by Martial Law Command investigators and released today said he was shot at close range with a pistol by Kim Jae Kyu, the Korean Central Intelligence Director, as the first step of an attempted coup.

title: Soviet Crop Chaos: View From the Inside
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 5  In 1975, the Soviet Union had a disastrous grain harvest of 140 million metric tons and set off on an international buying spree that drove American food prices sharply higher. This year, the crop has again suffered from drought and the United States Agriculture Department estimates that only 175 million metric tons are being gathered. again suffered from drought and the United States Agriculture Department estimates that only 175 million metric tons are being gathered.

title: Method Used in Times/CBS Poll
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted from Oct. 29 to Nov. 3 with 1,385 adult men and women around the United States. Of this total, 465 said that they were Democrats, 453 Republicans and 467 independents.

title: Court Told Scotto Got Cash for Cuomo Drive
description: Louis Valentino, a state official who worked in the 1977 New York City mayoral campaign of Mario M. Cuomo, now Lieutenant Governor, testified yesterday that he had picked up a $50,000 cash contribution to the Cuomo campaign that had been arranged by Anthony M. Scotto.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5  Robert S. Strauss, President Carter's special Mideast negotiator, will leave his diplomatic post to head Mr. Carter's reelection campaign, a campaign source said tonight.

description: In the Metropolitan Report yesterday, the following major contests were omitted from a list of candidates in today's election:

title: Panel to Weigh Closing Reactors Near Big Cities
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5  The Nuclear Regulatory Commission will have to determine whether some of the nation's 72 operating reactors might have to be closed because of their proximity to population centers such as New York City and Chicago, its chairman said today in response to Congressional questioning.

title: 6 Reported Dead in Sudan Clash
description: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Nov. 5 (AP)  Six persons were killed and 50 wounded in a clash in southeastern Sudan between Ethiopian refugees and West African immigrants, Governmentcontrolled newspapers here reported today. The fighting broke out Friday, for reasons as yet unknown.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5  The Senate opened debate today on a major national commitment to reduce reliance on imported oil by subsidizing the development by private industry of extensive new output of synthetic fuels.

description: Ayoung science called biomechanics is proving its ability to solve some difficult and unusual problems in biology, medicine and even sports.

description: TOKYO, Tuesday, Nov. 6  Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira won reelection today in a special House of Representatives ballot, defeating his Liberal Democratic Party rival, Takeo Fukuda.

Philip Braniff, coordinator for high school and junior college relations at Manhattan College since 1972, died Sunday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Yonkers following a brief illness. title: Pakistan Hangs Man for Attempt To Hijack a Boeing 747 in 1978
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 5 (AP) A Pakistani who tried to hijack a Pakistani Boeing 747 was hanged today at the Central Jail in Rawalpindi. He was the first hijacker to be executed in Pakistan.

title: OCTOBER AUTO SALES OFF MORE THAN 20% AT BIG 3 PRODUCERS
description: DETROIT, Nov. 5  The Big Three auto makers reported today that their total domestic sales of new cars fell by more than 20 percent last month, making October their worst sales month so far this year.

title: Notes on People
description: Richard N. Goodwin first got involved in politics as a speech writer for John F. Kennedy, and he helped shape some of the more important themes of the Administrations of Presidents Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson.

title: Film: 'The Fish' Offers A Galaxy of Big Names
description: A RECORD number of athletes and singers and comedians turn up in "The Fish That Saved Pittsburgh," and still this feels like a movie with nothing going on. The premise, which needed to be outrageous, is merely amiable. The cast is too enormous for individual players to make strong impressions. The tenor of the whole enterprise is tame. The soundtrack music is excellent, but you could listen to that at home.The movie's big joke would have been funnier a few years ago. Julius Erving, a.k.a. Dr. J, is cast as  here's a big surprise  a basketball star. And he's stuck on a losing team. Then the team's nice water boy (James Bond 3d) recommends a nice astrologer (Stockard Channing), and she recommends that he play with teammates who all share the same sign, so the Pittsburgh Pisces are born. Dr. J, who is also seen falling in love with the water boy's sister, does a capable job with his acting duties, as do the other basketball ringers, among them Meadowlark Lemon and Kareem Abdul-Jabbar.Astrology isn't the hot topic it used to be, and in any case the screenplay doesn't put it to much use. And the grand, gaudy sequence in which the Pisces appear for their end-of-the-movie game is somehow lacking in comic bravado  bravado like that of Bill Cosby and Sidney Poitier in their "Let's Do It Again" pimp outfits, for example. There's nothing in this present film, save of course for Mr. Erving's way with a slam-dunk, that doesn't seem to have been done better in another movie long ago.Still, "The Fish That Saved Pittsburgh," which opens today at the National and other theaters, isn't aimed at audiences with much of a memory. It's cheerfully inoffensive entertainment designed for the crowd that liked "Car Wash," with which one of the present film's producers was also involved, and it offers a similarly shapeless brand of merriment.There are some good individual performances, by Mr. Lemon, Mr. Bond, M. Emmet Walsh, Dee Dee Bridgewater, Debra Allen, that don't last long enough to get going. There are hits-to-be written and produced by Thom Bell, and recorded by the Sylvers and the Spinners, among others. There is enough basketball footage to keep the fans' attention from wandering. There's nothing much to remember, and nothing to complain about either.Stockard Channing, Flip Wilson and Jonathan Winters may sound like the movie's big guns as far as comedy is concerned, but each of them gives a flat performance. None of them fits comfortably into the movie, and none of them has been given material worth working with. Mr. Winters has made so few movie appearances in recent years that he may strike younger viewers as a strange fellow who does a not-bad Robin Williams imitation. That's a discouraging thought."The Fish That Saved Pittsburgh" is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"). It contains a few instances of vulgar language.

title: Shoes From Italy Stir Protest
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5  Special Trade Representative Reubin O. Askew has complained to the European Common Market about rising shoe imports from Italy as shoe workers press the White House for new trade relief to preserve jobs.

title: Oilers Turn Back Dolphins in Battle Of Field Goals, 96
description: MIAMI, Nov. 5 (AP)  Two longrange kickers dueled from between 32 and 51 yards out tonight as the Houston Oilers defeated the Miami Dolphins, 96.

title: Funeral for Slain Westchester Officer
description: Honor guard marched ahead of hearse carrying coffin of Kieran Grant after funeral at Church of St. Columbanus in Peekskill. Mr. Grant, a sheriff's deputy, was shot while serving an eviction notice on a Hastings, N.Y., resident.

title: The Record Is All
description: OXFORD, Ohio  As the Presidentialnomination season draws nigh, we will relearn what many observers have long recognized: major Republican contenders make essentially the same speech, a speech that has remained relatively constant since World War II. Its message: We need lower taxes, less Federal spending, less bureaucratic meddling, a bigger military budget, a tougher stance toward the Soviet Union. This may, or may not, be valid message, but one thing is sure: It almost never changes.

title: Jaws, on ABCTV, Overwhelms Rivals
description: In its ABCTV presentation Sunday night, Jaws so overwhelmed its competition in the overnight Nielsen ratings for New York, Los Angeles and Chicago that network analysts believe it may surpass Gone With the Wind as the highestrated televised movie.

title: Piano: Leslie Howard
description: LESLIE HOWARD is an Australian pianist with a sizable, dependable technique who plays with daring and obviously enjoys producing big sonorities. If this sounds like someone who might be a natural proponent of Liszt's piano music, so be it: at his Carnegie Recital Hall program on Sunday afternoon, Mr. Howard took on the complete Transcendental Etudes of Liszt, prefacing this fingerbreaking assignment with Beethoven's Six Variations on an Original Theme (Op. 34). A day's work, no matter who the pianist might be.

title: Program Suggests Ways to Lengthen Lives
description: ATLANTA

title: Deaths
description: SINGERFrances Beloved wife of David. Loving mother of Carolyn and Judith. Beloved sister of Mortlmer and Priscilla. Funeral services Wednesday, November 7, 9:30AM at I. J. Morris, Inc. Funeral Home, 1895 Flatbush Ave, (1 block north of Kings Highway), Bkiyn.

title: Another Gallstone Found in Shah; Surgery Possible
description: Physicians treating the deposed Shah of Iran have found another gallstone in his bile duct and might have to operate again to remove it, according to an announcement from the New York HospitalCornell Medical Center. The Shah is recovering there from surgery last month in which his gallbladder was removed.

title: BREZHNEV PROPOSES MISSILE PARLEY NOW
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 5  Leonid I. Brezhnev, elaborating on an offer to reduce missile forces aimed at Western Europe if the Atlantic alliance did not deploy new American missiles, said today that the Soviet Union was prepared to begin negotiations without delay.

title: Spinks Returning Under Don King
description: Leon Spinks, last seen four months ago being knocked out in the first round by Genie Coetzee, will resurface here tomorrow under Don King's direction. The promoter will announce that he has signed Spinks, the only active heavyweight to have beaten Muhammad Ali, to a threefight contract.

title: Sale of Mets Is Broached At Stockholders Meeting
description: The sale of the New York Mets moved a step closer yesterday when the possibilities were explored at the annual meeting of the team's stockholders.

title: Man Ray Painting Brings $750,000
description: A Man Ray painting of giant red lips over a landscape sold last night for $750,000, the highest price ever paid at auction for a surrealist painting and three times the previous record for such art.

title: Kuwait Raises Gas Prices
description: KUWAIT, Nov. 5 (UPI)  Kuwait announced today that it had increased the prices of its liquefied petroleum gas, retroactive to Nov. 1.

title: Kennedy to Fight Carter On Synthetic Fuel Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6  Senator Edward M. Kennedy, who will announce his Presidential candidacy tomorrow, has decided to supplement his political challenge to President Carter with a broad attack in Congress on the President's energy policies.

title: Books: A Woman's Story of Sailing the Globe Solo
description: NAOMI JAMES grew up on a remote New Zealand farm and later, after becoming disenchanted with school, became a hairdresser. In search of wider ALONE AROUND THE WORLD. By Naomi James. 192 pages. Coward, McCann & Geoghegan. $9.95. horizons, she left New Zealand at the age of 21 and wandered across Europe, holding jobs as a waitress, hairdresser and language instructor.

title: Utilities Warn on Delayed Plants
description: Utility companies constructing nuclear power plants in New Jersey, in Connecticut and on Long Island expressed disappointed yesterday over the Nuclear Regulatory Commission's decision to continue its ireeze on operating permits for new reactors for at least six months and possibly for as long as two years.

title: Careers
description: Working To Improve Output Rate

title: Letters
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Worries of Mortgage Trading
description: The recent sharp rise in interest rates has set the stage for devastating losses in the mortgage market, where hundreds of millions of dollars of securities backed by home mortgages are traded every day.

title: 150 Parties to Pay Full Mail Rates
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (UPI)  The Postal Board of Governors decided today to inform about 150 minor political parties across the nation that they would not be eligible for reduced mail rates unless Congress provided more postal subsidies.

title: Holiday Closings
description: Some banks were open and some closed yesterday, Election Day. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York was closed, while the stock exchanges and corporate bond markets were open. Markets in Government bonds were closed.

title: Samuel Sandmel
description: Dr. Samuel Sandmel, whose New Testament scholarship and unusual teaching skills fostered striking advances in the field of JewishChristian relations, died Sunday night in Jewish Hospital in Cincinnati after a long illness. He was 68 years old.

title: Confiscation Proposed To Curb Street Vendors
description: If Bruce C. Ratner, New York City's Commissioner of Consumer Affairs, gets his way, street vendors caught selling their wares at certain places and times will have their goods confiscated by the police.

title: For Spring, Fashions That Transcend Fashion
description: GEOFFREY BEENE has reached the point where he has transcended fashion. He is no longer concerned with making a statement. Using the best fabrics at his command, which means a good portion from Italy, in the prettiest colors he can assemble, he concerns himself with making clothes that women can not only feel secure in but feel comfortable with as well.

title: Theater: The Cavern
description: IN the plays of Jean Anouilh, actors are often called upon to play two roles, one of them presumably in life, the other in theater. That interaction between reality and illusion is the author's continuing obsession in works such as The Rehearsal, Poor Bitos and The Cavern (La Grotte), which is having its first New York engagement at the CSC Repertory. Compared to Anouilh's other plays in a similar vein, The Cavern, written in 1961, is distinctly a minor effort. It wears the mask of a murder mystery. The primary question would seem to be, who killed the cook?

title: P.L.O. Says a Group Is Being Sent to Iran To Aid U.S. Hostages
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 6 The Palestine Liberation Organization announced tonight that it would send a delegation to Teheran tomorrow to seek the release of the American hostages held in the United States Embassy there.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: LIGHTBULB jokes. We love them because there is no end to them; because they are easy to invent; because they permit us to indulge our most intense political, personal and ethnic frustrations, and because they are the current embodiment of former epidemics of drollery. You know, like goodnewsbadnews jokes, elephant iokes and grape jokes. A few of the lightbulb jokes, especially those involving Californians and WASPs, are overly familiar by now. So is the glowing How many psychiatrists does it take to change a light bulb? (One, but the light bulb has to really want to be changed), as well as the memorable How many Jewish mothers does it take to change a light bulb? (None: It's all right, I'll sit in the dark.) There are still plenty of dazzlers around, however, and here are the most incandescent of them:

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Film: Bette Midler in 'The Rose':Music-World Portrait
description: BY the time you realize what's wrong with "The Rose," it will have you hooked anyhow. There are so many finely drawn episodes, so much brittle, raunchy humor, and such an unexpectedly alluring performance from Bette Midler in the title role that the movie maintains its momentum even after it's gone off the track. Its strengths may only be those of a good show-business soap opera, and its structure is disjointed beyond repair. But "The Rose" has an earnest, affecting character at its core. Even at its most preposterous, it never feels like a fraud."The Rose," which opens at the Ziegfeld today, seems to have been conceived as both a vehicle for Miss Midler and a way to tell a story like Janis Joplin's. So The Rose  who shares The Divine Miss M's odd habit of incorporating an article into her nickname  emerges as a creature of many contradictions. Although the story is supposedly set in 1969, Miss Midler is so thoroughly a product of the 70's that it becomes hard for her to handle certain aspects of the tale, notably those having to do with Rose's hippie abandon and her essential fragility. Miss Midler herself seems about as fragile as a bull elephant, no matter how stridently the screenplay insists that she eventually self-destruct.This screenplay, which takes the form of a crazy flashback, introduces Rose as a hard-living but weary performer who is agitating for a year's rest as the story begins. However, her manager, played with a fine ruthlessness by Alan Bates, is not a man who believes in allowing his meal ticket to take vacations. So Rose embarks on a series of spiteful, funny escapades, which seem to serve as both distress signals and her only way of letting off steam.Frederic Forrest, who would be the surprise hit of the movie if Miss Midler didn't herself have dibs on that position, plays a chauffeur whom Rose kidnaps on one particularly trying evening. And he has a sweet, stirring exchange with her when she finally hauls him back to her hotel at dawn. He pauses on the front steps to describe an adventure he once had on a Western river, but only one detail interests her. "Were you really," she asks with genuine astonishment, "alone for six days?"The early part of the story, which is at its most involving in the lengthy sequence that launches this romance, also presents a withering portrait of the music world  much nastier than the image offered by Barbra Streisand's "A Star Is Born," a movie "The Rose" resembles in its general blowsiness and enormous scale. One of the most memorable scenes has Rose barging, with an excess of flamboyance, into the dressing room of a country star, superbly played by Harry Dean Stanton. He winds up snubbing her with a cruelty that corresponds, perversely yet perfectly, to her own good-timey style of aggression.But Rose, though temporarily daunted, is still someone who'll crash any party. In fact, her feistiness emerges as one of her most lovable attributes. During this section of the film, she is also seen marching into a homosexual nightclub, a men's bathhouse and a truck-stop restaurant, where a nervous waitress tells her "We don't serve hippies." "Well, that's okay," smirks Rose, who loves rising to such occasions, "cause we don't eat 'em, neither."These incidents don't have much to do with one another, but they have a certain emotional coherence that is sorely missed once the screenplay begins burying Rose alive. By the time her demurely dressed lesbian lover appears on the scene, it has become painfully clear that if the kitchen sink could walk, somebody would have written it an entrance line, too. Rose's former heroin habit, and her high school misadventure with an entire football team, are suddenly brought into the act, paving the way for a finale that will amaze amateur pharmacologists everywhere. Rose combines heroin and pills into a miraculous potion that, somehow, allows her to belt out a song at the top of her lungs before dying an arty death only seconds later.Mark Rydell's direction, which has been unobtrusively effective until this point, suddenly turns the movie into something very like a wrestling match. Miss Midler succeeds beautifully in giving her character depth and dimension; she may even be a better actress than a singer, on the evidence of her first film role. But she cannot seem to muster the requisite pathos, and after a while one begins wondering why she should. "The Rose" may have four-hanky aspirations as a weeper, but Miss Midler has a vitality that belies all that, and makes the gloomy-ending machinations look ridiculous. It's much to her credit that she doesn't go down without a fight."The Rose," which finally becomes paralyzed by the discrepancies between its actress and her character, is full of wall-to-wall anachronisms. If anything, the setting seems more like the present than like 1969  a year, if the movie is to be believed, without psychedelia, hippies, a war, long hair or short dresses. It is also a year without much rock-and-roll, since Miss Midler's singing, however ably it serves the movie's purposes, remains something of a different era.

title: Vietnamese Says Army Will Stay In Cambodia Till Regime Is Firm
description: MANILA, Nov. 6, Vietnam's Ambassador to the Philippines said today that Vietnamese troops would withdraw from Cambodia only when the Heng Samrin regime there was strong enough to defend the country. He denied that Vietnam had aggressive intentions against Thailand or any other Southeast Asian country.

title: Mrs. Carter Off Today on a Trip To Refugee Camps in Thailand
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6  The White House announced today that Rosalynn Carter will leave for Thailand tomorrow for a fourday visit to observe first hand the plight of refugees who have fled Cambodia and investigate the difficulties hobbling the international efforts to relieve massive starvation there.

title: Searching for the OldFashioned Doughnut
description: THE doughnut that America once knew and loved is apparently on its way to becoming an extinct species. Even the word doughnut has been downgraded to donut  in the rush to find a cheaper, faster way to make the popular pastry.

title: Israel Savings Shift Cited
description: TEL AVIV, Nov 6  A pending change of finance ministers in the Israeli Government has spurred the transfer of savings from state bonds to foreign currency bank notes, apparently for hoarding, according to sources in the Bank of Israel.

title: Putting Steel Into
description: WASHINGTON  In the United States, when we talk about energy problems, we say conserve and produce. But in Bonn and in Tokyo, they say conserve and then go on to talk about exporting manufactured goods. The West Germans and Japanese have had the ironic fortune of too few policy alternatives. Their limited energy resources have forced them to meet their higher energy costs by exporting. Their conserveandexport approach has contributed to trade surpluses, strong currencies, low inflation and relatively low unemployment and high growth in productivity. At the same time, we face persistent balanceoftrade and balanceofpayments deficits, a weak dollar, inflation, persistent unemployment and everlower rates of growth in productivity.

title: Shah's Family Dismisses Demands by Ayatollah
description: A spokesman for the family of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi said yesterday that the family was not worried by the demand of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini that the Shah be turned over to Iran.

title: An Election Day Issue: Where to Put the Gold
description: Election Day in New York posed a special problem for a Dutch businessman with a trunkful of glittering dinnerware destined for a new jewelry store in Washington.

title: CARTER SAID TO ASK FOR LOYALTY CHECK OF AIDES ON POLITICS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6  President Carter instructed his Cabinet officers last night to check the political dependability of their subordinates and strongly implied that those who were not prepared to campaign actively in his behalf should be dismissed, White House sources said today.

title: Green Defeats Former Prosecutor In Race for Mayor of Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6  William J. Green was elected Mayor of Philadelphia today, winning by a majority in a threecandidate race and running almost as well in the black neighborhoods that had shunned him in the Democratic primary.

title: A Detective Story With Female Leads
description: The street is a deserted one in the South Bronx; the social club, a single dingy room lighted by purple neon lights. It is 10 P.M. and a woman, neatly dressed in black pants and a denim jacket, enters the club and walks briskly past the jukebox. At first there are wisecracks from the men at the pool table, but then they recognize her and fall silent.

title: Watson and May Agree to Contracts With the Yankees
description: Bob Watson and Rudy May, as expected, have become George Steinbrenner's latest Yankee freeagent acquisitions, joining an evergrowing list that began with Catfish Hunter five years ago.

title: Two New Studies
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 6 (AP)  Seventyfive percent of all breast cancers can be detected by a combination of physical examination by a doctor and mammography, a radiation screening technique, researchers report.

title: IRAN'S CIVIL GOVERNMENT OUT; HOSTAGES FACE DEATH THREAT; OIL EXPORTS BELIEVED HALTED
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 6  Prime Minister Mehdi Bazargan's provisional revolutionary Government dissolved today, conceding power to the Islamic authority of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.

title: Limits on Spending and Busing Voted in California
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 6  California's voters went conservative today, approving a constitutional amendment that will limit growth in government budgets and another that will limit the power of state court judges to order busing of students to achieve racial balance in schools.

title: More Hearings Ordered On a Container Ruling
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (UPI)  A Federal appellate court said today that the Food and Drug Administration must conduct further hearings on its ban of certain unbreakable beverage containers.

title: Italian Wages Rise
description: ROME, Nov. 6 (AP)  Italy's wage escalator, which is used to set wages and is based on the cost of living, was raised by a record 8 points for the quarter beginning Nov. 1, the Government said today. This means a monthly pay increase of $22.90 for Italian workers.

title: Goodrich Expanding Plant in Indiana
description: AKRON, Ohio, Nov. 6 (AP)  The B.F. Goodrich Company said today that it planned to expand radial tire capacity at its plant in Woodburn, Ind., creating 240 new jobs over the next two years.

title: Bank to Buy Back Notes, S.E.C. Says
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) The State National Bank of Maryland has agreed to buy back oneyear $1,000 promissory notes that investors may have believed were Governmentbacked bonds, the Securities and Exchange Commission said today.

title: A Correction
description: In a recent article on Brie cheese (The Best of Brie: What to Look For, Oct. 3, 1979), the province where Brie originated was incorrectly identified. Brie originated in the province of Seine et Marne, in the area known as the Pays de Brie and is most closely identified with the towns of Melun and Meaux.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Mexico Nearer GATT Entry
description: GENEVA, Nov. 6  The way was cleared here today for Mexico to become a member of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the 84nation organization that sets rules for the conduct of world commerce.

title: News of the Theater Geraldine Fitzgerald Heads for Broadway
description: GERALDINE FITZGERALD, who has been touring much of the last year in her onewoman show of Irish songs, has just agreed to do a new Broadway play. She will star in the title role in Eve by Larry Feinberg. The play will be directed by Craig Anderson and produced by Terry Allen Kramer and Harry Rigby. Plans call for outoftown tryouts in Philadelphia and Knoxville, Tenn., before a Broadway opening this winter.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: A Federal court judge ruled yesterday that Bausch & Lomb Inc. had infringed on a valid patent for strengthening the glass in eyeglass lenses and that it must pay damages to the patentholder and licenser.

title: Topics
description: Universal

title: New F.D.A. Chief, a Pharmacist, Vows Fight to Cut the Use of Drugs
description: WASHINGTON, Nov, 6  The first pharmacist ever to head the Food and Drug Administration believes that Americans use too many prescription drugs and says he is determined to use his new cost to persuade them to cut down.

title: World News Briefs
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 6 (AP)  Prime Minister Joe Clark's fivemonthold minority Government defeated a noconfidence motion in the House of Commons by a vote of 140 to 138 tonight with the help of the 5 Social Credit Party members.

title: Personal Health
description: MRS. W., a 75yearold widow has been eating haphazardly since her husband died a year ago. Practically every day for half a century, she had eaten breakfast and dinner with him, wellbalanced meals that she prepared on weekdays, he on weekends.

title: Private Lives
description: WE were invited to lunch to meet The Novelist. With his gray curls, his blue eyes, his blue suit and the tie leaping out like a spurt of blood, he looked in shape, trim and ready, about to zap us with the telepathic logic of the unconscious. From lunch, he would be on his way to the various television studios, where they wanted him to make a fool of himself. He was determined not to make a fool of himself. He drank water. We wished for him a string of Iroquois arrowheads, like Greek worry beads, to finger.

title: Carter Campaign Head in Florida Offers to List Kennedy on Ballot
description: CLEARWATER, Fla., Nov. 6 (AP) President Carter's Florida campaign manager says the Carter forces will put Senator Edward M. Kennedy's name on the presidential straw ballot at next week's Democratic State Convention if Mr. Kennedy's supporters do not.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: Mayor White Is Easily Reelected In Boston for 4th Successive Term
description: BOSTON, Nov. 6  Mayor Kevin H. White, who less than five years ago was mapping out the beginnings of a campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination, tonight won an easy reelection victory over State Senator Joseph F. Timilty that will keep him in City Hall here for four more years.

title: Soviet Oil Output: Peak Seen for 1980
description: TOKYO, Nov. 6 (UPI)  Oil production in the Soviet Union will peak next year and then decline gradually, forcing the country to become a major oil importer by 1990, a world economic organization predicted today.

title: Money
description: There will be no Money Rates today due to Election Day holiday.

title: Victorious Japanese Premier Will Seek Party Unity
description: TOKYO, Nov. 6  Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira won a showdown vote against a persistent party rival in a special session of Parliament today and said he would immediately begin trying to repair damage done to the party.

title: PrenticeHall Profits Improve
description: PrenticeHall, a publisher of books, reported improved third quarter profits yesterday following flat results in the second quarter.

title: Environmentalists in Bonn Plan a National Party
description: BONN, Nov. 6 Environmentalist groups encouraged by recent local successes have set up machinery for a national political party whose probable entry into the 1980 general election is regarded as a significant factor in determining the next West German government.

title: Entertainment Events
description: DEVOUR THE SNOW, a play by Abe Polsky; directed by Terry Schreiber; starring Jon DeVries and Stephen Joyce. At the Golden Theater, 252 West 45th Street, 6:30.

title: After Party for a Bank, Boat Can't Float Alone
description: The Bank of America's 75th anniversary party was going strong Monday night on the Binghamton, a floating restaurant moored in Edgewater, N.J., and by 10 P.M., the 783 bank employees and companions were crowded at the ship's rails watching a display of fireworks.

title: Interior Dept. Assailed On Missing a Deadline For Species Protection
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6  To the dismay and anger of environmentalists, about 1,700 plants and a hundred animals are being dropped from consideration for protection as endangered species because a deadline Congress set a year ago for Interior Department action is about to pass.

title: EDITH WEINGARTEN
description: Edith Weingarten, chief of occupational therapy for the last 28 years at the Kings County Psychiatric Center in Brooklyn, died in her sleep yesterday at her home in Manhattan. She was 55 years old.

title: U.S. Advises Return Of Workers From Iran
description: The State Department said last night that it was advising all companies with American personnel still in Iran to move them out in an orderly and quiet fashion.

title: Police in Moscow Intercept Two Seeking to Enter U.S. Embassy
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 6 (Reuters)  The Soviet police detained a man and a woman who tried to enter the United States Embassy today and carried the woman away screaming, American witnesses said. The two, whose identities were not known, apparently were Soviet citizens.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Gov. Ray May Reopen Nuclear Waste Site if Enforcement Is Stricter
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (UPI)  Gov. Dixy Lee Ray of Washington said today that she might reopen her state's lowlevel nuclear waste disposal site in a matter of days if Federal officials cracked down on sloppy waste shipments.

title: Muslim Group at Columbia Urges Release of U.S. Hostages in Iran
description: A spokesman for the Muslim Students Association of Columbia University said last night that it had sent a statement to Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini urging that American hostages in Iran be released.

title: Best Buys
description: HIGHER meat and grain prices raised the New York City market basket to $88.30 last week, a 32cent increase over the previous week's level. According to the Department of Consumer Affairs, the cost of feeding a family of four in New York City, based on a 41item list of food products, was 6.2 percent higher than a year earlier.

title: Installment Credit in Peak Surge
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6  Consumer installment credit soared by a record $4.45 billion in September, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, underscoring one of the key forces behind the dramatic credittightening moves of Oct. 6.

title: TV: The Suicide's Wife Has Strong Guilt Feelings
description: HAVING failed to get tenure after nine years at various branches of the University of California, and having had to have his book published by a vanity press, the assistant professor played by Peter Donat in The Suicide's Wife ends it all.

title: Los Angeles Comes of Age in French Cuisine
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Times Co. Fills New Position
description: Leonard R. Harris has been appointed to the newly created position of director of corporate relations and public affairs of The New York Times Company, it was announced yesterday by Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, its chairman.

title: Economic Scene
description: Inflation Views Of Candidates

title: The U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: GOING OUT
description: FOOD FOR THOUGHT This is the fourth year of open forums on criminal justice, free to the public and sponsored by the Fortune Society. The subject of tonight's session at 7:30 is Teenage Prostitution. Panel participants are two female former offenders who are now staff members of the society, and Judge Margaret Taylor. The place is Calvary House, 61 Gramercy Park North, at 21st Street. More information: 6774600.

title: Stamford Cultural Center Gaining
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 6 Plans for a cultural center in Stamford's downtown urban renewal area took a major step toward realization today when two large corporations and the leading real estate developer here jointly purchased a row of buildings as the site of the center.

title: G.O.P. Dinners Raise $1 Million In New York and 4 Other Cities
description: Republicans raised a bit less than $1 million at countdown to victory dinners in five major cities last night, but party leaders were disappointed in the amount and some suggested John B. Connally's presence might have cut the crowd in New York.

title: N.H.L. to Meadowlands?
