In the last few years, Mr.Lombardo has hidden about 100 television sets behind twoway,or transparent, mirrors located over fireplaces, bureaus and wherever else there was space for a builtin set.

title: Hers
description: IHAVEN'T yet gotten the taste of bluefish out of my mouth and already friends are asking me to share a house with them in the Hamptons next summer. But what about the people you shared with this year? I ask.

title: MontedisonBerardi Deal
description: Milan, Nov. 7 (Reuters)  Montedison S.p.A said that it had reached an agreement with the Berardi Group of Brescia, a manufacturer of machine tools, under which Berardi would take over Montedison's unprofitable machinestools subsidiary, Ceruti Officine Meccaniche S.p.A.

title: P.L.O. Aides Say Group Is in Iran,;But U.S. Official Expresses Doubt
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 7 Palestine Liberation Organization officials said in interviews here today that a twomember P.L.O. delegation, headed by a leader of Al Fatah, the main guerrilla group, had arrived in Teheran and had begun efforts to protect the lives of Americans held hostage by students in the United States Embassy.

title: Guerrillas Report Blast in Israel
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Nov. 7 (Reuters)  Palestinian guerrillas said that they set off explosives at a market in southern Israel today, causing damaging to trucks and goods. The Palestinian press service Wafa quoted a guerrilla spokesman as having said that raiders planted the bomb in the central market at Qiryat Gat, east of Ashkelon. The report did not mention any casualties.

title: Home Improvement
description: A NEW selection of books on home building, improvement and maintenance has been published in recent months. Not surprisingly, energysaving projects and procedures are emphasized in many of these, and others are devoted to ways of cutting the high cost of building or remodeling.

title: Israeli Cabinet Adds a HardLiner
description: TEL AVIV, Nov. 7  A Cabinet shuffle involving the appointment of Yigal Hurwitz as Finance Minister was approved in Parliament today by a vote of 58 to 34.

title: Plan to Supplant;Con Ed Dropped;For Westchester
description: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 7  The defeat yesterday by Westchester County voters of a proposal that could have led to a countyrun utility as a replacement for the Consolidated Edison Company has prompted the county to abandon the project, County Executive Alfred B. DelBello said today.

title: Soviet Calls Memoirs of Shostakovich Fake
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 7  The Soviet Union, which tried unsuccessfully to stop publication of the composer Dmitri Shostakovich's posthumous memoirs in the West on copyright grounds, has now begun denouncing the book as a fake.

title: Q&A
description: Q.I live in an old apartment building whose ceilings keep peeling because the building's painter paints over old peeling paint and crumbling plaster. I would like to hire my own contractor to scrape where necessary and then paint. Is it necessary to put shellac over the peeling areas after they are scraped, or will semigloss or flat enamel solve the problem?  Mrs. M.D., Manhattan

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Iranian oil exports to the United States are continuing, Presidential Press Secretary Jody Powell said. The news came amid widespread concern among Administration officials that Iran might impose an embargo, which could upset the delicate supply and demand situation for petroleum. In his news briefing Mr. Powell also said that the White House had created an interagency task force to review plans for dealing with such a shutoff. [Page A1.]

title: Falls From Windows Decline
description: Incidents of children falling from apartment windows have declined more than 50 percent, the New York City Health Department reported yesterday.

title: Home Beat
description: The New York Times/Bill Aller and Robert Levin

title: Bridge:
description: The world's leading magazine in the field, The Bridge World, celebrated its 50th birthday last month and surveyed a wealth of fascinating material that has appeared in its pages in half a centurv.

title: Campaign Records at Trial Show No Cash Gift by Scotto
description: The prosecution presented official campaign records yesterday to show there were no reports of the cash contributions Anthony M. Scotto said he had given to two political campaigns.

title: 3 Accused of Lawyer's Slaying in Riverdale
description: Three Mount Vernon teenagers were arrested yesterday and charged with the murder of a prominent Phoenix lawyer who was fatally shot Oct. 27 during a robbery as he sat in a parked car in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: Maazel Has Big Plans for Vienna
description: IN Vienna, where musical affairs arouse the sort of fierce partisanship other cities reserve for politics or sports, the directorship of the Vienna State Opera can be a grueling and precarious assignment. Gustav Mahler and Richard Strauss, the two most eminent directors in the house's preWorld War II history, were both vigorously hounded out of office. Mahler's supporters were themselves so vigorous that when his successor, Felix Weingartner, tampered with Mahler's celebrated Fidelio production, police reinforcements were called to forestall antiWeingartner demonstrations.

title: A.M.C. to Lift Eagle Output
description: DETROIT, Nov. 7  The American Motors Corporation, which is expected later this week to report record earnings for its fiscal year ended Sept. 30, is planning to increase production of its new Eagle fourwheeldrive passenger car to 90,000 units during the 1980 model year. Previously it had planned to produce 50,000 Eagles.

title: Russia Tops S.M.U., 9784
description: DALLAS, Nov. 7 (AP)  Sergio Belov, a guard, scored 22 points and Vladimir ilachenko, a center, had 16 points as the Soviet Union's national basketball team rallied to defeat Southern Methodist, 9784, last night before 5,208 fans at Moody Coliseum.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Prices broke sharply in the credit markets yesterday, driving yields on longterm Government bonds to highs as investors worried about turmoil in Iran, a weaker dollar, a more restrictive monetary policy and the problems of distributing a heavy volume of Treasury securities.

title: The U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Sound
description: METAL tape, triumphantly heralded more than a year ago as the ultimate refinement in cassette recording, is at last sporadically appearing in the shops, and it's getting a cool reception. In fact, a good many audio fans, having bought suitable recorders and tried the new tapes, were expressly disappointed.

title: Loews Reports 2% Profit Rise
description: The Loews Corporation yesterday reported a 2 percent increase in its thirdquarter profits on an 18.5 percent rise in revenues.

title: Results of Tuesday's Voting in New York City and Metropolitan Area Contests; Vote on Ballot Issues;For New York State; Bronx; MAYOR (cities over 75,000)
description: PROPOSITION 1 Transportation Bond Issue (Statewide Totals)

title: Libyan And Saudi Muscle
description: CHICAGO  The oil boom has enabled Saudi Arabia and Libya to become the power centers of Islam's new international political thrust.

title: Temporary MOB Output
description: BL Ltd., formerly British Leyland, announced in London it would continue producing MGB sports cars through 1980 mainly for the American market  but that it would then, as previously announced, terminate production of the sports car. About 25,000 of next year's 30,000 MGB's are planned for the United States market, a spokesman for BL has said.

title: At the U.S. Embassy in Teheran, Prayers and Slogans Fill the Air
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 7 (Reuters)  Every few hours today, a student leader inside the gate of the United States Embassy compound shouted

title: Deaths
description: HILDRETHClara. In her 102nd year. On November 7, 1979. Wife of the late Lt. Col. Henry S. Hildreth, daughter of the late Mr. & Mrs. John Mayberry Young. Formerly of Ingleside, Madison, N.J. Mother of John M. Hlldreth, grandmother of Richard Mansfield Hildreth, great grandmother of Randolph Mansfield Hildreth. Service at St. Bartholomew's Chapel, Park Ave. at 51 Street, Friday, November 9 at 2PM. In lieu of flowers contributions to St. Bartholomew's Church, 109 E. 50 St., N.Y.C. 10022, would be appreclated.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Nov, 7  Jobrelated deaths in private industry decreased last year by about 4 percent, while injuries and illnesses occurred on the average to one in every 11 workers, nearly the same as in 1977, the Department of Labor reported today.

title: Rep. Rodino Submits Legislation For Stricter Controls on Pistols
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (UPI) Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr., Democrat of New Jersey, chairman of the House Judiciary Committee. introduced legislation today to ban the manufacture or sale of Saturday night specials and other easily concealed pistols.

title: Associated Press
description: ORDERED TO PAY EXPENSES: W.A. (Tony) Boyle, former head of the United Mine Workers union, being helped from court in Media, Pa. He had filed a motion to be declared a pauper so that he would not have to pay for appeal of conviction in assassination of Joseph A. Yablonski, but the motion was denied.

title: Repair Shops for Small Lamps
description: NEIGHBORHOOD repair shops probably offer the least expensive services for handling small lamp repairs.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Wednesday, Nov. 7,1979

title: 42% in Poll Favor U.S. Talks With P.L.O. on Mideast
description: Nearly half the Americans who have heard of the Palestine Liberation Organization believe the United States should negotiate with the group despite the objections of Israel. This conclusion emerges from a New York Times/CBS News survey.

title: Board Lists Budget Cuts For Schools
description: New York City's Board of Education reluctantly sent to City Hall yesterday a plan to cover a $45 million budget deficit. It would end free transportation for most pupils and lay off 2,300 teachers this year.

title: $120,000 Queens Jewel Robbery
description: Two men robbed a 68yearold jeweler yesterday of two suitcases containing more than $120,000 in jewelry, the police reported. They said the victim, Baruch Ayassof of 6610 Yellowstone Boulevard, Forest Hills, Queens, had been hit on the head while riding in the elevator of his apartment building at about 5:30 A.M. Mr. Ayassof was taken to St. John's Hospital for treatment. His condition was not serious, the police said.

title: The Lighting Designer: Bright New Star
description: INSTEAD of asking, Who did it? admirers of a status interior are now as likely to ask, Who lit it? The newest catchwords in interior design are amps, wattage, lumen, low voltage, recessed and direct, wallwashers, up and down lights, track, flood or spot. Lights, that is.

title: Corporate Reports
description: For periods as shown.(N) indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange arid (O) overthecounter.

title: Dallas to Exhibit Icebergs; Hunt Called Painting Buyer
description: Icebergs the Frederic Edwin Church painting that sold for $2.5 million last month at Sotheby Parke Bernet, becoming the most expensive American painting ever sold at auction, will be placed on view at Dallas Museum of Fine Arts from Nov. 20 through Dec. 30, according to George V. Charlton, president.

title: Political Crisis Avoided in Canada
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 7  By two votes Prime Minister Joe Clark staved off a defeat in the House of Commons last night that would have opened a political crisis and probably prevented a visit by President Carter Friday and Saturday.

title: Poll Finds Public Supports Variety of Moves in Fight on Inflation
description: The American people say they want to do almost anything to control inflation, including cutting their own standard of living, but the richer half of the popula tion is much readier to accept a variety of social hardships than is the poorer half, according to the latest New York Times/ CBS News Poll. Whites were also more prepared for overall sacrifice than blacks.

title: Sales Help Wanted 2677
description: We are looking fore person with either sales experience and/or involvement with the above sports to work in our busy athletic footwear department, Full time position, pleasant surroundings, good starting salary & immediate employee's discount. Call Ms. Roth for appointment ent 2558036; PARAGON 18th & Bway

title: Browns Sherk Ailing
description: CLEVELAND, Nov. 7 (AP)  The Cleveland Browns announced today that Jerry Sherk, a defensive tackle, would undergo surgery on his left knee and would be sidelined for four weeks.

title: McEnroe Extended To Defeat Buehning
description: STOCKHOLM, Nov. 7 (AP)  John McEnroe recovered from a set down to defeat Fritz Buehning, 46, 62, 62, today in the second round of the $175,000 Stockholm open tennis tournament. They are rivals from their junior years.

title: THANKSGIVING TREAT: TURKEYS FREE OF PCB
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 7  After a sevenweek inquiry involving hundreds of investigators, the Federal authorities are reasonably certain that no turkeys containing the toxic chemical PCB will end up on Thanksgiving tables.

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: BOSTON, Nov. 7  Amid all the rhetoric and emotion of Edward Kennedy's hour in Faneuil Hall there was one explicit statement on a major policy question. And in that statement could be seen the problems, the dangers, of this extraordinary candidacy.

title: REP. FLOOD TO QUIT CONGRESS ON JAN. 31
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP)  Representative Daniel J. Flood, facing a Federal retrial on bribery and conspiracy charges. announced today that he would resign from the House of Representives for health reasons, effective next Jan. 31.

title: Kingman Slams Homer in Opener of Japan Tour
description: YOKOHAMA, Japan, Nov. 7 (AP) Dave Kingman of the Chicago Cubs slammed a tworun homer in leading the National Leame AllStars to an 112 rout of the American League AllStars in the opener of their ninegame Japanese tour today.

title: The New York Times/Neal Boenzl
description: POLICE RECRUITS SWORN IN: The first recruits hired in five years in New York City were lectured on selfcontrol by Mayor Koch, who said he wanted to kill those who assaulted him Monday, but had exercised restraint. Page B3.

title: NATO Warned at Red Square Parade
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 7 (Reuters)  As Soviet tanks and missiles rolled through Red Square today, Defense Minister Dmitri F. Ustinov attacked the United States and other Western countries for planning to upgrade the missile arsenal of the Atlantic alliance in Europe.

title: 2 U.S. Executives Released in El Salvador
description: After 47 days in captivity, two executives of a United States electronics firm in El Salvador were released yesterday by leftist guerrillas in the Central American country.

title: PANEL URGES STRESS ON FOREIGN TONGUES
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7  To remedy what it called the scandalous incompetence in foreign languages among Americans, a Presidential commission today urged a return to more strineent language requirements in schools and colleges and proposed an array of new programs to encourage more study of languages and international affairs.

title: Miller Warns on Impact Of a Bankrupt Chrysler
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7  G. William Miller, Secretary of the Treasury, warned a House Banking subcommittee today that a Chrysler Corporation bankruptcy could cost taxpayers $2.75 billion and result in 75,000 to 100,000 lost jobs in the next two years.

title: Republicans Win Key Long Island Offices
description: Republican candidates won key electoral contests across Long Island Tuesday, ranging from the expected victory of Peter F. Cohalan in the race for Suffolk County Executive to triumphs in such longtime Democratic strongholds as Glen Cove and Huntington.

title: Istanbul Police Official Slain
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, Nov. 7 (AP) Four gunmen believed to be political extremists shot and killed an Istanbul police official today, the police reported.

title: New Strategy on Mobile Homes
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif.  Now that home construction is slowing and a recession casts a shadow over housing, William W. Weide, president of Fleetwood Enterprises Inc., a major producer of mobile homes, is talking of becoming a residential developer.

title: Trooper Is Killed as 15 Flee Prison
description: MOUNDSVILLE, W.Va., Thursday, Nov. 8 (AP)  Fifteen inmates, some armed, broke out of the state penitentiary here tonight and fatally wounded an offduty state trooper. the state police said.

title: Warner to Expand Qube 2Way Cable TV
description: Two years after its initiation in Columbus, Ohio, the first commercial audienceparticipation cabletelevision system, known as Qube, continues to operate at a loss.

title: CHARLES EVANS DIES; WAS NOTED GOLFER
description: Charles (Chick) Evans, who rose from the caddie ranks to play golf with five Presidents of the United States, died late Tuesday in Augustana Hospital in Chicago. He was 89 years old.

title: Democratic Top Executive Reelected in Greenwich
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 7  Ruth L. Sims, the first Democratic First Selectman, or chief executive, of this affluent Fairfield County town since 1905, won reelection to a second term by only 174 votes out of more than 21,000 cast, according to final official returns today.

title: IRAN DEMANDS SHAH
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 7  Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini tonight rebuffed an American attempt to negotiate the release of the American Embassy and the scores of staff members and others seized by students, but he appeared to leave open a possibility of a mediation effort by the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: The Region
description: TRENTON  The Human Services Department reported yesterday that a fifth patient stricken with food poisoning at the Marlboro Psychiatric Hospital Oct. 28 died Tuesday night at a private hospital. Three persons died Oct. 29 and one on Oct. 30.

title: Kennedy Declares His Candidacy, Vowing New Leadership for Nation
description: BOSTON, Nov. 7 Senator Edward M. Kennedy, who had declined entreaties to run for President in the last three campaigns, formally declared his candidacy for election in 1980 today with a pledge to provide a forceful, effective Presidency that would get the nation on the march again.

title: Rangers Batter Kings, 84
description: It was obvious from the start last night that something about the New York Rangers was different. It could be seen in the way Don Murdoch threw his body around in the corners, hitting the deiensemen from the Los Angeles Kings with newfound abandon. It could be seen in the way Ulf Nilsson, Anders Hedberg and Steve Vickers threaded passes to each other. It could be seen in the way Mario Marois did not hesitate to throw punches after he had felt the wood of a Los Angeles stick against his ribs once too often.

title: Deaths
description: BROWNRichard Fargo. The members and Officers of the Art Dealers Association of America mourn the loss of Rick Brown, a talented art historian, an outstanding museum director and a close and warm friend. His wife and family have our heartfelt sympathy.

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE
description: THERE are several new and useful lighting items on the market that do not require an electrician's services to install. The Thyrocon Controls Corporation makes two special sockets that screw into standard lamp or light fixture sockets.

title: Youth, 21, Wounded in Brooklyn By 4 Who Fired at Him From Car
description: A 21yearold youth was chased by four other young men and shot four times on a street in South Brooklyn early yesterday, according to the police.

title: To England: Leave Ireland
description: The assassination of Earl Mountbatten of Burma has resurrected the dormant gaggle of critics whose sole interest in Irish politics is denigrating the Provisional Irish Republican Army. As if the Provos, as the Provisional I.R.A is known, were the cause of the problem, these contemporary Cassandras have worked themselves into a veritable dither of inanity about terrorism and have omitted from their moral lexicon the concept of justice. Forgetting that one man's terrorist is another man's patriot, critics of every imaginable ideological hue have waxed stentorian about I.R.A. murderers while selectively ignoring the brutality and indecency of England's occupation of Irish soil.

title: Police Dept. Will Yield Abandoned Car Duties
description: The Sanitation Department will assume operation of the city's abandoned car program from the Police Department this month at an estimated saving of $750,000, the Sanitation and Police Commissioners said yesterday.

title: The Holy City of Qum Is the Center of Power For Khomeini Regime
description: The holy city of Qum is not only the seat of religion but also the seat of power in the Islamic republic that fervent Moslems in Iran are trying to establish.

title: Lukens President Resigns
description: The Lukens Steel Company said that James L. Plasterer, president of Lukens since 1977, had resigned for personal reasons. Charles A. Carlson Jr., chairman and chief executive, has been elected to the additional post of acting president, Lukens said.

title: Mrs. Humphrey Endorses Carter
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (UPI)  Muriel Humphrey, invoking the name of her late husband, Hubert H. Humphrey, today endorsed President Carter over Senator Edward M. Kennedy as the Democratic party candidate for President next year. She told reporters, I know this is what Hubert would have done if he were here.

title: International Artists Exhibit Their Glass
description: GLASSMAKERS have always been a peripatetic lot, but in this age of easy travel they bring their secrets with them  to share. Last summer, four wellknown glassmakers traveled from Europe to the Pilchuck Glass Center in Stanwood, Wash., to be artistsinresidence at the school and to produce work for a show in New York City.

title: McGrawEdison Rating
description: Moody's Investors Service, in an unusual move, said it had lowered its rating on McGraw Edision Company debentures, due 1999, and its industrial revenue bonds by two notches, to Baa from Aa. At the same time, Moody's commercial paper rating on McGraw Edision was changed to prime two from prime one. This action is the result of significantly increased leverage and sharply reduced interest coverage resulting from the company's purchase of StudebakerWorthington Inc., the service said.

title: G.O.P. Gained in New York and New Jersey Voting
description: Republicans made scattered gains in Tuesday's elections in New York State and New Jersey, but conflicting signals from the voters left most politicians puzzled.

title: 2 Workmen Killed and One Hurt After 2 Cars Crash on Fifth Ave.
description: Two workmen were killed and one was seriously injured on Tuesday when two cars collided at 36th Street and Fifth Avenue and slammed into barricades around a hole where the men were working on steam pipes, the police said.

title: Porter Chandler, Long a Lawyer
description: Porter Chandler, an authority on constitutional law and a former chairman of the New York City Board of Higher Education, died Tuesday at his home in Piffard, N.Y. He was 80 years old.

title: Screen: Fritz Lang's 'spiders
description: THE movie event of the month is not to be found at any posh East Side cinema but down on Vandam Street at the Film Forum, where, this evening, Fritz Lang's The Spiders (Die Spinnen) will be givenits American theatrical premiere approximately 60 years late. Looking atthis quite charming adventureserial,Lang's third feature and reportedly theearliest of his extant films, is to gazeinto a 1919 crystal ball.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Entertainment Events
description: ROMANTIC COMEDY, by Bernard Slade; directed by Joseph Hardy; starring Anthony Perkins and Mla Farrow, at the Ethel Barrymore Theater, 243 West 47th Street, 6:30.

title: Magic Carpet,
description: Edward Ardizzone, Artist, Dead

title: Carter Trade Bill Passed by House
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) The House today approved President Carter's trade reorganization Plan by a voice vote.

title: The Lost Treasure of the Concepcion
description: It was noon on Nov. 25, 1978, when Burt Webber's magnetometer whined  a signal that the sensor had detected metal of some kind under the coral sea bed. Webber and Jim Nace marked the spot and swam on. Less than 50 feet away, the $17,000 metal detector whined again. Something was there, something not created by nature alone.

title: Advertising
description: Philip H. Dougherty

title: Midtown Blaze Injures Several
description: A fire and explosion destroyed a furniture store in midtown Manhattan yesterday. Three firemen and a civilian auxiliary fireman suffered minor injuries, and at least four persons had to run through the flames to safety.

title: Submerged Sub Lofts Missile
description: POINT MUGU, Calif., Nov. 8 (UPI) A United States Navy Tomahawk Cruise Missile was launched yesterday from a submerged nuclear attack submarine operating off the southern California coast.

title: Books: Antonia Fraser's Biography of Charles II

title: Publishing: 26 Years Between Novels

It has been a long wait  26 years, in fact. But the most recent intelligence is that a new novel is forthcoming from Doubleday & Company, probably sometime in 1981.

title: More U.S. Aid Expected in College Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 Supporters of a Housepassed bill to increase Federal aid to higher education said today that the measure would provide extra money for New York State. It would do so, they said, by eliminating a penalty now assessed against states that spend large sums for higher education.

title: Bonn Central Bank Head Sees Dip in U.S. Inflation
description: FRANKFURT, Nov. 8  Otmar Emminger, president of the Bundesbank, West Germany's politically independent central bank, predicts cautiously that American inflation and the record interest rates it has brought have reached their peaks and that both will slowly decline within the next two to three months as the American economy tips into recession.

title: $200,000 Goes To Arts Unit For Training
description: The National Arts Consortium, formed in 1977 by minority groups working in the performance and visual arts to pool their administrative resources, has been granted $200,000 by the United States Department of Labor to establish a training institute for set, lighting and'design students.

title: Opera: New in Serail
description: KONSTANZE'S famous and lengthy aria, Martern aller Arten, in Die Entfiihring aus dem Serail is so exasperatingly difficult that one tends to agonize along with the soprano during its performance, wondering whether she will make all the notes, instead of listening to the music. This was somewnat me case with Gail Robinson, who was singing the role of Konstanze for the first time at the Metropolitan Opera in Wednesday night's presentation of the Mozart work.

title: Slumping Pistons Dismiss Vitale as Coach

Vitale, signed in May 1978, amid a fanfare of bugles, drums and cannon fire that was to have touched off a new Piston era, was the Pistons 14th coach since 1957.

That means an average of about $160 per homeowning family. Like or not, many of them must learn to afford it; but many obviously cannot. After much internal pulling and tugging, the Legislature managed to pass three bills that would somewhat reduce the fuel burden for all families, but Govenor Carey rightly resists.

title: Film: 'The Shout' Stars Bates and Miss York:The Magic Is Real
description: ACCORDING to the program notes accompanying the credits for Jerzy Skolimowski's "The Shout," there is an "ordinary" housewife living near Bristol, England, "who has undergone exhaustive tests in a sound chamber and proved, beyond doubt, that she can produce a vocal sound greater in volume and power than the Concorde."Now there is a story to mull over. Can you imagine what would happen if that woman tried to move to Queens? They'd probably pack her off to Dulles Airport in Washington.Unfortunately "The Shout" is not about that ordinary Bristol housewife. It's about an unstable fellow named Charles Crossley (Alan Bates) who one day turns up at the English country house of Rachel (Susannah York) and Anthony (John Hurt) and alternately terrorizes and charms them with stories about his life among the Australian aborigines.Charles also practices black magic learned from the aborigines, and it seems to work. When he takes an object from Rachel  in this case her shoe buckleshe falls completely under his spell. When she retrieves the buckle, the spell is broken. In a more dangerous way Charles fascinates Anthony with stories about a shout so piercing that it can kill all who hear it. Anthony, a composer of electronic music and a man always interested in a new sound sensation, challenges Charles to go into the dunes with him and let fly with one of his famous shouts."The Shout," which opens today at the newly remodeled New Yorker Twin 2, is a vivid, piercingly loud movie as well as an almost totally incoherent one. The screenplay by Michael Austin and Mr. Skolimowski is an adaptation of a 1926 short story by Robert Graves. Since I haven't read the story I can't be sure whether the obscurities are Mr. Austin's, Mr. Graves's or those of Mr. Skolimowski, the Polish director of such well received films of the 60's as "Rysopsis," "Walkover" and "Deep End."The story of the film is told in flashbacks in the course of a cricket match at a mental hospital. The narrator is Charles Crossley himself and the listener, also according to the program notes (though there's nothing in the film to confirm it), is Robert Graves, played by Tim Curry.The story starts off well, like almost any ghost story made up by a child, but then it becomes so full of loose ends, contradictions, cryptic symbols and close-ups of objects that, at the moment, have no meaning, that one eventually tunes out of the narrative, much as one does when the child's ghost story becomes too hopelessly muddled for even the child to unravel.A few things in the movie are clear: the magic we see in the film is real  that is, it works because its victims want it to work; Charles, played by Mr. Bates with the great loony relish he brings to such roles, is brilliant as are some certifiably mad people; Anthony is crazy too, or else he wouldn't be carrying on with a blowsy village girl when he has a wife, in the person of Miss York, at home. Everything else, though, is confusion."The Shout" is an elegant looking movie, nicely performed, but because it leaves one knowing less than one did at the beginning, it is easily forgettable. Except for the sound. Apparently to prepare us for the scene in which Charles screams his aboriginal scream, the producers seem to have sharpened or heightened the soundtrack in such a way that even ordinary sounds  the wind, for example  take on a painful sibilance.

title: Cello Redtak Kreger at Y
description: AS cellists go, James Kreger is hardly unknown. He won fourth prize in the 1974 Tchaikovsky Competition, and has turned up several times in Manhattan halls, most recently with the Tokyo String Quartet last season. Neverthe less, judging from his recital Wednesday night at the 92d Street Y, Mr. Kreger is an artist who deserves a bigger following than he has so far acquired.

title: Screen: 'Ballad of Orin' Arrives From Japan:A Blind Girl's Tragedy
description: "THE BALLAD OF ORIN," the Japanese film that opens today at the Cinema Studio 2, is the sort of solemn, perfectly composed, much too artfully designed movie that sends you out of the theater longing to see something rude, crass and sloppy, like "Car Wash." It's the work of Masahiro Shinoda ("Double Suicide," "The Scandalous Adventures of Buraikan"), whose pretentiousness has apparently been received with far more favor elsewhere than here. According to the film's publicity notes, "The Ballad of Orin" was cited earlier this year at the Los Angeles Filmex as "a romantic tragedy of the utmost beauty and emotional impact."Beauty it has  the kind that suffocates. Emotional impact is what it lacks, possibly because one is aware that there's been so much theorizing before each scene, before each camera set-up, that all sense of life has vanished. Mr. Shinoda's idols reportedly are Yasujiro Ozu and Kenji Mizoguchi, though the only things he seems to have understood in their works are the surface looks. The grandeur of Mizoguchi's visions appears to be beyond Mr. Shinoda's abilities, as are the humanity and wit that are apparent even in Ozu's most reserved works."The Ballad of Orin," set near the end of World War I, is the sad but picture-postcard-pretty tale of Orin, played by Shima Iwashita (the wife of the director), who, blind from birth, is apprenticed as a child to an itinerant band of blind women singers, known as the goze. The goze, we are told, live according to rules as strict as those that govern geishas. They devote their lives, including their chastity, to their art.When Orin falls from grace after having been "with a man," she wanders alone the length and breadth of Japan, singing for her supper and sleeping with any available fellow. In the course of her travels she is befriended by a young man who insists on accompanying her though he refuses to make love to her. To him she must remain a goddess. After an old peddler rapes Orin, the young man kills him, which means that he's now wanted by both the police and the army, from which he has deserted.Everything goes badly for poor Orin, which is the point of the movie that, I assume, thinks it's making a statement about Japanese society though it looks more like a series of weather reports from Japan's 50 most scenic spots. You've probably never seen so many beautiful mountains, plains, seacoasts and quaint villages, in sunlight, rain, snow and fog, in summer and winter, spring and fall. No matter where he looks Mr. Shinoda finds beauty that simultaneously reflects Orin's essential nature and contrasts with her awful lot in life.Mr. Shinoda's poetic conceits reach some kind of apotheosis (can a conceit be apotheosized?) in a sequence in which the 11-year-old Orin "becomes," as they say, "a woman." She and her fellow goze are walking single-file across a great, lovely expanse of virgin snow. Suddenly Orin drops back  she is experiencing her first menstrual period. After a few moments she runs to catch up with her sisters, leaving in the snow a trail of delicate drops of blood and one red poppy.There's something more than a little fake, as well as patronizing, about this kind of film making.

title: Stage: Slade's Romantic Comedy
description: IN Bernard Slade's Romantic Comedy, Anthony Perkins makes one mistake in the first scene and another for the remaining six. As a playwright whose bent is for elegance and whose marriage to a socialite is to take place within the hour, he first mistakes Mia Farrow for a masseuse. He's expecting someone to give him a rubdown, the unfamiliar Miss Farrow has strayed in wearing hearty green kneesocks and her blond tresses shoulderlength (you'd count her Swedish, for sure), and so, of course, when he meets her he is in the nude. She gets the front view, we're confined to the back.

At the same time, on another network, Senator Kennedy was giving a disturbing picture of himself in documentary mostly focused on the Chappaquiddick incident; but since Jaws took 57 percent of the available audience, the damage was probably limited.

title: To the InterestRate Barricades
description: Some wars are covered only in the financial pages, but they are just as earnest as those up front. Soon after the Federal Reserve Board dramatically tightened American credit last month to attack inflation home and raise the value of the dollar abroad, West Germany's central bank fired a retaliatory round equal weight. Although the Germans had been clamoring for a defense of the dollar, they tightened monetary policies to stop their inflation and raise the value of the mark. The Fed is now expected to counter with another volley of tighter credit, which presumably will fire up the Germans to do the same.

title: KENNEDY CAMPAIGNS IN CARTER TERRITORY
description: NASHVILLE, Nov. 8  Senator Edward M. Kennedy brought his new Presidential campaign to the South tonight, and his largest crowd to date heard him charge that President Carter lacked leadership qualities and that he mishandled the economy.

description: LONDON, Nov. 7 (UPI)  President Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia arrived here today with a proposal that British officials hope may help break a deadlock in the threemonthold Rhodesia peace conference.

title: The Screen: 'Normande':A Decorative Actress
description: THE only reason to see "Normande," Gilles Carle's French-Canadian film that opens today at the Quad Cinema, is to see Carole Laure whom you may have seen earlier in Bertrand Blier's "Get Out Your Handkerchiefs." Miss Laure possibly is a very good actress but at this point in her career she is primarily a decorative object, something to seduce the eye. She is a beautifully molded creature, her limbs finely balanced, with skin so velvety it invites touching.In "Normande" she does get touched from time to time, but not frequently enough to raise this gloomy domestic melodrama to the sunnier level of soft-core pornography. Mostly Miss Laure, in the title role, walks through the movie fully dressed and looking worried, and well she might.Normande works in a drug store and is the sole support of her nutty mother, who thinks of herself as an actress but is actually a long-in-the-tooth porn performer; her younger sister, who has asthma and no love for Normande; her lover, who is unemployed and not breaking his neck looking for work; and an asexual young man who is unhappy because people mistake him for a homosexual.Sharing the house with Normande and her "family," though in different apartments, are a senile old lady who keeps rats as pets, her grandson, who wants to be a musician, and a clean old man who lusts discreetly after Normande.Some suspense is provided by the knowledge that Normande is about to be evicted so that the apartment can be turned into a restaurant. It all becomes too, too much for Normande who retreats into a permanent dream world.The actors aren't bad but the movie is unreliable. Mr. Carle would like us to find something gallant about these eccentrics. Instead, being around them is like being panhandled by bores who ask for pity instead of money.

title: Huichol Indians Display Yarn Paintings
description: Leaving behind food and water, the Huichol Indians of Mexico once a year journey from the Sierra Madre mountains through the San Luis Potosi desert in search of the peyote cactus and the enlightenment they say it brings. The shaman, or medicine man. will shoot an arrow into the first peyote he sees as though it were a deer. Then the hunting party will eat the psychedelic plant, experiencing the spectacularly colorful hallucinations and loss of self brought about by the mescaline contained in the cactus.

title: Aid to Chrysler Clears Hurdle
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (UPI) A A House banking subcommittee approved a $1.5 billion package of Federal loan guarantees for the Chrysler Corporation today, the first step toward enactment of the Administrationbacked program.

description: MILLERLeah. The Trustees and Staff of the Riverdale YMYWHA express their deep condolences tc their devoted trustee, Dr. Jacob J Miller on the loss of his wife. May the family be comforted In their bereavement and may they be spared further sorrows,

title: Play It Again, Woody, Is Theme for a Festival
description: In Woody Allen's movie Annie Hall, there is a scene in the lobby of the New Yorker movie theater on Broadway and 88th Street, where a crowd is waiting to see the documentary The Sorrow and the Pity. In the scene Mr. Allen makes fun of people who stand on lines to see art and serious movies and actually have the nerve to talk about it in public.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Truth in Testing Law
description: Asserting that the socalled truth in testing law in New York violates the Federal Copyright Act, the Association of American Medical Colleges will file suit today in Federal District Court in Albany to ask that the measure be declared unconstitutional because it denies due process.

title: Modern Museum, at 50, Lets Visitors in Free
description: The Museum of Modern Art marked its 50th anniversary yesterday with free admission, which relatively few visitors appeared aware of, and a small dish of jellybeans sitting on the ticket counter at the entrance.

title: British Seeking Better Terms From Common Market
description: LONDON, Nov. 8  Last month, in speech of carefully calibrated firmness, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher warned that the financial relationship between Britain and its Common Market partners had become politically indefensible.

title: Cardinals Weigh Cuts in Bureaucracy
description: ROME, Nov. 8  A wideranging project to streamline and reduce the bureaucratic structure of the Roman Curia, the central administration of the Roman Catholic Church, has begun to emerge from discussions behind closed doors at the Vatican by the members of the College of Cardinals.

title: The Stakes in Iran
description: There have been good reasons for responsible Americans to hold their tongues about the outrage Iran this week. No one, plainly, has a really good plan to assure the rescue of the 60 hostages and other vulnerable Americans in that disintegrating society. John Connally was quick to cast blame; he seems to believe it is sinful only to appease a foreign crowd. But given the widespread frustration of Americans, the wonder that so many political figures have understood the predicament of the President  and of the hostages  and taken care not to goad the nation into frenzied action.

title: Treasury and House Unit Cool to Value Added Tax
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8  The Treasury Department and members of the Ways and Means Committee gave a chilly reception today to a proposal by the chairman, Al Ullman, to enact a Federal value added tax and reduce Federal income and Social Security taxes.

title: Transit for the Handicapped Is Seen Costing $38 per Ride Over 30 Years
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8  New Federal rules to make mass transit vehicles and stations accessible to handicapped riders could cost the Government a sum equal to $38 a trip for each disabled rider over the next 30 years, a Congressional agency reported today.

title: The City
description: Green Lines Strikers Will Vote on Pact

title: Police Capture 8 Who Fled Prison In West Virginia
description: MOUNDSVILLE, W.Va., Nov. 8  The police today recaptured eight of the 15 prisoners who escaped last night from the ancient State Penitentiary here after overpowering guards with a smuggled pistol. A ninth prisoner was found shot to death about 40 miles from this city in the West Virginia panhandle.

title: Buying or Just Browsing, the Action. Is at the Auctions
description: AUCTIONGOING, one of New York's least costly (or most costly, if you are buying something like the $2.5 million painting Icebergs by Frederic Edwin Church) and most popular weekend activities, has moved into high gear. In the days ahead, the gaveling and the gawking at all sorts of wares  and at the people who bid on them  will help make these events among the liveliest shows in town.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: BUSINESS Digest

title: Old Man With a Horn. Plays the Village Gate
description: When Gunther Schuller published the first volume of his history of jazz, Early Jazz, in 1968, he devoted several pages to a virtually unknown trumpet player, Jabbo Smith, a mention whose ripple effects are still being felt. They have brought Mr. Smith from musical retirement (he made his last record in 1938 and for 15 years he was a mechanic and driver for the Avis Car Rental Agency in Milwaukee) to a featured role at the age of 71, singing and playing in One Mo Time the recollection of black vaudeville in the 1920's at the Village Gate. And tonight at 10:30 and 12:30 and Sunday night at 10:30, Mr. Smith and his New Orleans Serenaders will join the Dizzy Gillespie Quartet in a concert at the Gate.

title: Martin Robertson, 75; Science Editor, Teacher
description: Dr. Martin Luther Robertson, retired editor in chief of Litton Industries educational books division, died Monday at his home in Loveland, Colo. He was 75 years old.

title: The New York Times/Nov. 9, 1979
description: Renderings by Alexander Cooper Associates

title: Union, Citing Birth Defects, Asks Ban on a Herbicide
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8  The International Chemical Workers Union announced today that it had asked the Federal Government to ban the production and use of a herbicide called Oryzalin, saying that babies of workers in a factory that made it suffered birth defects and early death.

title: Seventh Avenue Fashions Welcome the 80's
description: Oscar de la Renta filled the runway with bubble skirts and tiered flounces and gave his models balloons to carry to make sure his playful theme was fully appreciated.

title: Associated Press
description: BUSY AT BOTH ENDS OF THE COURT: Dan Issel, right, of Denver, attempting to block a shot by Adrian Dantley of the Jazz last night in Salt Lake City. Issel scored a gamehigh 23 points, leading the Nuggets to a 9692 victory.

title: Southern Illinois Sizing Up Carter and Kennedy Roles
description: WEST FRANKFURT, Ill., Nov. 5 The campaign begins for Jimmy Carter's downstate coordinator with a list of names, a rented car and acknowledgement of a certain politicalemotional reality that seems as burnished and seamless as the land hereabout.

title: Gambling Issues Help Stock Market To End FourSession Losing Streak
description: The stock market posted a small advance yesterday after four losing sessions in continued light trading, with the gambling issues scoring the biggest gains.

title: United Press International
description: FIGURE IN DR. KING INQUIRY IS KILLED: Investigators examining car in which John Paul Spica died when bomb exploded outside his home near St. Louis yesterday. Mr. Spica, who testified on the assassination of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., is a convicted hired killer and brother-in-law of Russell G. Byers, who also testified.

title: The TaxSaving Divorce Goes to Court
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8  Since 1966, Angela and David Boyter, a couple from Ellicott City, Md., have divorced, remarried, divorced, remarried and divorced again  all in an effort to take advantage of Federal tax laws that favor single couples living together over married ones.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: YOU should probably take Barry Tarshis's 'The Average American Book with at least a mountain of salt. After all, it's data are of uneven reliability, ranging as they do from reputable public-o-pin: ion polls through surveys of popular magazine readers, all the way to a tricky and controversial psychological experiment designed to expose unconscious racism. (Subjects were given the choice of either cheating at a given task or administering electric shocks - unbeknownst to them, imaginary to various victims. The subjects tended to shock black males who were dating white females more than they punished victims who were dating people of the same race.)

title: Herbert Migdoll
description: Glenn Edgerton of Joffrey II Dancers in Random Dances, this weekend in Brooklyn. See page C33.

title: 3 Mile Island Executive Urges U.S. Role in Cleanup
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8  The utility that owns the Three Mile Island reactor is seeking the help of the Federal Government and private industry to reduce its cost in the $300 million to $500 million job of cleaning up the severely damaged power plant, the company's president said today.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Screen: Singer's 'Magician of Lublin' Transformed:Wings Over Warsaw
description: ISAAC BASHEVIS SINGER'S "The Magician of Lublin" doesn't easily lend itself to film, and for that reason it's possible to admire the ambition, if not the finesse, at work in Menahem Golan's adaptation. Mr. Golan, an Israeli director best known here for "I Love You Rosa" and "Operation Thunderbolt," has co-produced, co-written and directed this version of Mr. Singer's novel. The film opens today at the Beekman Theater.The story is supposed to have supernatural overtones. But Mr. Golen's approach is so coarse, and Alan Arkin's performance in the title role so wonderfully dry, that some of the movie's ostensibly mystical moments smack of show business. The Magician is a nervy, self-promoting man who claims he can fly. But he won't attempt the trick until he lands an engagement in turn-of-the-century Warsaw's most prestigious theater. In the meantime, while his manager (Lou Jacobi) tries to land him this job, he keeps busy by trifling with the affections of more women than an ordinary man could perhaps manage. One of the lesser points of Mr. Singer's frequently bawdy tale is that they don't call this fellow the Magician for nothing.Although Yasha, the Magician, is frequently identified as a Jew in the course of the story, he is surely not a religious man. In fact, he seems to take particular pleasure in avoiding his Jewish origins  and his Jewish wifeby wooing Christian women. This is yet another sign of the vanity and arrogance that will eventually bring about a magical change in Yasha, a change which Mr. Golan is in no way equipped to render. To viewers unfamiliar with Mr. Singer's novel, the film may simply look like the story of an amorous, unprincipled man whose bizarre fate is not mysterious, just ill-explained.Were it not for Mr. Arkin, the crudeness of Mr. Golan's film might cancel out the forcefulness of its story. But Mr. Arkin makes the most of the character's shrewdness, and makes plausible his powers as a seducer. He brings warmth and intimacy to any number of scenes that might otherwise suffer from the vagaries of Mr. Golan's casting, which leads him toward actors who affirm things that are already obvious. It seems superfluous, for instance, to use Valerie Perrine as the tootsie of the piece, or Shelley Winters as the mean, ugly monster. Miss Winters makes new inroads into the realm of the horrible when she plays one scene in a corset and dark stockings, with a mouthful of rotted black teeth.Louise Fletcher is more successful as the Christian aristocrat Yasha purports to love, and she figures in the scenes of wealth and elegance that contrast Yasha's city life with the brown, gloomy village that harbors his wife. Maia Danziger, a new actress playing Yasha's assistant and mistress, completes the harem, and she has the film's most suspenseful scene, as the Magician attempts a Houdini stunt and her face makes it clear that she has tampered with the locks. Yasha himself is under water and having trouble breathing as this revelation is made."The Magician of Lublin" sounds stilted much of the time, and Mr. Golan's attempts to strike a note of earthy charm are, for the most part, in vain. But the undeniable energy of the story, and the expertise of a leading man who appears in almost every scene, are compelling enough to sustain interest. And the grand aspirations of this project suggests an attractive bravado very like the Magician's own.

title: Art: Prints of 2 German Romantic Masters
description: THE revival of interest in printmaking on the part of contemporary artists  and their copious output in this medium has encouraged a healthy respect for the print in its own right, rather than as a product accessory to the process of painting or sculpture. What's more, the new interest, coupled with the renascence of figurative art, enables us also to look again at graphic work of the past we had once rejected or forgotten. And so it is almost inevitable that in the last few years the superb graphic production of two German romantic realists should surface again: Max Klinger (18571920) and Richard Muller (18741954). The work of both is on view at two print galleries  Martin Sumers Graphics, 50 West 57th Street, and FitchFebvrel, 5 East 57th Street through Dec. 1, and fascinating work it is.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Sir Kenneth Keith, chairman of RollsRoyce Ltd., the aircraft engine manufacturer owned by the British Government, said yesterday that he would resign early next year. His announcement followed a day of rumor and denial.

title: TV Weekend Topper
description: TOPPER, OPPER, based on a Thorne Smith novel, is being revived again. It was a movie in the 1930's with Cary Grant, Constance Bennett and Roland Young, and in the 50's, it was turned into a television series that eventually was shown on all three networks. Now, incompetently updated, it is a television movie that can be seen tonight at 9 on ABCTV.

title: Philharmonic: 8 Soloists
description: IT is the custom in most American orchestras to dispense with imported soloists now and then and to turn a program over to frontline domestic talent. Last night's New York Philharmonic concert was one of those occasions. Zubin Mehta gathered togetner an oddly assorted group of works and conducted the Philharmonic and eight of its better musicians in what might be termed a carnival of concertos.

title: Yvonne de Gaulle, Widow of French Leader, Dead
description: PARIS, Nov. 8  Yvonne de Gaulle, the widow of President Charles de Gaulle and Aunt Yvonne to a generation of French people, died in a military hospital here today, one day before the ninth anniversary of her husband's death. She was 79 years old.

title: Leading School for Chefs Ousts Its Second Chief In Two Unsettled Years
description: For the second time in two years the president of the Culinary Institute of America in Hyde Park, N.Y., the country's largest and most prestigious school for professional chefs, has been removed from office by the 25member board of trustees. Though J. Joseph Meng, the president until Tuesday, technically resigned, he did so because he was told he would have been asked to leave.

title: Corporate Sales and Earnings Reports
description: For periods as shown.(N) indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (0) over-the-counter.

title: Jan Cushing Wed To E.J. Olympitis
description: Jan Cushing, daughter of Mrs. William Rose of New York and the late Arnold H. Golding, was married in London yesterday to Emmanuel J. Olympitis, a director of Bankers Trust International in London and a vice president of the Bankers Trust Company in New York. He is the son of John Olympitis of London, Athens and Kalymnos, Greece, and the late Mrs. Olympitis. The ceremony was performed in the Greek Orthodox Cathedral by Bishop Chrysostomos.

title: Dividends
description: THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 8, 1979

title: ExU.S. Envoy Asserts Iran May Disintegrate
description: William H. Sullivan, the United States Ambassador to Iran during the 197879 revolution that overthrew the Shah, said yesterday in New York that Perhaps as many as 300,000 weapons were in the hands of various factions in Iran and there is grave danger that the country will disintegrate.

title: The New York Times/Nov. 9, 1979
description: TOKYO, Nov. 8 (AP)  Using its abundant oil money, the Kuwaiti Government has acquired a total of 35.8 million shares of leading Japanese heavy electrical equipment manufacturers, officials said today.

title: Computer Rankings Temple in Top 20; Alabama Still No.1
description: Temple, which has a fourgame winning streak and a wonlost record of 71, is No. 16 in The New York Times computer rankings of majorcollege football teams this week following a 3431 victory over Hawaii at Honolulu last Saturday. It marks the first appearance in the top 20 for the Owls, whose only loss was by 1 point to Pittsburgh, a team that moved up a notch this week to No. 9.

title: U.S. Golfers Protest Ban on South Africans
description: ATHENS, Nov. 8 (AP)  John Mahaffey and Hale Irwin of the United States shot a combined total of 141, one under par, and took a threeshot lead today in the opening round of the 27th World Cup Rolf championship. Their pertormance, however, was overshadowed by the exclusion of South Africa from the event.

title: Associated Press
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP)  The White House appealed to Americans today not to vent their anger toward Iranian students in a way that would increase the risks faced by the Americans held hostage in the United States Embassy in Teheran.

title: The New York Times /George Tames
description: BOSTON, Nov. 8  Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California, whose late flurry of primary victories in 1976 failed to stop Jimmy Carter, formally declared his candidacy for President today, saying, Presidential leadership often seems more the exception than the rule.

title: PatriotsBroncos Clash Matches Two of A.F.C.'s Top Contenders
description: The leading contest in the National Football League on Sunday will be played at Denver, where the Broncos, who have won 27 of their last 32 games at home, take on the New England Patriots. Both have 73 wonlost records, and both hold first place in their American Conference divisions, Denver in a tie with San Diego and New England one game ahead of Miami.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 8 (AP)  The CocaCola Company announced today that it had purchased 1.8 million common shares of the CocaCola Bottling Company of New York from Warner Cornmunications Inc., a New Yorkbased entertainment conglomerate.

title: Carter Receives Ireland's Premier
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8  President Carter and Prime Minister John Lynch of Ireland today condemned terrorism and those who supported it as they began two days of talks in Washington.

title: The Pop Life
description: John Rockwell

title: IRANIANS BAR HOSTAGE TALKS, REPEATING DEMANDS FOR SHAH; U.S. LETS ENVOY CONSULT P.L.O.
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 8  Hopes that the Palestine Liberation Organization might negotiate the release of hostages held since Sunday at the American Embassy here appeared to be seriously damaged today by the insistence of students holding the embassy, and by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, that the United States turn over Shah Mohammed Riza PahLevi.

title: President's Trip to Canada Today Put Off Because of Teheran Crisis
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8  The United States said today that it had authorized President Carter's special envoy, Ramsey Clark, to meet with the Palestine Lib eration Organization if it would help to obtain the release of the Americans held hostage in the embassy in Teheran.

title: WASHINGTON Carter's Prudent Diplomacy
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8  President Carter has been knocked around recently for what his political opponents and even some of his supporters call lack of leadership, but he has been leading us through the latest Iranian crisis with admirable restraint, and deserves the patience and support of the nation.

title: Koosman Cited For Comeback
description: Jerry Koosman of the Minnesota Twins, who proved that all he needed was a change of scenery to regain his pitching success, was named the American League's comeback player of the year yesterday by United Press International.

title: Chorus of Sacred Renaissance Music
description: It is Richard Taruskin's contention that in the current revival of Renais sane music, more attention is paid to the secular than to the sacred repertory. There are Quite a few groups deal- ing successfully in concert halls with secular works. But as far as sacred music is concerned, he says, bits and pieces are performed in church services, usually by choirs who have to tackle so many styles that they are not fully at home in any one.

title: Restaurants
description: Mimi Sheraton

title: WNYC May Discontinue Broadcasts of John Hour
description: The head of the cityowned radio and television stations said yesterday that the stations might not resume broadcasting the names of convicted johns  men who patronize prostitutes. It was 17 days ago that the stations, WNYCAM radio and WNYCTV, complied for the first and only time with a request by Mayor Koch that news organizations publicize the names.

title: The Region
description: BAYONNE, N.J. (AP)  Three men were electrocuted in the Conrail freight yard here while apparently trying to steal copper wires, the police said.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 The Administration, facing the problem of protecting the lives of American hostages in Iran, has found itself at the mercy of a revolution that it has strived to accommodate.

description: Morning

description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 8  Rosalynn Carter arrived tonight for a firsthand inspection of the condition of refugees from war and famine in Cambodia and those who have fled from Laos.

description: IN the great whirligig of art, culture and commerce that has overtaken the photography scene in recent years, certain careers have earned an emblematic status  as much for their steadiness of purpose as for the quality of accomplishment they produced  and one of these, surely, is Henri

title: Saviano Tops Smith In Stockholm Tennis
description: STOCKHOLM, Nov. 8 (AP)  Nick Saviano traded match points with Stan Smith in the final set and then won a tiebreaker and the match, 67, 64, 76, today to advance to the third round of the Stockholm open tennis championships.

title: Notes on People
description: The People's Choices
