description: Rita Reif

title: Israeli High Court Bars Arab Mayor's Expulsion
description: TEL AVIV, Nov. 8  The Supreme Court in Jerusalem issued a temporary injunction today barring the Government from expelling Mayor Bassam Shaka of Nablus to a neighboring country.

title: Around the Nation
description: GREENSBORO, N.C., Nov. 8 (UPI) A 1,000member security force, including 500 National Guard troops, will guard marchers in a funeral procession to be held Sunday in memory of five demonstrators who were shot to death at an antiKu Klux Klan rally, the authorities said today.

title: Bonn Asks EastWest Force Cuts
description: BONN, Nov. 8  The West German Government forwarded a new proposal to its Western allies today on reductions in European ground forces.

title: Giscard Is Awarded a U.N. Medal In Geneva for His Aid to Refugees
description: GENEVA, Nov. 8  The Nansen Medal for outstanding contributions to refugee assistance had been awarded to President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, Poul Harding, announced today.

title: U.S. Decides To Put Off Request That U.N. Security Council Meet,
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 8 United States representatives sounded out other Security Council members today on the possibility of convening meeting on the seizure of the American Embassy and its staff members in Teheran, but action was put off for at least a day.

title: ProWest Cambodian Fights Both Communist Sides
description: BATTAMBANG PROVINCE, Cambodia  At the age of 68, a former Cambodian Prime Minister has left his luxury apartment in Paris and returned to his country. He lives in the jungle, sleeps in hammock and leads a liberation movement opposed to both of Cambodia's contending governments.

title: Car With Exterminator Chemicals Stolen, Setting Off Police Search
description: A car carrying highly dangerous exterminating chemicals was stolen in Brooklyn late Wednesday or early yesterday and the police have begun a search for it.

title: Sports Today
description: BOXING

title: Today's Football at a Glance
description: Other Games

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The Times Oct. 6 incor- rectly described the sponsorship of two publicopinion polls, one by The Los An- geles Times and the other a Harris Poll, on recognition of the Palestine Liberation Organization. They were not conducted for the State Depart- ment, which does not commission polls.

title: Employer of Rapist Is Told to Pay Victim, a Fellow Worker, $750,000
description: FRANKLIN, Ind., Nov. 9 (UPI)  A jury has ordered Avis RentACar to pay$750,000 to a female employee raped by a fellow Avis worker. The jury said that Avis had been negligent in hiring the man, who has been convicted of raping two of the company's employees.

title: Subway Suspect Wasn't Warned, A Detective Says
description: A city detective who gave a lie detector test to a man accused of pushing a young woman in front of a subway train testified yesterday that the transit detectives who pursuaded the man to take the test never indicated they thought he was a suspect in the case.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Dual Purpose Funds
description: Week ended Friday, Nov.9, 1979

title: A Life in Pictures: Lord Snowdon's 30 Years as a Photojournalist
description: I was born Tony ArmstrongJones and my byline is Snowdon  call me Tony, said the man with the bright blue eyes and toothy grin. Spiffily attired in navy blazer, rep tie and gray flannels, he was at ease in the Beekman Place apartment of his friend and publicist, Peter Schub, with the sun sparkling through the window from the East River. He was responding to a question whether he should be called Lord Snowdon now that he is no longer married to Princess Margaret of Britain. The reply was, typically, graceful and noncommittal.

title: Books of The Times A Sneeze of Poetry
description: His poetry shall live on,'unparallel, the simplicity, the multiplicity, loftiness and lowness, fragrance and flagrance, unflinchingness, promptness, ripeness, rareness, uncompliance, all so melodious and harmonious. I have read it all  all  and ensozzled myself.

title: Administration Halts Shipment Of $300 Million in Parts to Iran
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9  The Carter Administration has quietly ordered a halt in the shipment of $300 million worth of military spare parts to Iran, the first mild retaliation by the United States to the seizure of Americans in Teheran. Administration officials said the United States had not officially suspended the export of spare parts to Iran, but that none would be shipped until the impasse at the embassy in Teheran had been resolved.

title: Vintage Calvin Klein.
description: The magic American designer name in Europe these days is Calvin Klein. Do you like Calvin Klein? is the question American visitors are constantly asked in fashion circles there. The reasons are varied. He has an identifiable style  a freewheeling one that is considered as American as blue jeans; a predilection for the best European fabrics; a concern with simplicity, and an avoidance of the trendy whims of fashion.

title: L.I. Heating Oil Supplier Questioned on Spot
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9  Long Island's largest wholesaler of home heating oil, which has asked for Federal help in getting adequate supplies this winter, sold two million barrels of the fuel on the open, or spot, market last summer, although it had been notified by two of its suppliers that their contracts would not be renewed, a House inquiry was told today.

title: U.S. Sees Violations In Auto Pay
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9  The Government has notified the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company that their new threeyear contracts with the United Automobile Workers union probably violate the Carter Administration's voluntary antiinflation guidelines for pay re- qtritint

title: Staring Down the Bomb Breeders
description: President Carter's ambitious campaign to block the spread of nuclear materials that can be converted into bombs is running into stiff opposition. Nations like France, Britain and Japan are resisting. Influential study groups call the policy ineffective. Some American diplomats appear resigned to a spread of the dangerous technologies at least to safe and friendly industrial nations.

title: The Dance: Dan Wagoner
description: Dan Wagoner's dances are unusually sweettempered and his dancers are as frisky as puppies. They wiggle and squirm and dash about and then come bounding back again. Thursday night's program by Dan Wagoner and Dancers at the Brooklyn Academy of Music was a nlavful occasion.

title: JOHN S. WORDEN
description: John S. Worden, a former vice president of Texaco Inc., died Thursday at his home in Larchmont, N.Y. He was 80 years old.

title: Golden Act Is Rated CoFavorite in D.C.
description: The national turf championship could be decided this afternoon at Laurel Race Course in Maryland, where the Washington D.C. International will be run. While foreign horses have won 14 of the 27 times it has been held, two American entries, Bowl Game and Golden Act. are the favorites.

title: Stocks Up on Hope of Looser Credit
description: The stock market registered a sharp advance yesterday on the expectation that the Federal Reserve might soon relax its credittightening policy.

title: Serb Terrorist Guilty in Hijacking
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 9  Nikola Kavaja, a Serb terrorist already seNing a 20year sentence for bombing conspiracy, was convicted today by a Federal District Court jury of hijacking an American Airlines jetliner on a flight last June 20 from New York to Chicago. He could be sentenced to life in prison.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yesterday's Weather at t P.M.: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration/UPI

title: Robinson Rejoining Receivers
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 9  The Giants will have their healthiest receiver corps of the season available Sunday when Jimmy Robinson, who has yet to taste the team's success, returns from the insuredreserve list.

title: Mayor Given Extra Bodyguards
description: Extra bodyguards began accompanying Mayor Koch on his rounds of public appearances yesterday.

title: Americans Assail Iranians Rallying in Washington
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9  About 900 Iranian students, demanding the return of the deposed Shah for trial in Iran, ran headlong into thousands of angry and frustrated Americans in a demonstration today that turned downtown Washington into a verbal battlefield.

title: Japanese Fishing Ship Aground
description: SEATTLE, Nov. 9 (AP)  A Japanese factoryfishing ship, the Ryuyo Maru No. 2, ran aground today in the Pribilof Islands of Alaska, spewing 40,000 gallons of diesel oil, the Environmental Protection Agency said. A spokesman for the agency said the Coast Guard rescued the ship's 81 crew members.

title: Fredrica Teer, Executive Director And Consultant to Business, 43
description: Fredrica Teer, a consultant to business and private organizations and executive director for the National Black Theater, died Tuesday at the home of her sister in Manhattan. She was 43 years old and lived in New York.

title: Cooney Victor on Knockout
description: Gerry Cooney smashed his way into the world heavyweight picture last night at Madison Square Garden with one punch. Cooney crashed a left hook off the jaw of John (Dino) Denis and won a scheduled 10round heavyweight bout at 1 minute 14 seconds of the third round.

title: Sotheby's Innovator Giving Up the Gavel
description: LONDON, Nov. 9  Peter C. Wilson, who transformed Sotheby's from a small finearts auction house to a 19country, $380millionayear enterprise that also deals in real estate, stamps and livestock, is steeping down.

title: The City
description: Strikers Approve Green Bus Contract

title: U. S. Says Scotto Tapes Offer Best Proof
description: A prosecutor told the jury in the trial of Anthony M. Scotto yesterday that the best evidence in the case was Mr. Scotto's own voice on tape recordings of conversations about cash payments from a waterfront businessman.

title: The Region
description: NEWARK (AP)  Five men were sentenced by a Federal judge yester- day for their part in last summer's ab- duction of a New Jersey banker's wife.

title: Maritime Cadets In Bronx Felled; Food Suspected
description: One hundred and ten cadets at the State University of New York's Maritime College in the Bronx became ill Thursday night and yesterday, apparently of food poisoning, school authorities reported. It was the school's second such outbreak in less than nine months.

title: Exxon Cites Drop In Oil Stockpile
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 9 (UPI) Exxon U.S.A. said today that its stocks of crude oil were 19 percent lower at the end of last month than they were a year earlier. However, the company said that its supply of home heating oil and other distillates at that time was 6 percent higher than last year.

title: Politician Offers To Battle Jones
description: AUSTIN, Tex. Nov. 9 (UPI) A Texas legislator has challenged Ed (Too Tall) Jones, the former Dallas Cowboy football player, to a threeround bout that would force either the politician or the fish ter to retire.

title: Barclays Agrees to Buy Beneficial Units
description: The BarclaysAmericanCorporation has agreed to purchase 138 consumer fiance offices of two companies being aired by the Beneficial Corpora- tion. The cost to BarclaysAmerican is expected to be approximately $200 mil- lion.

title: Four Iranians Accused With Sudanese of Plot To Kidnap Gov. Quie
description: ST. PAUL, Nov. 9 (AP)  Four Iranians and one Sudanese, all students at Mankato State University, were arrested today near or inside the Governor's mansion on charges of conspiring to kidnap Gov. Al Quie. the police said.

title: Joseph B. Danzansky, A Washington Banker And Food Chain Head
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP)  Joseph B. Danzansky, the chairman of the board of the National Bank of Washington who was the former president of Giant Food Inc., died yesterday at his home here of an apparent heart attack. He was 65 years old.

title: British Rider Victor In Toronto Jumping
description: TORONTO, Nov. 9  Harvey Smith, a 40yearold Yorkshire farmer who is a member of the British Equestrian Team, rode Sanyo Music Center to victory in the International Jumper Class at the Royal Winter Fair horse show tonight and pulled into an early lead for the individual championship.

title: Gov. Brown, in New Haven, Offers Ener Inflation Plan
description: Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California brought his newly minted Presidential campaign to New York City last night after a day in which he stepped up his criticism of President Carter and the oil companies and proposed a sweeping program that he said would stabilize oil prices and curb inflation.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTON

title: McDonnell Indicted On Gifts
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9  The McDonnell Douglas Corporation, one of the nation's leading defense contractors, was indicted by a Federal grand jury today, along with a ranking corporate vice president and three other company officials, in connection with millions of dollars in payments to promote overseas sales of DC9 and DC10 aircraft.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: Short on Cash, County Closing Court and Jail
description: GRANT CITY, Mo., Nov. 9 (UPI) Judges in financially troubled Worth County have decided to close the courthouse, jail and road department in an effort to stretch dwindling revenues.

title: Cincinnati, in Face of a Deficit, Closing School System
description: CINCINNATI, Nov. 9 (UPI)  Cincinnati, Ohio's third largest school district, today joined the state's biggest school system, Cleveland, in shutting down, disrupting education for 150,000 students in the state.

title: High Court Removes Bar to Sale Of Rights to Offshore Oil Drilling
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP)  The Supreme Court removed one legal barrier today to the sale of offshore oil drilling rights in the Georges Bank fishing grounds off CanCod.

title: World Radio Talks Speed Up
description: GENEVA, Nov. 9 (UPI)  The World Radio Conference, way behind schedule in drawing up new global radio regulations for the coming 20 years, today adopted a schedule of dayandnight sessions, seven days a week.

title: Town Life Erodes Canadian Eskimo Pride
description: FROBISHER BAY, Northwest Territories  Graffiti, that anonymous social barometer so popular from the subways of New York to the public hallways of the Arctic, cover the siding of a store doorway where Eskimo youths congregate each afternoon.

title: Vatican Discloses Big Curia Deficit
description: ROME, Nov. 9  In apparently the first disclosure of its kind, the Roman Catholic Church announced today that its central administration, the Roman Curia, was operating with a budget deficit expected to reach 320.24 million by Dec. 31.

title: Carter Warns Top Aides to Avoid Budget Pledges He Might Overrule
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9  President Carter has sent a terse note to his Cabinet members and agency heads directing them to hold down expectations for spending next year and warning that any spending commitments they make could meet with a Presidential veto.

title: Ayatollah Gets a Plea From Pope on Hostages
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 9 (Reuters)  Pope John Paul H has sent a message to Iran's leader, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, asking him to insure the safety of the hostages being held in the American Embassy, Vatican diplomatic sources here said today.

title: Duncan Paints Dark Oil Picture
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9  Secretary of Energy Charles W. Duncan Jr. has told Congressional leaders in private briefings that world oil supplies are precarious, that there are threats to American imports from nations other than Iran and that the Carter Administration is developing contingency plans to deal with severe cuts in petroleum products.

title: U.S. Lead Cut to a Stroke
description: KAWANISHI, Japan, Nov. 9 (UPI) Tom Purtzer posted five birdies and no bogeys as he carded a five-under-par 67 today and took a fourstroke individual lead in the second round of the $135,000 U.S.Japan team golf tournament.

title: Letters
description: If Willie Mays Isn't Good Enough for Baseball

title: IN TEHERAN, PRAYERS AND DEATH CHANTS
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 9  On one of the holiest days of the Shiite Moslem calendar, thousands of Iranians knelt in Sabbath prayers here today and then streamed to the American Embassy to chant: Death to the Americans!

title: 3 Favorites in Semifinals
description: STUTTGART, West Germany, Nov. 9 (AP)  Martina Navratilova, Tracy Austin and Chris Evert Lloyd advanced today to the semifinals of a $100,000 Colgate Serles tennis tournament

title: Council Leaders Kill Plan To Erase School Deficits
description: The City Council leadership and the Board of Estimate yesterday rejected proposals by the Board of Education to eliminate a projected $42.6 million deficit in the school budget.

title: Jewelry Dealer Robbed Of $184,000 in Goods
description: A 55-year-old jewelry salesman was robbed of $184,000 in gold jewelry, diamonds and cash on a street in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn yesterday afternoon by four men, two of whom carried guns.

title: Martin, Kuhn Aides Meet In Investigation on Fight
description: Billy Martin, recently dismissed as manager of the Yankees, met for two and a half hours yesterday with members of Commissioner Bowie Kuhn's staff over Martin's involvement in a fight last month in Bloomington, Minn. The fight led to Martin's dismissal.

title: ROBERT W.KRETSCH
description: Robert Winston Kretsch, a professor of modem languages at the Polytechnic In- stitute of New York, died Thursday at the DeWitt Nursing Home in Manhattan after a long illness. He was 66 years old.

title: China Says 2,230 of Its Students Are Studying in Foreign Nations
description: PEKING, Nov. 9 (Reuters)  China has 2,230 students studying abroad, including 500 at American universities, The New China News Agency said today.

title: Khomeini Called a Lunatic
description: CAIRO, Nov. 9  President Sadat attacked Ayatollah Khomeini today as a lunatic who misrepresented Islam. The Egyptian President also criticized other Moslem leaders for failing to speak out against what he called the excesses taking place in Iran.

title: Democratic Leaders Hear Appeals For Carter's Rivals at Texas Parley
description: SAN ANTONIO, Nov. 9  The Democratic National Committee broke with tradition here today at its semiannual meeting, and heard impassioned pleas for support from advocates of President Carter, Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts and Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California.

title: Sexist
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 9  The United States Military Academy admitted today that female cadets had been ordered last summer during maneuvers to kill chickens by biting them across the tendons of their necks and that hazing antics were becoming malicious, degradina and in some cases. sexist.

title: U.S. OUTLINES STEPS TO EMBASSY SEIZURE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9  State Department officials said today that the Iranian Government had assured the American Embassy in Teheran three times that, despite the Shah's presence in the United States for medical reasons, the embassy would receive adequate security.

title: Egg-Thrower Free on Ball
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 9 (AP)  A woman accused of trying to pelt Senator Kennedy with eggs and garbage as he campaigned here yesterday has been freed on bond.

title: World News Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9  Prime Minister John Lynch of the Irish Republic today called on Britain to encourage the peaceful unification of the two parts of Ireland and asked the United States to support such an effort.

title: Genilaitis Toppled in Ecuador
description: QUITO, Ecuador, Nov. 9 (UPI) Andres Gomez of Ecuador, a virtual unknown on the international circuit, upset Vitas Gerulaitis of the United States, 64, 76, and reached the quarterfinals of a $50,000 Grand Prix tennis tournament today. Gerulaitis, the world's fifthranked player, recently won the Australian indoor title.

title: Connors, Tanner Advance
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 9 (AP)  Jimmy Connors and Roscoe Tanner advanced today to the semifinals of the $75,000 Hong Kong Tennis Classic. Connors was in brilliant form as he defeated a fellow American, Butch Walts, 61, 64. Tanner swept past Mark Edmondson of Australia, 62, 64.

title: Yale Mascot In Absentia
description: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 9  The smart money wrote it off as a prank by Princeton students in anticipation of today's football game, but the owner of Handsome Dan XII, Yale's bulldog mascot, was not amused last night when two men who said they were Yale cheerleaders borrowed the dog for a photograph and never returned it.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 10, 1979

title: 2 More Escaped Convicts Seized As Hunt Continues for 4 Others
description: MOUNDSVILLE, W.Va., Nov. 9 (UPI)  State troopers captured two more escaped convicts today but four others remained at large. They were among 15 convicted murderers and rapists who fled from the state's maximum security prison Wednesday night.

title: Around the Nation
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9 (AP)  The United States Justice Department asked a Federal judge today to allow an immediate appeal of his dismissal of parts of a lawsuit charging the Philadelphia Police Department with brutality.

title: Rate of Damage to Ozone Layer Termed Worse Than Believec
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP)  Earth's protective ozone layer is being depleted by chemicals at twice the rate previously predicted, raising concerns about possible climate changes and increases in skin cancer, the National Academy of Sciences reported yesterday.

title: Deaths
description: APTERMarilyn Wife of Samuel L. Mother of Fredric C. and Andrew Mother to Darla and Mary. Daughter of Mr &Mrs Loris Silverman. Sister of Rhoda Mintzer, grandmother of Timothy. Private grave side services 11 o'clock Sunday, November 11, at the Mount Hope Cemetery, Westchester, N.Y.

title: Golsteyn Signed by Colts As Backup After Tryout
description: BALTIMORE, Nov. 9 (AP)  Jerry Golsteyn, a free agent, was signed by the Baltimore Colts today as a backup for Greg Landry, the quarterback.

title: Farmers Squeezed by Rate Increases
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 9  Like many other bankers in the Middle West, Floyd Pinnick and W.W. Rodgers Jr. are starting to worry about the impact of their loan rates. Their principal clients are farmers who have already been rocked this year by rising costs, and farmers are among the country's most credit-dependent businessmen.

title: Hiding Behind English
description: Most Americans cannot speak or understand any anguage other than English, and the deficiency is ;rowing worse. Fifteen years ago, only one high school student in four studied a foreign language. Now the figire is one in seven. In 1966, 34 percent of American coleges required a foreign language for admission. Now mly 8 percent do. Scandalous incompetence, con- :Ludes a Commission on Foreign Language and International Studies, which has just reported to the President. Its findings merit sober attention from anyone concerned about the nation's effectiveness overseas.

title: Going Out Guide
description: VILLAGE BLOOM Judy Castelli, folk and rock singer, with Frank Christian, guitarist; and the instrumental and vocal duo called Children of Paradise are featured in tomorrow's Songwriters Concert Series at Folk City, 130 West Third Street, near the Avenue of the Americas. This is a return performance for the four musicians, in shows at 4 and 6 P.M. At other Sunday sessions, the cafe also introduces talent. Door admission tomorrow is $4; reservations are optional at 6854729.

title: Celtics Win 6th Straight
description: BOSTON, Nov. 9 (AP)  Cedric Maxwell, Dave Cowens and Nate Archibald combined to score 73 points tonight and the Boston Celtics raced to their sixth consecutive victory, beating the Kansas City Kings, 127119.

title: China Said to Weigh Lifting Revisionist Tag on Soviet
description: PEKING, Nov. 9  The Chinese Communist Party has circulated an important docunient to officials that concludes that the Soviet party should no longer be viewed as revisionist, according to knowledgeable Chinese sources.

title: Publicly Traded Funds
description: Friday, Nov. 9,1979

title: Sandra Silverman Is Wed To Robert Stephen Engel
description: Sandra Silverman, executive director of the Citizens Committee for New York City, was married yesterday to Robert Stephen Engel, president and chief operating officer of Ogden Storage, movers. The ceremony was performed at the home of Susan Glass by Rabbi Rov Rosenberg.

title: The U.N. Statement
description: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 9 (AP) Following is the text of the statement made today by the President of the United Nations Security Council, Sergio Palacios de Vizzio of Bolivia:

title: Mahaffey and Irwin Give U.S. 8Shot Lead
description: ATHENS, Nov. 9 (UPI)  John Mahaffey and Hale Irwin needed five and a half hours to complete 18 holes today in moving the United States to an eightstroke lead after the second round of the 27th World Cup golf tournament.

title: OBSERVER The Campaign Doctor
description: The phone rings constantly these days. Everybody wants advice. One moment it's John Connally. I'm a busy man, Connally, I tell him, so I'll give it to you straight from the shoulder. You've got the Arab vote and the millionaire vote. With that and Asbury Park, you could make a respectable run for alderman from the seventh district of Beirut. Lebanon.

title: Your Money
description: Valuing Assets Of Money Funds

title: Curbing Seattle's Police
description: SEATTLE  The postWatergate years have brought disclosures that police agencies have engaged in largescale collection of personal and political information about people's lawful activities. In Seattle, local policemen spied on black construction workers, Indians, antiwar activists and advocates of various causes.

title: New York Telephone Wins 4.5% Increase, $166 Million a Year
description: The New York Telephone Company won state approval yesterday for a 4.5 percent rate increase totaling $166 million a year. The company said the increase would cost the average New York City residential user 76 cents a month.

title: Notes on People
description: Hectic Party

title: Man Charged in Chesimard Escape
description: A Brooklyn man was arrested last night and charged with helping Joanne Chesimard, a former leader of the Black Liberation Army, escape last week from a New Jersey prison where she was serving a life term for the slaying of a state trooper, a spokesman for the Federal Bureau of Investigation said.

title: SPECIAL U.S. ENVOYS STILL WAIT IN TURKEY
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 9  President Carter's special representatives waited anxiously in Istanbul today for authorization to enter Iran but there were no developments, according to official American sources.

title: Helping the Iranians Change Their Minds
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  However outrageous the seizure of American hostages by Iranian students, we. should act analytically and purposively. Our purposes are, first, power  to preserve the reputation and prestige of the United States; second, peace to enhance respect for international law and order, largely by avoiding bad precedents; and, third, success  to win the release of the hostages.

title: U.S. and Korea to Hold A Joint Military Exercise
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 9 (Reuters)  The Combined Forces Command formed by the United States and South Korea will carry out a threeday exercise to test responses to a possible attack by North Korea, a command spokesman said today.

title: F.A.A. to Tighten Rules Against Unsafe Aircraft
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP)  The Federal Aviation Administration said today that it planned to crack down on what it called unscrupulous operators who fly unsafe aircraft.

title: Reed to Meet Pistons Today
description: Willis Reed will fly to Detroit this afternoon, seeking the Piston coaching job, exactly one year after he was dismissed as coach of the New York Knicks. After Reed spoke with Oscar Feldman, the Pistons legal counsel, yesterday morning, an airport meeting was set up between Reed and William Davidson, the Piston owner.

title: Judge Rules Catholics Must Pay For Pope's Philadelphia Platform
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9 (AP)Judge Raymond Broderick of Federal District Court ruled today that the Roman Catholic Archdiocese must pay for the platform built here for the visit of Pnne John Paul II.

title: Holiday Closings
description: Some banks will be open and some closed on Monday, Veterans Day. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York will be closed, while the stock exchanges and corporate bond markets will be open.

title: ExGuard Testifies He Received $5,000 for Photos of Berkowitz
description: A former New York City correction officer testified yesterday that he received more than $5,000 from a freelance writer for providing prison pictures and information about David R. Berkowitz after Mr. Berkowitz's 1977 arrest as the Son of Sam killer.

title: Nanseroan Wins
description: WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 9  Nanseroan and Muckalle Strike led the qualifiers into next week's final of the Silver Spoon series for 2yearold pacers at Roosevelt Raceway by sdoring victories tonight.

title: Countdown Set for Bowl Berths
description: BATON ROUGE, Nov. 9  Three games that may go a long way toward deciding which teams play in the Sugar and Orange Bowls will be contested at sites strung along a 400mile stretch of Interstate 10.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Church Council Postpones Move To Sanction Israel on Palestinians
description: The governing board of the National Council of Churches, meeting in New York City, yesterday postponed action on a controversial resolution that accused Israelis of violating the human rights of Palestinians and called for an end to all United States aid to Israel.

title: Paris Controllers Block Takeoffs
description: PARIS, Nov. 9 (Reuters)  Paris airtraffic controllers refused to give takeoff clearances for four and a half hours today and said there would be more stoppages over the weekend and next week. Major airlines have rescheduled flights to bypass France so the controllers action mainly affected internal flights.

title: Tellico Dam's Foes Lose Another Battle in Court
description: KNOXVILLE, Term., Nov. 9 (AP) Opponents of the Tellico Dam lost another court battle today when a Federal appeals court refused to forbid the Tennessee Valley Authority from completing the embattled dam.

title: Retail Sales Down 1.7% For Month
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (UPI)  Re- tail sales across the country fell 1.7 per- cent in October from September's total, the sharpest monthly drop in four and a half years, the Commerce De- partment reported today. Automotive sales paced the sharp decline by falling 8.2 percent.

title: SADAT OFFERS SHAH A REFUGE IN EGYPT
description: Sends Envoy to New York to Visit Deposed Ruler, Who Says He Will Consider Invitation

title: The New York Times/Jeffrey D. Smith
description: Councilmen Call for Investigation of Treatment of Hispanic Prisoners City Councilmen Gilberto Gerena Valentin, left, of the Bronx and Luis A. Olmedo, second from left, of Brooklyn, talking with Carlos Velez, an inmate at the Bronx House of Detention who said he was beaten and verbally abused by guards at the facility. Alter nearing complaints from relatives of inmates and visiting the facilty, the Councilmen called for an investigation into the treatment of Hispanic persons in correctional system.

title: Publisher Correcting
description: A book about how the Central Intelligence Agency and British intelligence helped to overthrow Prime Minister Mohammed Mossadegh in 1953 and put the Shah of Iran  now hospitalized in New York  in power has been called back by the publisher, the McGrawHill Publishing Company, to correct socalled inaccuracies. Some 7,000 copies are being scrapped and a corrected version of the book will apnear at the end of January.

title: President Tells Nation Not to Vent Its Outrage Over Embassy Seizure
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9  President Carter today asked Americans to suppress their outrage, anger and frustration about the events in Iran and to support Washington's efforts, through quiet diplomacy, to win the release of the Americans held hostage in Teheran.

title: World Gold
Gamble Breaks His Collarbone
description: Oscar Gamble of the New York Yankees broke his left collarbone yesterday playing basketball in a pickup game at his home in Mont: gomery, Ala., the club said yesterday.

description: Morning

title: PARK ASSASSINATON REENACTED ON TV
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 9  Millions of South Koreans watched a televised reenactment of President Park Chung Hee's assassination tonight in which Kim Jae Kyu, former director of the Korean Central Intelligence Agency, calmly showed prosecutors how he pulled out a pistol over dinner and shot the President.

title: The Law And The Rules
description: BOSTON  Out of the logjam in our courts, the outrageous costs of litigation, and the poor quality of trial ad vocacy, a fullblown courtreform movement has emerged. President Carter, in his courtimprovement proposal early this year, has challenged the courts to experiment with less-for- mal resolution of disputes such as arbitration. He also suggested greater reliance on magistrates. Chief Justice Warren E. Burger urges better training for trial lawyers and judges. Others would give judges more control over each step in a lawsuit.

title: UTILITY IN MICHIGAN FACES $450,000 FINE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9  The Nuclear Regulatory Commission today proposed that a Michigan utility be fined $450,000, the largest fine in the commission's history, because the utility forgot for 18 months to close the valve on a fourinch pipe leading from a reactor containment building.

title: Associated Press
description: SUNS OVERTAKE CAVALIERS, 110106: Kenny Carr of the Cavaliers going up for a layup over Suns Johnny High during game last night in Phoenix. Although the Cavaliers led most of the game, the Suns rallied in the fourth quarter to win.

title: New York Residents Are Angered And Frustrated by Situation in Iran
description: People in New York City expressed anger and frustration about the American hostages being held in Iran as they gathered yesterday in lobbies and on plazas and sidewalks to chat during breaks from work.

title: SOUTH KOREA CALLS PRESIDENTIAL VOTE
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Saturday, Nov. 10  Acting President Choi Kyu Hah announced today that elections will be held soon for a President to replace Park Chung Hee and, in an indication of sweeping democratic reform, said that the new President should then work toward revising the South Korean constitution.

description: Interest rates dropped sharply yes- terday, pushed downward by slower growth in the money supply and the biggest decline in retail sales in more than fnnr vearc

title: NEW SCHOOL POLICY SEEN IN PITTSBURGH
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 9  The defeat of three members of the Pittsburgh Board of Education by challengers who have expressed prointegration views is regarded here as portending significant changes in school policies.

title: False Alarm on Attack Sends Fighters into Sky
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (UPI)  A false alarm in the nation's early warning system sent 10 fighters into the air today before Pentagon officials determined that the nation was not being attacked by hostile missiles.

title: Pennsy Purchase Of Marathon Gains
description: The Penn Central Corporation announced yesterday that it had completed negotiating the financial terms of its proposed acqusition of the Marathon Manufacturing Company.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (UPI) A cash flow problem threatened to block President Carter's reelection committee from meeting its next payroll because funds were diverted to his campaign tour next month, officials said yesterday.

So have Dr. Frank Field, Dizzy Gillespie, Eli Wallach, Anne Jackson, Geoffrey Holder, Fred Gwynne and Jose Ferrer, all of them joining the legion of lawyers, doctors, diplomats, psychiatrists and status-seekers-about-town who already boast at least one.

description: The Studio Museum in Harlem, after a twoyear search for a new home and much soulsearching over where that home should be, has found a new home  on 125th Street in Harlem.

title: 1981 Militacry Budget Said to Seek Funds for 18 to 20 New Warship.
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9  The Garter Administration, refining its military budget proposals for the next fiscal year, plans a large increase in naval shipbuilding and an expansion of air and sea transport to deploy strike forces rapidly in emergencies, according to wellplaced officials:

title: Jazz: Highlights
description: There was a good representation of former Ellingtonians at the Highlights in Jazz concert on Thursday evening at the Loeb Student Center called The Duke Ellington Alumni. But, as chance would have it, two of the three most interesting performers were musicians who had no relationship to Mr. Ellington.

title: 300,000 Cans of Infant Formula Are Recalled Over Fear of Illness
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP)  The Food and Drug Administration said yesterday that Wyeth Laboratories was recalling 300,000 cans of its SMA infant formula because of a homogenization problem that made some infants mildly ill.

title: Canada Favors Higher Oil Tax
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 9 (Reuters)  The Canadian Government wants to increase taxes on oil company earnings that increase because of higher domestic prices, Prime Minister Joe Clark said today.

title: State Employees to Vote on New Contract Nov. 19
description: The 97,000 New York State employees represented by the Public Employees Federation are scheduled to begin voting Nov. 19 on a controversial labor contract that has been recommended by the union president but opposed by a majority of the federation's executive board.

title: About New York
description: Fertile Minds in Unlikely Soil

title: Blacks Come to Power in Oakland and Whites
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 9  In the mid1960's, the people who had been in charge around here for a century could see the change coming. Upperclass whites, Republican and conservative, felt their city was being overrun by blacks who one day would outvote them and take control of government in Oakland.

title: Kennedy, in Deep South, Charges President With Neglect on Crime
description: CHARLESION, S.C., Nov. 9  Senator Edward M. Kennedy, swinging through the Deep. South in search of support for his Presidential campaign, charged President Carter today with incredible neglect of the nation's crime and justice Problems.

title: Four West German Tourists Die After Boat Capsizes Near Sicily
description: LIPARI, Italy, Nov. 9 (AP)  A motor launch carrying 23 tourists capsized after running into rocks off this island north of Sicily today and four West Germans were drowned, the police said. Engine trouble combined with the effects of a big wave caused by a passing liner may have driven the boat onto the rocks, the police added.

description: 1. Demonstrators occupying the Statue of Liberty unfurled the banner pictured above, bearing their message of protest. What was printed on the banner?

title: Associates Press
description: PACHYDERMS POUND THE PAVEMENT: Handlers from the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus walking elephants along the road yesterday in Peninsula, Ohio. The animals were being moved to the Richfield Coliseum, where they will perform for the next two weeks.

title: Disorder in the California Court
description: Putting an entire court on trial has to be an ugly business, especially when it is as renowned as the California Supreme Court. What seems even worse is this week's ending to a year's inquiry by the State Commission on Judicial Performance: an announcement that no charges will be pressed against any justice, and no explanations. Some regard that inconclusive result as proof that the whole exercise was ludicrous. But for all its drawbacks, the investigation was still better than no investigation at all; some good may yet come of it.

title: Koch Assistants Carty Machines That Record His Public Statements
description: The tape recorder has become a ubiquitom symbol of Mayor Koch's administration, perhaps the most pressconscious administration to occupy City Hall in recent years.

title: U.S. and Phillips Reach Consent Pact on Oil Price
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP)  The Energy Department and the Phillips Petroleum Company reached a $200 million consent agreement today in which the oil company said it would purchase, refine and sell heating oil at lower than market prices.

title: This Giant Calls Size Internal
description: Steve Cady

title: Tarocchi, cavoli, belle cavolelle, donne, oh!
description: Not the pleasantest moment in any move is waking up in a new bed and not knowing where you are, or think- ing you are where you most decidedly aren't  your home or the last place you slept in. This bit of disorientation wac cmnething I had learned to expect in all my travels, but I was spared it early one morning in a Rome hotel after a flight from Boston, for I was aroused in my sleep by the call of an itinerant broom seller on the street right outside my window. Scoparo! it went, or rather Scopaaaro! and I immediately knew where I was. Yes, the cry was quite unmistakable; the Roman accent and familiar enunciation of the word clearly told me I could be nowhere else. It was a call I had never heard except in Rome, but in Rome always. It had the unabashed boldness of a cock's crow. There was also a certain sweep in the way the word was said, as if the very action, function of the broom were expressed. I got up and went to the window. There was the man, looking more like an exotic bird  a peacock perhaps  than a man, with several brooms on his shoulders, the handles all different colors and the straw pointing up to the sky, and whisks, and dusters made of soft real feathers, plumes, hanging from his forearms. What a load! How did he manage it? Myself, if I carried so much as an umbrella I felt encumbered.

title: 3 Suspected of CopperWire Thefts Found Electrocuted Next to Ladder
description: BAYONNE, N.J., Nov. 9  Three alleged thieves cutting down valuable, inactive copper electrical wires from utility poles in a desolate industrial yard were electrocuted last night when their aluminum extension ladder touched a 26,000volt line about eight feet above the dead wires, the police said.

title: Flames Strike Fast With Three Scores, Defeat Islanders, 52
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 9  The score of the game tonight was 52, the Atlanta Flames over the Islanders. As for why it had come out that way, it depended on whose ooint of view you listened to.

title: Jet Defense a Bulwark Against the Big Play
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 9  The Jets talk of this season's first Buffalo game, a 4631 loss, as if it were a rite of passage, an experience that brought them from adolescence into adulthood .

title: SECURITY COUNCIL URGES IRAN TO FREE AMERICAN HOSTAGES; CARTER ASKS PUBLIC RESTRAINT
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 9 The Security Council voiced its profound concern today for the American hostages in Teheran and urged in the strongest terms that they be released without delay.

title: Music: Pianist On Romantics
description: Pamela Mia Paul, who appeared at Alice Tully Hall Thursday night, is a young pianist who has performed with such orchestras as the Pittsburgh and Vienna Symphonies. She made her New York recital debut seven seasons ago, as a winner of the Concert Artists Guild auditions.

title: SENATE COMMITTEE SUPPORTS ARMS PACT BY A VOTE OF 9 TO 6
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9  The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted 9 to 6 today to send the strategic arms treaty with the Soviet Union to the full Senate with the recommendation that it consent to ratification.

title: Texas Millionaire Is Cleared of Soliciting a Murder
description: FORT WORTH, Nov. 9 (UPI)  T. Cullen Davis was found not guilty today of soliciting the murder of the judge in his divorce case and within two hours was declared free of all the murderrelated charges that have hung over his head since 1976.

title: U.S. Puts Corn Crop at a Record, Up 7% From 78
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) Farmers are harvesting a record corn crop of 7.59 billion bushels this fall, the Agriculture Department said today. The huge harvest, up 7 percent from last year, will also serve as a reserve for what officials expect will be a record foreign demand for United States corn, wheat and other commodities.

title: Official Status Asked for Empire State
description: The Empire State Building, the onetime king of skyscrapers that has been featured in countless movies, memorialized in song and probably sold almost as many times as the Brooklyn Bridge, has been recommended for the first time for designation as an official New York City landmark.

title: George A. Spiegelberg Dies at 82; Trial Lawyer Helped Lend Lease
description: George A. Spiegelberg, a trial lawyer who helped extend Lend Lease during World War II, died Tuesday in Bradford, Conn. He was 82 years old.

title: California Drops Inquiry on Charge Linking High State Aide to Thefts
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 9  The California Attorney General's office said today that it had ended an inquiry into allegations that Lieut. Gov. Mike Curb was involved with organized crime figures in the sale of stolen phonograph records.

title: Cousins: A Briton Skating In Style
description: Robin Cousins of Britain, a 22yearold figure skater, appears primed to win a gold medal at the 1980 Winter Olympics in Lake Placid, N.Y. He placed third in the world championships in 1978, was second this year, and won the gold medal in the freeskating competition both years. An extraordinary free skater, with a dazzling spirit to match, Cousins has grace, charm and an identifiable style that one former figure. skating iudge calls exciting.

title: Corporate Reports
B.P. Stock Sale Oversubscribed
description: LONDON, Nov. 9 (AP)  The British Government's offer to sell about 5 percent of its holdings of British Petroleum Ltd. to the public was oversubscribed today, one minute after the offer became available.

title: Two Banks Agree to Merge
description: WATERTOWN, N.Y., Nov. 9 (UPI)  The National Bank of Northern New York, which has 17 branches in four northern counties, and Key Bank Inc., a statewide bank holding company with headquarters in Albany, announced today that they had agreed to merge.

title: Mrs. Carter Visits Thai Camp: It's Like Nothing I've Seen
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 9  Rosalynn Carter walked through the hospital and orphanage tents of a camp for 30,000 Cambodian refugees today, knelt next to the mats on which the sick lie in the sand and declared at the end of her visit, It's like nothing I've ever seen.

title: ExUnion Leader on Carter Staff
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP)  John Ryor, who stepped down as president of the National Education Association in September, has quietly joined the White House staff as a $47,500ayear aide. Mr. Ryor said that he began work Monday as an assistant to Anne Wexler, President Carter's assistant for public liaison.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP)  The Justice. Department said today that six concrete companies and six of their executives had been indicted by a Federal grand jury on charges of conspiring to rig bids and allocate contracts on high- way bridge projects in California, Nevada and Arizona.

title: A WOUND THAT; WILL NOT HEAL
description: On April 19, 1968, on a narrow, scorched section of Route 9, the road to besieged Khe Sanh, the lead squad of Golf Company, Second Battalion, Ninth Marines moved slowly toward the edge of an open bridge. The marines held the road, but the intractable North Vietnamese Army owned the murderous high ground above it. The bridge, which straddled a deep ravine, was the objective of both sides.

title: Anne V. Berrill Is Married to John M. Whalen, a Lawyer.
description: Anne V. Berrill, a speechwriter and special assistant to the commissioner of the New York City Human Re- sources Administration, was married yesterday in New Milford, Conn., to John M. Whalen, a lawyer in Manches- ter, Vt. Msgr. James F. Coffey per- formed the ceremony in St. Francis Xavier Roman Catholic Church.

title: Duck Stamp Painting Wins Artist $1 Million
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP)Richard W. Plasschaert earned an estimated $1 million Thursday. That is the amount that he is expected to receive for his small painting of two ducks.

title: Inside General Motors
description: A new book appeared on the financial desks of the nation's news organizations last week, a book that seemed unlikely to ever see print. It was John Z. DeLorean's purported look behind the closed doors of the General Motors Corporation's executive suite. It is not a book that the country's biggest industrial company is likely to recommend to its many employees and stockhold- ers. What it portrays is an often befud- dled giant that is short on planning and creativity and long on executive perks and cronyism.

title: Georgia Wins, 3310; Irish Routed by Vols
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Nov. 10 (AP) - Buck Belue threw three touchdown passes today a: Georgia took advantage of Florida mistakes, beat the Gators, 3310, and moved to within one victory of clinching a Sugar . Bowl berth.

title: Seamen Look to Courts to End Slavery and Piracy
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 10 (AP)  A group of Peruvian seamen left their homes on a flight to the Netherlands, hired as crew- men on a ship sailing from Rotterdam straight home to Peru  a onemonth trip, at most.

title: A Long, Hard Road To, Fiddle Virtuosity
description: EDISON

title: Michigan County's Secession Drive Evoking 1835
description: EDWARDSBURG, Mich., Nov. 10 And who would cut up Michigan?

title: 3 States Feel Small Quake
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (UPI)  A small earthquake shook the tristate area of Ohio, Kentucky and West Virginia at 4:30 P.M. yesterday in the vicinity of Ash- land, Ky., the United States Geological Survey reported today. The survey's earthquake information service in Gold- en, Colo., said the quake registered about 3.3 on the openended Richter scale, not strong enough to cause much, if any, damage, a spokesman said. He said there were no reports of damage.

title: China to Levy Airport Tax
description: PEKING, Nov. 9 (Reuters)  China will impose a tax on airline passengers starting Jan. 1, according to the latest issue of its air services timetable. The tax of about $6 will be levied at the Peking, Shanghai and Canton airports.

title: Donna C. Anderson  Wed to Peter Krug
description: The marriage of Donna Clare Ander- son, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Freder- ick J. Anderson of New Canaan, Conn., to Peter B. Krug, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul L. Krug of Stamford, Conn., took nlace yesterday in Larchmont. N.Y.

title: 20,000 Toy Telephones Recalled As Electrical Hazard to Children
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (UPI)  The Consumer Product Safety Commission says that Montgomery Ward & Company is recalling. 20,000 toy telephone sets because children could be shocked or burned if they plugged the cords into electrical outsets.

title: Sunday Observer
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, has sound advice for Americans who want to get the economy back on the tracks. Lower your standard of living, he says. Unfortunately, he hasn't advanced any advice on precisely how to lower your standard of living, nor has anybody else ever come up with a foolproof method for doing the trick.

title: Marriages
description: SILVERMANFRIED

title: Agencies Aiding Cambodians
description: The following agencies are providing food and supplies for Cambodian refugees in Thailand. Those wanting to contribute to the Cambodian relief effort may write to one of them.

title: Chicago's Whites Seen As Minority Next Year
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 10 (AP)  Because of Chicago's declining population, blacks and HispanicAmericans will outnumber whites in the nation's secondlargest city in 1980 for the first time, a population expert has told a United States House subcommittee.

title: AIRLINES ENCOUNTER DEREGULATION SNAGS
description: After marking its first anniversary, airline deregulation, which became an instant success as an antiinflationary tool by ushering in an era of falling fares, rising competition and growing industry profits, has suddenly run into serious difficulty.

title: Those New Manhattan HighRises:
description: Some of the gaps in the Manhattan skyline have been filled lately by tall new apartment buildings that contain the smallest rooms and the highest rents of the set of postwar apartment houses that have become known as luxury highrises.

description: Midnight. Two huge magic boots dance in front of you. When the boottongues clap back and forth they say Inside my bones,/ Inside my meat,/ Inside my heart,/ Inside my FEET! And

title: Firemen Give Up Effort To Put Out Tanker Fire
description: GAINESTON, Tex., Nov. 10 (AP) Firefighters gave up trying to extinguish a 10-day-old fire on a crippled tanker today. They said that they would let the blaze burn itself out and try to keep it from spreading.

title: Palestinians Deported By Bavarians, Ending A Dispute With Bonn
description: BONN, Nov. 10  The Bavarian state government yesterday deported two Palestinians convicted of smuggling explosives into the country, ending a twoweek struggle of wills between the Government of Chancellor Helmut Schmidt and his conservative opponent in next year's election. Franz Josef Strauss.

title: In the New China, 1 + 1 Can = 4 No More
description: PEKINGTwo decades ago, China's most prominent economist, a man named Ma Yinchu, daringly warned that the country's population was expanding too fast and would interfere with economic development plans. For his temerity in going against a Marxist belief that more people mean more production, Mr. Ma was attacked and purged from his job as President of Peking University.

title: Marine Guards Are Trained for Limited Missions
description: QUANTICO, Va. Nov. 9The young Marine corporal jumped to attention behind bulletproof glass at Post No. as he was asked what he would do if someor.e charged through the door and threw a gasoline bomb against the map of the world that covered the waitingroom wall.

title: LETTER TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: As the providers of longterm care services in New Jersey, we have been following your series on problems of the aged with considerable interest. While agreeing in principle with many of your criticisms about the quality of care provided, we take issue with you on three points.

title: HOKE CLINIC Saving Heat Lost Up Chimneys

With most conventional types, only about 10 percent of the heat created by the burning wood actually finds its way out into the room where the fireplace is situated  the rest simply goes up the chimney and is wasted.

title: Flyers Top Islanders; Rangers 54 Victors
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Nov. 10  We have nowhere to go but up, said Glenn (Chico) Resch tonight following the Islanders 52 loss to the Philadelphia Flyers. It was the Flyers first regularseason National Hockey League victory at Nassau Coliseum since April 5, 1975, and it put them 10 points ahead of the Islanders in the Patrick Division race.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP)  The Food and Drug Administration has or- dered that warning labels, timers and other safeguards be put on sunlamps to protect the public from overexposure.

title: BRIDGE
description: More than in most other sports and recreations, the results of bridge tournaments are liable to be affected by apparently trivial decisions by lawmakers and administrators. Consider for example the most exciting world team championship ever played, won by the United States over Italy last month in Rio De Janeiro by the tiny margin of five international match points.

title: Abandoned Effort After the Gandhi Era
description: NEW DELHI  At a gas station near this city's Embassy Row, officials from the Health Ministry a short while ago unveiled the country's first automatic condom dispenser with a statement that such machines are to be placed in a number of locations and that they may encourage the use of contraceptives by Indian men who have been too shy to purchase them from shopclerks.

title: ANTIQUES
description: Over the last decade, kilims - those boldly patterned, flatwoven rugs made throughout the Middle East from the 10th century on have increasingly attracted the most sophisticated collectors. But until now enthusiasts were frustrated in their efforts to enlarge their knowledge and appreciation of these weavings, so seldom did museums and galleries offer formal exhibitions and publishers issue books that treated kilims as more than a footnote.

title: PAYING FOR COLLEGE
description: WHO can't afford to go to college? Theoretically now, the answer is no one. This is not because the cost of attending a fouryear college is going down. Like almost everything else these days, college is expensive and getting more expensive. This year, on average, those who have gone off to state school are paying $3,200 for nine months of board, room, tuition, books and incidentals. Those who have landed at a private college are paying anywhere from $4,000 to $9,000.

title: Small Dallas Airport Flourishing In Fight With Larger Competitor
description: DALLAS, Nov. 10  When the 17,500- acre DallasFort Worth Airport opened in 1974, the only casualty was supposed to be Dallas's rickety Love Field, the aging, congested airport that the new field planned to put out of business.

Garrett Jr. of Scarbor- ough, N.Y., to Timothy Benner Simp- son, son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Wil- liam H. Simpson of Lyruifield, Mass. The .ceremony was performed by the Rev. Richard Puryear.

description: Mr. and Mrs. Paul Brown of Merrick, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Gail F. Brown, to Dennis M. Karr, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carlyle Karr of Scarsdale, N.Y. The wedding is planned for Dec. 2.

description: Lisa Whitridge Collier and John Post Cool were married yesterday in St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church. The Rev. Bruce Forbes performed the ceremony.

description: A man needs his land, his territorial imperative, says Ron Marshall, 47 years old, who bought his home in Closter, N.J., three years ago. My need for a house goes back to my old New England individualism.

description: Lieut. (j.g.) Pamela Ann Connor, Nurse Corps, U.S.N., and Lieut. Colin Campbell Osborn, also of the Navy, were married yesterday in All Saints Episcopal Church in Leonia, N.J. title: Yale Captures Ivy Crown By Beating Princeton, 3510
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 10- Yale's undefeated football team crushed Princeton, 3510, with four touchdowns in the second half and won the Ivy championship before a crowd of 22,825 on a rainy afternoon at Palmer Stadium today.

description: GENEVA, Nov. 10 (Reuters)  More than 6,700 Vietnamese and Laotians fled to neighboring Southeast Asian countries last month, the United Nations said this week.

title: DINING OUT Where Simplicity Is the Best Course
description: FOR atmosphere, An OldFashioned Fellow in Jericho is an immensely appealing restaurant. The barnlike slateblue building with its carved, gilded sign has been divided into two dining rooms, separated by an ample yet cozy bar done in mellow oak and brick. The inviting wood- paneled dining room to the right, with a fire glowing in the hearth, is perfect on a chilly evening. Tables are nicely set with candles, flowers, white and brown napery and Windsor chairs. The other room, equally handsome, has a cathedral ceiling, slate floor and immense mullioned windows.

title: Tito, at 87, Still Has Firm Grip on the Reins in Yugoslavia

title: 2 Ensembles Opening
description: THOUGH the Long Island Philharmonic was formed in hope of furnishing a single, fullsize Long Island orchestra, the new season finds the Philharmonic competing with a new version of the Long Island Symphony, created by the musicians of the former Long Island Symphony, which was disbanded earlier this year by its board of directors. In fact, the openi.ng concerts of both the Long Island Philharmonic and the new Long Island Symphony fall on the same three evenings. A third professional Long Island orchestra, the 35member Orchestra Da Camera, begins its 197980 season this afternoon.

Rinck's grocery and Amoco station here, is something of countrystore philosopher. Recumbent in a spavined old easy chair in the middle of the cluttered room, he reflected on the rightness of things:

title: Shazam! A Shortcut for Computers
description: A garment manufacturer has three kinds of dresses  A, B and C. On hand he has 17 bolts of one cloth and 25 of another, as well as 200 buttons and 75 belts. He has three cutters, 10 sewers and one finisher. Dress A, on which he makes a profit of $1.25 a unit, requires one combination of material, accessories and work; the B dress, with a $1.50 profit, takes a different combination, and the $2.25 dress C has yet a third set of require- ments. Now should he schedule his production to make the most money?

title: AvantGarde: Max Neuhaus Sounds
description: Max Neuhaus is the most interesting, challenging environmental composer we have, the aural equivalent of Christo in the visual arts. What that means is that Mr. Neuhaus creates soundworks that exist for particular spaces, are sustained there continu- ously by electronic soundgenerating devices and are perceived by the ob- server in the same way a work of art in a gallery or an evironmental artwork is perceived.

title: Cornell Routs Columbia by 247
description: ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 10  Columbia's football miseries continued today as the Lions committed six turnovers and managed only one touchdown in 247 loss to Cornell before 6,000 fans at Schoellkopf Field.

title: Music: Debuts in Review
description: Jose Maria Pinzolas, whose New York debut took place last Sunday night at Alice Tully Hall, is a young Spanish pianist who has appeared throughout Europe. He played Bach's Partite in D, Liszt's B minor Sonata, and excerpts from Iberia by Albeniz and Goyescas by Granados.

title: Inflation: How 2 Families Cope
description: IT was a bright Saturday morning, seemingly not a day for worries about winter, as Douglas Pink watched a plumber drain the water from the pipes in the firstfloor master bedroom of his Hartsdale home. It was being done to protect the pipes from freezing, because Mr. Pink and his wife, Patricia, had decided to close off their bedroom and move to upstairs quarters.

title: Pope John Paul Honors Einstein
description: ROME, Nov. 10 (AP)  Pope John Paul II honored Albert Einstein today at a Vatican ceremony commemorating the centennial of the late physicist's birth. In his speech, the Pontiff equated the contributions of Mr. Einstein with those of Galileo Galilei, the 17th century physicist who, the Pope noted, was wrongly condemned by the Roman Catholic Church for advocating that the earth was not the center of the universe.

title: Refugees Fleeing to Salisbury
description: SALISBURY, Zimbabwe . Rhodesia, Nov. 10 (Reuters)  Zimbabwe Rhodesian refugees fleeing to the capital from the guerrilla war in the countryside have more than doubled the population of Salisbury, the city health officer said this week. The population is now 1 million to 1.5 million, he said, compared with 600,000 at the last census, in 1969.

description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Nov. 10 Williams won the Little Three title today by turning back Amherst, 1913, as Coach Bob Odell's Ephmen notched their seventh title in the last nine years.

title: MUSIC Offbeat Is in Tempo For Three Programs
description: THE New York State Symphoilia, a chambersized ensemble, will begin its second season in the Emelin Theater in Mamaroneck today at 2 P.M. The or- chestra is being brought to Mamaroneck by Louis Simon, conductor of the Hudson Valley Symphony. The idea is to bring topnotch performances to our audiences, he said, and also to revive some wonderful pieces that everybody else seems to have forgotten.

title: Home of the Artist Cole Nearer to Being Museum
description: CATSKILL, N.Y., Nov. 8  The headline in the local paper in 1962 read, Catskill Home of Thomas Cole Stud- ied for State Museum. Today, 17 years later, the project is one step closer to reality.

title: ABOUT CARS
description: Marshall Schuon

title: HOW THE NETWORK DIDN'T WORK
description: The Oregon primary was crucial to Robert Kennedy's 1968 campaign. This is how Bobby's people blew it.

title: A Helping Hand For the ExOffender
description: PARK RIDGE

title: Remaking All Quiet on the Western Front
description: MOST, Czechoslovakia It is ghostly quiet here, with dozens of stunted, blackened trees poking through a smokey battlefield. Their branches have been blown off by ex- plosives and the stumps have been singed by flame throwers. Hundreds of rubber tires are kept smoldering to provide a constant haze of smoke over the fighting. Trenches are sluiced down hourly with water cannon, and actors wade ankledeep in mud.

title: The Travels of Strider
description: At first, it seems a decidedly unlikely subject even for a venturesome Off Broadway theater, let alone Broadway: the story of a piebald horse

description: WASHINGTON

title: Another Bastion Falls to Women: Oxford
description: OXFORD, ENGLAND

title: Erving Sparkles as 76ers Nip Celtics, 9594
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10  At the end of the first quarter, Larry Bird of the Celtics scored 8 points in two minutes and Julius Erving, the 76er guarding him, was benched.

title: POINT OF VIEW Why the Fed's Cure Won't Work
description: The Volcker recession of 1980? is a terribly expensive way to restrain the American appetite for imported oil. But with more efficient energy policies not yet in place, the Federal Reserve chairman, Paul A. Volcker, had little choice. He faced serious risk of an endless vicious cycle of inflation, oil price increases, trade deficits and dollar depreciation, all feeding on each other.

title: THE LIVELY ARTS Keene Picks Up Philharmonic Baton
description: THE Long Island Philharmonic, which its supporters hope will join the Performing Arts Foundation (PAF) and the Eglevsky Ballet to become a third cultural cornerstone on the Island, makes its debut this weekend under the baton of Christopher Keene, a young conductor with a growing reputation.

title: Private Schools Get A New Student Breed
description: FOR the first time in its 74 years, the McCallie School in Chattanooga will not be holding weeknight dinner gettogethers for its new parents. These have been rescheduled to Saturday lunches because, according to Spencer McCallie, headmaster and greatgrandson of the school's founder, so many of our parents work in jobs that run into the evening and on night shifts that a whole block of them would have to be left out otherwise.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: A GOOD SCHOOL, by Richard Yates. (Dell, $2.25.) The death throes of Dorset Academy, a funny little boys school nobody ever heard of, the painful coming-of-age of its last graduating class and, in particu lar, the case of Bill Grove, who can't make its teams but does become editor of its newspaper. Our reviewer, Julian Moynahan, called this novel about the early 1940's a firstclass work of the imagination, marked by a sophisticated awareness of the ambiguous relation between any fiction and reallife sources.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: BEING a woman and a Democrat have usually been liabilities in seeking elective office in Southampton Town, but last Tuesday Patricia Neumann overcame both and won a seat on the allmale Republican Town Board. She is the first woman ever elected to public office in Southampton Town.

title: Survey of Civil Service Reports Most Workers Contented With Jobs
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10  Most Federal Civil Service workers say they are satisfied with their jobs and care greatly about what happens in their agencies, according to a new survey. But 56 percent of them also say they think it is unlikely that they will be promoted or get a raise if they do their jobs especially well.

title: Nancy Jill Greenstein Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank T. Greenstein of Lancaster, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Jill Greenstein, to Kenneth Alan Jones, son of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Jones Jr. of Grand Junction, Colo. The wedding is planned on March 15. Miss Greenstein is with the textile department of Nissho Iwai American Corporation in New York. Mr. Jones is a student at Colorado State University.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: As a member of the Rutgers University community, I am quite aware of the distressing rape problem that exists. Therefore, I was very disturbed by the interview [Oct. 14] with Lily Tu, president of the Rutgers University Parents Council.

title: Carol Patterson Engaged to Jeffrey Sanders
description: Col. William H. Patterson Jr., U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Patterson of Merritt Island, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carol Margaret Patterson, to Jeffrey C. Sanders, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles M. Sanders of Carlisle, Pa.

title: Consumer and Government Forces Pushing for JobCompetency Tests
description: WHEN when Albert Codi needed a new mechanic for his White Plains service station three years ago, he interviewed several young men. All were wellqualified, but Mr. Codi chose Danny Smallen, a 23-year-old mechanic certified by the National Institute for Automotive Service Excellence (N.I.A.S.E.). The fact that Danny had passed the examination was a key factor in my selection, recalled Mr. Codi. It's not that the other applicants weren't good, but since Danny was certified, I was more assured of his competence.

title: GARDENING
description: AS another outdoor gardening season comes to a close, number of important tasks may remain to be accomplished. In some instances, next season's success may hinge upon how well these chores are carried out.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: MOST homeowners with builtin fireplaces of brick or masonry are by now familiar with the fact that the traditional woodburning fireplace is actually a very inefficient means of heating. With most conventional types, only about 10 percent of the heat created by the burning wood actually finds its way out into the room where the fireplace is situated  the rest sim- ply goes up the chimney and is wasted.

title: So You Think Schools Make the Cur riculum!
description: decides what the kids will learn in the schools? Teachers, principals and superintendents of schools, right?

title: J. S. Taylor Fianc Of Nora C. Glancey
description: President Judge Joseph R. Glancey of the Philadelphia Municipal Court and Mrs. Glancey of Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia, have announced the en- gagement of their daughter, Nora Catherine Glancey, to Joseph S. Tay- lor, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul E. Taylor Jr. of Bronxville, N.Y. The wedding is planned for next June.

title: Age Bias Charged in Housing
description: HARTFORD  The Connecticut Commission on Human Rights last week began hearing an age-discrimination suit that lobbyists for the elderly say could exacerbate the housing problems of old people in condominium conversions.

title: Sudanese Released in Kidnap Plot
description: ST. PAUL, Nov. 10 (AP)  A Sudanese arrested with four Iranian students on charges of conspiracy to kidnap Gov. Al Quie was released today but the others were held in the alleged olot.

description: BOOK ENDS

title: Ideas & Trends
description: Last week, predictions of the rate at which the earth's ozone layer is being depleted went up, sharply. The National Academy of Sciences reported depletion from fluorocarbon chemicals at twice their previous estimate. The academy said new calculations indicate the ozone could be reduced by about 16.5 percent, with half of the reduction coming in the next 30 years.

title: Waldheim Calls on Iran's Charg And Offers to Help on Hostages
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 10 (Reuters)  Secretary General Kurt Waldheim called in the charg d'affaires of Iran's mission to the United Nations last night and told him he was ready to help in any appropriate way to end the detainment of hostages at the United States Embassy in Teheran.

title: P. L. O. Aide in France Gives a Piano Recital
description: RENNES, France, Nov. 10 (Reuters) - The Palestine Liberation Organization's representative in France, Ibrahim Souss, gave the first of a series of piano recitals here this week.

description: Martin Waldron

description: HARTFORD  Paintings of endangered spe- cies by Grant Lamb, Thursday through Dec. 3, Wiley Gallery, 19 High St. Tuesday through Saturday 9 to 5.2476689.

title: A Salute to Film
description: THE independent film movement is alive and thriving in Westchester. Fourth graders in Eastchester are participating. So are elderly residents in Ossining, and inmates at the Westchester County Department of Corrections.

title: Make a UTurn, Chrysler
description: FOR the first time in automobile advertising, the president of a major manufacturer appearing in his company's TV commercials. Lee Iacocca, Chrysler's sink-or-swim new boss, urges us to try it and to compare his 1980 offerings.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS SALT's Wrong Foes
description: WASHINGTON  The propensity of the stupid right to damage the very causes in which they profess to, and doubtless do, believe is well exemplified in the activities of the antiSALT lobby.

title: At Stage Center in Hartford: a Director's Exit
description: HARTFORD PAUL WEIDNER can look back over his 12 years as producing director of the Hartford Stage Company and find much to be proud of. It was during his tenure that the company won enough prestige and attracted enough community support to enable it to move from its warehouse home on Kinsley Street to its new $2.5 million theater, designed by Robert Venturi, on Church Street.

description: CAMDEN

title: 17th Century Medical Book Sets World Record at London Auction
description: LONDON, Nov. 10 (Reuters)  A 17th century book about blood circulation, regarded as a cornerstone of modern medicine, brought $193,600 at an auction today.

title: Tracy Austin Beats Mrs. Lloyd
description: STUTTGART, West Germany, Nov. 10 (AP)  Tracy Austin fought back from set point in the second set to beat Chris Evert Lloyd, 63, 75, in the semifinals of a $100,000 tennis tournament today. She will play Martina Navrati. lova in the final.

description: SAN FRANCISCO

title: Should Trustees Pull the Plug?
description: THE treeshaded campus of Wil son College in central Pennsyl vania is vibrant with the sounds of students. but had it not been for the intervention of a court, the campus might instead be still Without a ruling by the Franklin County Court, Wilson College would have closed last summer. another vic dm of the blight plaguing the nation's campuses

title: Jane I. Pasquier, Translator, to Wed
description: Mrs. Paul Pasquier has announced the engagement of her daughter, Jane Irene Pasquier, to Jean Vincent de Vaugelas, son of Jean Blanchard of Chateauroux, France, and the late Christian Vincent de Vaugelas.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (UPI) Americans see Vietnam veterans as victims, not perpetrators, of an unpopular war, and 62 percent think those who fought were made suckers, a new survey shows. AMERICUS, Ga., Nov. 10 (AP)  A monthlong boycott of schools in President Carter's home county ended with rumblings about a lawsuit, the threat of another boycott and pledges to oust school officials.

description: His Medals Poke Fun at the Contemporary Scene
