title: You Can Still Ride the Rails for Scenery
description: The North Coast Hiawatha has gone the route the 23th Century Limited. The Floridian is no more. The Lone Star, the National Limited and the Hilltopper have also chuffed off into railroad history. With these five longdistance Amtrak passenger trains put to the sword in recent weeks, the national passenger rail network shrank, virtually overnight, from 27,287 miles to 23,763 miles.

title: A Detour to the Maldives
description: The Republic of Maldives is Asia's smallest nation, mere 115 square miles of land made up of 1,196 islands (203 inhabited) scattered over 50,000 square miles of the Indian Ocean. The islands lie 400 miles westsouthwest of the south- ernmost tip of India, and none is over five square miles area. Last January, my wife and I spent a week at Villingili, one of the group's 17 resort islands that lie within a few miles of Male, the capital island, and Hulule, the airport island, 275 miles north of the Equator.

title: Town Votes After 40 Years Same People Win
description: MARENGO, Ind., Nov. 10 (AP)  It had been at least 40 years since the peo- ple of this tiny community elected local officials, but this time nearly 90 per- cent of the registered voters turned out.

title: Obituary 4 -- No Title
description: SCHALERRose H. Board of Directors are deeply shocked at the sudden untimely death of our beloved colleague, Vice President and Program Director. She gave valuable limitless services to the cause of mental health and to the patients who benefit from the broad program of therapy and rehabilitation of postgraduate center for mental health. We will miss her our dear friend greatly. Our sincerest condolences to the bereaved family. Memorial services Village Temple, 33 East 12th St NYC 8PM Tuesday November 13th.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY.
description: MY MOTHER died in a nursing home almost 10 years ago, yet I see her almost every day at the nursing home where I do a little work now.

title: Questions/Answers
description: JADE LEAVES YELLOWING

title: Women Who Work in Mines Assail Harassment and Unsafe Conditions
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Nov. 10 Women miners from throughout the Appalachian coal fields met here today to denounce with equal fervor the lack of safety in the mines and the sexism of thpir male neers and employers.

title: Boyer Leads Southampton
description: LONDON, Nov. 10 (AP)  Phil Boyer scored two goals today as Southampton upset Nottingham Forest, the defending European soccer champion, 41, in English League play.

title: Zaire: Nice Case History Of How Not to Run a Country
description: KINSHASA, Zaire  Essay question for student diplomats: You are the ambassador to a large, onceprosperous African state run by a dictator installed with the help of the Central Intelligence Agency. Widely feared, he presides over corruption and mismanagement which have brought his people to the brink of starvation. Yet, he is probably the only person capable of holding his ethnically diverse country together. His overthrow would risk anarchy, inviting Soviet gains, possibly repeating two previous invasions by rebels based in nearby Marxist countries. President Carter, who is determined to avert another embarrassing misjudge- ment of an ally about to be overthrown [after Iran and Nica- ragua] seeks your judgment on the following: How closely should the United States align itself with this Government? Should it increase or decrease aid, including weapons? In the event of another invasion, should it supply troops? Logis- tics? Neither? Explain.

title: In the Beginning, Williamsburg
description: WHENEVER Jewish writers of my generation come together to celebrate those books that really mattered to us when we were young, the novels that shaped us, more than leading the way, actually seeming to make our own work possible, somebody will unfailingly ask, Do you remember the Williamsburg Trilogy?

title: Architecture; A HUMBLE AG INTHE HAMPTONS
description: An opportunity to build a house in the Hamptons tends to affect an architect the way a roaring crowd inspires a clown. Egged on by the knowledge that eastern Long Island's posh re- treats are something of a showcase for architects work, a designer will strive for new heights of virtuosity inevitably, the house will strut whether or not it's got the stuff.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: Martin Gansberg

title: SUMMATION PRAISES SCOTTO'S DEDICATION
description: Lawyer Says Union's Leader Cared About City, State and Port Jury Will Get Case Today

title: Another Baby Boom
description: IT is fall. 1985. Construction work ers are putting up new elementary schools in preparation for new influx of 5-year-olds. Taxes nave doubled to pay for the new build ing costs Twice as many teachers have been hired. in fact, there are severe teacher shortages in several areas of the country. Administrators are trying to buy new materials and schedule overcrowded classes for the new school year. Parents are wondering, after a decade of school closings, why school districts weren't better prepared for their new charges.

title: Wine; WINE LISTS TOMATCH THE MENU
description: There is no doubt that it is still much easier to find good menu than it is to find a good wine list. This has nothing to do with prices. Nor does it have anything to do with availability. It has everything to do with the restaurant owner's interest in wine. In New York it is painfully evident that many restaurateurs couldn't care less.

title: Corporate Advisers Helping Hartford
description: HARTFORD

title: Union Routs Plainfield, 340
description: Union, the defending North Jersey, Section 2, Group 4 champion, clinched spot in the upcoming playoffs by trouncing Plainfield, 340, at Union for its seventh victory against one setback.

title: The New York Times/Edward Hausner
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov 10 - Rutgers solidified its chances of a bowl bid on a cloudy, rainy afternoon at Giants Stadium today by beating an injuryplagued Army team, 20.0, before 28,163 fans that included the 4,000 members of the Cadet Corps.

title: Bowl Game Captures Laurel Grass Classic
description: LAUREL, MD., Nov. 10  Jorge Velasquez, riding Bowl Game, had a simple plan of action in the Washington D.C. International today and he carried it out flawlessly and almost effortlessly.

title: Jennifer Wise Fiance of Francis Marsh 3d
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas A. Wise of Bed- ford N.Y., and East Hampton, L.I. have made known the engagement of their daughter, Jennifer Marie Wise, to Francis Marsh 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Marsh 2d of Dedham, Mass. Plans have been made for a wedding next month.

title: 147 Bridges Cited As Deficient
description: A survey of bridges in the county has found that 147 are structurally deficient, although not in danger of collapse, according to the State Department of Transportation.

title: Jacqueline L. Engel Wed to J. W. Payer
description: Jacqueline Lisa Engel and James Walter Payer were married yesterday afternoon in the Carmelite Chapel of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Rose of Lima in Short Hills, N.J. Bishop John J. Dougherty performed the ceremony.

title: 67 Antinuclear Protesters Seized At Atomic Plant Site in Arizona
description: WINTERSBURG, Ariz., Nov. 10 (AP) - Sixtyseven persons were arrested today when they disobeyed a sheriff's order and climbed a barbed wire fence around the Palo Verde Nuclear Generating Station, which is under construction.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: Of Special Interest

title: Pace on Top, 5328
description: Felix Coste ran 2 yards for a touchdown on the first play from scrimmage yesterday as Pace College captured its second straight Metropolitan Conference football championship by walloping St. Peter's College, 5328.

title: Barbara Bakal Is Engaged
description: Dr. and Mrs. Daniel Bakal of Baltimore have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Bakal, to Steven Loren, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Loren of New City, N.Y. An August wedding is planned.

title: Yale Takes Game, Ivy Crown And Purloined Mascot Home
description: As expected, Yale University won the game and, as expected, the team got its dognaped mascot back yesterday at halftime on the playing fields of Princeton.

title: Correction:
description: In Entertaining At Home, Part 2 of the Oct. 28 Magazine, two ingredients in the recipe for apple tart Tatin (page 95) were listed erroneously. The filling requires eight apples (about two-and-a-half to three pounds), and the crust requires onequarter of a pound of sweet butter.

title: CHURCH UNIT ASSAILS U.S. JUSTICE SYSTEM
description: National Council Urges Reforms in Treatment of Offenders and Attacking Crime's Roots The governing board of the National Council of Churches, assailing the nation's criminal justice ystem as unfair, inequitable, unjust, And in some instances itself illegal, proposed sweeping changes yesterday in the way criminals are treated and in attacking the roots of crime.

title: INFLUENCE OF KLAN IS DOUBTED IN STUDY
description: Despite recent membership gains, widening popular support and an increased use of violence, especially in the South, the Ku Klux Klan poses no present threat to American society and represents only a tiny fraction of the American people, according to a new study of the Klan by the AntiDefamation League of B'nai B'rith.

title: Paulette Castillo Wed to Dr. E. A. Griggs Jr.
description: Paulette Louise Castillo, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Rafael Castillo of Caracas, Venezuela, was married in Manhattan yesterday to Dr. Edward Albert Griggs Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Griggs of Livingston, N.J. The ceremony was performed in the Holy Trinity Lutheran Church by the Rev. Dr. A. James Laughlin. He was assisted by Msgr. Edward J. Fleming of the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of the Blessed Sacrament in Roseland, N.J.

title: New Yonkers Mayor Looks at the Future
description: IT was the morning after the election and the scene at Yonkers City Hall said it all. Seated at the head of the table, in a chair normally reserved for the city Manager, Pat T. Ravo, Gerald E. Loehr, the Democratic Mayorelect, was conducting his first news conference.

title: Iran Is Dominating Talk on U S. Campuses
description: From the dining halls of Harvard to the student center at San Jose State, the Iranian student takeover of the American Embassy in Teheran is dominating discussion on American campuses. But despite widespread expressions of frustrated outrage, a few calls for immediate American intervention and some threats against resident Iranian students, there has been virtually no violence and only few campus demonstrations.

title: Lest We Forget
description: It has become Veterans Day and has been moved around to provide threeday weekends, but to my parents generation and even to mine, Armistice Day can no more easily be moved from Nov. 11 than can Independence Day from July 4.

title: Joan Laura Lewis Wed To Ira Goldberg, Lawyer
description: Joan Laura Lewis, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Sydney B. Lewis of Lawrenceville, N.J., was married yesterday evening to Ira Edward Goldberg, son of Mildred T. Goldberg of Paramus, N.J., and the late Sam Goldberg. Rabbi Morton M. Rosenthal performed the ceremony at the Green Acres Country Club in Lawrenceville.

title: Chrysler: A Republican's Dilemma
description: WASHINGTON  It's all very frustrating sometimes, said Senator Jake Garn, the Republican who at the moment has more to say about the fate of the Chrysler Corporation than any other in the Senate. Nobody up here seems to care about the facts! All that many of my colleagues care about is how they're perceived! It's all perceptions, no facts!

title: Pop: Engelbert, a Singer
description: Engelbert  he has officially dropped the Humperdinck from his stage name  clearly believes himself irresistible to women. But he doesn't take himself terribly seriously, and while his shows always approach the very edge of gaucherie, they're such cheerful celebrations of lust that one iust about has to eniov them.

title: Milstein50 Years of Violin Virtuosity
description: There are people who talk like sonatas. They give you, like it or not, first and second sub- jects, expositions, develop- ments and recapitulations.

title: ExHeads of Atomic Plant Admit
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 10 (AP) Radioactive gases were slowly and delib- erately released into the air after a seri- ous accident 20 years ago at an experi- mental nuclear reactor just north of the populous San Fernando Valley, the plant's owners have conceded.

title: POLITICS
description: HARTFORD

title: Mrs. Carter's Visit Helps Refugee Camp -It's Cleaned
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 10  Rosalynn Carter visited another refugee camp, met with representatives of international and private relief agencies working to aid Cambodians and conferred with Prime Minister Kriangsak Chamanand before flying back to Washington today.

title: Republicans Gain, But Not TwoThirds
description: THE new County Board of Legislators will look a lot like the old one after last week's election, with Republicans still the dominant party but also still unable to override any veto by the Democratic County Executive, Alfred B. DelBello.

title: Susan M. Hart Bride on L. L
description: Susan Mary Hart, daughter of Mrs. Howard W. Hart of Garden City, L.I., was married there yesterday in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church to Robert C. Dahill Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Dahill of West Hartford, Conn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. James Swiader.

title: Bills Offer a New Test for Jet Draft Choices
description: If they were back in college, their seasons would be over after today's game. Instead, there will be a different sort of graduation for the Jets two top draft choices at Shea Stadium, where the New Yorkers face the Buffalo Bills.

title: ParentTeacher Unity Is Viewed as Past
description: IN the mid1970's the Home and School Association at Philadelphia's Overbrook High School announced to its parent members new opportunity: A day set aside each month when they could visit their children's classes.

title: 'I Don't Know if I'll Ever Get a Part Like This Again
description: SShe doesn't look much like the old Bette Midler, the trash with flash with the explod- ing red hair and the voluptu- ous figure, who camped her way across the nation's nightclubs and concert halls. No, this new Bette Mi- dler, the one sitting in the room full of roses in the Pierre Hotel, is a blonde, for one thing, her frizzy hairdo swept up on top of her head in a 1940's An- drews Sisters style. A pair of horn- rimmed glasses perched on her nose gives her a scholarly look. And she is slim, quite slim, and will be down to 100 pounds soon, she vowed between sips of orange juice, because she is on a juice diet to shed 10 pounds in time for the festivities connected with her first film, The Rose, in which she plays a selfdestructive hardrock singer circa 1969.

title: Paperback Best Sellers
description: Massmarket paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermar- kets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computerprocessed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: Syracuse Conquers Navy, 3014
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 10 (AP) Bill Hurley, Syracuse's quarterback, ran for one touchdown, passed for one and guided the Orangemen to a 3014 football victory over Navy today.

title: FollowUp on the News; Children as Advisers
description: When New York City set up a Task Force on Foster Care last June to con- sider ways to improve the childcare program, two foster children were named as fullfledged members of the panel. At City Hall the youngsters were reported to be excited, and they have a lot of ideas.

title: Land, c Sea and Surfers on a Southern California Drive
description: While visiting southern California last winter, I set off on a leisurely drive from Los Angeles to San Diego and discovered that by shunning Interstate 5, the main freeway route, I could travel close to the shore of the Pacific Ocean and enjoy the seascape for much of the way.

title: SUNY Plant Needs a Physical
description: AT one clinic of the State University of New York dental school in Buffalo, the dental chairs are so old that the manufacturer no longer has replacement parts, and the school is repairing broken plairs with the usable sections of other broken chairs. The poor equipment was one reason why the American Dental Association earlier this year downgraded the school's full accreditation to provisional accreditation.

title: View of College Financing From Higher Education Board
description: AS chairman of the budget and finance committee of the Board of Higher Education, I would like to correct and clarify several items in the article by Lawrence J. Davidson [Connecticut State Colleges: An Argument for Improved Financing, Oct. 28].

title: Dump Yields 1800's Dining Clues
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 10 (AP)  Evan DeBloois, an archeologist, started out digging for historic Fort Buenaven- tura and on the way down became an ex- pert on trash from old dining cars.

title: Casinos Create Demand for Housing
description: ATLANTIC CITY  Gambling is here. So are the glossy hotels, and construction activity along the Boardwalk signals many more to come. Entertainment figures and extravagant stage shows have moved in glamorizing this tired resort's oceanfront almost beyond recognition.

title: New Pope Uses Cardinals to Offset the Curia
description: ROME  The Sacred College of Cardinals, which met with Pope John Paul II last week, is, with 130 members, one of the world's more exclusive clubs. Their gathering may be a signal of the growing importance, after a period of decline, of their influence in the Roman Catholic church. The Second Vatican Council, held from 1962 to 1965, proclaimed the collegial nature of church government, a sharing of responsibility between pope and bishops.

title: Some Sample Fares
description: How much does'it cost to ride a longdistance train in the United States?

title: CAMERA
description: In the beginning, cameras were enormous in size and lenses were very slow. Exposures took several hours and could only be made in bright sunlight. Now, cameras are small enough to fit in the palm of your hand and lenses are so fast and sharp that they can record details that are all but invisible to the naked eye.

title: Pompeii Past and Present
description: Discede Morator  Move On, Idlerwarns the 1,900-year-old municipal antiloitering ordinance. The American tour group moved on. After all, they had only 45 minutes to take in Pompeii.

title: HIGHLIGHTS
description: Turmoil in Iran last week once again threatened the industrialized nations with a cutoff of petroleum exports and the resulting scramble for supplies. Although earlier rumors that irate work- ers had shut down the country's big Kharg Island loading terminal proved false, the National Iranian Oil Company notified some of its customers late in the week that they would recieve 10 percent less oil than they expected for the rest of the year.

title: The World
description: From the frying pan of the Foreign Relations Committee, the Strategic Arms Limitation Treaty made it last week, wellgrilled but still recognizable, to the Senate floor.

title: Shrinking Church Memberships Stirring Debate Over Evangelism
description: Some of the nation's leading Protestant denominations, faced with continuing membership losses, are engaged in vigorous debate over how to evangelize without compromising their theological liberalism and their emphasis on social justice.

description: Mondrian's Fruitful Period In New York

title: Friends of Slain Fireman Seek New Inquiry
description: KINGS POINT

title: WOMEN COMPARING CARTER AND RIVALS
description: Now that the two major challengers to President Carter for the Democratic Presidential nomination have formally announced their candidacies, women's groups around the country, like other organized interests, are scrutinizing the candidates records as the wary courtship dance between candidates and potential supporters begins in earnest.

title: Dartmouth Dashes Brown's Hopes, 2410
description: HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 10  A poor snap from center on a punt attempt in the closing minutes of the first half proved costly to Brown today as the Bruins lost, 2410, to Dartmouth and missed a chance to keep alive their hopes for a share of the Ivy League championship. Yale's victory Over Princeton clinched the title for the Ells.

title: Guerrillas Kill Three in India
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 10 (Reuters) Heavily armed guerrillas of the Mizoram National Front killed two Indian security force men and one civilian in a raid on police camp in northeastern Tripura state last night, officials said today. The guerrillas are seeking independence for Mizoram.

title: Woman Wages Citizen's War on Traffic Violators
description: CLIFFSIDE PARK, N.J., Nov. 10 (AP)  Marie DeMercurio is a onewoman police force when it comes to motorists who illegally pass stopped school buses.

title: China Expected To Turn to U.S. For Arms Help
description: Secretary of Defense Harold Brown's visit to China Jan. 6 to 13 will provide the Carter Administration with its first onthespot assessment of China's military situation and its relation to the American position in the Western Pacific.

title: Deaths
description: HUDESMAN-Anna. Died October 28, 1979 in Miami Beach, Florida. Age 85. Wife of Mortimore, mother of Nancy H. Ampel and Claire M. Bro- dY, grandmother of Frederick, Ken- neth, Jessica, Laura and Naomi. Sister of Esther Stein, Cella Hoff- man, Edith Flato, Tess Gelfman and A.Invin Kleinman. A Memorial Service will be held at Abraham Goodman House, 129 W 67th St, NYC on Sunday, Nov 11, 1979 at 2:PM. Contributions In her memory may be made to the Shoshanna Club, Pioneer Women Bklyn., Council, 375 Jay St, Bklyn., N.Y. 11201

title: THE KENNEDY NETWORK
description: Gorge Thomas/The New York Times

title: Traditional Stitchery Of Unusual Beauty
description: BETHEL PRIMITIVE tribal cultures have not, to put it mildly, fared well in a modern world of rapacious economic and political forces. Some have nonetheless managed an ironic survival by appeas- ing one civilized greed in particular: folk art. Think of the molas, fabric squares with appliqued designs in reds and oranges, of San Blas in the Carib- bean and the stone carving of the Inuit, or Eskimos, of the Canadian Arctic. In each case the practice of tribal tradi- tion for a commercial market has be- come the sustenance of a hardpressed people.

title: All Around the Town
description: IN the last several years  as the fortunes of New York in the money world, where it was once champ, declined  there has risen what has amounted to a New York love cult, a rallying around the flag by those who can't stand to see the old town go down. New York has always been a passionately loved city by those who live in it and even by those who visit it.

title: Letter TO THE EDITOR; Staablaysky's Many Faces
description: I don't mean to sound disingenuous, because I really enjoyed Can the Method Survive the Madness (by Su- zanne O'Malley, Oct. 7), but always thought that acting was not letting other people know your actual thoughts and feelings, and that the ability to manipulate emotion is what is also known as talent.

title: Trash Power: A Worthy Notion That Doesn't Yet Pay
description: Like alchemy and the Tower of Babel, it seemed a worthy notion. Cities have been hard put to find places to dump their garbage, so they could burn it. In burning it, they could produce electricity, thus liberating themselves from OPEC. Better vet. cities might even make money withthe garbage, selling steam or solid fuel to industries and power companies.

title: A Book on Jazz, And a New Life
description: BILL GOTTLIEB of Lake Success has not only written The Golden Age of Jazz, an unpretentious, carefully put-together tome with text and photos about the jazz greats he has seen in action as a lifetime music buff, but he also seems to be entering the golden age of William P. Gottlieb.

title: Man Found Slain on Sidewalk
description: A 33-year-old Manhattan man was found shot to death yesterday in front of 201 Allen Street on the Lower East Side, the police reported. The victim, identified as Robert Bonilla of 91 East Third Street, was found on the sidewalk at about 1:50 P.M. No motive was known.

title: Farmingdale Trims East Meadow, 250; Nassau III
description: Farmingdale extended its winning streak yesterday and in the process clinched the Conference I, Division A championship with a 250 victory over East Meadow. It was Farmingdale's 16th straight victory, including seven this season.

description: I just couldn't believe that the item Woodman, Don't Spare That Tree [Oct. 21] was not written in sarcasm. Reading it, with every successive paragraph I expected a turnaround of sentiment, but was disappointed.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10  At 1:20 P.M. today, Hamilton Jordan, wearing a blue warmup suit and windbreaker with Camp David insignia, came into the office of Jody Powell, the White House press secretary. Mr. Jordan's hair and shoulders were damp from jogging in the light rain.

title: Arnold Lobel and Friends
description: Last April when Arnold Lobel, author and illustrator of the Frog and Toad series and of dozens of other children'sbooks, left his home in Brooklyn to attend the Arnold Lobel Day festivities in Schenectady, his home town, he took with him a suitcase, some sample illustrations of frogs, toads, mice and grasshoppers, and a large, carefully tiedup cardboard box. Inside the box was a live turtle.

title: Ohira's Cabinet Reflects Effort to Heal Split in Party
description: TOKYO, Nov. 10  Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira, who narrowly survived a challenge to his leadership by powerful rivals in the governing Liberal Democratic Party earlier this week, has moved to repair the rift in Japan's conservative political forces. The success of his effort is still in auestion.

title: Alabama Wins, 30
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Nov. 10  Alabama's undefeated and untied football team barely avoided the embarrassment of a scoreless tie tonight when Alan McElroy kicked a 27yard field goal in the third period and gave the Crimson Tide a 30 victory over Louisiana State University in rainsoaked Tiger Stadium.

title: U.S.C., 2447 Victor, Assured of Rose Bid
description: SEATTLE, Nov. 10 (AP)  Southern California clinched its 10th Rose Bowl bid in 14 years today with a 2417 victory over Washington as Paul McDonald passed for two touchdowns and Charles White rushed for 243 yards on 38 carries.

title: THE EDUCATION CONSUMER
description: SHE got an inkling that her 18monthold son was an unusual child when she found him sit ting at the bottom of the stairs crying one day and she asked him what was wrong. I don't have the words to tell you yet, he replied.

title: Opera: The Neale Show
description: Last summer four American singers put together a show of light opera and operetta under the direction of Judith Neale and presented it with considerable success as one of the side attractions at the Edinburgh Festival. This past week that same show has been running at a small storefront auditorium called the N.E.T.W.O.R.K. Theater, which is just off the southeast corner of Ninth Avenue and 51st Street. This writer caught Friday night's performance, found it wholly delightful and regrets to say that it will be given for the last time this afternoon at 2:30.

description: WARSAW, Nov. 10  One of the rare occasions when Yiddish can be heard in Poland, and certainly the only oppor- tunity to see a rabbi, is on a Saturday, Sunday or Monday night when the curtain goes up at the Jewish State Theater.

title: Man Guilty in Stabbing Of Moon Group Member
description: A man with a long record of arrests for violent crimes was found guilty yesterday of murdering a member of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon's Unification Church last winter as she tried to deliver the movement's newspaper in Harlem.

description: BRUSSELS  The crowds elbowing and shoving their way through the doors of the Salle de la Madeleine recently for a mammoth dinner celebrating Krug's hommage to Belgian cuisine showed one aspect of the European spirit. The French said. Look how Belgians behave, and the others said, You can see they're mostly French who've heard the call to table.

title: Gov. Brown Says Medical Plans Ought to Stress Preventive Care
description: BOSTON, Nov. 10 (AP)  Gov. Edmund Brown Jr. of California said today that medical costs could be held down less were spent on treatment and more on preventive care.

title: 2 New Choices Considered
description: When the presidents of Brooklyn, City and Hunter Colleges all announced their retirements last winter, it was generally assumed that the City University of New York's Board of Trustees would find the post at Hunter the easiest to fill. Aside from having a strong academic reputation, Hunter appeared to be without the internal factionalism and external ethnic pressures that threatened to turn the presidential searches at Brooklyn and City Colleges into political free-for-alls.

title: Art Prize Awarded to Historian
description: Meyer Schapiro, professor emeritus of, art history at Columbia University, was awarded the Mitchell Prize for the History of Art Wednesday in a cere- mony at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The $10,000 prize was established in 1977 by Jan Mitchell, former owner of Liichow's and the Longchamps res- taurants, to acknowledge original con- tributions to the study and understand- ing of the visual arts.

title: CAPTIVES SAID TO ASK FOR RETURN OF SHAH
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 10 (Reuters) The Moslem students holding scores of hostages in the United States Embassy published a petition today purportedly signed by 33 of their captives calling on the United States to return the deposed Shah to Iran.

description: PARIS, Nov. 10  In the last month the Government of President Valery Giscard d'Estaing, previously untouched by scandals, was reported to be involved in events that have rocked the nation.

title: Deaths
description: THOMASLeslie G., 82, of Key Biscayne, Florida on Friday. A thirteen year residont formerly of Tenafly N.J. Was a member of St. John's Lodge el F&AM Mountain Lakes N.J. Was an early pioneer in electronics. Fellow of the Radio Club of America. Survived by beloved wife, Frances of Key Biscayne, Fla, devoted children, daughter Doris, sons Mortimer, George, Robert and Donald, ten grandchildren and nine greatgrandchlldren. The family reguests memorials to your favorite charity. For information regarding private funeral services and entombment contact Phibrick & Sons, Coral Gables, Fla.

description: FOUR school districts in Nassau County and seven in Suffolk County are currently on austerity. Some have been that way for more than a year. Only three have scheduled budget revotes.

title: For Judicial Activism
description: KEY WEST, Fla.  Do judges have too much power? Some people think so, asserting that they have begun to act unconstitutionally. Judges are charged with being undemocratic  unreachable authorities who deeply affect the lives of Americans against their will. Were it accurate, that would be a grave indictment. But it is not. Cries of judicial tyranny have been heard since the early 19th century. Today's assaults upon courts generally, and the United States Supreme Court specifically, should be seen in that perspective.

title: ABOUT CARS
description: THE car isn't what I really wanted to buy. Back when I really wanted to buy a car, it was a 1948 Plymouth convertible that I couldn't afford. And then it was the barely used 55 Coupe de Ville that got sold before I could convince the bank that a skinny 19-year-old kid could be a Serious Cadillac Person.

title: Anita Morgan Rhett Is Engaged
description: Anita Morgan Rhett, a second vice president in the mining and metals division of the Chase Manhattan Bank, and Nathaniel Sartell Prentice, who is with Alex Brown & Sons, investment bankers in Baltimore, plan to be mar- ried Dec. 29. title: WASHINGTON The New Warfare
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10  The first assault on a U.S. legation or embassy in this century occurred during the Boxer uprising in Peking, China, on June 11, 1900. The U.S. legation was sacked, seven U.S. Marines were killed, 17 wounded, and on Aug. 19 of that year an international military force, including U.S. troops, simply captured the city of Peking, dispersed the Boxers, demanded excessive payment for damages and got it.

title: Something in a Fuel Bill Will Chill the Warmest Heart
description: THE chill arrived early this fall. Too early. The oildelivery truck slipped into our driveway at 7 A.M., two days after the temperatures dipped to 35 degrees. in addition to leaving an acrid oil smell to mix with the coffee aroma of early morning, the truck left a sheet of paper carrying the information that our home furnace had just received 243 gallons of oil at $0.8329 a gallon. That rounds out to $202.40 owed for this year's first shipment of liquid gold. Assuming an increase in price in time for the Christmas shopping season, holding steady at perhaps $1 a gallon, we can count on owing our neighborhood fuel distributor $175 every month from November to March. No way!

The adoption of such a system by developing countries is still somewhat hypothetical, however, largely because most countries lack the required data. And Dr. Nathans and his colleague Romir Chatterjee, an economist and associate di- rector of the Institute, readily admit that cutting demand will be no easier than expanding supplies, as recent riots and official resignations over rising fuel prices, from the Do- minican Republic to the Sudan to Thailand, demonstrate. Consequently, they take a gloomy view of the outlook for the developing world over the next 20 years.

title: Kennedy: Upside Down on Energy
description: There may be no more important single litmus test for the 1980 Presidential campaign than energy. America's dependence on oil imports underlies national security and the economy. So, as Senator Kennedy verged closer to running, our curiosity about his energy policy mounted. Now he has announced his candidacy, declared his capacity for bold leadership and given his first answer. It is baffling.

description: The town of Huntington, L.I., has set up a culture bus like the one in New York City, 35 miles away.

title: HOME CLINIC Saving Heat Lost Up Chimneys
description: MOST homeowners with builtin fireplaces of brick or masonry are by now familiar with the fact that the traditional woodburning fireplace is actually a very inefficient means of heating. With most conventional types, only about 10 percent of the heat created by the burning wood actually finds its way out into the room where the fireplace is situated  the rest simply goes up the chimney and is wasted.

title: Old Tales, New Artists
description: There are two good reasons for plucking a tale by Hans Christian Andersen, the Brothers Grimm or Oscar Wilde out of its handy resting place in one of the many collections of each author's work and turning it into a picture book. The first is to make a particular story accessible and appealing to an audience that might otherwise not discover or enjoy it forvears w come -- i.e. one younger tnan tne taies actual reacting level. The other is to provide a rich vehicle for displaying the graphic gifts of a talented illustrator who, presumably, has some new insight or dimension bring to the story. When this sort of collaboration works, the theory has it, the child listener/viewer getting double value: a tale of unquestioned literary merit plus exposure to pictures of more than ephemeral esthetic interest.

title: World Cup Stresses Friendship
description: ATHENS, Nov. 10  In all of Greece there are only four golf courses, and the country's golfing population is proportionately small. Greece has no famous players, and no significant tournaments are held here. Yet, for all its paucity of golfing tradition and facilities, Greece is playing host this weekend to an international tournament in which 43 countries are represented by twoman teams.

title: Millions of Dollars Unaccounted for on South Dakota's Reservations
description: PIERRE, S.D., Nov. 10 (AP)  Mil- lions of taxpayers dollars are unac- counted for on South Dakota's Indian reservations, and no one knows exactly how much money has been misspent or wasted, according to an investigation by a group of reporters.

title: What's Doing in LIMA
description: CITYSCAPE  Limenos rightly complain that their city, once the glory of Spain's colonial empire, is rundown and dirty. As far as downtown and the poorer districts of the city are concerned, they are right; the gray mist that dominates Peru's central coast during the southern hemisphere's winter emphasizes the gloomier corners of what in the middle of the last century Herman Melville called the saddest city on earth.

title: Klan Killings Last Weekend Were Not the Only Example of Violence
description: The late Hugo L. Black believed in freedom of speech as deeply as anyone who ever sat on the United States Supreme Court. Soapbox orators, pickets, Communist Party leaders  in his view all were protected by the First Amendment. But 10 years ago, in a case involving civil rights demonstrators and a hostile crowd, he wrote: When groups with diametrically opposed, deepseated views are permitted to air their emotional grievances, side-by-side on city streets, tranquillity and order cannot be maintained even by. .. the finest and best [police] officers.

Richard Cassilly, Paul Plishka and Arturo Sergi slouch about the barroom, examining with professional interest a group of sleazy young women. From the orchestra pit, a rickytick piano sobs out an old sentimental ballad, The Maiden's Prayer  That's what I call eternal art, sighs Mr. Sergi.

title: Marine Accident Toll at 11

Pvt. Robert Larson. of Eau Claire. Wis., became the sixth Marine to die at the burn center from injuries sustained when a typhoon struck the Mount Fuji training camp, split open a gasoline storage tank and sent burning gas throughout the camp.

title: Picking Up On An Idea
description: AFAIR number of newspapers and magazines come into my house, most of them wanted and delivered in a manner that wouldn't offend me. The ones that were never wanted, and nonetheless appear with the inexorability of the seasons, taxes and death, are those infernal news sheets that arrive unsolicited, via unsummoned newsboys, and are wrapped in those cellophane envelopes that not only defy biodegradability but also defy all of my efforts to halt their delivery.

title: Error Alerts U.S. Forces To a False Missile Attack
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10  A false alert triggered some of the nation's defenses against a nonexistent missile attack yesterday morning, Defense Department officials said today. But the alert was taken skeptically, they said, and was deemed insufficiently urgent to warrant notifying top Government or military officials.

title: The Nation's Voters Seemed Reluctant to Make Changes

description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 10 (AP)  If Purdue beats Indiana next week, Ohio State will represent the Big Ten in the Rose Bowl no matter what the Buckeyes do at Michigan.

title: Taxi Fleet Owners Expected to Seek a Rise in Fare

title: OPPOSITION ATTACKS KOREAN VOTE PLAN

A pity that, because of the vagaries of scheduling occasioned by the compa- ny's lockout of a few weeks ago, the first performance of this double bill was also the last.

They have never gone to one because, atter all, It really isn't theater, not like Broadway or the regionals, is it? The implication is that dinner theater entertainment is always secondrate while Broadway and regional theater is always firstrate. I have seen the secondrate on Broadway and in regional theaters, and I have seen firstrate entertainment at dinner theaters.

title: Headliners; Flood Calls It Quits
description: You serve 16 terms, and what do you get? Old, sick, and prose- cuted. Representative Daniel J. Flood has had enough, and an- nounced last week that he would resign from Congress effective Jan. 31. Mr. Flood, whose first trial on bribery charges ended in a hung jury last Feb. 3, faces an- other trial, but that probability may be receding; psychiatric as- sessments introduced in Federal court last week in Washington by Mr. Flood's lawyer depicted him as suffering from depression, memory lapses and drug de- pendency, and the second trial was postponed pending further psychiatric examinations.

title: The Books With the Pictures
description: It's not been a brilliant season for picture books, but the best are astonishing. Donald Hall's OXCART MAN with illustrations by Barbara Cooney (Viking, $8.95) would be remarkable in any season. The text is delib- erately simple and precise: An early 19thcentury farmer packs his cart and drives to Portsmouth Market, N.H., in the tall. He sells all he has, in- eluding the ox and the cart, and walks home. As the seasons change, he and his family work hard until it's time for him to take their produce to market again.

title: Budget Racing for CostConscious Driver
description: In the early 1950's, many amateur road racers competed in dualpurpose vehicles. The light, easy-to-handle sports cars that started the foreign car explosion in America also were able race cars just as they came from the factory. One could tape the headlights, tape a number on the door, and go racing. Following the race, the driver could throw his toolbox in the trunk and drive home.

title: Hua Guofeng in West Europe Stressed a New Pragmatism
description: PARIS  For the first time in its 4,000year history, China's leader has ventured out to Western Europe. Hua Guofeng's 22day tour was anticipated with a sense of monumental occasion, as an extraordinary milestone. He went home last week, however, leaving only a sense of risk and opportunity, another sign of the fragility of modern international relations and their bewildering complexity.

title: SPORTS
description: HARTFORD LAME Plato. If there had been no Greek philosopher in Drew Hyland's life, he would have gone on to law school, become a lawyer and maybe made a million acting as some professional ballplayer's agent.

Rents are projected at $800 to $1,200 for onebedroom to threebedroom apartments.

description: HOUSTON, Nov. 10 (AP)  The Texas pressureproof defense intercepted three Houston passes, including two by Derrick Hatchett, and Donnie Little scored two touchdowns from quarterback as the Longhorns knocked the Cougars from the unbeaten ranks, 2113, tonight.

description: RODNEY DANGERFIELD is known widely as the man who gets no respect. Instead of being a comic, he should be librarian, a profession generally regarded with comparable lack of esteem.

title: Protesters Removed in Paris
description: Paris, Nov. 10 (UPI)  The 21 French conscientious objectors who occupied the Belgian Embassy Thursday and demanded political asylum were removed from the building by French police early today. Police sources said they acted at the request of embassy officials. There was no violence.

title: The Day America Began to Mature
description: TEN years have elapsed since the antiwar protest march on Washington of Nov. 15, 1969. It was a protest activity that failed to achieve its fundamental aim, that is the immediate end of the war in Vietnam. Yet the march served as catalyst for a process that persists today. Since that point in time America has been reevaluating its position visavis the rest of the world.

title: Margaret Clary Fiance of Tobias Bisharat
description: Mr. and Mrs. James Andrew Clary of Yarmouthport, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Mary Clary, to Tobias Mau- rice Bisharat, son of Clarita Uhlmann Bisharat of London and Victor Hanna Bisharat of Greenwich, Conn.

title: The Money Lenders Are Hurting
description: THE Beneficial Corporation of Wilmington, Del., makes money by lending money to consumers, usually at a rate of about 20 percent. Beneficial borrows the shortterm funds it lends at or near the prime interest rate. Usually there's a big difference between the two  10 percent or more  which leaves the company plenty of room to swallow delinquent accounts and make a profit.

title: Environment
description: WASHINGTON  It might be said that in some of his recent endeavors, Secretary of the Interior Cecil D. Andrus has been snakebitten. But Mr. Andrus, the lanky, homespun former Governor of Idaho who presides over what has traditionally been regarded as one of the least manageable of all Federal agen- cies, professes to be unrattled by the setbacks and controversies that have beset him of late.

description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 10 (UPI) Three Soviet warships ended a fiveday visit to the Vietnamese port of Haiphong, the Hanoi radio said today.

title: World of
description: THE arena at Madison Square Garden has changed. The spectators are of a different era, more blue jeans and fewer black ties. The attire of the riders is of stretch synthetic fabric, even the look of the horses is of this age. What hasn't changed is the feeling. The fans no longer arrive by horse and carriage for the National Horse Show but their love for the noble beast is just as strong.

title: BBC TURNS KEEN EAR TO ITS OWN SPEECH
description: LONDON, Nov. 10  The British Broadcasting Corporation, acknowledging its role as arbiter of how the spoken word should be spoken, is conducting a farreaching examination of its own lineuistic standards.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: WHEN it began, all Peter Featherston wanted was a halffare airline coupon to use on a trip to California to visit his brother. In May, on the day after he graduated from Iona College in New Rochelle, the Norwalk resident went to John F. Kennedy International Airport in New York, and started ask.. ing passengers getting off planes if they had extra coupons. Several airlines, to attract new business, were issuing the coupons in their own version of a halfprice sale.

title: Hawaii Board Delays Cleanup Plan to Open Schools
description: HONOLULU, Nov. 10  Gov. George R. Ariyoshi, who has been considering the use of National Guardsmen to get Hawaii's schools reopened, last night called for public pressure on the State Board of Education, following an unusual board vote that halted a plan to open some schools Tuesday by having them cleaned over the weekend with volunteer help.

title: REMND THE REST SELLERS

Lowry's How You Can Become Financially Independent by Investing in Real Estate, which Simon and Schuster published in November 1977. We started with a first printing of 35,000 copies, and by the end of 1978 the book had sold 100,000 copies. It never took off like a shot, but it sold steadily and well.

title: Topics Signs of the Times
description: News is a fleeting commodity yet newspapers, as institutions, can seem deceptively eternal. This is surely the case with The Times of London, once the thundering voice of an empire and long the acknowledged patriarch of its tribe. To journalists, it sounded like a death in the family when the owners of The Times and its sibling, The Sunday Times, talked of closing the papers during a labor dispute that had al- ready stopped the presses for a year. The death notice, happily, was prema- ture. The Sunday Times resumes pub- lication today.

title: Judith Helen Gibbons Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. E. Llewellyn Gibbons of Pembroke, Bermuda, of the engage- ment of their daughter, Judith Helen Gibbons, to James Stewart McKirdy, son of Mr. and Mrs. James McKirdy, also of Pembroke. The future bride, an alumna of the Oldfields School, at- tended Hollins College and graduated from the Art Institute of Boston. Mr. McKirdy attended McMaster Univer- sity in Hamilton, Ontario.

title: Princeton Clubs Feel. Pressure of Diversity
description: TO find the Princeton University where a student's reputation rested on the prestige of his eating club and the beauty of his imported weekend date, one would have to search between the covers of an F. Scott Fitzgerald novel. That part of Princeton's history ended conclusively in 1969 when the university began admitting women and more minority students.

title: Shah Said to Welcome Invitation from Sadat When Treatment Ends
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (UPI)  The Egyptian Ambassador to the United States said tonight that he believed Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi would accept President Anwar elSadat's invitation to come to Egypt, but not until he completes medical treatment in New York.

title: Knicks Toppled, 123119
description: Mark Olberding is the San Antonio Spurs muscle man. He is 6 feet 9 inches tall and weighs 230 pounds. His job is to provide rebounding, play defense and pass the ball. Since George Gervin and Larry Kenon are both outstanding Spur scorers, there is usually little need for Olberding to score a lot of points.

title: U.S. SEES JAPANESE IMPROVING DEFENSE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10  Last month, at the end of an afternoon of watching aerial acrobatics by Japanese jet fighter planes, infantry and tank maneuvers and a huge parachute drop, Secretary of Defense Harold Brown was surrounded by Japanese officers, soldiers and reporters wanting to know what he thought.

title: Nehru's Policies Return as a Political Issue in India
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 10  Fifteen years after the death of Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru, his policies and his role as the builder of modern India have become the subjects of intense political debate.

title: CALIFORNIA PRESSES MOVES ON CHURCHES
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 3 (AP)  The California authorities have taken action against alleged illegalities in several churches and have moved to restrict the religious activities of some others. Their actions have angered the churches, which contend that their First Amendment rights of religious freedom are being via lated.

title: Kahn Says Chrysler Should Trim Union Pact if U.S. Is to Offer Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP)  President Carter's chief inflation fighter said today that Federal loan guarantees to the Chrysler Corporation should be made conditional on agreement by the company and the United Automobile Workers to scale down their new wage settlement.

title: Top Rhode Island Court Permits RadioTV Advertising by Lawyers
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 10 (UPI)Rhode Island's Supreme Court has ruled that lawyers may advertise on radio and television as long as they do not appear in the commercials, dramatize them or accompany them by music or lyrics.

title: A School for a Select Few
description: ISOLATED in a lonely valley of the White Mountains in California 28 miles from the nearest town stands Deep Springs College, one of the most selective and innovative &lieges in the world.

title: Biggest Air Bargain Likely to Vanish
description: With plane fares rising and schedules cut back because of the priCe of jet fuel, one of the biggest bargains in airtravel history may soon disappear. It is the unlimitedmileage ticket, which allows passengers to travel almost anywhere they please in seven to 21 days on either Delta or Eastern Airlines.

title: Author's Query
description: For a book that will attempt to reconstruct Armistice Day 1918 in all its manifestations, I would appreciate hearing from individualswith sufficiently long memories of that day, or from others who have diaries, documents, photographs or art relating to it.

title: In Pro Football, A.F.C. Steals the Show
description: WHY do teams from the American Conference of the Na- tional Football League so consistently beat those from the other conference, the National? The score this season, 2610 or .722, is the highest yet but hardly new. The A.F.C. teams have won more interconference games than the N.F.C. every year since 1972 except for 1973, when it was a 1919 tie.

title: GARDENING For the Best Possible Plants Next
description: AS another outdoor gardening season comes to a close, a number of important tasks may remain to be accomplished. In some instances, next season's success may hinge upon how well these chores are carried out.

title: CALENDARS; Motor Sports
description: Today  Fairfield County Sports Car Club final autocross at Pitney Bowes parking lot, Route 7 (south of Merritt Parkway), Norwalk, Conn. Registration: 10 A.M. First car off noon.

title: Falcons See Giants As a Stepping Stone
description: In a sense, the motto for the Atlanta Falcons has been wait till last year.

title: Thanksgiving Away From Home
description: IN America at Thanksgiving, there is a wonderful confusion between nation and nature, and we celebrate them both at once. Almost every culture has a harvest ritual, but it is hard to think of another place where having good things to eat is a patriotic act. Recognizing that wantonly unused capacity is an affront to all that we hold dear, we must enlist at one table or another, and the question comes down to where it shall be. Most choose their own homes, but a surprisingly large number elect the freedom not to cook, and for them we list some restaurants that offer not only fresh and homemade dishes but also an ambiance that seems appropriate to this season.

title: ESCAPED CONVICTS HUNTED IN WEST VIRGINIA:; United Press International
description: As two policemen aimed shotguns, another opened the back of a trailer truck that was being searched at a roadblock in Parkersburg, W. Va. The police were searching for four convicts who were still at large after 15 inmates escaped Wednesday from the state's maximum security prison. One of the convicts died from wounds received during the escape and 10 others have been captured.

title: City Seeking Greater Income From Lease Program

title: They Flavor Their Rock With Reggae

But it plays more reggae than rock, or at least reggaeinfused rock. And that gives one pause for thought not only about the relationships between the white majority and black music in Brit- ain and America, then and now, but also about what those relationships presage for the future exchanges be- tween British and American rock in general.

title: Pop: Diana Ross Sings at Music Hall

They had all appeared in their respec- tive parts at the neighboring New York State Theater in the past; now they were singing them at the Met for the first time. (Actually, Miss Craig had first sung Micaela with the company last Monday night.)

title: Feelings And Acts
description: IREAD W. H. Auden: The Life of a Poet chapter by chapter, backward and forward. For readers who have less time to spare, I recommend back- ward. This corresponds to the plan of the book, in which the funeral alone seems to last half a decade. And it gives the picture of Auden's life that his biogra- pher has pieced together, with a sense of how he ar- rived at it. The Auden celebrated here is an institu- tion, whom Charles Osborne, as head of another insti- tution, Poetry International, came to know late and not quite intimately. (Poetry International sponsors a series of annual summer readings at which Auden was a frequent performer.) A list of honors, with dates, and quotations from reviews, is the substance of Mr. Osborne's story; and Auden's final years, which ex- hibit no new change of heart or of habits, giye him the least trouble. The Auden of the 1930's and 40's still awaits his biographer. We may suppose that his life was shaped by certain forces and that his career might be made to form a satisfying dramatic arc. But these things Mr. Osborne has left us to discover for ourselves.

title: Academic Proficiency Tests: They Are Not the Answer

title: Rhythm And Rhyme
description: Recently, a teacher in a college near Boston shared with me a curious problem she runs into. Her students, it seems, don't pick up allusions to Little Miss Mullet or the cow that jumped over the moon. Who is this Jack Sprat? they ask her. Mind you, these aren't Just any old college students  they're training to be children's librarians. My friend, while doing her best to enlighten them, doesn't feel that at this late moment in their lives she can fruitfully set them on her lap and read Mother Goose to them.

title: French Press and Politicians At Odds Over Scandal Reports
description: PARIS  After a quiet weekend at his father's chateau in the Auvergne, President Valery Giscard d'Estaing returned to the agitated capital and proclaimed that France was interested in inflation and unemployment, not in scandal. That set off another little scandalized crisis in Paris where the issue of power, probity and the press has become the focus of attention. And it provided another demonstration of the President's style of superb selfconfidence and his critics sense of impotence. Ine latest abrasions began with sensational reports in Le Canard Enchaine that the President and his family had received lavish gifts of diamonds from the deposed Central African Emperor Bokassa. Then came charges, in the right- wing tabloid Minute, of profitable stringpulling in private real estate deals by Prime Minister Raymond Barre and Minister of Labor Robert Boulin. These were shrugged off as nasty gossip, until Mr. Boulin committed suicide. It was a shock. Mr. Giscard and other govenmental associates im- mediately blamed the press. The President said his late minister had disappeared in circumstances which provoke indignation. . .. These methods are unworthy of France and of democracy. While he made no link with the revelations about his diamonds, the President was indicting those who make ugly disclosures, on the grounds of national and per- sonal honor.

The outspoken 54yearold executive was named to the same post at the corporation's principal subsidiary, the First National Bank of Chicago.

title: New Life for the Immortal Newsstand
description: There was a time when practically every corner in New York seemed to have its own ramshackle newsstand  a shelter sheathed in magazines and newspapers, a form of street art, a street event. The newsstand was also one of the great little conveniences of city life, offering fast reams of the world's experience to the passing crowd. But newsstands have gradually been closing down. In 1950, 1,325 were licensed. Now there are fewer than 400. For too many operators, the world's great issues in print have provided only small change in profit.

title: Sheila Joyce Herz Is Bride Of Stewart Edward Wilensky
description: The marriage of Sheila Joyce Hen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hermann Hen of Mankato, Minn., to Stewart Edward Wilensky took place yesterday in Temple EmanuEl. Rabbi Richard Chapin performed the ceremony.

title: Flyers 5, Canucks 4
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11 (AP) Rick MacLeish scored three goals to lead the Philadelphia Flyers to a 54 victory over the Vancouver Canucks tonight. The victory was the eighth straight for the Flyers, who extended their unbeaten streak to 12 games. Philadelphia now has a 1211 wonlost tied record for the season.

title: Greek Archbishop of Jerusalem Receives a Threat in Switzerland
description: SOLOTHURN, Switzerland, Nov. 11 (Reuters)  The Greek Catholic Archbishop of East Jerusalem, Hilarion Capucci, celebrated mass near here under police protection yesterday after death threat, police officials said today.

title: Going Out GUIDE
description: RIGHT LINE America's bestknown showbusiness caricaturist, Al Hirschfeld, sees his craft as a matter of line. According to the artist, whose drawings regularly appear in The New York Times, The placing of the right line in the right place has absorbed all of my interests across these many years.

title: D. Richard Williams Marries Janet M. Lavine in Syracuse
description: Janet M. Lavine, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Lavine of Syracuse, was married there yesterday to D. Richard Williams, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Williams of Daretown, N.J. The ceremony was performed in the Hotel Syracuse by Rabbi Theodore Levy.

title: Orthodox Bishop Consecrated
description: BOSTON, Nov. 11 (AP)  The Right Rev. Archimandrite Mark Forsberg, Roman Catholic priest before his conversion to Orthodoxy 15 years ago, has been consecrated bishop of the Albanian Or thodox Archdiocese in America. The archdiocese, part of the Orthodox Church in America, has 75,000 members. Metropolitan Theodosius I of New York, primate of the Orthodox Church in America, officiated at the services yesterday at St. George Cathedral.

description: WOODBRIDGE, N.J. (AP)  An intensified effort to apprehend and prosecute persons who throw rocks from overpasses and embankments along the Garden State Parkway has been announced.

description: By LES BROWN

title: 29,000 Lose Electric Power
description: Three Westchester County communities were hit by a brief power blackout yesterday afternoon, Consolidated Edison officials said. Approximately 29,000 customers in New Rochelle, Larchmont and Mamaroneck were without electricity for about 40 minutes after a circuit breaker on Main Street in New Rochelle went out at 3:14 P.M. All power was restored by 3:52 P.M.

title: IRANIANS IN BEIRUT BESIEGE U.S. EMBASSY; 50 Students Supporting Khomeini Break Into GroundsSyrians Beat and Disperse Them
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 11  Iranian students, chanting Death to Americans! and Long live Khomeini! broke into the grounds of United States Embassy here today, lowered the American flag and burned it. They were later dispersed by Syrian troops of the Arab League peacekeeping force.

title: Thailand Bars Press From Area Where Border Clash Took Place
description: ARANYAPRATHET, Thailand, Nov. 11 (Reuters)  Thai military authorities have barred journalists from visiting border area where Thai soldiers and antiCommunist Cambodian forces clashed last week.

title: Twins Born 20 Days Apart
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 11 (Reuters)  A woman has given birth to twin boys 20 days apart, the Belgrade newspaper Vecernje Novosti reported today. The first child was born on Sept. 16 and the second on Oct. 6 to Miljojka Tomic, 25 years old, at the Prokuplje hospital, 120 miles south of Belgrade, the paper said.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in Metropolitan Report Thursday reversed the identities of two assistant United States attorneys. Scott W. Muller was at the left and Alan Levine at the right.

title: Cauthen Unhurt in Japan Fall
description: TOKYO, Nov. 11 (AP)  Steve Cauthen fell from a horse in the first of his four races today, but returned to score a victory before more than 13.000 spectators at Ohi race track.

title: New Sailing Ship Runs Aground
description: THOMASTON, Me., Nov. 11 (UPI) The first sailpowered cargo vessel to be built in this country in 90 years ran aground today on a mussel shoal, a quarter of a mile into her maiden voyage. The 97foot schooner John F. Leavitt, christened Aug. 8 as a symbol of the new age of sail, ran aground on her way to Quincy, Mass., to pick up a cargo of lumber for transport to Haiti.

title: The City; Doctors Plan Strike At Flushing Hospital
description: The union representing 70 interns and residents at Flushing Hospital said yesterday that it would strike at 7 A.M. today because the 400bed private facility in Queens had refused to negotiate a first contract for the young doctors.

title: Patricia Sinnott Is Wed to Dirk Schenkkan
description: Patricia Luce Sinnott, a physical therapist in San Francisco, was married there yesterday to Dirk McKenzie Schenkkan, a lawyer. The Episcopal ceremony was performed in the chapel at Fort Mason by the Rev. Francis Hunt Geer.

title: Margaret Thatcher Vows to Bring Major Changes to Ulster Will Impose a Decision
description: LONDON, Nov. 11  Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher says she is determined to make major changes in the way Northern Ireland is governed, whether or not the squabbling Ulster political parties agree, in the hope that political evolution will eventually lead to reduced violence.

title: Suharto Leaves for Britain
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 11 (Reuters)  President Suharto of Indonesia left today for an official fourday visit to Britain. He was accompanied by a party that includes his wife and Foreign Minister Mochtar Kusumaatmadja. Mr. Suharto was to stop overnight in Geneva, where he will meet with Pierre Aubert, chairman of the Swiss Department of Foreign Affairs.

title: City's Failure to Build Is Said to Cost Millions
description: New York City lost $40 million in purchasing power in fiscal 1979 because of delays in spending available construction funds, the Citizens Budget Commission estimated yesterday. Citing failure to award $501 million, or 37 percent, in scheduled contracts, the group reported that samplings showed an average delay of eight months, with an inflation rate of 1 percent a month.

title: Iranian Student Held In a Killing in Denver As Protests Continue; One Killed, Two Wounded
description: By The Associated Press

title: A Cambodian Representative Stirs Things Up at the U.N. U.N. Notes
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 11 In the intricate games that diplomats play, Keo Prasat scored some points for his side last week.

title: Italy's Prices Rise
description: ROME, Nov. 11 (Reuters)  Italy's wholesale price index rose 1.9 percent in September, after a 2.2 percent rise in August, the Statistics Institute said last week. This put the index 17.7 percent higher than in September last year.

title: Eurodollar Curb Plan Reported; Central Bankers Seek to Limit Excess Growth
description: PARIS, Nov. 11  The Federal Reserve and the central banks of the other major industrialized financial powers have privately agreed on a twostage plan for controlling the explosive growth of the Eurocurrency markets, which they believe is fueling world inflation, according to a senior central bank governor closely involved in their discussions.

title: World News Briefs; 4 Aides Injured in Attack On Mrs. Gandhi at Rally
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 11 (AP)  A rockthrowing mob attacked former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's car today in eastern India and injured four of her aides, but she escaped unharmed, the United News of India reported.

description: By TOM BUCKLEY

title: WindfallProfits Tax Nears Senate Showdown; Windfall Tax Nears Showdown
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11  President Carter's ambitious energy program faces its toughest challenge when the tax on windfall oil profits reaches the Senate floor Tuesday.

title: One Town's Reaction of Anger to the Crisis in Iran One Town's Reaction of Anger and Frustration to the Iranian Crisis Football Victory Hailed Some Action Is Called for Iranian Children in Parish
description: CUMBERLAND, Md., Nov. 11  William F. Leyh, a brakeman for the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, did not have to think what he would say when asked about the American hostages held in Teheran. He had been thinking and talking about it all week and with every passing day he became a little more angry.

title: Ohira Asks Cut In State Bonds
description: TOKYO, Nov. 11 (Rueters) Japan's Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira said yesterday the Government must reduce a fairly large amount of state bond issues, which account for 40 percent of the current national budget. in a nationally televised news conference he said that fiscal 1980, beginning next April, should be the first year for Japan to reconstruct its deficitridden state finances.

title: 30 Americans Protest Peacefully Near Shah's New York Hospital
description: About 30 Americans protested loudly but peacefully yesterday outside the New York HospitalCornell Medical Center, where Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi is recuperating. Many called for stronger action by the Carter Administration.

title: James Millner, a Lawyer, Weds Susan Linda Meyer
description: Susan Linda Meyer, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Donald C. Meyer of Scarsdale, N.Y., and James Warren Millner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley C. Millner of Trenton, were married yesterday in White Plains. Rabbi Arnold S. Turetsky, assisted by Cantor Abraham Mizrahi, performed the ceremony in Temple Israel Center.

title: Giants Rout Falcons,; 243
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 11The Giants beat the Atlanta Falcons, 243, today in a game that proved football should not be played under water, but the victory will count anyway.

title: Congresswomen Hear Guns Fire In Cambodia Refugee Camp Tour
description: SA KEO, Thailand, Nov. 11 (UPI)  A delegation of American Congresswomen walked to within earshot of Vietnamese artillery today during a visit to Cambodian refugee camps where they talked with starving children.

description: By Samuel Rabinove

title: Lisa Ruth Wegweiser Bride of Robert Snyder
description: Lisa Ruth Wegweiser, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Wegweiser of Englishtown, N.J., was married at noon yesterday to Robert G. Snyder, son of Mr. and Mrs. Myron Snyder of Bookline, Mass. Rabbi David M. Posner performed the ceremony at Temple EmanuEl.

title: Group Is Urging Older Veterans To Fight Undesirable Discharges
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (UPI)  The American Civil Liberties Union urged today that 2.2 million veterans given undesirable discharges before 1965 appeal their cases to the Defense Department before the Dec. 31 deadline.

title: Maple Leafs 6, Oilers 3
description: EDMONTON, Alberta, Nov. 11 (AP)  Ron Ellis scored twice within a 2minute30second span to key a fourgoal first period as the Toronto Maple Leafs defeated the Edmonton Oilers, 63, today.

title: U.S. Wins Culp Golf: PoliticsScored; Leads All the Way
description: ATHENS, Nov. 11  A denunciation of the injection of politics into sports added a sobering note today to the United States sweep of the 27th World Cuo golf tournament. Hale Irwin and

title: Seahawks Survive Rally by Browns; Smith Scores Pair
description: AT KANSAS CITY, Mo.  The Steelers, marching to their ninth victory against two defeats, the best record in the N.F.L., were guilty of two oversights: 1) they were unable to score in the third quarter and, 2) they allowed the Chiefs to tally on a 42yard field goal by Jan Stenerud. Otherwise, the Steelers were dominant. Terry Bradshaw completed 17 of 29 passes for 232 yards, including three for touchdowns, and Matt Bahr booted field goals of 31, 20 and 37 yards. The Pittsburgh defense, which held the opposition to 7 or fewer points for the fourth straight week, sacked Steve Fuller, the Kansas City rookie quarterback, five times.

title: Meeting of 6,000 Rights Workers in Haiti Disrupted
description: PORTAUPRINCE, Haiti, Nov. 11 (AP)  A meeting of about 6,000 human rights activists here last week ended in chairswinging freeforall reportedly started by members of the Government's secret police.

title: MISS BELLAMY FINDS RENTALPLAN FLAWS Charges 2Party Payment System for Welfare Tenants Results in a Slumlords Subsidy
description: New York City's use of twoparty welfare rent checks  now totaling $100 million a year for 60,000 cases  was criticized yesterday by City Council President Carol Bellamy, who said that often the more such checks a landlord received, the more housing violations were found in his building.

title: Israeli Cabinet Supports New Settlements, but Only on StateOwned Land To Name Special Committee
description: TEL AVIV, Nov. 11The Israeli Cabinet decided today to continue its policy of building settlements in the occupied Arab territories but said they would be confined to stateowned land.

title: Young Kee Kim, an Ambassador For South Korea in Rhee Regime
description: HONOLULU, Nov. 11 (UPI)  Young Kee Rim, former South Korean Ambassador to the Philippines and to Italy and a longtime leader of the Korean community in Honolulu, died.here Wednesday. after an extended illness. He was 85 years old.

title: PALESTINIAN MAYOR ARRESTED BY ISRAEL, PROVOKING PROTESTS; He Faces Deportation for Allegedly Backing Terrorism Cabinet Votes New Settlements
description: NABLUS, IsraeliOccupied West Bank, Nov. 11  The Palestinian Mayor of one of the West Bank's major cities was arrested today by Israeli military authorities pending a court ruling on a move to deport him to Jordan for allegedly expressing sympathy for terrorists.

title: Nonprofit Groups Discuss Plans for a United Front The Birth of a Committee
description: DENVER, Nov. 11  The nation's third sector of private, nonprofit organizations is feeling somewhat picked on these days. At a threeday conference here, its representatives showed a developing determination to do something about it.

title: Music: Levi's Rockabilly
description: LEVI and the Rockats, who were at the Other End over the weekend, have had a curious history. They got together in England as an offshoot of the recent English mania for 1950 s American rockabilly music. From there they went to Los Angeles, where they soon became one of the more popular new wave attractions. Now they're in New York, and they'd certainly be a welcome addition to the rockclub circuit if they elected to stay.

title: Expert Discourages Conversion Of Three Mile Island Plant to Coal
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 11 (AP) Converting the damaged Three Mile Island nuclear reactor to coal would be expensive, difficult and unwise, according to a state enegy expert.

title: 500 March in a Procession for Five Slain Communists; March With Police Escort
description: GREENSBORO, N.C., Nov. 11 Chanting revolutionary slogans and vowing vengeance, about 500 marchers today escorted the reddraped coffins of five slain activists through the streets of this tense and heavily policed city.

title: 4 ARRESTED IN CHINA AT DEMOCRACY WALL They Are Detained as Transcript of Dissident's Trial Goes on Sale Charges Are Not Clear
description: PEKING, Nov. 11 Four persons were arrested at Peking's Democracy Wall today as the transcript of the trial of young Chinese dissident, Wei Jingsheng, went on sale.

title: Around the Nation; Hundreds in Florida Flee Area of Train Derailment
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., Nov. 11 (UPI)  A locomotive and 29 cars of a 109car Louisville & Nashville freight train derailed near here early today and six cars filled with liquid propane gas caught fire, forcing the evacuation of hundreds of people living up to nine miles away. No injuries were reported.

title: G.I's of the 82d Airborne Are Rarin to Go; Not for Real Yet
description: FORT BRAGG, N.C., Nov. 11 Like untried but true soldiers throughout history, the young men of the 82d Airborne Division say they're rarin to eo.

title: The Middle Way on Student Aid
description: Everyone in Washington seems to agree that the Government's tuition aid program for college students is seriously flawed. Many students dont repay their loans, and colleges are indifferent bill collectors. Despite Federal guarantees, some banks refuse make loans. Students lacking tuition money must therefore find costly shortterm credit. Colleges say the Government's ceiling on aid hasn't kept pace with inflation while others contend the interest rates on loans (as low as 3 percent) are too generous.

title: Schools Dropout Rate In New York City Stirs Worry Over Jobs Pool School Dropout Rate Stirs Concern Over Labor Pool
description: The high dropout rate in New York City high schools and the limited job skills of many graduates have stirred concern among businessmen and officials in the Koch administration that the quality of the local labor pool is declining and undermining the city's economic future.

title: Holiday Closings
description: Most banks will be closed today in observance of Veterans Day, although the Federal Reserve said few might exercise an option to remain open. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York will be closed. The stock exchanges and corporate bond markets are open.

title: ESSAY; Waterquiddick
description: WASHINGTON  Last week, that cruelest of cartoonists, Oliphant of The Washington Star, showed a brooding Nixon staring at Ted Kennedy on television. Caption: So, once upon a time he went on TV, and lied to the people ... so. what's wrong with that?

description: QUEBEC, Nov. 11 (UPI)  Real Cloutier scored a goal in each of the first two periods tonight to lead the Quebec Nordiques to a 41 victory over the St. Louis Blues.

title: ABROAD AT HOME; Cambodia: A Flicker Of Hope
description: BOSTON, Nov. 11 As the reality of the human disaster in Cambodia has been brought home to us in recent weeks, Americans have responded: contributing to relief agencies, volunteering, pressing for Government action. But some people wonder how much the effort will really helphow much aid will get through the physical and political bottlenecks

title: Rome Bourse Clerks Strike
description: ROME, Monday, Nov. 12 (Reuters) Clerks on the Italian Bourse called oneday strike today to protest delays in negotiation of a new labor contract, the union announced. Bourse sources said the strike was likely to disrupt share quotations.

title: IRAN STUDENT TELLS OF PLAN FOR ATTACK; A Leader of U.S. Embassy Raiders Thought That Many Would Die
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 11 (Reuters)A leader of the 500 Moslem students who stormed the American Embassy here a week ago said today that they had expected that many would be killed and were surprised to encounter such little resistance.

title: PRESIDENT TESTING THEMES OF CAMPAIGN; Stress is on Peace, Cuts in Taxes, Efficiency and a Willingness to Take Unpopular Steps Record of Achievements Prepared Effect of Tax Cuts Cuts in the on Federal Staff Theme of Difficult Choices
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11  Likening himself to Harry S. Truman, President Carter is telling audiences these days that he has been willing to make unpopular decisions. Invoking a theme of Pope John Paul II, he adds that he believes in the moral strength of American families and communities.

title: Fire Believed Set by Child Kills 14 In Ohio Boarding Home for Aged; 4YearOld With Matches
description: PIONEER, Ohio, Nov. 11 (UPI)  A child apparently set a fire today that swept through a boarding home for the elderly and retarded, killing 14 women, including the owner, who had run back into the burning building to rescue residents.

title: Rockies 5, Sabres 3
description: BUFFALO, Nov. 11 (UPI)  Lucien DeBlois scored two goals, including the goahead tally in the third period, to give the Colorado Rockies a 53 victory over the Buffalo Sabres tonight. The victory was the first ever for the Rockies in Buffalo and only their second triumph in 22 games against the Sabres.

title: Ranger Lapses Lead to 41 Setback; Nothing's Clicking; Picked Wrong Side
description: Fred Shero, the Rangers coach, called it sort of a funny game. Not laughingly funny, but strangely funny. The Rangers outshot the Penguins by 2827, played fairly stingy defense, swarmed around the Pittsburgh Penguin goal in the first and the third periods, and still lost, 41, last night at Madison Sauare Garden.

title: Broncos Run Wild Over Patriots, 4510; Broncos Statistics
description: DENVER, Nov. 11 (UPI)  Craig Morton threw two touchdown passes, and Rob Lytle scored twice on short runs as the Denver Broncos rolled up stunning 4510 triumph over the New England Patriots in a blustery snowstorm today.
