description: By GEORGIA DULLEA

title: Delaware Theater Group To Start With Overruled
description: Delaware's first professional resident theater company has been formed and is moving into a firehouse on French Street in Wilmington. It will present its first production, Overruled, by George Bernard Shaw, Dec. 7 through 9.

title: Notes on People; Joan Little's Defender on the Defensive; The Symphony vs. Coughers, Rustlers and Crinklers; The Effect of a Cause on Our Man at the U.N.; Driven Men and Others; First Lady Places Third; Princess Grace at 50
description: Remember Jerry Paul? He's the maverick North Carolina lawyer who defended Joan Little four years ago when she was acquitted of charges of stabbing a jailer to death in her cell. Mr. Paul lives in New York these days (as does Miss Little, for that matter), but if he ever wants to go home again, he'll find the going rough.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Sears Vice Chairman, First in Decade, Elected I.C.I. Americas Picks Lawyer To Succeed Retiring President A Network Man Moves to Cable
description: Jack F. Kincamion, 60 years old, has been elected vice chairman of Sears, Roebuck & Company, the world's largest retailer, effective next Feb. 1. Mr. Kincannon, whose new title has not been used for the last 10 years, will continue as chief financial officer.

title: RALPH THOMPSON, 75, BOOK CRITIC, IS DEAD; Was Reviewer for The Times, Daily and Sunday, and Secretary of BookoftheMonth Club Served in Army Intelligence
description: By HERBERT MITGANG

title: Sports News Briefs Romero Barcelo to Ignore Move to Extradite Knight
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Nov. 12 (UPI)Gov. Carlos Romero Barce16 of Puerto Rico probably will ignore a request from the commonwealth's bar association to ask for the extradition of Bobby Knight to serve a sixmonth jail sentence for assault, political observers said today.

title: The Right Way to Get Tough
description: President Carter is being both wise and firm in his contest against Ayatollah Khomeini. Removing oil as factor in that contest will not liberate the 60 hostages the American Embassy in Teheran. It also risks economic damage to the United States and other oil importers. But it summons the entire nation to join in the defense of principle and preserves the hope of somehow getting 700 vulnerable Americans out of Iran alive.

title: Federal Order Expected Today On Iranian Students in the U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12  The Justice Department is expected to issue a directive tomorrow giving all Iranians holding student visas 30 days to report to the Immigration and Naturalization Service for a review of their status, Government officials said today.

title: All Is Quiet After Funeral March
description: GREENSBORO, N.C., Nov. 12 (UPI)  A state of emergency giving the police wideranging arrest powers was lifted today by city officials, one day after 350 Communists and sympathizers conducted a funeral march to honor five demonstrators killed at an antiKu Klux Klan rally.

title: Woman Hurt in Robbery Dies
description: A 59yearold Manhattan woman who was robbed and pushed down a flight of stairs by her attacker in September died yesterda' in St. Clare's Hospital, apparently from her iniuries. a hospital spokesman said. The woman, Mary Singer of 228 West 72d Street, sustained serious injuries Sept. 12 in the fall on down a flight of stairs in an underground passageway at 1270 Avenue of the Americas, at 51st Street. The woman was apparently robbed and pushed down the stairs, a police spokesman said.

title: Hot Pink, Used in Test, Is Said to Cool Prisoners
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., Nov. 12 (AP) Two cells at the Santa Clara County jail have been painted hot pink to test a theory that the color of a person's surroundings affects his behavior.

title: 7% Oil Output Advantage Estimated From Senate WindfallTax
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP)  The Congressional Budget Office estimated today that the Senate Finance Committee's version of the Administration's windfall profits tax would increase United States oil production by 7 percent more than the bill endorsed by President Carter.

title: Bundesbank Reserves Off
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, Nov. 12 (AP)  Net monetary reserves of the Bundesbank dropped by $2 billion to $51 billion in the week ended Nov. 7, the West German central bank said today. The bank said the drop was due mainly to the repayment of currency exchanged with domestic banks.

title: CARTER BARS IRANIAN OIL FROM U.S. AND VOWS DEFIANCE ON HOSTAGES SMALL PRICE INCREASES PREDICTED; CONSERVATION ASKED President Says Economic Pressure Can't Weaken Stand on Principles
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12  President Carter ordered an immediate suspension of oil imports from Iran today, declaring that the United States would not yield to unacceptable demands for the return of the deposed Shah made by Iranians holding American citizens hostage in the United States Embassy in Teheran.

title: Qatar's Oil Output Rises
description: DOHA, Qatar, Nov. 12 (AP) Qatar's oil production increased by 4 percent and its oil exports by 13.5 percent in October, the Gulf News Agency reported today. Oil production in October rose to 14.1 million barrels, compared with 13.6 million in September, while exports rose to 18.7 million barrels, two million more than in the preceding month, the agency said.

title: Pop: J.D. Souther Sings
description: J.D. SOUTHER, who was at the Bottom Line Sunday night and last night, continues to act like a man with considerable talent who's just too cool to grab for the brass ring. As a respected songwriter within the charmed Los Angeles circle that includes the Eagles, Linda Ronstadt and Bonnie Raitt (all of whom have collaborated with him or recorded his songs), a former member of the popular countryrock aggregation Souther, Hillman and Furay, a singer with an expressively personal style, and a commanding stage presence, Mr. Souther should have it made. But he records lowkeyed, unremarkable albums, supports them by playing a few selected concerts with amiable, lackluster bands, and then goes back to whatever he does with the rest of his life.

title: No Strike at Flushing Hospital
description: Interns and resident physicians yesterday postponed for at least a week threatened strike at Flushing Hospital while they continue to negotiate a proposed contract that would cover the 70member medical house staff. The Cornmittee of Interns and Residents, which represents the physicians in training, said it had obtained a memorandum of understanding from the private voluntary hospital that recognized the committee as the physicians bargaining agent. The group had threatened a strike for yesterday.

description: The American alligator, which was being slaughtered and threatened with extinction a few years ago, has made such a dramatic comeback that it is now being legally sold as food in southern Louisiana, the Center for Wetland Resources at Louisiana State University has reported.

The State Police Superintendent, Harley Mooney, said that Ronald T. Williams, convicted of killing a Beckley police sergeant in 1975, was suspected of masterminding the escape and shooting the trooper.

Dutch and Ameri can firefighters tried unsuccessfully Nov. 5 to use chemical foam to extinguish the fire aboard the 772foot tanker Burmah Agate, which collided with the 482foot freighter Mimosa on Nov. 1, killing 32 crewmen.

title: The Morality of Speech
description: There is morality in the freedom of speech; there may be morality in the content of speech; but can there also be morality in the correctness of speech? Yes, says Denis Donoghue, a Dublin professor called on recently to help the British Broadcasting Corporation appraise the way it handles the English language. if someone today using the English language speaks badly, Professor Donoghue says, he should really feel that he is abusing Shakespeare, that he is abusing Milton, that he is repudiating the values which are implicit in the Canterbury Tales or Hamlet. It's a question of the morality of speech.

title: 400 in Ithaca College Protest

The slave was led around campus by a noose around his neck. The Ithaca College AfroLatin Society, which led the rally, seeks justification from the college for the decision to suspend four. of the students for the rest of the year. College officials said the decision was based on previous good conduct by the four at the private, fouryear college.

title: Film: 'Vanina Vanini,' Conventional Rossellini:From Stendahl
description: ROBERTO ROSSELLINI'S "Vanina Vanini," which opens today at the Little Theater in Joseph Papp's Public Theater, is one of the last more or less conventional theatrical films that Rossellini made before he began that extraordinary series of "teaching films" ("The Rise of Louis XIV," "The Age of the Medici," "Socrates," among others) on which he was still working at the time of his death in 1976.I emphasize "more or less conventional" because although "Vanina Vanini," based on a Stendhal short story, seems to be a highly romantic melodrama set against the background of Italy's Risorgimento, it's not to be so easily categorized. Its characters are neither idealized nor familiar, and if the ending appears to be tragic, it's as open-ended as that of a continuing serial. Rossellini put great store by historical facts but remained skeptical of the way they could be manipulated to substantiate fashions in contemporary thought and politics."Vanina Vanini" opens in 1823, during the conclave of the College of Cardinals in Rome to pick a successor to Pope Pius VII. It's the story of the love affair of a bored, spoiled young Roman princess, Vanina Vanini (Sandra Milo), and a dedicated young patriot, Pietro Missirilli (Laurent Terzieff), who has come to Rome to assassinate a traitor to his brotherhood of Free Masons, here identified with the fight against papal oppression and the campaign for a united Italy.Vanina hasn't much feeling, one way or the other, about revolutionary politics, though her father, like so many Roman aristocrats, allows himself to become an accessory to revolution simply by refusing to stand against it. Vanina and Pietro meet when her father, to save his mistress from an embarrassing situation, agrees to hide the wounded Pietro in his house.Vanina, after nursing Pietro back to health, follows her lover to the north of Italy and, with no immediate thought of the consequences, plots to free Pietro of the political obligations that are interfering with her happiness. Eventually she informs on his comrades and is surprised when he refuses to accept the terms of a church pardon that would save him from the guillotine."Vanina Vanini" sometimes sounds like the ripest of melodramatic romance, as when Pietro feels the need to say that he and Vanina belong to two different worlds, though as he points you, "You have the power to make me forget everything."Yet the movie is never quite that simple or simple-minded. Nor are Vanina and Pietro some sort of 19th-century equivalents to 20th-century lovers separated by class and conviction. They are deeply rooted in their own time, something that Rossellini respects and which distinguishes this film from Luchino Visconti's "Senso," which deals with the same period of Italy's history.There is an extraordinary scene in which Vanina, guilt-ridden by her illicit affair with Pietro, is quizzed by her young, handsome confessor, a priest whose genuine concern for her is very much at odds with his own passion. There's also a typical Rossellini exchange when Vanina, who refuses to take Pietro's political commitments seriously, suggests that perhaps they could run off to America."I don't think I'd like it," Pietro says in effect. "There's something to be said for bad government. If I went abroad, I'd be without passions, without feelings."Behind that statement are the wisdom and the purpose that illuminate all of Rossellini's later work. Rossellini did not, I think, often imagine a utopia, as a Marxist might. Utopia is for the dead. The world is for the living whose purpose is to strive, to evolve, to learn.Miss Milo, probably best remembered here as Giulietta Masina's demimondaine friend in Federico Fellini's "Juliet of the Spirits," has a somewhat hard, movie-actress edge to her that is not entirely out of keeping with her role as Vanina. Mr. Terzieff is effective without being memorable in any waywhich may have to do with the acting styles of the time.The print being shown at the Public has apparently been clipped in spots, though why or by whom, I don't know. Martine Carol, the late, pre-Brigitte Bardot French sexpot, appears in the film so briefly that I assume her role was once somewhat more important.

A suit, now in its seventh year, seeks to break up the industry's manufacturing capacity and to force the big three  Kellogg, General Mills, General Foods  to give away use of their brand names.

title: Russians Plan Oil Output Rise
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 12 (Reuters)  The Soviet Union produced 3.19 billion barrels of oil in the first nine months of 1979, the Soviet central statistics board said today. The production target for the full year is 4.4 billion barrels, the board said.

description: LONDON, Tuesday, Nov. 13  The Times of London resumed publication today after nearly a year's interruption.

title: Full Employment; for All
description: WHITE BEAR LAKE, Minn.  The advancing edge of productivity and the fixed structure of working hours, like the blades of a pair of scissors, are cutting people from their jobs.

title: Kurds Attack Several Iran Towns
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 12 (Reuters) Kurdish rebels have opened a new offensive against several towns of Kurdistan Province in northern Iran, the Pars press agency said today. An announcement from the Revolutionary Guard headquarters in Kermanshah, quoted by the agency, said that many people had been killed or wounded and that the attack was continuing. Two Kurdish rebels were reported killed and one wounded. The announcement said fullscale attacks were under way on the towns of Sanandaj, Javanrud, Nousud and Saqqiz.

title: Seattle Poor Get Unsold Fish; Cleaned and Frozen
description: SEATTLE, Nov. 12 (AP)  A fisherman's gift of 20 tons of rockfish that could not be sold for lack of a market will grace the Thanksgiving tables of Seattle's needy.

title: Notes on People; Megan Marshack to Take Publicity Job With Producer
description: Megan Marshack, the staff aide who was with Nelson A. Rockefeller when he died last January, is going to work for Alexander H. Cohen, the Broadway producer.

title: $2 Million in Watches Stolen at Jersey Plant; Thieves, Cutting 3 Cables, Steal 1,500 Watches
description: CARLSTADT, N.J., Nov. 12  At least $2.1 million worth of Lucien Piccard wristwatches were stolen from a factory here over the weekend by thieves who cut telephone trunk lines, knocking out hundreds of burglary alarm systems in the Hackensack Meadowlands and disrupting telephone service at police stations in three communities.

title: Texaco Finds More Gas In Baltimore Canyon; Near Previous Strike
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 12 (AP) Texaco Inc. said today that it had struck more natural gas 106 miles off the New Jersey coast. It was the fourth and biggest gas discovery reported so far in a small area of the Baltimore Canyon trough.

title: Peak Harvest In Soviet Area
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 12 (AP)  The Soviet Union announced today that a record grain crop had been harvested in the southwestern Siberian region of Omsk, but it did not disclose the nation's total harvest, which is predicted to be the worst since 1975.

title: Kennedy Tells Iowans Carter Farm Policy Is a Failure; Abortion Issue in State
description: DES MOINES, Nov. 12  Senator Edward M. Kennedy, traveling to the heart of the Farm Belt and the state he has called the first real test of the 1980 political campaign, charged today that President Carter had failed tb give the country a stable auriculture policy.

title: Mexican Plan to Capture Leaking Oil Meets Snag
description: CIUDAD DEL CARMEN, Mexico, Nov. 12 (UPI)  Mexico's plan to recover oil leaking from the Ixtoc I well off Yucatan has been delayed by a ruptured pipeline, an oil official announced today.

title: HELMS GROUP HELPS CONSERVATIVE CAUSE; Club That Raised Millions to Aid Senator Broadens Its Scope
description: RALEIGH, N.C., Nov. 12 (AP)  The political club that raised $7.7 million for Senator Jesse Helms's reelection last year has broadened its scope in an apparent bid to promote conservatism in general and Senator Helms in particular on national level.

title: Upstart Senate Frosh
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J.  For several years after arriving in the Senate in 1912 as a freshman from the new state of Arizona, Carl Hayden maintained the respectful silence then expected of new members. One day, however, in a burst of youthful exuberance, he resolved to make a speech. It wasn't a very controversial speech but he felt that he had been a Senator long enough to comment on a minor matter affecting his state. As Mr. Hayden returned to his seat, an aged colleague approached him and hissed: You just had to talk, didn't you?

title: Women's Enrollment In Universities Surges, Census Study Reports
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (UPI)  College enrollment has grown by onethird in this decade, largely because of a surge in the number of women seeking undergraduate and advanced degrees, a Government survey showed today.

She refuses to divulge her personal views on abortion or to be assertive on the dangers of smoking, and she has spent countless hours alone in her office mastering the nuances of her department's budget.

title: California Vintages. From Year to Year
description: For years it was common for California wine makers to suggest that the weather there was so consistently good that few variations ever occurred among vintages. Many wineries did not put vintage dates on their labels and often blended wines from several different years. But connoisseurs knew that some years were better than others and began seeking vintagedated bottles. Gradually, vintagedating took hold and, earlier this year, Christian Brothers became the last major California producer to adopt the practice.

title: Dr. King Holiday Bill Fails to Win in House
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UPI) The House, after hearing Republican arguments that it would cost too much, today rejected a bill to establish Jan. 15, the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., as a national holiday.

description: CONCORD, N.H., Nov. 13 (AP) The builder of the Seabrook nuclear power plant said today that it would have to delay construction of the plant's second reactor by four years because it was unable to reduce its ownership of the plant from 50 percent to 28 percent.

title: Who Needs Another Law School?
description: Now that City University is a ward of the state, CUNY officials are resurrecting an old dream: create a law school at Queens College. The idea was approved five years ago by the Board of Regents but then shelved because of the city's fiscal crisis. Now the college hopes to open the school by 1981 and seeks $500,000 in startup money. The Queens plan has several intriguing features, but by many estimates, the United States is already overlawyered. Why should taxpayers be asked to subsidize a new institution to pour more attorneys into a saturated profession?

But to the Indian cook Julie Sahni. it is a mellow, dark, cashewstudded fruitcake that evokes memories of high school days in Kampur, India. Her school's principal, an Indian Christian, prepared the molassesrich concoction each Christmas and invited selected young female students and their mothers for holiday tea and cake.

title: Screen: 'Boardwalk,' a Couple's Problems:Crises in Series
description: DAVID and Becky Rosen (Lee Strasberg and Ruth Gordon) are approaching their 50th wedding anniversay as full of love for each other and confidence in the future as they were the day they were married. It's not easy, though. Their once safe middle-class Brooklyn neighborhood is going downhill rapidly. A gang of toughs roams the Coney Island boardwalk in the daytime and ransacks houses at night. When David attempts to befriend a Puerto Rican boy who has tried to rip off David's no-longer-profitable cafeteria, the kid rudely ridicules him.Then, too, Becky has cancer and Florence (Janet Leigh), their widowed daughter, enters a loveless marriage with a man who sells vinyl floor coverings. Florence's 24-year-old son, Peter, wants to be a rock musician. When the Rosens' best friends, the Friedmans, who are as old as David and Becky but not as resilient, find themselves unable to cope with the constant threats of robbery, rape and random attack, they turn on the gas jets and, hand in hand, lie down to await the death of their choosing.This is just a partial listing of some of the more or less crucial events in Stephen Verona's "Boardwalk," a movie so cluttered with crises it has the look of something condensed, like a trailer or a promotional film for a film that has yet to be made.This is not surprising. Though Mr. Verona has made two theatrical features ("The Lords of Flatbush" and "Pipe Dreams"), his background is in promotional movies, the principal purpose of which is to sell a product. In this case the product is despair, though I'm not at all sure that Mr. Verona realizes it.Pay no attention to that cheery ad for "Boardwalk": "The next time someone tells you to act your age  tell them about these two," over a Hirschfeld line drawing of Mr. Strasberg and Miss Gordon, cuddling in bed while reading Playboy. There is such a scene in the movie, and it is carried off with style by Mr. Strasberg and Miss Gordon, but "Boardwalk" is otherwise a movie of unrelieved, unexplored gloom. This is not because of what happens but because Mr. Verona, both as the director and screenwriter (with Leigh Chapman), has no knack whatsoever for seeing beyond the troubles he dumps into his picture."Boardwalk," which opens today at the Manhattan 2 Cinema, is about a number of serious subjects, including old age, urban blight, the generation gap, terminal illness, inflation and the failure of the American dream. Though Mr. Verona identifies these problems, he has no idea how to shape them into a coherent, plausible movie.There even are indications that he is ashamed of making a movie that is, without doubt, the downer of the year. After he has allowed us to see the attempted rape of an old lady, or the firebombing of David's cafeteria, he immediately cuts to some dumb shot of Peter, the rock musician, in rehearsal, as if a little music will take our minds off the unpleasant business at hand. There's no irony here. It is, instead, a station-break.Mr. Verona also has no idea how to write individual scenes or how to allow characters to develop at their own speed. The movie proceeds in bits and pieces of sequences that undercut the actors, at the same time revealing the absence of anything faintly resembling a director's unifying vision.When the film is dealing with the home life of David and Becky, "Boardwalk" adopts the folksy, Jewish-cute manners of a situation comedy. When David or Becky is out on the boardwalk, about to be assaulted by the one gang that seems to own all of Coney Island, the film's style becomes that of "The Warriors"  the gang's appearance being announced by clickety-click soundtrack music and by close-ups of sneakered feet.The only thing the movie has going for it is a cast of good actors. Mr. Strasberg, Miss Gordon and Miss Leigh provide their roles with depths of feelings that come out of their own resources, certainly not the director's or the writers'. The supporting roles are nicely handled by Joe Silver, Eli Mintz, Eddie Barth and Merwin Goldsmith, while Lillian Roth makes a brief, sweet appearance as a lonely Jewish widow. Linda Manz ("Days of Heaven") wanders on and off as an anonymous member of the street gang, which is so carefully integrated you might suspect that Brooklyn now runs a busing program for muggers.Because "Boardwalk" is inept, it makes everything it touches seem trivial. How, one wonders, did Mr. Verona obtain the services of so many talented people, including Billy Williams, the cameraman? Chutzpah, perhaps.

title: Ducking the Buck on Schools
description: Almost since the beginning of public education, school boards have fought for independence from city government. Thus we are astonished to hear Chancellor Macchiarola of the New York City schools surrender his independence and ask the City Council and Board of Estimate to tell him which cuts should be made to cover the $55million deficit in his budget. The offer is a mistake. Mr. Macchiarola should design his own budget and then defend it, not disown it.

title: House Passes Airline Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (Reuters)The House of Representatives passed by voice vote today a bill authorizing the Civil Aeronautics Board to suspend or revoke permits and rates of foreign airlines whose governments place unreasonable restrictions on United States airlines. Under the bill, any actions by the board would be subject to review. The bill would also permit airlines to raise their international fares by up to 5 percent or lower them by as much as 50 percent without the board's prior approval. A similar bill has been passed by the Senate, and a joint conference was ordered to work out differences.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS Problems In Paradise
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Fiji's seductive blend of lush islands, faded colonial charm, comfortable tourist hotels and a still largely uncomplicated style of life hides some disturbing realities. Fiji, 2,000 miles north of Sydney, may be one nation but it is two countries. One is a land of kava (a totally disappointing traditional alcoholic drink brought from neighboring Polynesia) and the sulu, the Melanesian version of the sarong. The other is a land of Indian curries and saris.

title: Screen: 'Each Other,' Israeli Love Triangle:Meeting on a Train
description: "EACH OTHER" is an Israeli film about a friendship colored by something that only half-happens. Yola (Michal Bat-Adam) is on a train to Tel Aviv when she meets Anne (Brigitte Catillon), to whom she takes a very, very, very big shine. They begin to talk. They also begin to flirt. Anne eagerly accepts Yola's suggestion that they stay in adjoining rooms at the same hotel.Then Anne accepts another kind of invitation from Ilan, a security guard who works in the lobby. Yola, who hears more than she'd like to through Anne's door, becomes so jealous about the man that she makes an impetuous, expensive taxi trip to Jerusalem and back, all on a single night. Clearly, there's a great deal brewing between these two.What comes of it? Everything and nothing, in a film as simultaneously coy and earnest as "Each Other" turns out to be. Yola has a male lover, Avi (Assaf Dayan), who, while not averse to making love to both women, becomes unexpectedly straitlaced just as they are about to pounce on one another. Under pressure from this spoilsport, Yola and Anne desist  and when we see them years later, their love has endured and matured and lost many of its sexual overtones. Oh, they make a go at it, while Avi (whom Yola has married) is elsewhere. But the feeling has faded. The moment isn't quite right. Life goes on. Love is strange.Stranger still, some may feel, is the fact that Miss Bat-Adam, who plays Yola, also wrote and directed this story. "Each Other," which opens today at the Manhattan I theater, takes a smarmy, self-indulgent turn when Miss Bat-Adam executes a dance of sensual abandon (in a nightclub, as both Anne and Avi watch her with growing enthusiasm) before her own camera, or plays an explicit love scene.These episodes might not seem so jarring in the context of a film of broader scope, or a more generally animated performance. But Miss Bat-Adam presents Yola as a pensive, glum, rather distant character, one whose joyful impulses seem somewhat unexpected. And her film, which tries to address larger issues at times, remains teasingly fixated on the love affair.Miss Bat-Adam's direction, which is competent if unexceptional, involves some striking glimpses of Tel Aviv's tourist attractions, not to mention sunny scenery and local color. "Each Other" also achieves, very occasionally, that wistful quality of retrospection to which it evidently aspires. Miss Bat-Adam presents her story slowly, and without any exceptional vigor. But she and the other players are distinctive, if not particularly dynamic. Perhaps her film's leisurely mood and protestations of warmth will remind some viewers of how they spent a summer vacation.Miss Bat-Adam, whose directorial debut was produced by Moshe Mizrahi, has starred in several of Mr. Mizrahi's movies, among them "The House on Chelouche Street" and "I Love You, Rosa."

title: Events Today; Theater Films Music Dance
description: STRIDER, a play with music by Mark Rozovsky, adapted from a story by Leo Tolstoy. English stage version by Robert Kalfln and Steve Brown, based on a translation by Tamara Bering Sungurott; directed and staged by Robert Kaifin and Lynne GannewaY. At the Helen Haves Theater, 210 West 46th Street, 8.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Libby, McNeill & Libby Inc., Chicagobased food processor, has appointed Walter W. Keightley vice presidentfinance.

title: Economic Adjustment Seen in U.S.; O.E.C.D. Cites Needed Reverses
description: PARIS, Nov. 13  The United States is experiencing a difficult but necessary period of adjustment, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and

title: TV: All Quiet on the Western Front
description: By JOHN J. O'CONNOR

title: Natt, Jordan Star in 10182 Victory Getting to Know You Nets Defeat Hawks As Jordan, Natt Star We Moved the Ball Atlanta's Big 3 Terrible
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Nov.13  Just one day over a month since the National Basketball Association season started, the New Jersey Nets began their own campaign in earnest tonight, routing the Atlanta Hawks, 10182, in concerted manner they had not previously displayed. A crowd of 4,580 gathered at the Rutgers Athletic Center and finally had something to cheer about.

title: George Meany Describes Khomeini as a Madman
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13  Speaking from a wheelchair, George Meany today called Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini a madman and said of the Iranians who are holding Americans hostage. We have got to get the message to them that they can't treat our citizens that way.

title: Market Place; DeepinMoney Call Options
description: Robert Metz

title: Brother Joseph and Legal Right to Die; Catechism Is Recalled
description: MINEOLA, L.I. Nov. 13  In Brother Joe's small rooms at Chaminade High School, his chair is surrounded by cases of homemade root beer, cassette tapes of the Scriptures and science fiction novels sent him by the Xavier Society for the Blind, samples of the smooth calligraphic hand in which he penned names to the school's diplomas, and a picture of the auxiliary bishop of Baltimore he coached in high school basketball.

title: Soviet Lawmakers Fly to U.S.
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 13 (AP)  A delegation of members of the Supreme Soviet, or Parliament, left by air today for Washington, the press agency Tass said. The group is headed by Serge F. Medunov, first secretary of the Krasnodar regional committee of the Soviet Communist Party.

title: Key Members of Crisis Task Force in Washington; David D. Newsom; Harold H. Saunders; Henry Precht; Peter D. Constable
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13  The Iranian crisis has spawned a special working group in the State Department's seventhfloor operations center that isstaffed around the clock. Its centerpiece is a large conference table, with maps, a blackboard, source materials and files of the latest relevant information from Teheran and elsewhere.

title: College Attendance Rises
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UPI) College attendance has grown by onethird during this decade, largely because of a surge in the number of women seeking undergraduate and advanced degrees, a new Government survey showed yesterday.

title: Mrs. Nixon Reported Improved
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Nov. 14 (UPI)  Pat Nixon was reported in improved condition today at San Clemente General Hospital where she is being treated for bronchial pneumonia. Her husband, Richard M. Nixon, spent an hour with the former First Lady last night and 40 minutes this morning.

title: Rising Mortgage Rates Curbing the Mobility of Job Seekers
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 13  She was from Louisiana, not used to the manners, rhythms and tempo of the Northeast, and her blood pressure could not take Baltimore. The doctor said she would be better off in the South. So, like uncounted millions of Americans before them, John and Janell Kuban did not hesitate to move their household to another region when personal wellbeing seemed to dictate it.

title: L.I. Study Finds Solar Power Saves Most
description: A detailed study of conditions on Long Island has resulted in a conclusion that ordinary energy conservation measures and the use of solar energy could reduce dependence on imported oil and stimulate the American economy far more than constructing nuclear power plants.

title: Obituary 7  No Title
description: LAKENHyman. Beloved brother of Abraham and Irving. Member of Workman Circle Branch 3 and retired Fur Dresser. Services today Parkside Chapel, 10:30. 66 Ave & Queens Blvd, Forest Hills.

title: Indonesia Lifts Oil Price 11%
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 14 (AP)  Indonesia Is raising its price for some types of exported oil by about 11 percent to $23.50 a barrel, the Government said today. Indonesia is the seventh member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, to raise prices in recent weeks.

title: LAWMAKERS TO SEEK AN INQUIRY ON CRISIS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14  Once the Iranian crisis is over, members of Congress are saying, the Administration will have to answer some tough questions about the events leading up to the seizure of the United States Embassy in Teheran. Lawmakers also say that they will be demanding some form of retaliation against Iran, either diplomatic or military.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a translation error, a Reuters dispatch published in The Times on Sunday gave incorrect causes of death for 22 children in the Dominican Republic. The children died of measles and gastroenteritis.

title: House Revises Beef Imports
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP)  The House voted today to reverse present law and allow more foreign meat into the country when American supplies are tight and retail prices are rising.

title: Labor Facing Major Challenges As It Plans for Leadership Shift
description: Organized labor, once a young and zesty movement prideful of its workingclass ways, is now a middleclass institution facing major questions about its vigor and commitment.

title: Bent to Be 2d Play to Open at New Apollo
description: The New Apollo, where Bent starts previews next Monday night, is the first of three theaters on 42d Street between Broadway and Eighth Avenue to be converted from movie houses into legitimate theaters, with the entrances shifted to 43d Street. Plans to convertthe other two houses, the Lyric and the Selwyn, have been stalled, however, because the Brandt Organization, owner of the three theaters, has been unable to find bookings for them.

title: GARDENING Plant a Bulb Now And It'll Bloom At Christmastime
description: IF planted within the next few days, paperwhite narcissus will be in full bud by Dec. 23 and in perfect condition for gift giving. In the recipient's home, they will burst into cheerful and fragrant bloom. A single poinsettia surrounded by pots of paperwhite narcissus makes a festive display.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SHORE TO SHORE Starting this morning, a threeday celebration of the downtown Tribal Arts Gallery's 10th anniversay will feature African music and free delicacies, with discounts on ceremonial sculpture and handicrafts. The array of masks, statues and ritual objects ranges in price from $10 to $10,000 in the brownstone building at 84 East 10th Street. Store hours today are from 11 A.M. to 9 P.M., and until 6 tomorrow and Saturday.

title: Article 1  No Title
Swiss Bond Rates Rise
description: BERN, Nov. 14 (Reuters)  Switzerland said today that the interest rate on Federal mediumterm bonds would be increased. It said that the rate on fouryear bonds would be raised to 3.25 percent from 2.75 percent, and that the rate on eightyear bonds would go to 3.75 percent from 3.5 percent, effective immediately.

title: Action Disturbs Financial Circles
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19  Administration officials said today that Iranian assets in the United States had been frozen only to protect American financial claims against Iran. But the action immediately raised concern in international financial circles about the future willingness of foreigners to keep funds in American banks.

title: World Gold
description: WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 14, 1979

title: Open Oil Market Firm
description: Despite President Carter's decision to stop buying Iranian oil, prices for crude oil on the open market have held steady, according to oil brokers in New York.

title: Budget Director, Defending Carter, Warns of Political Easy Solutions
description: BEDFORD, N.H., Nov. 14 (AP)  The director of the Federal Office of Management and Budget defended President Carter's economic policies today, warning against the glib phrases and easy solutions of other politicians.

title: Problems for the Elderly
description: And, of course, not everyone who moves can count on corporate resources. The guy who suffers is the guy who changes jobs or whose company doesn't have a thirdparty plan for taking the old house off the employee's hands, said Nancy Sartain of Baxter and Swinford, one of Houston's largest realestate concerns.

title: Pianist: Gilels Plays Beethoven and Tchaikovsky
description: IT was with the Tchaikovsky B flat minor Piano Concerto that Emil Gilels introduced himself to New York in 1955. Last night, at the Pension Fund Benefit Concert of the New York Philharmonic, Mr. Gilelsplayed the popular concerto once again. If memory serves, he has not played it in this city since his imposing entrance 24 years ago.

title: Major League AllStars Defeat Japan on Homers
description: NISHINOMIYA, Japan, Nov. 14 (AP)  A team of American major league allstars rallied on home runs by Ted Simmons and Larry Bowa and edged the Japan AllStars, 65, today in the opener of a twogame series between the teams.

title: Proposed Mass Transit Projects
description: New York Projects

title: Home Improvement
description: MOST of today's wallpapers are not paper at all  they are wall coverings made of vinyl, or a vinylfaced paper or fabric. Most of these, available in a huge array of different patterns, styles and colors, are washable and stainresistant, andmany are also strippable  the material can be peeled off the wall without scraping when you want to remove it.

title: Judge Bids School Board End Queens Segregation.
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that New York City and community school officials were responsible for some, but not all, of the segregated school conditions in a school district in western Queens.

title: Astros, Not Yankees, Likely Ryan Choice
description: Nolan Ryan, a free agent with a blazing fastball and a redhot chance to become the highest paid player in baseball history, said yesterday he had decided which team he wanted to play for. His nod seemed to be pointing in the direction of the Houston Astros.

title: A Designer's Secret: Details, Details
description: WHO, these days, cares about detail? For one thing, who can afford it? For another, who has the time? Ours is a hurried world, with convenience the summum bonum, easy care the guiding principle. The dignity of craftsmanship has bowed to the imperative of efficiency.

title: TenDay Car Sales Down 26%
description: DETROIT, Nov. 14  The nation's Big Three auto makers reported today that their sales of new Americanmade cars plunged 26.7 percent in the first 10 days of November, with the Chrysler Corporation showing the steepest drop, of 43.4 percent. Sales at each of the three were more than 20 percent below yearearlier levels.

title: Carter Asks Allies to Limit Oil Imports From Iran
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14  The Carter Administration has asked major Western countries to demonstrate their support for the United States in the Iranian crisis by not expanding imports of oil from the Persian Gulf nation, Government officials said today.

title: Arafat Ends Brief Moscow Visit; Sees Gromyko but Not Brezhnev
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 14 (UPI)  Yasir Arafat, head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, left Moscow today without having met with Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, and apparently without discussions of the Iranian seizure of the United States Embassy.

title: Miss Meyers Agrees To Sign With Gems
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 14  Ann Meyers has agreed to sign a threeyear contract worth $130,000 with the New Jersey Gems of the Women's Basketball League, the team announced today.

title: Wounded Israeli Envoy in Lisbon Is Out of Danger, Hospital Says
description: LISBON, Nov. 14 (Reuters)  Ambassador Ephraim Eldar of Israel, wounded in a machinegun and grenade attack outside his embassy here yesterday, is out of danger after an operation, hospital officials said today.

title: ExBanker Gets Prison Sentence
description: ROCHESTER, Nov. 14 (AP)  Dean B. Griffis, a former vice president of the Red Creek National Bank in Wayne County, was sentenced yesterday to an 18month Federal prison term for misapplying 550,381 in bank lands in October 1975. Mr. Griffis, who is 49 years old, and Anthony Scalzo, 42, were arrested in connection with loans made for a ranch that Mr. Scalzo operated in Wayne County. Mr. Scalzo pleaded guilty to conspiracy to misapply funds and was given an 18month prison term in September.

title: Pro Athletes Join A.F.L.C.I.O.
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14  The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations granted a charter today to the Federation of Professional Athletes as its 105th affiliated union.

title: Soviet Union Buys More U.S. Wheat
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP)  The Soviet Union has bought 101,600 more metric tons of United States wheat for delivery in the coming year, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: OddEven Gas Order By Gov. Brown Vexes Dealers and Officials
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 14  Service station owners and some officials are disgruntled because Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. yesterday signed an order making mandatory the oddeven day restriction on gasoline sales that had been discarded by most of those California counties that took it up last spring on a voluntary basis.

title: Article 4  No Title
Pope's Personal Envoy in Britain Is Said to Gain Diplomatic Status
description: LONDON, Nov. 14 (AP)  The Pope's personal representative to the Roman Catholic Church in Britain is being given diplomatic rights as a first step toward establishing diplomatic relations between Britain and the Vatican, The Times of London reported.

title: Mine Union Leader in Hospital After Heart Attack
description: CHARLESTON, W.Va., Nov. 14 (AP)  Arnold R. Miller, president of the United Mine Workers of America, has been hospitalized here after suffering a heart attack. He entered the hospital Monday, after suffering pains in his chest while hunting, a hospital spokesman said.

title: Obituary 6  No Title
description: Death

title: I.T.T Posts Quarter Loss
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation reported yesterday a net loss of $137 million for the third quarter, compared with net income of $133.5 million, or 94 cents a share, in the same period last year.

title: When Parents Steal Their Own Children
description: AT the time of the divorce, a Michigan court decided that custody of 10yearold Allison and 6yearold Seth (not their real names) would go to their father. A year later, after a routine visit with their mother, Allison and Seth were not returned. Their mother had movedthem to a secret location in New York City where she then lived.

title: Hypnosis Said to Cast Doubts on Confession In Renee Katz Case
description: The man accused of pushing Renee Katz in front of a New York City subway train last June said under hypnosis that he confessed because the police forced me to say those things, according to a psychologist who hypnotized the suspect.

title: $455 Million Westchester Budget for 80 Includes Property Tax Cut
description: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 14  A $454.8 million Westchester County budget, providing for a property tax cut for a second consecutive year despite its record size, was proposed today by County Executive Alfred B. DelBello.

title: House Committee Links Fuel Use to Chrysler Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14  The House Banking Committee today voted, 30 to 7, to require the Chrysler Corporation to produce energysaving cars as a condition of receiving up to $1.5 billion in Federal loan guarantees.

title: Currency Trading In Turmoil
description: Currency markets were thrown into turmoil and gold gained in value yesterday after reports that Iran intended to withdraw its funds from banks in the United States were followed by President Carter's action to freeze those assets.

title: Vietnam Says Mrs. Carter's Visit Proves That U.S. Backs Pol Pot
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 19 (Reuters)  Vietnam said today that Rosalyrm Carter's recent visit to Thai refugee camps was evidence of the United States support for the routed Cambodian regime of Prime Minister Pol Pot and Foreign Minister leng Sary.

title: 2 Officials Disputing Whether New Zealand Has Radiation Fallout
description: WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Nov. 14 (AP)  The two authorities responsible for monitoring radiation levels in New Ze aland are at odds over whether or not the country is being subjected to fallout from a nuclear test.

title: Modern Cutler Rethinks His Craft
description: SHEFFIELD, ENGLAND COMING up the sweeping driveway Broom Hall, the great 18thcentury Georgian house, a visitor assumes that he has gotten lost, or is in the wrong place. But a glimpse inside confirms that this is a factory rather than a livedin manor house. Instead of polished period furniture there are immaculately kept machines. Instead of matrons sipping tea there are smocked workers producing cutlery by the English designer David Mellor.

title: Murphy Beds Spring Back Into Popularity
description: IN 1910, William Murphy's inlaws insisted that he do something civilized. So he gave up the reins to his sixhorse stagecoach in the Sierra Nevada and began making Murphy beds  to the delight of Buster Keaton and other silent movie slapsticks, who sometimes used the magical beds to torment their inlaws.

title: Stocks Rally for Modest Gain
description: The stock market made a moderate gain in continued light trading yesterday after an initial selloff that followed news of the freeze on Iranian assets in the United States.

title: A Conflict Over Trot Dates
description: A request by Roosevelt Raceway for one continuous sevenmonth meeting in 1980, which would conflict with the harnessracing season at New Jersey's Meadowlands, was presented yesterday to the State Racing and Wagering Board. Yonkers Raceway, on the other hand, asked four short meetings, alternating with Roosevelt. The board deferred a decision.

title: Rivalry Marks TV Bids in Atlantic City
description: An applicant for a license to operate a new television station in Atlantic City urged the Federal Communications Commission yesterday to dismiss a rival application by a group with casino interests.

title: New York City Donates $650,000 for S.I. Field
description: Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin turned over a $650,000 city check yesterday to the Staten Island Athletic and Recreation Alliance. The money, with $400,000 from the Staten Island War Memorial Association, will build an athletic field.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Money
description: WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 14, 1979

title: Citibank Branch Held Up
description: Police officers captured a man who used a starter's pistol to rob a Manhattan Citibank branch yesterday. The holdup man, identified as Charles Sullivan, 25years old, of 62 East 130th Street, was arrested two blocks away from the branch, at 1275 Madison Avenue a few minutes after the 9:30 A.M. robbery. The police said they had recovered all the loot, but had no immediate idea of how much had been taken.

title: Campaign Discussed As Carey and Carter Have Private Dinner
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14  Governor Carey, returning from a brief trip to France to promote economic interests for New York State, flew here this evening for an unpublicized private dinner with President Carter at the White House to discuss, among other things, the Presidential campaign.

title: City Finds Getting Tough On Traffic Really Works
description: If you promise them convenience, will New Yorkers use taxi stands? If you confront them with policing, will they give up driving on streets where they're not supposed to be?

title: Head of Psychiatric Center on Leave During Inquiry
description: As a result of allegations of misconduct uncovered in a monthlong state inquiry, the director of the Bronx Children's Psychiatric Center began a paid leave of absence yesterday pending completion of the investigation.

title: Books of The Times
description: HOWTO books that more or less resemble Albert J. Lowry's How You Can Become Financially Independent by Investing in Real Estate are published every week of the year. Normally, one yawns. But last month Ifound myself driving at 2:30 A.M. through a rainstorm in an unfamiliar city. Mr. Lowry was being interviewed on a radio talk show. Despite my being tired, lost and unable even to make out the street signs, I found myself completely riveted by what he was saying. It was not so much that he was explaining how anyone can purchase, say, a $60,000 apartment house without paying any money down, and immediately start earning over $3,000 annually though that was interesting enough, I'll have to admit. It was the absolute conviction with which he spoke, and the clarity and precision with which he kept rebutting all the Doubting Thomases who kept telephoning in. He seemed to be possessed by a vision.

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Rangers Late Goal Beats Wings, 32
description: If the New York Rangers were bothered by the 105 rout they suffered at Nassau Coliseum on Tuesday night, they certainly did not show it last night in Madison Square Garden.

title: U.S. to Join Industry in Talks on Auto Fuel Goals
description: DETROIT, Nov. 14  Secretary of Transportation Neil E. Goldschmidt said here today that within the next 30 days officials of his department and executives of the major automobile manufacturers plan a series of exploratory discussions on automobile fuel economy goals beyond 1985.

title: A.T.&T. Earnings Up 6.5%
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company had earnings of $4.25 billion, or $6.07 a share, for the first nine months of this year, up 6.5 percent from $3.987 billion, or $5.88 a share, in the same period last year, according to Charles L. Brown, chairman.

title: Cleveland Officials Predict Rise In City's Budget Deficit This Year
description: CLEVELAND, Nov. 14 (AP)  Despite a voterapproved 50 percent payroll tax rise this year, Cleveland officials say that the city will finish 1979 with an even bigger deficit than it had last year.

title: German Bonds Reissued
description: FRANKFURT, Nov. 14 (Reuters)  The West German central bank said today that Federal Government financing bonds with maturities of about one and two years would be reissued nextMonday with higher issue rates of 7.75 percent each. It said that the new rates compare with 5.65 percent previously for oneyear paper and 6.40 percent for twoyear bonds. It said that the yields would rise to 8.40 and 8.79 percent, respectively, from 5.99 and 7.09 percent.

title: Askew Warns of Curbs on Japan Car Sales
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14  Japan could face restrictions on car sales in the United States if it does not follow the European example and invest in a major automotive manufacturing operation here, Reubin 0. Askew, the special trade representative, warned in an interview.

title: Soderholm Is Cleared
description: The Yankees trade for Eric Soderholm was approved yesterday by the commissioner's office, but not necessarily for the three minor leaguers who originally were reported to be going to the Texas Rangers in the deal.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: A bright band of frontal clouds extends from northern New England to southern Florida. Broken cloudiness Is visible In New England, the central Appalachians, the lake region and the upper Mississippi Valley. Broken cloudiness also lingers over the Pacific Northwest. Clear skies cover the rest of the country.

title: Five Killed in Illinois House Fire
description: WASHINGTON PARK, Ill., Nov. 14 (AP)  Fire raged through a tworoom frame house today, killing four young children and a woman, the authoritiessaid. The dead were identified as Mary Saunders, 21 years old; Wesley, her 23monthold son; Leroy Moseley, her 4yearold stepson; Christoper McCann, 3, and Malisa McCann, 17 months. The cause of death was believed to be smoke inhalation.

title: ABROAD AT HOME Lowering The Gate
description: WASHINGTON  It is five years since Richard Nixon left the White House, forced to resign by the virtually unanimous, nonpartisan judgment of his constitutional peers in Congress. Has the meaning of that profound event already begun to dim? Arewe in danger of being seduced by the cynical notion that it signified nothing, that it was just politics?

title: U.S. Jump Team Extends Royal Winter Fair Lead
description: TORONTO, Nov. 14  Until this year, Val de Loire, an import by way of France and Spain, had been Melanie Smith's No. 1 open jumper. But the aged chestnut gelding has had to take a back seat to Miss Smith's newest mount, Calypso, for the last three months.

title: Lindsay Makes a Move To Toss Hat in the Ring
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP)  John V. Lindsay has taken the first official step toward becoming a candidate for the United States Senate from New York State next year, campaign aides said today. They said the 57yearoldformer New York City Mayor had sent a letter registering his fundraising committee with the Federal Elections Commission here, as required by law.

title: Geneen Plans to Resign As Chairman of I.T.T.
description: Harold S. Geneen, the $1.1millionayear board chairman of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, said yesterday that he would relinquish his post at the end of the year.

title: 10 Illegal Aliens Seized on Boat
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Nov. 14 (UPI)  Coast Guard officers investigating an apparently abandoned 25foot boat in the Intracoastal Waterway peeled back a tarpaulin on the deck today and found 10 Haitians who were trying to enter the country illegally. The eight men and two women were turned over to Border Patrol officials.

title: Rock: The 60's Reinvented
description: ALARGE and fascinating segment of the contemporary rock world is engaged in reinventing the music of the early and middle 1960's for an 80's audience, and it's a process that's a lot of fun to watch. One thing the new rock haslacked up to now is the sort of poporiented but toughvoiced women who scored occasional hits in the 60's. Deborah Harry of the group Blondie comes closest, but while she's a distinctive stylist, visually and musically, she isn't an exceptionally strong singer.

title: Koch Signs Bill to Aid Rebuilding
description: Mayor Koch signed into law yesterday a measure that provides tax benefits for owners who rehabilitate apartment buildings.

title: Counting on the Bishops
description: Putting aside the usual qualms, State wants Church to come to the aid of the country. The Census Bureau is groping for ways to avoid extensive undercounting among the poor, minorities and nationalities in the 1980 nationwide headcount. Now the bureau hasgone to the National Conference of Catholic Bishops, meeting in Washington this week. It has asked for help in persuading the public to cooperate with the census and in assuring people that Uncle Sam means it when he says that information gathered in the census will. be kept strictly confidential. We hope that the bishops are willing to help.

title: TV: Luxury Liner Is Hijacked . . . in 3 Installments
description: THE French Atlantic Affair, beginning a threepart run on ABCTV tonight at 9 o'clock, is one of those gigantic constructions held together with the glue of familiar faces and a plot so incredible as to be perversely fascinating. This particular luxuryliner concoction is part Voyage of the Damned, part Poseidon Adventure (Shelley Winters is on hand once again), and part Love Boat.

title: McEnroe Triumphs
description: LONDON, Nov. 14 (UPI)  John McEnroe, last year's winner, scored a 64, 61 victory over John Lloyd of England in the first round of the $175,000 Wembley Grand Prix tennis tournament tonight. But secondseeded Guillermo Vilas and fourthseeded Peter Fleming were eliminated.

title: Corporate Sales and Earnings Reports
description: For periods as shown.(N) Indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Talking Business with Rimmer DeVries of Morgan Guaranty
description: Concern about the stability of the international money markets is on the rise again as the system struggles to adjust to this year's 60 percent jump in oil prices and the continuing aftermath of the Iranian revolution. The huge surpluses generated for the oil producers by their spiraling energy prices will mean another explosive burst in the size of the Eurocurrency markets. Increasingly, the individuals close those markets are warning that the private banking system may not be able to handle the new stresses.

title: U.N. ASSEMBLY BIDS VIETNAMESE FORCES EVACUATE CAMBODIA
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 14 The General Assembly demanded overwhelmingly today that Vietnam withdraw its troops from Cambodia.

title: National Grange Elects Chief
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP)  Edward Anderson, a farmer from Waterloo, Neb., was elected today as master of the National Grange at the organization's annual meeting in Lancaster, Pa., according to the national office here. Mr. Anderson, 53 years old, succeeds John Scott, of Butler, Pa., as head of the nation's oldest farm organization. Russell Stauffer, of Springfield, Ill., was elected to succeed Mr. Anderson national overseer.

title: Monks at Sinai Cloister Bid Israelis Sour Goodbye
description: ST. CATHERINE'S MONASTERY, Mount Sinai, Nov. 9  In his long black cassock, the Greek Orthodox monk was saying a final goodbye to the Israeli official, who had come in his dungarees and khaki jacket through the vast wilderness of the Sinai desert into this remote, monastic sanctuary behind a fortress of thick stone walls.

title: All 25 Arab Mayors Resign to Protest Arrest by Israel
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 14  Any chance for a compromise on the Israeli order for deportation of a Palestinian Mayor evaporated today when Israel's Ministerial Defense Committee, composed of Prime Minister Menachem Begin and other top Cabinet members, ruled that the expulsion of the Nablus Mayor should go ahead as ordered.

title: The U.N. Today
A Convicted Child Molester Gets Term of 3 to 6 Years for Pimping
description: A man with two prior convictions for sexually abusing youngsters was sentenced yesterday to three to six years in prison for pimping for a 14yearold boy.

title: Design Notebook
description: A DEPARTMENT store is not like any other kind of retail space; it is not only bigger, it is deeper and wider. Its whole is more than the sum of its parts  it isnot merely an amalgam OT little shops, but a big place that, however broken up and subdivided into boutiques as it may be, has nonetheless a sense of totality.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Last May, when the Fairchild Camera and Instrument Corporation invited Schlumberger Ltd. to play the role of white knight in rescuing Fairchild from an unwelcome takeover attempt by Gould Inc., Wilfred J. Corrigan, Fairchild's 41yearold president, had an inkling that not everyone would be living happily ever after.

title: The Region
description: The Unification Church filed a suit yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan asking $3 million in damages against the Town of New Castle in northern Westchester County. It charged delays on its efforts to get a permit to use a 97acre estate it bought from a Roman Catholic order.

title: Market Place
description: IN recent weeks, the moneymarket funds have been inundated, as people have withdrawn money from savings accounts and sought the generally higher returns the money funds provide. Some 75 funds now have $39.7 billion on deposit, rivaling the assets of the equity funds.

title: Hers
description: WHEN I heard that Dick Clark had taken post in the Kennedy campaign, I got so excited. Not only might Camelot be regrouping, but there'd be a good shot that Dion and The Belmonts would, too. I pictured Joanand Ted, happily reconciled, doing the Hully Gully while the former host of American Bandstand tried to unload freebie rock albums on Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. and Allard K. Lowenstein. Boy, was I grateful to the television newscaster who identified Dick Clark as a former Senator from Iowa before I'd embarrassed myself.

title: Anastasio Role Topic of Review At Scotto Trial
description: The jury in the trial of Anthony M. Scotto, on the fourth day of deliberations, focused most of its attention yesterday on the codefendant in the case, Anthony Anastasio.

title: Hundreds Reported Killed as Earthquake Strikes Iran
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 14 (UPI)  A powerful earthquake ripped through 14 mudbrick villages in northeastern Iran today and killed at least 248 persons, most of them in their sleep, relief officials renorted.

title: Entertainment Events
description: THE MICHIGAN, by Dan Owens; directed by Dean Irby; starring Douglas Turner Ward and Hattie Winston; presented by the Negro Ensemble Company, St. Marks Playhouse, 133 Second Avenue, $.

title: Mississippi Youth, 16, Is Charged With Slaying of Greenville Priest
description: GREENVILLE, Miss., Nov. 14 (AP)  A 16yearold Greenville youth was ordered held without bond today on charges that he murdered the Rev. Eugene Chatagnier, a Roman Catholic priest who was found earlier in the week shot three times.

title: Complaints of Abuses By Pension Programs Bring Abrams Inquiry
description: Robert Abrams, the New York State Attorney General, announced yesterday an investigation into abuses in the $100 billion in pension plan programs that cover seven million workers in the state. A public hearing has been scheduled for Dec. 13.

title: Bernstein Leads Viennese
description: The Vienna Philharmonic played Beethoven's Ninth Symphony last night at Carnegie Hall under the direction of Leonard Bernstein. This concert was reviewed by Harold C. Schonberg when it was performed at Kennedy Center on Oct. 29. Mr. Schonberg said, This performance simply pulsated with life.

title: CHASE BANK SILENT ON IRAN STATEMENT
description: A spokesman for the Chase Manhattan Bank yesterday declined to comment on the statement by Iran's foreign policy director, Abolhassan BaniSadr, that Iran was justified in withdrawing funds from American banks on the ground that banking interests led by Chase Manhattan and its chairman, David Rockefeller, were responsible for the admission of the Shah to the United States.

title: Appeals Court Upholds Conviction of Rep. Diggs
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP)  A Federal appeals court today upheld the conviction of Representative Charles C. Diggs Jr. on charges that he took kickbacks from staff members and had Government paychecks issued to persons who handled his personal affairs.

title: Problems Grow With Ridership
description: As ridership on commuter lines continue to rise, a trend attributed partly to fears of yet another gasoline shortage, service problems appear to have increased, too. Following figures show ridership increases and ontime performances of rail lines in New York and New Jersey, as well as traffic on bridge and tunnel crossings in the metropolitan area.

title: Article 6  No Title
Rail Riders Doubt Bond Issue Will Help
description: When the 6:46 train from Brewster, N.Y., pulled into Grand Central Terminal at 8:22, more or less as scheduled yesterday morning, some commuters aboard credited their timely arrival to an act of Providence. It could not be improved service on Conrail's Harlem Division line, they reasoned.

title: BRITAIN CONSIDERING CUT IN IMMIGRATION
description: LONDON, Nov. 14  The Government today proposed a tightening of the rules on immigration that would significantly reduce the number of nonwhite people moving to Britain.

title: Razing of One Skyscraper to Build 3 New Ones Proposed in Times Sq.
description: A revised urban renewal plan to redevelop 42d Street at Times Square recommends demolishing the wedgeshaped skyscraper known as One Times Square. The building was formerly the Times Tower and then the Allied Chemical Building.

title: Chevrolet Brake Plant Is Struck
description: SAGINAW, Mich., Nov. 14 (AP) About 1,850 workers struck a Chevrolet brake plant of the General Motors Corporation over local issues today. It was thefourth strike over local issues since the United Automobile Workers and the cornpany agreed to a national contract on Sept. 14. The three others have been settled. Rudolph Nagel, president of Local 467, said that a principal reason for the strike was commitments made to us a year ago March on health and safety issues such as noise, dust and cleaning the electric trucks used in the plant.

title: New Course Set for Shah's U.S. Foundation
description: Two years ago, Manoucher Shafie, an Iranianborn house builder from upstate New York, joined antiShah demonstrators who had gathered outside the White House while Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi was visiting President Carter.

title: Dividends
description: WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 14, 1979

title: Electronic Games A Big Winner For the Holidays
description: Bolted securely to counter tops or locked away in display cases in department stores across the land, this year's galaxy of 120 or so electronic toys and games is tantalizing Christmasminded youngsters, taxing their parents pocketbooks and bedazzling a toy industry that has somehow stumbled onto a $500 million bonanza.

title: Parents Sue Over 3 Deaths in Wilderness Program
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 14  Parents of three young people who lost their lives while participating in wilderness training programs have charged in civil suits that the organization conducting the training, Outward Bound, was negligent in challenging the students to undertake situations beyond their capabilities without adequate safety precautions.

title: Bridge:
description: A great many tournament players are convinced, Beyond reach of argument, that the computer that deals the cards in many events is out to get them. Whenever trumps are bunched in one hand or somebody has an eightcard suit, the computer gets the blame.

title: STARVING PEASANTS CAMP IN PHNOM PENH
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Nov. 12About 30 hungry and exhausted people are camping on the bare floor of a small band pavilion in a park in the center of the city. They just arrived, and they do not know when they are going on.

title: Recital: Lieder by Berry
description: WALTER BERRY is a veteran member of the Vienna State Opera and hence has been in this country during the company's visit to Washington and, more vestigially, New York. Tuesday night Mr. Berry took time off for a lieder recital at the 92d Street Y, a recital that was full of sturdy competence and good intentions and wound up sounding rather perfunctory.

title: Big Oil Price Increase. Because of Iran Cutoff Regarded as Unlikely
description: New York City's Commissioner of Consumer Affairs said yesterday that the cutoff of Iranian oil would not justify substantial increases in gasoline or heating oil prices. He envisioned probable rises of 1 or 2 percent.

title: Lawyer for Justice Dept. Denies Lance Indictment Was Held Up
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 14 (AP)  The lawyer who headed the Justice Department's investigation of Bert Lance has denied that the bank fraud indictment was held back several months to gain a tactical advantage at the trial of Mr. Lance, former director of the Office of Management and Budget.

title: Assembly Text On Cambodia
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 14 Following is the text of the United Nations resolution calling on Vietnam to withdraw its troops from Cambodia, whose traditional name is Kampuchea:

title: Still, Jonestownism Runs On
description: We have had a year now to digest the horror of the People's Temple massacre in Guyana: the battered washtub of lethal fruit punch, the 900 colorfully clad bodies. The images remain indelible, but apparently the national concern they produced was shortlived.

title: U.S. Steel In Chemical Expansion
description: The United States Steel Corporation, which has been expanding its chemical business, has made another major move in that area by signing a letter of intent with Texaco Inc. to produce and market highdensity polyethylene, the steelmaker announced yesterday.

title: Lasker Medical Research Prizes Go to 2 Americans and a Briton
description: Research on the chemistry of life and the functioning of the human brain was honored yesterday when the 1979 Albert Lasker Medical Research Awards were won by two Americans and a British scientist.

title: Concern Is Expressed by U.S. Bankers
description: President Carter's decision yesterday to freeze Iranian Government accounts in American banks caught most of the nation's bankers off guard. Many privately expressed concern that the move might harm the international banking and payments systems.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Most Bond Prices Decline Moderately
description: The credit markets, confused by the uncertainty of Iranian developments, traded with great volatility yesterday and closed with most prices moderately lower than on Tuesday.

title: Parents Join School Officials In Drive Against More Cuts
description: Angered by the prospect of additional cuts in the school budget, parents, teachers, principals and community school boards have joined ranks to exert pressure on elected officials in what they say is their battle to save the city's schools.

title: Campaign Letter Angers Conservative L.I. Parties
description: HUNTINGTON, L.I., Nov. 12  A letter mailed to members of Jewish organizations here the weekend before Election Day by a prominent town Democrat attempted to discourage voting for candidates of the antiabortion Right to Life Party and the Conservative Party on ethnic and religious grounds and by a reference to the Holocaust.

title: Swedish Journalist to Take Over As Amnesty International Leader
description: LONDON, Nov. 14 (Reuters)  Amnesty International, the Londonbased international human rights organization, announced today that Thomas Hammarberg, a Swedish journalist, will become its secretary general next July.

title: I.C.C. to Query Pulp Surcharge
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19 (AP) The Interstate Commerce Commission plans to investigate a $280 freight surcharge that is being imposed by Conrail on shipments of pulp, fiberboard and paperboard from the South to Northern manufacturers of corrugated paper products.

title: House Approves Loan Plan to Aid Depressed Areas
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14  The House of Representatives tonight approved legislation to provide $5.9 billion in loans, loan guarantees and other fiscal assistance for companies in economically distressed areas.

title: Refugee Tells a Congresswoman He Saw Vietnam Use Poison Gas
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP)  Representative Millicent Fenwick, Republican of New Jersey, said today that a Laotian refugee told her he witnessed poison gas being used by Vietnamese forces in Laos.

title: Obituary 3  No Title
description: Deaths

title: For the Whites of Rhodesia, Smith Is a Fallen Idol
description: SALISBURY, Zimbabwe Rhodesia, Nov. 12  Time was when all but a small minority of Rhodesian whites felt Ian D. Smith could do no wrong. No longer.

title: IRAN DEFENDS MOVE TO WITHDRAW FUNDS
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 14  In announcing that it intended to withdraw its funds from American banks and their overseas branches, Iran declared today that the move was justified on the ground that banking interests were responsible for the admission of the deposed Shah to the United States.

title: British Let Ultimatum Pass at Rhodesian Conference
description: LONDON, Nov. 14  Another deadline in the 10weekold talks on the political future of Zimbabwe Rhodesia slipped by without a decision today, but there were signs of significant behindthescenes progress.

title: Transit, Not Westway
description: The signal given to Governor Carey in last week's election is that the rescue and revival of the city's steadily deteriorating masstransit system is a top priority for New York City voters.

title: CARTER TO SEEK AID FOR SPACE SHUTTLE
description: President Carter assured space agency officials yesterday of his full support for the manned space shuttle and his intention to ask Congress for additional funds to help prevent further delays in the troubled multibilliondollar project.

title: About Westfield
description: WESTFIELD, N.J., Nov. 11  New Jersey for many is the commuter state, with all roads leading to the Romes that are New York or Philadelphia or points south. With so many largescale railroads running through, it seemed a logical place to see many smallscaletrains on display at the Ninth Annual Model Railroad Hobby Show, an event that turned the National Guard Armory in this Union County community into a Grand Central of miniaturization.

title: Price for Kennedy's Quick Entry Into Campaign Was a Ragged Start
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14  Senator Edward M. Kennedy has paid a price for accelerating his campaign timetable to gain control over the sprawling Draft Kennedy movement and catch up with President Carter's head start in organization, some Kennedy partisans concede, and that price is a somewhat ragged entry into his formal campaign.

title: Perkins Wants Bucs To Keep Guessing
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 14  When Ray Perkins reaches a turning point against the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, he tries to make it as difficult as possible for John McKay to know which way he is headed.

title: Modern Museum, 50, Has a 20's Party
description: THE party Tuesday evening was to celebrate the opening of Art of the Twenties, and many of the guests were as illustrious as the artists in the show at the Museum of Modern Art. And when the hosts for a party are Blanchette Rockefeller, Richard Oldenburg and Paul Elicker, that's only to be expected.

title: Nostalgia to Disco In Styles for Sheets
description: WHILE many consumers are still trying to make up their minds how to make up their beds, a whole range of new sheet patterns are being presented this week and some of them will be in the stores next spring.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: AKRON, Ohio, Nov. 19 (UPI)  The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company said today that it would realign and discontinue some European production and marketing operations at a cost of $67 million.

title: WoodBurning Stoves: The Danger Factor
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (UPI)  Are woodburning devices more dangerous for home heating than gas, oil or electric units? Some insurance in. dustry reports seem to suggest that they are. But a United States Department of Energy official said that no one really knows at this point.

title: U.S. Cites 4 On Oil Pricing
description: The Energy Department said yesterday that it had begun an enforcement action against four major oil companies for possible price overcharges in violation of Federal controls on petroleum products.

title: BeltTightening Planned by Ford
description: DEARBORN, Mich., Nov. 14 Philip Caldwell, president and chief executive officer of the Ford Motor Company, has spelled out some unpleasant news to salaried employees in the November issues of Ford World, the salaried employees newsletter.

title: Home Beat
description: IF New Country Gear has its way, there will be a new American Revolution afoot. Bettye Martin, president; Raymond Waites, creative vice president and designer, and Judy Garb, marketing vice president, have put together an enviable if carefully studied collection of household items based on a countrified theme. Country meansAmerican, not rural, said Miss Martin, who started the company two years ago with $8,000, a borrowed conference room and two people. The other person was Mr. Waites, who had just returned from Europe. A new coziness, a new warmth was needed in contemporary design, he said, adding: This is an emotional, not an intellectual statement. We also wanted to add a little humor to the Shaker tradition. He was referring to the small prints and subtle geometries, all in muted, natureinspired colors that had been spread across products ranging from sheets and towels to fabrics and wall coverings, paint, pot holders, shower curtains, soap and laundry bags. We feel this is not in and out fashion, but an evolving design statement, Miss Garb said. But it takes a lot of work, organization and marketing ability to achieve a look that is simple, with just the right touch of innocence. The New Country Gear collection will be available at Macy's and Bamberger's in midMarch.

title: Former SS Colonel Held In Murder of 105 in War
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Nov. 14 (Reuters)  The police have arrested a former colonel in the Nazi SS, or special police, on suspicion of wartime murders of civilians in the Soviet Union, Bavarian justice authorities said today.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Order on Iranian Assets
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14  Following are the text of an executive order issued by the White House freezing Iranian assets in the United States and the text of a statement issued by Jody Powell, the White House press secretary, announcing the move.

title: 5 Killed in Bombay Train Crash
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 14 (UPI)  Two trains collided today in Matunga, a suburb of Bombay, killing five people and injuring 50, officials said.

title: Article 2  No Title
Jersey Customs Chief Suspended
description: The area director for the United States Customs Service in New Jersey has been suspended following a monthlong investigation into allegations of kickbacks and illegal payoffs to allow cargo to enter the United States duty free, a spokesman for the Customs Service said yesterday.

title: Mets Staff TOM Sale Likely
