description: The frontoffice staff of the New York Mets has been told what the public already surmised: that the club probably would be sold, but that there was no rush to sell and the sifting of offers would take time.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: RCA's Tender For C.I.T.
description: The RCA Corporation said yesterday that about 17.5 million shares of common stock of the C.I.T. Financial Corporation had been tendered in response to an RCA offer of $65 a share, which expired yesterday.

title: EARNINGS Rockwell's Profit Up 53.3% for Quarter
description: Rockwell International Corporation, a leading diversified company serving commercial and aerospace markets, reported yesterday that its net income for the fourth fiscal quarter ended Sept. 30 increased 53.3 percent on a sales gain of 16.7 percent.

title: Around the Nation
description: GREENSBORO, N.C., Nov. 14 (AP)Hearings will be held next Tuesday to determine if there is enough evidence to bring to trial 14 men charged in the shooting deaths of five leftists at a demonstration against the Ku Klux Klan.

title: RCA Picks a President
description: The RCA Corporation, after a twoyear search, yesterday named Maurice R. Valente, a wellregarded executive vice president of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, to be president and chief operating officer.

title: In Rout, Goalie Suffers the Most
description: Goalies always seem to take the brunt of a poor team effort. They are the ones that stand out when the red light goes on behind them. Everyone suddenly forgets how the forward did not go back to check or how the defenseman allowed the shooter to skate around him. Two Quick red lights andthe booing begins. It happens to a Doug Soetaert, who is the Rangers No. 1 goalie for the time being, and it happens to a Ken Dryden, who won the Vezina Trophy last season as the league's best goalie and then retired from hockey.

title: Duncan Spencer, Officer Of Fiduciary Trust Co.
description: Duncan M. Spencer, honorary chairman of the Fiduciary Trust Company of New York, died Saturday at his home in Manhattan at the age of 82.

title: Piecing Together Shattered Glass
description: THERE is an F. Scott Fitzgerald short story in which the smashing of a cutglass bowl foreshadows, and ultimately results in, the shattering of all happiness in the family. Crystal's fragile qualityhas often served as a symbol for personal dreams and ambitions.

title: Seoul Becomes Partner In U.S. Economic Talks
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 13  The United States has quietly welcomed South Korea into the exclusive group of industrial nations with which it consults annually on major economic policy developments.

title: Arabs Facing New Doubts on Investment of Oil Money
description: LONDON, Nov. 14  President Carter's decision to freeze official Iranian assets in the United States will force other major oil exporters to reconsider the wisdom of accumulating their surplus funds in Western economies and almost certainly strengthen the hand of those producers wno are caning tor production cutbacks, according to Arab banking and oil experts in London and Paris.

title: Goltz to Sign With Dodgers
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 14 (UPI)  The Los Angeles Dodgers came to terms today with Dave Goltz, a freeagent pitcher who was one of the most soughtafter players in the majorleague reentry draft this year.

title: U.S. Seems to Be Winning U.N. Delay
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 14 American diplomats were waging a successful campaign here today to put off a Security Council meeting requested by Iran until the hostages in Teheran are freed.

title: House Votes for a Takeover by City Of Old Army Terminal in Brooklyn
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14  The House of Representatives approved a measure today that would allow New York City to take title to the abandoned Brooklyn Army Terminal and turn it into an industrial park that could provide thousands of jobs.

title: Iran's Students in the U.S. Feel Disquiet and Disunity
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14  Staring into her coffee cup a few blocks from the White House, an Iranianborn student named Shahrzad tries to summarize the point she finds Americans have been missing through the days of the siege of the United States Embassy in Teheran: Imagine the reaction if the United States had taken in Eichmann  that's how Iranians felt when you took in the Shah.

title: Obituary 9  No Title
description: FRANCIS (MOOSE) GOHEEN

title: Capitals Release Belisle
description: LANDOVER, Md., Nov. 14 (UPI) The Washington Capitals released their coach, Danny Belisle, today and replaced him with Gary Green, coach of the National Hockey League club's Hershey affiliate.

title: New Bank of France Chief
description: PARIS, Nov. 19 (AP)  The French Government today appointed Renaud de la Geniere as the new governor of the Bank of France for a fiveyear period. He has been deputy governor of the bank since 1974 and will replace Bernard Clappier, who is retiring.

title: Pop: Maxene Andrews
description: AFTER all those years singing harmony in the Andrews Sisters razzledazzle arrangements, it now turns out that Maxene Andrews's real forte is as a ballad singer. At Reno Sweeney, whereMiss Andrews is appearing this week and next on her own, not as a sister, the warm, outgoing quality of her voice and its belllike purity give a fresh glow to Remember, as well as dark colors for a torchy I Wanna Be Loved. These are songs that were outside the Andrews Sisters lively hubbahubbahubba repertory. But Miss Andrews does not neglect the songs she did with her sisters. Her performance is basically a survey of the sisters singing career, from the hitt song they sang together (a version of Dinah that reveals the early influence of the Boswell Sisters) through their records, radio performances (with Bing Crosby) and films (with Carmen Miranda), winding up with Where Did the Good Times Go?, a song from their 1974 musical Over Here, which Miss Andrews sings against a montage of pictures of the sisters that supplements her musical biography.

title: Effort to Jail Mrs. Gandhi Adds Spice to Election Race
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 14  With India's election campaign barely under way, Indira Gandhi, the presumed frontrunner, has raised the alarm that the present caretaker Government is pressing for her speedy conviction in pending court cases in the hope of having her disqualified from the race.

title: Ballet: Sonate Scarlatti By Martins in Premiere
description: PETER MARTINS'S new ballet, seen for the first time in the New York State Theater at Tuesday night's opening of the New York City Ballet, dazzles the mind with a brilliance that immediately confirms his very recent promise as a choreographer.

title: William Arbogast Dead
description: William F. Arbogast, a former correspondent for The Associated Press, died Tuesday. He was 71 years old and a resident of Alexandria, Va.

title: World News Briefs
description: MISSISSAUGA, Ontario, Nov. 14 (AP)  The majority of the people in this city of 276,000 have been allowed to return home, but 75,000 were warned to stay away for a third night because there was still a danger of gas explosions from the derailment that caused the biggest evacuation in Canadian history.

title: China Dissident Likens Present to the Repressive Past
description: PEKING, Nov. 14  A transcript of the trial of Wei Jingsheng, the dissident, quotes him as having said that, if a citizen cannot criticize the leaders, China today is little different from what it was in the Cultural Revolution when the Gang of Four, the now discredited radicals, ruled the country.

title: Reagan: Oblivious to Iran?
description: Ronald Reagan was wellprepared for the flurry of activity this week over his formal announcement that he is running for President. But there were some things he hadn't thought of.

title: Brother Joseph Termed In Coma Permanently
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Nov.14  Two physicians testified at a hearing in State Supreme Court here today that Brother Joseph Charles Fox was permanently in a coma that leaves him with only vegetative functions. Two of his fellowsin the Marianist community testified before Justice Robert Meade that Brother Joseph had agreed with the Roman Catholic Church's position that extraordinary means, such as respirators, need not be used to preserve life.

title: A Trial Recalls An Old Reality: Cash in Politics
description: A political campaign organizer, reflecting this week on the prolonged drama of Anthony M. Scotto's Federal trial on racketeering charges, recalled with fond nostalgia the time not so long ago when cash contributions flowed with uninhibited ease into campaign coffers in New York. Few gave such frequently illegal money a second thought.

title: Reagan Bars Debate With Rivals For Fear of Dividing the G.O.P.
description: MANCHESTER, N.H., Nov. 14  Ronald Reagan today ruled out participating in public debates or other joint appearances with the nine other candidates who are competing with him for the 1980 Republican Presidential nomination.

title: French News Agency's Reporter Gains Cabanes Journalism Prize
description: PARIS, Nov. 14 (Reuters)  JeanPierre Gallois, Hanoi bureau chief of Agence FrancePresse, the French news agency, received the 1979 Bernard J. Cabanes Prize for journalism today for a series of articles he wrote from Cambodia after the Vietnameseled invasion that ousted Prime Minister Pol Pot.

title: The City
description: The trustees of a Lower East Side synagogue did not have the right to sell the building to a Buddhist group, Justice Martin Stecher ruled yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan. He ordered that a trial be started to determine if the $180,000 sale should be set aside.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Wednesday, Nov. 14, 1979

title: Texas Senators Call for an End To Training Iranian Pilots in U.S.
description: DALLAS, Nov. 14 (Reuters)  Both Texas Senators have called for an immediate end to training of Iranian Air Force pilots in the United States.

title: Stage: Eulo's Frankenstein Affair Monster Mash
description: LATE in the second act of The Frankenstein Affair, the monster  a tall, gray creature that looks as if he had been dipped in latex  returns to Dr. Frankenstein's laboratory and groans mournfully to his creator, Make . . . me . . . happy. Actually, he wants the doctor to make him a lady monster. The doctor refuses.

title: BBC to Retain Overseas Programs As Mrs. Thatcher Yields on Cuts
description: LONDON, Nov. 14  The Conservative Government of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher yielded last night to protests at home and abroad against its plan to cut more than $5 million from spending on the British Broadcasting Corporation's foreignlanguage services.

title: Carter's Strategy on Iran
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19  President Carter's predawn move to block Iranian assets in American banks was part of a strategy of graduated response adopted by the Administration in an effort to project a tough posture without jeopardizing the lives of the hostages in Teheran.

title: Moscow Is Said to Arrest Son of Viktor Korchnoi
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 14 (Reuters)  The 20yearold son of Viktor Korchnoi, the Soviet chess grandmaster who defected five years ago, has been arrested in Moscow after a year in hiding to avoid conscription into the armed forces, his mother said today.

title: Administration Denies Pressing Shah to Leave
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14  The State Department denied tonight an NBC News report that the Administration was aware of plans for the Shah to leave the country in 10 days and that it was pressing him to do so.

title: Aide to Carter Questions Byrne Gift to Kennedy
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 14 (AP)  The head of President Carter's campaign in Illinois says that a $5,000 contribution by Mayor Jane M. Byrne of Chicago to the campaign of Senator Edward M. Kennedy might be illegal.

title: Maj. Gen. Ernest N. Harmon, 85
description: Maj. Gen. Ernest N. Harmon, a World War I cavalry officer who became one of the Army's most daring and aggressive armored division commanders in World War II, died Tuesday at the Veterans Administration Hospital in White River Junction, Vt. He was 85 years old.

title: International
description: BUSINESS Digest

title: Stage: Gent's Balcony
description: RICHARD SCHECHNER'S Performance Group is devoted to environmental theater; when we go to the Performing Garage we can expect to be involved in the action. Sometimes the environmentalapproach seems to run counter to the best interest of the work itself  as in Mr. Schechner's production of The Tooth of Crime  but Jean Genet's The Balcony, which opened Saturday, would seem to be a suitable subject for Schechnerization.

title: Norway's Parliament Now Controls the Banks
description: OSLO  Should Congress try to make big United States banks more responsive to the people's will by appointing the chairman and directors itself, instead of letting shareholders elect them?

title: Green Line Resumes Sunday
description: Service on the Green Bus Line will resume Sunday morning after a 17week strike, a company representative said yesterday. The line's 200 buses serve south Queens. Drivers and mechanics for the line, which carries approximately 100,000 Queens riders daily, walked off the job July 1 over the issues of salary and costofliving adjustments. The union ratified a new contract on Nov. 9.

title: Obituary 5  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Q&A
description: Q. there were small cork disks under a sheet of heavy glass covering our mahogany coffee table. The disks left visible marks on the table's surface. Rubbing with paste wax did not get them off. Is there any simple way you can suggest?  K.S.A., Bronxville, N.Y.

title: Campaign for Memphis Mayoralty That Had Racial Overtones Ends With Vote Today
description: MEMPHIS, Nov. 13  When a cross was burned on the frosty lawn at W. Otis Higgs's home this week and a stone was thrown through the front window, the campaign chairman for Mayor Wyeth Chandler questioned whether the black challenger had brought it on himself with campaign literature that forecast the possibility of a black victory here Thursday.

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE
description: TUBULAR metal bed guardrails, made to be tucked between a mattress and a box spring, are designed to keep children from falling out of bed. While useful as such, there is also a decorative use for these rails. They can easily be used to make a bed look like a couch or a daybed. The guardrails come in two sizes: 38 inches long by 15 inches high, and a larger size that expands from 40 to 70 inches and is also 15 inches high. The rails are tan but can easily be spraypainted another color.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Obituary 4  No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO 3543900 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. FOR WEEKDAY EDITIONS. UNTIL 2:30 P.M. ON SATURDAY FOR SUNDAY EDITION. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY; NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900; WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES(914) WHITE PLAINS 95300; NASSAU CO. (516) 7470500; SUFFOLK CO. (516) 6691800; CONNECTICUT (203) ??487767.

title: Gulf to Reduce Oil for Japan
description: By The Associated Press

title: 2 Nations Are Cool to Reagan Plan
description: Officials in Canada and Mexico reacted without enthusiasm yesterday to Ronald Reagan's proposal for a North American accord.

title: Sanitation Dept. Girding to Meet Snow Challenge
description: New York City's Sanitation Department is marshaling its flotilla of plows, salt spreaders and manpower to minimize the impact of the winter's first snowfall.

title: CBS Raises Dividend
description: CBS Inc. said yesterday that it had increased its quarterly dividend to 70 cents a share from 65 cents, payable Dec. 14 to shareholders of record Nov. 30.

title: Excerpts From Peking Trial Transcript
description: PEKING, Nov. 14  Following are translated excerpts from a transcript of the indictment against Wei Jingsheng, editor of the Chinese dissident journal Explorations, as read by the prosecutor, Gao Wenyu, in the Peking Intermediate People's Court on Oct. 16, and of Mr. Wei's defense. The transcript was published by the underground journal Fifth of April Forum and sold at Democracy Wall.

title: Obituary 8  No Title
description: MARIE GREEN

title: Even at 7%, California Bonds Drag
description: California sold $150 million of tripleA bonds yesterday that were priced to yield as much as 7 percent, the highest rate of return on topquality state bonds available to investors since 1970. Even with their rare yields, however, the bonds did not sell rapidly. About $90 million of them remained unsold at the end of the day.

title: Sound
description: WITH all the bells and whistles and newfangled gadgetry festooning the fancier tape recorders these days, it's getting harder and harder to tell the frills from the real improvements. Besides, one man's frill is another's necessity, so where can you draw the line?

title: New Carbide Plant
description: The Union Carbide Corporation announced that it would build a multimilliondollar airseparation plant in Brownsville, Tex. The facility will produce 1,500 tons of oxygen daily, 1,320 tons of nitrogen and 68 tons of argon. The construction is scheduled to be completed in the third quarter of 1981.

title: Irish Premier and Waldheim Meet On Dublin Peace Unit in Lebanon
description: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 14 (Reuters)  Prime Minister John Lynch of Ireland, in the United States for discussions with Administration officials, met Secretary General Kurt Waldheim today for talks on Lebanon. He was accompanied by the Irish Foreign Minister, Michael O'Kennedy, and Ireland's representative at the United Nations, Paul Keating.

title: Notes on People
description: A quick look around the packed Board of Estimate chambers in City Hall yesterday was all one needed to get an idea of Lewis Rudin's influence in New York.

title: New Method to Preserve Foods
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (UPI)Scientists at the University of Maryland have developed a new method to preserve raw or partly processed foods that is substantially more energyefficient than canning or freezing.

title: Ballet: The Pennsylvania
description: THE Pennsylvania Ballet opened its fall season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Tuesday with a nice balance of youthful high spirits, froth and knotty NeoClassicism.

title: ESSAY To Restabilize Iran
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14  When one nation deliberately infringes on the sovereignty of another, and seizes prisoners in the bargain, that is by definition an act of war.

title: Arab Businessmen Assert Freeze Will Hurt Trade, Weaken Dollar
description: Spokesmen for Arab businessmen with billions of dollars invested in this country said yesterday that President Carter's freeze on Iranian assets would hurt United StatesArab economic relations and weaken the oil producers commitment to the dollar.

title: Repairing the Pothole Law
description: New York's City Council will decide today whether to make it harder to sue the city for injuries from potholes and cracks in streets, sidewalks and other municipally owned pavement. Mayor Koch has become passionate on the subject. He is vigorously pressing bill that would block pothole suits unless the city government has received written notice of the damaging defect 15 days before an accident.

title: Ramsey Clark Ending Attempt to Reach Iran
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (UPI) Former Attorney General Ramsey Clark, sent last week by President Carter to seek the release of American hostages in Teheran, was recalled to Washington tonight without ever having reached Iran.

title: U.N. SESSION AVERTED
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14  The United States froze all official Iranian assets in American banks today, only hours after Iran announced that it planned to withdraw billions of dollars in funds from this country and transfer them to other ones.

title: Bent to Dramatize LittleTold Nazi Horror
description: FOUR or five years ago, Martin Sherman was saying, he had even stopped fantasizing about getting one of his plays produced on Broadway. He had been at it fulltime for 12 years, his works had been produced in workshops, at university theaters, Off Off Broadway and even once, disastrously, Off Broadway, but the bigtime seemed farther away than ever.

title: Volcano Erupts in Galpagos
description: QUITO, Ecuador, Nov. 14 (UPI)  A volcano on Isabela Island in the Galpagos archipelago began spouting lava and volcanic ash yesterday, forcing the evacuation of residents of the area to Puerto Villamil, the island's main town. There were no immediate reports of injuries or damage. The Galpagos, in the Pacific Ocean, belong to Ecuador.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Advertising
description: TELEVISION newscasters were denounced yesterday for their alledged antibusiness bias by Leonard S. Matthews, president of the American Association of Advertising Agencies. And, although he kept maintaining his support for the provisions of the First Amendment, his speech to the annual conference of the Eastern Region of the association contained the veiled threat of economic

title: Temple, Under Hardin, Gains Football Heights
description: Wayne Hardin is one of the most highlyregarded college football coaches. He is rated among the best tacticians for a passing offense. For the last 10 years he has been the coach at Temple, which is better known for basketball than football.

title: Serpentine Book Sold To Films for $1 Million
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 14  The most recent of the flock of books sold to the movies for one million dollars is Serpentine, Thomas Thompson's true account of the exploits of the bizarre thief and murderer Charles Sobhraj. Serpentine was purchased by Elliott Kastner, producer of Where Eagles Dare, Equus and Farewell My Lovely.

title: FuelSaving Ideas In Con Ed Display
description: WHEN the Consolidated Edison Company opens new quarters it doesn't usually make headlines. But when the new quarters offer ideas for reducing Con Ed bills, that's news. What'smore, the ideas are nicely pacKaged and the price is right: no admission is charged to the utility's Conservation Center, which opened Tuesday on the ground floor of the Chrysler Building at Lexington Avenue and 42d Street.

title: Turks to Boycott Cyprus Debate
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 14 (Reuters)  A Turkish Cypriot spokesman said today that his community would boycott this year's General Assembly debate on Cyprus, as it did in 1976 and 1977, and it would not regard as binding any resolution adopted by the world body. The debate is scheduled to begin tomorrow.

title: Bananas, Peanuts and Economic War
description: A foreign exchange trader in London yesterday described the initial effect of Iran's threat to withdraw its assets from American banks: It's bananaville down here. But by this morning, the compensating effects of President Carter's decision to freeze those assets should already be felt. And in any case, $6 billion is peanuts compared with America's gross national product approaching two and a half trillion dollars, bank deposits of a trillion dollars and exports and imports of hundreds of billions.

title: Westmoreland Opposes Women in Combat Role
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (UPI)  Gen. William C. Westmoreland, retired, former Army Chief of Staff, warned Congress today that morale would suffer if women were allowed to fight alongside men in war. He said the issue was too important to be based on a simple social trend.

title: Calendar of Events: Antiques Fair in White Plains
description: 89th Eastern States Antiques Fair, County Center, White Plains, N.Y.

title: Immigration Judge Orders Iranian Deported After Arrest in Chicago
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 14 (UPI)  A United States immigration judge today ordered one of three Iranians arrested at O'Hare International Airport to be deported from the United States.

title: Jet PlaceKicking Trio Tries to Snap Slump
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 14  The three virtual strangers responsible for the Jets placekicking  the snapper, the holder, the kicker  assembled today in an attempt to avoid another fiasco when they face the Bears in Chicago on Sunday.

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 15, 1979

title: A.F.L.C10. Leaders Endorse Carter's Plea For Restraint on Iran
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14  With George Meany presiding for the last time, the executive council of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations today endorsed President Carter's call for restraint on Iran, called for a labor campaign to help Cambodians, admitted a new affiliate union and proposed a per capita dues increase of 3 cents a month.

title: Pianist: Orth in Debut
description: PETER ORTIZ, who gave a debut recital in Alice Tully p Hall on Tuesday night as a result of winning the Naumburg International Piano Competition in memory of William ICapell, proved to be a refreshing and distinctive musical personality. The 25yearold artist is aformer pupil of Adele Marcus at the Jui!Hard School who now studies with Rudolf Serkin. He asserted his individuality early in the program, but it was in the Opus 25 Etudes of Chopin, which made up the second half, that he demonstrated best his special qualities.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: First National Bank in Dallas has elected Jim R. Erwin, Hugh H. Scheurer and John H. Wilson 3d executive vice presidents.

title: Liberals Capture 3 ByElections From the Ruling Party in Quebec
description: QUEBEC, Nov. 14  The Parti Qubcois, which is attempting to lead Quebec to independence, lost three byelections to the Liberals today in its most serious setback since it took power in 1976.

title: House Panel Approves a TradeIn Of Highway Aid for Mass Transit
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14  The House Public Works and Transportation Committee gave unanimous approval today for New York City to take $75 million that had been intended for repairs to the Long Island Expressway and apply it instead to mass transit improvements.

title: Baron's New Chance
description: As usual, Bruno Bich sounded cheerfully confident. He always does when he talks about another America's Cup challenge by his father, Baron Marcel Bich.

title: Carter's Freeze Power Grew Out of 1917 Act
description: WASHNGTON, Nov. 14  In freezing all official Iranian assets in the United States, President Carter acted today under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act of 1977.

title: Bishops Reject Removal Of Word Men in Prayers
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14  The Roman Catholic bishops of the United States refused today to replace the word men in the central prayers and liturgical rites of the church with language that made no reference to sex. The opposite outcome of the vote had been widely expected.

title: Article 5  No Title
COMMODITIES Precious Metals Given Early Lift by Iran Freeze
description: Gold and silver futures rebounded yesterday at the opening of New York's Commodity Exchange as the dollar's value dropped overseas on the news that Washington had frozen Iran's bank deposits in the United States.

title: Insurer Alters Driver Rating
description: HARTFORD, Nov. 14  The Motors Insurance Corporation will eliminate such factors as age, sex and marital status in determining auto insurance rates for Connecticut drivers, John J. MacDonald, president, said today.

title: Regents Propose Establishing Clinics For InSchool Health Care of Students
description: The State Board of Regents, charging that a serious lack of medical care has contributed significantly to learning disabilities, said yesterday that most physical examinations and immunizations of pupils should be conducted in the schools the children attend. The board recommended that the medical program be paid for by Medicaid or fees charged to parents.

description: By RONALD SULLIVAN

title: East Germans Side With Iranians On Seizure of American Embassy
description: EAST BERLIN, Nov. 15 (Reuters) The East German newspaper Neues Deutschland showed sympathy today for the Iranian occupation of the United States Embassy.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 Unwilling to accept strict House limitations on federally financed abortions, the Senate voted today for a more liberal policy, assuring another SenateHouse confrontation on the eve of a planned 10day Thanksgiving recess by the House.

title: Off the Track
description: Bet a Hunch for Lunch is the new slogan of New York's Offtrack Betting Corporation, the first brainstorm of its newly hired advertising agency. You don't have to be an expert. Bet your initials, it suggests. A television pitch depicts a wife berating her husband for playing the ponies until he announces that his lunchtime hunch paid off. Her mood shifts to euphoria. Ours shifts to anger. There's no excuse for this siren song to pull people out of the cafeteria to wager on their initials or phone numbers. OTB has grown well enough, from $20 million in revenue in 1971 to 156 parlors and $804 million last year. Racing, we gather, is trouble nationwide. Not the gasoline lines of summer but inflation seems to be reducing the take. Tracks are offering an array of giveaways. But to urge betting on those not normally interested in horses when they can least afford it is a nasty business for government.

description: LONDON, Nov. 15  Britain and the rival factions in Zimbabwe Rhodesia reached agreement today on arrangements for a transition from guerrilla war to allparty elections, increasing the possibility of an early end to the 14yearold crisis.

title: TeenAger Free on Bail Accused of Crime Spree
description: A recent spree of robberies and burglaries in a midtown Manhattan hotel were caused by a Brooklyn teenager who was free on bail in a shooting inci dent, the police said last night after they arrested 19yearold Glen Lawson for the crimes.

title: Bridge:; TopRanked Woman's Title May Come to a New Yorker
description: CINCINNATI, Nov. 15  The title of world's topranked woman player appears to have crossed to this side of the Atlantic, thanks to a belated administrative decision this week by the American Contract Bridge League, prior to the start of the Fall National Championships here tomorrow.

title: Poverty in U.S. Seen as Exaggerated By a Subterranean Cash Economy; Problem of Unreported Taxes
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15  Peter Gutmann, a professor of economics at Baruch College in New York City, told Congress today that the Government failed to take account of a $250 billion subterranean economy and consequently exaggerated unemployment and poverty.

title: Bolivian Coup Leader To Step Down Today, Defense Chief Reports; Bolivian Is Said to Agree to Resign
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Friday, Nov. 16 Col. Alberto Natusch Busch, who seized power from President Walter Guevara Arze two weeks ago in a violent coup and has faced popular opposition ever since, has agreed to give up the presidency immediately, the nation's defense chief announced early today.

title: Two Unions in Dispute Delay The Daily News
description: Publication of today's New York Daily News was delayed for more than six hours by what management called a jurisdictional dispute between two unions at the newspaper  the photoengravers and the stereotypers unions.

title: The West Bank Folly
description: Israel is turning the offer of autonomy to Palestinian Arabs into a sham. Under the cover of a developing peace with Egypt, Prime Minister Begin and his Cabinet seem to be doing their utmost to frustrate the other half of the Camp David accords. they are provoking even moderate West Bank leaders into hostility and binding them to the Palestine Liberation Organization. How the Israelis expect to negotiate with people they seem determined to humiliate is almost beyond understanding.

title: BONN SET TO DEPLOY NEW NUCLEAR ARMS; Acceptance of U.S. Missiles Seen as Bolstering Development of NATO in the 1980's
description: BONN, Nov. 15  West Germany, in major statement reinforcing the development of Atlantic defenses for the next decade, said yesterday that all the conditions it held out for the deploymentof new American nuclear missiles here have been fulfilled and that it planned to support the deployment.

description: NEWARK, Nov. 15  Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson today vetoed an ordinance designed to force him to hire more police officers to meet a growing crime problem. He said there was no correlation between numbers of policemen and statistics on crime.

title: Roller Discothque Wrecked
description: Three gunmen disguised as Consolidated Edison employees entered a West Side rollerskating discothque today, tied un an employee and then wrecked the interior, causing $100,000 in damage, the police said. The men gained entry at 5:15 A.M. to the discothque, the High Roller at 617 West 57th Street, according to a police spokesman. After tieing up the employee, they destroyed stereo equipment, toilets, furniture, walls and the floor. The police said they knew of no motive.

title: A Jazz Concert That's Simply Heavenly; A Shift in Styles
description: When the angels sing, do they swing? To put it another way, does heavenly rest necessarily mean an end to fingersnapping and toetapping? This much is certain: at the Church of the Heayenly Rest, Fifth Avenue at 90th Street, fingers snap, toes tap, and angels do swing. This Sunday from 5 to 6:30 P.M., the church's fourth jazz concert season begins with the blues and jazz vocalist Joe Williams, his trio, and two special guests, the tenor saxophonists Al Cohn and Billy Mitchell. These gentlemen may not be angels, but they are all expert swingers. And they're angelic enough to be performing for the benefit of the scholarship fund at the Day School, which adjoins the church and receives proceeds from all the jazz concerts held there.

title: Met Opera: A Tatyana For Onegin
description: THE role of Tatyana in Tchaikovsky's Eugene Onegin is the stuff of which either great drama or great soap opera can be made. In the Metropolitan Opera's fourth Onegin of the season, Wednesday night, the Tatyana was Raina Kabaivanska, the Bulgarian soprano. She brought something of both aspects to her performance, but on the whole, drama was favored. This was Miss Kabaivanska's first assumption of the role with the Met, where she last appeared six seasons ago.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK; MANHATTAN
Screen: The Ordeal Of a Country Priest:Church on the Range
description: A LITTLE boy has a splinter. But the nun who's supposed to be removing it keeps forgetting to finish the job, because she's caught up in a heated discussion with a priest. A woman has been told that her father is about to die. But this same nun, who's supposed to be consoling her, is once again arguing with her friend the priest, and for a devout, spiritual woman, she's got an awfully bright gleam in her eye. Strange behavior for a nun? Strange tactics for a movie. Heaven help anyone who tries to take this story at face value."The Runner Stumbles," which opens today at Loews New York Twin I, is ostensibly about a young nun (Kathleen Quinlan) and an older priest (Dick Van Dyke) who have what might, in any other line of work, be considered an office romance. Directed by Stanley Kramer, and adapted by Milan Stitt from his play, it tells what happens when jaunty, life-affirming Sister Rita wanders into the world of Father Rivard, whose assignment to a small, isolated Western community has begun to damage his faith and his disposition.As soon as Sister Rita arrives, she begins raving about the landscape and putting flowers in the vases and teaching the schoolchildren racy songs that aren't in Latin. Even the prostitutes  this is a town where everyone knows everyone else's business  think Sister Rita is a bit much. But Father Rivard is entranced. And he begins squiring her for walks along the local lanes, to the chagrin of the nosy townsfolk.There's nothing improper in their conversation  in fact, they talk mostly about God. But everyone blames Father Rivard when Sister Rita dies under mysterious circumstances, which prove to be preposterous circumstances in the end. The movie is structured as a series of flashbacks during his incarceration and trial, and not until the finale can the audience be sure what sort of attitude toward Father Rivard it ought to have. He seems to be an essentially decent man, whose behavior is questionable on only one or two occasions. Mr. Van Dyke, in about the movie's only strong scene, registers tremendous shock and self-contempt when he watches Sister Rita lie to a senior Church official, and realizes the extent to which she has been compromised.For all its talk about God and faith and whether it's O.K. for Sister Rita to move into Father Rivard's house after the other two nuns she lives with develop consumption, "The Runner Stumbles" is without a great, galloping Big Issue at its center. And without anything momentous to sink his teeth into, Mr. Kramer is very evidently at a loss. The movie plods along with nothing to propel it; the love story is so discreetly rendered it's barely there, and the moral question of the priest's complicity is presented too fuzzily to be of interest.The movie's ethics are, in fact, so hazy, and its attention to religion so perfunctory, that it almost seems as if this were a story about something else that had been transferred, as an afterthought, to a Church setting. The story of a middle-aged man dissatisfied with his career, or wondering whether to leave his wife for a younger woman, could very easily have taken the same dramatic route and seemed a lot clearer. As it is, Mr. Kramer treats the film's religious questions as afterthoughts, and too often achieves a dispirited, noncommittal tone.An all-star cast is probably not what an already distracted film like "The Runner Stumbles" needed. But an all-star cast is what it has. Beau Bridges doubles as both the town good-for-nothing and Father Rivard's lawyer. Maureen Stapleton and Tammy Grimes, as the priest's housekeeper and one of his parishioners, both seem normal enough until the screenplay reveals them to be mentally unsound. Ray Bolger makes a brief, effective appearance as the Church superior to whom Sister Rita tells her lie.Miss Quinlan is ebullient to a fault, but that seems to be what both the screenplay and Mr. Kramer had in mind. Mr. Van Dyke's performance, though extremely sympathetic, is hard to assess. He worries and suffers, but the film finds nothing vital in his ordeal."The Runner Stumbles" is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"). It includes an off-screen murder, infrequent harsh language and references to prostitution.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Popular Citation Makes An Unpopular G.M. Aide
description: Robert D. Lund, the general manager of General Motors Chevrolet division, has an embarrassment of riches, as well as a potful of angry customers to soothe. The new Chevrolet Citation, with 200,000 units sold and delivered in seven months, has gotten off to the fastest start of any car in American automotive history. But the car, the most popular of G.M.'s new Xbody series, is in such fierce demand that a backlog of 285,000 orders from consumers, dealers and corporate fleets has accumulated and shows no immediate, signs of abating. Some orders.have gone unfilled for months.

title: ExAgent Is Guilty of Conspiracy

description: The New Jersey Symphony Grebes. tra hopes to fill the 3,400 seats in Newark's Symphony Hall, tripling the usual sales for the orchestra, with George Gershwin's music  sung by the Newarkborn jazz singer Sarah Vaughan and playedby the Leningradborn pianist Lazar Berman.

title: British Physicist Denies He Disclosed U.S. Data
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (UPI)  A Britishborn physicist today denied allegations that he was the fifth man in a British spy ring that betrayed American atomic and other secrets to the Soviet Union.

title: Floats Are Readied for Thanksgiving Day Parade
GOING OUT Guide
description: AHOY Today the intrepid explorers of Adventure on a Shoestring are off on another tour, inspecting a luxury liner, prow to stern. Recent Shoestring trips have included chats with an interior designer, a vampire researcher and a casting agent for television commercials.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 20.

title: Capacity Use In Factories Off
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP)  The nation's manufacturing plants operated at 85 percent of capacity in October, down slightly from September's 85.2 percent rate, the Federal Reserve said today.

title: Steel Plant's LifeorDeath Vote
description: About 900 workers at the American Bridge Company plant in Ambridge, Pa., began filing into the storefront offices of Local 1270 of the United Steelworkers Union yesterday to vote on an issue that will not only affect their jobs but also the future of the town where many have spent their entire lives.

title: Notes on People
description: After dickering that apparently began last July, Josephine Ford, sister of Henry Ford 2d and wife of Walter B. Ford 2d, has bought the Anchorage, Nelson A. Rockefeller's summer home on the Maine coast at Seal Harbor.

title: Ford to Offer Dealers New Cash Incentive Plan
description: The Ford Motor Company, following similar moves by both the General Motors Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation, announced yesterday in Dearborn, Mich., that it was offering its car dealers, effective immediately, a new cash incentive program. The new plan involves certain 1979model cars and trucks that along with previously implemented yearend allowances could reduce certain car prices more than $1,000.

title: World News Briefs
description: TORONTO, Nov. 16 (Reuters)  The last of 223,000 evacuated residents of Mississauga were allowed to return home tonight for the first time in almost a week when experts finished draining potentially lethal chlorine gas from a railroad tanker car.

title: An Arena of the Future
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 16  First the race track, then the stadium... and now the arena. As the New Jersey Sports Authority's latest promotional brochure says, The future has a habit of becoming the present more quickly than we think.

title: Bolivian Congress Picks President
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Nov. 16 (UPI)  Congress tonight selected its presiding officer, Lidia Gueiler, as interim President, replacing Col. Alberto Natusch Bush, who seized power in a coup 15 days ago.

title: Bullets Rally to Beat Nets, 9291, As Williamson Stays on Bench
description: PISATAWAY, N.J. Nov. 16  It was one of the little ironies of basketball that Rich Kelley played so well tonight and yet probably will be remembered for missing a crucial shot in his Nets 9291 loss tonight to the Washington Bullets.

title: Article 1  No Title
Louis Clifford Goad, 78, Is Dead; Engineer and Executive for. G.M.
description: Louis Clifford Goad, who joined the General Motors Corporation in 1923 as young engineer and retired 43 years later as the company's executive vice president,. died Wednesday at his home in Bloomfield Hills, Mich. He was 78 years old.

title: Witty Furniture Designs From the Milan AvantGarde
description: At last September's Furniture Fair in Milan, the most talkedabout furniture pieces were those from Studio Aichymia, a group of avantgarde Milanese designers.

title: Dancers of Ballet Theater Reject New Contract Offer
description: The dancers of American Ballet Theater rejected the company's latest contract offer yesterday. The company's subsequent call for arbitration was also rejected by the dancers. Ballet Theater, which announced Thursday that it would cancel its coming fourweek season at the John. F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington if the dancers rejected its proposal, yesterday said that a decision on cancellation of the Kennedy Center season, which is scheduled to start Dec. 4, would be made by tomorrow.

title: Mine Workers Vice President Replaces Ailing Leader
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16Sam Church Jr., vice president of the United Mine Workers of America who had become the de facto leader of the nation's 250,000 unionized coal miners, took the title of president today, replacing the ailing Arnold R. Miller in a transition secretly negotiated with Mr. Miller at his hospital bed.

title: Musical Cartoon to Play At the Brooklyn Academy
description: Holeville, a musical cartoon by Jeff Wanshel, will be presented at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Attic Theater, 30 Lafayette Street, by the Dodger Theater, the academy's resident company, in a threeweek engagement that will begin with previews on NOV. 27.

title: Awkkkkkkkk
description: Certain people see a parrot and immediately ask, Does it talk? They loom over the unhappy bird and repeat the old imbecilic question, Polly want a cracker? No sophisticated bird will tolerate so old hat a name as that one, and the Parrot is nothing if not sophisticated.

title: Brezhnev Said to Assail U.S. Alert
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16  Government officials say that Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, has sent President Carter a note complaining about a recent American nuclear alert that stemmed from a malfunction in equipment designed to give the United States early warning of a missile attack.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The St. Joe Minerals Corporation an: flounced yesterday that it was considering closing its zinc smelter in Monaca, Pa. The operation employs about 1,500 workers and is the largest zinc smelter in the United States.

title: Senate Panel Abandons Order on Budget Cutting
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP)  The Senate Budget Committee today dropped its demand for a formal order requiring Congress to save $3.6 billion, but it voweed to fight any attempt to raise the 1980 budget ceiling if those savings were not made.

title: Moscow Repeats Offer To Reduce Its Missiles Aimed at West Europe
description: MOSCOW, Saturday, Nov. 17  The Communist Party newspaper, Pravda, today repeated Soviet promises to cut the number of mediumrange nuclear missiles aimed at Europe if the United States deoloved no new rockets of its own there.

title: David Rockefeller Says Aim in Aid To Shah Was Solely Humanitarian
description: In response to growing speculation about his role in the decision to admit the deposed Shah of Iran to the United States, David Rockefeller issued a brief statement yesterday saying that he had acted not only for friendly but for strong humanitarian reasons.

title: Methodist Church Unit Accused Of Fraud in Housing for Elderly
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 16  A branch of the United Methodist Church and the management of Pacific Homes, a group of seven bankrupt retirement homes in the West and Hawaii, have been accused by a courtappointed trustee of defrauding hundreds of elderly residents of the homes.

title: Obituary 4  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Around the Nation
description: HONOLULU, Nov. 18 (AP)  Striking public workers shut down the state's docks today for the second time since they walked off their jobs Oct. 26 in a pay dispute.

title: Trade Deficit Rises in Japan
description: TOKYO, Nov. 16 (AP)  Japan posted a customscleared trade deficit of $1.38 billion in October, compared with a deficit of $742.5 million in September and a surplus of $1.54 billion in October 1978, the Finance Ministry said in a preliminary report today.

title: United Airlines Cancels Option for 22 Boeing 727's
description: United Airlines has canceled options for Boeing equipment valued at $300 million, but the Boeing Company said yesterday that its production rate would nonetheless remain at the current high level at least through 1981.

title: Britain Will Send an Ambassador To Argentina After 4Year Break
description: LONDON, Nov. 16 (Reuters)  Britain announced today that it would send an ambassador to Buenos Aires after a fouryear break. Anthony Williams, a senior career diplomat, will take up his post in January.

title: Costly 80 Texas Race Under Way For Oil and Gas Rezulatory Panel
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 16 (AP)  A fourperson race is already heating up in a 1980 election for two positions on the Texas Railroad Commission, an agency that regulates so many things besides railroads that it may be the most powerful regulatory denartment in the nation.One indication of the power of the $45,200ayear positions is that one candidate says his campaign will cost $600,000.

title: U.N. Office in Vietnam Is Ready to Aid Emigrs
description: GENEVA, Nov. 16 With the opening two days ago of an office in Ho Chi Minh City by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, the stage is set for regular departures of Vietnamese wanting to emigrate, a United Nations official said today.

title: CONGRESS APPROVES AN ABORTION ACCORD
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16  With the House poised to begin a 10day recess, Congress hastily passed an emergency money bill today after agreeing to a compromise on use of Federal funds for abortions.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In the obituary of the Broadway producer and director Jed Harris yesterday, funeral arrangements were described incorrectly. The family will receive friends and relatives tonight starting at 7 o'clock at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, Madison Avenue and 81st Street. The funeral service, which is not private, will be held at Campbell's at 2 P.M. tomorrow. A memorial service will be announced later. Mr. Harris, who died Thursday, left a grandson and two granddaughters.

title: Bergland on Visit to Sweden
description: STOCKHOLM, Nov. 16 (UPI)  Secretary of Agriculture Bob Bergland arrived in Sweden today for a threeday visit. He will leave Monday for West Germany.

title: Bridge:
description: CINCINNATI, Nov. 16  Thousands of players arriving here for the start of the Fall National Championships today were greeted by the news that the American Contract Bridge League, the country's ruling body of tournament bridge, had been hit for the second time in a month with an antitrust suit by players under a cloud because of cheating charges.

title: Fink Preparing to Fight Vetoes Of 2 Bills to Ease Heating Costs
description: Assembly Speaker Stanley Fink yesterday called a session for next Tuesday to attempt to override Governor Carey's vetoes of two measures designed to help the working poor and the elderly with their heating bills this winter.

title: Gold Prices Up As Dollar Slips
description: Gold prices rose yesterday as the dollar went on a rollercoaster ride in foreign exchange markets at home and abroad, mainly on conflicting reports that Iran was planning to require that its oil be paid for with several currencies rather than dollars. The dollar recovered later in the day, but only slightly.

title: Radio Satellite Decision: Delay Seen
description: GENEVA, Nov. 16  The Administrative Radio Conference, reviewing the use made of the world's airwaves, is expected to postpone for about five years a decision on the controversial issue of how nations should share the availability of satellite communication, delegates report.

title: McEnroe Subdues Fibak After a Tiff With Referee
description: WEMBLEY, England, Nov. 16 (AP)  John McEnroe survived a long argument with the referee tonight and went on to defeat Wojtek Fibak of Poland, 62, 6.1, in the quarterfinals of a $175,000 Grand Prix tennis tournament.

title: Gibson Faces a Key Test In Vote on Bill He Vetoed
description: NEWARK, Nov. 16 In what is widely viewed as a key test of who now runs New Jersey's largest city, the Newark City. Council will try Tuesday to override Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson's veto of legislation mandating a 20 percent increase in the police force.

title: State Acts to Take Over the Assets Of Iran Bank Offices in New York
description: The New York State Superintendent of Banks summoned the top officers of the four New York offices of Iranian banks to her office yesterday and handed them orders that placed most of their assets under her control.

title: Judge Rejects City's Attempt to Narrow Heart Bill
description: A State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that Mayor Koch had acted improperly when he reinterpreted the state's socalled Heart Bill in an effort to reduce the number of police officers and firefighters who receive accident disabilitv pensions.

title: The Region
description: EAST LYME, Conn. (AP)  Three teenagers, stranded for hours on a small island off Millstone Point in Long Island Sound after their boat ran aground, were rescued and then arrested on charges of stealing the boat, the police said.

title: Beyond the Embargo
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  The President's embargo against Iranian oil is certainly manageable. After all, during the Arab oil embargo of 1973, the international oil companies managed to swap around more than twice the amount of oil that we have been importing recently from Iran.

title: Flames Turn Back Rangers, 42
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 16  Between periods, as the organist at the Omni is running through her repertory of disco tunes and just before the Atlanta Flames are getting ready to return to the ice, Dan Bouchard, the Flame goaltender, skates to the net and begins what looks like a choreographed routine. Bending his knees and digging hisskates into the ice, he starts scraping together little piles of ice that rim the crease like a small barricade.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 17, 1979

title: 3,000 in Amsterdam Protesting Plan for NATO Nuclear Missiles
description: AMSTERDAM, Nov. 16 (Reuters) About 3,000 people staged a torchlight demonstration here last night protesting NATO plans to install new nuclear missiles in the Netherlands and other West European countries.

title: Commodity Tables Explained
description: Next to each commodity in the table is a key to the exchange on which it is traded, the minimum contract size and the monetary units represented by the figures in the table. Open interest is the number of contracts outstanding each month and not liquidated by delivery of the commodity or by en off setting contract. The exchange keys are:

title: Union Adopts Chrysler Pact
description: DETROIT, Nov. 16 (UPI)  The United Automobile Workers said,today that it had won rankandfile approval for a threeyear contract granting $203 million in cash concessions to the financially ailing Chrysler Corporation.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Friday, Nov. 16. 1979

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: HAROLD W. SCHLOSS

title: Last Chance for Battery Park City
description: For almost a decade the vacant landfill of Battery Park City in Lower Manhattan has produced nothing but grass. Those 91 acres along the Hudson River are still a prime resource for commercial, residential and recreational development. But what was once the promise of a new town in town is now just a fiscal morass.

title: Bache Net Declines In Quarter
description: The Bathe Group Inc., the first company to disclose the impact of the severe October decline in security prices on brokeragehouse profits, reported yesterday that earnings for its most recent quarter fell to 41 cents a share from 71 cents a year earlier.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yesterday's Weather at 1 P.M.: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration/UPI

title: Crater in Hawaii Emits Fire
description: VOLCANO, Hawaii, Nov. 16 (UPI) Kilauea volcano emitted two small curtains of fire from Pauahi crater today in an eruption that scientists said appeared to be small and localized. Pauahi crater is southeast of Halemaumau, the main crater of the Kilauea volcano.

title: Fourth Tucker Concert Will Be Held on Feb. 17
description: The fourth annual Richard Tucker Memorial Concert will be held at Carnegie Hall on Feb. 17. The participating artists will be Luciano Pavarotti, Carlo Bergonzi, Katia Ricciarelli, Ileana Cotrubas, Sherrill Milnes, Jose Van Dam, Tatiana Troyanos, Ruggero Raimondi and Paul Plishka.

title: OBSERVER Furniture Kicking Time
description: Not surprisingly, emotions in this country have been turbulent ever since the Ayatollah kidnapped the American Embassy in Teheran and started making ransom demands.This sort of behavior is what the Soviet lexicon calls a provocation, and if the Ayatollah's aim was to provoke Americans, he succeeded admirably.

title: Life's Not Bad, but French Foresee Disaster
description: PARIS, Nov. 16  Michel Debre, once Charles de Gaulle's Prime Minister and now the most eminent and persistent Cassandra in France, declared recently that the country had fallen into a crisis of the regime, implying that its problems embraced the whole structure of national politics.

title: Schultze Says Other Countries Have Backed U.S. Action on Iran
description: PARIS, Nov. 16 (UPI)  The United States has received substantial support for its boycott of Iranian oil, President Carter's chief economic adviser said today.

title: Soviet Buys More Wheat
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP)  The Soviet Union has bought an additional 100,000 metric tons of United States wheat for delivery in the current marketing year, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Rights Groups Helping Black Students in Libel Suit
description: KANSAS CITY, Kan., Nov. 16A libel trial under way here in which a white college administrator is suing four black former students has drawn the attention of national civil rights organizations that say the dispute represents another serious attack on affirmative action efforts to achieve desegregation.

title: College Quiz Show, Favorite of the 60's, Tests Wits Again
description: It came right between Ted Mack's Amateur Hour and our family dinner, Louise Mowder recalls of College Bowl, the scrubbedface television quiz show that was a Sunday evening staple throughout the 60's. The show went off the air in 1970, routed by televised Sunday football games and other opponents.

title: Television
description: Afternoon

title: Sports Today
description: Knlcks vs. Boston Celtics, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 8 P.M. (Television  Manhattan Cables 8 P.M. RadioWHEW, 8 P.M.)

title: Taxi Contract Lapses; Negotiations Continue
description: Negotiators for the Taxi Drivers Union and the city's fleet owners pressed their bargaining efforts late last night and early this morning in an attempt to reach agreement on a new contract covering 10,000 drivers.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Books of The Times Fuzz on the Peaches
description: A woman asks the clerk at an outdoor market to dry the vegetables before putting them on the scale. She says Water weighs something, you know. Another woman asks What is this stuff on these peaches? And the clerk says It's called fuzz. Someone ob

title: ROY LATHAM, KNOWN AS L.I. NATURALIST, 98
description: Roy Latham, a naturalist whose taxidermic collections of birds, mammals and fish and Indian artifacts were said to represent one of the most complete pictures of Long Island wildlife, died in Orient Point, L.I., on Tuesday. lie was 98 years old..

title: COMMODITIES Precious Metals Higher On Concern Over Iran
description: Gold and silver futures rose yesterday, reversing themselves for the fifth time this week on concern over the situation in Iran.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 17, 1979

title: Dublin Commuter Trains Collide
description: DUBLIN, Nov. 16 (AP)  Two packed commuter trains collided at the entrance to a tunnel near Dublin today, injuring at least 25 persons, many of them children.

title: Pop: Fleetwood Mac Plays Like Three Acts in One
description: Fleetwood Mac has been through a bewildering succession of personnel changes since its inception more than 10 years ago, but the configuration that finally struck paydirt in 1975 was surely the oddest of the band's career.

title: Government Warning to ExSpy Sets Off Political Storm in Britain
description: LONDON, Nov. 16  A political storm developed today over the case of Anthony Blunt, the former Soviet spy and curator of Queen Elizabeth II's art collection, as it was disclosed that the Government had warned him this week, in time for him to flee his home in London, that his secret Dast was about to be made public.

title: School District Has a Growing Pain: It Grows Smaller
description: BALDWIN, L.I.  The school board here has approved a third reorganization plan to ease the economic burden caused by a surplus of school buildings, but critics say the plan does not go far enough in dealing with the problem.

title: A Chicago Developer Named Commerce Chief
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16  Philip M. Klutznick, a Chicago realestate developer and prominent American Jewish leader, was nominated today by President Carter as Secretary of Commerce.

title: Thomas Matthews Jr.; Challenged Hatch Act
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16  Thomas C. Matthews Jr., a Washington lawyer who gained prominence when he challenged the constitutionality of the Hatch Act, died Tuesday at George Washington Hospital after a heart attack. He was 48 years old.

title: Jack Butterfield, 50, Killed in Auto Crash; Was Yankee Official
description: Jack Butterfield, a vice president of the New York Yankees, was killed early yesterday in an automobile accident on Route 17 near Paramus. N.J.

title: Fiske Quitting as U.S. Attorney, Returning His Talent to Wall St.
description: There is a common wisdom about lawyers who become prosecutors: most harbor political ambitions, most are too busy administering their offices to appear in court and most have large egos and are in constant search of the limelight.

title: Reports on Freeze and Oil Hurt Dollar
description: LONDON, Nov. 16 Published reports of moves that would intensify the economic war between the United States and Iran raced across Europe today, depressing the dollar in foreign exchange markets.

title: MILITANTS CHARGES AROUSE LIBRARIANS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16  Librarians, according to stereotype, are a timid lot. But it was a note of militancy that roused a gathering of several hundred here today as speakers accused elected officials of consciously neglecting libraries and cheered a call for commercial users of Federal information to pay for that privilege.

title: Rockets Defeat Knicks, 133130
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 16 (AP)  Moses Malone and. Rudy Tomjanovich combined to score 69 points tonight as the Houston Rockets defeated the New YorkKnicks,133130.

title: American Airlines Fined $500,000 For Improper DC10 Maintenance
description: The Federal Aviation Administration announced yesterday that American Airlines had paid a record $500,000 fine for improper maintenance of DC10 jumbo jets, including the plane that crashed in Chicago last May with a loss of 273 lives.

title: The City
description: The New York City boy whose case led to the state'`s tough new juvenile justice law has been sentenced to up to four years in prison for his escape last year from a youth detention center.

title: Bucs Clarify Williams Pact
description: TAMPA, Fla., Nov. 16 (AP)  Top executives of the Tampa Bay Buccaneers huddled with the team's quarterback, Doug Williams, today after two recent articles had reported that he was dissatisfield with his salary. Williams's agent, Jimmy Walsh, was quoted as saying that Williams is paid just over $50,000 a year, and that the quarterback was taken advantage of when he signed because he was a poor black.

title: Publicly Traded Funds
description: Friday, Nov, 16, 1979

title: The Dance: City Ballet Presents Tchaikovsky Piano Concerto
description: The New York City Ballet is dancing with unusual, and bright energy this week, the first of its fall season at the New York State Theater.

title: Mrs. Carter Wins Award
description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Nov. 16 (AP)  Rosalyn Carter has received an award for her work with the mentally ill and said she accepted it on behalf of all persons striving to build a more caring world. At a dinner attended by 3,000 people here last night, the President's wire received the International Humanitarian Award of the St. Boniface Hospital Research Foundation. In the past it has been given to Dr. Christiaan Barnard, Dr. Jonas Salk and Prince Philip, husband of Queen Elizabeth II.

title: Article 2  No Title
Most Banks Set 15% Prime Rate
description: Most of the nation's leading banks raised their prime rates by onequarter of a percentage point yesterday to a record 15 percent.

title: Release of Iran's Assets Linked To Hostages and Improved Ties
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16  A senior Treasury official suggested today that Iranian assets frozen earlier this week would be released if the hostages were freed and relations between the two countries improved.

title: Your Money
description: IN recent days, bank advertisements have been telling people that if they do not have the cash on hand to purchase a sixmonth savings certificate, they can borrow up to $5.000 at low cost to buy one.

title: Adviser's Post To Entremont
description: Philippe Entremont will become music adviser and principal guest conductor of the New Orleans Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra, next season. He will succeed Leonard Slatkin, who this season took over the music directorship of the St. Louis Symphony Orchestra.

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: LEON YUDKIN

title: Harvard in Way of Yale's Perfect Season
description: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 16  With the Ivy League championship won, Yale's football team goes for another goal tomorrow: its first undefeated and untied season in 19 years and only its second in 56 years.

title: CONNALLY IS SEEKING VICTORY IN FLORIDA
description: KISSIMMEE, Fla., Nov. 16  John B. Connally will make his first serious effort to derail Ronald Reagan's bid for the Republican Presidential nomination tomorrow at a party convention in Florida.

title: U.S. Notes Favorable Events
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP)  The State Department said today that reports from Bolivia indicate an apparently favorable turn of events which promises to restore constitutional processes.

title: U.S. Tells of Asian Hostages
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16  The State Department said today that it believed the hostages in the American Embassy in Teheran included 10 or so embassy employees who are neither American or Iranian. The department said that they are thought to come from the Philippines, Pakistan, South Korea and Bangladesh.

title: Getting Things Done
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 16When Philip M. Klutznick returns here from a trip he gets.into his limousine and is handed a batch of mail that his aides have marked urgent. By the time hereaches his office he has answered most of it and is ready forthe next task at hand.

title: Massachusetts Democrats Get 2dEarliest Primary
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (UPI)  Massachusetts Democrats won permission from national party officials today to hold a Presidential primary March 4, which will make it second in the nation and a likely boon to Senator Edward M. Kennedy.

title: The Quiet Guardians of City Hall
description: Without a hint of influencepeddling or closeddoor politics, it can be said in City Hall that John Wrynn and Frank Weber control access to the Mayor, although only a handful of the city's voters have heard of either man.

title: Radio
description: 89 A.M., WNCN. Bachianas Brasileiras No. 5, aria, VillaLobos; Overture to The Creatures of Prometheus, Bcethoven; Sonata  tre, Schmelzer; Images Our orchestre, Rondes de printemps, Debussy; Sonata a tre in D, Tartini.

title: A corny, Average BridetoBe Who Happens to Be a Princess
description: We're as corny as you can get, said Simon Abrahams, and his fiance smiled in agreement.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the last week. Answers appear on page 24.

title: Brooklyn Dockers Cite Gains Under Scotto
description: At thp headquarters of Anthony M. Scotto's union in Brooklyn, down on the main floor of the bright, modern hall, William Maineculf, a dockworker for 30 years, said: I feel very bitter. The system stinks. We always had to fight ourway up. Finally we got some place and now we get this, a real slap in the face.

title: Damurez Triumphs In Jumpoff
description: TORONTO, Nov. 16  A year ago, Mark Laskin, born in New York but now a resident of Vancouver, British Columbia, attracted the attention of officials of the Canadian Equestrian Team.

title: Political Feud in Colombian Town: 22 Down, More to Go
description: TRUJILLO, Colombia, Nov. 12  On a recent morning in this picture postcard mountain town, a wealthy coffee planter and political leader, Leonardo Espinosa Saldarriaga, was breakfasting on his patio. He reached across thetable to pick up a piece of bread  and survived the 10th attempt on his life in 18 months.

title: Kison Signs Angel Pact For 5 Years
description: It doe's not happen often, but George Steinbrenner lost his man last night. Bruce Kison, a pitcher whom the Yankee owner recruited aggressively with Rich Gotsage's help, chose the California Angels over the Yankees and agreed to a fiveyear contract.

title: Security Agency At Indian Point To Be Replaced
description: The company that provides security guards for the nuclear power plants at Indian Point is being replaced for having failed to maintain proper records on training, the utilities that run the plants announced yesterday.

title: Stocks Show Moderate Decline; Some Oil Issues Strengthen
description: The stock market registered a moderate decline yesterday In lighter trading with some of the oil and special situation issues making the biggest price moves.

title: Events Today
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Tchaikovsky's Eugene Onegin, 2, and Verdi's Atda, 8.

title: Koch Reports Progress In Project to Clean Up City's Theater District
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that substantial progress had been made in his administration's 18month Times Square Action Plan to eliminate the tawdriness that has permeated the theater district.

title: Carter Discourages Recriminations Against All Iranians Living in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16  President Carter urged Americans today not to allow their anger over events in Iran to produce recriminations against all Iranians living in the United States.

title: Opera: Mahagonnyls Sung at the Met
description: The WeillBrecht Rise and Fall of the City of Mahagonny came to the Metropolitan Opera last night, and at least one question about the work was answered. There were those who predicted that Mahagonny, with its cabaret roots, smallish orchestra and jazz elements, would not go in a house as big as the Met's. It does. Whether or not it is an opera, and Weill strongly insisted that it is, it does use voices skillfully, it has a big chorus, and it was not lost on the stage of the big house.

title: Jets Reactions Mixed to Garvey's Charges of Racism in N.F.L.
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.1., Nov. 16  The New York Jets, one of only 10 teams in the National Football League with a black assistant coach (Bob Ledbetter) and one of the few teams ever to play a black quarterback (J.J. Jones. in 1975). had Mixed reactions today to the memorandum on racism in the league put out by Ed Garvey, the head of the Players Association.

title: For Meany, From Labor: Love and $110,000 a Year
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16  Frederick O'Neal, president of the Associated Actors and Artists of America, today turned to a paraphrase of Shakespeare's Henry WI! to express his feelings: Embrace this man with a true heart and brother love.

title: 8 Iranians With Rifles Are Seized at Baltimore Airport
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16  Eight Iranians carrying rifles, telescopic sights and ammunition were arrested by Federal agents last night in BaltimoreWashington International Airport, a Treasury Department spokesman disclosed today.

title: Carter Aide Pauses
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19  Last July, the White House announced that Hedley Donovan, who had retired two months before as editor in chief of Time Inc. publications, had been appointed senior adviser to the President. His job was to provide substantive advice on the full range of matters before the President.

title: Connally Shunning Tactics of Past DarkHorse Victors
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 16  John B. Connally is defying the conventional wisdom in his long, uphill run for the 1980 Republican Presidential nomination.

title: A Juror Calls Tapes the Key In Rejecting Scotto's Story
description: A juror in Anthony M. Scotto's racketeering trial said yesterday that in the end it was hard evidence  especially the prosecutibn tape recordings  that persuaded the jury to find the waterfront labor leader guilty Thursday.

title: Obituary 3  No Title
description: MOE KATZ

title: All 44 Survive Plane Crash at Rim of Grand Canyon
description: A plane carrying 41 French tourists and three crew members lost power in one of two engines on takeoff and crashed near the south rim of Arizona's Grand Canyon yesterday afternoon. Everyone aboard scrambled to safety before flames engulfed the aircraft.

title: Vast Saudi Industrial Program
description: DHAHRAN, Saudi Arabia  The eastern province of Saudi Arabia, beneath which lies most of the country's oil, has been turned into a giant construction site.

title: Japanese Group Gives $1 Million For a New Unesco Peace Prize
description: PARIS, Nov. 16 (Reuters)  A Japanese foundation gave $1 million to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization today to finance a new annual peace prize.

title: Students Warn Hostages Will Pay If Shah Goes Anywhere but to Iran
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 16  A spokesman for the militant students holding scores of hostages at the American Embassy here said today that if the deposed Shah was allowed to leave the United States for any country other than Iran, the hostages will find themselves in more difficult conditions.

title: Reagan Critical of Plan . For U.S. Aid to Chrysler
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Nov. 16 (UPI)  Ronald Reagan, campaigning in Michigan, where the automobile industry is an economic mainstay, said today that he disagreed with President Carter's loan guarantee program for the financially ailing Chrysler Corporation.

title: For the Son, Is Father Key To Manliness?
description: SAN ANTONIO, Nov. 16 (UPI) The popular assumption that boys learn to be masculine by emulating their fathers is a myth, according to an associate professor of psychiatry at the University of Texas Health Science Center.

title: T.W.A. Pilot Layoffs
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo. (UPI)  Trans World Airlines, beset by declining air traffic and rising costs, announced today that 100 of the airline's pilots would be laid off early in 1980. T.W.A. has more than 3,300 pilots.

title: Nablus Mayor on Hunger Strike
description: TEL AVIV, Nov. 16 (AP)  Arab mayors from the occupied West Bank of the Jordan and the Gaza Strip said today that they would join the imprisoned Mayor of Nablus, Bassam alShaka, in a hunger strike to protest his impending deportation.

title: SCOTTO IS REMAINING IN DOCK UNION JOBS
description: Anthony M. Scotto declared yesterday that he would continue to serve as a leader of the International Longshoremen's Association while he appealed his conviction on payoff charges.

title: Pelican Roundup: Captors 5, Birds. 0
description: Three Dalmatian and two American white pelicans, their wings clipped, skipped across Cope Lake at the Bronx Zoo yesterday trying to dodge fish nets and outwit 12 wouldbe captors.

title: Arizona State Forfeitures Cause Turmoil
description: Pacific10 Conference officials, after deciding Thursday night that Arizona State University must forfeit its five victories this season because of the use of ineligible players, said yesterday that the conference was finished with its investigation of the matter.

title: Letter: On City Prisons
description: To the Editor:

title: Revolutionary Zeal Had Been Lagging Before the Embassy Seizure
description: TEHERAN, Iran  After visiting the Islamic students holding the United States Embassy and 62 Americans hostage for the return of the deposed Shah, the commander of the Pasdaran, Iran's revolutionary militiamen, clambered atop a car to address the thousands of people standing outside. As the imam says 1a, ne told the cheering crowd, using the Arabic word for no, the Arabic giving religious force to his words since it is the language of the Koran. Surrounded by crouching gunmen, he shouted through a bullhorn: No to negotiations, no to compromise. I salute those who support our children inside. We are willing to face any bloodshed, any death to defend them. And we, too, say- la.

title: Mit Schlag
description: Writers about Vienna presume on a special indulgence in readers. They see us dimpling even as we open to. their page one, sighing with pleasurable melancholy, curling our legs up under us. We're going to be reading about suicide and despair, but it's going to be elegant and nostalgic. Of course, it will also be cynical, even satirical, but above all nostalgic, and in the most literal sense. We will see Vienna as everyone's lost heritage. At the end of A Nervous Splendor, which is built upon the suicide of Crown Prince Rudolf in 1889, Frederic Morton tells us that Rudolf was the precursor of our own youth: Each time we hear of another strange young death in a good house we hear of another Mayerling. But how often is that? It's years since I've thought of a good house at all. Only Vienna can cast such a Tory spell  if Vienna can. I remained unenchanted. If I want to feel the fragile excitements of youth and doomed love, I go to the Natasha Rostov chapters of War and Peace, where they are flanked and framed by other kinds of life; not to such tales of the Vienna Woods, where they are isolated as in a hothouse.

title: Pace Show, Imprisoned Art, Offers Work of Inmates
description: WHEN Karamoko Baye left the Federal penitentiary in Marion, Ill., after serving eightandahalf years for a New York City bank robbery, one of the first things he planned to do was to start an organization that would help artists in prisons.

title: E.P.A. and Idaho Debate Nuclear Waste Seepage
description: IDAHO FALLS, Idaho, Nov. 17 (AP) The Federal Environmental Protection Agency says it wants to know why radioactivity is seeping out of a Federal research facility's underground aquifer through the water table that feeds the Snake River at a rate faster than Federal officials had predicted.

title: Port Authority Planning Building In Newark to Aid Meat Importing
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey will build a $2.8 million facility in Newark in an effort to eliminate delays in the processing of imported meat.

title: United Press International
description: Israelis Halt Arab Mayors Going to Gaza for a Fast

title: Barbara Diane Knox Is Married
description: The marriage of Barbara Diane Knox, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Berkeley Knox of Babylon, L.I., to Robert Stanley Pearsall of Bayport, L.I., took place yesterday in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Babylon. The Rev. Charles Staiger performed the ceremony. The bridegroom is a son of Robert Floyd Pearsall of Easton, Md., and the late Mrs. Rebecca Mildred Pearsall.

title: ANTIQUES
