description: Antiques collectors visiting museums may well have discovered that sometimes the smallest exhibitions deliver the largest messages. Certainly this is true of the Japanese Ceramics from the Tanakamaru Collection, on view at the Metropolitan Museum of Art through Jan. 6.

title: Williamson Returns And Helps Nets Win
description: DETROIT, Nov. 17  John Williamson went from the doghouse to the penthouse tonight when he hit two clutch jump shots in the final minute of play to help give the New Jersey Nets their first road victory this season, 9893, over the Detroit Pistons.

title: Florida State Gains Orange Bowl Berth
description: The dream of bowlgame organizers is to match two unbeaten teams in game to decide the national championship. That may happen on New Year's night in Miami, if Florida State, which accepted a bid to the Orange Bowl yesterday, meets Nebraska.

title: Both Honor and Water Evaporate in Bill Test
description: NEWBERRY, Mich., Nov. 17 (UPI)  Since village officials decided to put water customers on the honor system last year, 78 million gallons has apparently evaporated in this community in the Upper Michigan Peninsula.

title: Occasions of Constraint
description: G. MOJTABAI made her literary debut in 1974 with Mundome, an extraordinary, poetic novel about a library staffed by eccentrics and haunted by revenants. It was also about the intense, doomful relation of a mentally alienated young woman to her loving brother. This first novel was a dark, moderngothic book, lighted by shafts of demonic wit and marked by distinction of style and bold imagination. One surmised that this strangely named writer of the work with the strange name had been there and back, had by herself descended some distance into the imprisoning abyss where her characters languished. Hers was the report of a survivor.

title: MARTIN BERNHARDT
description: Martin Bernhardt, a lawyer and retired executive of the Schering Corporation in Germany and the United States, died Thursday at the Cherry Nursing Home, Montclair, N.J. He was 93 years old.

title: THIS WEEK IN SPORTS
description: The Knicks meet the Houston Rockets Tuesday at 7:30 P.M. and the Cleveland Cavaliers Saturday at 8 P.M. at Madison Square Garden. The Nets are at the Rutgers Athletic Center in Piscataway, N.J., to face the Milwaukee Bucks Thursday at 8 P.M.

title: HIGH COURT VS. THE PRESS
description: Apart from its criminaljustice rulings, the Burger Court's interpretations of the press's First Amendment rights have led to the greatest constitutional confrontations of the past decade. Second of a twopart series.

title: Bachrach
description: Jane Crowell Reade, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Reade of Rye, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Nordo Mauro Nissi 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nissi Jr. of Bradford, Mass. The ceremony was performed in Christ Episcopal Church by the rector emeritus.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: MOUNT KISCO THE Fox Center is a small building in an outoftheway place, Abut for a whole group of people, it has become a second home.

title: Maura Wogan Sets Nuptials for Jan. 12
description: Maura Jeanne Wogan and Kenneth Ian Schacter, New York lawyers, will be married on Jan. 12. Their engage. ment has been announced by the bridetobe's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Anthony J. Wogan of Hicksville, L.I Mr. Schacter is a son of Mrs. Harriet L. Hirsch of Rye, N.Y., and the late Philip Schacter.

title: Czech Activists Accuse Police
description: VIENNA, Nov. 17 (Reuters)  Czechoslovak dissidents, in a statement issued here, accused the Prague police today of increasing acts of violence and said the actions were unconstitutional. The statement, addressed to civil and military prosecutors, was signed by Jiri Hajek, former Foreign Minister; Denize Tominova and Ladislav Heidanek.

title: IN THE NATION A Taint of Innovation
description: Hard times have a way of shaking people's certainties and opening their minds to new possibilities. Thus, the Great Depression created a receptivity to New Deal programs that would have been unthinkable a decade earlier.

title: New Jersey/ This Week
description: BLOOMFIELD (Bloomfield College, Franklin and Fremont Streets)  Death of a Salesman, in an Actor's CafTheater production. Thursday through Saturday, 8:30 P.M. (through Dec. 15). $3.50$5.50; students and the elderly, 52.5044.50; group rates. (201) 4297662. Westminster Theater.

title: The End of Pax Britannica
description: HAVING been partly educated in the United States (which I never for a moment regret), and therefore brought up on Bull Run and Vicksburg rather than Ladysmith and Mafeking, I have to admit that I have never properly understood what the Boer War was all about; nor, indeed, wanted to find out as a matter of priority. That is, until I read Thomas Pakenham's huge but compellingly readable account of it.

title: HOKE CLINIC Leaking Roof Not Hard to Fix
description: WHEN minor leaks develop on a flat roof, the homeowner can often make the necessary repairs without too much difficulty.

title: Memphis School Trains Truckers
description: MEMPHIS, Nov. 17 (AP)  What do you do when you see a car with a student driver sign on it? Give it room.

title: Realty News
description: The law firm of Beinhauer, Rouhana and Pike is moving from the World Trade Center to One State Street.

title: GARDENING Providing Winter Security for Plants
description: WINTER protection is essential for many ornamentals. Without it, they may be killed or severely damaged by extreme cold and fluctuating temperatures or by strong, desiccating winds. Hungry rodents and deer also pose a threat to certain plants.

title: Iran Decree and Carter Reply
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP)  Following is an unofficial translation of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's decree ordering the release of female and black hostages from the American Embassy in Teheran, and the text of a White House statement in response. The Iranian decree was broadcast by the Teheran radio and monitored in London.

title: Innovation: Up and Away, Or Just Around and Around?
description: WASHINGTON  Handwringing over America's putative loss of technological prowess is as perennial as cherry blossoms in Washington; every President since Herbert Hoover has had it studied. Now the Carter Administration, claiming to be the first actually to do something, has proposed a modest agenda to rectify a widely perceived and widely lamented lag in American industrial innovation. Last week, doubts were raised in a Senate committee whether even those proposals are on target.

title: A Developer's Plan to Preserve Land
description: PATRICIA HUBBELL'S artile, A Grim View of a Farmless Connecticut, [Opinion Page, Sept. 9], seemed to say that Connecticut's rarming nentage would soon be thing of the past and that we should pack up our bags and leave. I, for one, lost my heart to Connecticut good many years ago. I have lived here all my life, and I propose to stay and to find ways and means of preserving not only Connecticut's farmlands, but also its forests, lakes, rivers and historic buildings.

title: Beauty
description: Christmas time is the Super Bowl of the beauty business. During this highrevenue season, each firm issues its most special  and competitive product offerings of the year.

title: A Carnival of Crisis
description: As in the old movies about mine shaft disasters, the victims are trapped out of sight while a carnival of crisis rages overhead. Menaced by an unstable mob in an ungoverned land, they wait for rescue before the place explodes. The rescuers dig tunnels by every route, through the United Nations, the Arab League, the Elyse Palace, the Vatican. But most of the visible commotion no longer concerns the victims. The vultures of crisis, we among them, seem to have more important business.

title: A Trip to Panda Land for Black and White Answers
description: ROXBURY GEORGE B. SCHALLER bounds across the lawn toward a visitor with great surefootedness. The gentle slope of a Connecticut hillside  even covered with a thin layer of slippery autumn leaves  is no challenge for someone who has climbed the Himalayas.

title: GARDENING Providing Winter Security for Plants
description: WINTER protection is essential for many ornamentals. Without it, they may be killed or severely damaged by extreme cold and fluctuating temperatures or by strong, desiccating winds. Hungry rodents and deer also pose a threat to certain plants.

title: Philip Levine to Marry Laurie Weber in Spring
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Weber of Ardsley, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Laurie Ann Weber, to Philip Levine, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur M. Levine of Fair Lawn, N.J. The wedding is planned for the spring.

title: Federal Prisons Giving Considerations to Muslims
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP)  Federal prisoners who practice Islam, once identified with militant Black Muslim inmates, are getting new consideration from prison officials for their social and religious practices.

title: Deadly Gas Escapes From Train
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 17 (AP)  A small cloud of deadly chlorine gas escaped from a railroad tank car at a Clorox Company plant yesterday, then dispersed naturally over San Francisco Bay, the authorities said. About 20 persons were taken to hospitals because of breathing problems and eye irritations.

title: House Welfare Bill Would Aid Northeast
description: WASHINGTON MEMBERS of the NortheastMidwest Congressional Coalition, backers of the House's new $2.7 billion welfare reform bill, describe it as a modest, compromise plan that neither offends nor excites.

title: ART  20 Years of Will Barnet at Neuberger
description: WILL Barnet has been painting to generally benign notices for many years. As for his graphic work, there can be few print galleries  in Manhattan, at least  that do not carry his pictures of women with cats, as familiar in their way as the imagery of Warhol and Calder. Wellknown as an artist and as a teacher (at the Art Students League and at the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts) Mr. Barnet nevertheless remains slightly apart from the scene.

title: Clarissa Bushman And Charles Ortel Plan August Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard L. Bushman of Newark, Del., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Clarissa L. Bushman, to Charles Kampmann Ortel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Gormley Ortel of New York.

title: In Haute Savoie: The Long Run Down the Vallee Blanche;
description: When the weather is perfect, Daniel Simond, my guide in Chamonix had said, making a circle with his thumb and forefinger, only when it is perfect, then I take you to the Vallee Blanche.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: Frederick Ashton, who turned 75 this autumn, is rapidly becoming the world's greatest choreographer whose ballets New Yorkers are not seeing. This is a sad paradox, since it was in New York that many of Ashton's ballets in the Royal Ballet earned the seal of international reputation. With the British company's absence from New York since 1976 and the current suspension of the Joffrey Ballet  the main repository of Ashton ballets in the United States  as well as the absence of Illuminations from the New York City Ballet, the Ashton repertory has suddenly dropped out of view.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: The Dresden Staatskapelle Orchestra, founded in 1548, is one of the oldest orchestras in the world and has seen such conductom as Herbert von Karajan, Karl Boehm and Seiji Ozawa at its helm at one time or another. However, in the course of its long history, it has never made its way to New York  until this week. This afternoon, at Avery Fisher Hall, the orchestra will make its New York debut, with Herbert Blomstedt conducting. (See Music)

title: Koch Aide Urges End Of Sweeps for Aliens During Census Period
description: Mayor Koch's special adviser on the 1980 census called last week for a moratorium on socalled sweeps by immigration authorities until the April 1980 census was completed.

title: His Age and Two Previous Failures Remain Encumbrances
description: KISSIMEE, Fla.  Ronald Reagan is off and loping, formally in the Presidential race at last. Last week, his first on the road, showed some of the reasons why his candidacy is formidable and why his rivals for the Republican nomination have their work cut out for them. But it did not resolve the doubts about whether, after two decades of discussing public policy in a fundamentally negative way  as catalogue of mistakes or evil moves by government grown too big  the 68yearold conservative can really shift to a style that makes him look knowledgeable and in command.

title: MentalPatient Release Program Leaves Many to Face Harsh Fate
description: The fetid odor of unclean bodies and the grayblue haze of cigarette smoke hang like smog about the destitute clientele of the Men's Shelter on the Bowery in Manhattan.

title: Growing Trend to Use of Firewood Sparks Fears on Supply
description: ELWOOD HOYT is not a newcomer to the wood business. His grandfather established the Eastern Fuel Corporation in Hamden, Conn., in 1868. His father ran the businegs for decades before turning it over to him. But things have changed for wood sellers in the last three generations.

title: N.C.A.A. Suspends 6 Colleges
description: Six universities have been placed on probation by the National Collegiate Athletic Association for the 197980 college basketball season. AlaskaAnchorage, Auburn, Cincinnati, East Carolina, Memphis State and San Francisco are thus ineligible to take part in postseason tournaments or appear on television in N.C.A.A. sponsored games.

title: Texas Defeats T.C.U.
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 17 (AP)  A.J. (Jam) Jones slashed for four touchdowns, two on pitchouts from Donnie Little as Texas defeated Texas Christian, 3510, in Southwest Conference play today.

title: Gems Lose
description: ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 17  I played O.K.

title: Calling a Chauffeur Instead of a Cab
description: Pity the family of four Manhattan dwellers, laden with luggage, who have to catch a plane at Kennedy Airport. A cab will cost them about $23, including tip, and a private limousine $12 to $14 more. They might travel more economWally by catching a minibus service from a midtown hotel or taking the subway system's special Train to the Plane, but they have too many belongings and the children get too restless.

title: Mrs. Carter, in Florida, Warns Iran Authorities
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Nov. 17 (UPI)  Rosalynn Carter, pinchhitting for the President, told cheering Florida Democrats today that those in authority in Iran must understand that the American people hold them accountable for the safety of our fellow citizens.

title: HONE CLINIC Leaking Roof Not Hard to Fix
description: WHEN minor leaks develop on a flat roof, the homeowner can often make the necessary repairs without too much difficulty.

title: The Region
description: Two weeks ago, after a petition drive led by a former candidate for mayor in crimeconscious Newark, the City Council adopted an ordinance it had rejected earlier, setting a minimum of 1,200 patrol officers for the city's police force, about 250 above the current level.

title: Swarthmore Bows To Upsala by 2313
description: Upsala ended the best season in its 54year football history by defeating Swarthmore, 2313, yesterday. The Vikings closed with an 811 wonlosttied record in the 23d season of Coach John Hooper.

title: Hilary Carpenter Hubbard
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Hustace Hubbard Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Hilary Carpenter Hubbard, to Robert Bruce Bennett of Cos Cob, Conn., son of Anne Bennett of Huntington, L.I., and J. B. Bennett of Ocean City, N.J.

title: Jean Fertitta, Ad Executive, Is Married to Leslie R. Riley
description: Jean Mary Fertitta, daughter of Anthony Fertitta of New York and the late Jean Donaldson Meeker of Woodmere, L.I., was married yesterday to Leslie Randolph Riley, son of Mr and Mrs. Leslie Walter Riley Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., and Raleigh, N.C. The Rev. Kenneth Jones performed the ceremony at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: The Oil Crisis: A Need for Facts
description: Robert Sherrill's article The Case Against the Oil Companies (Oct. 19) was the most informative and understandable article on the oil companies place in the energy crisis that I have ever read. It confirms my suspicions that oil companies control the availability of oil, manipulate its price, and reap unjustified profits.

title: Life Experience
description: MAHWAH MONG the lures being usedto attract adult undergraduates to enrollmenthungry colleges and universities, including almost all of the 28 public colleges in New Jersey, are credits for life experience.

title: Plant Workers Reject A 3Year Wage Freeze Proposed by U.S. Steel
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 17  Workers at the American Bridge Company plant in Ambridge, Pa., voted yesterday to reject a threeyear wage freeze proposed by the United States Steel Corporation, which owns the company.

title: U.S. Analysts See Iran's Armed Forces In Disarray
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17  Iran's once highly touted armed services are no longer an effective military force, Defense Department analysts said in interviews this week.

title: RARE DOG FOUND IN JUNKYARD:
description: A Neopolitan mastiff being held by Babette Lewyt of the North Shore Animal League in Port Washington. The dog is a rare breed of ancient lineage and is said to be worth $1,000. It is believed to be one of only a few in United States and will be put up for adoption after obedience training.

title: Canton: More Than a Way Station for China Visitors
description: My wife and I are sitting in a boxy, cramped tour bus, which is zigzagging through hordes of bicycles and honking vainly as it tries to snake through bumpertobumper truck traffic in Canton. We are outbound from our hotel for a skipthrough look at the city from which most Chinese emigrants to the United States have come.

title: Richard Goode Strikes a New Chord
description: Always, for me, Richard looms as one of our most important pianistmusicians, in the line of people who think deeply and inexhaust ibly about music  people like Schnabel, Serkin and Horszowski.

title: Immanuel Velikovsky, Who Wrote Worlds in Collision, Is Dead at 84
description: Immanuel Velikovsky, the Russianborn writer whose theories about colliding planets entertained and outraged the scientific world while mesmerizing millions of science buffs, died yesterday at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 84 years old, and still hard at work on several new volumes.

title: FEMINISM TAKES ANEW TURN
description: In California last month, I went into the office of a television producer who prides himself on being an equal opportunity employer. His new executive assistant was waiting for me. She wanted to talk to me alone before her boss came in. Lovely, in her late 20's or maybe 30ish, dressed for success like a model in the latest Vogue advertisement, she was not just a glorified secretary with a fancy title in a deadend job: The woman she replaced had just been promoted to the position of creative vice president.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THE United States Geological Survey recently reduced from. 13.5 trillion to 4.1 trillion cubic feet its estimate of the recoverable natural gas in the ocean off New Jersey. But even that much could provide a significant economic boon to the state.

title: Karen Thornwell
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward Allison Thornwell Jr. of Atlanta have announced the engagement of their daughter, Karen Kathleen Thornwell, to Manuel Anthony Mky, son of Helena Johnson Hackley of New York and Philip Davidson May of Laguna Beach, Calif. A Jan. 5 weddin2 is planned.

title: 5,000 See DePaul Rally To Beat Seton Hall, 2014
description: Dan Kees, a junior quarterback, connected with Bill Kohl on an 80yard scoring pass with 3 minutes 26 seconds to play to give unbeaten DePaul a 2014 victory over Seton Hall before 5,000 in the Parochial North A playoffs at Pequannock.

title: Physicians and Flushing Hospital Agree on Pact, Averting a Strike
description: The threat of a strike by doctors at Flushing Hospital has been averted by an agreement on a new contract between the hospital and representatives of 78 physicians in training.

title: The Nation
description: In New York City of all places, Ronald Reagan last week formally announced that he was once again after the Republican Presidential nomination. And for his first few days out in the open, the former California Governor's every word and deed seemed calculated to demonstrate that to be 68 years old is not to be infirm, that to be conservative is simply sensible.

title: Country MusicConfusion in Profusion
description: The 1970's will be remembered as, among other things, the decade during which the South was at long last readmitted to the Union. Indeed, the economic ascendancy of tne sun Belt and the political ascendancy of Jimmy Carter prompted some pundits to observe that the South had not simply risen again  it had plumb taken over.

title: Mormon Leader Has Surgery
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 17 (AP) Spencer W. Kimball, president of the Mormon Church, underwent successful surgery today for an accumulation of fluid in his skull, a church spokesman said. Mr. Kimball, who is 84 years old, will spend three days in intensive care and probably two weeks in the hospital, according to a spokesman for the Church of Jesus Christ of Latterday Saints.

title: Shows and Events
description: Wednesday  Identification Day at the Newark Musuem, 49 Washington Street, Newark. Curators will identify paintings, sculpture, coins, decorative arts and ethnological, classical or Oriental objects. No charge, but a limit of three objects a person. Appraisals will not be given. Hours: Noon to 2 P.M. Parking, at a small fee, is available behind the museum. For information, call (201) 7336600.

title: Frenzied Market For Major Art
description: For the art world, the beginning of November produced a bonanza. Impressionist, modern and postWorld War H art auctioned in New York fetched prices undreamed of just a few months before. And it registered gains that were greater even than most of the other tangible investments that have been rocketing upwards recently as investors seek refuge from inflation.

title: Changes in Celtics Reviving Cowens
description: John Y. Brown is the Governorelect of Kentucky, Bob McAdoo is playing for the Detroit Pistons, Coach Dave Cowens is now Capt. Dave Cowens and the Boston Celtics have won 12 of their first 16 games.

title: Now the Subject Is Frank D. Gilroy
description: There seems to be an idea that I completely abandoned the theater these past 11 years. Not so. I've been writing plays all the time. And any playwright who tells you that when he has an idea for a play he doesn't sit down and write it is absolutely kidding you. You can't stop doing it. It's a desire, a compulsion, a joy.

title: U.S.Korean Naval Exercise Set
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 17 (Reuters)  South Korea and the United States will hold a weeklong antisubmarine exercise off southeast Korea beginning tomorrow, the Combined Forces Command of the two nations announced here today. The exercise follows a threeday combined operation that began last Tuesday involving air force, marine and army units of the two allies

title: Sewanhaka, Farmingdale in Rematch
description: Farmingdale blanked Hicksville, 220, yesterday for the 17th straight victory for the Conference I Division A champions. Coach Don Snyder's team scored 200 points this season and gave up only 12.

title: U.S. Funds Go to Towns Said to Lack Real Needs
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Ann Bates to Be Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. O. Frederick Bates of Hinsdale, Ill., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ann Flint Bates, to Eric W. Tillman, son of Mr. and Mrs. William L. Tillman of Rye, N.Y. Miss Bates is assistant to the designer of Christy Associates, interior designers in New York, and Mr. Tillman is on the faculty of the Christchurch (Va.) School. The couple are graduates of Ohio Wesleyan University. The wedding is planned for June 28 in Hinsdale.

title: Ocean Grove: Back to the Drawing Board
description: WASHINGTON AFTER 109 years of living under its own set of laws, the tiny seashore community of Ocean Grove last week lost its lastditch battle to keep those laws and the type of government that made them.

title: ON THE ISLE
description: There's nothing like an oldfashioned Thanksgiving, circa the 1850's. And to get things started early, residents of the Old Bethpage Village Restoration start cooking up a traditional storm in the village's quaint openhearthed kitchen today. Then, from Friday through next Sunday, the costumecrowd inhabitants will turn their attention to preserving and storing late fall crops and showing visitors how they would have hunted had they been around on the Island a century ago. The village, on Round Swamp Road, is open from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Tuesdays through Fridays; 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. weekends; closed Thanksgiving Day. Admission is $2.75; children $1.50; Nassau residents $2.25, $1.25, respectively. 4205280.

title: Dance: 4 by Miss Sorkin
description: It takes a brave soul  perhaps even an arrogant one  to dance a program of solos. Gesture and projection are nearly all, and neither seems the province of dance today. Naomi Sorkin. a former member of the American Ballet Theater and Eliot Feld Ballet, is the rare dancer who has gone ahead and tried the genre. The body and face were less than ballerinaperfect, that first instant out on stage for an evening of solo dance presented by the Dance Umbrella at Camera Mart/Stage One on Wednesday. Then, with the unfolding of an arm, luxuriously, into that huge and vivid empty space, the stage was filled with an unusual, quietly impressive presence.

title: HIGHLIGHTS
description: Just last month, the Chrysler Corporation stunned the nation when it an. nounced that it would lose more than $1 billion this year and asked for a Fed. eral bailout. Chrysler's illness has been treated in isolation, but last week it be came apparent that the virus had spread through the domestic industry.

title: Cameroon's Unexpected Pleasures
description: Lameroon seems an improbable destination for a tourist. Nestled in the great bend of the west coast of Africa, at the very place where west and central Africa join, it is rarely noticed by much of the world. There are no charters to take you there. You have to get a whole battery of shots before you go. There are few paved roads. The State Department advises against drinking the water. There is no television. And there are no McDonald's. But unexpected pleasures await the traveler: the rich folk art of the Bamoun tribe in the town of Foumban, the unspoiled beaches of Krlbi, the sight of wild animals in their natural habitat.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: The Laurentian String Quartet, in residence at Sarah Lawrence College, will perform a quartet by Mendelssohn (Op. 44, No. 2) and one by Mozart (K. 156), at 4:30 today in the West Center Congregational Church, Pondfield Road West and Chatfield Road, Bronxville.

title: Will the Jets Predictably Stick to Ground?
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 17  His name is Gary H. and he is a Jet fan. He still remembers Joe Namath tossing the ball 35 times a game, but he also remembers loss after loss.

title: The Onliest Ones
description: HROUGHOUT most of its history in this country, the Communist Party has been associated with pure, unadulterated evil In the public mind. The very thought of it is enough to send nor malty responsible people  especially liberal intellectuals who came of age in the 1930's into paroxysms of vituneradon And no wonder: By twistiruz basic human ideals into a rationale for despotism, the Cornmunists made idealism itself suspect. Given such monumental perversity, it is easy to overlook the fact that at certain times and in certain places  and for certain individuals  the Communist Party has been an important force for progress and justice.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: The second annual Pequot Running Club Thanksgiving Day Race is to start at 9 A.M. at the Wakeman Memorial Association on Center Street in Southport. Put the turkey in the oven and run, urged a spokesman for the event, and 1,000 entrants have already signed up, many of them women. Children under 9 years of age may not enter.

title: Article 5 -- No Title
description: Article 5 -- No Title

title: FINDING FAULT WITH THE TESTERS
description: The WLC Model 300 Sheet Scanner looks like an oversized homemovie projector, except that it sits on top of a computer with pale blue sides and lots of brightly colored buttons, and what passes through it are answer sheets for standardized tests. The sheets are covered with hundreds of circles, some of which have been filled in by students working with No. 2 pencils, and the sheets click in and out of the machine at the rate of one sheet every 0.2 seconds, 300 every hour, 10 million every year.

title: Headliners
description: Mormons for E.R.A.? How about Astronauts for a Flat Earth? However improbable it seems, there are Mormons who support the Equal Rights Amendment, despite the official opposition of their church, and one such is Sonia Johnson, who says her organization, Mormons for E.R.A., has about 500 members who press for adoption of the amendment. Last week, two young men from the local Mormon congregation in Sterling Park, Va., showed up on the doorstep to summon Sonia Johnson to a bishop's court being convened to consider the relationship between your church membership and your conduct during the past months. Mrs. Johnson, who has said The church is the basic thing in my life, also says she really believes she faces excommunication. Mormon officials have declined to comment, but she is certainly in for a careful examination; the bishop of her congregation is Jeffery Willis, who is, in civil life, chief of personnel for the Central

title: On Bummy Davis
description: At the age of 7 he was working as lookout for his father's speakeasy in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn. At 12 he was selling fruit and vegetables and berries in season from a pushcart on Blake Avenue. Business competition was lively on Blake Ave.. and many competitors were twice his size. He learned to use his fists because he had to. When he was 14 or 15 he started boxing in the bootleg amateurs. Because he was under age he concealed his identity, boxing as Giovanni Pascone in clubs like the Golden City Park Arena in Canarsie, Ridgewood Grove and Ardley Palace. The standard pay for an amateur on the bootleg circuit was a watch, which he sold back to the promoter for cash. Giovanni Pascone had earned and disposed of enough watches to fill Cartier's window when an amateur boxing official overhead him and his father in animated conversation in Yiddish. That was how Albert Abraham Davidoff blew his cover.

title: A Model Family From Ridgewood
description: RIDGEWOOD THERE they sit, the Baker family, not looking quite like your runofthemill family next door. Ken Baker and his daughters, Kim and Tanya, are all professional models, and there is no getting around it: They are beautiful.

title: Army to Raise Schooling Aid to Lure Combat G.I.'s
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP)  The Army will soon offer high quality young volunteers increased educational benefits of up to $6,000 to enlist in the infantry or other combat branches. At the same time, the Army is planning to broaden its testing of a twoyear enlistment, a year shorter than the present minimum term.

title: U.S. Builders of Negev Airfields Race Clock
description: IN THE NEGEV, Israel  American engineers and construction crews, with laborers from Portugal and Thailand, have arrived in the heart of the Negev to begin building two air bases to replace military fields Israel is giving up as it withdraws from Sinai under the peace treaty with Egypt.

title: HOME CLINIC Leaking Roof Not Hard to Fix
description: WHEN minor leaks develop on a flat roof, the homeowner can often make the necessary repairs without too much difficulty.

title: Sunday Observer
description: I am often asked to reveal my secrets for saving time. My answer is: You have to work at it. Start early in the morning, at 9 or 10 o'clock, the minute you are out of bed, and keep your eye on the clock every second thereafter. Let me illustrate with my savings chart from a typical Sunday, which was Oct. 28, 1979.

title: Does the American Conductor Have a Future?
description: Acouple of weeks ago Riccardo Muti gave his first concert in New York since being elevated to the post of musicdirectorelect of the Philadelphia Orchestra. About the same time, Lorin Maazel announced that he was taking over the Vienna State Opera in 1982and would thus give up his post as music director of the Cleveland Orchestra.

title: Plan for Klan Rally
description: VINELAND WITH two events scheduled for the same hour next Saturday, Mayor Patrick R. Fiorilli is hoping that one will outdraw the other by 5,000 to 15.

title: For the Automobile, the End of the Road
description: The automobile came of age when oil was priced at less than $2 a barrel and supplies seemed inexhaustible. The spectacular 7 percent annual growth in world oil output between 1950 and 1973 was closely paralleled by the 6 percent annual growth in automobile production. But now this golden age for the automobile appears to be coming to an end. In recent years growth in both oil output and automobile output have been slowing. All signs indicate that world oil production will not expand much further.

title: Beth McDonald Wed to Nicholas Wyman
description: At the Church Center for the United Nations yesterday, Beth M. McDonald, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William R. McDonald of Western Springs, IIl., was married to Nicholas A. Wyman, son of Marjory R. Moran and Oliver A. Wyman, both of New York. The Rev. B. Gail Joralemon, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony.

title: SocialService Aid Shifting to Elderly
description: WHITE PLAINS SOCIAL service expenditures in Westchester are changing character, shifting toward increased medical assistance to the elderly and away from forms of public assistance more traditionally associated in the public mind with welfare, home relief and aid to dependent children.

title: Energizing the New Season
description: FROM Maine to California the nation's ski areas are bracing for the coming season by attacking the problem energy. Their plans range from running snowmaking equipment more efficiently to encouraging car pools and operating shuttle bus services for skiers wary of gasoline shortages.

title: Penn State Topples Temple
description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Nov. 17 Penn State rallied to defeat stubborn Temple, 227, before 76,000 fans today and immediately accepted a bid to play Tulane in the Liberty Bowl on Dec. 22.

title: 31 Food Establishments Are Cited for Violations
description: The New York City Department of Health has listed 31 food establishments as health code violators.

title: Faster Boats Pose New Risks
description: The gauge showed that the propeller was turning at 12,000 revolutions per minute. The boat was ripping across Seattle's Lake Washington at 220 miles per hour. For a few seconds, Dean Chenoweth was the fastest man afloat. Then the boat shuddered, shot out of the water, flipped, smashed into splinters and sank.

title: U.S. Rule on Energy Use Has an Uncertain Impact
description: George . Lillie was sitting behind the desk of his large Rockefeller Center office. It was a brisk fall day, one of the first during which Mr. Lillie will be responsible for holding down the heat in the city's largest office complex to the federally set level of 65 degrees.

title: Chaucer Tales Beget A Cinderella Story
description: ROSLYN HEIGHTS IT'S a literary Cinderella story right on the Island: middleaged suburban housewife (and parttime professional student) sells her first novel to a major publisher for $40,000. And now, just weeks after Going to Jerusalem, a contemporary retelling of Chaucer's Canterbury Tales, hit the bookstores, Judith Bruder is keeping her fingers crossed, hoping that the same bestseller lightning that struck Evergreen and Belva Plain, another suburban first novelist, will come her way, too.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Business Editor: The article The Money Lenders Are Hurting. (Nov. 11) has caused great concern to the management of the Dime Savings Bank of New York and unnecessary worry to many of our depositors.

title: Colombians Vigorously Debate Abortion Proposal
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Poets Don't Run Out of Gas
description: Walt Whitman avenged its loss at the State Public High School championships last week by winning the title yesterday in the sixth annual New York State Federation crosscountry championships at Saratoga Spa State Park.

title: Associated Press
description: RESCUE FROM CRASH: A passerby removing a youth from the burning wreckage of two cars that collided early Yesterday on a Los Angeles streetAfter crashing, the cars smashed into a restaurant; two persons died, one was injured.

title: Church Is Using TV As a Discussion Aid
description: BEDFORD WHEN the adulteducation committee of a Bedford church was looking for a resource to develop better communications between parents and children, it turned to the favorite communications medium of children television. In an attempt to teach parents how to reach their children, the Bedford Presbyterian Church on the Village Green has invited families to take part in Parent Participation TV Workshops, a nationwide education project aimed at changing television in the home from a conversation deterrent to a talkprovoking tool.

title: GasStation Owners Plan Gasahol Sales
description: SADDLE BROOK IlliNTICIPATING reduced allocations of gasoline as a result of President Carter's decision to bar oil from Iran, more than 100 servicestation owners in Bergen and Passaic Counties will meet here tomorrow to plan for the sale of gasahol as soon as possible.

title: Richard P. Schram And Jean Rosaler Plan Jan. 20 Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Rosaler of Ardsley, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jean Alice Rosaler, to Richard Paul Schram of San Francisco. He is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Louis Schram of Wilmette, III.

title: Harvard Upsets Yale, 227
description: NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 17  A Harvard team that had lost six of its eight games beat previously undefeated and untied Yale today in a game that was not even close. The Elis went down, 227, before a crowd of 72,000, the largest crowd in the Yale Bowl for a Yale contest in 25 years.

title: Major News
description: As 62 Americans neared the end of their second week as captives of Iran's Islamic revolution, the revolution's father announced that he was taking a twoweek vacation. He was feeling slight fatigue, aides to the 79yearold Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini said and, besides, there was nothing to discuss. The hostages would stay until Washington gave up the deposed and ailing Shah.

title: Deploying The Oil Weapon
description: WASHINGTON  In a phrase that has become almost a clich in energy circles, the world demand and supply of oil is balanced on a knife edge. The phrase has been used over and over again here by the Carter Administration, a British Cabinet minister, a top official of the Common Market and the Saudi Oil Minister, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani.

title: GALLERY VIEW
description: Pittsburgh, in most of the arthistory books, means the Carnegie International: a multinational exhibition with a multinational jury that was responsible among much else for the first visit of Henri Matisse to this country. The Carnegie International had its ups and downs, but it was a serious and disinterested attempt to bring the best new art from all over the world to people who might otherwise have known nothine about it.

title: FILM VIEW
description: Several years ago a friend whom I trust in such matters said that every time I described a movie as pleasant she suspected that what I wanted to say was that the movie was wellintentioned but uneventful and not really much good. She wasn't far off the mark. I found that when I described a movie or a performance as pleasant I was, without being aware of it, attempting to be polite, as if it were an occasion not worthy of rudeness. A horse movie like The Black Stallion is such a film. It contains some pretty scenery, one effective shipsinking sequence, a boyhorse relationship that is, I suppose, positive, and a happy performance by Mickey Rooney.

title: West Islip Is Defeated By Sachem
description: Sachem, whose only loss during the regular season was to West Islip, came back yesterday to defeat the Lions, 197, to win the Suffolk AAA championship for the third straight year. The loss was West Islip's first in eight games this season.

title: Regan Urges L.I.R.R. To Cut Ticket Sellers To Save Line Millions
description: State Comptroller Edward V. Regan asserted yesterday that the Long Island Rail Road's ticketselling operation was extremely inefficient and that a revamping and paring of the staff could save approximately $1.5 million a vear.

title: OneMan Law Firm Serves Students Free
description: EWING TOWNSHIP UNDERGRADUATES at Trenton State College can drop in at their Student Center just about any time of the day and buy food, a book or a bar of soap, watch TV, have a beeror see a lawyer.

title: GARDENING Providing Winter Security for Plants
description: WINTER protection is essential for many ornamentals. Without it, they may be killed or severely damaged by extreme cold and fluctuating temperatures or by strong, desiccating winds. Hungry rodents and deer also pose a threat to certain plants.

title: Ithaca Gains Final
description: ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 17  Topseeded Ithaca College advanced to the Eastern Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women Northeast Regional field hockey final by defeating C.W. Post, 60, today.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: Old Maroon vs. Old Blue, at RandalIs Is land, 1:30 P.M.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Stock up on quality bird food for the winter months . Cut mums to the ground . Last call to plant hardy bulbs; they are better in the ground than left forgotten in the tool shed . Lightly prune roses if canes are unwieldy to prevent winter wind damage.  . This is a good time to transplant shade trees and deciduous shrubs . Feed dogwoods with high phosphorus fertilizer . Cleanup perennial borders; cut to the ground yellowed stalks.

title: ANTIQUES
description: PALISADES, N.Y. WHEN I bought the building in 1935,' Tippy O'Neil recalled, I used to tell people how to get here with directions like, You go straight for a couple of miles and then turn left at the big oak tree.

title: Do What I Say, Not What I Do
description: ONE of the most puzzling characteristics of our state legislators is their refusal to live by the standards they impose on everyone else.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, a song described in Robert Trumbull's story, Exploring the Other Hawaii (Travel Section, Nov. 4), was mistitled Alaska Falls. The correct title of the song is Akaka Falls.

title: Mailbox: Zoom In on Wildlife
description: A humane alternative is now present for those who enjoy the outofdoors, observing and tracking wildlife in all seasons. This alternative would allow animals to continue living, so all could enjoy seeing them. It can eliminate the dangers of people roaming around private and public lands with highcaliber weapons, endangering others who would also like to roam the woods safely in fall and winter. It can begin to lessen the peoplephobic conditioning many animals now have for selfpreservation to stay out of sight of all (including wildlife lovers) for fear of being destroyed.

title: Fancy Detection
description: The subtitle is a bit of a misnomer, and those who believe the jacket blurb's statement that the book contains an eloquent discourse on the relation of detective fiction to literary tradition are going to be disappointed. A mystery is a mystery is a mystery, David Grossvogel might say, and by its nature cannot be solved. His subjects are Sophocles Oedipus, Dostoyevsky, Camus, Pirandello, Borges, Kafka, RobbeGrillet and, sandwiched between them, Poe and Agatha Christie. The two last are the only writers of what are generally called mystery stories, and Poe is dealt with solely in relation to The Purloined Letter. Agatha Christie is there as an awful example of the mystery's degeneration. Professor Grossvogel's thesis is that man, unable either to grasp or to abandon mystery  inyents incar4ations with Which he can cope. Such incarnations are essentially ritualistic, and their lasting t sonance springs from a refusal accept logical solutions. The lution of the riddle in Oedipus and the murder in The Brothers Karamazov are used as instances of human duality, so that the mystery appears to be resolvable without being resolved. The meaning of The Trial, it is suggested, is that life goes beyond logic, a premise accepted by logical, reasonable K, who goes as far as to abet the conspiracy of which he is a victim. Such writers as Jorge Luis Borges and Alain RobbeGrillet have used the framework of a detective puzzle for ends very different from those of Christie and her kind. For Borges a labyrinth must remain a labyrinth  the quest is important, not the solution at the center of the maze.

title: K.G.B.'s Knight Unhorsed
description: Sir Anthony Blunt, K.C.V.O., distinguished art historian and retired traitor, was exposed last week as secret agent who spied for the Russians while he was picking out paintings for the Oueen.

title: When Composers Make the Grand Gesture
description: What goes into the making of a Major Musical Statement? This esthetic question has been hotly debated for centuries and the argument usually runs to two extremes. At one end there are those analysts who claim an extramusical significance for every note in Beethoven's Eroica Symphony, a work that for them conjures up sound images of Napoleon, the French Revolution and the entire Age of Enlightenment. On the other side of the coin, a pragmatist like Toscanini will dismiss such fancies and maintain that the Eroica means only one thing  Allegro con brio, the tempo indication of the first movement.

title: Uli Rose
description: Uli Rose

title: Other Ideas &
description: The case of Mark Rothko is now closed. After years of legal wrangling, final disposition of the artist's estate has been determined and executed. The Mark Rothko Foundation, established by the artist 1969, will receive between $20 and $23 million, the bulk of this in the artist's own works; Dr. Kate Rothko Prizel and her brother Christopher Rothko, the artist's children, will divide the remaining $40 million. Mr. Rothko, a leader of the Abstract Expressionist school, committed suicide in 1970. His daughter successfully sued the estate's executors, Marlborough Galleries and its head, Frank Lloyd. The court agreed they had contracted in a shocking manner to sell 798 Rothko paintings for a fraction of their worth, and fined each party several million dollars.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: Given the present interest in the dance, this book should be assured of an audience. Erik Bruhn is one of the outstanding dance figures of the 20th century, and audiences lucky enough to have seen him treasure their memories. For serious ballet fans probably the most interesting part of this biography is the material on the influence of August Bournonville, the 19thcentury Danish equivalent of George Balanchine. His career is undergoing a reassessment just now, 100 years after his death; there have been contemporary revivals of his work, and a new translation of his autobiography, My Theatre Life, was recently published. Mr. Bruhn is the choreographer's most distinguished heir and interpreter, and his descriptions of Bournonville training are fascinating.

title: More of The Same
description: Saveteran reader of historical novels, I am no stranger to the Indian mutiny of 1857. 1 don't even need M. M. Kaye's handy glossary to remind me that the Bibigurh (women's house) I was the site of a notorious massacre of Angreziiog oiritisn people) particularly of the women and children. But that doesn't mean I'm tired of reading about it. The Sepov Mutiny is one of those historical episodes that has everything, and M. M. Kaye is a fabulist who splices into it a romance that has even more. (More of different stuff, that is.) season, pick up the story of Winter de Ballesteros, an AngloSpanish heiress born in India and orphaned in infancy. Winter is sent home to England and shipped back to India at 16 by a wicked aunt. Auntie has connived to marry her off to a gross fortunehunter who is a district commissioner for the East India Company.

title: REAGAN WINS A POLL OF G.O.P. IN FLORIDA
description: KISSIMMEE, Fla., Nov. 17  Ronald Reagan blunted an allout challenge by John B. Connally today and defeated him in a Presidential straw poll at the Florida Republican Convention.

title: New York Farms Earned Record $2.1 Billion in 78
description: ALBANY, Nov. 15  The gross income of New York State farmers in 1978 totaled more than $2 billion, the highest since farm statistics have been kept in the state, according to figures made available this week by the New York Crop Reporting Service.

title: Iran Buys Ad to Explain Its Position on Hostages
description: Iran is running a fullpage advertisement in today's issue of The New York Times containing the 3,500word text of onehour Iranian television address delivered Nov. 10 by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini. In the speech, the Ayatollah rejected a plea by the papal representative in Iran for the release of the hostages held in the American Embassy in Teheran.

title: Stanhouse Gets Dodgers' Pact
description: With free agents seemingly receiving lucrative contracts as quickly as they can get, in line for them, Don Stanhouse became baseball's newest millionaire yesterday by agreeing to a fiveyear contract with the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: Growth SlowPaced In Squash Racquets
description: For the last 20 years they've been saying the squash boom was just around the corner, said Clive Caldwell, the president of the World Professional Squash Association. The growth has been steady and slow.

title: Luxury Tower Is Not Above a Rent Strike
description: The Sovereign, the 48story luxury apartment building that has marble bathrooms and some of Manhattan's highest prices, is in the throes of a problem common to more modest buildings.

title: Where Did All the MiniSeries Go?
description: The miniseries  usually the focal point of the monthlong sweeps during which the ratings people measure the audiences of local stations around the country  is strangely absent this month from the schedules of CBS and NBC. Indeed, ABC's The French Atlantic Affair, a sixhour serialization about a hijacked ocean liner that will end with a twohour episode tonight at 9, is the only miniseries to be seen during the November sweeps.

title: How It Really Is In the Dance World
description: The dance world is frequently depicted in films and fiction as a hotbed of turmoil and intrigue, full of torment, jealousy and fierce struggles for recognition. Both The Red Shoes, a stylish, overblown, highly influential 1948 English film about backstage life at the ballet, and the more recent The Turning Point stress the supposed truism that a career in dance and a normal family life can never mix.

title: Energy Official Is Disappointed By Utilities Conservation Drive
description: The State Energy Commissioner has expressed extreme disappointment with efforts of New York State's electric and gas utilities to promote smallhome energy conservation and insulation.

title: Papal Visit to Manila Held Likely
description: ROME, Nov. 17 (UPI)  Vatican sources said today it was highly probable that Pope John Paul II will visit the Philippines in February. Jaime Cardinal Sin said in Manila that he had urged the Pope to visit Asia in February because it is the only time when there are no typhoons. The sources also said the Pope was still considering a trip to Istanbul, Turkey, for the Nov. 30 celebration of the Feast of St. Andrew.

title: Kennedy Center Halts Sales for Ballet Theater
description: The labor dispute that has locked out dancers of American Ballet Theater for three weeks has postponed today's scheduled start of boxoffice ticket sales for the company's fourweek engagement next month at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington.

title: DuPre and Lutz Win
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Nov. 17 (AP) Pat Dupre beat Bill Scanlon, 61, 63, in an allAmerican semifinal of the $75,000 Grand Prix tennis tournament today.

title: Getting Around Condominiums Pet Peeves
description: ONE of the major dilemmas confronting buyers of condominiurns these days is what to do about the family pet. Whereas dogs, cats and other varieties of household animals may have been given carte blanche to roam the spacious environs of a house and yard, the rules imposed by a sudden transfer to a condominium may have curtailed their freedom considerably.

title: Huskies Keep Alive Rose Hones
description: SEATTLE, Nov. 17 (AP)  Tom Flick threw a 20yard scoring pass to Paul Skansi and Vince Coby ran 3 yards for a touchdown in the second quarter today as Washington remained alive in the Rose Bowl picture with a 177 triumph over Washington State in a Pacific10 Conference game.

title: Thrust &
description: WASHINGTON  To the casual eye, economic warfare has been declared by the United States on Iran. Last week, the Government halted imports of Iranian oil and prevented Iran from removing its assets from American control. To Americans anxious for forceful action to free the 62 American hostages in Teheran, the twin moves on oil and on assets were widely taken to be appropriate pressure. President Carter was deluged with praise.

title: June Wedding Set By Elizabeth Porter
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William E. Porter of Wyckoff, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Porter, to Philip Linton Hawkins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Hawkins of St. Paul. The wedding is planned for June.

title: Rock: Garland Jeffreys
description: Garland Jeffreys has been kicking around the New York rockandroll scene since the mid60's, impressing people with his intense performances, making critically acclaimed albums, and never quite getting his career into high gear. He's survived attention and neglect alike, and often he's taken a scattershot approach to his music that diffused the impact of his considerable talent. But his Friday night show at the Bottom Line was triumphant.

title: Pearl Buck's 7 Adopted Children Win SixYear Battle Over Estate
description: DANBY, Vt., Nov. 17 (UPI)  A sixyear battle over the estate of Pearl Buck, the Nobel Prizewinning author, has been settled to the benefit of Miss Buck's seven adopted children.

title: Ohio State Wins, Gains Rose Bowl
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 17  Ohio State played its way into the Rose Bowl for the first time in four years today on a blocked kick in the fourth quarter that gave the Buckeyes an 1815 victory over Michigan.

title: Megan Edwards Is Betrothed to a Professor
description: The engagement of Megan F. Edwards, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Spencer Edwards of Sierra Madre, Calif., to Dr. Richard D. McKirahan Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. McKirahan of Ridgefield, Conn., has been announced by the future bride's parents.

title: Puerto Ricans Vow to Avenge Death in U.S. Prison
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Nov. 17  Advocates of independence for Puerto Rico have vowed to avenge the death of a Socialist who was found dead in a Federal prison in Florida, where he was serving a sixmonth sentence for trespassing on Navy land while military maneuvers were under way.

title: CETA Layoffs Could Have Been Worse
description: Last week, a member of the State Board of Regents recommended that health aides trained under the Comprehensive Employment and Training Act (CETA) should staff pilot projects in health care in New York City public schools. There would be no cost to the city, he noted.

title: ART VIEW
description: No other decade in the entire history of the modern era quite rivals the 1920's in its mythic appeal. The sheer glamour of the period still exerts a magic spell, and the sheer richness and variety of its accomplishments in every field of artistic endeavor still shape our vision of the culture in which we live. The 20's was a period of buoyant optimism and dour prophecies, of utopian aspirations butting against harsh realities, and the classics that it spawned  from glass skyscrapers to The Waste Land to jazz and the movies  remain, for the most part, the classics by which we live today. In the very pace and texture and scale of the culture of the 20's we recognize the origins of our own world.

title: Alix Weiss Married to Dr. Vernon H. Sharp
description: Alix Ingrid Weiss and Dr. Vernon Hibbett Sharp were married yesterday in the Episcopal Church of the Ascension by the Rev. Donald Goodness. The Rev. Lorene S. White, a sister of the bridegroom and pastor of the Donelson Presbyterian Church in Nashville, assisted.

title: Inflation, a Capitalist Evil, Surfaces in Soviet Union
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 17  Inflation exists only in the West, the Soviet Government keeps assuring people here, but the talk of Moscow these days is how the ruble isn't worth a kopeck anymore.

title: Censorship Medicine
description: Moscow  Somehow it seemed so familiar: first, publication abroad of the memoirs of one of the Soviet Union's most prominent figures, the composer Dmitri D. Shostakovich, with sensational and bitter revelations about the dead and the living, from Stalin down to the reigning head of the composers union, Tikhon N. Khrennikov. Then the inevitable official denials and denunciations of the book as an antiSoviet falsification concocted by enemies of socialism.

title: McEnroe Gains Final In London
description: WEMBLEY, England, Nov. 17 (AP)  John McEnroe swept past Italy's Gianni Ocleppo, 63, 60, in the semifinals of the $175,000 Grand Prix tennis tournament today.

title: Elizabeth Boynton Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Carroll A. Boynton of Pottersville, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Carroll Boynton, to Lawrence A. Allen of Newport, R.I. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Allen of Barrington. R.I.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: ROSLYN THIS column is really about Long Island, I promise, but will take a while to get to the local angle. Let's start by noting that for many years I have felt deep and perhaps even mystical love for Mexico.

title: Showy Discoveries From a Seed Packet
description: Gardeners who become intrigued with succulents soon discover so many different kinds, they are forced to pick and choose. Even if the great cactus group is ruled out, no one could possibly grow all the available kinds there are.

title: LETTERS TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR
description: Suzanne Reade's fine account of the economic plight of the teacher [Teacher Income: The Bottom Line, Opinion Page, Oct. 28] ends with a sentence that expresses, most sincerely, to be sure, the basic reason why teaching is badly underpaid. I am one of the thousands, she writes, who love teaching, but I wonder how much longer any of us can afford to indulge (my italics) ourselves.

title: Around the Nation
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 17 (AP)  A tentative agreement between the Bay Area Rapid Transit system and two anions was reached yesterday, and officials were optimistic that full service would resume within a week for the first time in two and a half months.

title: Connecticut This Week
description: BETHEL  Textile arts from the Hmong and Yao people of Southeast Asia. Wall tapestries, belts, purses, embroidery suitable for clothing, from $25 to $350. Bethel Gallery, 186 Greenwood Ave., noon to 5:30 Wednesday through Sunday, through Nov. 25.7436644.

title: Congdon Publishers Sold to Frenchman
description: A new ihdependent hardcover publisher, Congdon & Lines, is introducing French ownership into general tradebook publishing in the United States.

title: Bachrach
description: Representative and Mrs. James H. Scheuer of New York and Washington have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Helen Scheuer, to Peter Joseph, son of Mr. and Mrs. Marc Joseph of Englewood Cliffs, N.J., and Saltaire, Fire Island, N.Y.

title: The Duke and the Shah
description: As a kid addicted to Saturday movie matinees in the late 1940's, I saw a Western in which John Wayne sacrificed himself to the Indians in order to save the others besieged in the fort. Details are fuzzy, but The Duke. a great American, as we have all been told, was not guilty of the dastardly murder for which the Indians demanded his life. He became a hero though a dead one. He was not above martyrdom.

title: MUSIC Notes From Campus
description: ALL too often we regard university musicmaking as something for students only, and as a result we forget how richly Connecticut's colleges and conservatories are contributing to everybody's esthetic wellbeing. Faculty ensemble concerts, highcaliber student recitals and a remarkable number of campus programs by worldrenowned artists add up to an extraordinary cultural bounty that should not be overlooked.

title: India Team Hurries to Save Temples From Flood
description: HYDERABAD, India  On a promontory at the confluence of two rivers 150 miles from here, teams of workmen have almost dismantled an important seventh century Hindu temple. It is one of 59 temples in the area that archeologists are trying to save from the flood that will come when a hydroelectric dam begins to push back the of waters the Kistna.

title: HONE CLINIC Leaking Roof Not Hard to Fix
description: WHEN minor leaks develop on a flat roof, the homeowner can often make the necessary repairs without too much difficulty.

title: TV VIEW
description: Public television is understandably sensitive to the old charge that it has become a dumping ground for foreign imports, particularly of the British variety. But executives of the system can always claim that the purchases from abroad add undeniable quality to their primetime schedule, ranging from The Forsyte Saga to Glittering Prizes, from the 40odd dramas shown on Masterpiece Theater to the documentaries acquired for the Nova or World series. Still, domestic productions must be given serious attention, and public television, while always strapped for money, is indeed trying. Some recent offerings, however, are no less troubling than is the heavy flow of imports.

title: West Bank Concern Is Terrorism, Not Promoting Political Allegiance
description: JERUSALEM  A military occupation is never pretty, and Israel's is no exception. In the 12 years since Israeli troops smashed Arab armies and captured territory from Syria, Jordan and Egypt, the Jewish state has made few friends among the 1.2 million Palestinian Arabs under its military rule.

title: Tallahassee Feminists and Doctors at Odds
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Nov. 17  Anyone who remembers the 1960's might feel a sense of dj vu in the chaos of pamphlets, posters and communiqus in the sprawling, Mediterranean house near the center of the state capital, so isolated in the Florida Panhandle that people say you can't fly to heaven from here without going through Atlanta.

title: Eastern Facts
description: DON'T be misled by the promising title; this is still not the book Robert Shaplen's readers, either of his Letters from all over Asia in The New Yorker or of his earlier books that were based on them, have been awaiting. The summingup, valedictory promise of the subtitle and introduction, which post the milestones of Mr. Shaplen's distinguished journalistic career in Asia  from walking ashore in Leyte in 1944 to rushing out of Saigon by helicopter in 1975- is not fulfilled.

title: ART Photo ournalism as Art
description: LINCROFT AN EXHIBITION here of photographs taken by the late W. Eugene Smith is very much more than the sum of its 24 chiaroscuro prints. Originating at the George Eastman House in Rochester, N.Y., the pictures are on view in the diminutive Gallery 10 at Brookdale Community College, where they will remain through Nov. 30.

title: Payments Become Way of Track Life
description: The deal is relatively simple, the athlete explained. You buy a special oneway plane ticket from Los Angeles to Corfu, Greece, that costs about $1,000 but allows you almost 10,000 miles of free travel. Then you schedule a series of 10 track meets between the two points, hitting promoters at every stop for maximum expenses that include airfare. Net profit for the trip: about $15,000 and no legal hassles.

title: Emma Lazarus to the Contrary
description: ONE reason the poor will always be with us is that the supply is growing, and heading our way. Within the lifetimes of most people now living, write Loy Bilderback and Paul and Anne Ehrlich, celebrated students of the population explosion.

title: Custom Tailored Sound For the Home
description: In the current film version of Don Giovanni, the tenor in the role of Don Ottavio ambles moodily across open fields, singing his great aria 11 mio tesoro. Mozart's magnificent music notwithstanding, the effect is  as the critics have pointed out ludicrous.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY Thanksgiving Dinner, Unchic Style
description: AN ARTICLE in a recent special section of The New York Times described in loving detail how chic and trendy New Yorkers feed and cosset their fortunate guests.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS A Scepter'd Insularity
description: ARDMORE, Ireland  There have been many funny movie scenes of people trying to walk upstairs on a downgoing escalator. When a government has to do it, the scene is funny only if you are in no way affected by the final outcome. The Bank of England and British Government were seen spectacularly engaged in that excruciating exercise in recent days.

title: The New York Times/John Sotomayor
description: Daniel Murdock, nine days old, being monitored in Long Island screening program on sudden infant death syndrome. Dr. Renu Aggarwall holds the baby as his mother, Christine Murdock, observes. Story on Page 6.

title: How Darien Builds
description: DARIEN THERE aren't many things that get people in Darien excited, said Peter Dayton, one of many commuters in CMS wellIOGO MUM that is characterized more by insouciance than enthusiasm. But Mr. Dayton and thousands of other Darien residents are plenty excited this fall about the undefeated Darien High School football team.

title: Radio
description: 77:30 A.M., WBLS: Tenant Survival Program.

title: Stanley Cloud to Marry Lynne Olson Jan. 5
description: Christine Lynne Olson, White House correspondent for The Baltimore Sun, and Stanley Wills Cloud, assistant managing editor of The Washington Star, will be married on Jan. 5.

title: Births ABELSON
description: Ronnie and Chuck Abelson (nee Sachs) proudly announce the birth of their daughter Marisa Julie on October 13, 1979.

title: Theater: Recent Ruins,  A Meredith Monk Work
description: For all the backlash early in this century against Richard Wagner's idea of a total work of art, there have been some fascinating attempts to redefine and extend his notion by New York artists in the last decade. Robert Wilson is the best known, and still at his best the most compelling. But for sheer literalness in interpreting the idea of an artwork by one person that extends through all mediums, Meredith Monk must surely take the prize.

title: At the Mad Fringes of Art
description: LARRY RIVERS is one of the most fascinating personalities of the last 30 years in art, and if you would like to get to know him here's your chance. Besides over 300 reproductions, about a fourth of them in color, this sumptuous volume features an autobiographical text, edited from tapes by Carol Brightman, which is as revealing and entertaining as any in the literature of artists talking. It is a document, full of slightly scandalous anecdote, that tells of survival in the New York art world  and at its maddest edges, where artistic and personal ambition, esthetics and career tactics, art and life mingle in a social milieu that is a hall of distorting mirrors. The terPeter Schjeldahl is a New York poet and critic. His latest book is Since 1964: New and Selected Poems. rible human costs of persistence in such a world, where ego is the only dependable reality (if you have a weak one, forget it), are implicit in the book, but so are the great fun and sense of spiritual election, of being a gang member in the boiler room of modern culture.

title: Fiorello! Shines at Paper Mill
description: MILLBURN THE name is La Guardia. And, astonishingly, so are the billowing jowls, the accordionpleat forehead and the voice that sounds like Donald Duck clamping a megaphone to his bill and quacking against Tammany Hall's tyranny.

title: Lawsuit Vowed on Nassau Beach Cabanas
description: LIDO BEACH THE summer heat of battle to improve Nassau Beach lingers on as wintertime approaches. The Committee to Save Nassau Beach voted at a recent meeting to file a lawsuit against Nassau County and its Board of Supervisors if an acceptable proposal for a renovation program for the beach is not presented to the committee by Dec. 3.

title: Paperback Best Sellers
description: Massmarket paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computerprocessed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 90,000 outlets across the United States.

title: DINING OUT Experiments Yield Some Success
description: THE Pewter Horn is a promising small restaurant in CrotononHudson with betterthanaverage food, an engaging staff and the oldhouse comfort that can make Westchester dining so pleasant.

title: Complacency about houses near a nuclear power plant. Page 18.
description: SHORTLY before the nuclear accident at Three Mile Island in Pennsylvania earlier this year, Maynard and Harriet Addato of Bloomfield had put down a deposit on a house in Lanoka Harbor, Lacey Township, not far from the Oyster Creek nuclear plant.

title: Thanksgiving Day Proclamation
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (UPI) Following is the text of President Ccirter's Thanksgiving Day proclamation:

title: Associated Press
description: NEW HAT: Convention Hall in Atlantic City is being topped with a new roof for the first time in 50 years. The job, which will cost the city $1 million, is being done by the same company that installed the original roof.

title: Chinese Memories
description: THE place is Lintung, a hotsprings spa in North China on the road to Mongolia. The setting is the fairytale palace built for the pleasure of the emperors of the Tang Dynasty, which ruled the great Confucian empire from the 7th to the 10th century. The time is the summer of 1927, a year of cataclysmic political upheaval created by the violent rivalries of two hostile wings of the Kuomintang (Nationalist Party), two opposed wings of the Chinese Communist Party, and a congeries of warlords  all frightfully complicated by the intervention of the Comintern on behalf of Moscow, where Joseph Stalin was having his own problems with Leon Trotsky, and the ineffectual efforts of Western nations to stem the revolutionary tide on behalf of their citizens with financial interests in China.

title: Cornell Six Looms As Best in the East
description: Cornell University, whose alumnus, Ken Dryden, earned more credibility for Eastern college hockey than any other player, should be the East's best team for the season that begins in earnest this week.

title: Pacing Series at Roosevelt Is Captured by Philabuster
description: WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 17  By the margin of a bobbing head, Philabuster won the final of the Silver Spoon pacing series at Roosevelt Raceway tonight, and stamped himself this year as the best 2yearold bred in New York I thought I won by more, said his driver, Norman Duplaise. My wheels seemed to be well ahead of the other horse's.

title: ALBANY COURT RULES A WIFE MUST TESTIFY
description: The New York State Court of Appeals ruled last week that a woman who had sued for $6 million in damages after her husband died in a 30story plunge could invoke neither the doctorpatient privilege nor the conjugal privilege to prevent those she had sued from asking her questions about her husband's mental condition.

title: HARLEM GETS U.S. AID FOR HEALTH CENTERS
description: Federal financing for four neighborhood health centers in Harlem, an area that health officials say has New York City's worst health problems, was announced yesterday by Mayor Koch and Representative Charles B. Rangel.

title: Editors' Choice
description: THE MAN WHO KEPT THE SECRETS, by Thomas Powers. (Knopf, $12.95.) The life of Richard Helms  who spent 30 years in the spy business, seven of them as head of the Central Intelligence Agency  serves as an ideal pathway through the secret history of our times.

title: The Diction of the Slums
description: LOVEJOY is the name of an allblack town on the banks of the Mississippi that its residents persist in calling Brooklyn, much as the Avenue of the Americas is still Sixth Avenue. Many people in the surrounding area, Elin Schoen writes in her first 7 and still are. although its glamour days are oast. Tales of an AllNight Town invites comparison with Norman Mailer's The Executioner's Song. Both books take essentially the same choral approach to their material, letting the voices of the characters do the heavy work of shaping the narrative. Like Mailer in Provo, Utah, Miss Schoen conveys the language and idiom of the streets and roadhouses of Lovejoy, Ill., so convincingly that her story actually seems to be told from the inside out. We are made witnesses to a community arriving at a complex and subtle understanding of its own passions; the truth emerges only in the sum of each citizen's partial knowledge of the whole.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: Gertrude Dubrovsky's article on nursing homes [Nov. 4] put its finger on a problem that has long been ignored: the need to keep nursinghome patients active and gregarious.

title: THE LIVELY ARTS Sondheim Again, Even Better
description: FARMINGDALE SIDE by Side by Sondheim, cornucopia of Stephen Sondheim's songs, was packaged by Ned Sherrin for British consumption. Missionary work for the cause of Sondheim is one way Mr. Sherrin expressed the musical entertainment's purpose; a celebration is another.

title: Ogaden War Producing Little but Refugees
description: Special to The New York Times

title: A Shop in Westport That Takes the Cake
description: WESTPORT ALL of Antionette Hyde's friends had jobs, and when her two sons graduated from school, she wanted something to do, too.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: SPURRED by a twoyear study it did of ethics in American higher education, the Hastings Center, a research and educational organization in HastingsonHudson, is looking into professional ethics in a variety of fields, according to Daniel Callahan. the center's director.

title: Opera: Mahagonny at the Met
description: The WeillBrecht Rise and Fall of the City of Mahagonny came to the Metropolitan Opera Friday night, and at least one question about the work was answered. There were those who predicted that Mahagonny. with its cabaret roots, smallish orchestra and jazz elements, would not go in a house as big as the Met's. It does. Whether or not it is an opera, and Weill strongly insisted that it is, it does use voices skillfully, it has a big chorus, and it was not lost on the stage of the big house.

title: Giants' 4 Stack Up With Best
description: They are the backers, and no one gives nicknames like Fearsome Foursome or Steel Curtain to linebackers, even when they are the most noticeable defensive players, even when they may be the best in the National Football League.

title: One Potato, Fast Potato
description: It must be one of those things that's obvious but isn't. Hamburgers sell like hot potatoes. So do tacos, chicken, roast beef and pizza. The fastfood business is so refined now that there are chains specializing in nothing but salad. So why not hot, baked Idaho potatoes?

title: Sally Bishop Gilmore Engaged
description: The engagement of Sally Bishop Gilmore to Randolph Davies Barranger has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William H. Gilmore of Westfield, N.J. Mr. Barranger is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Barranger of Roanoke, Va. A wedding is planned in March. Miss Gilmore is an alumna of the Kent Place School and Weithampton College of the University of Richmond. Her fianc was graduated from the College of William and Mary.

title: Future Events
description: Ticket to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated.

title: EXSPY FOR RUSSIANS IN HIDING IN BRITAIN
description: LONDON, Nov. 17  Anthony Blunt, the aristocratic art scholar and curator who was unmasked Thursday as a top Soviet spy, has gone into hiding somewhere in Britain.

title: STAMPS
description: Wiley Post, a largerthanlife aviation pioneer of the 1930's who broke speed record after speed record in the days before supersonic flight, is being commemorated with a vertical pair of 25cent international airmail stamps coming out this Tuesday at Oklahoma City.

title: DINING OUT Italian Vibrancy and Value
description: BEFORE assuming that decent food at reasonable prices in pleasant surroundings is a thing of the past, try Sta Via in Port Washington. The restaurant opens off a pizzeria with which it shares the kitchen, but this is more than a newly expanded pizza parlor, as the sign Ristorante clearly asserts. Carpeting, curtains, tablecloths, wines and a menu that often ventures beyond the robust tomatosauce specialties of southern Italy suggest a certain northern accent.

title: BEHIND THE BEST SELLERS
description: When Robert Stobaugh organized the Harvard Business School's Energy Project back in 1972, he expected that one or more scholarly books would result from the research. What he did not expect was that one of the books would become a nationwide best seller with a flashy blue and orange jacket, and would go to seven printings with 106,000 copies in print. The book is Energy Future, and it carries the subtitle, Report of the Energy Project at the Harvard Business School.

title: Columbia Crushed By Brown
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 17Coach Bill Campbell's longshot hope of a victory from his Columbia team as a goingaway present were jolted today as the Lions were routed by Brown, 3114, in the season's finale.

title: Nassau Budget Expected to Pass Despite Tax Rise
description: MINEOLA THE proposed budget that Nassau County Executive Francis T. Purcell has released seems headed for a smooth road to. ward approval by the Board of Supervisors, despite such controversial items as a tax increase for police district residents and a proposed raise for board members.

title: The Flap That Splits The Street
