description: Wall Street brokerage houses are rather like geese. In teaming up to sell new offerings of securities, they align themselves, in the perfect formation of their somber tombstone ads, with the biggest and strongest taking the lead and distributing the scraps to the firms further back in the flock. It's a generationsold system that has always worked, but of late the pecking order has fallen into disarray.

title: New Mayor Signals
description: DANBURY WHEN James E. Dyer is sworn in tomorrow as the 26th Mayor of Danbury, it will mark a transition to new generation of leadership for this western Connecticut city, which is growing and changing rapidly.

title: Suffern Downs Nyack by 2813 To Win P.S.A.L. Championship
description: Suffern defeated Nyack, 2813, yesterday to clinch the Rockland County Public Schools Athletic League championship. Suffern's Richard Gene Louie, one of Rockland's top rushers, ran for two touchdowns and its quarterback, Tony DeFrancesco, accounted for the other touchdowns by throwing to Keefe Healy and Pat Tracey.The Nyack quarterback, Andy Cowen, was responsible for both Nyack touchdowns, combining with Steve Garrison and Ray Schaub.

title: Alison Teal Married To Sam Brown Jr.
description: Alison Teal, who is with the Department of Housing and Urban Development in Washington, was married there yesterday to Sam W. Brown Jr., director of ACTION, the Federal Agency for Volunteer Service. The ceremony was performed in St. Margaret's Episcopal Church by the Rev. Steven Arpee. He was assisted by the Rev. John Lewis, associate director of ACTION.

title: North American Jews Widen Debate on Israeli Policy
description: MONTREAL, Nov. 17  The Council of Jewish Federations ends its annual meetsing here this weekend with the usual sessions on Endowment Fund Development and Telephone Solicitation. But perhaps the most significant development was unscheduled and occurred in the hallways and neighboring rooms outside the formal convention.

title: Public Officials Read for Children
description: MOST children think of a police chief leading a parade or whizzing by in a patrol car, but Yonkers area youngsters can hear their's read a story to them over the telephone.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: Dreadful and neardreadful accidents in the rail transportation of hazardous materials occur about three times a day in the United States alone. Last year, 26,381 Americans had to leave their homes because of 1,035 railroad accidents involving such materials. These figures were dwarfed last week in Canada when a Canadian Pacific train bearing chemicals derailed.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: HENRY J. MURER is standing pat. I consider my large plurality in the recent election a mandate from the people to stay here, said Mr. Murer, Huntington's newly reelected Superintendent of Highways. Mr. Murer, a Republican, has so far successfully resisted all efforts by Town Supervisor Kenneth C. Butterfield, a Democrat, to move the Highway Department from its present quarters into the newly opened Town Hall, several miles away.

title: Villanova Upsets Rutgers, 3217
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Nov. 17 (AP)Don Zeisel scored two short touchdowns, Chuck Bushbeck kicked three firsthalf field goals, and Villanova destroyed the bowl aspirations of Rutgers with a 3217 victory today.

title: Change the M.V.P. Rules
description: Even the definition of the word is somewhat vague. Aside from monetary worth, valuable is defined by Webster as having great merit, use or service; highly important, esteemed. Which means it's primarily a matter of opinion. And each year that is what baseball's most valuable player awards are  a matter of opinion by qualified baseball writers in each league, two from each city. The votes of the 24 on the Natonal League panel created an unprecedented tie last week when Willie Stargell of the Pittsburgh Pirates and Keith Hernandez of the St. Louis Cardinals shared the award. When the 28 votes of the American league selectors are counted this week, another tie is conceivable, this time between Don Baylor of the California Angels and Ken Singleton of the Baltimore Orioles.

title: Japan Beef Is World's Costliest
description: OSAKA, Japan, Nov. 17 (Reuters) The price of beef in Japan is the highest in the world and five times as high as that in New York, according to a survey of consumer prices released by a Japanese trading company today. In Tokyo, 100 grams, or just over onefifth of a pound, of roast costs $3.20, compared with 60 cents in New York, the Sumitomo Corporation said in a report on a survey conducted in August.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: BYRON: A Portrait, by Leslie A. Marchand. (University of Chicago Press, $7.95.) A picture of the life and times of the romantic British poet drawn from the author's own threevolume 1957 biography, now out of print. Like its source, it is most authoritative from a scholarly point of view, disappointing only in that Leslie Marchand shows little of the narrator's art, and relies on Lord Byron's own words and acts to carry the reader through the details of his dramatic story.

title: A Briton Vineyards
description: PARIS  A few steps off the Place de la Madeleine, the traditional carriagetrade gourmet center of this gourmetminded city, an Englishman is leading a revival of interest in fine wines here.

title: Stars Drop Garden Debut, 9795
description: When Dean Meminger, the former Knick, decided to return to Madison Square Garden as coach of the New York Stars basketball team, he did not know how well women could shoot the ball or how fast they could move down the court.

title: Judith Lois Fisher Fiance
description: Judith Lois Fisher, a fashion consultant in Los Angeles, where she has her own concern, Clothestrophobia, and Lance R. Freed, the executive vice president of the A & M Music Publishing Company in Los Angeles, will be married Dec. 16 in Deal, N.J. Announcement of their engagement has been made by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Fisher of New York and Deal. Mr. Freed is the son of Betty Lou Greene of Greensboro, N.C., and the late Alan Freed.

title: Stamford Police Air Protests on Changes
description: STAMFORD IN a remarkable outpouring of personal frustration and professional anxiety, a group of about 60 police officers complained and appealed to the civilian Police Commission and to the police chief last Wednesday evening over the many recent changes in the department.

title: SENATOR THREATENS SUIT OVER THRUWAY
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan threatened last week to institute a taxpayer suit to force the New York State Thruway Authority to accept Federal highway maintenance aid in return for an agreement to drop tolls on the highway eventually.

title: GARDENING Providing Winter Security for Plants
description: WINTER protection is es; sential for many ornamentals. Without it, they may be killed or severely damaged by extreme cold and fluctuating temperatures or by strong, desiccating winds. Hungry rodents and deer also pose a threat to certain plants.

title: Byrd Says Carter Agrees To Consult Him on Iran
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17  Senator Robert C. Byrd, the majority leader, said today that he had complained to President Carter that the Senate leadership had received only occasional afterthefact briefings in the Iranian crisis. He added that the President had agreed to daily consultations.

title: Bonnie Tisch
description: Bonnie Jeck and Daniel Richard Tisch were married yesterday at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Laurence A. Tisch of Rye, N.Y. Rabbi Phil Hiat of the Central Synagogue in Manhattan performed the ceremony.

title: Nets Defeat Pistons
description: The New Jersey Nets beat the Detroit Pistons, 9893, as John Williamson came oft the bench to hit two clutch baskets. Article, Page 6.

title: A Different Kind of Alert Sounded Over South Korea
description: WASHINGTON  As soon as they heard that Iranian militants had captured the United States embassy in Teheran, planning officers in the Pentagon began pulling books crammed with information on Iranian airfields, ports, transport, terrain, locations, water supplies and a myriad of other details out of thick steel files. No one had to tell them to do that because their assignment, once such an emergency flares, is to draw up a range of contingency plans for the deployment of American military forces.

title: Right to Life Party Gains Leverage
description: THE Right to Life Party has emerged from the recent Long Island elections with nearly as much bargaining power as the Conservative Party for next year's crucial Congressional and legislative elections.

title: New Look at Valley Forge: Washington's Men Had Some Comforts
description: VALLEY FORGE, Pa., Nov. 17 (AP) Though they nearly froze and starved, George Washington's soldiers were not a pathetic, demoralized band when they retreated here in 1777, some historians now say.

title: Woman's may Offers a Fresh Approach to Learning
description: Do women ski differently from men?

title: Rail Improvements Said to Be Years Away
description: WHITE PLAINS COMMUTER rail lines serving Westchester are scheduled to receive $92 million in improvements under the state transportationbond act passed earlier this month, but commuters looking for quick results will probably be disapppointed.

title: Degnan and State Board of Psychological
description: TRENTON THE state's Board of Psychologicial Examiners will meet tomorrow at the request of Attorney General John J. Degnan to try to resolve the question of the granting, revocation and order to reinstate the license of Dr. Sylvia Herz, South Orange psychologist.

title: Inactive Quake Fault Is Cause of a $40 Million Error
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Nov. 17  The supposedly active earthquake fault that forced California to spend $40 million to move two schools for the handicapped has turned out to be inactive, and its spurs may not run beneath the original buildings at all.

title: CONNECTICUT HOUSING Study Challenges Zoning's Effect
description: IS largelot zoning as crucial a factor in perpetuating suburban exclusivity as is generally believed?

title: ISLAMIC CREED CITED
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Sunday, Nov. 18 Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini yesterday ordered students occupying the United States Embassy here to release women and blacks among the hostages they have been holding for two weeks if it is proved they have not committed acts of espionage. The students agreed to carry out the Ayatollah's order.

title: Overcoming Holiday Blues
description: LOVE, peace, hilarity, companionship  these are a few feelings that often arise in the upcoming holidays of Thanksgiving, Hanukkah, Christmas and New Year's Eve. The joy and deep meaning ox these festivities are happily anticipated, but not the considerable stress. Each holiday is different, but they share in common both cheerful and stressful expectations that can contribute to depression.

title: Ironic Comedy
description: EACH of the nine stories in V. S. Pritchett's new collection is admirably crafted, like nearly all that this novelistcriticmemoiristbiographer has produced in over a halfcentury of literary labor. But it matters more that the book is dense with knowledge of the intricacies of human feeling  the sea, as it was once universally understood to be, on which everything in firstrate fiction floats.

title: European Places, People and Events
description: JANET FLANNER, who diet just about a year ago, claimed wryly that she was not one of those journalists with a staff. I act as a sponge. I soak it up and squeeze it out in ink every two weeks.

title: Music: Debuts in Review
description: Add one more name to the growing list of Soviet migr musicians. Genya Paley, a graduate of the Byelorussian State Conservatory and a pianist who had an active career in Eastern Europe before arriving in the United States two years ago, made her New York debut Sunday night at the Abraham Goodman House. The concert was presented as a benefit for the Friends of Refugees of Eastern Europe.

title: Thailand Is Said to Plan Refugee Shift to Interior
description: ARANYAPRATHET, Thailand, Nov. 17 (Reuters)  Officials plan to move 50,000 Cambodians grouped along the Thai border to a refugee camp deep inside Thailand on Monday, military sources said here today.

title: TENNESSEE PLAYERS PACING TITLE BRIDGE
description: CINCINNATI, Nov. 17  One of the world's best husband and wife contract bridge partnerships headed the national mixed pair championship going into the final session here today. In the opening event of the American Contract Bridge League's fall nationals, Tom and Carol Sanders of National, Tenn., had 464 match points after leading the qualifying stage yesterday.

title: Dome May Shelter a Whole Town
description: WINOOSKI, Vt., Nov. 17 (UPI)  This city's Community Development Committee has applied for a $55,000 Federal grant to study the feasibility of building a dome over the entire city, or at least parts of it.

title: Male Chauvinist Romp
description: MAGINE a novel of contemporary sexual mores or a study of feminism from the point of view of Jack the Ripper, andyou'll have something of the flavor of George Stade's first novel, Confessions of a LadyKiller. Here is a novel that bristles with irony and wit, has a fine instinct for the folly of social fashion and cultic delusion, is packed with literary allusions, summoning everything from the lima to  The Maltese Falcon to its defense, and is as determinedly bloody as any Elizabethan revenge tragedy.

title: Islanders Lose, 54
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Nov. 17  The Islanders bade farewell to 14,995 fans at Nasssu Coliseum tonight by losing another hockey game. They are going on a sixgame, twoandahalfweek road trip and left behind a 54 loss to the Detroit Red Wings as a remembrance.

title: To Reserve:
description: If you want to attend next year's Ahwahnee Bracebridge Christmas dinners (sittings are at 9 P.M. Dec. 24 and at 4:30 and 8:30 P.M. Dec. 25), you must apply for a booking soon. Write for an application in the period between Thanksgiving and Christmas, and submit it between Dec. 15 and Jan. 15. Applications for both rooms and dinner are available from Bracebridge Reservations, Yosemite Park & Curry Company, Yosemite National Park, Calif. 95389.

title: Inquiry. Into Security At Indian Point Plants Being Pursued by U.S.
description: The Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission said yesterday that it would continue its inquiry, begun last month, into allegations of security lapses at the Indian Point nuclear power plants. The statement came a day after the plants operators announced that they had replaced the company that had provided security zuards for the complex.

title: Progress Report From Stamford On a Cleanup
description: STAMFORD CHANGE is not accomplished without trauma. The recent history of Stamford represents change in the extreme.

title: Pitt Tops Army, 400; Gets Fiesta Bowl Bid
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 17 Pittsburgh trounced Army, 400, at Michie Stadium today and immediately accepted an invitation to play in the Fiesta Bowl on Christmas Day.

title: NATURE WATCH
description: Pagarus pollicarus Size: Three to five inches. Color: Pink to reddish or brownish. Where found: In eelgrass of coastal shallows and on oyster beds and rocky bottoms of Long Island Sound.

title: Leonard Cohen Reaching for The Right Idiom
description: Because Leonard Cohen is not primarily a singer, the presentation of his songs has always required special care. Mr. Cohen's deep, droning voice is not a particularly musical instrument. And he writes lyrics that are often too dense or attenuated to be listened to casually; some of them are equally at home, or perhaps even more so, when they turn up in his volumes of verse. Nevertheless, he remains determined to make the popular song format work to his advantage, on the evidence of Recent Songs, his latest album. And this time, with the ingenious assistance of his coproducer, Henry Lewy, Mr. Cohen has come closer than ever before to finding an ideal musical idiom for his idiosyncrasies.

title: Music Notes: A Peripatetic Violist
description: Nathan Milstein and Vladimir Horowitz are 75 this year. So is another distinguished performer who is, however, no longer heard by the New York public. He is William Primrose, the man who probably more than any other turned the viola into a concert instrument. He was in town the other day, for the first time in 15 years, to help promote some of his contributions to G. Schirmer's Great Performer's Edition. His face may be lined now, but he is as chipper as ever. His comments, as in the prefaces to his editions, often have a dry humor that probably has its origin in his Scottish blood.

title: Wein Sparks Matawan's 208 Victory
description: Larry Wein scored three touchdowns and intercepted three passes to spark Matawan to a 208 triumph over Madison Central in the semifinals of the Central Jersey, Group 4 playoffs before 5,000 yesterday in Old Bridge. Wein, a senior fullback, cracked over from 1 yard out at 7:30 of the second quarter to climax a 7play, 19yard march. Matawan again scored with 14 seconds remaining in the first half on a 2yard run by Wein.

title: Covington Running, Passing by Harmon Make Bayside No. 1
description: Jamie Covington may be the best halfback in New York City, and Derrick Harmon may be the city's best quarterback. There are no maybes about Bayside being the best Public Schools Athletic League team, as it won its fourth Division A championship, 408, over Jefferson yesterday.

title: Rep. Aspin to Aid Kennedy Drive
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (UPI)  Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, was named chairman of the provisional Wisconsin for Kennedy Committee today by the national Kennedy for President Committee. Mr. Aspin, a fiveterm Congressman, said a permanent committee working for the Presidential nomination of Senator Edward M. Kennedy would not be in place in Wisconsin until early January.

title: Christmas Feasting In Snowy Yosemite
description: Dinner at the Ahwahnee Hotel in Yosemite Valley in California's Sierra Nevada Range is a rewarding experience any time of the year, but at Christmas it is something special  a recreation of the feast described by Washington Irving in his chapter The Christmas Dinner from The Sketch Book of Geoffrey Crayon, Gent. was ante to participate in last year's festivities only through a combination of planning and luck. Thirteen months earlier my brother and a group of his neighbors in Mariposa, Calif., had sent in an application for a. table for 10; their names had been drawn in the lottery that determined who would be seated, and they invited me to be one of their party. (Those interested in attending the dinner at Christmas 1980 may write to the hotel for applications between Thanksgiving and Christmas this year, but they should be aware that only about one out of four of those who apply are selected.)

title: Votes in Congress
description: 1. Amendment to let the elderly and ill poor people receive Federal fuel aid to help pay airconditioning bills in summer, passed, 68 to 27, Nov. 13.

title: Aubagne Museum Commemorates French Foreign Legion
description: French Foreign Legion! The name evokes romantic images of battlefield heroics, of suffering, discipline, camaraderie and esprit.

title: Winter Garden Tour
description: SOMERVILLE HOULD you want to stroll through romantically lighted gardens in winter without leaving New Jersey, you will soon be able to do so.

title: Trenton Takeover
description: TRENTON THE appointment last week of a monitor general to help the troubled Trenton school system overcome its financial and educational problems is viewed by many as less a brave experiment in urban education and more a lastditch effort to save a dying patient. It is also seen as a prelude to the takeover of other equally distressed urban school districts around the state.

title: Donn Randall, Sally A. Lodge Will Be Wed
description: Sally Anne Lodge, an editor of Publishers Weekly magazine, and Donn Alexander Randall, an associate with the New York law firm of Mudge, Rose, Guthrie & Alexander, plan to be married June 7 at Martha's Vineyard, Mass.

title: Harvard Unit Opposes A Nationwide Primary
description: BOSTON, Nov. 17 (UPI)  Harvard University's Institute of Politics has advised against establishing a nationwide Presidential primary, arguing that the procedure would weaken the party system.

title: Food
description: There are three miracle foods  cream puffs, puff pastry and souffls  whose magic derives from expansion by air. Of the three, souffls are considered to be the most elegant and the easiest to make. One of the finest souffles is a doublelayered affair that has a base of creamed or sauced foods with souffl mixture piled on top. Outlined here is a doubledecker favorite, the components of which could also be served separately without apology.

title: White Plains Defense Halts Ketchum
description: White Plains, helped by a goalline stand in the first quarter, shut down the powerful offense of Roy C. Ketcham yesterday and scored a 170 victory to win the Class A 1 Title at Franklin D. Roosevelt Stadium in Hyde Park.

title: Letters to the Travel Editor
description: To the Editor: I did not have to read the heading Partaking of a Rich Past in the Old Spanish City of Ronda (Travel Section, Nov. 4) to know that the story was, about Ronda  I saw the picture of the one I love.

title: Few Clues Are Found In 4 Slayings Upstate; Automobile Is Sought
description: LEE CENTER, N.Y., Nov. 17 (AP) Authorities in central New York searched today for a Volkswagen that was apparently one of the few clues in the slayings of four persons here, one of them a coin dealer and collector.

title: Cleaver Pleads Guilty to Assault
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 17 (AP)  Eldridge Cleaver, the former Black Panther leader, has pleaded guilty to assaulting Oakland policemen 11 years ago and, in exchange, murder charges against him will be dismissed.

title: Television This Week
description: 5 P.M. (2) WHY A CONDUCTOR? A onehour discussion and demonstration, at a New York Philharmonic Young People's Concert, of the art of communication between an orchestra and its conductor. Zubin Mehta will conduct works by Handel, Strauss, Wagner and Stravinsky; Beverly Sills will be the commentator.

title: RIVAL KOREA PARTIES AGREE TO COOPERATE ON REVISING CHARTER
description: Accord Announced After Chiefs of LongEstranged Groups Meet  Bipartisan Panel Due

title: Consumer Group Urges Warning On Use of Caffeine in Pregnancy
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP)  A consumer group concerned about women's intake of caffeine in pregnancy urged the Government anew today to require warning labels on coffee and tea.

title: Straight or Mixed, It Wins Friends
description: REDDING ABOUT six times a year, Tom Lalley and his wife, Helen, travel to Delaware, where they join 13 women and five men for a weekend of cleaning and chopping 6,000 pounds of onions, 5,000 pounds of celery and 3,185 pounds of green peppers.

title: A preview of major local college basketball. P. 13
description: Among the things that make college basketball the Metropolitan area interesting every season are the shifting local rivalries, the rise and fall of programs and the exciting ballplayers, old and new. This season should be no exception.

title: CONNALLY: COMING ON TOUGH
description: As the 1980 Presidential campaign heats up, the former Governor of Texas hopes to toughtalk his way into the White House.

title: A Dinner Outing On Skinny Skis
description: It was one of those spectacular colarodo night when stars shine yet snow falls at the same time. Our group of 24 gathered outside the rustic King Cabin, and as we made final preparations we looked like a cluster of overgrown fireflies. The batterypowered miners lamps strapped to our foreheads bobbed in the darkness as we bent over to adjust our boots and bindings.

title: L.I.'s Fate in the Next 20 Years: Energy Is Called the Key
description: ENERGY is the single issue that a number of prominent Long Islanders agree may decide the economic and social fate, of the Island. They do not, however, concur on what course national, state and local officials ought to take in drawing up an energy policy for the next 20 years.

title: Junior Gladiators Enter the Arena
description: THE setting is mellow and suburban: a highschool football field ringed by trees, a living catalogue of L. L. Bean and Bloomie's leisurewear scattered throughout the wooden stands. There is comfortable laughter as neighbor greets neighbor. Men shake hands or slap backs. Women brush cheeks or pat arms.

title: Obituary 4  No Title
description: BERGERMarie. The members of the Cele Butwin Foundation deeply mourn the passing of their beloved comember and extend their profound sympathy to their former President, Marvin Berger and his family.

title: Kennedy Decision On Dugan Awaited
description: NOW that Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts has formally entered the race for the Democratic nomination for President, the task of putting together a New Jersey campaign organization is attracting the attention of a number of state party leaders.

title: The Twenties Created the Classics of Today
description: The Museum of Modern Art's Art of the Twenties show is a splendid antidote to kitsch. It leads from strength, rather than from nostalgia. What comes through everything on display is the exceptional quality of the museum's holdings of the period, and the remarkable role the museum itself played in shaping and recording the modernist revolution.

title: GAME SHOWS TV'S GLITTERING GOLD MINE
description: WWIhen you line up for The Price Is Right outside CBS Television City in Hollywood, you get_ an adhesive name tag and a number, from 1 325, which is the capacity of the studio. You are formed in rows of three, in numerical order, three feet apart, by redjacketed ushers.

title: Paper and Ceramics Are the Canvas
description: PAINTERS can get impatient with their art, especially those primarily concerned with color and gesture. Sometimes, the distance between the self and the canvas is too great and the tools seem more like impediments to ideas rather than their conductors. It is then that the immediacy of collage and the physicality of modeling can be remedial diversions.

title: The Porn Thorn In Midtown's Side Gets Less Painful
description: At the same time, the hotels and office buildings can be said to have achieved a healthy level of occupancy for the first time in years. Redevelopment schemes are moving ahead, even though the national financial picture may impede them. New investment in office buildings is especially noticeable on Broadway north of the Garment District.

title: LITERARY LETTER FROM LOS ANGELES
description: IN the City of the Angels, when you ask a writer you respect What's happening on the literary scene? he'll say, There isn't one. And after you've asked the same question of Christopher Isherwood, Gore Vidal, Brooke Hayward and Neil Simon, and have had no kind of encouragement for your quest except from Louis L'Amour's press agent, someone says, Of course, the Dunnes.

title: When the Medium Is Cloth or Clay
description: EAST ISLIP THE Islip Town Art Gallery, in the gatehouse of Brookwood Hall since 1973, has now moved to more spacious quarters in the main building of the old Knapp estate, just a few yards down a treelined drive from its former home. The estate, including the tunrofthecentury mansion and its grounds, is a gracious setting for the many and varied cultural activities sponsored by the town.

title: INVESTING
description: Investors riveted their attention last week on events in Iran, beginning with President Carter's order to end oil imports from that country, and they responded with a rousing rally led by energy issues.

title: Magic Fable
description: AFTER 12 years, the novelist, nearing 70 now,. emerges like Merlin the wizard to cast a new spell. He conjures a 19 re to begin with, the London blitz: The men at the edge of the fire could only watch it burn, out of control It was a glare, a burnlag bush.  The heart of ne bush, where the little streets had been, was of a more lambent colour. It shivered constantly but with an occasional diminution or augmentation of its brightness as walls collapsed or roofs caved in. Through it all. the roar of the fire, the drone of the departing bombers, the crash of collapse  there was now and then the punctuating explosion of a delayed action bomb going off among the rubble, sometimes casting a kind of blink over the mess and sometimes so muffled by the debris as to make nothing but noise.

title: Joan Sturgis
description: The engagement of Joan Lindsley Sturgis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Post Sturgis of Greenwich, Conn., and Chathamport, Mass., to Paul Robert Parsons, son of Dr. and Mrs. WillHam Parsons of Dover, Mass., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents.

title: IRAN'S MOSLEM SECT ASSESSED BY EXPERTS
description: Embassy Seizure Is Linked to Both Shiite Approval of Authority and Anger Over the Shah

title: 3 Vote Victories Cheer Foes of Quebec Separatism
description: QUEBEC, Nov. 1%  A Liberal Party sweep of three Quebec byelections, the worst setback for the secessionist Parti Quebecois government since its election three years ago, has strengthened the drive of the province's federalist forces to defeat the government's proposal for a sovereign Quebec linked to Canada in a new association.

title: Amanda Van Dusen Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard C. Van Dusen of Birmingham, Mich., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amanda Van Dusen, to Curtis Brevoort Blessing, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Blessing of Detroit.

title: Carter Hails Khomeini's Directive And Vows to Press Release Efforts
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17  President Carter today welcomed the announcement in Iran that female and black hostages in the United States Embassy would be freed. He said he would continue to press for the release of the remaining hostages.

title: Cover: Photograph by Shelly Katz/ Black Star
description: Cover: Photograph by Shelly Katz/ Black Star

title: Cancer Scare Forgotten, Cranberry Farms Thrive
description: BOSTON, Nov. 17 (UPI)  Twenty years ago, just before Thanksgiving, Arthur Flemming stepped to a podium in Washington and squashed the cranberry industry.

title: South Side Captures Title With Hempstead's Help
description: South Side won the Conference III Division A championship yesterday when the Rockville Centre team played Lynbrook to a 66 tie while Hempstead upset New Hyde Park. 60.

title: Remembering Football Behind Walls
description: DID Scared Straight serve its purpose in helping youngsters to lead a crimefree existence? The controversial television documentary had prisoners shout obscenities at teenagers and now it has been criticized by those who say the program was a failure, that it wasn't possible to scare monle straight.

title: DOCTOR GETS $44,000 IN KANSAS LIBEL CASE
description: KANSAS CITY, Kan., Nov. 17 (AP),A jury awarded $44,000 in damages today to a white physician who filed a libel suit against four blacks who had been his students at the University of Kansas Medical School. Dr. Dante G. Scalpelli, who is no longer with the school, sued after the students accused him of discrimination.

title: Susan C. Watson to Be Married
description: Thomas J. Watson, Ambassador to the Soviet Union, and Mrs. Watson of Moscow and Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter. Susan Chancy Watson. to Stephen Laurence Whitman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Whitman of Weston, Mass. The wedding is planned for May.

title: Garson Kanin Recalls Hollywood's High Times
description: It was 1937, and Samuel Goldwyn, then head of United Artists and probably the most powerful man in Hollywood, had just hired 24yearold Garson Kanin at $250 a week. Having given up a promising directorial career on Broadway as George Abbott's assistant, Mr. Kanin arrived at the studio and was told to start learning the business. More specific instructions Were not forthcoming, and he soon found himself spending most of his time in the projection room, running and rerunning old movies. Finally, he demanded to know exactly why he had been hired. Goldwyn looked at him intently for a moment, then replied, You look just like Irving Thalberg. I hired you because you look like a clever genius.

title: Emory U. Seeks New Stature on a Gift and a Dream
description: Al LANIA, Nov. 16  While many institutions of higher education are looking toward the 1980's as an era of declining enrollments and fiscal retrenchment, Emory University is preparing for expansion and greater spendine.

title: Hashish is Top Lebanon Export
description: BAALBEK, Lebanon, Nov. 16 (Reuters)  Lebanon's hashish growers are expecting to export at least 700 tons of their product next year, making it their country's most valuable single export.

title: Miss Bellamy Assails School Administration Outlay
description: City Council President Carol Bellamy asserted yesterday that the city's Board of Education was adding administrative expenditures even as it proposed to meet a projected $56 million deficit by laying off teachers and paring instructional services.

title: At I.B.M., Lilliputian Work for Brobdingnagian Minds
description: YORKTOWN HEIGHTS THE International Business Machines Corporation may be a giant enterprise, and its think tank here may be housed in a soaring tripletiered structure fronted by 1,000 feet of metal and glass, but inside, among the thinkers, large scale is definitely out.

title: Park's Village Vastly Altered By Prosperity
description: SANGMO, South Korea, Nov. 14 -President Park Chung Hee has been dead for nearly three weeks, but the tempo of economic progress he started in the valley where he grew up has skipped only one beat: the minute of silence observed nationally during his state funeral on Nov. 3.

title: Surgical Unit Set Up in Medical Center Parking Lot
description: GALLUP, N.M., Nov. 17 (AP)  With the help of the Army and the blessing of a Navajo medicine man, the back parking lot of the Gallup Indian Medical Center has become a surgical center.

title: A PAIR TO SET THE ICE AFIRE
description: Shortly after sunrise one morning recently, the tumultuous strains of The Planets boomed over a loudspeaker in a cavernous ice rink in Santa Monica, coastal suburb of Los Angeles. No one said so. but Gustav Holst's music was a kind of overture to an act of EastWest high drama that will be played out in the Adirondack Mountains next February.

title: George Horton Jr. Weds Jane Cowles
description: Grace Episcopal Church in Madison, N.J., was the setting for the marriage yesterday of Jane Christine Cowles and George Shortland Horton Jr., both of Grosse Pointe, Mich. The Rev. Hayward Levy performed the ceremony.

title: T.G. Eaton Fianc Of Patricia Weill
description: Mr. and Mrs. Guy A. Weill of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Anne Weill, to Thomas George Eaton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome A. Eaton of New York and Gallatin, N.Y. The wedding will take place next month.

title: Wintry Weather Brings Thoughts of Summer Camp. But Why?
description: IF this is the International Year of the Child, why is the only sure sign of winter the annual camp reunion?

title: Oysters Under Sail
description: Back when Herman Melville was skipping up the rigging of the whaler Acushnet, sailing ships did not seem especially romantic. They seemed. and were, commonplace. Most were also grubby. Tacky little schooners coasted down the breeze from Maine, bringing city people their winter firewood. Sailing scows moved garbage around New York harbor. It's only in the 20th century that sails have come to symbolize glamour and sport and cleanhandedness, while any actual work is done by some dreary craft with an engine. One bit of the old system survives in this country  one working fleet that still moves under sail. Down in Chesapeake Bay, when men go out to dredge oysters they go out on sailing vessels. At least in Maryland's part of the bay they do. There are 30odd skipjacks that make up the Maryland oyster fleet. Each has a tall mast, a crew of six, a grubby deck and some 1,200 square feet of sail. They owe their survival to a centuryold state law that forbids dredging for oysters by vessels under power. So much for the theory that you can't control technology by legislation.

title: POLITICS Transforming Legislators Into Lobbyists
description: HARTFORD WHAT some people at the State Capitol here call the revolving door  state legislators who leave office but come back as lobbyists  has turned once again.

title: News Summary
description: The release of the blacks and bwomen among the hostages held at the American Embassy in Teheran, was ordered by Ayatollah Khomeini, according to the students who holding them captive. The Ayatollah's son, Ahmad, told reporters last night that the hostages would not be released immediately, but maybe tomorrow. [Page 1, Col. 6.]

title: CAMBODIA PROMOTES ANTIPOL POT CULT
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Nov. 12 For those in the audience to whom the words of the song were not translated, the children on the stage of the school auditorium in Phnom Penh today might have been singing about sunshine and orchids, so happy were their faces and bright their smiles.

title: CASTRO'S ROOTS IN SPAIN
description: LANCARA, Spain. New York City greeted Fidel Castro last month with massive police protection, occasional eruptions of hostility on the streets and, at the United Nations, a mixture of thunderous applause and diplomatic silence. Now this little town across the Atlantic is told it can expect a visit soon from the father of the Cuban revolution  He says he wants to stay for a month! explodes one incredulous state official  and the reception, though certainly smaller, will no doubt be equally ambivalent. Fidel Castro has cousins and not a few enemies scattered across the green hills of Galicia. The vast majority of Spaniards are antiCommunist in their political views. But for others, Fidel, the wayward son of their vanished empire, is a source of sweet revenge for their last drubbing by foreign arms  the SpanishAmerican War of 1898, which old men still call the disaster. Fe still others, Castro is Horatio Alger onceremoved. In a society where upward mobility is blocked by barriers of class, background and money, many of its people have tried to improve their lives by emigrating. And those who succeed abroad are acclaimed when they return. On Dec. 8, 1875, Angel Maria Bautista Castro Arguiz was inscribed in the birth register of Lancara in Galicia, a backward, neglected region of northwestern Spain. Born in a dank, slateroofed house with an earthen floor, the first of three children of a poor farmer, Angel Castro as a young man worked as a day laborer in the fields near the tiny River Neira, known for its fat trout; he was an avid gambler at cards, and usually won. At the age of 23, big and restless, Angel Castro accepted a small sum to take the place of a wealthier man in Spain's disastrous campaign to hold its rebel colony, Cuba  a war that turned into a national humiliation for Spain when the United States, seething with a newfound Manifest Destiny and aroused by the sinking of the Maine, intervened on the side of the Cuban rebels. Angel Castro survived the 1898 war and returned, briefly, to Spain. But like many fellow Gallegos he found his native Galicia confining, the horizons of the New World enticing. While his younger brother Gonzalo emigrated to Argentina, Angel sailed back to Cuba, where he settled in the savage sugar territory of Oriente, a virtual fief of the United Fruit Company. Though he bitterly hated the North Americans, who had humiliated Spain at war, he worked for them, but at the same time he hacked a cane plantation of his own from the untamed bush. The Castro hacienda, called Manacas, grew to perhaps 20,000 acres, and employed several hundred men.

title: Court Backs Regulation On ExOfficer Job Forms
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (UPI)  A Federal appellate court has upheld a regulation asking all retired regular military officers to submit voluntarily to the Defense Department a description of their current employment.

title: St. John the Baptist Wins
description: St. John the Baptist defeated Mater Christi, 91, to win the Catholic High School Metropolitan soccer championship at St. John's University. Bob Waizzenegger scored two goals, and Bill Vogel and Kevin Maffei each scored one to lead undefeated St. John the Baptist to its 13th triumph this season. Mater Christi (1132) finished the season as City Catholic High Schools Athletic Association champion.

title: Shah Reportedly Bitter At Carter in Interview
description: LONDON, Sunday, Nov. 18 (UPI) The deposed Shah of Iran defended his human rights record, denied he was a dictator and spoke bitterly of President Carter in an interview published today in the Sunday Times of London.

title: Works Like Painted Music
description: SOUTHAMPTON USUALLY paintings that we term rational tend to appeal more to our minds than to our senses. We appreciate them for their logic, structure and rigorous pictorial relationships. But we are not arawn to tnem for their emotional depths nor for their sensuous warmth and prepossessing passions. Rational paintings are mathematical precepts in color, visual embodiments of theorems. At times, they are more paintings of ideas than feelings.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor: The review by Josephine Hendin of The Passion Artist by John Hawkes (Sept. 16) misrepresented rather badly the new novel by one of this country's best writers. While Mrs. Hendin correctly places Mr. Hawkes among the most innovative and original American writers, she nonetheless describes the book as superficial and as a detour to nihilism. The novel is also characterized by facile perversions and colorful cruelties described by a supreme stylist.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: Hit songs of the 1930's will be played, and dances popular in the period, such as the Continental, the Peabody and the Beguine, will be performed in the Music Room of the Ridgefield Public Library. Curtain time is 2 P.M.

title: A Shop That Takes the Cake
description: WESTPORT ALL of Antionette Hyde's friends had jobs, and when her two sons graduated from school, she wanted something to do, too.

title: For Spring, Styles That Make the Most of Every Hour
description: Giorgio Sant'Angelo excelled in both knitted styles and party clothes. Suits continued their relentless climb in popularity. And Fernando Sanchez showed what to wear in private hours.

title: Patricia Keane Fiance Of David Crawford King
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sydney H. Keane of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Ann Keane, to David Crawford King, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward C. King Jr. of Waterville and Long Lake, N.Y.

title: GarageSale Rules Tightened in Nassau
description: EAST HILLS THAT familiar sign of the suburbs, Garage Sale, may be coming down from utility poles all over the Island if a current move toward municipal regulation of the popular sales gains widespread support.

title: Pioneer Waste Plan
description: TRENTON IN A move designed to greatly reduce reliance on smelly, unsightly landfills that now pollute surface and ground water, New Jersey is considering a pioneering $800 million, 10year program of technically sophisticated solidwaste treatment plants.

title: It Takes More Than Vitamins to Make Johnny Big and Strong
description: Scientists at several pediatric research centers across the country are now convinced that the failure of some children to grow normally is related to disturbed patterns parenting ranging from outright physical abuse to more subtle, but no less dangerous, forms of emotional abuse.

title: Horse Racing Must Look To Teletracks in Era Of the Casinos
description: HORSE racing in the Northeast has been given a reprieve by the postponement of casino gambling in New York State. But if casino gambling finally surfaces, a bleak future seems in store for thoroughbred and harness racing.

title: Byrne Throws Meadowlands Plans Into Limbo
description: APROPOSED $1 billion complex of housing, office buildings and a large shopping mall in the Berry's Creek section of the Hackensack Meadowlands, as well as plans for a large rival mall about three miles away, have been dumped into bureaucratic limbo by the Byrne administration.

title: Work on the Railroads Gets Back on the Track
description: BEACON FALLS I T's an exciting time to be working in mass transit, said Richard Hollis as he walked along the railroad tracks in this Naugatuck Valley town. As Mr. Hollis, a planner with the state's Department of Transportation, walked along the rightofway, a caravan of 10yellow trackrepair vehicles crept along, cutting and pushing out every third or fourth rotted tie, swinging a new, tarsoaked support beam into place and embedding it in the gravel beneath the tracks.

title: CALENDARS
description: Today  Empire Jaguar Club autocross, at Gateway National Recreation Area, Floyd Bennett Field, Brooklyn. Registration: 9 A.M.; first car off 11.

title: DINING OUT A Transformation in Bernardsville
description: TWO years ago, Carla Ford and Steve Sipos joined forces to convert a Bernardsville bar into a restaurant that they called Bistro II. They wanted to create an unpretentious neighborhood dining spot with gemiitlich, a place where clients would become friends, rather than an elegant haute cuisine restaurant.

title: Rider, La Salle Advance
description: TEANECK, N.J., Nov. 17  Rider College and La Salle each scored 10 upset victories today and advanced to the final tomorrow of the Eastern College Athletic Conference MidAtlantic soccer regionals. Rider beat Fairleigh Dickinson on Steve Schmier's goal and LaSalle downed Temple on Donnie Smith's goal.

title: New U.S.Saudi Pact Forecast
description: BAHRAIN, Nov. 17 (Reuters)  Saudi Arabia and the United States will sign a new fiveyear technical cooperation agreement next week, the Gulf News Agency said today. The agreement is to be concluded during a visit next Friday by Treasury Secretary G. William Miller, according to the agency.

title: Chinese Face First Major Price Increase in 25 Years
description: PEKING, Nov. 17  Wang Ping is angry. Like other urban Chinese, she must get accustomed to a Governmentmandated 33 percent increase in the cost of meat, eggs, milk and fish.

title: World News Briefs
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 17 (Reuters) More than 100,000 people have been arrested at sitin protests in India's northeastern state of Assam during the last few days, officials said today.

title: Chef Otto and Friends
description: THIS new collection is replete with the reportorial virtues for which John McPhee is so much respected; like all his books, it will be particularly welcomed by those who neglect to save old copies of The New Yorker. This one even adds a little spice (or, to supersenstive palates, a lot of cayenne) by reprinting that celebrated impertinence Brigade de Cuisine, a friendly profile that somehow managed to raise hackles in Manhattan all the way from the Ease: 50's to the West 80's and beyond. Chef Otto had guessed that the turbot was frozen, but  in Mr. McPhee's succinct footnote Otto guessed wrong.

title: DINING OUT Good Value at Westport Newcomer
description: WESTPORT Crestaurant is a pleasing, threemonth old restaurant that doesn't yet seem to have found the large, loyal group of supporters clearly deserves. Its upstairs location may have something to do with it. To reach it, you must walk past, but not through, the bar, a rather empty, raw and rusticlooking place that isn't particularly inviting.

title: Health
description: For centuries, schoolteachers on the Mediterranean island of Sardinia have witnessed a curious phenomenon. Every February, as spring arrives some of their students suddenly become listless. For the next three months, their schoolwork suffers; they feel dizzy and nauseous, fall asleep at their desks. Then, just as suddenly, their energy returns. And they remain healthy and active until the next February rolls around.

title: A Club For Skiers Over 70
description: Is there skiing after 70? There are more than 200 men and women in the National 70+ Club to prove that there is, indeed.

title: Rogers Shares Japan Golf Lead
description: GOTEMBA, Japan, Nov. 17 (AP) Bill Rogers of the United States shot 69 today for a threeround total of 209 and moved into a share of the lead with Norio Suzuki of Japan in the $300,000 Taikeiyo (Pacific) Club Masters golf tournament.

title: On Language
description: Believe it or not, the vocabulary of disbelief has come into its own. Years ago, the standard response to a startling statement was You've got to be kidding, which replaced Kimble Mead the ancient G'wan and Pshaw! Now, the most popular phrase in teenagers' patois  picked up and amplified by television sitcoms  is I don't believe it, usually pronounced, I don't buhLEEV it, and its variant, I don't buhLEEV this.

title: FOOD/STYLE Now for Pumpkin Pie, or Apple, or..
description: FOR Thanksgiving, pie is almost as traditional as turkey. Virtually every bakery on the Island, whether Italian, German, French, American or Hungarian, has been featuring appropriately seasonal pies along with the regular wares.

title: Japan's GoodWill Campaign
description: The Japanese have launched a campaign to attract more Western tourists by seeking to allay travelers fears about the high cost of living, the language barrier and the difficulty of meeting the veoole.

title: U. S. Decision to Admit the Shah: Key Events in 8 Months of Debate
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17  On Oct. 20, quiet Saturday in Washington, an urgent cable was sent to L. Bruce Laingen, the acting Ambassador in Teheran, telling him that President Carter and Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance had decided to allow an ailing Shah to enter the United States in a few days for emergency treatment of cancer and gallstones.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: For more than a decade the Franklin Mint has built its worldwide reputation and its financial success on the production and sale of its numismatic items such as limitededition medals, silver bars and ingots, and coinage for foreign governments.

title: Museum Picks Up the Pieces
description: WINDSOR LOCKS ON Oct. 3 the Bradley Air Museum suffered what airline pilots sometimes tell their passengers is a little turbulence. In this instance, the euphemism refers to the tornado that tore through the communities around Bradley International Airport, a dozen miles north of Hartford.

title: Kimberly Morgan Is Betrothed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Clifford S. Morgan of. North Valley Stream, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Kimberly Patricia Morgan, to John Robert Byrnes Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Byrnes of Middle Village, Queens. Mr. Morgan is director of advertising and public relations for United States Lines Inc. at the company's corporate headquarters in Cranford, N.J.

title: Topics Discomania
description: When is a cabaret a disco, and when is a disco a neighborhood nuisance? That's easy, if you live in the neighborhood: It's when one persons's entertainment becomes another's insomnia.

title: The Candidates Economists
description: WASHINGTON SCRATCH an academic or a private consultant and in any number of instances you'll find a frustrated policy maker. That's rarely more apparent than it is now, as the Presidential political season arrives, and with it a horde of economists to advise the candidates.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: DEFIANCE (Farrell Lines). Bremerhaven Nov. 27, Amsterdam 28, Felixstowe 29 and LeHavre 30; sails from Howland Hook, Staten island.

title: Navajos Worry About Uranium Pollution of River
description: CHURCH ROCK, N.M., Nov. 17 (AP)  White wooden signs warn residents in English, Navajo and Spanish: All Use of Water From This River Is Discouraged.

title: Must Every Bus Kneel to the Disabled?
description: Do the 30 million Americans afflicted with physical or mental handicaps have a right of access, no matter what the cost, to all publicly sponsored activities? That is now a central question because the price of such access for the disabled promises to become very great.

title: CHILDREN'S BOORS
description: The star S. writes Seymour Simon, are lo remote that measuring their distance in miles would be ike trying to measure the dis ance between New York and London in inches.

title: Washington Briefs County Democrats
description: WHITE PLAINS IF you can get a dozen of your people together, a White House aide told Michelle Aisenberg, a Democratic national committeewoman from New Rochelle, I think we can arrange a Mideast briefing. That was last summer.

title: CAMPAIGNS RAISING DEBATES ON PRIVACY
description: The private lives of public figures have increasingly become the subjects of open political discussion and will probably be more so in the 1980 election campaigns than ever before.

title: Alleged Gacy Victim Identified
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 17 (UPI)  Investigators have identified the 21st alleged victim of John Wayne Gacy, the mass murder suspect. David Talsma of Chicago was identified by the Cook County medical examiner, Robert J. Stein, yesterday, which would have been Mr. Talsma's 21st birthday. Officials said he had been identified through Xrays.

title: POINTS OF VIEW
description: Over and over again lately the refrain is heard: A recession won't cure inflation. It is a theme with variations. Some say it would take a disastrous depression to have any effect on inflation  and who wants that? Others say that a slowdown might have some effect but only if it lasted five or 10 years. Still others take a positive view: the only way to stop inflation is with wage and price controls. Once in a while there is an appeal to history': since the inflation rate kept right on rising duiing the last recession, which was the worst since the 1930's, what can another recession be expected to do?

title: Bachrach
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Reed of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Linda Maie Reed, to Dr. Donald Smith Masters Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Masters of Santa Barbara., Calif., formerly of Rye, N.Y. The wedding is planned for April.

title: Iranians at U.S. Schools Feeling the Strain
description: Special to The New York Times

title: CAPITAL REPORT
description: DURING a phonein program on New Jersey Public Television last week, Governor Byrne hinted, without commiting himself, that he would not sign into law the abortion bill now wending its way through the State Legislature.

title: Cab Driver Is City's Fifth Slaying Victim in 6 Hours
description: A gypsy cab driver was found shot to death, the apparent victim of a robber, in a deserted area of the South Bronx early yesterday.

title: Yearning for the Big Score
description: IT is claimed on the dust jacket of this confession of an obsessional odyssey through Nevada to the stews of Macao that the gambler's world is a subculture seldom discussed. This is not so: if Dostoyevsky's The Gambler is the most notable exploration of the pathology of hazard, Hunter Thompson's Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas is no small contribution to the sociology of the subculture. Mario Puzo has written often and sometimes well about the interior geography of the gambler, and John Gregory Dunne's Vegas is a geek show of pimps, hookers, hustlers, dreamers, losers and temporary winners.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: We are always impressed by a writer who is working on! trilogy or an even longer series. It shows the dedication of a longdistance runner who has thought out his sprint moves. Albert Murray is now writing The Spyglass Tree for McGrawHill, the tentatively titled second novel of a trilogy begun with Train Whistle Guitar, winner of the Lillian Smith Award for fiction in 1974. He is perhaps best known to readers for South to a Very Old Place. An expert on popular music, he is also editing the autobiography of the jazzman Count Basie, as told to Albert Murray. That seems only natural for the author of Stomping the Blues, which was acclaimed when it appeared in 1977. The Count is more popular now than he was during the heyday of the big swing bands, he says. I tape his memories in nightclubs, dance halls, at rehearsals, on chartered buses. The tapes are backed up by the sounds of musicians warming up and the drone of those buses on the road. It gives the conversations a reality. The autobiography should read like a novel. My job is to help him get his voice right so readers will say: I know that's Count Basie talking; what did Albert Murray do , to get his name on the book?

title: How I Turned the Giants' Season Around
description: WHEN the Giants take the field in Tampa Stadium this afternoon, I will be sitting high up in Row 101 gloating over the dramatic manner in which my team has turned around a dismal season.

title: Congress Weighing StudentLoan Raises
description: WASHINGTON MORE than 75,000 students, or almost half of those attending colleges and universities in New Jersey this school year, are receiving Governmentguaranteed loans, and final Congressional action in the coming weeks is likely to provide for much larger assistance in 1980.

title: Nebraska Board Orders 1980 Cut In Personal and Corporate Taxes
description: LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 17  The burden of Nebraska incometax payers, individual and corporate, was lightened Thursday by the Nebraska State Board of Equalization and Assessment.

title: Back to the Slopes After 13 Years
description: AFTER trying skiing one season and then staying off the slopes for 13 years, my wife, Marge, and I resumed the sport last winter. In the interim, two children were added our family, and the questions were many. Could man in his mid40's and a woman in her early 30's make skiing progress after such a long layoff? Would we be bewildered by new equipment and new teaching methods? And could we afford to put our family of four on skis?

title: Hospital Costs Defeat Last Week Was a Case in Point
description: WASHINGTON  Ordinary citizens stream onto Capitol Hill by the thousands, arriving in convoys of buses. They overflow Congressional offices and corridors, some wearing small blue pins depicting grains of wheat that symbolize support for feeding starving Cambodians. Others sporting redapple lapel pins that signify that they love New York. Still others, opponents of legislation that would make abortions easier to get, hand out red roses. In the winter, tractors clog the city's streets as farmers arrive from the Middle West, demanding higher price supports. In the summer, when school is out, college students hold antidraft rallies on the Capitol steps.

title: Auburn Sets Back Georgia
description: ATHENS, Ga., Nov. 17 (AP)  Auburn, led by the running of James Brooks and Joe Cribbs, trounced Georgia, 3313, today and denied the Bulldogs the Southeastern Conference championship and a berth in the Sugar Bowl for the second straight year.

title: ROBERT BYRNE
description: Off the games Mikhail Tal produced in his kickoff streak of 5 points out of six rounds in the Riga Interzonal Tournament, his best, he judged, was his sixthround victory over the American grandmaster James Tarjan.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: A few years ago, Thomas L. Holton, then one of hundreds of partners at the big accounting firm of Peat, Marwick, Mitchell & Company, sent a doctored clipping of a newspaper cartoon to the chief accountant of the Securities and Exchange Commission, A. Clarence Sampson. Mr. Sampson is the accounting profession's principal regulator.

title: United Press International
description: SALISBURY, Zimbabwe Rhodesia  There was no dancing in the streets when word arrived of the breakthrough in the London peace talks last week. After seven years of war and at least eight unsuccessful settlement initiatives, neither whites nor blacks will believe that the worst is over until they experience peace for themselves.

title: Conversions of Empty Schools Move Ahead Despite Obstacles
description: For the last five years the huge 1891 redbrick structure that used to house the Benjamin Franklin High School in Yonkers has been standing empty, its windows cracked, its walls swelling and peeling. Its interior was used as a dumping ground for old equipment from other schools. The yard became littered with neighborhood trash. Instead of the buzz of student chatter there has been silence, a sense of limbo about the place.

title: WESTCHESTER HOUSING How to Trace the History of a House
description: EVEN if a homeowner knows that George Washington never slept in the house, he or she is often curious about who did, how old the house is and what interesting events occurred there, according to Karen Kennedy, a preservation consultant who lives in Rye.

title: AN UPSURGE IN CRIME IS PROBLEM IN CHINA
description: PEKING, Nov. 17  When a middleaged Communist Party official was invited to see a play recently at a small theater in an unfamiliar section of Peking, she debated whether to go. That is in a dangerous area, she told a friend.

title: Ignatowicz Paces Union, 1512
description: Mark Ignatowicz, who has scored 133 points this season, scored a touchdown and kicked the extra point with less than two minutes remaining to lift Union over Belleville, 1512, in the semifinals of the North Jersey, Section 2, Group 4 playoffs yesterday at Giants Stadium in East Rutherford.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Dense low clouds cover portions of northern New England. Shower clouds are visible in southern Texas. Multilayered precipitation clouds extend along the Pacific Coast from the Southern Pacific States to the Pacific Northwest. Clear skies prevail In most other sections of the country.

title: Richard T. Henshaw Jr., 67, Dies; Retired From Insurance Concern
description: Richard Townsend Henshaw Jr., a retired executive vice president of Johnson & Higgins, an international insurance brokerage company, died Friday at his home in Riverside, Conn. He was 67 years old.

title: JONESTOWN: THE SURVIVORS STORY
description: Russell Banks keeps the snapshots in a small brown paper bag. In one picture, his wife is smiling, a blue bandana around her short Afro. She holds their baby in one arm. Her other arm is around Banks's brother. Behind them, in a green dashiki, holding their 2yearold daughter, stands Banks himself. In the background is the jungle.

title: Joseph Iglehart, Former Oriole And Yank Owner, Dies in Mishap
description: LUTHERVILLE, Md., Nov. 17 (AP) Joseph Alexander Wilson Iglehart, who once was the largest individual stockholder of the Baltimore Orioles and partowner of the New York Yankees, died yesterday at the age of 88, after having been hit by a car in the driveway of his home in this Baltimore suburb.

title: Quake Rocks North Fiji Islands, Causing Much Property Damage
description: SUVA, Fiji, Nov. 17 (AP)  An earthquake rocked several islands in northern Fiji early today, officials said, including one owned by the New York publisher, Malcolm S. Forbes. No deaths or iniuries have been reported in the quake, Which registered 6.1 on the openended Richter scale.

title: CRIME
description: Almost two years ago, Edith Piller Green's Rotten Apples attracted attention. It was a mystery introducing Dearborn V. Pinch, a querulous old boy with the morals of a tomcat and a thorough command of Edwardian English befitting so veneral5le a gentleman. Now Pinch is back, in SNEAKS (Dutton, $9.95), and he is as engaging a rascal as one can recall.

title: Backgammon:
description: Often in backgammon the game reaches a critical position in which the outcome will be decided in the next few rolls. In such positions accurate tactical play is essential. A key ingredient for precise tactics is an awareness of specifically which numbers are good for your opponent each roll.

title: What's Doing in ZAGREB
description: THE TIES THAT BIND  The 1,000milelong Sava River flows through the heart of Zagreb and passes through Belgrade before emptying into the Danube River. But the ties that bind Zagreb, the commercial capital, with Belgrade, the political capital, often seem as watery as the river that connects them.

title: Italian Commits Suicide At Tomb of John XXIII
description: ROME, Nov. 17 (AP)  A 50yearold Italian barber stepped down into the crypt of St. Peter's Basilica yesterday, asked where Pope John XXIII was buried, then knelt in front of the tomb and shot himself to death, the Vatican police said.

title: Two Large Projects Started
description: Two new federally financed apartment buildings that have design characteristics specifically aimed at assisting the handicapped and the aged are under construction within New York City.

title: A Jazz Label Changes Direction
description: Ten years ago, a classically trained bassist and former production assistant for Deutsche Grammophon started a new record label.

title: Other World Events
description: Emerging last summer from 11 years of military government, Bolivians were not so willing to take back a junta Col. Alberto Natusch Busch thought. Colonel Natusch, who seized power Nov. 1 from a civilian President chosen by the Bolivian Congress in August, stepped out last week after failing to gain support from legislators, labor unions and many of his fellow officers. In his place Congress put its president, Lidia Gueiler. She will serve a oneyear term, followed by new popular elections.

title: G.A.O. Details Rentals Decline
description: WASHINGTON  The nation's rental housing market has reached a crisis stage and the need for housing assistance far outstrips the Government's ability to provide aid, according to a General Accounting Office study.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: The duel between the United States Senate and former President Richard M. Nixon began Sept. 5. On that day the Senate voted a resolution calling on Mr. Nixon to repay the Government for its improvements to his estate in San Clemente, Calif., that had increased the value of the property.

title: Contract Talks Seen as First Big Test
description: From his modest base as a Brooklyn dock union leader, Anthony M. Scotto climbed sometimes gracefully, sometimes toothandnail, toward the peak of political and union power. Many politicans, including President Carter, Governor Carey and former Mayors Abraham D. Beame and John V. Lindsay, sought his support. Nationally, he was an important labor leader, a vice president and general organizer the International Longshoremen's Association. Locally, he was a vital figure in determining the economic future New York's harbor.

title: Young Audiences Shows Dispel Myths
description: If you herded fourthgraders into school auditorium and told them they were about to hear a lecture on opera, their response would almost certainly be Yuck 1  No more eager would they be to find dancers in tutus waiting to inform them about ballet.

title: WASHINGTON Thanksgiving 1979
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 17  Dear Lord: We have so many things to be thankful for this year that I scarcely know where to begin, but for the general sense of gratitude among our people we give special praise.

title: Half Hollow Wins in Soccer
description: Hempstead, L.I., Nov. 17Half Hollow Hills West defeated North Shore of Glen Head, 32, today on John Mashikian's goal after 4 minutes 2 seconds of a second overtime period in the opening round of the Class B New York State scholastic soccer championships at Hofstra University. It was Mashikian's second goal of the game.

title: Managing Director Is Appointed For the American Press Institute
description: David A. Roe, an associate director of the American Press Institute, has been named managing director of the institute, which operates in Reston, Va., a nonprofit education and training center for American and Canadian newspaper executives and staff members.

title: Clemson Hands Irish 4th Defeat
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 17 (AP) Billy Lott's 26yard touchdown run and three field goals by Obed Ariri enabled Clemson to rally from a 10point deficit today and score a 1610 victory over Notre Dame.

title: United Press International
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Nov. 17  Bolivia returned to democratic government today under an interim President, Lydia Gueiler Tejada, and the United States said it would resume aid suspended since a military coup here 16 days ago.

title: Ransom Frees Venezuelan
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 17 (Reuters)  A wealthy retired military officer was released by kidnappers after paying a $365,000 ransom, the police said today. Lazardo Marquez was abducted from his ranch in the state of Apure, 370 miles southeast of here, on Oct. 29.

title: Westchester/This Week
description: ELMSFORD  Same Time, Next Year, starring Betsy Palmer. Tonight and Tuesday through next Sunday. Opens 6:15 P.M., buffet 7 P.M., show 8:30 P.M. Sundays one hour earlier. $18.15 to $20.35. Reservations. An Evening Dinner Theater, 11 Clearbrook Rd. 5922222.

title: Sally Dexter Handel Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard W. Handel of Wilbraham, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sally Dexter Handel, to Alan Scott Wylde, son of Mrs. Katharine W. Wylde of Hendersonville, N.C., and Robert T. Wylde of Denver. Miss Handel and her fiance graduated from Kenyon College.

title: PRESIDENTIAL RACE DIVIDING A.F.LC.I.0.
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17  Although George Meany is leaving behind a labor movement that is largely united, the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations is a house divided on one current issue Presidential politics.

title: French Poster Art
description: NEW BRUNSWICK IT IS hard to imagine the French poster without Paul Colin. He is to poster art in France what Picasso was to Cubism and Monet to Impressionism.

title: Long Island/ This Week
description: ALBERTSON  Watercolors by Joan Sanders; through Nov. 27; Shelter Rock Library, 165 Searingtown Rd. CH 87363.

title: Babybook boom.
description: When the time comes for the statisticians of Publishers Row to close the books on 1979, they may come up with an unexpected conclusion one of the year's liveliest trends has been the increase in popularity of books about the American baby. Twice this year we've had occasion to remark on the unusual number of new volumes dealing with problems of fertility, pregnancy, childbirth and childrearing.

title: Checks Are Demanded On Grants for Colleges
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP)  The Government has shamefully handled its duty to check up on grants to struggling small colleges, a top education official has said, acknowledging Congressional complaints that virtually no auditing is done.

title: CAMERA
description: Sports photography provides enough action and variety of picturetaking opportunities to satisfy the most avid of photographers. In addition to the large professional events, there are also amateur and local sporting events which one can attend in almost every community.

title: President Honecker Was in Ethiopia Last Week
description: SALISBURY, Zimbabwe Rhodesia  Joshua Nkomo calls them the best friends his Rhodesian nationalist army ever had. The approbation shared in many African countries with Marxist or leftleaning governments and by Mr. Nkomo's counterparts in other insurgent movements. In South Africa, Prime Minister P.W. Botha and his generals regard them as the most dangerous harbingers of Communist onslaught they perceive as organized by the Soviet Union and its allies.

title: Dentists Form Union
description: PORT JEFFERSON STATION IN the expectation that a national healthinsurance program will be instituted, the first union specifically for dentists in New York State has been formed on the Island to bargain with the Federal Government.

title: Scuanizzi at War
description: Foreigners don't often linger in Naples these days. The era of dolce far niente is far in the past. There are few firstclass hotels, the vistas have been marred by overbuilding, the bay has been badly polluted, and there was an outbreak of typhoid several years ago that the local authorities, typically, tried to conceal. For those who have seen Naples and its teeming slums only on the screen in The Gold of Naples or, more recently, Seven Beauties, Neapolitan rascality can seem rather endearing. It may be less so for the tourist who has just discovered that his pocket has been picked by the picturesquely ragged putti who he thought were tumbling and dancing about him in hopes of a few coins.

title: Poor Nations Drop OilPrice Plan
description: Special to The New York Times

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: It did not take 32 years for the world to hear the message of Cantor Abraham Brun [About Long Island, Oct. 21]. It was heard and remembered by a shy little girl whose parents were congregants of Temple BethEl in 1948.

title: The Airline and the Astronaut: Can Borman Pull It Off?
description: FRANK BORMAN, the tough, cleancut guy who rose abruptly from national space hero to the top executive post at Eastern Air Lines, is probably facing his most difficult challenge since he piloted the first Apollo spacecraft around the moon a decade ago.

title: Laurie Beth Sikowitz Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Sikowitz of Stony Brook, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Laurie Beth Sikowitz, to David V. Siegel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norton Siegel of Brooklyn. Miss Sikowitz and her fianc are students at the State University of New York at Stony Brook, from which the prospective bridegroom expects to graduate next month and the bridetobe in May.

title: Knicks
description: Until last night Michael Ray Richardson knew Richie Guerin only as the color commentator for the Knick radio broadcasts. What he did not know was that Guerin once played for the Knicks, and that he held the team record of 22 assists in a game, set against the St. Louis Hawks in 1958.

title: City Parcels Bring $11.2 Million
description: New York City made almost $11.2 million this year through the sale of surplus municipal property, the Department of General Services announced yesterday. The department said four sales spread over the year had allowed 461 parcels of land to be returned to productive neighborhood use and full taxpaying status.

title: Article 8  No Title
description: Article 8  No Title

title: Now's the Time to Hit the Trail
description: CONTRARY to popular belief, hiking is not for the glorious summer. The glorious summer has heat, flies, sweat, midges and wasps. Experienced backpackers start to hit the trail in November, when the weather begins to cooperate.

title: Greenwich's History On Display in Tours
description: GREENWICH THE hottest ticket in Greenwich this fall has been a series of Sunday walking tours centering on the town's historical and dwindling architectural heritage. Waiting lists have had to be drawn, and plans are already afoot to revive the series next spring.

title: For Feldman, Office Anyway
description: WITH the elections over and the political junk mail out of our mailboxes, I feel compelled to empty my heart. I want everybody to know why I voted for Martin J. Feldman for Suffolk County Executive:

title: Letters
description: Your editorial (Nov. 11) criticizing my opposition to President Carter's decision to decontrol the price of crude oil has a basic inconsistency of its own. You call decontrol the one action most likely to reduce dependence on. OPEC. Yet you also say decontrol is unlikely ever to reduce imports by more than 5 percent.

title: THE MARKETS
description: The stock market rode a roller coaster last week amid the turmoil over Iran and oil supplies to finish with a token advance. The Dow Jones industrial average moved ahead 9.22 points to close at 815.70.

title: BRIDGE
description: Many of the world championship contests for the Bermuda Bowl, which began on an annual basis in 1950 and are now biennial, have been excellently organized; Taipei in 1971, Bermuda in 1975 and Manila in 1977 come to mind. But those who attended the championships in Rio De Janeiro last month were unanimously of the opinion that the Brazilian organizers headed by Ernesto D'Orsi were about as perfect as human planners can be.

title: The World
description: Israel further consolidated peace with Egypt last week by giving back more of the Sinai, but new trouble in the stilloccupied territories worsened its relations with the Palestinians. The Government ordered the deportation of the Arab Mayor of Nablus, Bassam alShaka, who had been reported as sympathizing with terrorist violence.

title: Victor Herbert  Recordings Pioneer
description: Victor Herbert occupied a unique position in American music during the early years of this century. From concert halls to opera houses to Broadway theaters  even to the halls of Congress, where the latest amendment to the copyright and performance licensing laws was being debatedhis music and name loomed prominently.

title: Lou Carnesecca: On Top of the Charts
description: EACH day, each winter, smoothtalking men in polyester suits, their briefcases bulging with promises, arrive at New York's airports. They are seeking some of the best high school basketball players in America and offering them  at the very least  huge fieldhouses, steelandglass dormitories, steaks on the training table and green lawns.

title: Californians, a Year Later, Still Question Guyana Massacre Events
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 17  A year after Jonestown was wiped out by mass murders and suicides, feeling is still strong here that the events leading to the tragedy at the religious commune in Guyana have not been fully explored and that the role of the United States Government still remains untold.

title: Passing by Melfi Keeps Masuk in Title Picture
description: Masuk completed an undefeated regular season and kept alive its hopes for a Class M state championship berth with a 220 romp over Pomperaug in the highlight of an abbreviated schedule yesterday.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: IF we all do our part, the Federal Department of Energy keeps saying, we can survive the energy crisis. The part the D.O.E. now has in mind is about threequarters of an inch high and is made of bright red plastic.

title: Late TV Listings
description: 9 A.M. (Channel 7) Interface: Teenage prostitution.

title: Rights Leaders Troubled by Prospect of Leftist Gains Among Blacks
description: The killing of five members of the Communist Workers Party by purported members of the Ku Klux Itlan earlier this month has posed a quandary for black civil rights activists.

title: Making Peace With Ghosts of Thanksgivings Past
description: IREMEMBER the summer my grandmother came to take care of us because my mother had pneumonia. I remember she bought a Chubby Checker Let's Twist record at John's Bargain Store.

title: TAXI UNION REACHES A TENTATIVE ACCORD
description: Negotiators for the city's taxi fleet owners and their 15,000 unionized drivers and garage workers reached a tentative agreement early yesterday on a new threeyear contract that reportedly would allow drivers to lease cabs from the fleets and operate them as independent businessmen.
