title: FuelAid Plans: Ready, but Not Set to Go
description: ITH the winter heating season, if not winter itself, already here, Federal and state energyconservation and welfare officials were still grappling last week with the distribution mechanisms of three Federal programs designed to ease the heatingcost burdens of the poor.

title: Comedy Disks, From Mirthful to Morbid
description: How funny are the recent comedy records? A good Index as to how funny such records used to be can be gleaned from listening to 25 Years of Recorded Comedy, a threerecordset recently released by Warner Brothers, containing material not only from their own vaults but from those of other companies as well. Here is Stan Freberg in a deadly accurate takeoff on the thenpopular Dragnet series, tracking down the facts in the case of St. George and the Dragonet. Here is Lily Tomlin, as Ernestine, snorting her taunts at Mr. Gore Veedal  as she threatens him with blackmail if he doesn't pay his phone bill. (Elaine May plays an even more highly educated, totally compassionate Ma Bell supervisor trying to soothe Mike Nichols panic over the prospect of losing his dayim to an impersonal coinbox.)

title: Ashley E. Sweeney To Become a Bride
description: Barbara M. Sweeney of Woodbury, L.I., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Ashley Elizabeth Sweeney, to Walter Gybbon Spilsbury Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Spilsbury of Huntington Bay, L.I. Plans have been made for a wedding next September.

title: In Suburbia, the Fox's Last Stand
description: WILTON WE saw a fox the other night. Its glossy red coat was caught in the glare of the car's headlights as stood uncertain about which way to go.

title: Hearings Start Tomorrow on a New Phase of School Integration
description: LOUISVILLE  The old industrial river town that survived venomous riots and demonstrations by antibusing forces five years ago to establish the country's first citysuburban school integration plan has been quiet recently.

title: Best Sellers
description: The listings above are based on computerprocessed sales figures from 1,400 bookstores in region of the United States.

title: Synagogue's Plan on Cottages Opposed
description: NORTH PATCHOGUE ASYNAGOGUE'S proposal to turn a cluster of rundown summer cottages in North Patchogue into condominiums has met with resistance from residents and civic leaders who live in this lakeside community.

title: Military Seeks to Ease Environmental Curbs On MX Missile Bases
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17The Defense Department, eager to begin work on the new MX mobile intercontinental missile, is seeking the approval of Congress for easing legal and environmental restrictions that many officials believe could pose major obstacles to building the multibilliondollar weapon.

title: Karl Hagenauer, of the famous family of artisans, sculpted this pair of heads.
description: In her own apartment, interior designer Nita Lederman evokes an Art Deco ambience with just two pieces of furniture, which she designed  a rounded sofa of mohair and a glass table with a ziggurat base

title: Engagements
description: Mrs. Joseph Warren Scott Pierson, of New York atil,erannounces the engagement of daughter, Juliet Scott Varick Pierson, to Wilson Michael Parker, of New Milford, Conn. Miss Pierson Is the daughter of the late Joseph Warren Scott Pierson and the granddaughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Walter Pierson of Greenwich, Conn.

title: ARMY COMBAT ROLE FOR WOMEN OPPOSED
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP)  It is clear from a week of hearings that neither Congress nor the Carttr Administration is ready to put women into military combat. But both are considering more combatsupport jobs for women to give them more opporttmities for career advancement.

title: Music of Mountains, Ham and Biscuits
description: ROCKY POINT ERNIE SYKES, who five years ago founded with his son bluegrass band called the Sykes Boys, has never forgotten his mountain heritage, even though he left his West Virginia home to live on the Island when he was 9 Years old.

title: Taxation: Spreading the Burden Is the Equitable Way
description: MOST New Jerseyans  in fact, most Americans rarely stop to think about property taxes except when they pay them and cringe. However, property taxes serve many purposes.

title: Notes/ Ireland's Railroads to Join the Eurailpass System
description: On Jan. 1 Ireland will become the 16th country to join the Eurailpass system, which will then include every western European country except Britain. At its inception in 1959 the system was made up of 13 western European countries and remained at that level until 1978 when it was enlarged by the addition of Finland and Greece. According to an official of the Eurailpass Executive Committee, both of those countries, as well as Ireland, asked to join, but Britain has repeatedly declined invitations to become part of the system that offers the firstclass Eurailpass and the secondclass Eurail Youthpass, both providing travelers with unlimited rail trips for various periods of time.

title: Tough Characters
description: HINESE  AMERICAN freelance journalist Ray Huang is happily sitting in a Vientiane bar one night when he witnesses the brutal murder of an elderly, eccentric American oil geologist. His reportorial instincts aflame, Huang decides to pursue the story. Soon the story is Pursuing him. Monlca Inclsa

title: ANTIQUES Deacon Hale's Chair Is Returned
description: COVENTRY ACHAIR made about 1776 for Nathan Hale's father, which was removed from the Hale homestead when the house was sold in 1832, is now back in the same room where it first was used. The handsome combback Windsor chair with a writing arm was returned Monday  147 years later  to the room where Deacon Richard Hale, Nathan's father, held justice court in the latter part of the 18th century.

title: Those Cordial New York Melodists
description: The latest albums by Barry Manilow and Rupert Holmes  New York pop personalities with formal musical training  attest to the vitality of the Tin Pan Aileynroaaway traamon. Because this tradition dominated American popular music for half a century before the rock revolution, antiestablishment rock critics routinely dismiss it as shallow, elitist and obsolete. But now that New York pop no longer monopolizes the music market, perhaps it is time for a reevaluation.

title: U.S. Team Captures Toronto Jump Title
description: TORONTO, Nov. 17  Despite the loss of two mounts because of injuries, the United States Equestrian Team captured the International riding championship for the seventh time in eight years tonight at the concluding session of the Royal Winter Fair Horse Show.

title: A Successful American Tour Came to an End Last Week
description: DUBLIN  Returning to Ireland after an eightday visit to the United States, Prime Minister Jack Lynch found, government leaders often do in such circumstances, a plateful of disagreeable domestic political issues awaiting him.

title: Associated Press
description: A SURVIVOR'S VIEW OF PLANE MISHAP: A flight attendant walking away from chartered plane that crashed on takeoff Friday near the Grand Canyon In Arizona. Although eight of the 44 persons aboard were hurt, an observer called the emergency landing a very nice piece of flying. Photo was made by Phillipe Georges, passenger.

title: Female Business Owners on the Increase
description: MANY of them started with home offices, working while their children slept or attended school. Others invested life savings in new companies and then devoted seven days a week to insure their success. Some received large loans from family members or local banks. And a handful have recently received the benefit of federally financed training programs.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: There are no fewer than three playwrights involved in Romantic Comedy at the Barrymore, and the trouble with Romantic Comedy at the Barrymore is that not one of them seems to know what a romantic comedy is. Two of the playwrights are characters in the play: Anthony Perkins, highstrung as an overbred racehorse and already celebrated: and Mia Farrow, a mousy admirer from the hinterlands who becomes Mr. Perkins's new collaborator. The third, of course, is the actual playwright who put them there, Bernard Slade, author of Tribute and Same Time, Next Year.

title: Dance: Caracas Ballet Presents Pas de Deux
description: Anyone who feels compelled to say that it takes two to tango might feel just as inclined to say that it takes two to step through a pas de deux. Certainly, that point was made 13 times over Friday night at the City Center when the International Ballet of Caracas presented what was billed as an All Pas de Deux program.

title: Rock Headliners of Today and Yesterday
description: THE BEE GEES SPECIAL  The musical and personal lives of the popular trioMaurice (left), Robin (center) and Barry Gibbare the focus of a 90minute program that will include film footage of several of their recent concerts and interviews conducted by David Frost, Wednesday evening at 9:30 on NBC.

title: Anne Love Fiance Of E. D. Adkins 3d
description: Anne Love and E. Dale Adkins 3d, lawyers in Maryland, will be married on March 1. Their engagement has been announced by the bridetobe's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John B. Love of Westport, Conn. Mr. Adkins is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Adkins Jr. of Salisbury, Md.

title: Nikolais in City Center Run
description: The Nikolais Dance Theater will appear at the City Center, from Dec. 27 through Jan. 6, as part of the Masters of American Dance Series. Two works will have their New York premiere: Count Down and Aviary: A Ceremony for Bird People. The company's repertory will also include its 15yearold work Tent, and Sanctum Suite, Scenario, Divertissement I, Guignol and Gallery. Tickets, from $8 to $15, are available at the City Center box office, at 131 West 55th Street. Performances are at 8 o'clock nightly, except for the 7:30 P.M. openingnight time, and 2 P.M. at matinees.

title: Henry Frommer to Wed Barbara Hymson
description: Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Hymson of Lexington, Ky., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Gay Hymson, to Henry Frommer of New York, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Barney Frommer.

title: MaximumSecurity State Prison Will Be Erected in Ulster County
description: ALBANY, Nov. 17 (AP)  A maximumsecurity state prison will be built at a cost of about $27.5 million near the state's mediumsecurity facility at Wallkill in Ulster County, state officials said today.

title: THEATER A Brisk Delight Without Superstars.
description: DARIEN I HAVE learned strange and wondrous things about musical theater during my visits to productions at dinner theaters. I won't say that I received much necessary education, but I found it all interesting.

title: 2 Filipinos Saved From Sharks
description: MANILA, Nov. 17 (UPI)  The Altai Maru, a Japanese vessel, rescued two Filipino fishermen encircled by sharks after their boat capsized off the coast about 150 miles northeast of Manila, Government report said today.

title: Laughable Bowl Pairings
description: Bowl officials, politicians and members of the National Collegiate Athletic Association have unwittingly combined to offer such a jumble of bowl pairings this season that, in reality, they have created a strong case for a major college football playoff, something the bowls have successfully lobbied against for years.

title: Solving Diverse Problems Leads
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 18 (AP) For 35 years, people looking for answers to questions ranging from how to make profits to how to save lives have brought their problems to the Midwest Research Institute here, one of the country's fastest erowine research facilities.

title: Soprano: Neva Pilgrim
description: ALWAYS a resourceful and imaginative program builder, Neva Pilgrim presented an especially enterprising vocal recital at the Abraham Goodman House Saturday night. The most conventional songs were four selections from Schumann's Minnespiel (Op. 101), but even these attractive inspirations are not exactly overexposed.

title: Yorkshire Killer Writes Of Regret for One Death
description: LEEDS, England, Nov. 18 (Reuters) The police today issued part of a letter believed to be from the longsought killer known as the Yorkshire Ripper in which he apologized for one of the 12 slayings attributed to him.

title: Seahawks 38, Saints 24
description: AT SEATTLE  Jim Zorn completed 24 of 33 passes for 384 yards and four touchdowns as he became only the third player in league history to gain more than 10,000 yards in his first four seasons. The others were Joe Namath and Norm Snead. Both teams emerged from the game with 66 records. The loss was costly for the Saints, who lead the N.F.0 .'s Western Division by only half a game over the Los Angeles Rams. Los Angeles plays Atlanta tonight. Zorn's scoring pitches were of 51 yards to Sam McCullum, 39 and 35 yards to Steve Largent, and 5 yards to Brian Peets. Archie Manning of the Saints completed 20 of 27 passes for 268 yards and one touchdown, a 4yard toss to Wes Chandler. Manning also ran yards for a score.

title: 3 Killed as a Small Plane Strikes A Mountain in Western Vermont
description: BENNINGTON, Vt., Nov. 18 (UPI) Search parties today reached the wreckage of a small plane that crashed into a mountain in the rugged woods of southwestern Vermont. All three persons aboard were dead.

title: Democratic Chiefs Split On Presidential Choices
description: Democratic leaders of the major counties in New York State are divided over whom to support for the Presidential nomination.

title: Khomeini Interview: Networks Face Ethics Issue
description: Mike Wallace, the CBS News correspondent, was in California when the call came in. The message, delivered in a telephone call to New York late last week by an aide to Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini in Iran, was that revolutionary leader was ready to air his views. He would grant the network's longstanding request for an interview if questions were submitted in advance.

title: Chile Judge Seeks Answer to 320 Unmarked Graves
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 18  A civil judge has opened an investigation to determine the origin of hundreds of unmarked graves in the main cemetery here. Roman Catholic bishops say the victims of political executions are buried in the cemetery.

title: Annenberg Proposes TV University of the Air
description: Walter H. Annenberg, president of Triangle Publications and former Ambassador to Britain, is proposing to donate $150 million to public television for the creation of a national university of the air, according to industry sources.

title: In Memoriam
description: GRODINJules. In loving memory. Frances Prter

title: Thais Will Open Border This Week For Huge New Flow of Cambodians
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 18  Urged by Western nations, Thailand has decided to open its borders this week to a huge flow of Cambodians from among as many as 560,000 camped along the frontier.

title: Sporting Gear
description: With the SkateMate kit, you can now take your favorite pair of sports shoes, bolt them to a set of trucks and wheels, and you will have your own personalized roller skates. The kit, produced by American Cycle Systems of Covina, Calif., requires only a drill and screwdriver to install any shoes from size 4 to 11. The mounting hardware includes a footshaped aluminum platform with builtin adjustment holes, trucks, heel risers and toe stops. Kits without wheels cost $25, while those with wheels are $50. They are available at Dream Wheels, 295 Mercer Street, Manhattan, (212) 6770005.

title: Miss Madruga Wins
description: BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 18 (AP) Topseeded Ivanna Madruga of Argentina won the rainplagued Argentine women's open tournament today with a 61, 63 victory over secondseeded Hana Strachanova of Czechoslovakia.

title: The U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Relief Units, Sending 500 Tons of Food Daily to Cambodia, Expect Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 The international organizations providing food to starving Cambodians have built up their shipments to about 500 tons a day, roughly half the daily amount they say they need to avert largescale starvation, accordine to relief officials.

title: Last Week's Active Issues
World News Briefs
description: SALISBURY, Zimbabwe Rhodesia, Nov. 18 (UPI)  Prime Minister Abel T. Muzorewa flew home from London to a hero's welcome today and said ceasefire violations could lead to Britain's banning some parties from planned elections.

title: U.S. Aides Frustrated by Delay in Release of Hostages
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18  Carter Administration officials were frustrated today by the delay in the promised release of black and female hostages from the Embassy in Iran and were tense and concerned over the threatened trial of other hostages.

title: Freight Train Derails in Utah
description: DEVILS SLIDE, Utah, Nov. 18 (UPI)  Union Pacific Railroad said today that five locomotives and 42 cars of a 120car freight train derailed here after a frontend loader hit a bridge and knocked the tracks out of alignment. A Union Pacific spokesman said the westbound freight derailed last night and blocked mainline tracks through Weber Canyon. No one was injured, the spokesman said.

title: Kahn Stand On Chrysler Faulted
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18  Alfred E. Kahn, chairman of the Council on Wage and Price Stability, spoke out of turn and misstated the Administration's position in his recent remarks on the proposed Chrysler loanguarantee program, according to Treasury Secretary G. William Miller.

title: Ellen Berelson Wed To E.M. Mensch 2d
description: The Harmonie Club was the setting at noon yesterday for the marriage of Ellen S. Berelson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving P. Berelson of New York, to Capt. E. Michael Mensch 2d, U.S.A., son of Col. Lester N. Mensch, U.S.A.F., retired, of Moore Haven, Fla., and Dollie B. Mensch of Bradenton, Fla. Rabbi Irwin Lowenheim of the Reform Temple of Suffern, N.Y., performed the ceremony.

title: Browns 30, Dolphins 24
description: AT CLEVELAND  Miami (75) fell out of a firstplace tie in the Eastern Division of the A.F.C. by squandering a 2417 lead late in the fourth quarter and then succumbing in overtime. Don Strock had replaced Bob Griese at quarterback for Miami with Cleveland ahead, 1710. Strock then threw touchdown passes of 2 yards to Bruce Hardy and 4 yards to Delvin Williams, the latter with 3:53 remaining in regulation time. But Brian Sipe, who gained 358 yards with 23 pass completions in 42 attempts, took the (84) Browns 72 yards to the tying touchdown, with Ozzie Newsome scoring on a 35yard reception with 1:21 to play. The Browns needed less than two minutes of overtime to nail down the victory. They covered 74 yards in five plays, winning on a 39yard pass from Sipe to Reggie Rucker. Griese completed 10 of 21 passes for 115 yards but was intercepted twice. Strock hit on six of 10 attempts for 89 yards. The Browns, working against the league's toprated defense, continued as the only team to gain more than 300 yards in every game this season.

title: The Region
description: BORDENTOWN, N.J. (UPI)  Bordentown Regional High School will reopen this week with additional security and without 19 students who were suspended for their part in the fighting between blacks and whites that forced officials to close it Thursday and Friday.

title: Supplementary OvertheCounter Listings
description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: Demand for Iran Flags Is Reported Up in U.S.
description: DETROIT, Nov. 18 (UPI)  Requests for Iranian flags are rising, and local flag dealers report they are unable to meet the demand.

title: The Woman in Charge of Bolivia
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Nov. 18  This weekend brought a first in the numbingly repetitive politics of Bolivia: The Government was entrusted to a woman.

title: Bears Defeat Jets, 2313
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 18  In a final gesture of frustration, Richard Todd grabbed the face mask of Alan Page today when Todd's desperation pass was picked off in the closing seconds by the Chicam Bears.

title: ON PLANE TO EUROPE
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Monday, Nov. 19 The Iranian militants who took over the United States Embassy 15 days ago released three American hostages early this morning, and the three, two black Marines and a woman secretary, left the country.

title: Civil Rights and Church Groups Join Indians Suit Opposing Dam
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (UPI)  Two civil liberties groups and three churches announced today that they would join the Cherokees in their battle to stop the Tellico Dam in Tennessee from flooding sacred Indian burial grounds.

title: Ogaden Refugees Overwhelming Somali Resources
description: ALLAY BADAY, Somalia  The border with Ethiopia is a dry creek bed that also serves as the southern edge of this village of 16,000.

title: Music: Dresden Orchestra Makes American Debut
description: ONE of the sad facts of modern symphonic life is the increasing tendency of the better class of orchestras all over the world to sound pretty much alike. To hear the music historians tell it, at least, that was not the way it was in the days before air travel and recordings made musicians everywhere familiar with one another and with the standards of tone, ensemble and musicianship that could be reasonably expected of uppercrust orchestras. Now it is rare orchestra that can be said to be distinctive in any way.

title: Study Charges Inequities
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP)  Most of the country's 435 Congressional Districts pay more in taxes for the Pentagon than they receive in military spending, and more than half have a net loss of at least $100 million a year, a new study says.

title: Israelis on Patrol Boat Kill 2 Palestinian Guerrillas
description: TEL AVIV, Monday, Nov. 19 (UPI) A navy patrol boat stopped a rubber dinghy approaching the coast of Israel for an apparent attack on a civilian site and killed two Palestinian guerrillas on board in an exchange of fire, the military command announced today.

title: Music: Schneider Leads a New School Concert
description: THE New School began a series of concerts yesterday afternoon, this one yet another extension of Alexander Schneider's already considerable pedagogical and careerbuilding work. The idea here is to pair Mr. SClinetcler  ana perhaps some other established professionals  with alumni of his New York String Orchestra Seminar. That meant yesterday that Mr. Schneider was joined by Samuel Sanders, the pianist, plus four young women players: Linda received a slightly rough but generally hearty and direct runthrough. Otherwise, however, the musicmaking was considerably less effective. In the Haydn Quartet, which has a predominant firstviolin part, Mr. Schneider sounded distinctly uncomfortable in both pitch and tone, and the three women accompanied him timidly. Miss Strommen was pinched and uneasy about pitch in the Mozart and unsure as to phrasing and breathplacement in the Schumann, and the three women Strommen, oboe; Cornelia Schwartz, violin; Tina Pelikan, viola, and Vivian Barton, cello.

title: Treasury 2Year Note Sale Due
description: The Treasury is going to sell twoyear notes on Wednesday, and the securities are expected to yield slightly more than 12 percent.

title: WINE TALK
description: It's Beaujolais time again, and the bombardment of news about the fresh new wine from France is already beginning. Consumers in line at zinctopped bars in Paris are described as agog over the new vintage, and stores in New York are urging customers to put in their orders.

title: OneParty Rule Weakens in Japan
description: TOKYO, Nov. 18  A widening rift in the conservative governing party headed by Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira strongly suggests that oneparty government in Japan is on its last legs, political analysts here say.

title: Notes on People
description: The Bard of Brooklyn Has His Eye on the Bridge

title: Palestinians Burn Truck
description: TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 18 (AP) Palestinian demonstrators burned an Israeli truck in the occupied West Bank today and stoned a busload of Israeli hikers in scattered protests against the planned expulsion of Mayor Bassam alShaka of Nablus. But a general strike in Nablus was reported over.

title: British ExSpy Urges Full Inquiry
description: LONDON, Nov. 18  From his hiding place somewhere in Britain, Anthony Blunt said through his lawyer today that he would welcome a full public inquiry into his 20year career as a Soviet secret agent and the Government's decision in 1964 to grant him immunity from prosecution in return for his confession.

title: MACCHIAROLA TOLD TO RETAIN TEACHERS IN CUTTING BUDGET
description: The New York City Board of Education, attempting to close a $55 million budget deficit, ordered School Chancellor Frank J. Macchiarola yesterday to make specific administrative cutbacks rather than lay off at least 2,300 teachers, as he had proposed.

title: Rono's Running Is as Good as Gold
description: BETHLEHEM, PA.

title: Martie's Anger Captures Cup
description: CAMDEN, S.C., Nov. 18 (AP)  Martie's Anger took the lead after the last of 17 fences today and went on to win the Colonial Cup international steeplechase. The triumph gave Martie's Anger the United States thoroughbredjumping crown for 1979.

title: Kheel to Aid Unions in City Talks
description: The New York Central Labor Council has appointed Theodore W. Kheel, the lawyer and mediator, as a special adviser during the forthcoming transit and municipal labor negotiations, Harry Van Arsdale Jr., president, announced yesterday.

title: Physicians at Metropolitan Lay 2 Deaths to Staff Cuts
description: Staff cuts at Metropolitan Hospital have led to the deaths of two kidney patients there, a group of doctors and nurses at the hospital on the lower fringes of East Harlem charged yesterday.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Kennedy Friend Withdraws Candidacy for Judgeship
description: BOSTON, Nov. 18 Paul F. Markham, the Boston lawyer who was one of two persons who came to the aid of Senator Edward M. Kennedy the night of a fatal auto accident on Chappaquiddick Island 10 years ago, said today that he had withdrawn his name from consideration for a state judgeship.

title: Leslie Cohen Bride Of Stan M. Godoff
description: Leslie Jane Cohen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Cooper Cohen of Chestnut Hill, Mass., and Stan Mark Godoff of Sharon, Mass., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Manuel Godoff. were married yesterday at the Belmont (Mass.) Country Club. Rabbi Emeritus Israel Kazis of Mishkan Tefila of Chestnut Hill and Rabbi Emeritus Roland B. Gittelsohn of Temple Israel in Boston officiated.

title: Money a Weekend Thing At Meat and Potatoes Co.
description: Money, a Victorian comedy about a sudden wealth by Edward BulwerLytton, will be presented by the Meat and Potatoes Company in its showcase at 58 West 39th Street weekends from this Friday to Dec. 16.

title: Carter Easily Defeats Kennedy in Straw Vote Among Florida Democrats
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Nov. 18 President .Carter today collected the straw vote victory that his Florida supporters earned for him last month, defeating Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts 1,114 to 351.

title: Edward Fradkin Weds Eileen Kuhlik, Personnel Aide
description: Eileen Kuhlik and Edward J. Fradkin, a widower, were married yesterday afternoon at the bride's Manhattan home by Rabbi Richard Chapin of Temple EmanuEl.

title: DOOMED BLACK POSES SOUTH AFRICAN ISSUE
description: JOHANNESBURG, Nov. 18  In a country where hangings are commonplace, James Daniel Mange poses an unusual dilemma for the Government, one that could end by destroying Prime Minister P. W. Botha's efforts to present South Africa to the world as a country in the midst of a racial transition.

title: Music: Chamber Society Plays New Crumb Work
description: CHAMBER Music Society of Lincoln Center commissions are coming in, and yesterday it was the turn of George Crumb.

title: Deaths
description: BAKERLucy MiInes. November 18, 1979, of Bedford, N.Y., formerly of Brookhaven, L.I. Wife of the late Alan G., mother of Alan G. Jr., and John Mi!nes Baker. Sister of Albert V. and Kenneth W. Mines. Also survived by nine grandchildren. Memorial Mess at Saint Mary's Church, Katonah, Friday Nov. 23, 1979 at 10:30 A.M. Interment private.

title: Karen Newman Bride Of Richard W. White
description: Karen Jill Newman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Newman of North Woodmere, L.I., was married there yesterday at the Sephardic Temple to Richard W. White, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome B. White of Valley Stream, L.I., and Philadelphia. Rabbi Morris Friedman performed the ceremony.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Iran's threat to withdraw its deposits from American banks and the Carter Administration's decision to freeze Iranian financial assets will make it less likely for interest rates to decline.

title: Marine Shown on TV, But Mother, in U.S., Is Unsure of His Fate
description: MEMPHIS, Nov. 18  The evening television news brought Ladell Maples voice from Teheran, Iran, to the farming town of Earle, Ark., for the first time in almost three weeks today, leaving the young Marine's mother choking back emotion and still unsure of her son's fate.

title: Chiefs 24, Raiders 21
description: AT OAKLAND  The Chiefs (57), beating the Raiders in Oakland for the first time in 13 years, also topped the Raiders twice in one season for the first time since 1964. The victory ended a fivegame losing streak for Kansas City, and severely hurt the Raiders playoff chances. Ken Stabler had a good day for Oakland (66), throwing touchdown passes of 2 yards to Mark van Eeghen, 16 yards to Derrick Ramsey and 3 yards to Cliff Branch. Horace Belton, Tony Samuels and Henry Marshall scored for Kansas City on running plays, and Jan Stenerud booted a 41yard field goal that eventually proved decisive.

title: Amy L. Gold Married to Martin Kaufman
description: At the Fresh Meadow Country Club in Great Neck, L.I., last evening, Amy Lynn Gold, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene P. Gold of Kings Point, L.I., became the bride of Martin Robert Kaufman, son of Mr. and Mrs.tharles Kaufman of Far Rockaway, Queens. Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson performed the ceremony.

title: BirdWatchers In the Garden
description: FOR the first time in this National Basketball Association season, Madison Square Garden was sold out. But the 19,591 devotees had not gathered Saturday night to see the Knicks; instead they had come to view Larry Bird, to see if all those tall tales could possibly be true, to see if he almost singlehandedly had turned the Boston Celtics into a contender again. When the Celtics were introaucea, Dave Cowens and Nate Archibald, two old names, were accorded polite applause. But when the new name, Larry Bird, with his blond mane and blond mustache, trotted into the spotlight in his green warmup suit, the decibels increased.

title: Cindy Israel Is Married to Ronald J. Levine
description: Cindy Israel, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Hyman Israel of West Orange, N.J., was married last evening to Ronald J. Levine, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis L. Levine of North Valley Stream, L.I. Rabbi Edward Feld, director of the Princeton University Hillel Foundation, performed the ceremony at Temple Beth Sholom in Livingston, N.J.

title: Hearing Today on 5Year Plan
description: The first in a series of statewide hearings intended to help devise a fiveyear plan to provide better and more comprehensive care for the mentally ill in New York State is to start at 10 A.M. today on the 44th floor at 2 World Trade Center. The State Office for Mental Health will also hold sessions tomorrow, in the meet ing room on the 56th floor. The talks in the morning will be devoted to plans for children and youth and services for the elderly, while in the afternoon the discussions will deal with forensic services and plans for adults. Dr. James A. Prevost, Commissioner of Mental Health, is to make an interim report to the Governor and the Legislature in February.

title: Consumer Confidence Up Again
description: Consumer confidence rose for the second consecutive month in October, according to the Conference Board's latest survey, released yesterday. The confidence index was at 8,5.6 in October, up 9 points from September.

title: Uganda to Allow Miniskirts
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Nov. 18 (Reuters)  Wigs, miniskirts and split skirts, banned in Uganda under the administration of Idi Amin, the deposed dictator, will get the approval of the country's interim Parliament tomorrow.

title: Demonstrations by U.S. Students Are Revived by New Iranian Move
description: Though student protesters in the United States last week were As vocal as their counterparts holding the American Embassy in Teheran, most campus demonstrations were limited to flagburning, marching and the occasional harassing of Iranian students.

title: Texas Burn Center Strives to Heal Injured Marines
description: SAN ANTONIO, Nov. 15  It is warm on the ward, 80 degrees. The seared young bodies, stripped as they are of the insulating envelope called skin, would lose too much heat otherwise. Many of them tremble anyway.

title: Local Business Journals Bullish on Their Future
description: CHICAGO  Last year Joe Cappo, an experienced business columnist for The Chicago SunTimes, left to join a fledgling publication, Crain's Chicago Business, published by Crain Communications Inc. His colleagues were surprised and skeptical.

title: Postseason Bowl Lineups
description: Garden State Bowl  Dec. 15, East Rutherford, N.J.: Temple (82) vs. team to be named.

title: Ballet Theater Cancels Fall Season in Capital
description: The management of the American Ballet Theater yesterday canceled the company's fourweek fall season, scheduled to begin Dec. 4 at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington. The action came after Ballet Theater dancers had overwhelmingly rejected the company's latest contract offer in a vote Friday.

title: 10 Injured as Japanese Plane Hits Turbulent Aii Over North Pacific
description: TOKYO, Nov. 18 (Reuters)  At least seven American passengers and three Japanese flight attendants were injured today when a Japan Air Lines DC10 bound for New York was jolted in turbulent air over the North Pacific, a spokesman for the airline said.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: QUIET NIGHT Mondays are traditionally subdued on the neon scene. But there is a real bargain at Backstage, 318 West 45th Street, where you can stop by after a show and enjoy one of the best pianobar entertainers in town, Charles DeForest. He plays like liquid gold, with a mellow voice suggesting he has curled up inside the melodies, and he dusts off gems nobody has heard in years.

title: Jilting Love
description: From here, he said, sipping wine 107 stories high at Windows on the World, even slums look beautiful.

title: Outdoors: Ski Equipment Is Speeding Into the 80's
description: AS the 1980's approach, speed is the name of the game in skiing. The dominant trend in equipment now is highperformance gear. And the reasons, contend industry experts, are due in part to the surge of interest in downhill skiing generated by the 1980 Winter Olympics as well as the boom in recreational racing.

title: Volcanic Rocks Strike 2 Planes
description: KAGOSHIMA, Japan, Nov. 18 (Reuters) Redhot rocks cracked the windshields of two Tristar jet airliners over the Sakurajima volcano but both planes landed safely, officials of All Nippon Airways said today. The two planes were carrying a total of 330 people. The 3,663 foothigh volcano is six miles east of this southern Japanese city.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Canucks 5, Canadiens 2
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Nov. 18 (UPI)  Thomas Gradin and Jere Gillis scored in an eightsecond span tonight to spark the Vancouver Canucks to a 52 victory over the Montreal Canadiens. It was the Canucks first victory ever at home against the Canadiens; they had previously lost 15 and tied six.

title: Too Many Hours in Front of the Tube
description: Parents who fret that their children's minds are turning to mush from watching too many television cartoons and comedies may be relieved to learn that the Federal Communications Commission is worried, too. A recent F.C.C. staff report concludes that broadcasters have done little to strengthen the educational value of television. It recommends that stations be required to broadcast at least seven and a half hours of instructional programs each week.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Barnes Group Inc., a diversified international company, has elected to its board John D. Fassett, president and chief executive officer of the United Illuminating Company, New Haven.

title: Byrd Says Nation Has No Choice But to Switch to Coal for Energy
description: WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Nov. 18 (UPI)  Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, the Senate Democratic leader, said today that the United States had no alternative but to turn to coal to meet its energy needs.

title: Plane With Thorium Blows Up, 3 Die
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 18 (AP)  An airplane whose cargo included 15 pounds I of explosive devices and a minute quantity of lowlevel radioactive material blew up in flight today and crashed in a thinly populated area. All three crewmen were killed, officials said.

title: Washington Watch
description: WASHINGTON

title: Indian Point Nuclear Plant Site Assailed
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18  A senior official of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission has said in a sworn statement that placing the nuclear power plant at Indian Point near New York City was insane and that emergency response planning for a serious accident there was a nightmare.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Fred L. Hartley, the chief executive officer of the Union Oil Company who was elected last week as chairman of the American Petroleum Institute, knows that he has his work cut out for him. But he also knows exactly what he wants to accomplish during his twoyear tour, which begins next year, as head of the oil industry's principal trade association and lobbying arm.

title: Trial of Hostages Unacceptable, Senator Baker Tells Governors
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 18  Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee declared today that Iran's threat to try some of the American hostages held in Teheran on possible espionage charges was totally unacceptable and should bring an American reaction.

title: Iran's Exports: Hard to Limit
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (Reuters) Iran's cash needs are likely to keep it from holding down oil exports to the level forecast by Iranian leaders, according to a Congressional study.

title: Patriots 50, Colts 21
description: AT FOXBORO, Mass.  Rebounding from a 35point loss to the Broncos in Denver last week, the Patriots (84) scored 27 points in the second quarter and took sole possession of first place in the American Conference Eastern Division. New England, reaching 50 points for the second time this season, was led by three players: Steve Grogan, who threw two touchdown passes; John Smith, who booted three field goals, and Stanley Morgan, who returned a punt 80 yards for a score. The Colts (48) played again without Bert Jones.

title: Bottom Line in School Budget for New York City: Politics
description: The tumult in City Hall in recent weeks and the emergency Board of Education meeting yesterday over how to eliminate the projected deficit in the board's budget are proof once again that at bottom the budget is a political document.

title: Proposal Rejected On Steel Wages
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 18 (UPI) Workers at three United States Steel Corporation fabricating plants, facing possible shutdowns because of rising labor costs, this weekend overwhelmingly rejected a proposal to hold the line on wages.

title: Chargers Top Steelers, 357
description: Bidding for their first playoff appearance in 14 years, the San Diego Chargers put their credentials on the line yesterday before a national television audience. They were most impressive. The Chargers intercepted five Terry Bradshaw passes, four of the steals setting up touchdowns, and pounded the Pittsburgh Steelers, 357, at San Diego.

title: The City
description: A small pipe bomb exploded yesterday between two banks in midtown Manhattan, shattering several windows, but causing no injuries or extensive damage.

title: Labor Blunts White House Plan on Jobless Benefits
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18  Organized labor appears to have gained the upper hand in two politically significant battles with most of President Carter's economic advisers, over cash benefits for the unemployed.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: Go Michigan Car Set Afire
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 18 (UPI)  Reveling Ohio State University fans set fire to a car bearing a Go Michigan sign yesterday, a few hours after their football team had beaten Michigan at Ann Arbor for the Big Ten Conference title and a trip to the Rose Bowl.

title: McEnroe Captures London Tournament
description: WEMBLEY, England, Nov. 18 (AP)  John McEnroe continued his twomonthold winning streak today, defeating Harold Solomon, 63, 64, 75, to win the London Grand Prix tennis tournament.

title: Stage: jail Diary of Albie Sachs, on South Africa
description: AMONG the works of dramatic literature condemning South Africa's policy of apartheid, The Jail Diary of Albie Sachs occupies an odd but intriguing position. As adapted for the stage by David Edgar, this actual story of a white South African lawyer who was imprisoned in solitary confinement for almost six months for his political dissidence lacks the intensity and the profundity of the plays of Athol Fugard. Mr. Fugard is the conscience of South Africa. Mr. Edgar is an Englishman, whose distance is more than one of geography. His play, which opened last night at the Manhattan Theater Club, is more didactic than dramatic. It is a reasonable assessment of an irrational situation  an approach that is justified by the subject matter.

title: Spot Oil Market Expanding
description: BONN, Nov. 18  The spot oil market, despite international criticism and attempts to control it, is booming.

title: Bills 19, Packers 12
description: AT ORCHARD PARK, N.Y.  The Bills (66) stayed in contention on four field goals by Nick MikeMayer and then scored the winning touchdown with 3:04 left to play on a 1yard plunge by Mike Collier, a reserve fullback. The score ended an 81yard drive that took 15 plays. Green Bay (48) scored all its points in the first half.

title: Banks Fear Erosion of City Gains
description: New York City's two largest banks have warned that the expected recession will largely wipe out the economic gains the city has made over the last two years.

title: Union Rejects Contract Proposal In Coast Transit System Dispute
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 18 (UPI) One of two unions involved in a dispute with the Bay Area Rapid Transit District rejected a contract proposal today that would have returned 1,700 employees to their jobs for the first time in almost three months.

title: Helayne Oberman Is Bride of Dr. Paul Mitchell Stoopack
description: Helayne Oberman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Oberman of Flushing, Queens, was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. Paul Mitchell Stoopack, son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Stoopack of the Bronx. Rabbi Abraham Eckstein performed the ceremony at the Fresh Meadows (Queens) Jewish Center.

title: North Stars Lose Their Top Scorer
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Nov. 18 (AP)  Bobby Smith, last season's National Hockey League rookie of the year, will be lost to the Minnesota North Stars for four to six weeks because of a broken ankle

title: Connecticut State Police Approve TwoYear Pact
description: MERIDEN, Conn., Nov. 18 (AP)  Illustrating their discontent over contract negotiations and staff levels, the state police gave only a narrow margin of approval to a twoyear contract today

title: Bridge:
description: CINCINNATI, Nov. 18  A pair from California, using a most unusual convention, captured the national mixed pair championship title at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here last night.

title: In N.B.A., Even a Scorecard Doesn't Help
description: The following article is based on reporting by Sam Gotdaper and Carrie Seidman and was written by Miss Seidman.

title: Books of The Times
description: DRINK. By Constantine FitzGibbon. 201 pages. Doubleday. $8.95.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Rest Puts Gladiolus In Form at Aqueduct
description: Freeman E. McMillan, the trainer, gave Sea Spray Farm's Gladiolus an eightmonth vacation at an upstate New York farm earlier this year. The rest has helped.

title: Bucs Rout Giants, 313
description: TAMPA, Fla. Nov. 18  So it goes for the Giants, another season without making the playoffs.

title: Bruins Top Whalers On Secord's Goal, 54
description: BOSTON, Nov. 18 (AP)  Al Secord scored on a 30foot shot with less than three minutes to play tonight to give the Boston Bruins a 54 National Hockey League victory over the Hartford Whalers. It was the first game ever between the New England rivals.

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: Two years ago today Anwar elSadat went to Jerusalem. Astonished millions in Israel and around the world heard him tell the Knesset:

title: A Feminist's Trials In an Islamic Society
description: Laila AbouSaif scholar, dramatist and filmmaker  is one of the Arab world's most notorious women. It isn't a distinction she sought, nor one that makes life easy. As a feminist in Egypt and an active and outspoken cntic at the Khomeini regime's treatment of women in Iran, she has collided headon with Islamic fundamentalism, and feels bruised by the encounter. Attacked in print, reviled in public and stripped of her small Cairo theater, she recently turned up in New York to rest and think hard about her choices. Feminism takes no small courage and stamina in the Middle East.

title: Music: Calypso Rose
description: I LIKE experimenting, Calypso Rose commented halfway through her Saturday evening concert at Columbia University, especially on humans. So she borrowed an electric guitar from a member of MaSter Mind, the Brooklynbased band that had been engaged to back her, and accompanied herself on a new composition, as yet unrecorded.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Patchy cloudiness is visible in the South Atlantic States and low clouds stretch from Central Plains States to the Texas Gulf coast. Broken low and middle level clouds cover the Rockles and the Pacific Northwest. Clear skies cover the rest of the country.

title: TV: Dionne Quintuplets, A Study in Exploitation
description: AS children, they were the cuddly darlings of a decade badly in need of diversions from economic woes. Growing up after World War II, they began suffering the consequences of a childhood that had elevated exploitation to almost vicious levels.

title: The Palestinian Mission
description: The question of Palestine is a matter with a detailed history traced in the lives of the four million Palestinians. it is not sometmng mat can be made, whether by legal, military, cultural, or psychological means, to go away. Yet the question of Palestine is a concrete historical one that can be comprehended in human terms; it is not a gigantic, psychological monster poised to threaten the entire world. But this is precisely how It has been represented. Zionism first refused to acknowledge the existence of native inhabitants in Palestine, and when it did, it recognized only native inhabitants with no political or national rights; insofar as those natives claimed rights, the struggle for those rights was equated with terrorism, genocide, antiSemitism. This is not only nonsense; it is also license to extend a century of violence against Palestinians for another long period of time, and to refuse to settle with history and with truth. Worse, such an attitude insures the recurrence of more violence, more suffering, more waste, more futile security arrangements.

title: Governments Fault Hold on Iran Assets
description: PARIS, Nov. 18  President Carter's decision to freeze official Iranian Government holdings at American banks is coming under criticism by foreign governments and central banks that fear it will add to world economic woes by further undermining confidence in the dollar.

title: Amid Oil Riches, Mexico's Poor Fare Badly
description: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 18  Marta Marin has cut out pocket money for her six children since bus fares went up again. Baldina Rojas de Mendoza can now afford milk and meat for her family only two days a week. Blanca Estela Prendes this fall switched her 6yearold son to a Government school because private tuition fees had risen so sharply.

title: Weekly Lotto Numbers Drawn
description: The numbers picked Saturday night in New York State's weekly Lotto drawing were 36, 10, 31, 4, 11 and 32. The supplementary number was 28.

title: David Herz, Stage Manager, Weds Janet Stahl, Teacher
description: Janet Stahl, a specialeducation teacher in the New York City schools, was married yesterday afternoon to David Herz, a stage manager for the National Broadcasting Company. Rabbi Michael Rosen performed the ceremony at the couple's home in Briarwood, Queens.

title: Women's Colleges: Issues for the 80's
description: The difficulty women face in obtaining faculty posts and the confusion female students reel about accommodating personal interests with career goals were among the key problems addressed by a weekend gathering of British and American women's college presidents.

title: Redskins Topple Cowboys, 3420
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18  The Washington Redskins defeated the Dallas Cowboys decisively today, 3420, and after the game the calm Cowboy coach, Tom Landry, said, We are in a lot of trouble.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: It is part of baseball lore that Bill Wambsganss made the only unassisted triple play in a World Series game. When and how did he do it?

title: Girl, 3, Is Killed in Gunfight
description: GLENDALE, Calif., Nov. 18 (AP) The 3yearold daughter of a reserve Los Angeles County sheriff's deputy was killed in a gunfight between her father and two suspects in a supermarket robbery, the authorities said. They said that the deputy, Gerald Slagle, saw the robbery in progress last night and confronted two men when they came outside. Mr. Slagle had placed his daughter, Jennifer, behind a car, but she was struck by a bullet fired by one of the suspects. The two men escaped. Mr. Slagle was unhurt.

title: Officer Shoots Woman As He Fights Attacker On Subway Platform
description: A female subway passenger was slightly wounded last night by a New York City police officer who was firing at a man who had attacked him in a Queens subway station, the police said.

title: Kennecott Dividend Up
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 18 (Reuters)  The Kennecott Copper Corporation increased its regular quarterly dividend on Friday to 35 cents a share from 30 cents a share, payable Dec. 17 to shareholders of record Nov. 27.

title: Oilers 42, Bengals 21
description: AT HOUSTON  The Oilers moved into a tie with the Steelers for first place in the A.F.C. Central Division as Earl Campbell ran for a pair of touchdowns and Dan Pastorini passed for one before suffering an eye injury. Helping the Oilers to their fourth straight victory were five interceptions of Cincinnati passes, including three off Ken Anderson. Campbell, the A.F.C.'s leading rusher, scored on runs of 2 and 13 yards while gaining 112 yards on 19 carries. Pastorini passed 17 yards to Mike Barber before his eye was scratched in the second quarter. He was sidelined the rest of the game and was replaced by Gifford Nielsen, who hit on his first six passes and 10 of 16 over all for 139 yards. Houston doctors said the injury to Pastorini was not believed serious.

title: Confusion Clouds Issue of Iranians Holding Student Visas in the U.S.
description: American immigration officials say there may be twice as many Iranians holding student visas in this country as previously believed. But they say they have no idea how many of the Iranians are here illegally because the Immigration and Naturalization Service has made little effort up to now to determine which of them are holding expired visas or are no longer attending classes.

title: Sports Briefs
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 18 (AP) Berwy Parsons won the $188,000 Los Angeles Times 500 stockcar race and Richard Petty, who finished fifth, captured his seventh Grand National championship by finishing ahead of Darrell Waltrip in the final NASCAR race of the season today at Ontario Motor Speedway.

title: The Shrine Revisited
description: IN Ann Arbor, Mich., Waco, Tex., Seattle, and way stations, college football teams were contending for invitations to postseason bowls. In New Haven, Conn., they were undergoing a religious experience. It was The Game, Yale versus Harvard in the shrine called Yale Bowl, the 96th observance of a rite first solemnized 104 years ago.

title: Around the Nation
description: BOSTON, Nov. 18 (AP)  Firefighters created a curtain of water to protect historic Faneuil Hall and the Quincy Market in downtown Boston from a threealarm fire raging 100 feet away last night.. GALVESTON, Tex., Nov. 18 (UPI) New waves of crude oil leaked from a burning supertanker washed ashore on Galveston Island today, and the Coast Guard said it would probably continue to wash ashore until the winds changed. CARUTHERSVILLE, Mo., Nov. 18 (UPI)  At least three persons were missing and presumed killed in a fire that caved in a 70yearold hotel, the authorities said today. Three persons were injured, including a man who jumped from the second floor of Chaffin's Motor Hotel to escape the flames. WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (UPI)  The General Aviation Manufacturers Association has embarked on a program to enroll the largest number of pilots in aviation history in air safety seminars.

title: Vikings 14, Lions 7
description: AT BLOOMINGTON, Minn.  The Vikings (57) halted a threegame losing streak and extended Detroit's plunge to eight games with Rickey Young's two thirdquarter scoring runs. The Lions (111) had scored in the second quarter on a 13yard keeper by Jeff Komlo. After intermission, Young raced 23 yards for the tying touchdown and 2 yards for the game winner.

title: Ecumenical Service Is Set Today In Boston to Foster Racial Peace
description: BOSTON, Nov. 18 (AP)  An ecumenical service in search of racial peace is scheduled for tomorrow on the Boston Common.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: International

title: Advertising
description: THE heads of most of the nation's top ad agencies indicate that clients have been making no advertising budget cuts, minimal cuts or cuts not related to the economy.

title: Ransom Costs Rise for U.S. Business
description: Many of the world's largest companies, lacking a unified defense and willing to pay large ransoms, have become the favored targets of international terrorist groups. By one estimate, they have paid at least $250 million in ransoms in the last decade.

title: San Antonio Symphony Discharges Conductor
description: SAN ANTONIO (AP)  The San Antonio Symphony has discharged Francois Huybrechts, the young conductor hired 18 months ago, according to symphony officials.

title: 5 Dead as Plane Is Discovered Where Another Crashed Nearby
description: LIVERMORE, Calif, Nov. 18 (UPI)A second plane crash was discovered yesterday 400 yards from where another downed plane was found the night before. Five persons were killed in the two crashes. The authorities said the two light planes may have collided during a heavy rainstorm.

title: Sports World Specials
description: Slamming the Dunk

title: Broncos 38, 49ers 28
description: AT SAN FRANCISCO The Broncos remained tied with San Diego for first place in the A.F.C. Western Division, rolling to their fourth straight triumph. The Broncos trailed, 2110, in the first half, but rallied as Craig Morton threw three touchdown passes, of 13 yards to Rick Upchurch, 12 yards to Otis Armstrong and 9 yards to Riley Odoms. Bo Swenson of the Broncos ran 88 yards for a touchdown with a fumble recovery in the second half. James Owens, a rookie, ran 85 yards on a kickoff return for a San Francisco (111) touchdown.

title: Israel Delays Dismantling of Settlement on West Bank
description: TEL AVIV, Nov. 18  The Israeli Government averted a showdown with militant settlers today by partially delaying the enforcement of a court order to dismantle the settlement of Eilon Moreh on the Israelioccupied West Bank.

title: Lake Placid Braces Itself As Olympic Games Near
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Nov. 18  The blue and white banner flapping from the wall of the new Olympic Center bears the message Welcome World, We're Ready. And Main Street is a festive blur of Olympic signs, souvenirs anO stickers.

title: Pope to Visit Turkey This Month
description: ROME, Nov. 18 (UPI)  Pope John Paul II announced today that he would visit Turkey at the end of this month to seek further progress toward reuniting the Roman Catholic and Eastern Orthodox Churches.

title: City's Jaycees Take Sides in Dispute Over Women's Role
description: No group in New York City calls itself the New York City Jaycees anymore. But for the last year, in a continuing disagreement over the role of women in the organization, two groups have claimed to be that group's true representative in New York.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Freeing of Hostages by Race and Sex Is Debated
description: The whole thing is so unfair; now we're dealing with degrees of unfairness. Joann SiIke, a Des Moines teacher, said when asked about Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's decision to release women and blacks among the hostages held at the American Embassy in Teheran.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Sharif Khan Victor; Miss Maltby Wins
description: At the age of 35, Sharif Khan is, by his admission, getting old, but not, he hastens to add. over the hill.

title: Area Districts Compared
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP)  Following are New York, New Jersey and Connecticut Congressional districts, listed by representative, with statistics showine how each district fared in comparing tax payments that go for United States military purposes and district receipts from military spending. The figures are from an analysis by Employment Research Associates.

title: Some Freed Mental Patients Make It, Some Do Not
description: Mental Patients and the Community

title: Market Place
description: IF the small investor is not doing well in the stock market, he should consider mutual funds  or so argue two of the more successful women in the field of finance.

title: Sports Today
description: FOOTBALL

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for week follows:

title: G.M. Layoffs in Buffalo
description: BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 18 (AP) The General Motors Corporation announced the indefinite layoff of 364 workers, effective Nov. 26, at the Chevrolet axle plant here. G.M. said the layoffs would result from cutbacks at Chevrolet assembly plants. The axle plant normally employs about 3,500. On Aug. 10, the plant furloughed 360 workers and all but 79 have been called back to work.

title: Trinity Church Celebrates New Housing Site
description: Parishioners and participants in the St. Margaret's House project, a 250 unit complex for the elderly and handicapped, paraded from Trinity Church yesterday to the building site, on Fulton Street. Maggie Kuhn, a founder of the Grey Panthers, an activist group for the elderly, spoke at a service of celebration. Sponsored by St. Trinity parish, the complex was named for the Society of St. Margaret, whose sisters perform social service work in the community.

title: Dance: Nancy Meehan Offers Two Premieres
description: THE Nancy Meehan Dance Cornpany presented two premieres by Miss Meehan Saturday night at Pace College's Schimmel Center for the Arts. As usual, they were marked by the strong sense or form and highly original combinations of phrasing and movement typical of Miss Meehan's work.

title: Candidates Unite on Trucking
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18  However intense the contest may grow between President Carter and Senator Edward M. Kennedy for the 1980 Democratic nomination, the two candidates thoroughly agree on at least one issue: The nation needs sweeping changes in trucking regulations.

title: $60,000 Theft A Blow to Pride Of School Team
description: Three years after losing its athletic equipment in a theft, the football team at George Washington High School in upper Manhattan took possession in September of a new football field and $60,000 in uniforms and other equipment.

title: Town on the Cold Alaska Tundra Warmed by Frontier Hospitality
description: BETHEL, Alaska, Nov. 18 (AP) With its ramshackle buildings, negligible roads and an eroding waterfront lined by rusting car bodies, Bethel is one of Alaska's ugly ducklings. But, its residents say, in terms of people this may be one of the nation's beauty spots.

title: De Gustibus Exploring Bartenders Secret Code
description: The term 86 is used widely by bartenders and others to indicate that a customer is in his cups and must not be served another drink. Similarly, in restaurants it indicates that the kitchen has run out of one dish or another.

title: Rozelle Assails Garvey Memo
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 18 (UPI)  Commissioner Pete Rozelle of the National Football League today condemned a memorandum issued by Edward J. Garvey, the executive director of the N.F.L. Players Association that charged professional football with racism.

title: Theater Hall of Fame Enshrines 51 Artists
description: The Theater Hall of Fame, providing sustained applause for a largely evanescent art form, made up for lost time last night by enshrining 51 illustrious names in its Broadway pantheon.

title: Long Island Philharmonic in Debut
description: THE Long Island Philharmonic, which its backers hope will furnish Nassau and Suffolk Counties with a symphonic organization of unprecedented local prominence, made its debut over the weekend with concerts in Hempstead, Hauppauge and Huntington. Christopher Keene was the conductor, and the program consisted of Rossini's Semiramide Overture, Stravinsky's The Rite of Spring and Rachmaninoff's Second Piano Concerto, with Jorge Bolet as soloist. .

title: Stevenson Weighs Race But Rules Out Primaries
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (UPI)  Senator Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois said today that he might still seek the Democratic Presidential nomination, but probably only if the party's national convention deadlocks on choosing a candidate.

title: Harold D. Hodgkinson, Retired Head of Filene's
description: Harold D. Hodgkinson, former president and chairman of the Board of Filene's, the Boston department store, died Saturday in Boston. He was 89 years old.

title: Struggling Rangers Win
description: For one night anyway, they looked like springtime's Rangers again. There was Don Murdoch, firing in two firstperiod goals after the St. Louis Blues had taken a 10 lead. There was Ulf Nilsson, still recovering from the flu, killing off a 5on3 penalty almost singlehandedly. There was Mario Marois, coming out of a personal slump with a goal after he had worked two perfect giveandgo passes with Nilsson and Anders Hedberg. There were the Rangers, winning, 53, last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: An Aggressive New Leader for Mine Union
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18  The charges of simple assault were dropped by the city prosecutor here because, on the District of Columbia court record, the man was a first offender. But people who walked the castlelike corridors of the United Mine Workers building here in 1976 say they will long remember the 220 pounds of Sam Church Jr.  the miner who became the union's 13th president Friday  hurtling down the hall and punching out Rick Bank, a young staff lawyer, for allegedly disclosing unflattering information about the union to reporters.

title: Footprints, Possibly the Oldest By Ancestor of Man, Are Found
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18  Seven footprints that may be the oldest made by direct ancestor of man have been unearthed by scientists exploring the ecology of an ancient lake in northern Kenya.

title: Chess:
description: One mark of a strong player is the ability to spot the right moment to force a transition from the middle game to the end game. There are many cases where retaining a Middle game offers obscure winning chances, but converting to an ending produces decisive advantage.

title: Eagles 16, Cardinals 13
description: AT PHILADELPHIA  The Eagles (84) joined Dallas and Washington in a threeway tie for first place in the National Conference Eastern Division. Tony Franklin, the rookie placekicker, had booted three field goals, but after three quarters the Eagles trailed, 139. Philadelphia scored the deciding touchdown seven seconds later on a 40yard pass play from Ron Jaworski to Keith Krepfle. Ottis Anderson gained 112 yards on 17 rushes for St. Louis. Jaworski completed 11 of 27 passes for 141 yards but completed three on the crucial 70yard drive that resulted in the winning touchdown. Wilbert Montgomery carried 26 times for Philadelphia and netted 118 yards.

title: ESSAY
description: WASHINGTON  The opening bell is breaking up that old gang of mine.

title: A Southern Sheriff With a Ph.D.
description: LEXINGTON, S.C., Nov. 18 (UPI) With his beefy appearance, red face and Southern drawl, Sheriff James R. Metts fits the stereotype of a redneck sheriff from Dixie.

title: KENNEDY DECLARES HIS FITNESS IN CRISES
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18  Senator Edward M. Kennedy asserted today that he had always acted responsibly under pressure and that that, in addition to his long, indepth involvement in government, made him uniquely qualified to be President.

title: Police in Chicago Suburb Gather
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 18 (AP)  week before his death, Mayor William Hawkins of the Chicago suburb of Phoenix scrawled a brief and chilling note: I was to be executed Tuesday but I got a stay of sentence and I am now on probation.

title: 3 in Courtyard News Conference Tell of Life as Embassy Captives
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 18  Shortly before 7 o'clock this evening, acting on word passed by the students holding scores of American hostages here, several hundred journalists from more than a dozen countries began lining up at a side gate in the 12foot brick wall surrounding the American Embassy.

title: Good News From Three Continents
description: Against the odds, British diplomacy has produced an agreement that could end a long, cruel and bloody war in southern Africa. Only the terms for a ceasefire remain to be decided at the Zimbabwe Rhodesia talks In London. Considering the distance the rival delega tions have covered to reach this compromise, the last lap, though it has its pitfalls, ought to be downhill.

title: Nets Down Spurs, 107105
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Nov. 18  I can't believe it, screeched a middleaged woman seated near midcourt at the Rutgers Athletic Center tonight, dumping the contents of her purse onto the floor as she jumped to her feet. Neither could most of the 5,248 feverpitched fans, who rose in in unison.

title: Nation's Schools Struggle to Hold Down Fuel Costs
description: Insulation and wood paneling now cover half of the windows in elementary schools in Etowah, Ark. One hour before classes end at St. Elizabeth's High School in Oakland, Calif., custodians turn the heat down 25 degrees. Students at Dart mouth compete regularly to maintain the most energyefficient house on campus. The most frugal dorm recently won a keg of beer from administrators who in the last year have seen oil prices climb from $12.50 to $22 a barrel.

title: Campbell Raises Dividend
description: CAMDEN, N.J., Nov. 18 (Reuters) The Campbell Soup Company said Friday that it had increased its quarterly dividend to 471/2 cents a share from 44 cents, payable Jan. 31 to shareholders of record Jan. 10.

title: Rodale Press: Organic Venture
description: EMMAUS, Pa.  At the Rodale Press recently, there was one person , working on building a better thermoshade, something to put on your window to shut out the winter cold. Another staff member was toiling over a contraption roughly resembling an exercise bike that would shred grain as you pedaled. Somebody else was harvesting a crop of catfish in a backyard swimming pool.

title: Theater: Altar Boys
description: ALTAR BOYS does what Anita Bryant could not. The play by Stephen Magowan, which opened last night at Theater Four, makes homosexual love not so much naughty as tedious, and not so much erotic as egocentric. Perhaps this is what Mr. Magowan has in mind, although more likely he is on to something else: the desperate straits, for instance, to which love may drive us. The problem, however, is that Mr. Magowan's two lovers must have been pretty desperate to begin with.

title: ZAIRE IS QUESTIONING FUTURE OF MOBUTU
description: KINSHASA, Zaire  They got rid of Amin, Masie and Bokassa, a Zairian journalist was saying here the other day, referring to three African tyrants deposed over the last seven months. I guess the next most likely candidate to go is Mobutu.

title: Commodities
description: IF there is a conservative approach to commodity futures trading, it is the esoteric spread.

title: Creative Directors Quit Della Femina
description: Kathleen Kavanagh and Joseph Genova, the awardwinning cocreative directors of Della Femina, Travisano & Partners, have quit because the agency has refused to give them oneyear contracts. They had just been named partners in the agency.

title: Music: Rostropovich And Miss Vishnevskaya
description: GALINA VISHNEVSKAYA and Mstislav Rostropovich played to strength with her song recital at Carnegie Hall Saturday night, with an allRussian program. And since her strengths as a singer and his as a pianist are considerable in Russian repertory, the occasion was a notable one.

title: A Touch of Lace: Flattery Out of the Past
description: The new fashion in neckwear is one of the fabrics that grandma thought was pretty, too lace.

title: Ryan Pact Reflects Splurge in Baseball
description: In signing a $4.5 million contract with the Houston Astros, the richest in baseball history, Nolan Ryan yesterday placed a large exclamation point on the latest development in the area of player procurement.

title: Msgr. Michael J. McLaughlin, 60, Pastor of Church in Wantagh, L.I.
description: Msgr. Michael J. McLaughlin, pastor of St. Frances de Chantal Church in Wantagh, L.I., who was active in interracial affairs and vocational education in the Roman Catholic Diocese of Rockville Centre, died Saturday of a heart ailment at Mercy Hospital in Rockville Centre. He was 60 years old.

title: Japan Says It Intends to Develop Iwo Jima as Military Training Site
description: TOKYO, Nov. 19 (Reuters)  Iwo Jima, site of one of the fiercest World War II battles in the Pacific, will be used by the Japanese as a military training site, a spokesman for the Japanese Defense Agency said today.

title: Mets Sale One Step Closer
description: The impending sale of the New York Mets was brought a step closer yesterday when the board of directors of the team approved the appointment of a threeman committee to review offers, and reported it expected a sale this winter.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The financially troubled Lafayette Radio Electronics Corporation said yesterday that, based on preliminary results, it had failed to meet the networth requirement at the end of October in its credit agreement with its banks.

title: Britain Informs France It Wants to Give Less To Common Market
description: LONDON, Nov. 19  Britain told France today that the British budgetary contribution to the European Common Market had to be reduced.

title: Taxes
description: Deborah Rankin

title: IN THE NATION
description: LONDON, Nov. 19  British Airways is making preparations for the resumption of direct flights to Salisbury, Rhodesia, perhaps within a week or two, reflecting a remarkable diplomatic achievement about to be concluded here.

title: Two Banks Cut Mortgage Fees
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 19 (AP)  Further signs that the tightness in the supply of mortgages may be easing appeared today when two major California banks announced they were lowering their rates on home loans.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Jersey Utility Bonds to Yield 12%
description: The escalation in returns on fixedincome securities took them to another peak yesterday when an issue of doubleA rated electric utility bonds was offered publicly at 12 percent the highest yield for this popular instrument in the current yield cycle. But even this return was not rich enough for anything resembling a quick sellout.

title: Nixon Immunity Claim Rejected In Suit on Alleged F.B.I. Abuses
description: A Federal judge ruled here yesterday that Richard M. Nixon does not have absolute immunity against a civil damage suit stemming from alleged wiretapping and other activities during his years as President.

title: Piano: Anievas Marks 1959 New York Debut
description: AGUSTIN ANIEVAS made his New York debut in 1959 at Town Hall and promptly set out on a promising career, winning competitions and playing with maior orchestras. On Sunday night, 20 years to the day since his comingout, the pianist gave an anniversary recital at the 92d Street Y that demonstrated his continuing stature as a virtuoso. The way Mr. Anievas stormed through Liszt's Hungarian Dance No. 12 at the conclusion of his program certified him, if certification were needed at this advanced date, as a lion of the keyboard. It was not spotless playing, but it was something better: dashing, controlled, sharply contrasting and altogether idiomatic.

title: World News Briefs
description: PEKING, Tuesday, Nov. 20 (UPI) China charged today that Vietnamese troops intruded deep into Chinese territory and said the incursion resulted in heavy loss of life. The Chinese Foreign Ministry sent the protest note this morning to the Vietnamese Embassy in Peking, The New China News Agency said.

title: Asbury Park's Future, in Black and White
description: ASBURY PARK, N.J.  A few days after Joanne Chesimard, a black militant convicted of murdering a state trooper, escaped from prison, a white policeman arrested four black women, all students at the University of Maryland, outside a bar in a black neighborhood here. The officer, who suspected that one of the group was Miss Chesimard, fired a shot into the air as he was surrounded by a jeering crowd.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yesterday's Weather at 1 P.M.: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration/UPI

title: The
description: James V. Napoli Sr., the reputed organized crime leader, was sentenced to one to four years in state prison after being convicted of paying $500 to a prison official in 1975 in return for special favors while imprisoned. But the sentence will not mean additional time in prison for Mr. Napoli.

title: Building Of Houses Slows 8%
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) Home building declined 8 percent in October, indicating that the housing industry was feeling the pinch from the Federal Reserve Board's upward push on interest rates, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Closing of Two Hospitals Sought By Mental Health Commissioner
description: Dr. James A. Prevost, the State Commissioner of Mental Health, said yesterday he would ask the Legislature to close two state psychiatric hospitals so that $30 million in state funds could be shifted from institutional to community programs for the mentally ill.

title: Rep. LaFalce Says Draft Report Inflated Love Canal Cancer Risk
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19  A draft report on the cancer risk of people living near the Love Canal, which was widely reported in newspapers last week, overstated the risk tenfold, a Congressman said today, citing the findings of the Federal Environmental Protection Agency as they appeared in the revised report.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: International

title: List of the 10 Hostages Released in Iran Today
description: WASHINGTON, Tuesday, Nov. 20 (AP) Following is a list of the 10 hos tages who appeared at a news confer ence at the United States Embassy in Teheran and who Iranian authorities released today:

title: Release of Mentally Ill Spurring Doubts
description: As part of a deliberate national reform, hundreds of thousands of mental patients have been discharged from the country's psychiatric hospitals in the last two decades. The policy grew out of the belief that mental institutions were doing as much harm as good.

title: Iran Says It Will Stop Dollar Use; Asks OPEC to Shun U.S. Currency
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 19 (Reuters) Iranian officials said today that their nation would stop using dollars to pay for its imports and asked other oilproducing countries not to accept dollars for their oil exports.

title: Conflicts Sap Arab Effort to Punish Sadat
description: CAIRO, Nov. 18  Two years after President Anwar elSadat's trip to Jerusalem, the campaign by his Arab critics to ostracize Egypt for its peace treaty with Israel has been sapped by regional animosities.

title: Mexico Oil Unit Set in Japan
description: TOKYO, Nov. 19 (Reuters)  A new company has been established by a group of Japanese oil companies, trading houses and banks to import crude oil from Mexico and to extend financial aid to the Mexican state oil corporation, Petroleos Mexicanos, a spokesman for the company said.

title: Sadat Leads Mount Sinai Prayer Ceremony Marking His Jerusalem Visit
description: AT MOUNT SINAI, Egypt, Nov. 19 Preaching a worldwide message of peace and love, President Anwar elSadat of Egypt led a prayer ceremony today in the remote wilderness at the foot of Mount Sinai to mark the second anniversary of his journey to Jerusalem.

title: 100 Zen Students Keeping Vigil Over Body of Man Slain in Street
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 19 (AP)  Zen students kept vigil over the body of Chris Pirsig, son of the author of Zen and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance, after the 23yearold Mr. Pirsig was stabbed to death just two blocks from the Zen Center where he lived.

title: Cost of Chlorine Spill in Ontario Is Estimated at $25 Million a Day
description: MISSISSAUGA, Ontario, Nov. 19  A Mississauga city official estimates that the chlorine spill resulting from a train derailment last week and the evacuation of 250,000 people cost the community about $25 million a day in lost business and wages.

title: Better Child Care Urged As a Support to Family
description: Although only one of the 13 panels at yesterday's conference on the future of the family was devoted to child care, the subject was brought up by numerous other panel participants.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In an article last Thurday about Martin Sherman, the writer of Bent, which is playing previews at the New Apollo Theater, his agent was identified incorrectly. It is Fill Oscard Associates.

title: The Day Satcom 2 Wobbled in Orbit
