description: EARLY one morning a couple of months ago, a communications satellite 22,300 miles above the eastern Pacific Ocean at the Equator lost control of itself. Unable to hold its solar panels in a stable, pitched position, the satellite had trouble recharging batteries with energy from the sun. Wobbling, it could not keep its antenna aligned with ground stations.

title: Dividends
description: STOCK

title: About New York
description: Five food and restaurant experts from Sichuan, China, are foraging in the city to test their palates on the version of the Sichuan taste in New York, where the regional cuisine, usually spelled Szechwan or Szechuan here, has in recent years seized the imagination of New York's Chine food fanciers.

title: Books of The Times
Woman Gets Award Of $50,000 in a Suit On Ford Transmission
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP)  A Virginia woman was awarded $50,000 today by a jury that found she had been injured as a result of an automobile transmission made by the Ford Motor Company. Similar transmissions are used in about 10 million other vehicles.

title: Indian Ocean Nation of Mauritius Struggles Through Economic and Political Crisis
description: PORT LOUIS, Mauritius  Diwali, the Hindu festival of lights, is traditionally celebrated with gaiety by the large Indian immigrant population. Gifts and sweets are exchanged, firecrackers are exploded and Moslems and Christians join in the revelry.

title: Hostages Recount Life As Embassy Captives: Bound Day and Night
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 19  It got to be light and tragic and funny and sad and tears and laughter and tantrums and where are my contact lenses and I've got to go to the bathroom and all sorts of problems.

title: Women's Movement Sets Its Sights on the Future of the Family
description: The women's movement officially entered its second stage yesterday, as more than 60 specialists and 2,000 interested observers from government, labor, business, education and public affairs attended an assembly on the future of the family.

title: Thomson Running for President to Save the U.S.
description: ORFORD, N.H., Nov. 19 (AP)  With an evangelical conviction that America is disintegrating, Meldrim Thomson Jr., the former Governor of New Hampshire, is running for President.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Monday, Nov. 19,1979

title: National Theater Plays
description: Granada Television, one of Britain's leading commercial stations, has entered into an agreement with the National Theater of Britain to televise six of its productions over the next two years on the independent television network there.

title: Growth in Oil Output Drops Sharply in Soviet
description: The Soviet Union, in its thirdquarter economic report, has disclosed a dramatic slowdown in oil production gains this year as the new Siberian oilfields have been increasingly hard pressed to make un for declines in older fields.

title: Du Pont Dividend
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 19 (Reuters) The E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company said today that it had declared a yearend dividend of $1.25 a share, which includes an extra 75cent dividend, payable Dec. 14 to shareholders of record Nov. 28. The company said the dividend included the normal 50centsashare quarterly dividend plus the additional 75 cents a share. The company said that dividends for 1979 were $2.75 a share, after a 3-for-1 stock split, compared with $2.42 a share in 1978.

title: Prosecutor's Sister Found Dead; Jacobson Trial Is Delayed a Week
description: Authorities were investigating yesterday the death of the 36yearold sister of the prosecutor in the Howard Jacobson love triangle case.

title: CAREY AIDES WARN OF BUDGET DEFICIT FOLLOWING SURPLUS
description: ALBANY, Nov. 19 Governor Carey's administration projected today that New York State would end its fiscal year next March with a $303 million surplus. But the State Budget Director warned that the state would have to use this money and also cut spending by up to $400 million to close a budget gap the following year.

title: Hospitals Merge In Plan to Serve Downtown Area
description: New York Infirmary and Beekman Downtown Hospital announced a merger yesterday that is to eventually give lower Manhattan and the city's financial district its first fullservice community hospital.

title: Posner Battles Steinberg; CashRich UV the Prize
description: The longexpected battle between Victor Posner and Saul P. Steinberg erupted yesterday, with the winner expected to collect more than $300 million in cash.

title: Attardi &
description: Not only was last Friday's hint accurate that the Attardi & Davis division of Geer, DuBois might be getting the Aramis men's fragrance and skincare products from Este Lauder Inc., but the agency is also getting Devin, a new product. And the billings will be twice previous estimates, or $2 million.

title: Food and Drug Official Resigns
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP)  Sherwin Gardner, deputy commissioner of food and drugs for the last seven years, has resigned effective Dec. 14. He will become vice president for science and technology of the Grocery Manufacturers Association. responsible for energy problems, not food and drugs, a spokesman for the Food and Drug Administration said today.

title: EARNINGS Allied Stores Net Up; Gimbel Ends Loss
description: The Allied Stores Corporation, a leading department store chain, yesterday reported that profits increased 18.2 percent for the 13 weeks ended Nov. 3 and 22.1 percent for the 39week period, both setting new records.

title: Teachers Reach Tentative Pact In a Vocational District in Jersey
description: EAST ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 19 (AP) A tentative contract settlement was reached tonight in a teachers strike in the Essex County Vocational and Technical School District. Classes could start as soon as Wednesday if the teachers ratify the contract when they vote on it tomorrow. district officials said.

title: Truckers In Rift Over Rules Issue
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19  The trucking industry, which is trying to present a united front in opposition to the Carter Administration's sweeping regulatory changes, is having a sharp dispute with private company haulers, who favor dropping some of the rules.

title: Risk in the Long Haul
description: Next month, the United States and its North Atlantic Treaty Organization allies are expected to make a farreaching decision in Brussels to introduce strategic nuclear missiles into West Germany and perhaps Belgium and the Netherlands for the first time

title: Texas Marching Band Is Accused of Sex Bias
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP)  The Justice Department charged today in a test case on women's rights that Texas A&M University had discriminated against women students by barring them from the Texas Aggie marching band and three other organizations.

title: TV: Busy Time in India
description: INDIA: Machinery of Hope, which will be shown on WNETTV from 8 to 9 o'clock tonight as part of the Nova series, presents the thesis that that country can make significant economic and social progress by encouraging laborintensive cottage crafts and the construction of small factories rather than large ones.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: Study Grim On Outlook For Energy
description: CALGARY, Alberta, Nov. 19 A recent decline in expectations of world crude oil supplies and in the role of nuclear power will compound the already predicted tight energysupply situation in the decades ahead, according to the latest report of the World Energy Conference.

title: Families Joy Tempered by Concern for Other Hostages
description: Relatives of hostages being released from the United States Embassy in Teheran tempered their joy with concern for the 49 other Americans and an undetermined number of foreigners still held by Iranian militants yesterday.

title: Tough Playoff Path For Cowboys, Oilers
description: Of the 14 leading contenders for the 10 positions in the National Football League's postseason playoffs the Houston Oilers and Dallas Cowboys, who meet on Thursday in Dallas, have the most difficult four remaining games while Chicago, Los Angeles, Tampa Bay and Miami have the easiest schedules. Each of the league's 28 teams have four games to play and the regular season will end on Monday night, Dec. 17, with a game between playoff contenders. That last game matches Denver and San Diego, now tied for first place in the Western Division of the American Conference.

title: City Hall Park Loses a Tree
description: Workers from the forestry division of the Parks Department taking apart a London plane yesterday. The tree, which stood behind City Hall (background), was the victim of a disease that ate away the center of its trunk.

title: Old Man in Search of a Home
description: Kenneth Quagenti, who has been a crisis intervention worker for 10 years in New York City, stood at the door of a room in a West 95th Street hotel. He surveyed the cracked walls, the broken mirror, the full ashtray and the nearly empty bureau drawers that made up the life of a 70yearold resident who had been missing for three days.

title: Theater: Negro Ensemble Company
description: INFORMED that a close friend of his has died, Fletcher Lacey (Douglas Turner Ward) expresses his sympathy and, without a pause, wonders if he should gamble on the time of death, 2:15, as a number. Lacey, one of two characters in Dan Owens's The Michigan, which opened the Negro Ensemble Company's 13th season on Sunday at the St. Mark's Playhouse, is an irrepressible confidence man. Mr. Ward endows the character with a hearty playfulness and Hattie Winston is a guileful match as the con man's mistress, but the play itself is a long, increasingly unprofitable evening. The title is a gambling term referring to a large bankroll $50 bills on the outside, blank paper on the inside. In keeping with the title, as the playwright slowly unravels his plot, the work loses its currency.

title: Webster Has Cast Removed
description: Several hours after the 7foot1inch Marvin Webster had the fulllength cast he had been lugging around on his right leg for six weeks removed, the Knicks center sat in a whirlpool in the training room, splashing and smiling with all the giddiness of a baby in a bubble bath.

title: First They Are Robbed
description: Using leg and shoulder pads, shoes and torn practice jerseys borrowed from three Bronx high schools, George Washington High School in upper Manhattan played its last football game of the season yesterday afternoon. The game was originally scheduled Sunday but had to be delayed because between $30,000 and $60,000 worth of the Trojans equipment was stolen over the weekend.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Gus Hall and Angela Davis Lead Communist Party's Ticket for '80
description: Gus Hall, the 69yearold head of the Communist Party, U.S.A., is running for President of the United States for the third time. Angela Davis, the black militant, is running with him as candidate for Vice President.

title: Trenton Moves To Establish 19 As Drinking Age
description: TRENTON, Nov. 19 The New Jersey Legislature, in an effort to keep alcohol out of high schools and to cut down on traffic accidents involving teenage drivers, gave final approval today to bills raising the legal drinking age in the state from 18 to 19 on Jan. 1.

title: Despite Union Vote, San Francisco Triples Train Runs
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 19  The Bay Area Rapid Transit District today tripled the number of miles it has been serving during a protracted labor dispute, even though two unions stayed off the job because members of one of them turned down a new contract by a fivevote margin.

title: Ceausescu, Opening Party's Parley, Affirms Rumanians Independence
description: BUCHAREST, Rumania, Nov. 19 President Nicolae Ceausescu opened the Communist Party congress today with a restatement of Rumania's position of relative independence from the Soviet Union in foreign affairs.

title: Cheer and Song as Labor Chiefs Meet
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19  A band was retained to play for the opening of the American Federation of LaborCongress of Industrial Organizations convention. The men were dressed in black, shiny suits but, despite their melancholy appearance, they played lively songs.

title: Gun Arrest Bond Lowered
description: BALTIMORE, Nov. 19 (AP)  A United States magistrate reduced the bond today for three Iranians held on Federal firearms charges, but refused to lower bond for two others he said were more heavily involved in an alleged scheme to smuggle guns to Iran.

title: Excerpts From Senate Panel's Majority and Minority Reports on Arms Treaty
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 Following are excerpts from the majority report released today by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on the strategic arms limitation treaty with the Soviet Union and from a minority report signed by four Republican members  Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee, S. I. Hayakawa of California, Jesse Helms of North Carolina and Richard G. Lugar of Indiana:

title: Society Needs Draconian Justice
description: Recent events in our neighborhood: a young woman murdered in her apartment on East 91st St.; an elderly lady slain in a nearby housing project; a young woman killed in her apartment at 89th St. and Second Ave. After mass on a recent Sunday here at St. Joseph's, I spoke to John D., who is 62 years old. They can't do anything, Monsignor. The sight in that eye is completely gone. John had recently been mugged. The mugger took some small change and John's left eye.

title: Rushing to Gut the F.T.C.
description: It's open season on the Federal Trade Commission. On the pretext of shielding the innocent from wasteful regulation, Congressmen by the dozen are pressing for legislation to exempt their favorite industries from F.T.C. scrutiny. In fact, the commission has generally acted quite responsibly; this assault on its power nothing more than specialinterest politics.

title: Deaths
description: ASHErnestine Josephie. on November 19 In North Augusta, S.C. Devoted mother of Lee, Bethany, Conn. Memorial service to be held later.

title: 2 Women Who Were Not Freed
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 One was the ranking American official on duty when the United States Embassy in Teheran was seized on Nov. 4. The other was an information officer.

title: Rev Dale Recker Dies; Minister Was a Leader Of Programs for Blind
description: The Rev. Dale C. Recker, who lost his sight 31 years ago but nevertheless remained active in the Lutheran ministry and in programs for the blind, died Sunday at White Plains Hospital after a long illness. He was 72 years old and lived in White Plains.

title: Viola Billings, Retired Chairman Of Savings and Loan Institution
description: Viola C. Billings, chairman emeritus of the Island Federal Savings and Loan Association of Hempstead, L.I., died Saturday at the Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center in Manhattan at the age of 87. She lived in Head of the Harbor, St. James. LI.

title: Market Practically Unchanged at 815.27
description: Oil and some specialsituation issues were the best performers yesterday as the stock market ended practically unchanged despite Wall Street's concern over Iran and a weakening dollar.

title: Science Watch
description: Prenatal Diagnosis

title: Advertising
description: Building A Print Archive

title: U.S. Copters Save 18 Koreans
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 19 (AP) The United States Air Force has rescued 18 South Korean fisherman from the East China Sea, the Air Force reported, but two others were missing. A spokesman said that the 18, from a small ship that sank yesterday in heavy seas, were picked up by two helicopters south of Cheju Island, off the south coast.

title: Increased Burning of Fuels
description: WHAT will the climate of the future be like? Warmer? Colder? Few questions are more important to those who must plan future energy and agricultural policy.

title: United Press International
description: OILERS QUARTERBACK HURT IN VICTORY OVER BENGALS: Dan Pastorini on the Oilers bench in Houston Sunday after suffering an eye injury in the second quarter. Pastorini passed for one touchdown before being sidelined in the 4221 victory over Cincinnati.

title: Travel Agent Indicted
description: A travel agent has been indicted for allegedly fleeing from the Bronx to San Juan with $15,000 in customers airline ticket money, Mario Merola. the Bronx District Attorney, said yesterday. He said Irma Acevedo, 46 years old, formerly of 1491 Watson Avenue, the Bronx, took the money from customers between August 1976 and October 1977 and went with her son and husband to San Juan, P.R., where she bought a share of another travel agency.

title: Appeals Court Says U.S. Judges Must Reveal Financial Holdings
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 19 (AP)  An appeals court today ruled against six Federal judges in their attempt to avoid making annual disclosures of how much money they have and what they own.

title: BMT ARent Is Forced to Rob 2 Safes
description: A subway collection agent, who said he had been kidnapped by two men and forced to remove more than $18,000 in cash and tokens from two change booth safes in Manhattan over the weekend, was freed yesterday by his captors.

title: Fire Deaths Termed Shootings
description: Two persons believed to have died in a fire last weekend in a Harlem apartment were actually shot to death, the police reported yesterday. The bodies of the vietim's, Lillian Woodson, 61 years old, and her son Philip, 28, were found in their apartment on the top floor of a fivestory tenement at 90 Convent Avenue shortly after midnight Saturday. The medical examiner determined Sunday that both had died of gunshots.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Paine Webber Increases Its Ad Budget by 20%
description: Thank you, Paine Webber, said the Marschalk agency upon hearing that its brokerage client's new ad budget would be $3 million, a 20 percent increase from last year.

title: Business Envoy Lists Spain's Needs
description: Political change seems to have come relatively quickly in postFranco Spain, but development of a freer economy after 41 years of rigid Fascist control will be long and difficult, according to Carlos Ferrer, chairman of the Spanish Confederation of Industries.

title: Marines Held in Iran Not Bound by Conduct Code
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19  A Marine Corps spokesman said today that the Code of Conduct for prisoners of war did not apply to marines held at the United States Embassy in Teheran, adding that the paramount interest of the corps was that hostages should get out any way pos sible.

title: United Press Intematioall
description: TWO JERUSALEM BUSES BOMBED: A bus driver inspecting the damage yesterday after a bomb exploded in his vehicle, injuring eight people. Within 15 minutes, another bomb exploded in a bus and the driver and two policemen were injured. The Palestine Liberation Organization was said to have claimed responsibility for the blasts, which came on the second anniversary of the visit to the city by President Anwar elSadat of Egypt.

title: ELLEN ENGEL
description: Ellen Engel, former general manager and executive vice president of Christian DiorNew York, died last Thursday at Doctors Hospital in Manhattan after a long illness. She was 76 years old.

title: Rams Beat Falcons, Tie for Division Lead
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 19 (AP) Vince Ferragamo, making his first National Football League start, threw for two touchdowns and set up another as the Los Angeles Rams downed the Atlanta Falcons, 2014, tonight.

title: K Mart Closes NoFrills Grocery
description: The K Mart Corporation said yesterday that it had closed an experimental nofrills grocery store in Pontiac, Mich., after less than a month of operation. The company cited poor sales as the reason for the closing.

title: Rhodesian Commandos Strike Deep Into Zambia
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Nov. 19 (AP) White Zimbabwe Rhodesian commandos struck deep inside neighboring Zambia for the second straight day today, destroying at least three bridges in a series of attacks on the transporation network of this landlocked nation, the authorities said.

title: Georgia May Refuse Sugar Bowl
description: Vince Dooley, the head football coach and athletic director at the University of Georgia, asked the Southeastern Conference yesterday to excuse his team from appearing in the Sugar Bowl if it loses on the final day of the regular season. Although Georgia has a 51 wonlost record in the conference, the Bulldogs would finish with a 56 overall record if they lose to Georgia Tech on Dec. 1.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Allied Maintenance Corporation, a diversified service company, has elected Stanley Haggett a vice president.

title: RECRUITING OUSTERS BY ARMY TOTAL 427
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP)  The Army said today that 427 recruiters had been dismissed from their jobs in the worst recruiting scandal since the end of the draft six years ago.

title: New York Telephone Is Increasing Its Rates For 6 Million Homes
description: ALBANY, Nov. 19 (AP)  The New York Telephone Company said it would raise its rates tonight at midnight, increasing basic bills 44 to 61 cents a month for nearly six million residential customers.

title: Aid Barge Reaches Phnom Penh
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 19 (Reuters)  A barge carrying 1,500 tons of relief supplies from the British charity Oxfam has arrived in Phnom Penh, the Cambodian press agency reported today.

title: Iran Bids Some Oil Concerns Pay Through NonAmerican Banks
description: PARIS, Nov. 19 Iran has told at least two major oil companies that regularly buy its oil to make their payments through nonAmerican banks in the future, and is believed to have sent similar orders to other customers.

title: Turkish Premier Presents Policies
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Nov.19  Prime Minister Suleyman Demirel presented his new Government's program today, pledging to give martiallaw forces free rein in an effort to end anarchy and terrorist activity in Turkey.

title: COMMONS TO DEBATE CASE OF FORMER SPY
description: LONDON, Nov. 19  The Government yielded today to demands from angry members of Parliament for a fullscale House of Commons debate on the bizarre case of Anthony Blunt, the art historian who was unmasked last week as a Soviet agent 15 years after he had confessed. The debate will take place on Wednesday.

title: Inside Sports Is Going National
description: Newsweek has decided to go ahead with its new Inside Sports magazine, not as a regional magazine as originally planned, but as a national publication. That is because the magazine did so well in its September tests, according to E. Daniel Capell, the publisher.

title: Corporate Earnings
description: For periods as shown. (N) Indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) over-the-counter.

title: United Press International
description: PATERSON FIRE KILLS TWO CHILDREN: Firemen in Paterson, N.J., climbing over the charred rubble of a house at 457 Union Street after recovering the bodies of Michael Smith, 8 years old, and his I2yearold sister, Roberta. Their father, Robert Smith, 39, suffered burns. His wife, Ann, and seven other children safely fled the house which was completely destroyed.

title: Pritzkers Bid to Buy Levitz
description: The Pritzker family of Chicago, a prominent investment group that already owns 9 percent of the Levitz Furniture Corporation, has reached an agreement to buy 24.7 percent more from the Levitz family as an initial step to purchase the entire company, Ralph Levitz, board chairman of Levitz Furniture said yesterday.

title: Port Body Pressuring Scotto To Give Up His I.L.A. Posts
description: The Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor said yesterday that it would seek under state law to prohibit the International Longshoremen's Association and its Brooklyn Local 1814 from collecting membership dues in the port if Anthony M. Scotto retained his union posts pending the outcome of his racketeering conviction.

title: Dr. A. O. Davidson, 69, President Of Wagner College for 14 Years
description: Dr. Arthur 0. Davidson, president emeritus of Wagner College on Staten Island, died Sunday at Mary Hitchcock Memorial Hospital in Hanover, N.H. He was 69 years old and lived in Hanover.

title: Events Today
description: SORROWS OF STEPHEN, by Peter Parnell, directed by Sheldon Larry, Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, 8.

title: Policemen Help Guard The Shah at Hospital
description: For the first time, New York City policemen were added yesterday to the private security force guarding the deposed Shah of Iran inside New York HospitalCornell Medical Center.

title: Zinnemann to Produce and Direct for Ladd
description: HOLLYWOOD, Nov. 19  Fred Zirmemann will produce and direct his first movie since Julia in 1977 for the newly formed Ladd Company.

title: Strikeouts, Walks and History
description: Think of it this way. Nolan Ryan's $4.5 million contract with the Houston Astros for the next four seasons represents a retroactive payment of approximately $1,000 for each of his combined total of 4,548 strikeouts and bases on balls in his major league career  2.902 strikeouts and 1.646 walks. Because he lias always been wild enough to keep the fear of the ball in the batter's mind, Nolan Ryan's walks have been as much a part of his past as his strikeouts. And they will be as much a Dart of his future. Not Quite 33 years old, Nolan Ryan

title: Ford Seems to Soften His Stand Against a 1980 Race
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 19  Former President Gerald R. Ford, pressing a broad attack on Carter Administration policies, caused a stir of excitement among Republican governors today by leaving open a chance that he might be drawn into the 1980 Presidential race by unforeseen developments.

title: Boom in Canadian Film Making Hits Snag
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 19  There is, as always, trouble in Paradise.

title: Miller Captures Key Policy Role
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19  In just three months on the job, G. William Miller, the new Secretary of the Treasury, has forcefully but smoothly established himself as the Carter Administration's main voice on economic policy

title: Henderson Waived by Cowboys
description: Thomas (Hollywood) Henderson apparently played the role of the clown rather than the Dallas left linebacker once too often, and he no longer is a Cowboy.

title: Rescue Plan Devised for School Budget
description: Mayor Koch and the Board of Education yesterday put together a rescue plan involving $25.3 million in state and Federal funds and $7.6 million in city funds to offset a $55 million school budget deficit, although some city officials questioned whether the money would be forthcoming.

title: A New President for the A.F.L.C.I.O.
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 At the end of an arduous and emotional news conference earlier this fall, at which he disclosed that George Meany would retire and announced that the A.F.L.C.I.O. had entered a national accord with the Carter Administration on economic policy, Lane Kirkland was asked what problems Mr. Meany's successor would face. He eroaned. rolled his eyes heavenward and said, Whatever Jesus flings.

title: Senate Defeats Another Move to Cut Windfall Tax
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 The Sen ate turned back another attempt today to reduce the proposed tax on addi tional windfall profits earned by the oil industry as a result of price decon trol.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Richard R. Aurelio, a former First Deputy Mayor of New York City, has been appointed to the newly established position of senior vice presidentgovernmental affairs of the Warner Cable Corporation. The appointment, made last week, came as Warner, a major systems operator and programmer in the growing field of cable television, was petitioning the city for the right to construct cable systems in Queens, Brooklyn and Staten Island.

title: More Students Return To Campus Housing As Outside Costs Rise
description: In Los Angeles, home of the University of California, the unattainable is an apartment lease, not a movie contract. A junior at the school forlornly describes undergraduates walking the streets in search of offcampus housing as mice looking for the same moldy piece of cheese.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Bundesbank Opposes Wider Role for Mark
description: BONN, Nov. 19  The West German central bank signaled anew today its objection to any widening in the role of the West German mark as an international reserve currency, a possibility that could be one result of any Iranian move out of dollarbased assets.

title: A.S.L. Set To Dismiss Bob Cousy
description: Bob Cousy, the former basketball star who has been commissioner of the American Soccer League since December 1974, will not have his contract renewed because he hasn't got soccer in his blood, according to Willie Ehrlich, a club owner.

title: Kirkland Urges To A.F.L.C.I.O.
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19  Lane Kirkland was elected today as the second president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations and immediately called on unions now outside the federation to rejoin the fold.

title: Hospital Cost Bill Defeat: Elements in the Decision
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19  As the House of Representatives concluded its debate last Thursday on the hospital cost containment bill, Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. took the floor and made an emotional appeal for its passage. After reciting a series of medical horror stories, Mr. O'Neill pleaded, This is truly legislation where you are voting for the average citizen, you are voting for the common man and woman.

title: Periodical Growth At Oxbridge
description: Oxbridge Communications, 183 Madison Avenue, is very big in periodical directories and is getting bigger.

title: City Ballet: Le Baiser de la Fe Divertimento
description: DIVERTIMENTO From Le Baiser de la Fe, which George Balanchine created for the New York City Ballet's 1972 Stravinsky Festival, remains one of his greatest and most unusual works.

title: Monopoly Playoff: Tears On Park P1.
description: In a grueling match marked by much wheeling and dealing, four bankruptcies, and even a few tears, Dana Terman of Maryland retained his title as United States Monopoly champion here yesterday.

title: C.I.A. ISSUE INJECTED INTO INDIA ELECTION
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 19A passage in a recently published American book reporting that the United States Central Intelligence Agency had an Indian Cabinet minister as an agent eight years ago has provoked campaign charges and innuendoes, calls for an inquiry and at least the appearance of indignation.

title: Condition and Spirits of 3 Freed Hostages Called Good
description: WIESBADEN, West Germany, Nov. 19  Three American hostages, the first freed from captivity in the United States Embassy in Teheran, flew to an air base near here today and were reported to be in good physical condition and excellent spirits.

title: Stroock and Krause, Law Firms, to Merge
description: Stroock & Stroock & Lavan, a 103yearold corporate law firm based in New York City, has reached a merger agreement with Krause, Hirsch & Gross, a leading firm specializing in bankruptcy and reorganization law.

title: Associated Press
description: RADIATION CHECK AFTER AIR CRASH: A technician checking Air National Guardsmen for exposure after military plane crashed Sunday, killing three. A harmless amount of thorium, used on watch dials, was on board.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THE BIRDS Audubon and His World, the new exhibition at the NewYork Historical Society, provides a rare opportunity for the public to see the painter's 433 original watercolors of his famed Birds of America. The show, marking the society's 175th birthday, is opening in two sections. The first starts today and the second on Dec. 6, with the entire display remaining on view until Feb. 29. Only once before have all of John James Audubon's watercolors been seen at one time.

title: The Region
description: HACKENSACK, N.J. (AP) A state appeals court has unanimously ruled that the press and the public cannot be barred from a pretrial murder hearing in a Passaic County court.

title: Pension Subsidy Bill Signed
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP)  President Carter today signed a measure that will provide up to $52 million a year in Federal subsidies for District of Columbia pension systems. The measure is scaled down significantly from an earlier subsidy bill that Mr. Carter had disapproved because, he said today, it overstated Federal responsibility for District of Columbia pensions.

title: New Rules On Energy
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP)  The Energy Department proposed new standards today to limit the energy used by new residential and commercial buildings.

title: Convict Killed in Caracas Revolt
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 19 (Reuters)  A prisoner was killed and four were wounded when policemen and guards used machine guns, automatic rifles and tear gas to crush a revolt by 400 inmates at the Modelo jail near here last night,

title: Rhodesian Rebels Ask a Stronger Peacekeeping Force
description: LONDON, Nov. 19 The leaders of the Patriotic Front guerrilla alliance called today for a Commonwealth force of several thousand men to enforce a ceasefire in Zimbabwe Rhodesia instead of the force of several hundred, with its duties limited to observation, proposed by the British.

title: Regulations Eased For Small Business
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (UPI) President Carter directed Federal departments and agencies today to insure that their regulations do not place unnecessary burdens on small businesses and organizations.

title: STATEMENT IS SHARP
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19  The United States demanded today that all the remaining hostages in the American Embassy in Teheran be released and said that if any of them were tried on espionage charges it would be a further flagrant violation of human rights, religious precepts and international law.

title: Music: Carol Ferri In Piano Recital
description: REVIEWERS encounter so many inferior performances by known artists that it's tempting to overpraise fine work by less familiar performers. Carol Ferri's piano recital Sunday night at Alice Tully Hall was such an occasion. Miss Ferri has a respectable but not overpowering background when it comes to schools and teachers, and is now on the faculty of Kean College of New Jersey; her biography helpfully informs us that she appears there annually in a faculty recital. And it should be added that her poorly attended recital Sunday was dogged by a piano with a dull and weak upper register.

title: Pianist: Liora Hendel
description: LIORA HENDEL did not have her mind on minor matters Sunday afternoon at the Abraham Goodman House. Her program consisted of a pair of works by Beetho ven, two of his most technically and in terpretively challenging piano sonatas the Hammerklavier (Op. 106) and the C minor Sonata (Op. 111), the com poser's last essay in this form.

title: Iranians Who Seized U.S. Embassy Release 4 Women and 6 Black Men
description: Teheran, Iran, Tuesday, Nov. 20 Ten more hostages released from the American Embassy here flew out of Iran early this morning. They included four women and six black men.

title: OBSERVER
description: A New York man writes that articles he reads about Senator Kennedy and his advisers invariably describe them as tough minded and high powered. He believes high powered refers to their cars, but for the life of me, he says, I cannot understand what it means to have a tough mind. He requests explanation.

title: Jets Stay With Todd; Linhart Is Replaced
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 19  Walt Michaels, the Jets head coach, said today that, barring injury, Richard Todd would stay as the Jets quarterback for every remaining down this season, indicating that all that remained for Matt Robinson was to hold the ball for a new placekicker.

title: U.S. Horseman Halted
description: PARIS, Nov. 19  A threejudge court ruled here today against Wayne Murty, an American horseman, in his battle with the Aga Khan for 56 horses purchased from the bankrupt Marcel Boussac, once the king of the French thoroughbred racing.

title: People
description: Penny Hawkey, Henry Holtzman and Joan Lipton have been elected senior vice presidents of McCannErickson Inc.

title: Boston Clergy Condemns Racial Hatred in the City
description: BOSTON, Nov. 19  Boston's religious leadership today joined in the first concerted condemnation of this city's racial atmosphere since longsimmering tensions began breaking out into violence earlier in the decade.

title: Text of the Statement On Teheran Hostages
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 Following is the text of a statement issued today by the White House on American hostages in Teheran:

title: A Cool Look That's Affordable
description: She's very professional, Mollie Parnis said about her new designer, Caroline Simonelli. When I make a suggestion, she says, Sure, let's try it,  and usually she makes it work.

title: The Editorial Notebook Counting Cops and Crime
description: Newark's Force May Need More Police; It Does Need Improving

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP)  The Government will enforce provisions against sex discrimination that prohibit schools from setting different dress codes for males and females, Patricia Roberts Harris, the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, announced today.

title: The U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Bellevue Doctors Battle Handicaps
description: The other night at New York City's Bellevue Hospital, where 1,000 patients come each month for emergency psychiatric care, a man about 35 years old was screaming steadily and incoherently in the waiting area. The doctors suspected he was having a reaction to a hallucinogenic drug.

title: Bridge:
description: CINCINNATI, Nov. 19 Two Canadians led going into the final round of the Lifemaster Men's Pair Championship tonight at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals, with two New York experts in close pursuit.

title: Appeals Court Upholds U.S. Ban on Iranian Protests Near White House
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) A Federal appeals court ruled today that the Government could ban demonstrations across Pennsylvania Avenue from the White House that are related to Iran because they could affect the safety of American hostages in the United States Embassy in Teheran.

title: Next Week Again On Giants Agenda
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 19 The Giants will still play em one at a time, Coach Ray Perkins said today, because winning is still everything. For him, it's wait till next week, not next year.

title: Defendant in Sam Picture Case Cites Assurances by Post Editor
description: A freelance writer charged with bribing a correction officer to obtain prison pictures of David R. Berkowitz testified yesterday that the metropolitan editor of The New York Post had assured him it would not be a crime.

title: SENATE PANEL ISSUES ARMS PACT REPORT, URGING ITS APPROVAL
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19  The Senate Foreign Relations Committee made public today its majority report on the nuclear arms treaty with the Soviet Union, urging the full Senate to approve it and to resist suggested changes that would force renegotiation.

title: For Stage Fright, A Remedy Proposed
description: VLADIMIR HOROWITZ is said to suffer terribly from it, Arthur Rubinstein calls it the price I have to pay for my wonderful life, and Pablo CasaIs described it in his autobiography.

title: Money
description: Prime rate: 15

title: COMMODITIES
description: Commodity futures trading patterns were heavily influenced yesterday by normal preholiday factors and the breakdown of the computerized price reporting system of the Chicago Board of Trade, the nation's largest exchanee.

title: Notes on People
description: Maureen Stapleton Closes the Books on Her Tavern

title: Q&A
description: Q. What material is the space shuttle's heat shield composed of?

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Union Opposes Cutting
description: The leader of 35,000 transit workers has protested a proposal that some subway token booths be closed at night to reduce costs.

title: Rail Service Aid Backed
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (UPI) Transportation Secretary Neil E. Goldschmidt asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to extend for another 90 days its order providing Governmentsubsidized service along track belonging to the bankrupt Rock Island railroad.

title: Market Place
description: Robert Metz

title: Three Men Are Accused of Scheme
description: Three men have been charged with operating fraudulent apartment referral services that allegedly conspired with three landlords to keep a certain number of rundown apartments vacant to show to unsuspecting customers, Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan District Attorney, announced yesterday.

title: Selective Service Chief Voted In
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP)  Bernard Daniel Rostker of Virginia was confirmed by the Senate today to be director of the Selective Service System. Mr. Rostker, approved by voice vote without dissent, will succeed Byron V. Pepitone, who resigned.

title: Rangers Call Up 2 Farm Hands
description: The Rangers, who have been less than explosive on offense and inconsistent on defense, looked for a solution yesterday within their organization. They brought up Ed Hospodar, a defenseman and Claude LaRose a left wing, from their New Haven farm team.

title: Song Recital: Kelly Garrett Is a Belter
description: KELLY GARRETT is such a bundle of energy with such a big voice that she felt called upon to apologize for the lack of quiet songs in her program at the Grand Finale last weekend.

title: U.S. to Extend Gas Surcharge
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP)  Carrying out a plan written by Congress, the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission began preparations today to extend a surcharge that had been levied on natural gas used in large industrial boilers to other large industrial users of natural gas.

title: Digby Diehl, Chief Editor Of Harry Abrams, to Quit
description: Digby Diehl, vice president and editor in chief of Harry N. Abrams, the publisher, since July 1978, will resign on Jan. 1 to pursue some writing of my own and to explore some individual creative opportunities. Andrew Stew art, president of Abrams, expressed his high regard and warm personal feel ings for Mr. Diehl.

title: Luring Manufacturers From Europe and Japan
description: With the help of advertising from Marsteller and public relations by BursonMarsteller, New York City hopes to attract light manufacturers, primarily from West Germany, Britain and Japan.

title: Kuwait Buys More Japan Stock
description: TOKYO, Nov. 19  The Government of Kuwait, expanding its direct portfolio investment in Japan, has acquired substantial holdings in two large resources development companies, the Teikoku Oil Company and the Nippon Mining Company, according to market here

title: Researchers Examine Terrorist Psychology
description: SOMETIMES when terrorists or bank robbers hold hostages for a long time, a bond grows between the captors and the captives. In some instances the attachment has been so intense that hostages have threatened rescuers with assault, later visited their captors in jail, set up legal defense funds for them and even agreed to marriage. In other cases, the captors attachment for their hostages is all that saves the captives lives.

title: Value of Frozen Assets Now Put at $8 Billion
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 Robert G. Carswell, Deputy Secretary of the Treasury, said today that the official estimate of the value of the Iranian as sets frozen last week had been raised to more than $8 billion. Initially, Adminis tration officials had said that the assets totaled $5 billion to $6 billion.

title: About Education
description: THE latest secret weapon against school failure is called parents. After years of being told to stay out of teacher's way, mother and father are being invited, urged, even begged to come back in.

title: Art Commission Raises Cry Over Hues in Picking Colors for Bridges
description: Beneath the somber stares of former commissioners frozen in portrait and a grandfather clock that stopped long ago, the city's Art Commission was riven by disagreement yesterday over what the correct colors for city bridges should be. In fact, there was even disagreement over what color Yankee Stadium was.

title: Governments Move to Stem Amazon Destruction
description: TWO scientists who recently returned from the Amazon River Basin in Brazil, report that for the first time coordinated efforts are being made by the Brazilian and other South American governments to stem the destruction that has already wiped out more than a quarter of a million square miles of the world's largest forest that surrounds the world's longest river.

title: Steel Output Off in Week
description: Production of steel in the United States fell 1.5 percent to 2.35 million tons in the week ended last Saturday from the previous week's 2.39 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Insti, tute reported yesterday. The industry used 81.2 percent of capacity iast WeeK,  down from 82.4 percent in the previous. week, the institute said. Estimated figures for the year to date showed production at 121.3 million tons, up 1.5 percent from 119.5 million tons a year earlier. Production so far this year used 88.4 percent of capacity, up from 86.1 percent a year earlier.

title: TV: The Last Ride Of the Dalton Gang
description: MOVIES made for television began as tidy 90minute affairs. Then, for purposes of scheduling convenience, they were stretched, or padded, to two hours. Now, obviously in an effort to take care of a full evening of prime time with one programming package, they are increasingly running to three hours.

title: South Africa Warning of Chaos In Rhodesia Hints a Military Role
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Nov. 19 Warnings by South Africa that it will not tolerate chaos in Zimbabwe Rhodesia have created renewed uncertainty about the Pretoria Government's attitude if the Patriotic Front guerrilla movement should win the election Britain proposes to conduct there next year.

title: The Ayatollah Discovers Law
description: There is no comfort in it yet, but there might be one of these days: Ayatollah Khomeini has discovered international law. That is a realm in which he can, at least, be debated and in which he might eventually find a facesaving retreat toward the release of his American hostages.

title: EDUCATION
description: MENDOTA HEIGHTS, MINN.

title: A FrenchCanadian Wins 79 Goncourt Prize
description: PARIS, Nov. 19  A FrenchCanadian woman today won the 1979 Goncourt Prize, France's most important literary award. Antonine Maillet, 49 years old, a university lecturer, won the Goncourt for her novel Pelagie la Charrette. (Pelagie and the Cart). Six women have won the prize. She is the first in 13 years.

title: Rono Beats Salazar, Wins Harrier Crown 3d Time in N.C.A.A.
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., Nov. 19  Yesterday Alberto Salazar of Oregon said a winning time of 28 minutes 20 seconds was possible in the National Collegiate crosscountry championships.

title: Cambodians Are Eager to Leave, but Fear Leaders
description: SISOPHON DISTRICT, Cambodia, Nov. 20  In the two largest concentrations of Cambodians anywhere in this depleted country, about 400,000 men, women and children anxiously await word from Thailand that those who wish may move into a huge holding area away from this dangerous border region.

title: Art: Masterworks Of a Great Collection
description: WASHINGTON

title: State Wants Coop City to Increase Charges 40 Percent
description: The directors of New York State's Housing Finance Agency, which holds the mortgage on Coop City in the Bronx, recommended yesterday that maintenance charges to tenants in the huge housing complex be increased 40 percent over the next three to five years to meet projected cost increases.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: Codes for Gloomy Days

title: Chrysler Idles Plant; Adds Sales Incentive
description: The Chrysler Corporation said it would idle 1,600 hourly workers by closing its Lynch Road assembly plant in Detroit for one week, beginning next Monday, to control inventories. The plant builds fullsize Chryslers.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: CARTER SHIFTS STAND
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20  The United States suggested to Iran today for the first time that it might resort to military force if the remaining 49 American hostages in Teheran, now facing the threat of trial, were not freed.

title: Wine Talk
description: ChARLES PLOHN SR., an investment banker who made wads of money in the gogo stock market of the 1960's, was afraid of flying. So e traveled by ship whenever he visited his vacation home in Italy, most often on a vessel of the Italian Line. The Leonardo da Vinci and the Michelangelo were well stocked with fine Italian wines, and Mr. Plohn took a liking to one in particular, a Barolo of the 1947 vintage produced by one of the leading wine makers of Italy's Piedmont District, the Marchesi di Barolo.

title: Topics
description: We were wrong recently in remarking that Boy Scouts were now calling themselves Scouts, period. To set the record straight  the Boy Scout Handbook is still called just that; so is Boy's Life magazine. And both are published by an organization still formally known as the Boy Scouts of America.

title: Fire Kills Bay Ridge Man
description: A Brooklyn man was killed early yesterday as he tried to escape from a fire that swept through his home at 466 72d Street, in the Bay Ridge section. The victim was Joseph Strype, 52 years old. Officials tern ed the fire suspicious.

title: Denver Theater Complex to Open Dec. 31
description: The new $13 million theater complex of the Denver Center for the Performing Arts will open New Year's Eve and begin a threeday celebration that will end with the presentation of the National Artist Award to Henry Fonda. The occasion will also mark the debut of the theater complex's repertory company.

title: Zambia Puts Army on Full Alert After Rhodesia Raids
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Nov. 20 (Reuters)  President Kenneth D. Kaunda called up reservists and canceled the leaves of all soldiers today to meet what he called a fullscale war situation brought about by a series of raids from Zimbabwe Rhodesia on Zambian road bridges.

title: The Price of Eating the Rent;
description: Carol Bellamy, the City Council President, has tripped over a vital housing issue. Waving a report by her staff, she has imprudently asked the city to reduce its use of socalled twoparty welfare rent checks. twoparty welfare rent check is made payable to both the tenant and the landlord; neither can cash it unless both endorse it. These checks are permitted, under Federal regulations, in no more than 20 percent of the city's welfare cases. They go to tenants who have in the past lost, withheld or misused rent checks formerly made out to them alone.

title: Arabs Rebuff Iraq's Bid To Use Oil as a Weapon
description: TUNIS, Nov. 20  Leaders of Arab League countries met here today and sidetracked a proposal by Iraq to revive the use of oil as a weapon against Western countries supporting Israel.

title: British Industry Board Said to Quit
description: LONDON, Nov. 20 (Reuters)  All 10 members of the National Enterprise Board, the Government body that controls Bntain's nationalized industries, reportedly resigned tonight in a row'over the future of stateowned RollsRoyce Ltd. Sources close to the board said the members were forced to step down after being told by the Industry Secretary, Sir Keith Joseph, that the Government had decided to take charge of RollsRoyce.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Chess:
description: In the book, How to Open a Chess Game, Lajos Portisch says: Your only task in the opening is to reach playable middle game. This might seem modest enough, but it doesn't jibe with the practice of the 42yearold Hungarian grandmaster.

title: A March of Cultural Discovery for Children in the Bronx
description: Spirited cheerleaders urged on their classmates along the Grand Concourse yesterday as several thousand school children from District 9 in the Bronx marked the fifth annual Puerto Rican Discovery Day Parade. Sponsored by the school district, the parade featured costumes and floats depicting history and heritage of Puerto Rico.

title: Investigation Is Urged On Plan for Payment To Antipoverty Panel
description: A City Councilman called yesterdayfor a city investigation of an agreement under which a oncepopular antipoverty agency in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn would get $400,000 in proceeds from a proposed housing project.

title: 10 Hostages Released in Iran Meet in Wiesbaden With 3 Freed Earlier
description: WIESBADEN, West Germany, Nov. 20  Ten hostages released from the besieged American Embassy in Teheran were flown to an Air Force base here today and joined three other freed captives in a guarded and isolated wing of hospital in what was described as an emotional reunion.

title: Saving Species Together
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  How can a developedworld conservationist speak of the International Union for Conservation of Nature without speaking at the same time of the new international economic order? This is the query of a thirdworld leader speaking about the problem of disappearing species. True, the problem represents an impoverishment for the world insofar as species constitute part of everybody's natural heritage and to the extent that people anywhere on Earth use drugs, foods and other products manufactured from wild species anywhere on Earth. But developing nations tend to see the problem differently from developed nations, and they see it increasingly as part of the resource confrontation between the North and the South.

title: ASSEMBLY OVERRIDES CAREY'S TWO VETOES ON HEATING BILL AID
description: ALBANY, Nov. 20  The State Assembly voted today to override Governor Carey's vetoes of two bills to help needy people with their heating bills. One veto was rejected unanimously and the other with a single dissent. Mr. Carey had argued that the state could not afford the assistance.

title: Real Estate
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.

title: TV: Pilgrims Adventure
description: THE story could scarcely be more familiar and the timing more obvious, but superior acting and production provide mellow patina for Mayflower: The Pilgrims Adventure, which will be shown from 9 to 11 o'clock tonight on CBSTV.

title: New Rules Planned on Takeovers
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20  The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed significant new rules and adopted other proposals today designed to enhance stockholder rights in corporate takeovers and to encourage meaningful participation in company shareholder elections.

title: Best Buys
description: WHAT Carnegie Hill needed, decided Phyllis Lieberman, was a place to get a decent cup of coffee, a fresh croissant, a light, pretheater snack. So a few weeks ago, Mrs. Lieberman and her partners, Eva Weiss and Douglas Coffin, combined their knowledge of food, design and business and opened Baked Expectations, at 1312 Madison Avenue at 93d Street.

title: The First Call to Christmas
description: Against a backdrop of a doubledecker bus and St. Patrick's Cathedral, a Salvation Army band initiated the organization's annual Christmas campaign yesterday by playing to passersby on Fifth Avenue at the foot of the Rockefeller City promenade. The weather for the performance was ideal, reaching a high of 66 degrees.

title: Economic Scene
description: SPRING HILL CENTER, MINN.

title: Judge Allows I11 Veterans To Sue Defoliant Makers
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 20  A Federal judge decided today that Vietnam veterans who were allegedly injured by the defoliant Agent Orange and their children born deformed could sue bring suit in Federal court against five chemical companies that manufactured the chemical.

title: DEWEY SHORT
description: Dewey Short, a former Republican Representative from Missouri who was Assistant Secretary of the Army in the Administration of President Eisenhower, died of a heart attack Monday at his home in Washington. He was 82 years old.

title: EARNINGS
description: Profits of leading retailers showed substantial gains in the normally slow fall fiscal quarter despite inflationary pressure on discretionary income and consumer resistance to increasing debt burden.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Multilayered, warm frontal clouds cover New England and heavy cloudiness stretchs from the upper Mississippi Valley through the Plains States to the northern and central Rockies. Clear skies cover the Middle Atlantic States, the Southeast and the Far West.

title: Kirkland Announces Plan to Place Minorities and Women in Top Jobs
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20  In his first major action as president of the A.F.L.C.I.O., Lane Kirkland announced today an initiative to bring women, blacks and HispanicAmericans into top leadership positions with the federation.

title: $27.4 Million in Overruns For Meadowlands Arena
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 20 Cost overruns totaling nearly $27.4 million have accumulated this year during construction of the Meadowlands Arena and the Pegasus restaurant atop the grandstand of the Meadowlands race track, officials disclosed today.

title: News of the Theater
description: MAUREEN O'SULLIVAN, who has not appeared on Broadway since 1973  in the shortlived No Sex, Please, We're British  is talking about returning this winter in a revival of Paul Osborn's comedy Morning's at Seven. She acted in the play last summer in Lake Forest, Ill., and the production sparked interest in bringing Morning's at Seven back to New York.

title: Chicago Facing U.S. Fund Loss, Rebuff to Mayor
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20  The Secretary of Transportation, Neil E. Goldschmidt, said today that he would look for opportunities to deny Federal funds to Chicago in the aftermath of Mayor Jane M. Byrne's decision to support Senator Edward M. Kennedy's challenge to President Carter.

title: Global Builder Coming Home
description: BOISE, Idaho  Four of the MorrisonKnudsen Company's people are only now getting out of Iran. And they were not the first employees of this international construction and engineering company to find themselves in a tight spot overseas. In August, the Saudi Arabian Government seized the passports of 31 employees as part of an investigation into alleged kickbacks to Saudi suppliers on the huge King Khalid Military City construction project, in which MorrisonKnudsen has a $1.2 billion share.

title: Central Park Pathfinders Blaze 3Mile Urban Trail
description: As squirrels rooted in fallen leaves, Central Park joined dozens of national forests and a handful of urban parks yesterday as it became part of the United States system of national recreation trails.

title: Text of Statement by Briton Who Spied for the Russians
description: LONDON, Nov. 20 (AP)  Following is the text of a statement released today by the attorney for Anthony Blunt, the art historian who was a spy for the Soviet Union:

title: U.S. Aides Pleased By Move on Fibers
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 American officials welcomed today the European action on synthetic fiber imports from the United States and said they believed the Common Market, by throwing the case into consultative proceedings under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, was trying to defuse the problem.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: ONE of the most delicate and coveted deepfried foods is coquilles St. Jacques panees a l'Anglaise, that is, scallops breaded and deep fried. The essential factor is speed, to which this column is dedicated. The scallops should be cooked as briefly as possible, just until they lose their raw look in the center. If overcooked, they become chewy and tasteless.

title: Police Ruled Not Liable in Killing
description: A Brooklyn grand jury announced yesterday that it had found no criminal liability by five police officers who had killed a mentally disturbed man by shooting him 21 times.

title: Illinois Drops Moeller
description: CHAMPAIGN, III., Nov. 20 (UPI) Gary Moeller, whose football team won only six games in his three seasons as head coach, was dismissed today by the University of Illinois. John Hummen, cnairman of tne University of IIhnois Athletic Association, said after a threehour meeting that Moeller had been released from his duties effective Dec. 1 in the best interests of the football program and overall progress of the athletic association.

title: 25 Haitian Refugees Held
description: ST. LUCIE, Fla., Nov. 20 (UPI) Twentyfive Haitian refugees found seven miles off the Florida coast by the Florida Marine Patrol yesterday have been turned over to local officials, who in turn will turn them over to immigration officials.

title: Lack of Interest K.O.'s Jones Bout
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Nov. 20 (AP)  Low ticket sales for Ed (Too Tall) Jones's third professional boxing match forced the promoter to cancel it today.

title: A Reagan Victory by Default
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 20  Former President Gerald R. Ford may have stolen the show from the active 1980 Republican Presidential contenders at the Republican Governors Conference here but it appears that in the short run and perhaps even longer, Ronald Reagan was the principal gainer  by default.

title: Knicks Rally to Rockets in Overtime
description: The Knicks, in a heroic comeback that was reminiscent of their glory days, rallied from a 23point deficit in the third quarter last night and defeated the Houston Rockets, 130125, in overtime at Madison Square Garden.

title: Mecca Mosque Seized by Gunmen Believed to Be Militants From Iran
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20  A group of armed fundamentalist Moslems believed to be from Iran seized the Grand Mosque in Mecca today and fought off a counterattack by Saudi troops for several hours before relinquishing control of Islam's holiest shrine, American intelligence officials reported.

title: Steel Trigger Price Up an Average 5%
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20(Reu ters)  The Treasury Department said today that it would raise its trigger prices on imported steel by an average of 5 percent for the first quarter next year.

title: WASHINGTON Japan's Uneasy Success
description: TOKYO, Nov. 19  It's more comfortable to get from San Francisco to Tokyo these days. The big jumbo jets now have comfortable sleepers, as big as the old railroad car bedrooms, upstairs behind the flight deck, and you can actually sleep through the night across the Pacific unless you wake up thinking about the cost.

title: Associated Press
description: STORM IN ROCKIES BLAMED FOR FIVE DEATHS:  Commuters in Denver waiting for a bus yesterday as up to two feet of snow fell in Colorado and Wyoming. Blizzard warnings caused closings of schools and factories over a large area, and five deaths, two in an air crash and three in a truck accident, were attributed to the storm.

title: Boswell Traded to Jazz
description: DENVER, Nov. 20 (AP)  The Denver Nuggets traded Tom Boswell, a fiveyear forward, to the Utah Jazz today for a secondround choice in the 1980 National Basketball Association draft.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 20  The Amdahl Corporation and the Memorex Corporation said today that they had broken off merger talks that began more than three months ago.

title: Appeals Court Limits Grounds for Excluding Press at Trial Hearings
description: The New York Court of Appeals narrowed the grounds yesterday under which the public and press can be excluded from pretrial hearings.

title: Godunov Quits Ballet Theater
description: Aleksandr Godunov, the former Bolshoi Ballet star who defected last August, was released from his contract with the American Ballet Theater yesterday at his own request because he felt he had become an issue in the company's labor dispute with its dancers.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Kings 112 Warriors 109
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 20 (AP) Scott Wedman scored 10 of his 20 points in the fourth quarter to lead the Kansas City Kings to a 112109 victory over Golden State tonight.

title: Plain and Fancy Desserts From Four Famous Chefs
description: FOR some reason, cooks who let months pass without donning an apron or picking up a whisk are magnetically attracted to the kitchen during these final weeks of the year. And once drawn, it's likely that holiday baking, in the form of elegant, luscibus desserts, will appear on the agenda.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The Economy

title: Bridge:
description: CINCINNATI, Nov. 20 Experience and youth each won a major title at the American Contract Bndge League's Fall Nationals here last night. The life master women's pair championship was taken by Edith Kemp of Miami Beach, who captured the first of her 22 national titles back in 1941, and Nancy Gruver of Ellicott City, Md., who finished second in the World Women's Pair Championship in 1966.

title: Okinawan Village Halts U.S. Drill
description: NAHA, Okinawa, Nov. 20 (Reuters) About 280 villagers forced the United States Marine Corps to suspend a parachute jump when they entered the drill site at the American base near here, the police said. Residents asked the Marines Corps and Japanese authorities to stop the drills after a parachute carrying an instrument to measure wind velocity fell near a home early this month.

title: Islam Scholars Say Iranian Seizure Runs Against Teaching of Koran
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 20  The takeover of the American Embassy in Iran has confronted Moslem scholars with questions about whether there is anything in the Koran to justify the taking of hostages. They say there is not.

title: U.S. Reportedly Does Not Seek Action by Allies but Receives Their Help
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20  The United States has not asked its major allies to take any overt actions against Iran to obtain the release of the American hostages in Teheran, Carter Administration officials said today.

title: British Offer 6 Plans for Ulster Home Rule
description: LONDON, Nov. 20  The British Government put forth a range of possible forms of home rule for Northern Ireland today and asked the politicians of the province to choose from among them.

title: Carter Sending 6 More Navy Ships, Including Carrier, to Arabian Sea
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20  President Carter ordered a second naval task force, including the aircraft carrier Kitty Hawk, into the Indian Ocean south of Iran today, Administration officials said.

title: CBSTV Tops Ratings On Sunday Night Power
description: Powered by its Sunday night lineup of hit series and the popular appeal of the Thursday night movie, Silver Streak, CBSTV won last week's Nielsen ratings decisively with an average of 22.1. ABCTV was second with an 18.7 rating average, and NBCTV trailed with a 17.7. With the victory, CBS moved into second place, behind ABC, for the season to date.

title: Film: 'Arabian Adventure'
description: "ARABIAN ADVENTURE," which opens today at the Rivoli and other theaters, is a sweet-spirited, bargain-basement variation on the sort of film that reached its peak of splendor in 1940 with Alexander Korda's "The Thief of Bagdad."The new movie, also English-made, is about a cheerful, inventive beggarboy (Puneet Sira), a wicked caliph (Christopher Lee), a comically ineffective villain (Milo O'Shea) and a pair a young lovers (Oliver Tobias and Emma Samms), who are simultaneously pretty and transparent, which is part of the magic of such films.The color and special effects aren't great, but they're not of an order to be dismissed by the very young, especially those who have a fondness for magic carpets, usurped thrones, genies, secret passwords, forbidden rooms and pet monkeys that don't bite. The best thing in the picture is a brief appearance by Mickey Rooney, who plays the harried custodian (what we used to call janitor) of an Ali Baba-like cave, much in the manner of a latterday W.C. Fields.Kevin Connor directed the film, produced by John Dark and written by Brian Hayles.

title: Judge James M. Carter; ExCivil Rights Lawyer
description: LA JOLLA, Calif., Nov. 20 (AP) James M. Carter, a civil rights lawyer who became a judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, died Sunday of a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 75 years old.

title: Associated Press
description: BLUES DEFEAT ISLANDERS IN ST. LOUIS: Glenn Resch, Islanders goalie, watched shot by Blues Perry Turnbull (9), fly over his head in first period. Islanders Stefan Persson hit ice trying to block shot. Blues won, 63.

title: Brown, in New York City, Finds Skepticism on a Credit Proposal
description: Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California met some skepticism from New York City business and political leaders when he proposed yesterday that the Government should play a stronger role in deciding who is allocated financial credit.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS Iran's Dollars
description: WASHINGTON  President Carter had little political choice but to freeze the Iranian Government's assets in the United States.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE WINE OF LIFE AND OTHER ESSAYS ON SOCIETIES, ENERGY AND LIVING THINGS. By Harold J. Morowitz. 261 pages. St. Martin's Press. $10.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: The dollar generally held its ground yesterday in erratic trading dominated by conflicting reports on whether Iran was moving to stop taking dollars in return for its oil.

title: Hartford Votes Increased Loans For Heating Aid
description: HARTFORD, Nov. 20  The General Assembly completed its special session on energy today by expanding the state's program of energy conservation loans and approving new loans to help moderate income families pay for heating oil this winter.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: 6 Devoted City Workers Get $5,000 and Mayor's Thanks
description: Six New York City employees received $5,000 awards last night and the plaudits of a Mayor who has frequently been critical of the Civil Service system they serve.

title: ... and So Does Shue
description: SAN DIEGO, Nov. 20 (AP)  Brian Taylor, Freeman Williams and Lloyd Free combined for 81 points tonight as the San Diego Clippers defeated the Phoenix Suns, 117110, to give Gene Shue his 500th National Basketball Association victory as a head coach.

title: Injured Nureyev a Spectator at World Premiere of His Manfred
description: PARIS, Nov. 20  At the world premiere of his new ballet, Manfred, tonight, Rudolf Nureyev will be unhappily constrained to watching, not dancing. It is obviously a serious disappointment, the result of a broken bone in his foot suffered during a performance in West Berlin on Nov. 4.

title: The City
description: The New York City Planning Commission yesterday approved amendments to zoning regulations designed to permit sidewalk cafes only in certain areas of the city, setting specific design criteria to prevent their interference with pedestrian traffic and strengthening procedures against illegal cafes.

title: Around the Nation
description: GREENSBORO, N.C., Nov. 20 (AP) The Greensboro City Council has asked for a Federal evaluation of the city Police Department's investigation into its own handling of an antiKu Klux Klan rally where five were slain on Nov. 3.

title: Murdoch Seeking Australian Papers
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 20 (AP)  Rupert Murdoch bid $142.5 million today for a controlling share of one of his major Australian newspaper competitors, the Herald and Weekly Times Grow.

title: Blast Derails Empty Train
description: BENTLYVILLE, Pa., Nov. 20 (UPI) Conrail tracks near this Washington County community were dynamited today, causing the derailment of an empty 30car freight train. The police said that it was apparently a case of sabotage. There were no injuries. The derailment occurred about two miles southwest of Somerset Township. The explosion could be heard 50 miles away.

title: Israel's Tough Inflation Curbs
description: TEL AVIV, Nov, 20  The price of basic food items shot up by as much as 100 percent in Israel's supermarkets this morning as the Government introduced tough economic measures designed to brake the spiraling inflation.

title: Excerpts From Speech by Khomeini Broadcast Over Teheran Radio
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 Following are excerpts from a speech by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini broadcast today by the Teheran radio, as received and translated here by the United States Foreign Broadcast Information Service:

title: Kitchen Equipment
description: To judge by the profusion of pastamaking machines in the city's stores, a great many cooks have learned that the difference between fresh, homemade pasta and the dehydrated version is one that matters.

title: Chicago School Board Averts a Missed Payroll by LastMinute Deals
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 20  The Chicago Board of Education said today that it had obtained enough financial commitments from the city and state to avoid having to skip a payday for its 49,000 school employees tomorrow in order to retire $89 million in debts that become due on Monday.

title: CowboyOiler Game Highlights Long Weekend of Pro Football
description: Houston against Dallas tomorrow in Texas Stadium is the most important game on the National Football League schedule over the long weekend. The OilerCowboy matchup (Channel 4, 4 P.M.) will be the second part of the Thanksgiving Day televised doubleheader, following the Chicago at Detroit contest (Channel 2, 12:30 P.M.).

title: Delaware Wins Lambert
description: Delaware, which compiled a 101 wonlost record, has been named winner of the Lambert Cup as the outstanding National Collegiate Division II football team in the Northeast this season. It was the 12th time in 23 years that Delaware had won the award. Its only loss was to Temple, a Division IA team. Lehigh (92) placed second and Boston University (811) third in the voting by a committee of sportswriters and broadcasters.

title: 2 Found Guilty in a Bank Collapse
description: Two former officers of the American Bank and Trust Company were found guilty yesterday of charges that they contributed to the collapse of the bank in 1976 by making illegal loans to an Argentine financier.

title: Where to Find Nuts for Baking
description: Stumyland Farms and Torn Ranch had consistently high quality nuts. Goodbee pecans and pecans from Nat's Nut Shoppe were excellent; for those who prefer a strongflavored walnut,

title: DrunkenDriving Law Is Reinstated
description: The New York State Court of Appeals reversed yesterday a lower court decision that had struck down the main portions of the state's drunkendriving statutes as unconstitionallv vague.

title: Europe and U.S. Plan Fiber Talks
description: BRUSSELS, Nov. 20 The Common Market and the United States agreed today to hold talks on America's fastrising exports of synthetic fibers, which European nations say enjoy an unfair price advantage because the Carter Administration keeps the price of domestic crude oil below world levels.

title: Xerox and WUT Near Merger
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP)  The proposed merger of the Xerox Corporation and WUI Inc. gained the conditional approval of the Federal .Commumcations Commission today.

title: Prices Mixed After Early Gains
description: Bond prices closed mixed yesterday after moving higher early in the day on the strength of a sellout of this week's only major corporate offering. But disquieting news reports from Iran pared gains in the fixedincome sector late in the session. Some Government securities even showed token declines.

title: Thanksgivings Abroad: Tales Of No Turkey in Turkey, Etc.
description: BECAUSE most of the Thanksgivings of my life have been spent in New York with family and friends eating more or less the same meal, my recollections of that day tend to blur into a composite memory. Not one of those traditional celebrations stands separately in my mind's eye; Thanksgiving to me, is, in fact, the sum total of all those happy, laughing, fragrant and delectable days.

title: Goodrich Mexican Venture
description: AKRON, Ohio, Nov. 20 (Reuters) The B.F. Goodrich Company said today that Policy S.A. of Mexico, a Joint venture between Goodrich and the Cydsa Group of Mexico, had begun construction of a polyvinyl chloride resin plant near Tampico, Mexico. Goodrich said the plant would have an annual output of 150 million pounds when it begins operation in 1981.

title: Players Take a Back Seat on the Sputtering Cowboys
description: The heat is on the Dallas Cowboys, America's most popular professional sports team. And again, as they struggle to make the National Football League playoffs for the 13th time in the last 14 years, the Cowboys have followed their philosophy that says the organization is bigger and stronger than any single player.

title: Woolworth Picks I.B.M. For 8,000 Store Systems
description: The International Business Machines Corporation, in a major coup in the growing market for computer terminals used in retail stores, has won an order for 8,000 of the systems from the F.W. Woolworth Company, the nation's fifthlargest retail chain.

title: Private Lives
description: THEY will rise on the morrow  lashed by tradition, moon faces full of teeth, foaming mouths, friends and relatives who happen to be friends, human kelp  and wash down the doors of the house. The coat rack, of which I am inordinately fond, will grow like a tree in the hall, out of the wreckage of their canoes and rafts; the caps and scarfs in its antlers will be blossoms, fallen stars. The feet on the stairs will propel a groaning of pie plates, stuff in bowls, saddlebags of vegetable matter, upward, ever upward in the Ark, to the warm galley where the bird sweats. On the jukebox will be horn concertos by Mozart, fanfares by Lully, Purcell volunteering for two trumpets.

title: Notes on People
description: It'saLiving Dept.

title: Hawaii: Danger Under The Palms
description: HAIKU, Hawaii  Romantic Hawaii attracts millions of visitors each year with visions of glorious eternal sunshine, statuesque palm trees swaying majestically in the cool breeze, and perhaps, most lucrative of all, friendly Polynesian beauties awaiting with fragrant floral greetings and aloha spirit.

title: The Fallout Shelter Leftovers
description: HIDDEN far beneath the streets of the city, in thousands of dusty basement hideaways, are 10,000 tons of crackers, candies, medical supplies and toilet tissue  just about everything millions of New Yorkers would have needed to survive a nuclear war in 1963.

title: Corporate Earnings
description: For periods as shown.( N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (0) overthecounter.

title: Outside Doctors Raise Questions About Shah's Treatment
description: Four weeks ago today, gallstones were surgically removed from Mohammed Riza Paldevi, the deposed Shah of Iran, at New York HospitalCornell Medical Center here, and since then at least five radiation treatments have begun shrinking a cancer in his neck.

title: The U.N. Today
