description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: NEW KHOMEINI ATTACK
description: President Carter, the Ayatollah said, must not think that we will retreat one step.

title: World News Briefs
description: TEL AVIV, Nov. 20 (Reuters)  United States, Israeli and Egyptian teams ended a round of Palestinian autonomy talks in Tel Aviv today and reported progress in negotiations on elections in the occupied West Bank and the Gaza Strip.

title: COMMODITIES
description: New York gold futures advanced yesterday despite softer prices in London and the general tendency among commodity traders to confine their activity to preholiday squaring of accounts

title: Ramsay Joins 500 Club. .
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 20 (AP) The Portland Trail Blazers handed Coach Jack Ramsay his 500th National Basketball Association coaching victory tonight, a 11499 triumph over the Los Angeles Lakers.

title: Nestl to Acquire BeechNut Foods
description: Nestl S.A. of Switzerland, one of the world's largest producers of dairy products, chocolate, infant foods and instant and liquid drinks, announced yesterday that it would acquire the BeechNut Foods Corporation, a privately held maker of baby food best known for its emphasis on salt and sugarfree products. The terms of the transaction were not disclosed.

title: Prague Unyielding in Its Drive Against Dissidents
description: PRAGUE, Nov. 17  Although apparently taken aback by the international protest over the trial and conviction of six leading activists last month, the Goverment shows no signs of easing its campaign to crush the humanrights movement known as Charter 77.

title: M. TA. May Face Deficit Next Year of $200 Million
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority will face a $200 million deficit next year unless there is a substantial increase in revenues from transit and commuter railroad fares or there are new legislative subsidies, sources in the authority said yesterday.

title: To Roast Nuts
description: The taste of raw nuts is considerably heightened by roasting. Roasted and salted nuts are available at most nut stores and mail order sources; homeroasting and seasoning maintain control over the amount and quality of butter. oil and salt.

title: Events Today
description: KING OF SCHNORRERS, music and lyrics by Judd Woldin, directed and choreographed by Grover Dale, starring Lloyd BattIsta, Playhouse, 359 West 48th Street, 8.

title: Suspect Goes on Trial As Alleged Assailant Of a Decoy Policeman
description: A decoy police officer who was slashed with a knife last April testified yesterday that the suspect arrested had never left his sight from the moment he was attacked until the man was taken into custody by two backup police officers.

title: Long Assures Carter on Oil Tax
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20  Senator Russell B. Long, the Finance Committee chairman, has predicted privately that Congress will send President Carter a windfall oil profits tax bill that will raise 80 to 85 percent of the revenue the White House has reouested.

title: Iranian Flags Sell Fast in U.S.; Buyers Burn Them at Protests
description: There's a small run on Iranian flags in the United States and they're for burning.

title: Economy Grew 3.5% In Quarter
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP)  The Government reported today that the nation's inflationadjusted gross national product increased 3.5 percent at an annual rate in the third quarter, compared with a preliminary estimate last month of a 2.4 oercent rise.

title: Cavaliers 119, Jazz 107
description: RICHFIELD, Ohio, Nov. 20 (AP) Campy Russell scored 33 points to help the Cleveland Cavaliers snap a fivegame losing streak and beat the Utah Jazz, 119107, tonight.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Bernard M. Fauber, 57 years old, has been named chief executive officer of the K Mart Corporation, effective Jan. 31, 1979, and chairman, effective the following May. He will succeed in those posts Robert E. Dewar, also 57, who will continue as a fulltime employee as chairman of the executive and finance committees.

title: Starting Over on High Medical Costs
description: Everyone agrees that something has to be done to control exploding medical costs. In two decades, they have gone from 6 cents of every consumer dollar to a dime and from 2 percent to 9 percent of Government spending. But there is little agreement on how costs should be controlled.

title: Troubled Islanders Lose to Blues by 63
description: ST. LOUIS., Nov. 20 The Islanders climbed out of one rut tonight but fell into another as the St. Louis Blues beat them, 63, at the Checkerdome. For the first time in five games, the Islanders did not allow exactly five goals, but the loss was the fourth in their last five contests

title: Texts Bearing On US. Stand
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20  Following are the text of a statement released by the White House today and articles of the Charter of the United Nations that could be cited as a basis for remedies"avai/able under the Charter:

title: Civil Defense Fallout Shelters: Relics of the 60's
description: In the early 1960's, especially after the heightened fears of nuclear attack following the Cuban missile crisis, fallout shelters were believed to be the chief means of defense against the effects of a nuclear blast.

title: Desserts From Four Famous ChefsFrancis Lorenzinl's Roulade Ananas (Pineapple Cake)
description: The jelly roll must be prepared at least eight hours before assembling the cake. The entire roulade can be frozen, well wrapped, for up to one month, then thawed in the refrigerator for a day. Do not glaze until day it is to be served. The jelly roll:

title: F.C.C., 43, Upholds the President In Bid for Prime Time on Television
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20  President Carter's reelection committee won a close but important victory today when the Federal Communications Commission ruled in a 4to3 vote that the television networks had acted unreasonably in refusmg Mr. Carter's request to buy 30 minutes of prime time next month to announce his candidacy for a second term.

title: Market Place
description: WHEN J. Peter Grace, chairman of W.R. Grace & Company, disclosed on Oct. 4 that he was considering breaking up the company into as many as seven publicly held concerns, the stock jumped to 41 from 35.

title: Senate Panel Backs Curbs on F.T.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20  The Senate Commerce Committee unanimously approved a bill today that would restrict the powers of the Federal Trade Commission and tighten Congressional control over the agencv.

title: Fuel Costs Bring Hardship in New England
description: FITCHBURG, Mass., Nov. 16  The dull gloom of a New England November was sliding imperceptibly into full darkness as Marion Francis shuffled over to table, lamp and switched on a 40watt bulb, the only light on in the fourroom house she has lived in for 22 years.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Flute Trio in D, Quantz; Lyric Pieces, No. 4, Grieg; Reverie and Caprice for Violin and Orchestra, Berlioz; Le Poisson d'Or, Berners.

title: Money
Pilots and Controllers See Threat Of Crashes in Computer Failures
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20  Air traffic controllers and airline pilots expressed growing concern today about the danger of midair collisions, citing what they said was an increasing frequency of breakdowns in computerized control equipment.

title: Play: Gilroy Drama Of Me, Last Licks
description: I THINK we're apt to get things backwards at the Longacre. Frank D. Gilroy's new play, Last Licks, looks like a tart and impish comedy that turns unaccountably sober in the second of its two acts. It's probably nothing of the sort. My best second guess, now that I've fought my way through considerable bafflement, is that Mr. Gilroy sat down to his typewriter determined to untangle a deeply serious psychological snarl, tossing in some light laughter as relief along the way. And that he got up from his typewriter, a long time later, to discover that his three characters had played him false. They were much too funny for much too long. Treachery, can thy name be comedy?

title: Personal Health
description: ONE of the special characteristics of mammals is their ability to maintain a stable body temperature despite a wide range in environmental temperatures. This is wnat it means to be warmblooded. A tiny section of the brain called the hypothalamus houses the body's thermostat, which is normally set at about .6 degrees Fahrenheit, give or take a degree or two.

title: The Region
description: Bail was set at $50,000 yesterday for an Elizabeth man seized Monday in Plainfield on a Federal warrant in connection with an attempt to extort a $100,000 ransom from a bank manager on Aug. 31. There had been two similar kidnappingandextortion attempts in Essex County earlier in the summer, and authorities said the suspect may have been involved in all three of them.

title: Influx to Mecca a Strain on Saudis
description: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia  The largest yearly mass movement of human beings was at its peak earlier this month as two million Moslems clogged the holy city of Mecca in fulfillment of the Islamic command of pilgrimage.

title: Another Name Enters the Bidding for the Mets
description: Another bidder for the New York Mets surfaced yesterday. His name is Bernard Gimbel  no relation to the store  and he wants to hire Billy Martin as manager and Whitey Herzog as general manager.

title: Radio and Poll Consultants Hired for Start of Kennedy Drive
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy has hired television, radio and polling consultants for the initial stages of his Presidential campaign and, almost a year before the election, is producing his first television commercial for use in Iowa in early December.

title: Irish Eleven in Tokyo
description: TOKYO, Nov. 20 (AP)  Notre Dame's football team arrived tonight for a regularseason game against Miami of Florida on Sunday. Miami is due to arrive tomorrow.

title: Prices for Burgundy Off at Hospices Sale
description: BEAUNE, France, Nov. 18 Someone was saying after the famous Hospices de Beaune wine auction here today that Burgundy avoided two disasters during the 1979 vintage: a small harvest of very fine wines and, equally, a large harvest of mediocre wines.

title: 76ers 118, Spurs 114
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Nov. 20 (AP)  Julius Erving scored 26 points and Darryl Dawkins 24 and the Philadelphia 76ers fought off a late San Antonio rally tonight to register a 118114 victory over the Spurs.

title: Credit Squeeze Barred On Home Heating Oil
description: A new city regulation to protect New Yorkers from unjustified credit squeezes by retail home heating oil dealers this winter went into effect yesterday. Consumer Affairs Commissioner Bruce C. Ratner said the dealers were barred from imposing more stringent credit terms, payment schedules or debt collection practices than those they had in the last heating season. Violations can lead to fines from $2 to $350.

title: U.S. Judge Harold Leventhal, 64
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20  Judge Harold Leventhal of the United States Court of Appeals for the Distnct of Columbia suffered a heart attack today after playing tennis and died a short time afterward at the George Washington University Hospital.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Allied Stores Corporation has appointed Bruce L. Burnham as president and chief executive officer of Bonwit Teller.

title: ADE SCHWAMMEL
description: HONOLULU, Nov. 20 (AP)  Ade Schwammel, a former football player for Oregon State and the Green Bay Packers, died Sunday. He was 71 years old. Mr. Schwammel, who resided here for the last 31 years, played tackle at Oregon State in 1931, 1932 and 1933. He played with the Packers for three consecutive seasons, starting in 1934, and again in 1943 and 1944.

title: Canada to Reduce Stake In Development Concern
description: TORONTO, Nov. 20 The Canadian Government is planning to reduce drastically its ownership in the Canada Development Corporation, a large diversified holding company with $2.6 billion (Canadian) in assets, including the single largest block of shares in Texasgulf Inc.

title: Opposition Parties Win 2 Elections In Canada in Government Setback
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 20  Victories by the opposition parties in two byelections yesterday have reduced to one the potential majority of Prime Minister Joe Clark's minority Government.

title: Careers
description: AROUND the age of 30 job uneasiness often becomes a fact of life and it reappears at 50. In the early period of one's career the question is: Do I like what I'm doing and does it have the future I want? At middie age, the question might be a little different: If I have gone as far as I can in this job is it time for a change? Or in the case of a mother who wants to go back to work the question might be: What shall I do now?

title: Themes in Fashion for Spring
description: WHEN fashion designers decide en masse to shorten skirts or widen shoulders, as they have been doing, they explain it by saying certain feelings are III the air. This is true, to a certain extent, because after hemlines have descended almost to the ankles, they have no place to go but up, and the widespread use of shoulder pads in recent seasons certainly called attention to a broader line at the top.

title: California To Play in Jersey Bowl
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 20  The University of California, which has a 65 wonlost record, today accepted a bid to meet Temple in the second Garden State Bowl at Giants Stadium on Dec. 15. It will mark the first time in 20 years that the Golden Bears of the Pacific10 Conference have appeared in a postseason bowl game.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FULL EVENING The free holiday entertainment at the Citicorp Center's Market atrium is scheduled for tonight, with a double bill of humor and classical music. Starting at 6 o'clock, Paul Dunkel will conduct the Orchestra of New York in Samuel Barber's Capricorn Concerto and Igor Stravinsky's Dumbarton Oaks. Afterward, the humorist trio of Weeden, Finkle and Fay will take over at 8 for two hours, in their regular Wednesday slot this month, with a prankish commentary on living in New York.

title: Venice Flooded for Sixth Day
description: VENICE, Nov. 20 (Reuters)  High tides flooded parts of central Venice for a sixth day today. The high water, which puts St Mark's Square and other areas under a few inches of water, had never before occurred six days in a row.

title: Senate Unit For Curb on Oil Industry
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP)  The Senate Judiciary Committee approved legislation today that would limit the ability of the 18 largest United States oil companies to acquire other companies.

title: Anheuser Drops LowAlcohol Brew
description: AnheuserBusch Inc., the nation's largest brewer, said yesterday that it would discontinue production of its 15monthold, lowalcohol beverage Chelsea.

title: Advertising
description: IN a deal born in the Chung Chuig Chinese restaurant in Davenport, Iowa, a newly formed joint venture has purchased McAvoy Publications International, advertising representatives, and has formed China Advertising, which will use a new chain of worldwide sales offices to sell advertising space in 53 Chinese scientific and technical publications that have never before run advertising.

title: When the Body Temperature Rises
description: Feeling the forehead with your lips or hand does not give an accurate reading, or even a good guess, of body temperature. You must use a fever thermometer oral, rectal  and shake it down to at least 96 degrees.

title: Kosygin, Out of Sight for Month, Is Reported Under Medical Care
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 20 (Reuters)  Prime Minister Aleksei N. Kosygin, who will be 76 years old in February, has been undergoing medical treatment in recent weeks, Soviet and East European sources said today.

title: New Yorkers,etc.
description: THERE are few certainties left in life, but one is that Christmas falls on Dec. 25. This is approximately two blinks away from tomorrow's turkey and it is just as well to remember that although cheer and goodwill may be a cinch to summon up on command, it isn't quite so easy to come up with the goodies that relatives, friends and sundries have come to expect.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Tuesday, Nov 20,1979

title: Minority Hiring Ordered by State Is Ruled Invalid
description: The New York Court of Appeals yesterday struck down executive orders by Governor Carey and former Mayor Abraham D. Beame directing construction companies to establish hiring programs that would increase the number of minority and female construction workers.

title: Dutch Parliament Assails Iran
description: THE HAGUE, Nov. 20 (Reuters)  The Dutch Parliament today condemned the occupation of the United States Embassy in Teheran, saying that the action amounted to an attempt to legitimize the taking of hostages. The resolution was adopted by the 150member lower house without opposition.

title: 3 at Citicorp in Running For Its Top Post in 1984
description: Citicorp, announcing a reorganization of its corporate structure, yesterday indicated the three candidates most likely to succeed Walter B. Wriston as chairman and chief executive officer when he reaches retirement age  in 1984.

title: Film 'Between Miracles'
description: BENEDETTO (Nino Manfredi) wants to sin but he can't, being too guilt-ridden in the way of rural Italians as we've come to know them in Italian movies.When he was very young, a poor orphan living with his tyrannical aunt, Benedetto had been prey to all of the impure thoughts and desires that are common to boys of his age. Most boys learn what to do about them. Benedetto didn't. Unfortunately for him, his life had been saved (or so it was interpreted) by the intervention of his patron saint, Eusebio, after which Benedetto was given to the care of monks to be raised and schooled.Some years later, actually when he's "nearing 40" as someone says of him, Benedetto is still living at the monastery and still having impure thoughts, which, when you're nearing 40, suggests the existence of major problems."Between Miracles," the 1971 Italian comedy that opens today at the Cinema I, is the story of Benedetto's liberation  sort of  when he meets a free-thinking old pharmacist named Orestes (Lionel Stander), who inspires the young man to throw off religion's crushing yoke. That Orestes has a beautiful daughter, Giovanna (Delia Boccardo), with whom Benedetto falls in love, also helps.For a film that is so essentially pious and conformist, "Between Miracles" is suprisingly offensive, mostly, I suspect, because Mr. Manfredi, one of Italy's most popular performers, does not travel well. He projects this middle-aged man's innocence with all of the conviction of of an over-the-hill vaudeville performer.In addition to being the star of "Between Miracles," Mr. Manfredi also directed it and collaborated on its screenplay. The result is not a comedy of manners but a demonstration of ego, as were most of Jerry Lewis's later films.There are occasional charming moments early on, when Paolo Armeni plays Benedetto as a child, but the charm disappears when Mr. Manfredi lines himself up in his own viewfinder. The director appears to be so enamored of his star that he allows him to give the sort of patronizing, totally bogus imitation of innocence that, in tone if not in mannerisms, may remind you of Red Skelton at his worst. I'm not one of the many admirers of Mr. Manfredi's performance in the award-winning "Bread and Chocolate," but that one was a model of sincerity compared to what he does as Benedetto in "Between Miracles."I should also admit that I have trouble relating to Lionel Stander (who here seems to speak perfect Italian in his familiar, gravelly voice), both as a lovable character, which I never believe, and as an actor, since every performance is like the one that preceded it. He has become a very boring actor, but then "Between Miracles" is a very boring movie. It's among Mr. Manfredi's peculiar accomplishments to have made a film in which there is absolutely no sense of time, place or people, Just actors.

title: Mayor Sees Dirty Politics
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 20 (UPI)  Mayor Byrne charged today that Secretary Goldsc.hmidt was playing dirty politics and was totally out of line in saying that Federal funds could be reduced because of her support for Senator Kennedy. I think it is very dirty politics, she said. I wouldn't want anybody to be this vindictive.

title: A Rookie Surprise Sizzles for Rockets
description: During his six National Basketball Association seasons, E. C. Coleman was noted as a defensive specialist and rebounder. As a parttime scout for the Houston Rockets last season, Coleman came up with a player who many observers think is the rookie discovery of the year. He is Allen Leavell of Oklahoma City, the 105th choice of the college draft

title: Deaths
description: ALBERTAnn A. The Sisterhood of Temple Beth Emeth of Flatbush mourns the loss of its fellow officer and expresses its deepest sympathy to the family

title: Alan Barth, Editorial Writer, Dies; Championed Civil Liberties Causes
description: Alan Barth, a former editorial writer for The Washington Post and author of many books espousing the cause of civil liberties and rights, died yesterday of pneumonia at the Veterans Aciministray lion Hospital in Washington, where he had been suffering from cancer. He was 73 years old and lived in Washington.

title: Con Ed Gets State Approval To Burn Dirtier Oil as a Test
description: ALBANY, Nov. 20  New York State approved today a longstanding request by Consolidated Edison to burn cheaper but dirtier oil on a test basis at two sites in New York City.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: WONDERING how we might survive Thanksgiving this year, we sought the expert help of Richard Smith. Not only is Mr. Smith someone who is much practiced in eating, he is also the author of The Bronx Diet, a book that has as its golden rule, To reduce, eat less; to gain, eat more. Here is his counsel:

title: Soviet Corn Purchase
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP)  An additional 301,600 metric tons of United States corn has been bought by the Soviet Union for delivery in the marketing year that began on Oct. I, the A2riculture Department said today.

title: Newark Council Fails to Override Police Jobs Veto
description: NEWARK, Nov. 20  Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson won his showdown with the City Council tonight when the ninemember Council failed to override Mr. Gibson's veto of an ordinance designed to increase the strength of the city's Police Department.

title: School Collects $3,200 For Cambodian Relief
description: Without bake sales, raffles, phone appeals or marathon dances, the students of the Dwight School in Manhattan have collected $3,200 that they will turn over today to the Catholic Relief Services for Cambodian refugees.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Drops In Oil Use Spur Hope
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20  Federal and corporate energy officials said today that there had been significant drops in demand for oil in recent weeks. They expressed optimism that this would extend into the new year.

title: Post Coach Resigns
description: GREENVALE, L.I., Nov. 20 Dom Anile resigned as C.W. Post's football coach today, after 12 consecutive winning seasons at the Division II college. He said he was leaving because of differences over financial commitments to the football program. The Pioneers won five games and lost four this season.

title: Stocks Decline on Concern Over Iran
description: The stock market, concerned over the intensifying Iranian situation, declined moderately yesterday in active trading. The biggest price moves were posted by some of the special situation issues.

title: Hawks 109, Pistons 105
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 20 (AP)  Armond Hill's driving layup with 39 seconds remaining broke a tie and led the Atlanta Hawks a 109105 victory tonight over the Detroit Pistons.

title: Meaty Ingredients for Holiday Baking   in a Nutshell
description: In the depths of autumn, nature fires the trees with color and heaps the markets with nuts. The almonds, pecans, walnuts and hazelnuts coming to stores now are seasonal symbols of hospitality; traditional zestgivers to appetizers, stuffings, cakes, pies and cookies, and among the most nutritionally generous examples of natural food  filled with vitamins, minerals, protein, polyunsaturated fats and carbohydrates.

title: The Rights of Iranians
description: President Carter has stirred passionate reactions by ordering the Immigration Service to check the status of Iranian students and to start deportation proceedings against those who lack valid visas.

title: IronImport Subsidy Found
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (UPI) Acting on complaints from the United States steel industry, the Treasury Department ruled today that pig iron imported from Brazil was being subsidized by the Brazilian Government.

title: Ramsey Clark Advised Iran on Damages From Shah
description: Before President Carter sent him to try to get American hostages out of Iran, Ramsey Clark wrote a letter to Iranian officials advising them on how to seek damages from the Shah, his family and his confederates, Mr. Clark acknowledged in a statement yesterday.

title: TV RATINGS
description: Following are the top 15 national television shows of the past week (Monday, Nov 12, to Sunday, Nov 18), listed according to their rank in the ratings compiled by the A C Nielsen Company A rating is a percentage of the total number of United States households with television sets

title: TV: Bee Gees Special and Ormandy
description: THE Bee Gees, subject of a 90minute NBCTV special tonight at 9:30, have a talent for putting certain defenders of rock music on the snidely offensive. Like many pop music stars, the Brothers Gibb  Barry, Maurice and Robin have impeccable lowerclass roots credentials. But unlike, say, Bruce Springsteen, they do not wear their urban fury on their performance sleeves.

title: Mayor of Houston Wins 2d Term In Runoff Against a Councilman
description: With 325 of the 355 precincts reporting in the nonpartisan runoff election, Mayor McConn had 82,458 votes to 66,023 for Mr. Macey, according to unofficial returns.

title: Wise, Hrabosky and Perez Sign MillionDollar Pacts
description: Rick Wise, Al Hrabosky and Tony Perez have become the latest of baseball's free agents to agree to milliondollar contracts. Wise signed a fiveyear contract worth $2.1 million with the San Diego Padres, while Perez reached agreement yesterday for three years and $1.1 million with the Boston Red Sox. Hrabosky signed a fiveyear deal with the Atlanta Braves, but he will reportedly receive deferred payments totaling $5.9 million spread over 35 years.

title: 12th Marine Dies of Burns
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Nov. 20 (UPI) Willie Davis, a 22yearold lance corporal from Detroit, is the 12th marine to die of burns suffered in a gasoline fire in Japan, officials of Brooke Army Medical Center said today.

title: Unmasked ExSpy Admits an Appalling Mistake
description: LONDON, Nov. 20  Anthony Blunt emerged from hiding today to admit that he had made an appalling mistake, one he came to bitterly regret, by agreeing 40 years ago to spy for the Soviet Union. But he insisted that he had done so out of idealism.

title: 60 Join Fire Department
description: Sixty New York City firefighters graduated yesterday, bringing the department's strength to 11,600, of whom 1,245 have been added since Sept. 1, 1978. Besides the 60 new members, Commissioner Augustus A. Beekman swore in 60 new probationary firefighters, who will undergo six weeks of training before joining the ranks.

title: ALBANY UNIT PUSHES MINORITY JOB FIGHT
description: State Agency Forming a Coalition Against Federal Plan Setting New Construction Goal

title: A Good Way to Help Small Colleges
description: Waste and mismanagement have been discovered in recent years in one Federal domestic program after another. One of the latest targets of Government auditors is Title III of the Higher Education Act, which dispenses Federal aid to small, underendowed colleges that serve large numbers of lowincome students. Ac- cording to the General Accounting Office, the program is riddled with favoritism, conflicts of interest and questionable expenditures. What's more, the auditors doubt the continuing justification for a program that has failed to achieve the ostensible purpose for which it was created: to help struggling institutions achieve selfsufficiency.

title: Adopting a Parent For Holiday Dinner
description: THE time is almost here. The air is crisp and chill, the stores aretrilliant with glittering displays, the streets throng with shoppers.  Tis the season to be jolly, the ancient song admonishes. Perhaps. For some of us it is a season fraught with guilt and gloom.

title: Commerce in Flatbush Gets a Lift
description: Healthy neighborhoods need healthy commercial strips, Mayor Koch said yesterday as he signed a contract to provide $66,000 in public funds for use as seed money for capital improvements on Church Avenue, in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn.

title: A Teheran Family Backs Embassy Seizure
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 21  Seven miles and an entire generation from the angry Iranian students who have taken over the United States Embassy on Taleghani Street, Beyoq Assadullah Zadeh of Badami Street is in his own quiet way no less full of fervor than the youths, and no less persuaded of the righteousness of their actions.

title: PekingBonn Oil Venture
description: PEKING, Nov. 21 (UPI)  China and West Germany signed agreements today providing for joint prospecting for hydrocarbons in eastern China and joint surveying of oil and gas reserves on China's east coast.

title: Letters

title: Iran Said To Default On Loan
description: Iran has defaulted on a $500 million loan from a syndicate of international banks, according to banking sources.

title: Whalers 5, Sabres 3
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Nov. 21 (UPI)  Blaine Stoughton scored three goals and added an assist tonight, pacing the Hartford Whalers to a 53 triumph over the Buffalo Sabres.

title: Mrs. Lloyd Concedes No. 1 Spot
description: BRIGHTON, England, Nov. 21 (UPI)  Chris Evert Lloyd routed Brigitte Simon of France, 61, 60, in the first round of a $100,000 women's indoor tennis tournament today, then said that capturing the event would not salvage her year.

title: War Crimes Alleged in Suit On Citizenship of L.I. Man
description: The Justice Department, in a series of new actions against alleged Nazi war criminals living in America, filed suit yesterday to revoke the citizenship of a 60-year-old Long Island man.

title: Now, Warm Dessert
description: A certain Mrs. Avril Crabtree of Cheshire, England, has resourcefully sent us, on a small sheet of ivory-coloured note paper that is six and fif- teensixteenth inches wide and eight and threeeighth inches long, the infor- mation that I have in my possession a scrapbook, inherited from an old family friend, which was compiled just after the turn of the century. One of the items, of which I enclose a copy, is an extract from a newspaper pub- lished at the end of December 1904. The title of the paper is unfortunately not shown. In this International Year of the Child and with the approach of Thanksgiving Day you may be inter- ested to see . . . the account of what was done for the children of New York on Thanksgiving Day . . . in 1879.

title: Japan Imports Of Crude Gain
description: TOKYO, Nov. 21 (Reuters) Japan's imports of crude oil in October rose 10.5 percent from September, to 157 million barrels, and 12.7 percent from October 1978, the International Trade and Industry Ministry said today.

title: Attack in Mecca Attributed to Khomeini Influence
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 21  The seizure of the Grand Mosque in Mecca yesterday by a band of armed men was described today by Moslems here as a result of a radicalizing influence that the Iranian revolution of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini has had on the entire region, from North Africa to Pakistan.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: 2Year U.S. Notes Sold at 12.24% Yield

title: Kitchen Design: Advice from Three Experts
description: ABOVE all else, insists Maurice MooreBetty, a kitchen must be sensible. Sturdy restaurantstyle cooktops. Unfussy pots. A refrigerator wide enough to hold a whole fish. For Giuliano Bugialli, practicality is important, but not primary. Walnut cabinets, handmade tiles, counters of Italian marble create a showcase for a life's collection of Florentine antiques. To Sherry Zitron, the essential kitchen is maintenancefree, with Formica countertops, easy-on-the-feet vinyl squares, fingerprintproof mattefinish cabinets and selfcleaning ovens.

description: Offbeat Energy Speculation

title: Mayor Koch and Governor Carey Join Prayer Service for Hostages
description: NEW YORK, Nov. 21 (UPI)  Governor Carey and Mayor Koch attended an ecumenical service in St. Patrick's Cathedral today to pray for the safe release of the American hostages in Iran.

title: Music: Wolf Trap Soloists
description: THE Concert Soloists of Wolf Trap is a group of instrumentalists that has performed at the Wolf Trap music center outside Washington and now has branched out as a touring ensemble. Sometimes this kind of festival collaboration, with its opportunities for intensive rehearsal and repetition of programs, can deliver superior results, as witness the successes enjoyed by similar groups such as the Santa Fe chamber players. The Wolf Trappers, who pleaded their case on Tuesday night at Carnegie Hall, made a good impression despite the hall, which is =hospitably large for chamber music.

title: Soviet Buys Soybean Meal
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP)  The Soviet Union has bought 280,000 metric tons of United States soybean meal, the first of the current season, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Theater: Ketron's Character Lines
description: LARRY KETRON'S plays have all shared a certain texture. The settings are rural, the characters mildly confused, and the dominant moods downhome rustic and provincial. His latest play, Character Lines, which is playing at the WPA Theater, also displays those traits, but this time, the values of the big city intrude on that hermetic world. Although

title: Around the Nation
description: HONOLULU, Nov. 21 (UPI) A tentative contract agreement was reached tonight in the monthlong strike by 7,700 state government bluecollar workers that forced the public schools to close and has left garbage piled in the streets and airports.

title: Army Says Tests of Tanks Show Technical Problems Are Solved
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP)  Four months of rigorous testing have shown that major technical problems with the new XM1 tank have been solved, the Army said yesterday.

title: About New Hyde Park
description: NEW HYDE PARK, L.I.  This is not, strictly speaking, a story of Thanksgiving, such as the writer on this day feels bound to put upon a reader already suffused with spirit and stuffing. But Thanksgiving evokes a

title: Civiletti Files a Decision On Jordan Allegations
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP)  Attorney General Benjamin R. Civiletti has informed a special threejudge court of his decision on whether a special prosecutor will be named to investigate charges that Hamilton Jordan, the White House chief of staff, used cocaine.

title: Explosion Burns 4 in Pittsburgh
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 21 (UPI) An explosion of undetermined origin ripped through the Shenango Inc. cokemaking plant on an island in the Ohio River yesterday and four workers were seriously burned. The explosion was believed to have occurred in a in a gas compressor, but company officials said that an investigation was under way to determine the exact cause.

title: UV Reportedly Moves Meeting
description: UV Industries board members, originally expected to meet on Monday to hear a report by the company's investment adviser on rival bids for the remaining assets of the cashrich concern, have moved up the meeting to Saturday, industry sources said yesterday.

title: U.N. Offers 2 Forums For Iran to State Case In Return for Captives
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 21 Top United Nations officials offered Iran two forums today in which to state its case, in return for the release of the American hostages.

title: Events Today
description: APPALSHOP: FILMS FROM APPALACHIA, shorts, at the Film Forum, 15 Vandam Street.

title: Capturing Winter Sun for Growing
description: FREEZING temperatures, as every vegetable grower knows, spell doom for the vast majority of crops. Even when protected by a cold frame, their growing season can be extended by a mere three or four weeks beyond the frost. But the solar grow frame, a recent development in solar technology, enables gardeners to harness the sun's relatively weak winter warmth and keep crops cruising along in the 30's and 40's while outside temperatures are below zero  and all without spending a penny on conventional fuels.

title: Harry Zisk, 80, Business Leader In Hackensack Until Retirement
description: Harry Zisk, a community leader and retired president of Famous Fain Knitting Mills in Hackensack, N.J., died yesterday at Hackensack Hospital after a brief illness. He was 80 years old and lived in Hackensack.

title: Oilers 4, Maple Leafs 4
description: TORONTO, Nov. 21 (UPI)  Wayne Gretzky, Edmonton's 18-year-old star, scored two goals tonight, including one on a thirdperiod power play, to help the Oilers gain a 44 tie with the Toronto Maple Leafs.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: DETROIT, Nov. 21 (UPI)  Production cutbacks announced today by two of the major auto makers will cause the temporary layoff of 37,000 more workers and the temporary closing of 14 more assembly plants next week.

title: 6 U.S. Companies In Mexico Gas Bid
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (Reuters)  The Energy Department said today that it had received an application from six major United States pipeline companies to import 300 million cubic feet of natural gas a day from Mexico.

title: Gunmen Still Hold Mecca Mosque; Identity and Motives Are Unclear
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Nov. 21 Gunmen who seized the Grand Mosque in Mecca early yesterday were still holding out with hostages in the shrine late today, but the Saudi Government said its troops were deployed and awaiting orders.

title: NEW YORK BROADENS ITS POWER TO BLOCK EDUCATION SPENDING
description: Major changes that give city budget officials greater control over spending by the Board of Education were a result of recent agreements that eliminated a $55 million deficit in school spending and prevented a layoff of teachers, according to officials of the Koch administration.

title: Nuclear Accident
description: IDAHO FALLS, Nov. 21 (AP)  Scientists have opened a valve on a small nuclear reactor at the Idaho National Engineering Laboratory and purposely set off the type of nuclear accident that shut down the Three Mile Island nuclear plant.

title: Houston's Challenge to Dallas Extends Far Beyond the Gridiron
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 21  Ooowee, Jim Bob, look out nowt_

title: Piano Recital: James Cresce
description: JAMES CRESCE played a bit of this and a bit of that at his piano recital Monday night in Carnegie Recital Hall. There were 19 selections on his program, none of them very long or of any particular musical depth, and most were designed to display Mr. Cresce's considerable technical facility.

title: SCM Claims Victory In Shareholder Case
description: The SCM Corporation said yesterday that a preliminary count of ballots in the proxy fight between management and an insurgent group of stockholders indicated that management had won the battle, by a better than 2-to-1 margin, to keep control of the company.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Martin Rubenstein Named Mutual Network President
description: Martin Rubenstein has been named president of the Mutual Broadcasting System Inc., operator of the Mutual radio network. Mr. Rubenstein had been executive vice president of Mutual for the last 18 months and a member of the executive committee that ran the company in lieu of a president since December.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York Stock Exchange issued yesterday its latest report of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchange.

description: Yesterday's Weather at 1 P.M.: National Oceanic and Atmospheric AdministratIon/UPI

title: Iranians in U.S. Fear Retaliation On Two Fronts
description: Angry Iranian faces at demonstrations outside the United States Embassy in Teheran flashed across the television screen, and seven Iranians huddled together in a Long Island living room stared back at them in silence. When a picture of the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini appeared before them, one of them suddenly shook his head and burst out, That madman!

title: i One of 3 Is Guilty in Second Trial In Slaying of a Harvard Athlete
description: BOSTON, Nov. 21 (AP)  One man was convicted of manslaughter and two others were acquitted yesterday in the knife slaying three years ago of Andrew Puopolo, a Harvard University football player.

title: Stocks Overcome Early Loss
description: Decline in Dow Reduced to 1.80

title: Officer Who Deserted To Cuba 12 Years Ago Flies Back Voluntarily
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP)  The Army announced today that Maj. Richard H. Pearce, who it said deserted to Cuba more than 12 years ago, had returned voluntarily to the United States.

title: Murdoch Ends Australia Bid
description: ADELAIDE, Australia, Thursday, Nov. 22 (Reuters)  News Ltd., Rupert Murdoch's Australian company, said today that it had ordered the sale of all its shares in the Herald and Weekly Times Ltd., the country's biggest newspaper group, and that it had no intention of acquiring any interest in the group.

title: U.S. Renews Campaign On the Drunken Driver
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (UPI)  The Government today renewed its campaign against the drunken driver, citing successful state programs that had significantly cut fatal highway accidents.

title: Mrs. Grasso Fights Budget Deficit
description: HARTFORD, Nov. 21  Connecticut is facing a budget gap of $148.9 million in its next fiscal year, which will require some combination of spending cuts and new or higher taxes to close, Gov. Ella T. Grasso disclosed today.

title: SST Making Money and Friends
description: The supersonic transport Concorde, an economic !allure on most of its international routes, has become a financial success in the two years that the needlenosed jet has been linking New York with Paris and London. In sharp contrast with its experience elsewhere, the plane has attracted a loyal coterie of repeat riders here, mostly businessmen, and one operator, British Airways, says it will soon add two more flights to London every week.

title: Iran Is Said to Monitor Vessels in Vital Strait
description: Iran is now monitoring all ships entering and leaving the Strait of Hormuz, the critical passage through which all oil tankers leaving the Persian Gulf must pass, according to an authoritative oil industry newsletter.

title: Reported Crime in New York State Goes Up 4.8% in First Half of'79
description: Reports of crime in New York State rose by 9.8 percent in the first half of 1979 over the same period last year, the State Division of Criminal Justice Services said yesterday.

title: TV: A LowKey Retirement Drama
description: LETTERS From Frank, on CBSTV tonight at 9 o'clock, is being marketed as a heartwarming holiday drama. Press releases call the twohour television movie sensitive. The advertisements proclaim, You can't retire courageous man from life. In fact, the production, starring Art Carney and Maureen Stapleton as husband and wife, is downbeat and generally depressing. Perhaps, given the reluctance of television to deal with uncomfortable realities, this is to be applauded.

title: Wary Approach To Iranians Seen In Arms Arrests
description: BALTIMORE, Nov. 21  The White House, in an effort to avoid publicity that might further endanger the Americans being held in the embassy in Teheran. was reported today to have ordered Federal agents here to be careful in their public statements about the arrests last week of eight Iranian students on gunrunning charges.

title: U.S. Lugers Struggle for Lake Placid Olympic Training Time
description: Already hampered by a serious identity crisis and shortage of funds, United States lugers now find themselves struggling for training time in Lake Placid for the 1980 Winter Olympics.

title: Coffee Futures Curbed To Prevent a Squeeze
description: The usually quiet coffee futures market yesterday became the latest scene of a possible market squeeze by holders of large amounts of contracts calling for the delivery to them next month of coffee beans.

title: Davidson Under Heavy Barrage On His Return as Netminder
description: On the bulletin board in the Rangers dressing room, next to an old picture of Pete Stemkowski, hangs a brief poem entitled State of Mind. It begins: If you think you are beaten, you are. That is not the Rangers problem: they think they will win, but they don't.

title: Old Homes: New Focus For Building Supplier
description: BOISE, Idaho  The Boise Cascade Corporation, believing that the next decade will see a decline in the construction of new housing, its traditional field, is planning to focus on the maintenance, renovation and remodeling of old housing.

title: Phone Company to Let Banks Handle Its Bills
description: ALBANY, Nov. 21 (UPI)  The New York Telephone Company's customers soon will be unable to pay their bills where the comnanv sells phones.

EXBLACK PANTHER SEEKING NEW TRIAL

description: A twomonth investigation into the alleged neglect of artwork valued at more than $180,000 led yesterday to a musty storage vault on the Upper East Side.

description: IN John D. MacDonald's new bestselling suspense novel, The Green Ripper, the hero's great love is a woman with a compelling need for total  or almost total independence.

title: IRANIANS SAY IF AMERICANS ATTACK, ALL HOSTAGES WILL DIE ON THE SPOT
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 21  Students holding the United States Embassy and 49 Americans warned tonight that all hostages will be destroyed on the spot if the United States mounted any military action here.

title: Mrs. Thatcher Tells Commons Spy Harmed Nation
description: LONDON, Nov. 21  Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher told a silent and expectant House of Commons tonight that Anthony Blunt, the art historian who served as a Soviet agent during World War II, had caused considerable harm to his country.

title: News Summary
description: All hostages will be destroyed if Washington mounts any military action in Iran, students holding 49 Americans in the United States Embassy in Teheran warned, and they added that the embassy compound would be blown up. Millions marched through the capital, chanting faith in the Iranian revolution, proclaiming defiance of America and shouting Death to Carter! [Page Al, Column 6.]
