title: Katharine C. Balderston, 84, Dies; Professor Emeritus at Wellesley
description: Katharine C. Balderston, professor emeritus of English literature at Wellesley College and an authority on the literature of the 18th century, died yesterday in a nursing home in South Natick, Mass. She was 84 years old and lived at 49 Cottage Street in Wellesley.

title: Design Fair in 80 Is Planned for New York
description: YOU have international design fairs in Milan, Copenhagen and other European cities, but we don't have one here even though New York is the design capital of the world, said Dede Draper, the designer who unveiled City Hall exhibition Tuesday that officially started planning for New York's first annual design fair, scheduled for next fall.

title: Theft of Food Reported by 30 Schools in Last 60 Days
description: Food stored in the kitchens of New York City schools has become a popular 1 target of thieves, according to Leonard N. Sabatino, director of security for the Board of Education.

title: ESSAY Man On Dark Horseback
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21  I am harbinger of horror, Al Haig told the assembled White House staff as the Nixon Presidency was crumbling. That showed both a good grasp of reality and an aptitude for alliteration.

As the new Islamic century began, armed members of a shadowy Moslem sect tried to seize the holiest shrine of Islam  the Great Mosque of Mecca and its sacred Black Stone. In Pakistan's capital of Islamabad, soon afterward, a mob, believing the invaders to be nonMoslems defiling Mecca, surrounded the American Embassy, burned down its buildings and killed a Marine. In Teheran, a huge crowd gathered outside the seized American Embassy and shouted not just Death to the Shah! and Death to Carter! but also God is Great!

title: Nets Again Fail in 4th Period as Bird Paces Celtic Victory, 111103
description: BOSTON, Nov. 21  There was banner hanging from the upper seats of the Boston Garden tonight that the New Jersey Nets might have taken to heart, after their 111103 loss to the Boston Celtics had taken the wind out of a twogame winning streak.

title: Kerosene Blast Kills Worker
description: BRADLEY JUNCTION, Fla., Nov. 21 (AP)  A maintenance man was killed and another worker was badly burned today when a huge kerosene storage tank blew up at the Kingsford phosphate mine, spewing flames 50 feet in the air and setting off smaller explosions, the police said. Frank Tracy, a spokesman for the International Minerals and Chemical Corporation, which owns the mine and refining facilities, said the 50,000gallon tank exploded as workers were welding it. The victim was tentatively identified as Tony Coney, 22 years old.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 22, 1979

title: Technology
description: NEVER before in the 25year history of the data processing industry has there been such an acute shortage of computer programmers. In California, for example, the Security Pacific National Bank has put a $1,000 bounty on these most sought after of computer professionals. And the Con- necticut General Insurance Corporation recently rewarded employees who were successful in recruiting programmers with an ounce of gold and 3700. These examples are by no means atypical.

title: Jacobs, Jet Kicker, Chooses No. 1 for Jersey
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Nov. 21  Dave Jacobs has three good reasons for choosing jersey No. 1 and none of them has anything to do with winning the No. 1 placekicking job on the New York Jets.

title: 13 Million Italian Unionists Stage 4Hour Strike to Protest Inflation
description: ROME, Nov. 21 (Reuters)  About 13 million unionists joined a fourhour general strike today aimed at speeding Government action on inflation and unemployment.

title: GROMYKO IS OPPOSED TO ASSAULT ON IRAN
description: MADRID, Nov. 21 Andrei A. Gromyko, the Soviet Foreign Minister, today issued a veiled warning against the possible United States use of force in Iran.

title: Changing Housing As Families Change
description: WITH the traditional family husband at work, wife at home and two children making up only 7 percent of American households, to what extent are architects and planners responding to contemporary housing needs?

title: One Day of Security
description: Thankfulness is a relative state of mind. One can count a thousand material blessings or be glad just to make it through the day. The Thanksgiving holiday that started as a ceremony of gratitude for the fruits of the harvest and the miracle of survival has turned into a celebration of nostalgia and homage to an earlier way of life. For many of us, the day is a chance to affirm continuity, an occasion for holding onto traditional values, an opportunity to create one day of security and comfort in a troubling world.

title: Laker Coach Improves
description: TORRANCE, Calif., Nov. 21 (UPI) The Los Angeles Lakers coach, Jack McKinney, who was injured in a bicycle accident two weeks ago, was listed as improved and in fair condition today.

title: World News Briefs
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 21 (Reuters)  Thousands of sick and exhausted Cambodians, loaded in trucks and buses, began moving across the border into Thailand today headed for a camp built by the International Committee of the Red Cross.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Frank C. Nicholas, the man behind the planned sale of the BeechNut Foods Corporation to Nestle S.A. of Switzerland, seems to have no intention of resting on his laurels.

title: Dorothy Tiffany Burlingham, 88, A Noted Child Psychologist, Dies
description: Dorothy Tiffany Burlingham, a Manhattanborn child psychologist who became an associate of Dr. Anna Freud in the 1930's and a specialist in the relationship of twins and in the effects of war on children, died Monday at her home in Hampstead, London. She was 88 years old and had lived in London since 1938, when she fled Vienna with the Freuds to escape the Nazis.

title: Britain Names Industry Chief
description: LONDON, Nov. 21 (Reuters)  Keith Joseph, Britain's Secretary of State for Industry, announced today that a new chairman of the National Enterprise Board, the Government holding company, had been appointed. All the board's previous members had resigned after a Government decision to take control of RollsRoyce (1971) Ltd. from the board.

title: 13 Released Hostages Elect to Remain Silent To Protect Colleagues
description: WEISBADEN, West Germany, Nov. 21  The 13 hostages released from the United States Embassy in Teheran to.. night elected to show their concern for their colleagues left behind by refusing to answer any questions and having spokesman read a statement issued by their former captors.

title: Bankers Bar Pledge On Chrysler
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21  Prospects for legislation to aid the Chrysler Corporation were clouded today as two of the company's major bankers said they could not pledge that they would commit new credit to Chrysler, even if Congress approved $1.5 billion in Federal loan guarantees.

title: RushHour Traffic in Jersey Snarled by Suspicious Fire
description: Firemen battling a blaze at an autopainting shop yesterday In Carlstadt, N.J. Morning rushhour traffic on heavily traveled Route 17 was snarled for three hours as fire units from seven communities tried to control flames. The blaze fed on barrels of paint, lacquer and thinner as well as the gasoline from the exploding tanks of 35 cars in the shop. The state police arson squad began an investigation of the fire, described by officials as suspicious.

title: Short Interest on Big Board Down 4.9 Million Shares
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest fell 4.9 million shares in the month ended Nov. 15 to 49.6 million shares. The short interest for the yearearlier level totaled 39.5 million shares.

title: Kaiser Steel Ends Talks On Sale of Some Assets
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 21  The Kaiser Steel Corporation, which has lost money on its main business for 13 straight quarters, announced today that it had terminated discussions with Nippon Kokan K.K., Japan's secondlargest steel producer, for the sale of a substantial part of Kaiser's assets.

title: General Assembly Is Retired
description: Bertram Firestone's General Assembly, one of the top 3-year-olds this year and a son of the Triple Crown winner Secretariat, has been retired to stud, LeRoy Jolley, the colt's trainer, said yesterday.

title: Pacers Get Big Lead And Defeat Knicks
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 21 (AP) The Indiana Pacers, sparked by the longrange shooting of Joe Hassett, and the inside scoring and defense of Clemon Johnson, ran off 20 straight points in the first six minutes of the second quarter tonight and went on to beat the New York Knicks, 119108.

title: Shostakovich Author Responds to Criticism
description: Harper & Row and Solomon Volkov, author of Testimony: The Memoirs of Dmitri Shostakovich, have responded to criticism of the book in Moscow last week by the late composer's family and a group of Soviet musicians who challenged the book's validity. The issues in the international literary dispute involve money, music and freedom to Publish.

title: Film: Five Shorts From Appalachia:Portrait of a Region
description: THE documentary films that constitute the Film Forum's program are deceptively plain. These five shorts are the work of Appalshop Films, a nonprofit cooperative based in Whitesburg, Ky., and Appalshop's reputation as one of the nation's best regional film making concerns is well-earned.The value of its work doesn't lie in jazzy editing, or shrewd camerawork; its direction is generally matter-of-fact. This simple approach is applied to local people whose very presence on film is remarkable, and whose evident ease is a tribute to the film makers' talents. Appalshop's catalogue lists nearly 30 films, all part of the collective's efforts to assemble a living chronicle of its region. On the evidence of the Film Forum's installments, the cumulative effect of several such films is perhaps greater than the individual impact of any one. But even in small groups, these shorts make it clear that Appalshop is performing a valuable service and performing it well.The obvious standout on the Film Forum's "Appalshop: Films From Appalachia" program is "Nimrod Workman: To Fit My Own Category." The reason is Mr. Workman himself, a retired coal miner who has suffered black lung, shrunk down to 121 pounds, and somehow retained his vivacity and humor. Mr. Workman, apparently in his 70's when the film was released in 1975, likes to sing, and will make up a verse for any occasion. ("Any kinda beans is good beans . . ," begins one ditty.) He is seen singing and chatting and performing chores with the various members of his large family, and to each of these activities he brings a special spark. Chores, by the way, figure prominently in many of these films. So do samplers bearing homilies that the impoverished scenery seems to belie.Mr. Workman, in one memorable sequence, tries to repair his ramshackle house with a board that keeps falling down, while the soundtrack plays a song about mansions in the sky. There is considerable emphasis, here and in the other films, upon an unwavering optimism that life doesn't often seem to justify. One of the seamstresses who appears in "The Millstone Sewing Center" remarks that "everything we've ever needed has always been right here at our fingertips." Later, a closing title explains that Federal funding for the center was cut back in 1972, just after the film was made. The juxtaposition might seem ironic, were it not for the quiet tenacity with which that woman insists that God will surely provide."Waterground," the most recent of the Appalshop films (it was made in 1977) and the only one in color, visits a small, old-fashioned grist mill and Walter Winebarger, whose family has operated it for generations. It also visits a General Foods mill nearby, fully automated, and a place about which Mr. Winebarger has no curiosity at all. He contents himself with grinding natural flour, and with running something that, through no effort of his own, has become a tourist attraction. "People come from everywhere, really, to look at this old mill, to draw it and to take pictures," he says, sounding slightly baffled. "People just go wild over it. It needs painting, but people say just let it stand like it is, cause it's old . . . and that's what people are lookin' to go back to.""Judge Wooten and Coon-on-a-Log" is about a local contest for dogs. Each dog swims out to a log and is expected to dislodge an angry raccoon in record time. A man, who has been casually explaining the goings-on, says something about the region's peace and happiness at the end of the film, and the camera suddenly zeroes in on two animals snapping at each other. This is as close to direct commentary as the Appalshop films choose to come.

title: Chicago Police Briefly Hold Man As Suspect in Murders in Britain
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 21 (UPI)The police questioned a man partly fitting the description of the killer known in Britain as the Yorkshire Ripper early today, then released him.

title: A Lecture by Muhammad Ali: The Topic Is the Greatest
description: He folded his body into a blue plastic chair and scanned the sea of faces.

title: 2d Trial Ordered Over Tax Evasion in RareBlood Sale
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 21 (AP) Federal appeals court has ordered a new trial for a Florida woman convicted by jury of evading taxes on $87,200 she made in 1972 by selling her rare blood plasma.

title: Philharmonic: Bruckner's Ninth
description: ASYMPHONY conductor is like a professional linguist, who may speak many languages but speaks some of them more fluently than others. With conductors, the languages that must be mastered are musical styles, in their multifoliate varieties and endless dialects. Zubin Mehta, who speaks Bruckner as if to Vienna born, led the New York Philharmonic last night in the elegiac Ninth Symphony, of which he is

title: Israel Defense Minister Says U.S. Should Use Military Force in Iran
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 21  Defense Minister Ezer Weizman today called for American military intervention to free the hostages in Iran and said he had concrete ideas on how to do it and would tell Washington if asked.

title: Calendar of Events
description: Winter Antiques and Crafts Show, Hotel Prince George, 28th Street between Fifth and Madison Avenues.

title: Bridge:
description: CINCINNATI, Nov. 21  A partner ship from the Middle West led the standings at the halfway stage of the Blue Ribbon pair championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals tonight. Pacing the field of 120 pairs were Tom Hodapp of Cincinnati and Norman Fischer of Columbus, Ohio, with 572.6 points.

title: Deadly Blizzard Paralyzes Parts of 3 States in West
description: By The Associated Press

title: Soccer Tea Men Seeking New Rhode Island Home
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 21 (UPI)  The New England Tea Men of the North American Soccer League are shopping for a new home  in Rhode Island.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Volatile Silver Is Down; Gold and Copper Strong

title: CORRECTIONS
description: CORRECTIONS

title: Giants'
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 21  It's become a weekly thing now, Ray Perkins announces that Ken Johnson and Doug Kotar are his starting running backs and Billy Taylor wonders why. Taylor says he thinks it is because the Giants coach doesn't like me.

title: Design Notebook
description: ABOUT this time each year, youngsters at one Manhattan school take a minicourse in house construction. The children build homes and decorate them, and then they eat them. Gingerbread houses, of course.

title: The U.N. Today
Orders for Durable Goods Off
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) New factory orders for durable goods slipped 4.2 percent last month, in sharp contrast to a 5.4 percent upsurge in September, the Government reported today.

title: Operetta: Sousa's The Free Lance,
description: PHILADEPHIA, Nov. 21  The curtain at the Academy ofMusic had n drawing of JohnPhilip Sousa on it, the beautifulold house was festooned with Ameri-can flags, and the set itself had Americanflags all over it. That was strange, because the locale was supposed to be the countries of Braggadocia and Graftania. The occasion was a performance of Sousa's operetta The Free Lance, and the idea was to point up the Americanism of the man who wrote America's greatest marches. But it did not work very well, and this directorial jingoism only detracted from the sweet, innocent little work  a work, by the way, that is as American as Gilbert and Sullivan.

title: OPEC Increase Is Predicted
description: VIENNA, Nov. 21 (AP)  Humberto Calderon Berti, Venezuela's Energy Minister, said today that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries would raise oil prices next month at its meeting in Caracas but that payments would continue to be made in dollars.

title: Yale Steel Plans To Close Soon
description: WALLINGFORD, Conn., Nov. 21 (AP) The Yale Steel Corporation laid off most of its 240 employees today and announced that it would close in a few days.

title: Synthetic Crude Plant Set
description: CALGARY, Alberta, Nov. 21 (Reuters)  Shell Canada Ltd. said today that it planned to build a $297.5 million refinery near Edmonton, Alberta, that would be the first to be used exclusively to process synthetic crude from oil sands. The company said that the refinery would produce gasoline, stove oil, diesel and jet fuel.

title: Todd Wieseneck Weds Linda Schoen in Jersey
description: Linda Susan Schoen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Schoen of Livingston, N.J., and Todd Jay Wieseneck, son of Marilyn Wieseneck of New Milford, N.J., and the late Norman H. Wieseneck, were married yesterday at the New Milford Jewish Center. Rabbi Harold D. Halpern and Cantor Leonard Rieter officiated.

title: LEGISLATORS UNITED ON CARTER'S ACTIONS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 Members of Congress united in support of President Carter's handling of the Iranian crisis today and warned of military reprisals if the hostages in Teheran were harmed.

title: Troops Rescue 100 in Islamabad; U.S. Offices Are Burned in 2 Cities
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 Hundreds of Pakistanis, apparently inflamed by inaccurate broadcasts, stormed and partly burned the United States Embassy in Pakistan today, killing a Marine guard and trapping 100 persons for five hours in a vault. They were rescued by Pakistani troops as thousands of Moslem demonstrators milled about outside.

title: ABC Drops Plan to Buy Macmillan
description: In a surprise turnabout, the American Broadcasting Companies yesterday abandoned plans to acquire Macmillan Inc., just nine days after the boards of both companies gave their goahead to the merger agreement.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: Dollar Slips, Gold Gains Amid Confusing News

title: Less Building Seen for 1980
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (Reuters) The Commerce Department said today that it expected real spending on new construction to decline about 9 percent next year.

title: Taking Tougher Stand
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21  The Carter Administration raised the possibility of military action against Iran yesterday only after senior White House officials became concerned that Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini had seriously misread their

title: US. Editor Had Key Role in Shaping Book on British Spies
description: The British book that caused Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher to identify Anthony Blunt, former curator of the Queen's art collection, as a onetime Soviet spy, was based on information he obtained from American intelligence sources.

title: Richard Florsheim, 63; Painter of Urban Scenes
description: Richard A. Florsheim, a painter and lithographer noted for his paintings and prints of urban scenes, died Tuesday of a coronary arrest at Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago. He was 63 years old and lived in Chicago.

title: Parents'
description: AMERICUS, Ga., Nov. 21 (AP)  A parents organization has filed a suit contending that control of the schools here should be taken away from local officials because they refuse to spend enough money to provide a good education for the students, most of whom are black.

title: Scraps From History's Table
description: LONDON

title: Money
description: WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 21, 1979

title: Piano: Atamian Plays Rite of Spring
description: MANY years ago, Igor Stravinsky formed a piano solo from three movements of his ballet Petrouchka, dedicating it to Arthur Rubinstein. It became one of that pianist's famous showpieces and a challenge to the virtuosity of later generations of pianists. Now Sam Raphling, the American composer, has transcribed Stravinsky's subsequent ballet, The Rite of Spring, for piano in its entirety. It was given its premiere on Monday night by Dickran Atamian, the gifted former Naumburg winner, in recital in Carnegie Hall.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Carey, Fink and the Oil Veto
description: Personal disagreements as well as political ones were responsible for the Assembly's overwhelming rejection on Tuesday of Governor Carey's vetoes of two bills to help the needy with their heating bills.

title: Trudeau Resigns as Party Leader; Calls for March Vote on Successor
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 21  Six months after his defeat as Prime Minister, Pierre Elliott Trudeau announced today that he was stepping down as leader of the Liberal Party and called for a convention next March to elect a successor.

title: 24 Debutantes Presented
description: Twentyfour provisional members of the Junior League of the City of New York were honored last night at the league's 31st annual Thanksgiving Eve Ball in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza. The young women, all college freshmen, were presented to Mrs. E. Ward Smith, the league president, and to Mrs. Stewart B. Clifford, chairman of the ball committee. Proceeds from the event will go to the league's Community Services Trust Fund.

title: Iranians Are Rebuffed In Their Bid to Crash Arab League Meeting
description: TUNIS, Nov. 21 Three uninvited visitors from Iran tried to crash the Arab League summit conferekce here today as delegates took up discussion of the situation in southern Lebanon.

title: Holiday Closings
description: Banks, stock exchanges and commodity markets in the United States will be closed today, Thanksgiving Day.

title: Rangers Bow to Jets, 64
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Nov. 21 The Islanders ran into a hot goaltender tonight  their own. But even though Glenn Resch stopped 41 shots by the Minnesota North Stars, he only deadened the pain. The Islanders lost, 31.

title: Associated Press
description: CHEMICAL FIRE CLOSES SAN FRANCISCO BRIDGE: Acrid smoke bil- lowing from a warehouse containing explosive chemicals near a ramp to the San FranciscoOakland Bay Bridge. The bridge was reopened after firemen controlled the blaze and determined that there was no threat of an explosion.

title: Home Beat
description: IT took Elaine Louie, at left, six months to research The Manhattan Home Furnishings Shopping Guide (Collier Books, $5.95.) 1 walked by day and wrote by night, went from south to north, from east to west, said the tireless Miss Louie, who hassled in Chinese in Chinatown, and in Yiddish on the Bowery and on Grand Street. The San Franciscoborn journalist, who came to New York in 1970, said her idea was to prove that you can get fabulous things without going to decorator showrooms. Mark Strong, the interior designer, and friends in and close to the decorating trade were consultants. She visited 291 shops, finding secret sources  artisans, antiques stores and out-of-the-way shops. If you deal with fine sources, you're dealing with passionate peopie, she said.

title: Hers
description: ONE bright blue day this autumn, on the corner of 46th and Broadway, near the heart of the Xrated underwear and film center of the universe, two street musicians were playing to a large receptive crowd. One played a zither, the other (when his strings weren't popping loose) played a guitar and both of them, like most of the audience, could be summed up as being more or less on the skids. But if misery loves confirmation, wasn't showing up in the songs being requested. Over and over again, people were asking for Grated tunes full of waltztime optimisni about couples on twoseater bicycles, wearing tulips, down by the old mill stream.

title: Dance: Living Pictures
description: ALTHOUGH the two theater pieces presented Tuesday night at the Open Space in SoHo were stylistically different, each could be described as a set of living pictures.

title: ORVILLE H. MANN SR.
description: Orville H. Mann Sr., former senior partner of the law firm of Mann & Mann in Nyack, N.Y., where he had practiced 48 years, died Monday at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 73 years old. He moved from his native Nyack to Boca Raton, Fla., when he retired recently. .

title: Sound
description: THE following succinct and wellreasoned letter was received by this department: In his column for October 25, Hans Fantel misses an important point regarding deluxe stereo systems which carry fourfigure price tags, compared to mediumpriced and budgetpriced systems costing substantially less. It may be true, as Fantel claims, that mediumpriced systems offer the buyer the best cost/performance ratio, but it is not the case  as he seems to imply  that deluxe systems offer little or no performance advantages over the mediumpriced alternative.

title: U.S. Radio Expansion Thwarted at World Parley
description: The United States has been experiencing some setbacks at the World Administrative Radio Conference in Geneva in its efforts to expand its share of the world's broadcast frequencies for governmental and scientific use, and also to meet the growing demands of the exploding communications technologies.

title: Alice Finkel Becomes Bride Of Brian Markinson, Student
description: At the Manhattan Beach Jewish Center in Brooklyn last night Alice Finkel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Finkel, became the bride of Brian Markinson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Markinson. Both families live in Brooklyn. Rabbi Seymour Leibler performed the ceremony.

title: Associated Press
description: INDEPENDENT ENDEAVOR WINS TRANSOCEANIC RACE: The 62foot ketch, Independent Endeavor, arriv- ing In Freemantle, West Australia, yesterday after sailing 11,000 miles from Plymouth, England. Skippered by Skip Novak, a 26year old American, the craft outsailed a fleet of 29 yachts in the annual Plymouth to Freemantle Parmelia Yacht Race, which commemorates the arrival of West Australia's first settlers in 1829.

title: Associated Press
description: BALLERINA CELEBRATES A BIRTHDAY: Natalia Makarova of the American Ballet Theater cutting a cake with the dancer Mikhail Baryshnikov, who is a fellow defector from the Soviet Union. Miss Makarova was 39.

title: Chicago Mayor Warns Carter Administration Not to Punish Her City
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 21  The Mayor of Chicago and the Secretary of Transportation continued their feud over politics and Federal funds today, with the Mayor warning the Carter Administration not to punish the city because of her support for Senator Edward M. Kennedy, and the Secretary pleading misinterpretation. Neither was speaking to the other, and the White House was making no comment.

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE
description: BULKY sports equipment is hard to store, but there are several items available that are especially suited to tackle the problem. The Sears catalogue has a gym bin, a chromeplated oneinch tubular steel spring/tension pole that fits ceiling heights up to 9 feet 2 inches. It comes with one double hook that can hold a tennis racquet handle or a bat, and two single hooks for skates, helmets and mitts. The hooks are about 8 inches long. A blue vinyl bin 31 inches high and 12 inches in diameter at the bottom of the pole holds things that cannot hung up, such as balls, shoes and bats. The gym bin costs $14.99. Extra hooks cost $1.99 for a package of two single hooks and $1.99 for one double hook. Shipping and tax are extra.

title: Iranian Pilgrim Tells of Mecca Attack
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 21 The raid on the Grand Mosque in Mecca, the holiest site in the Moslem world, was led by a man who had been wandering about Mecca for several days claiming to be the Twelfth, or Hidden, Imam of the Shiite branch of Islam, according to an Iranian pilgrim who observed the assault.

title: Talking Business
description: with Lelan F. Sillin jr. of Northeast Utilities

title: A Long Island Family Grieves
description: SELDEN, L.I., Nov. 21The Marine Corps representatives arrived here at 9 A.M., well before the pack of reporters and photographers seeking interviews with the family of Cpl. Steven J. Crowley, 20 years old, who was killed today when an angry crowd stormed the United States Embassy in Islamabad, Pakistan.

title: Home Improvement
description: This is the second of two articles on hanging wall coverings. The first, which appeared last week, described preparation and measuring tech- niques, and told how to paste, fold and hang the first strip.

title: Notes on People
description: Although he's been trying for eight years to find D. B. Cooper, who pulled off something of a criminal first on Thanksgiving Eve, 1971, Ralph Hlmmelsbach says be's not discouraged. It hasn't been frustrating, said Mr. Himmelsbach, a Federal Bureau of Investigation agent in Portland, Ore. It has been fascinating.

title: Letters
description: To THE HoME SECTION:

title: Premier Stuns South Africa by Moves to Relax Apartheid
description: JOHANNESBURG, Nov. 21  Under the influence of army generals who advocate changes in racial policy as a hedge against revolution, Prime Minister P. W. Botha of South Africa has stunned his Afrikaner constituency with a welter of speeches across the country in recent months that have questioned some of the fundamental tenets of apartheid.

title: RCA Will Launch 3d Domestic Satellite
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) RCA American Communications Inc., a unit of the RCA Corporation, was given authority by the Federal Communications Commission yesterday to launch its third domestic satellite for television transmission.

title: A Thanksgiving Day For Elston Howard
description: TEANECK, N.J., Nov. 21  His face is puffed from the cortisone pills he must take, but Elston Howard is not complaining. He remembers the day late last May when his forehead suddenly was damp with a cold sweat. He had been recuperating since February from a virus that had inflamed the muscles around his heart. Too ill to resume his role as a Yankee coach, he had spent six weeks in Lenox Hill Hospital, then in May he

title: Books of The Times
description: CLOSE TO HOME. By Ellen Goodman. 251 pages. Simon & Shuster. $9.95.

title: First Haitian Concert Hall Opens Today
description: A special concert and dedication ceremony today will celebrate the completion of the first concert hall and music school in Haiti, in Port-auPrince. The project is the result of a 25year effort by Sister Anne Marie Bickerstaff, a missionary nun, to establish a symphony orchestra and music training center.

title: Rock Band: The Jefferson Starship
description: EVALUATIONS of rock bands that have been around for a long time and have undergone drastic personnel changes tend to be pretty subjective. Take the Jefferson Starship, whose latest configuration, with only one member of the original Jefferson Airplane, performed at the Paladium on Tuesday evening. Most of the band's fans will undoubtedly miss the vocalist Grace Slick, who lent the music much of its flavor from the mid1960's until this year, and others will insist that the group has never been up to par without its other distinctive vocalist, Marty Balin.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: A-T-O Inc., Willoughby, Ohio, a maker of industrial equipment, has formed a New York Citybased licensing division and named William F. MacMullen president.

title: Opera: Kness as Don Jose
description: RICHARD KNESS, who appeared in Carmen for the first time at the Metropolitan Opera on Tuesday night, is neither the best nor the worst of the five tenors who have been heard as Don Jose since James McCracken quit the company last season.

title: Moscow Rumor Mills About Kremlin Shifts Grinding Once Again
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 21 A spate of rumors has descended on Moscow as the Communist Party's Central Committee prepares to meet next week in its usual secrecy.

title: A Security Guard Is Fatally Shot; Russian Roulette Theory Studied
description: YONKERS, Nov. 21 (AP) A security guard who may have been playing Russian roulette shot himself to death in an insurance office here as a horrified coworker looked on, the police said.

title: Dance: Benitez Troupe
description: Dance: Benitez Troupe

title: Stage: 6Week Celebration of OneActers Opens
description: A ONEACT play can be an undernourished dramatic idea an imp that never grew up or it can be looseleaf pages from a longer work in progress. Ideally a oneact play should be a self-contained piece of theater, no longer than it need be, and unembarrassed by its brevity.

title: Toys, Canned Pumpkin and PeptoBismol Recalled
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (UPI)  The Consumer Product Safety Commission announced the recall today of more than 400,000 stuffed toy mobiles after the death of a baby girl who strangled when she became entangled in the plastic cords that suspend the toy.

title: MSGR. A. P. JANNARONE
description: Msgr. Augustine P. Jannarone, former assistant pastor of the Church of St. Theresa of the Infant Jesus in the Bronx, died Monday at a nursing home in Middletown, N.Y., at the age of 101.

title: The Region
description: WHITE PLAINS  A 41-year-old Hastings-on-Hudson man was indicted yesterday in the murder of a Westchester County policeman who was serving a courtordered eviction notice.

title: Elyse L. Moscot Is Married
description: Elyse L. Moscot, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joel Y. Moscot of Great Neck, L.I., and Andrew C. Scherk, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Scherk of Woodmere, L.I., were married yesterday. Rabbi Judah Cahn performed the ceremony at the Regency Hotel. The bride, a spe- cialeducation teacher in Franklin, Mass., and her husband, an account manager with the NCR Corporation in Providence, R.1., are graduates of Boston University.

title: Jazz: Dick Cone's Band
description: ALTHOUGH the main point of rehearsal band is to rehearse, few of them have the crisp, clean, fully realized attack of the 17piece group that Dick Cone leads on Tuesday evenings at the West Bank Cafe, Ninth Avenue at 42d Street.

title: Jehovah's Witness Is Still Weak After Artificial Blood Transfusion
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 21 (UPI) A 67yearold Jehovah's Witness who received the first transfusion of artificial blood in the nation last week was reported to be weak today but stable and improving.

title: Letter: On Inflation and Tax Cuts
description: To the Editor:

title: Dr. Max Deutscher, 63, Manhattan Psychologist
description: Dr. Max Deutscher, a Manhattan psychologist and psychoanalyst, died Tuesday of complications following surgery at University Hospital of the New York University Medical Center. He was 63 years old and had homes in Manhattan and East Hampton, L.I.

title: Virginia Supreme Court To Hear Plea by Lesbian
description: RICHMOND, Nov. 21 (AP)  The Virginia Supreme Court has agreed to rule on the case of a lesbian denied parental rights to her son because of her way of life.

title: Kennedy, Campaigning in New Hampshire, Offers His Own Energy Plan
description: MANCHESTER, N.H., Nov. 21 Senator Edward M. Kennedy campaigned through the cold hills of New Hampshire today, delivering his harshest attack to date on President Carter's energy policy and offering a detailed alternative proeram of his own.

title: Student Designers Face Up to Reality
description: WE have an opportunity to do something here that was done only once before  at the Bauhaus, said David C. Levy, executive dean of the Parsons School of Design. Recall- ing the esthetic collaboration of the famous Weimar school of art and architecture, Dean Levy said the the goal of the new Design Resource Center at Parsons is to provide a meeting ground for young talent and massmarket manufacturers.

title: Cellist: Richard Sher
description: GENERAL excellence is what is expected of the principal cellist in an orchestra, and that is the kind of playing Richard Sher provided in his program in Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night. A former principal cellist with the St. Louis Symphony, he now holds a similar position with the Brooklyn Philharmonia.

title: The Military Choices: Full of Obstacles
description: Military action against Iran would present the United States with difficult choices. And these would be compounded by problems of sustaining deliveries of ammunition, fuel, food and equipment.

title: Skipat Is Victor by a Neck In Stakes at Meadowlands
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. Nov. 21  Carrying top weight of 120 pounds, John A. Grondin's homebred Skipat gained her eighth victory in a dozen starts this year in capturing the $54,000 Miss Liberty at the Meadowlands tonight. The 5-year-old daughter of Jungle Cove paid $9.20 for $2 to win.

title: Sharp Decline in Sales Of Home Heating Oil Is Reported by Dealers
description: BOSTON, Nov. 21  Oil dealers in the nation's two coldest regions report that their customers are buying sharply reduced amounts of home heating oil as the winter heating season begins with substantially increased prices and fears of shortage.

title: WRITERS CHALLENGE CONTROLS IN PEKING
description: PEKING, Nov. 21  After a hesitant start, many of China's writers, artists and professors have joined in a debate with the nation's leaders over how much creative freedom they should have and whether their work must be limited to serving the Communist Party's interest.

title: Guide
description: RIGHT THIS WAY Many workers in the Times Square area enjoy a lunchtime break in the Bryant Park acreage behind the New York Public Library, but the public seldom has reason to step inside an impressive structure nearby, facing the south side of the park. The sleekly Gothic AmericanStandard Building, formerly the American Radiator Building, is a 21story tower with a gold terra cotta top, midblock between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas. Erected in 1924, the landmark structure was Raymond Hood's first major building in New York.

title: HAROLD A. L. LAWRENCE
description: BIDDEFORD, Me., Nov. 21 (AP) Adm. Harold A. L. Lawrence of Saco, a former Navy legal officer and Congressional aide, died yesterday in a Biddeford hospital. He was 78 years old.

title: Television
description: Olivia Walton worries about a son, reported missing in World War II, on The Waltons at 8 P.M. on CBS.

title: Scandal at Japan's Phone Giant; Scandal Embroils Japan's Phone Giant
description: TOKYO, Nov. 21  The luggage of the three executives disgorged jewels, wristwatches, earrings, pendants and pens  a $16,000 cornucopia of gift items bought at the London branch of the Mitsukoshi Department Store and elsewhere in Europe, and all undeclared.

title: Fishing Town in Texas Tells the Klan to Stay Away
description: SEADRIFT, Tex., Nov. 21 (AP)  The City Council of this troubled fishing community has issued a stay out plea to Ku Klux Klan group from Louisiana, which has announced plans to demonstrate here Saturday against the presence of Vietnamese refugees.

title: JULIET B. THROCKMORTON
description: Juliet Brenon Throckmorton, a stage and screen actress in the 20's, and widow of Cleon Throckmorton, a noted stage designer who worked closely with Eugene O'Neill, died Sunday at the Cabrini Medical Center. She was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Return of the Rustics
description: Page C8

title: Brascan's Results Are Sharply Lower
description: Brascan Ltd., a Canadian holding company, reported a sharp decline in thirdquarter net income yesterday. It said income for the period amounted to $11.8 million, or 43 cents a share, compared with $28.1 million, or $1.06 a share, in the comparable quarter last year, which included $26.4 million, or $1.01 a share, from discontinued operations.

title: ABROAD AT HOME Dealing With Terror
description: BOSTON, Nov. 21  From the start, Washington has ruled out a military operation to rescue the American hostages in Iran. The experts said it would not work. Why, then, did President Carter decide to move an aircraft carrier toward Iran and to signal the possibility of some military action?

title: Village Strives for Growth With Character
description: TIVOLI, N.Y.  Sound of Spirit, a 2-year-old daughter of Secretariat, stood quietly behind new wooden fences nibbling grass on a hill overlooking the Hudson River here with the Catskill Mountains outlined against the sky to the west.

title: Nonprofit Psychiatric Clinic in City Under Inquiry on Medicaid Billings
description: A New York City psychiatric clinic criticized by the state in September for billing Medicaid for consultations as brief as 30 seconds is again under investigation because of allegations that many of the sessions might never have been held.

title: U.S. TELLS IRANIANS TO HEED WARNINGS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 The United States warned Iran today that the latest American military moves should be taken seriously and said that Iran would be held strictly accountable if the 49 hostages in the American Embassy were physically harmed.

title: A Jury Acquits Writer Who Got Berkowitz Data
description: A freelance writer was acquitted of bribery charges last night in a case in which he had admittedly paid a New York City Correction officer for providing prison pictures and information about David R. Berkowitz.

title: On Beacon Hill, a Happy Man in the Dark
description: BOSTON, Nov. 21 (AP)  It took a court hearing, but Richard White has won the right to live without electricity in his apartment on Beacon Hill. The Boston Housing Court has dismissed a complaint brought against Mr. White by the Housing Inspection Department for having no electrical service in his apartment. Mr. White had the electric meter removed more than a year ago.

title: EARNINGS
description: Sears Net Down 9.8% Despite Policy Shift

title: The Centerpiece Needn't Dry Up as the Turkey Fades
description: WHILE Thanksgiving feasters are usually glad when the last of the turkey disappears, the floral centerpieces never seem to last long enough. But they can. Longevity will depend on the initial care the flowers receive the minute they arrive.

title: GEORGE R. PAYNE
description: George R. Payne, senior vice president of Janney Montgomery Scott Inc., stockbrokers, of Philadelphia, died Sunday of complications following surgery at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 67 years old and lived in Mount Kisco, N.Y.

title: Gasoline Supplies Drop
description: Gasoline supplies continued to decline last week, falling 5.2 million barrels to 212.7 million barrels, according to figures released yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

title: Beaths
description: ALTERCantor Israel. Inspiration to us all as teacher, composer, Hazzan. Rest in peace.

title: Baylor Chosen American League's M.V.P.
description: Don Baylor of the California Angels won a landslide victory yesterday in the voting for the most valuable player in the American League. And he did it without the controversy that beset last week's tie vote in the National League.

title: New Harrah's Link With Holiday Inns
description: RENO, Nov. 21 (AP)  Harrah's and Holiday Inns Inc. said today that they would present a revised merger agreement to their shareholders and to the Nevada gaming control authorities.

title: Idaho Congressman Flies to Iran And ExSenator Says He Will Go
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) A Congressman is in Iran and a former Senator has accepted an invitation to go there, both in connection with the seizure of American hostages in Teheran, but the State Department said neither was representing the United States Government.

title: World Gold
description: WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 21, 1979

title: The City
description: The football team at George Washington High School, which had $60,000 worth of equipment stolen last week, has a new benefactor a 1947 alumnus of the school.

title: Tomato Spraying Overruled
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Nov. 22 (UPI)  A Federal appeals court has overturned a judge's order permitting distribution of tomatoes illegally sprayed with the pesticide Orthene. Last Friday Federal District Judge James Carter granted two San Diego County growers, Ocean View Farms and Nagata Brothers, a temporary restraining order against a fourweek ban on marketing tomatoes containing traces of Orthene.

title: Garden Salute for a RedBlooded Boxer
description: He was the epitome of the club fighter, the boxer upon whom Sylvester Stallone based the movie Rocky. He fought in clubs so small you had to share the corner with your opponent, in arenas where there were no showers and where the dressing rooms were almost as big as a closet.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS Britain's Spy Serial
description: ARDMORE, Ireland  It may be that in Britain's present mood of economic gloom a scandal is just what the doctor ordered. The scandal occa- sioned by the unveiling of Anthony Blunt (until a few days ago Sir Anthony), art adviser to Queen Elizabeth II, as a former Soviet spy is the latest installment of a longrunning spy serial. It started with the flight to Moscow in the early 50's of diplomats Guy Burgess and Donald Maclean and continued with the similar flight of the socalled third man, H.A.R. Kim Philby. Mr. Blunt is described as the fourth man. One of the attractive aspects of the scandal is that most people believe that there are at least 50 other men who will bob up from time to time.

title: Air Controllers in France Decide To. Extend Their Work Slowdown
description: PARIS, Nov. 22 (UPI)  French air controllers decided today to extend their threeweek work slowdown at least through Monday, delaying flights at most airports.

title: Koch Pays Some Calls To Express His Thanks For Service on Holiday
description: Mayor Koch walked through the wards of a Bronx hospital yesterday, made calls on a Queens fire company and a Brooklyn precinct station and spoke to 200 people at a Brooklyn center for the elderly. He said he wanted to extend the city's thanks to municipal employees and volunteers who gave up their holiday to work on Thanksgiving.

title: Developer Proposes Office Building Above Approach to Battery Tunnel
description: A $100 million office building over the open pit of the Manhattan approach to the BrooklynBattery Tunnel that would substantially alter the skyline of lower Manhattan has been proposed by a leadine real estate develouer.

title: TV Weekend ABC Recounts Early Days of Beatles
description: THE prospect of a television movie about the Beatles is daunting. On the one hand, it seems too early. The Beatles are still very much with us, if only on old records or as musical influences. On the other, any pop treatment could very likely resemble a waxworks in the style of the stage production Beatlemania.

title: Hawaii Public Workers Will Vote On Pact Ending Monthlong Strike
description: HONOLULU, Nov. 22  More than 7,700 striking bluecollar workers on Hawaii's six major islands are to begin voting next week on a twoyear contract that would increase their average pay by 23.8 percent by July 1, 1981.

title: Obituary 5 -- No Title
Ruth Gordon and Lee Strasberg: Two Old Troupers Who Age Like Fine Wine
description: Lee Strasberg, her costar in the new film Boardwalk and her neighbor across the park, had strolled down to Central Park South for a late afternoon visit, and Ruth Gordon was apologizing for her messy apartment. What with galley proofs to a new book of memoirs to correct and suitcases from a recent trip to the West Coast to unpack, she simply hadn't had time to straighten up the living room. What's more, she had spent the morning at the Cornell Medical Center, gettin a little electricity put on my bum for a twisted nerve. Listen, age don't have anythin to do with it  it's just numbers anyway, said the irrepressible actress, dismissing her ailment in that familiar New England voice of hers. We were having a pillow fight during rehearsals for another movie I'm doing, and I just got carried away, and there it went voom, just like that.

title: SOVIET WARNS WEST ON NEW U.S. MISSILES
description: PARIS, Nov. 22  Although the volume has been reduced during this period of crisis for the United States in Iran, the Soviet Union has adopted an extremely sharp tone in its warnings to the European allies against accepting new American nuclear weapons in Europe.

title: Iran Says It Will Pay On Loans
description: LONDON, Nov. 22  Iran's central bank, in an apparent bid to take some pressure off foreign banks and governments that have been drawn into the IranianAmerican dispute, said today the revolutionary Government did not intend to repudiate its foreign debts.

title: A d'Amboise Dance Anniversary
description: The craggy good looks have scarcely changed since the 1950's, when Jacques d'Amboise stared out of New York City Ballet programs in the guises of gaspump jockey, Greek god and cowboy, and leaped across movie sets in Seven Brides for Seven Brothers and Carousel. But it is 1979, and tonight

title: Play:Angry Young Britain in Class Enemy
description: EVERYBODY'S going, includ- ing the lollipop man! cries the permanently infuriated ringleader of a group of unmanageable high school boys in Nigel Williams's Class Enemy. The ringleader, whose niclmame is Iron and whose looselimbed strut is as close to a film cowboy's as he can get it, hates absolutely everybody and is out to destroy absolutely everything.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 23,1979

title: Gangster Who Escaped Is Found Slain in Sicily
description: CATANIA, Sicily, Nov. 22 (UPI) Sicilian gangster who recently made daring escape from police custody was found murdered today.

title: Arabs Turn Down Beirut on Withdrawal of Guerrillas
description: TUNIS, Nov. 22  The Arab League's summit conference wound up today by rejecting the plea of Lebanon for a withdrawal of Palestinian guerrillas from its southern border region and endorsing instead the right of the guerrillas to a military presence there.

title: Moslems Demonstrate In Turkey at the Home Of American Official
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, Nov. 22  A large Moslem crowd demonstrated in front of the residence of the United States Consul General at Izmir on the Aegean coast today but there were said to be no casualties or material damage.

title: Cleveland Quartet Tonight
description: The Cleveland Quartet  Donald Weilerstein, Donald Salaff, Martha Strongin Katz and Paul Katz  will appear tonight at 8 at Alice Tully Hall in Lincoln Center, Broadway and 65th Street. The concert, which marks the quartet's 10th anniversary, will honor the 20thcentury composer Ernest Bloch, whose Quartet No. 2 is on the program. Also to be played are Mozart's Quartet in B Flat (K. 458) and Dvorak's Piano Quintet in A. (Op. 81), with Ruth Laredo as guest pianist. Tickets are $5, $7 and $10. Information: 3621911.

title: Discount Stockbroker to Add Commodities
description: Phone wires crisscross the Kelly green rug in the front office at the Source Securities Corporation. The smell of new wood desks pervades a side office. One floor below, an employee relocation specialist surveys responses to an advertisement for account executives.

title: Dance: Eiko and Koma Under Umbrella
description: AS everyone apparently agrees, dance is an art of movement. And most people would agree that some interesting dances can be crammed with movement. But one can also argue that another interesting kind of dance is a dance in which motion threatens to become motionless. The dances of Eiko and Koma exist on this edge between movement and stillness.

title: Britain Condemned by Zambia as Spineless Hyena
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Nov. 22  Foreign Minister Wilson Chakulya condemned Britain today as a spineless hyena. His condemnation came a few hours after 30 demonstrators, encouraged by 2,000 people shouting White pigs! and Kill the oppressors! scaled a steel fence outside the British High Commission here and lowered the Union Jack.

title: Louisiana Man Admits Holding Illegal Mexican Aliens in Peonage
description: MONROE, La., Nov. 22 (AP)  Connie Ray Alford owns a prosperous 300acre cattle and chicken farm at Truxno, a onestore village in the red clay hills just south of the Arkansas state line. He calls it Welcome Home Ranch.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS Dollar Firm In Light Trading
description: LONDON, Nov. 22 (AP) The dollar firmed against most major currencies today as money markets stayed calm despite concern over the situation in Iran and over antiAmerican demonstrations in Moslem countries.

title: Broadway
description: John Corry

title: FourHand Piano On a Bosendorfer
description: It is sometimes true, as the popular song has it, that the best things in life are free. One of them is a series of con- certs with pianists of the caliber of Ur- sula Oppens, AndreMichel Schub and Emanuel Ax. They or their colleagues

title: Darien Defense Stops Greenwich, 170; Connecticut
description: Darien won its first Fairfield County championship and closed out an undefeated season in the process by defeating Greenwich, 170, yesterday in Stamford.

title: Henny Youngman's Brother Dies
description: MIAMI, Nov. 22 (UPI)  Lester Youngman, brother of Henny Youngman, the comedian, died yesterday in North Miami General Hospital. He was 70 years old. Mr. Youngman was his brother's manager 35 years and the target of one of the comedian's favorite oneliners: My brother saw a sign Drink Canada Dry,

title: OPEC Increase Seen
description: VIENNA, Nov. 22 (Reuters)  Economic experts of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries today ended a nineday strategy meeting by recommending that petroleum prices be raised in 1980, official sources said.

title: Auctions
description: THE Americana sales each November at Sotheby Parke Bernet, Madison Avenue at 76th Street, are the year's largest of their kind at the auction house. And this year's, which takes place next Tuesday through Saturday, Dec. 1, is the largest ever held. There are 1,700 lots, filling nine sessions, all documented in two catalogues and including most categories of antiques and collectibles: Chinese export porcelains, silver, pewter, historical autographs and documents, prints, paintings, glass, furniture, quilts, scrimshaw, folk art and clocks. The top lots in the sale are three 18thcentury highboys that may sell for up to $50,000 each: a miniature flattop design, attributed to William Savery of Philadelphia; a Queen Anne bonnettop highboy crafted by Jonathan Brooks of New London, Conn., and a Chippendale scrolltop version carved in Pennsylvania after 1760.

title: Onondaga Tribe Appears to Win Autonomy Issue
description: SYRACUSE, Nov. 22  After years of disputes with nonIndian law enforcement officials, the Onondaga Indians appear to have won recognition of their claim to jurisdictional autonomy on the Onondaga Indian Reservation, about eight miles south of here.

title: Trade Study Discounts U.S. Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22  The Carter Administration should get little credit for improvements in the American trade and international payments accounts, the Congressional Budget Office said in a study.

title: Council of Europe Issues Appeal on the Hostages
description: STRASBOURG, France, Nov. 22 (Reuters)  Foreign ministers of 21 European countries jointly appealed to Iran today to release the hostages held in the United States Embassy in Teheran.

title: Dave Maloney Lost for Week
description: Dave Maloney, the Ranger captain, will be lost to the team for about a week because of a bruised knee, William Jennings, the club's president, said yesterday.

title: For Children
description: NEWARK MUSEUM THANKSGIVING FRIDAY PROGRAM, noon to 4 P.M., with art workshops and science demonstrations, movies and planetarium shows, kite and banner workshops, 49 Washington Street, Newark, N.J. Information: (291) 7336600.

title: IN THE NATION The Kissinger Campaign
description: IN THE NATION The Kissinger Campaign

title: Catalogues of Christmas Cheer
description: Tis the season to be poring over Christmas catalogues.

title: The Way of Dissent in Peking
description: The case of the young Chinese dissident, Wei Jingsheng, is rapidly becoming a human rights cause celebre. It is also becoming a cautionary tale. Peking may have given up Maoism-by-the-book but it certainly hasn't given up ideological discipline. The Chinese people are free to consent to official policy.

title: Forgotten 5 at Embassy Step Onto Center Stage
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 22  Until tonight, no one quite seemed to know who they were or how many. there were, or what they were doing inside the United States Embassy when it was invaded 18 days ago by Iranian students.

title: Bid
description: LAUREL, Md., Nov. 22 (UPI) Spectacular Bid, the Kentucky Derby and Preakness winner, will be flown to California in the first week of December to prepare for his 4-year-old racing

title: The Region
description: Two firemen received thirddegree burns early yesterday when the roof of a burning synagogue collapsed on them in Valley Stream, L.I. They were hospitalized in serious condition.

title: Hartz Mountain Drops Meadows Mall Plan
description: SECAUCUS, N.J., Nov. 21  An intense, twoyear struggle between two rival developers for rights to build a major shopping center in the Hackensack Meadowlands ended today when one of the competitors, Hartz Mountain Industries, dropped plans for a $1.25 million mall and office building complex.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Urges Foreign Regimes to Improve Security
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22  The Carter Administration las instructed American embassies around the world to undertake greater security precautions and has urged foreign governments to do all they can to protect American citizens and property from attack, according to State Department officials.

title: Argentine Plane Missing
description: BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 22 (Reuters) A plane carrying eight people, including two Argentine officials, is missing in the Beagle Channel area south of Tierra del Fuego, an air force spokesman said today.The plane was on a flight to Ushuaia on the Beagle Channel.

title: Ship Rammed in North Sea Port
description: WILHELMSHAVEN, West Germany, Nov. 22 (UPI)  The Indonesian cargo ship Lawanti rammed the Norwegian freighter Hitra in this fogshrouded North Sea harbor today, rupturing two of its gasoil tanks, the harbor police said. No injuries were reported.

title: Experts Say Iran Can Find Other Sources for Grain
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22  Iran's search for more grain to replace that usually purchased from the United States is expected to be successful, experts say, but only with some difficulty and at considerably more expense.

title: Thanksgiving Day Parade Is Still a Smash in 53d Year
description: New York was at its best and brightest yesterday as Macy's held its 53d annual Thanksgiving Day Parade and the city's population of children seemingly tripled overnight.

title: About Real Estate
description: Let's try a conversion in Queens, someone must have said a couple of years ago. As it turned out, that meant Elmhurst, a bustling and varied community of central Queens.

description: MANHATTAN

title: Candid Talk About Marital Equality
description: No two people are equal, Frances Lear said. One person has to be more aggressive, more dominant, more controlling, more successful.

title: Curtis, Free Agent Pitcher,. May Sign With Padres
description: SAN DIEGO, Nov. 22 (UPI)  John Curtis, a freeagent pitcher who posted a 109 record with San Francisco last season, is very close to agreement with the San Diego Padres, according to his agent, Jerry Kapstein. Curtis, a 31-year-old lefthander, had a 4.17 earnedrun average in 27 appearances, 18 of them starting assignments.

title: Issue and Debate Closed Adoption Records: New Challenges to Established Tenets
description: Karen TInkham, a 36-year-old Phoenix, Ariz., resident, made a phone call to another woman three years ago, asked a series of questions, listened carefully to the answers, and said, I have reason to believe I'm your daughter.

title: Optimistic Bush Fired Up,
description: WICHITA FALLS, Tex., Nov. 20 It's tough out there, George Bush keeps telling people. But he says that it is getting easier as he tries to persuade listeners that he and his Presidential campaign are taking off, just as Jimmy Carter did four years ago.

title: Lions Beat Bears, 200, In an Upset
description: PONTIAC, Mich., Nov. 22 (AP) The Detroit Lions, behind the passing of Jeff Komlo, a rookie quarterback, snapped an eightgame losing streak today with a 200 National Football League triumph over the Chicago Bears.

title: Ignatowicz Leads Union Into Playoffs; New Jersey South
description: Six players, led by Mark Ignatowicz, shared in the scoring yesterday as oncebeaten Union coasted to its ninth victory, 950, over Linden in a tuneup for its North Jersey, Section 2, Group 4 championship clash against Livingston next week.

title: Ford and G.M. Cut Back At German Subsidiaries
description: BONN, Nov. 22  The German subsidiaries of the Ford Motor Company and the General Motors Corporation, long sources of major profits for their parent companies, are becoming the first auto makers to show symptoms of a slowdown in West Germany's fouryearold auto boom.

title: Panel Predicts Mild Slowdown But No Recession for Bonn
description: BONN, Nov. 22  A West German panel of economic experts forecast today that the country's economy would slow down next year, but would remain in the best overall shape of any of the world's major economies.

title: Letters
description: TO WEEKEND:

title: Fed Warning On Members
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP)  Onetenth of the total bank membership of the Federal Reserve System might abandon the system if Congress does not enact legislation easing the terms of membership, according to Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.

title: 31 Summons Are Issued in Drive To Block Illegal Dumping in City
description: Thirtyone summonses for illegal dumping were issued by the New York City Sanitation Department from Nov. 1 through Nov. 15, according to Commissioner Norman Steisel.

title: Daylight Racing Card a Meadowlands Flop
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 22  Competition posed by holiday high school football games and patrons troubles getting to the track because of holiday traffic are among the reasons the Meadowlands will remain dark next Thanksgiving Day.

title: Change the Spot Market's Spots?
description: Bigger dollar signs than usual are appearing in the eyes of oil producers. Oil currently sells for $40 in the Rotterdam spot market even though OPEC's price is about $24. If the producers could find some excuse to shift oil from their contractual sales to the spot market, they would earn an extra $16 on every barrel. The $40 spot price also tells OPEC members that their contract price is too low. They could charge more and still have plenty of buyers.

title: GULF OIL SLICK STIRS NEW FEARS IN TEXAS
description: GALVESTON, Tex., Nov. 22 (AP) ribbon of oil leaking from the disabled (tanker Burmah Agate has washed ashore along Galveston Island, and scientists warned that its effect could be worse than last summer's slick from a runaway Mexican oil well.

description: Topics Masterful Advocacy; Politics as Usual

description: AFTER 94 years, Strider: the Story of a Horse has arrived on Broadway. The Chelsea Theater Center version of Tolstoy's classic allegory about a noble piebald opened Wednesday night at the Helen Hayes Theater after a sixmonth engagement at Chelsea's Westside Theater. Cast and concept are the

title: White Plains Routs Stepinac
description: Undefeated White Plains overpowered Stepinac, 448, and New Rochelle edged Iona Prep, 70, in traditional Thanksgiving Day games yesterday.

title: A State Radiation Plan Is Fought
description: Twentyseven members of the New York City Council called yesterday for opposition to a state legislative proposal that they said would eliminate the City Health Department's Bureau of Radiation Control.

title: Trolley Maker Agrees to Refund $40 Million to Boston Authority
description: BOSTON, Nov. 22 (AP)  The Boeing Vertol Company, which supplied Boston with trolley cars that the city's transit officials say work only half the time, has agreed to refund $40 million on its $53 million contract, Gov. Edward J. King has announced.

title: World News Briefs
description: PEKING, Nov. 22 (AP)  Vietnam today accused China of building up a huge concentration of troops in preparation for a new invasion and proposed an immediate ceasefire along their border.

title: U.S. Pledges to Maintain Presence in Islamic World

But he said that the United States had no intention of cutting back the American presence in the Islamic world because of the latest developments.

title: NEW U.S. WARNING ISSUED TO IRANIANS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22  The United States again warned Iran today that would be held strictly accountable for the safety of the American hostages in Teheran, and officials said the American concern was also relayed to the Soviet Union.

title: 6 Iranians Lose Jersey Bus Jobs
description: Six Iranian bus drivers have been dismissed from their jobs on bus lines in Hudson County, New Jersey, James LaFante, president of the Hudson County Bus Owners Association said yesterday.

title: Audubon and Gottschalk At Historical Society
description: Pleasures for the eyes and ears are offered this weekend at the NewYork Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, at 77th Street. An exhibition on the life and works of John James Audubon is on view through February. The show, in two installations, includes memorabilia of the pioneer ornithologist and more than 400 of his watercolors. In addition, the museum is presenting a view of New York City in Audubon's time (the late 1700's to mid1800's). Tomorrow at 2 P.M. there will be a free screening of two films  The Life and Work of John James Audobon and The Colonial Naturalist.

description: A month after an equipment failure at the automated Morgan Station in midtown Manhattan, the nation's largest postal operation, mail service in the New York metropolitan area continues to be marked by delays that are making life difficult for millions of people, from recipients of unemployment compensation to mail order businesses.

title: DISASTER PAYMENTS FOR FARMS ASSAILED
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP)  Agriculture Department records show that 46 farmers received a total of more than $10 million in disaster payments from the Agriculture Department in the last three years, according to documents released this week.

description: BRIGHTON, England, Nov. 22 (AP)  Chris Evert Lloyd strolled to a onesided victory in a $100,000 women's tennis tournament today, defeating Terry Holladay, 63, 61, for a place in the quarterfinals.

description: FOR the second time in less than a decade, the Whitney Museum of American Art has mounted a major exhibition devoted to the work of Andy Warhol. The new show, which occupies the entire fourth floor

description: Mitch Kupchak is ready to play again, and his return could bring relief for the struggling Washington Bullets.

The Crimson Tide has been No. 1 in the rankings since they were introduced a month ago.
