title: Sydenham to Begin Closing; Metropolitan Wins Reprieve
description: Koch administration officials said yesterday that they would begin within three weeks the long process of closing inpatient services at Sydenham Hospital in West Harlem. The procedure, they said, could take at least four months.

title: In the Safest City in the World
description: It is nine o'clock at night in Tokyo, hot and humid, and I am sitting in a park. A small park. Bushes, benches, gravel paths. There are children playing, a few students, lovers, a man with a dog. The park borders on a school of music, and I can near a sort saxophone, backed by a piano. The air is so

title: Ballet: Batucada Fantastica
description: Saludo a America Latina, a program presented on Thursday by the International Ballet of Caracas, now in its last week at City Center, started off with a new work by the company's artistic director, Vicente Nebrada, that seemed to have less to do with Hispanic arts or tradition than discos and male cheesecake.

title: Joseph Kaitz, Known As Docks Investigator For New York, Was 69
description: Joseph Kaitz, whose career as an investigator was capped by 15 years as the New York Commissioner on the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor, died Thursday at Mount Sinai Hospital after a brief illness. He was 69 years old and lived at 200 East 33d Street.

title: Patents
description: Maximum Solar Power

title: Earthauake in Colombia Kills 35
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Nov. 23 (AP)  A strong 90second earthquake rocked mountainous western Colombia tonight, killing at least 35 persons, injuring more than 400 and destroying scores of buildings, authorities reported.

title: RICHARD H. ROVERE OF NEVI YORKER DIES
description: Richard H. Rovere, who wrote some of the most penetrating and respected commentaries on American politics as a col. umnist for The New Yorker magazine, died yesterday of emphysema at Vassar Brothers Hospital in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. He was 64 years old and lived in Barrytown, N.Y., where he did most of his writing.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: SAUDIS SAY MOSQUE IS IN THEIR CONTROL
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Nov. 23  A Saudi Government official said today that security forces were in complete control within all areas of the Grand Mosque in Mecca, which was seized Tuesday by fundamentalist Moslems.

title: MOUNTBATTEN CASE BRINGS A CONVICTION
description: DUBLIN, Nov. 23  A 31-year-old Irishman was found guilty today of the murder of Earl Mountbatten of Burma on Aug. 27, and was sentenced to life in prison.

title: China Says 76 Quake Killed 242,000 People
description: PEKING, Nov. 23  The earthquake that hit Tangshan in northern China in 1976 killed 242,000 people and seriously injured 164,000, China said today. This is the first time China has issued an estimate of the extent of the disaster.

title: 2 U.S. Companies in South Africa Caught in a Dispute With Blacks
description: JOHANNESBURG, Nov. 23  Two American corporations that are among the biggest employers in the South African automobile industry have become embroiled in confrontations with their black labor forces that are at least partly rooted in pentup frustrations over apartheid, the official doctrine of racial segregation.

title: Bronze Statues Gleam Again
description: Some of New York Citys historic statues have doffed their coats of crusty green to reveal bodies of bronze.

title: Patricia Murphy, 74; Operated Restaurants In the New York Area
description: Patricia Murphy, who combined charm, talent and a taste for food into a career as a wellknown restaurateur who began in a Brooklyn basement, died yesterday at her home in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., after a long llness. She was 74 years old.

title: Standing Up for Chile
description: The tide of international criticism against Chile is rising once again, and United States private interests in that country may well be caught up in its backwash. Congressional critics are calling for an end to private United States bank lending to Chile in retalia- tion for the refusal of that country's Supreme Court to hand over to United States justice three high officials allegedly involved in the assassination in Washington of Salvador Allende Gossens's Foreign Minister, Orlando Letelier.

title: Fog Disrupts Travel, but Not the Christmas Shoppers
description: The New York Times/D. Gorton

title: Associated Press
description: TOWERING SHOT: Johnny Davis of the Indiana Pacers went high above Jeff Judkins of the Celtics during the first quarter of game last night at Boston. Celtics won, 118103.

title: Hooks Assails Connally's Affirmative Action Stand
description: Benjamin L. Hooks, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, has termed John B. Connally's critical remarks about affirmative action programs irresponsible and unreasonable. He has invited the candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination to a public or private discussion of those efforts.

title: How to Pay for the Mentally Ill
description: New York City's financial difficulties will become even more desperate unless the state pays more to care for the thousands of mental patients it has sent here. That's the grim message that Carol Bellamy, the City Council President, has been pressing Albany to heed. The same message is clear from the recent New York Times articles on the problem by Robin Herman and, Lawrence K. Altman. The state has work to do.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 16.

title: Music Comes to Brentano's
description: Schirmer Music, the 118-year-old sheetmusic and instrument store, has moved from 4 East 49th Street into the recently renovated and enlarged Brentano's bookstore at 586 Fifth Avenue, and a weeklong festival with music celebrities will formally launch the union.

title: New Documents Show Scientologists Plotted To Have Writer Jailed
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP)  The Church of Scientology plotted to get a New York freelance writer who criticized the church sent either to jail or to a men- tal institution, according to court docu- ments made public today.

title: Susan Weist Is Married To Laurence D. Wiley
description: The marriage of Susan H. Weist, director of food services at the NightingaleBamford School, to Laurence D. Wiley, head of the mathematics department at NightingaleBamford, took place at St. Thomas Episcopal Church yesterday. The Rev. John Andrew, assisted by the Rev. Gary Fertig, performed the ceremony

title: Firestone Unit Loses Swiss Labor Case
description: GENEVA, Nov. 23  The Swiss subsidiary of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company of Akron, Ohio, was ordered today to pay the equivalent of $1.6 million to three unions for breach of a contract covering 505 workers at a plant that it closed in northern Switzerland

title: St. John's Tops Polish Five
description: Curtis Redding scored 18 points to lead St. John's University to a 7865 victory over the touring Polish national basketball team last night at Alumni Hall, Jamaica. Wayne McKoy, a junior center, and David Russell, a freshman. each scored 16 points. Mieczyslaw Mlynarski tallied a gamehigh 24 points for the Poles who will conclude their tour tonight against Princeton. So far they have won five games and lost six.

title: Article 3 -- No Title
description: Associated Press

title: Elizabeth Sue Bober Is Bride Of Paul Polivy, Accountant
description: Elizabeth Sue Bober, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence H. Bober of New York, was married at the Harmonie Club yesterday to Paul David Polivy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Polivy of Glen Cove, L.I. Rabbi David Blumenfeld performed the ceremony.

title: Irate Zambian Youths Again Attack British Grounds
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Nov. 23  A crowd of about 2,000 youths rocked the British High Commission here today, uprooting plants and trees and tearing up a stone wall during the second demonstration against Britain apparently inspired by the Zambian Government in as many days.matic source said today. The statement was made right after Kaunda called for allout war and full compensation immediately. It just came like a quick message to shove off and it got everybody sore as hell.

title: Alternative to Darwin Asked for Florida Pupils
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Nov. 23 (AP) Florida lawmakers may soon have to decide whether public schools should be required to teach a Biblelike alternative to the theory of evolution.

title: Jones Able Sub for Jets
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 23  The Jets never expected that Bobby Jones would make fans forget Wesley Walker, the allpro wide receiver who is considered the most dangerous deep receiving threat in the National Football LeaRue. In the last couple of weeks. however, Jones has been doing a good job filling in for the injured Walker.

title: Celtics Set Back Pacers, 118105
description: BOSTON, Nov. 23 (AP)  Larry Bird scored 30 points tonight, the highest total in his brief National Basketball Association career, as the Boston Celtics recorded their ninth straight home victory tonight by defeating the Indiana Pacers. 11S103

title: COMPANY NEWS Penn Central in Pact To Buy Marathon
description: The Penn Central Company and the Marathon Manufacturing Company signed a definitive agreement yesterday for the acquisition of Marathon at the slightly reduced price that Penn Central proposed Wednesday following a jury award against Marathon and two other companies in a Federal Court Before

title: Mideast Aides Tell of Dangers to U.S. in Iran Conflict
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 23  The explosion of mob anger in Pakistan this week has brought home to Western diplomats and local officials in the Arab world the full dimension of the dangers inherent in the AmericanIranian conflict.

title: Hammond Is Feeling At Home as Redskin
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 23 Two plays, that's all he wanted from the Giants. Pitch left and pitch right. But Bobby Hammond is not angry at the Giants for making him a Washington Redskin. Maybe the Giants were stupid for letting him go, he said, but he won't be angry when he returns here Sunday.

title: Tender Report Made By Pier 1 Imports
description: Pier 1 Imports Inc. said that about 1.66 million of its shares had been tendered as of last Wednesday in response o an offer by Pier 1 Acquisitions Inc., a unit of Newcorp Inc. About 490,000 of Pier 1 Imports common shares remain mitstandin2. it said.

title: Soviet Says Rats on Space Trip Did Not Lose Weight and Mated
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 23 (UPI)  Scientist have concluded that weightlessness is neither an effective contraceptive nor a way to stay thin, Tass, the official Sov;ei press agency, reported today.

title: Alaska Has Problem: $1 Billion Surplus
description: ANCHORAGE, Nov. 23 (AP)  While old industrial cities hover on the edge of bankruptcy and inflation licks at local governments across the land, Alaska's Treasury is bursting with a spare $1 billion.

title: The City
description: A Brooklyn grand jury has found no criminal liability on the part of a policeman accused of assaulting a State Assemblyman during a clash between police officers and Hasidim at a police station in Borough Park a year ago.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 24, 1979
description: International

title: Banking World Puzzled Over Iran's Stand on Debt
description: LONDON, Nov. 23  The report that Iran intended to repudiate its foreign debt startled and puzzled international hankers here today and left them struggling to make sense of conflicting statements on the status of their banks loans to Iran.

title: A 3 1 -Year-Old Banker Is Appointed to Head New York Rent Board
description: Marvin Markus, an investment banker and former deputy commissioner of the New York City Department of Housing Preservation and Development, has been appointed chairman of the city's Rent Guidelines Board.

title: Merle Oberon, 68, Star of Films Including Wuthering Heights
description: Merle Oberon, the hauntingly beautiful star of Wuthering Heights and more than 30 other films, died yesterday afternoon at CedarsSinai Medical Center in Los Angeles after having suffered a stroke at her Malibu, Calif., home late Thursday. She was 68 years old.

title: Shortage of Nursing Home Beds Keeps L.I. Hospitals Full
description: WEST ISLIP, L.I.  The Christmas decorations are starting to go up in the halls and the rooms of Good Samaritan Hospital here, but for Marian Cooley, 75 years old, the sight does not cheer. It reminds her of the fact that she has been in the hospital almost since last Christmas, even though she was healthy enough to leave in March.

title: Iran Viewed as Loser in a Debt Default
description: If Iran has repudiated its foreign debt, as the Iranian foreign minister proclaimed yesterday, it is cutting itself off from obtaining any new commercial foreign credits and probably reducing its international commerce to a shambles, United States bankers and economists predicted yesterday.

title: Airwaves Talks Are Extended
description: GENEVA, Nov. 23  A conference being held here on allocating broadcast frequencies for future telecommunications needs has been extended, officials said today.

title: Money
description: FRIDAY. NOVEMBER 23. 1979

title: Texas International In Merger Revision
description: The Texas International Company and the NFC Corporation said that they had revised the terms of their previously announced agreement in princiI vie to merge.

title: Obituary 4 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Houston Triumphs, 1410
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 23 (AP)  Terry Elston, a secondstring quarterback, ran 72 yards for a touchdown with 11 minutes 21 seconds left to rally ninthranked Houston from a 100 third-quarter deficit to a 1410 victory over Texas Tech.

title: Changing U.S. to Metric Basis
description: Should the Government continue to endorse voluntary conversion from the United States customary system of measurement to the metric system if the public does not seem to want it? Is conversion an inevitability that needs no assistance from Federal agencies?

title: Antismoking Law Upset as Misleading and Ineffective
description: RICHMOND, Nov. 23 (AP)  The Virginia Supreme Court has thrown out a Newport News antismoking ordinance on the ground that although people in an open room can be segregated, smoke cannot.

title: Is the U.S. Provoking the Soviet?
description: MOSCOW  Uncertainty is not the best feeling for any family, be it American or Russian. Unfortunately, the Soviet people now feel great uncertainty about what content the United States Administration puts into this formula: We want good relations with the Soviet Union on the basis of rivalry.

title: Alaskan Oil Is the Public's Business
description: Gas lines and the vulnerability of foreign oil have focused public attention on synthetic fuels as one way to increase the domestic production of energy. But far more important decisions about future fuel supplies are being made out of the limelight. The Department of Interior is pressing ahead with offshore Alaskan oil and eas leases that could provide 4 to 5 million barrels of oil a day by the early 1990's  three times the target of the developing $100billion synthetic fuels program. These leases will be vigorously opposed in court by the Eskimos and some environmentalists who fear damage

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Jet Evacuated at Toronto
description: TORONTO, Nov. 23 (UPI)  Passen- gers were evacuated from an Air Ja- maica plane today when workers at To- ronto International Airport spilled fuel on the runway as they were loading the jet's tanks. No one was injured and the plane took off after a delay of 25 minutes.

title: Where Yaz Is Forever an AllStar, Honus Wagner Eternally Young
description: Thousands of baseball memorabilia collectors, many wearing jerseys with the numbers of their favorite players, lined up yesterday for a baseball card show in the auditorium of St. Paul the Apostle Roman Catholic Church on Columbus Avenue at 60th Street.

title: Obituary 3 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: L.I. Man Guilty In Effort to Steal Gear for P.L.O.
description: A Long Island engineer and businessman who describes himself as an adviser to the Palestine Liberation Organization was found guilty last night of trying to smuggle stolen communications equipment to the Middle East in the spring of 1978.

title: NEW GAS DISCOVERY IS MADE BY TEXACO OFF JERSEY'S COAST
description: Baltimore Canyon's Biggest Find Stimulates Fresh Speculation on Commercial Potential

title: Radio; Music
description: 7 A.M.Noon, WNYCFM. A special program of music for children. Gassenhauer, Orff ; Ah, vous diraije, Maman, Mozart; Variations on a Nursery Song, Dohnanyi.

title: Ad Hoc TV Networks Planning Assaults on the 3 Majors
description: There will be no period of normalcy for the television networks this season.

title: Fed Shift Detailed in Minutes
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. Li  reUeldl Reserve Board members in making the decisions last month that led to much higher interest rates were motivated to an unusual extent by international considerations  specifically the weakness of the dollar and generally unsettled conditions in the gold, commodity and financial markets.

title: Bernard Hoffinan, 66; A Photographer for Life
description: Bernard Hoffman, one of the original members of Life magazine's photographic staff and later owner of Bernard Hoffman Laboratories, custom photo finishers in New York City, died yesterday of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, at his home in Freehold, N.J. He was 66 years old.

title: IRANIAN NOW CALLS FOREIGN DEBTS VOID BUT EXEMPTS SOME; BANKERS ARE PUZZLED
description: TEHERAN, Nov. 23  Abolhassan BanffSadr, Iran's Economic and Foreign Minister, declared today that all foreign debts were repudiated, throwing into confusion Iran's policy toward its financial commitments.

title: Suit Bids Boys
description: BOSTON, Nov. 23 (AP)  If a suit be- fore the State Supreme Court succeeds, the Arlington Boys Club may have to change its name to the Arlington Boys and Girls Club. The Civil Liberties Union of Massachusetts filed the suit, which seeks equal access to the club for fe- males. It acted on behalf of the Arlington Committee to Promote Equal Oppor- tunity for Girls and Women.

title: Red Sox, Lockwood Agree on a Contract
description: Skip Lockwood, a former Met, and Rennie Stennett, who the Mets had hoped would be a Met, have made their freeagent decisions. Neither has chosen the Mets.

title: Chrysler May Get Japan Credit Again
description: TOKYO, Nov. 23 (AP)  Japanese banks are likely to resume in December the financing of the Chrysler Corporation's imports of motor vehicles made by Japan's Mitsubishi Motors Corporation, bank officials said.

title: Notes on People; TV Show's Producers Discover Their Real Person Isn't
description: They all laughed when Edward Ben Elson, who has to be one of the zaniest lawyers in Madison, Wis., if not the whole state, announced his candidacy for district attorney wearing nothing but a big smile.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yesterday's Weather et 1 P.M.: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration/UPI

title: Police Still Seek Leads in Killing Of an L.I. Youth
description: DIX HILLS, L.I., Nov. 23  The police reported no leads today in the slaying of 18-year-old John Donahue Jr., whose body was found yesterday in a marsh north of Kennedy International Airport.

title: Houston Council Expected to Assert Independence
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 23  Jim McComl. as expected, was elected Tuesday to his second twoyear term as Mayor of Houston. Somewhat less expected, perhaps, was the degree to which the face, and perhaps the substance, of the City Council was changed at the ballot box.

title: Nuclear Officials Jarred by Arrests Of Plant's Guards on Drug Charges
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 23  Managers of nuclear power plants were jarred early this month when II guards at the Portland General Electric Company's Trojan plant on the Columbia River were arrested by the Oregon state police and charged with dealing in marijuana, amphetamines, cocaine and LSD.

title: A Church Bell Appeal For Hostages Is Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23A Thanksgiving message from L. Bruce Laingen, the United States charg d'affaires in Iran, asked that church bells be rung throughout the United States to symbolize hopes of Americans held hostage for a peaceful resolution of the dispute and restored friendship.

title: OBSERVER Great Galloping Swamis
description: OBSERVER Great Galloping Swamis

title: Market Rises, Led By Defense Stocks
description: The stock market advanced yesterday in light trading. Defense, energy and computer issues led the way in the first gain after four declining sessions.

title: GROMYKO, IN BONN, WARNS ON MISSILES
description: BONN, Nov. 23  Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union tonight stepped up Soviet efforts to head off NATO's deployment of new nuclear weapons in Western Europe, warning that such a move could damage future talks on limiting such weapons.

title: Recital: Ana Maria Trenchi de Bottazzi, Pianist
description: Ana Maria Trenchi de Bottazzi is the Argentine pianist who returned to the concert stage after sustaining brain damage in a nearly fatal automobile accident. When this writer first heard Miss de Bottazzi two seasons ago, his main reaction was surprise that, under the circumstances, she could play so well. Hearing her last Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall, his main reaction was disappointment that she does not play better.

title: Ending Silence on Iran, East Germans Appeal For Hostages
description: EAST BERLIN, Nov. 23 For the first time since Iranian students occupied the United States Embassy in Teheran on Nov. 4, East Germany today expressed concern about the situation and published a call for the release of the American hostages.

title: New Play Clothes That Inspire Dreams Of Snow and Sun
description: I've done my share of sensible, responsible clothes, John Weitz told his audience at Doubles, a private club to which he belongs, the other evening. Now I'm showing some frivolous ones.

title: Koch Breaks Ground for a Peddlers Mart on 125th St.
description: Mayor Koch, recalling that his grandfather was a peddler in Poland at the turn of the century, broke ground yesterday for an enclosed market for street peddlers on the busiest commercial thoroughfare in Harlem.

title: ROY E. NORCROSS
description: WATERBURY, Conn., Nov.23 (AP) Roy E. Norcross of Cheshire, a Univer- sity of Connecticut professor and for 33 years New Haven County's agricultural extension agent, died yesterday at St. Mary's Hospital in Waterbury after a long illness. He was 77 years old.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last Monday incorrectly described Walter H. Annenberg's connection with TV Guide. Mr. Annenberg's company, Triangle Publications, acquired the magazine In 1953 from Lee Wagner, who established it in the late 1990's.

title: Car Total Up In Germany
description: FLENSBURG, West Germany, Nov. 23 (Reuters)  The number of new au- tomobiles and trucks registered in West Germany in October was 17.6 per- cent higher than in September, the fed- eral vehicles bureau said today.

title: Commonwealth Oil Sees End to Its Bankruptcy
description: The Commonwealth Oil Refining Company said yesterday that it might be out of bankruptcy proceedings, where it has been for 20 months, as early as next March or, at the latest, by the middile od 1980.

title: Florida State Stays Unbeaten
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., Nov. 23 (AP)  Orange Bowlbound Florida State completed an unbeaten regular season today with a 2716 victory over Florida.

title: United Press International
description: WOULDBE HIJACKER FOILED: Kazumi Nomura in custody of policemen yesterday at Tokyo's new international airport at Narita after his attempt to hijack a Japan Air Lines DC10 en route from Osaka to Tokyo was foiled. Mr. Nomura, carrying a bottle opener and a small plastic knife, demanded that the plane be flown to the Soviet Union. During a refueling stop, he was over- powered by the crew and passengers when he opened the door to the cockpit.

title: Defrosting Human Rights in the Senate
description: In 1965, the Senate somehow found the time to ratify the Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Relations. For that, Americans can now be thankful: it is the legal bedrock of the American case against the embassy seizure in Iran. Yet, shamefully, the Senate has never found time to vote on other covenants of a far broader scope addressed to the urgent concern for basic human rights  a concern that President Carter has called the heart and soul of his foreign policy.

title: The Region
description: RIVERHEAD, L.I.  The executive director of the Suffolk County Human Rights Commission pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges stemming from allegations that he ordered three county employees to help him build a patio at his home and kept a $700 paycheck overpayment.

title: Letter: On Breeder Reactors
description: To the Editor:

title: Balancing Act for Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 23The I attack two days ago on the United States Embassy here by students carrying photographs of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini underscored Pakistan's difficult balancing act: trying to preserve old ties to Washington while forging new links with Iran

title: Television; Morning
BUSINESS Digest
description: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 24, 1979

title: Dividends
description: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 23, 1979

title: Jazz: John Lewis's Group
description: Since the Modem Jazz Quartet broke up five years ago, John Lewis, who was the group's pianist and musical director, has been devoting most of his time to teaching at City College and composing. His public appearances have been infrequent and sometimes unannounced, as when he has filled in for his friend, Hank Jones, with whom he occasionally plays twopiano engagements.

title: Around the Nation
description: DETROIT, Nov. 23 (AP)  Robert F. Leonard, the Genesee County prosecutor for 16 years, was found guilty today of embezzling Federal revenuesharing money.

title: World News Briefs
description: ROME, Nov. 23 (UPI)  Pope John Paul II said today that his meeting with Patriarch Dimitrios I in Turkey next week was intended to further the cause of Christian unity between the Roman Catholic and Eastern Orthodox churches, split more than 900 years ago.

title: Backlash Against Caviar From Iran
description: Sales of Iranian caviar have declined sharply in New York in recent weeks, according to many of the city's leading caviar retailers. The drop is a result of public reaction to events in Teheran, they said.

title: SnowMelting Weather Postpones Ski Season
description: HUNTER, N.Y., Nov. 23  Continued unseasonably warm weather in the East, with temperatures in the mid 60's, has caused postponement of the official opening of more than a dozen major ski areas equipped with snowmaking machines. Only two resorts, Killington in Vermont and Waterville Valley in New Hampshire, were operating, but on a limited basis.

title: Teaching Children
description: The plume de ma tante didn't come up at the French Workshop for Children. And although there was some talk of a bol de Paul, any resemblance to boring and promptly forgotten French lessons ended there.

title: Refugees
description: In April 1975, only days before Cambodia fell to the Communist forces, a charter plane landed at the besieged Phnom Penh airport. It paused long enough, engines running, for the 23 baskets on the runway to be loaded into the hold. Each basket contained an orphaned Cambodian child. The plane took off for Bangkok, Tnanana, wnere the children were taken to Sue Morton, an American housewife and mother who cared for them until they were flown to the United States for adoption.

title: ANDREW J. MANGAN
description: Andrew J. Mangan, who was with the JohnsManville International Corporation 40 years and served as traffic manager and vice president, died Wednesday at Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan. He was 74 years old and lived at 410 East 57th Street.

title: 390 Americans Arrive Home From Pakistan
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) Some 390 Americans arrived home from Pakistan tonight after being ordered to evacuate following an attack on the United States Embassy in Islamabad two days ago.

title: Shipping/Mails; Outgoing
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Miller Cites Plans to Cut U.S. Oil Use
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Nov. a Treasury Secretary G. William Miller said today that he hoped recommendations for new energy conservation measures would be on President Carter's desk by midDecember, with a decision to come about a month later.

title: G.A.O. Critical On Oil Leases
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (UPI) The Government is inadequately monitoring Federal offshore leaseholders for assurance that gas and oil wells are pumping at peak efficiency and that gas is not needlessly burned off, a Congressional report said today.

title: Bargaining Talks Set for Monday In Strike by Legal Services Staff
description: A state mediator has scheduled a bargaining session for Monday in an effort to end a strike that has crippled service for the poor in civil legal actions in New York City since Nov. 14.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the last week. Answers appear on page 21.

title: Books of The Times To Plan, Perchance to Dream of Economics
description: CAPITALISM: Sources of Hostility. Edited by Ernest van den Haag. 206 pages. Epoch. Heritage Foundation. $9.95.

title: United Press International
description: EVERYONE LOVES A PARADE: Notre Dame's marching band entertaining Japanese children during parade through Tokyo yesterday. Fighting Irish will play football game against University of Miami tomorrow in Japan.

title: The Mets
description: When the baseball season opened in 1962, Ed Kranepool cut classes at James Monroe High School in the Bronx and went straight to the Polo Grounds. Hundreds of other 17-yearolds probably did the same thing that April afternoon, but not with Kranepool's style or opportunity. He was the guest of the new team m town, the New York Mets.

title: Bridge:
description: CINCINNATI, Nov. 23  Two young experts from Miami scored a convincing victory in the Blue Ribbon Pair Championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here last night.

title: U.S. Listens to Israeli Rescue Plan
description: TEL AVIV, Nov. 23  The American Embassy confirmed today that Ambassador Samuel W. Lewis interrupted his Thanksgiving holiday for sudden consultations with Defense Minister Ezer Weizman.

title: Waldheim Receives Report From His Aide in Teheran
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 23 Secretary General Kurt Waldheim re- ceived a report early today from Winston Prattley, a New Zealander who is the top United Nations official in Teheran and Mr. Waldheim's representative there, but a spokesman would not say whether the report contained a response from Iran to the proposal made by United Nations officials two days ago for the freeing of the American hostages.

title: Stars of Ballet to Appear in Gala for Dance Institute
description: Jacques d'Amboise, Mikhail Baryshnikov, Patricia McBride and other international dance stars will appear with a group of New York schoolchildren in a gala performance at the Felt Forum next May 25 to benefit the Na- tional Dance Institute. The institute, founded by Mr. d'Amboise in 1976, sponsors weekly dance classes for children at 29 schools in and around New York, including classes for deaf children.

title: U.S. SAID TO GIVE UP ON A HOSTAGE PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23  Government officials said today that after an extensive study of the problem, the Carter Administration had failed to come up with an acceptable military plan for freeing the hostages in Teheran.

title: Union Wins a Contract With Retailer in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23  The Retail Store Employees Union has organized the workers of Woodward & Lothrop, the department store chain, and is promising to continue its efforts at other stores here, including Bloomingdale's.

title: In Teheran, Friday Prayers Mix Politics With Theology
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 23  Soon after 9 o'clock this morning, Ashraf Lotfi Arabshahi kissed her sleeping 2-year-old son on the forehead, whispered instructions to her mother, who was keeping the *boy company and tending his cold, summoned her husband, Riza, and stepped out of their small apartment on Azadi Street.

title: 3 Sisters Die in a Fire in Brooklyn
description: Three young sisters died and a fourth was hospitalized in critical condition yesterday afternoon when a fire in a television set filled their Brooklyn apartment with smoke, the police said.

title: Events Today; Music
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Weill's Rise and Fall of the City of Mahagonny, 2, and Verdi's Aida, B. NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC, Avery Fisher Half, 8. SERAPHIM TRIO, 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue, 8

title: Your Money
description: Keeping an Eye On Liquidity

title: Doubts Mount on Chrysler Bill's Prospects
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23  Confident predictions by supporters of Federal aid to the Chrysler Corporation that the Administration's rescue package would sail through Congress this year have given way this week to growing doubts about the legislation's prospects, according to Congressional and Administration officials.

title: About New York
description: The office walls of Franklin Feldman, one of 46 partners in the supertankersized Wall Street law firm of Stroock & Stroock & Lavan, are strewn with art, as befits executive suites.

title: Networks Seek Review by F.C.C. Of PrimeTime Ruling on Carter
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (UPI)  The three commercial television networks have asked the Federal Communications Commission to reconsider its finding that they acted illegally in refusing to sell prime time to President Carter's re-election committee.

title: ARABS APPREHENSIVE ON U.S.IRAN DISPUTE
description: TUNIS, Nov. 23 With few exceptions, the Arab nations have resisted being drawn into the Carter Administration's confrontation with the Iranian leadership of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini over the seizure of the American Embassy in Teheran and the holding of hostages.

title: Advance Is Reported in Research On MutationCausing Chemicals
description: Researchers at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory have found that a substance called ethylnitrosourea, or ENU, causes 15 times more genetic damage in mice than any other known chemical.

title: Venezuela Sets OilPrice Rises
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 23 (AP)  Venezuela said today that it would raise the price of its residual fuel oil by an average of $2.70 a barrel beginning Sunday.

title: Amnesty in Effect in Portugal
description: LISBON, Nov. 23 (Reuters)  An amnesty went into effect in Portugal today for people facing charges in the wake of attempted coups from the left and right in 1975. But those pardoned could still face a review of their conduct by military councils, the Council of the Revolution ruled last month.

title: 4 Large Banks Close in Ireland
description: DUBLIN, Nov. 23 (AP)  The four main banks in the Irish Republic were closed today, one day after worried de- positors withdrew $217 million, or roughly onequarter of the banks total liquid assets.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Friday, Nov. 23,19/9

title: Woman Surrenders After Siege
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 23 (UPI) Sandra Spicer, 35 years old, surrendered to the police this morning after barricading herself in her father's house for 20 hours and threatening to kill her two teenaged children, the police said. The woman, who became distraught alter dispute with her father, was not immediately charged, the police said.

title: Article 4 -- No Title
description: Associated Press

title: Pistons 119, Bucks 100
description: PONTIAC, Mich., Nov. 23 (UPI) John Long, Bob Lanier and Eric Money combined for 72 points tonight to lead the Detroit Pistons to a 119100 victory over the Milwaukee Bucks.

title: Investigator of a Slaying Shoots a Man in Queens
description: A youth was killed and a man was seriously wounded last night in Corona, Queens, in a series of incidents that began with an attempted holdup and ended with an assault on a detective, the police said.

title: Czech TradeOff: A Life of Plenty, the Chill of Repression
description: PRAGUE, Nov. 17  In these prewinter evenings, when the mist that rises from the Vltava River mingles with the fumes of burning brown coal, Prague resembles nothing so much as the setting for Graham

title: Foreign Exchange FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 23, 1979
Dr. Charles Joiner Weds Marion Steinmann
description: In the Chapel of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church yesterday, Marion Steinmann of New York, a freelance science writer, was married to Dr. Charles A. Joiner of Philadelphia, chairman of the department of political science at Temple University and a widower. The Rev. Thomas D. Bowers performed the ceremony.

title: Ferrari Seeks More U.S. Sales
description: Ferrari, the Italian company wnose exotic automobiles can outrun and outmaneuver almost anything else on the highway, is trying to gain a bit in the American sales race.

title: Christie's easta division of Christie, Manson &
description: Exhibitions open until 7:30 pm every Thursday

title: Mary de Bary Bride of Rev. Peter Heinrichs
description: Mary Beatrice de Bary, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William Theodore de Bary of Tappan, N.Y., and the Rev. Peter Ernest Heinrichs, son of Dr. and Mrs. Waldo Heinrichs of Wallingford, Pa., were married yesterday in St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University. The Rev. Thomas Berry, a Roman Catholic priest, and the Rev. Dr. Donald McKinney, minister of the First Unitarian Church in Brooklyn, officiated.

title: Lori B. Kantrowitz Married; In Jersey to Charles Ludmer
description: The marriage of Lori B. Kantrowitz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. S. Edward Kantrowitz of Teaneck, N.J., to Charles G. Ludmer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lionel Ludmer, also of Teaneck, took place yesterday at the Montammy Country Club in Alpine, N.J. Rabbi Sidney Nissenbaum officiated.

title: Italy's 65th Kidnapping of 79
description: VENICE, Nov. 24 (Reuters)  The police said today that two masked gunmen abducted a Venetian shoe manufacturer, Diego Rossi, last night, making him Italy's 65th kidnapping victim this year.

title: TYPICAL OPTICAL
description: In the days of my youth mid many a caper I drew with my nose a mere inch from the paper, but now that I'm older and life has grown hard I find can't focus inside of a yard.

title: Music: Debuts in Review
description: Priscilla Fullerton, whose New York recital debut took place last Sunday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, is a pianist who has degrees from the Cleveland Institute of Music and the University of Illinois. Her playing is conscientious, honest and forthright. But it cannot be said that she is an imginative artist, or a subtle one.

title: Events Today
description: Science Fiction Costume Contest: Children up to age 13 dressed as space creatures; 1 to 4:30 P.M.; Wiidcliff Museum, New Rochlle. (Call (914) 6362108 for details.)

title: Bum Has
description: For those who like to think they know sports trivia, who is Oail Andrew Phillips?

title: Seeking the Past In the Present
description: EARLIER this year, my office in Trenton was moved to a new building there. In front of it runs the Assunpink Creek, and to the left I can see the spot where the original gristmill stood. The mill was built in 1679 by Mahlon Stacy, one of the first settlers in this area.

title: The Old Vic Takes `Hamlet to China
description: PEKING With all his doubts and indecision, Hamlet is far from an ideal revolutionary hero, observed Toby Robertson, the director of the Old Vic Theater Company.

title: Public Radio Tries Morning Edition
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24There is a new twohour radio network news program on the air, but its debut has gone unnoticed by most Americans, because it is on public radio, and that makes for some problems other kinds of networks do not ordinarily face.

title: A.Week of Concern On Home Heating
description: IT was almost as if someone had proclaimed last week Home Heating Week. Officials in the metropolitan area seemed occupied with little else.

title: Parents Etiquette On College Visits
description: FOR parents who have invested in their offspring's college tuition, there is a dividend known as Parents Visiting Weekend. Within two or three months after sending your child off to college, you can see where your dollars are going (while at the same time being relieved of a few more) in a condensed immersion into campus life. The following advice can help you get the most out of the twoday exercise  and you might even be asked back again.

title: Occupied West Bank Also Preoccuppies Israel' Court
description: JERUSALEM  Little reflects Israel's gnawing ambivalence about being an occupying power so vividly as the solemn deliberations of its Supreme Court, where blackrobed justices are being asked with growing frequency to rule on behalf of Palestinians when the military government arrests them, takes their land or tries to deport them.

title: Music: Blends by Nyman
description: The six recent compositions by Michael Nyman presented at the Kitchen on Friday evening all blended elements from classical, popular and repetition, or process, music. Five Orchestral Pieces Opus Tree fashioned repetition structures that were variously wintry and metallic out of materials derived from the work of Anton Webern  who wrote some attenuated but genuine repetition music himself. Bird List sounded like the extended coda of the sort of rock number that ends sets and albums, but without the thunderous amplification, improvised solos and drumming.

title: Canadian Arctic Gearing Down For the Winter
description: PANGNIRTUNG, Northwest Territories  In these Arctic parts of Canada, winter is not so much a season as it is way of life.

title: ABC Is Sued by Insurance Agent In Hidden Filming of Sales Pitch
description: TOWSON, Md., Nov. 24 (UPI)  An insurance agent is suing the American Broadcasting Companies Inc. for more than $4 million on charges that the network violated his privacy when it used a hidden camera to film his sales presentation to two elderly women.

title: M.I.S.L. Opens Second Season
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24  The presence of established North American Soccer League players should assure the Major Indoor Soccer League better quality of play than it had in its innaugural season last year.

title: Widow, 60, Fights To Adopt Girl, 4
description: CALVERTON

title: Leslie Morse Sets February Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lester Morse Jr. of Stamford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Leslie Ann Morse, to Mitchell Jay Nelson, son of Dr. and Mrs. Irving Nelson of Scarsdale, N.Y. The wedding is planned for February.

title: Adirondack Forest Preserve Gets 1,313Acre Estate of Hop Baron
description: ALBANY, Nov. 21 The former estate of the Hop Baron of the North in the Adirondack Mountains has been bought by New York State for an addition to the Adirondack Forest Preserve.

title: Eisenhower Farm May Be Open Next summer as Historic Site
description: GETTYSBURG, Pa., Nov. 24 (AP) The farm of former President Dwight D. Eisenhower and his wife, Mamie, should be open to the public by next summer as the Eisenhower National Historic Site, according to a Federal official.

title: Toast and Jelly In New Brunswick
description: NEW BRUNSWICK BEN BRENNAN has problems, and so does Toast and Jelly. Trying to get in shape and having given up smoking, 42yearold Ben does pushups and keeps away from cigarettes by dousing a pack of True Menthol with roach spray.

title: Chinese Official Ends Nepal Visit
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, Nov. 24 (Reuters)  The Chinese Foreign Minister, Huang Hua, ended a fourday official visit to Nepal today saying it had been a complete success. Before flying on to Burma, he said he was pleased to have signed a protocol earlier this week defining the boundary between Nepal and the Chinese autonomous region of Tibet.

title: ON THE ISLE
description: The Whaling Museum in Cold Spring Harbor has a perfect way to end a long holiday weekend: a pictorial jaunt down to Bonaire, off the coast of Venezuela, for a visit with the flora and fauna that inhabit that bit of paradise's coral reef. Shot and narrated by Michael Fairchild, a nature photographer, A Coral Reef, a slide show with music and natural sounds, will be seen at 2 P.M. at the museum, on Main Street. Admission is 75 cents; for children, 25 cents. The museum itself, with its extensive collection of Long Island sea lore, is open from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. 3673418.

title: ABOUT CARS
description: LIDAY giftbuying for the car buff in the family sometimes takes a rather obvious route  a tape deck or CB radio, for example  but there are any number of interesting and inexpensive items whose only moving parts are their pages, and they shouldn't be overlooked.

title: The Books That Made Writers
description: What book made you decide to become a writer and why? When the Book Review asks such a question of writers, as we often do for our holiday issues, we have hopes but no certainty about the results. The question above, however, touched something. Not only were most of the authors willing to answer, they did so with feeling and variety. Memories were stirred, debts were acknowledged, and we learned more than we had expected to about the making of writers.

title: Divorced Father Is Told To Keep Dates or Pay
description: REDWOOD CITY, Calif., Nov. 24 (UPI)  A domestic relations commissioner has ruled that a man must pay his estranged wife the Federal minimum wage whenever he misses an appointment to pick up their three children for scheduled parental visits.

title: Carter Sets Campaign Swing
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UPI) President Carter will make a fiveday campaign swing after his Dec. 4 announcement that he will seek reelection, his campaign committee said today. On the night of Dec. 4 he will appear at a fundraising dinner in Washington, and 1 the next day at a similar affair in New York City. On Dec. 6 he will appear at dinner in Chicago, and one in Atlanta Dec. 7. On Dec. 8 he will be at a brunch and also a lunch in Austin, Tex.

title: 10 Hurt in Newspaper Fire
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 24 (UPI)  The Chicago SunTimes successfully put out its editions today despite a fire yesterday that injured 10 persons and caused extensive damage to the newspaper's press room.

title: Newark Police Issue A Question for 1980
description: NEWARK

title: Michigan Revives Plan for Highway to Skirt Detroit
description: DETROIT, Nov.24  For the second time in two years, the Michigan Transportation Commission is expected next week to consider the fate of a 22yearold plan to construct a 24mile stretch of highway northwest of here that could save motorists eight minutes driving time, cost about $100 million to build and cut through a state park.

title: So, the Teamsters Win in the End
description: The shining hour of the A.F.L.C.I.O. was its 1957 expulsion of the gangsterridden International Brotherhood of Teamsters as a disgrace to organized labor. No other major institution, and certainly none in the business community, ever demonstrated a comparable readiness to sacrifice to rid itself of corruption. In the face of warnings by Jimmy Hoffa that you need us more than we need you, the merged labor federation kicked out its biggest and strongest affiliate, a union with makeorbreak power over every other union's strikes and organizing campaigns.

title: INVESTING
description: The return on bonds over the past three years has been disappointing, to say the least. But Peter Nadosy of the Fiduciary Trust Company of New York has run a bond portfolio with an enviable return of 27 percent in 1977 and 37 percent in 1978. So far this year, the portfolio has more than broken even. The secret to his success is that the bonds are not denominated in dollars.

title: Kennedy Hoping G.O.P. Will Help Him in Texas
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 24  Strange as it may sound, Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts is hoping that Republicans, especially John B. Connally, will help him score an upset over President Carter in the Democratic contest here May 3.

title: LateSlumping Nets Lose to 76ers by 9182
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24  When the Philadelphia 76ers reached a 13point lead in the final quarter of tonight's 9182 victory over the New Jersey Nets, strains of We Are Family, the theme song of their crossstate neighbors, the baseball champion Pittsburgh Pirates, filtered over the speaker system. The 7,422 gathered here at the Spectrum joined in, clapping and singing, as if it was their anthem.

title: Gail Suzanne Wheeler Bride of Timothy Digby
description: St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Darien, Conn., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Gail Suzanne Wheeler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Willard L. Wheeler Jr. of Darien, to Timothy John Digby, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Digby of Allison Park, Pa. The Rev. Frederick Bender performed the ceremony.

title: Parade in Hometown Welcomes a Secretary Released by Iranians
description: CAMBRIDGE SPRINGS, Pa., Nov. 24 (AP)  With sirens blaring and signs proclaiming Welcome home, Kathy, this small town held a Main Street parade yesterday to celebrate the return of Kathy Jean Gross from Iran.

title: Abstract Landscapes At Montclair Show
description: MONTCLAIR AREPRESENTATIONAL landscape is often a composite of observed facts about, say, specific mountains, trees and rivers. It is a chronicle or a piece of visual reportag.markedly atmospheric paintings. They are soft and ethereal, lyrically vaporous veils of color suffused with the sensation of mist, fog and the kind of air that seems tangible to the skin.

title: A New View of Eli Whitney, And a New Hamden Museum
description: HAMDEN ELI WHITNEY invented the cotton gin and brought prosperity to the South. That, as generations of schoolchildren learned, was his contribution to American history. But the cotton gin was an easily duplicated machine that earned the inventor practically nothing because the patent was unenforceable. He demonstrated perhaps greater genius with the idea of interchangeable parts for the manufacture of guns.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: A band of clouds extends along a front from eastern Canada to the central Gulf Coast. Low clouds cover the Northern Plains States and southern Texas. Thick clouds are visible in the Pacific Northwest. Clear skies are apparent elsewhere.

title: STAMPS
description: his has been a year devoted to the creativity and activity of children  during the year through issues of the International Year of the Child, and now at year's end through drawings by children on what Christmas means to them. postal service and have come to be regarded as specialty field of philately, covered in detail in Scott's Specialized United States Catalogue.

title: Article 9 No Title
STAGE VIEW
description: The wave of musical revivals that has swept over Broadway can no longer be rationalized as an overdue appreciation of classic shows. It is making business of show business and it is drowning out the new musicals. Without new shows and a place for new showmakers, the theater is dead.

title: Joseph P. Kearney, Energy Aide, Weds Michele Trutanic
description: The marriage of Michele Martine Trutanic, daughter of Nina Bogdanovic Trutanic of Los Angeles and the late Nicholas Frank Trutanic, to Joseph Patrick Kearney. son of Mr. and Mrs. John NcHenry Kearney of Brooklyn, took place yesterday afternoon. Msgr. Thomas A. Kiefer performed the ceremony in Mary Star of the Sea Roman Catholic Church in San Pedro, Calif.

title: ART
description: SOMEWHERE behind everyone who writes about art and artists there lurks an ancestor. His name is Giorgio Vasari. In his time he was a terrific swell on more than one count, but we remember him primarily for a book that he published in 1550 and republished, enlarged, in 1568. Its original title was The Lives of the Best Italian Architects, Painters and Sculptors, From Cimabue to the Present Time.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: Awardwinning drawings, prints and paintings by Theodora Ilowitz, whose work is on view at the Newark Museum and Lincoln Center in New York, among other places, can be seen at the Art & Frame Gallery in Westwood through Dec. 31.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: The guest editorials on the Opinion Page of Sept. 16 captured two approaches to regional development that echo an ageold conflict between urban views and pastoral visions.

title: ABOUT CARS
description: HOLIDAY giftbuying for the car buff in the family sometimes takes a rather obvious route  a tape deck or CB radio, for example  but there are any number of interesting and inexpensive items whose only moving parts are their pages, and they shouldn't be overlooked.

title: Firefighters Stop Pouring Foam To Fight Tanker Blaze Off Texas
description: GALVESTON, Tex., Nov. 29 (AP) Firefighters abandoned a technique of using foam to extinguish the 25dayold blaze aboard the tanker Burmah Agate today, but they said the fire could burn itself out sometime next week.

title: Senate to Hold Hearings on Busy Car Theft Rings
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP)  The Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations on Tuesday will open five days of hearings on automobile thefts, which reportedly involve organized crime in several cities. Witnesses will indude convicted criminals, subcommittee investigators and law enforcement officials, including William H. Webster, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: GARDENING
description: CONSIDER Hedera helix, the English ivy. It seems that the commonlygrown forms, those with the pointed lobed leaves, are immature forms  juveniles, if you will. While they can be propagated by rooting cuttings, they are not yet capable of flowering and sexual reproduction.

title: Cedarhurst Debates; Parking for Disabled
description: CEDARHURST THE question of how far a municipality can go in extending special privileges to the handicapped has become an issue in this village, whose highfashion specialty shops attract shoppers from many areas of the Island and New York City.

title: ART New Jersey Art at Trenton
description: TRENTON

title: Oslo Honors The Vikings, Old and New
description: In the 9th and 10th centuries this prayer was said daily in areas of Europe where Christians lived in mortal terror of heathen Viking raiders. The Vikings descended on them from the southern shores of presentday Norway and from parts of Denmark and Sweden to plunder and slay.

title: Indian Point Protest Trial To Begin
description: BUCHANAN THE 150 antinuclear protesters who are to go on trial here tomorrow on charges of trespassing at Consolidated Edison's Indian Point power plant on Aug. 5, say they intend to put forth a defense of competing harms, a state statute that allows criminal conduct when such conduct is necessary as an emergency measure to avoid an imminent injury.

title: FILM VIEW
description: In one of the least sentimental, most savagely witty songs he ever wrote and recorded, Nol Coward asks, with just the tiniest hint of polite impatience, Why must the show go on? After considering the subject at length, wishes that those legendary troupers, the ones who insist on playing for us when they have a temperature of 103 degrees or have just lost their entire family in a flood, would stay decently at home and not inflict their suffering on us. Why must the show go on? is vintage Coward, the work a man who grew up in show business and knew better than anyone why the show does, indeed, go on, at least most of the time. It goes on not because the performer can't bear to let down his public but because the performer needs his audience more than the audience needs the performer and, more important, because the audience feeds on the unhappiness its stars. It's box office.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: The largest tire recall in the nation's history began a year ago this week when the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company and the Federal Government jointly announced an agreement. The Akron, Ohio, company was to replace free 7.5 million Firestone 500 steelbelted radials sold after Sept. 1, 1975, and to exchange at half price about six million such tires sold before then.

title: Budget Cuts Damaging, Say Colleges
description: WHEN the students in the Introduction to Poetry course at Central Connecticut State College were told to write a term paper, they knew that there were too few books in the college library to supply the whole class. The library has been hit especially hard by years of skimpy budgets, and this year by lastminute cuts in the money the college was told it would receive.

title: Democrats in Area, Unlike G.O.P., Revising Delegate Selection System
description: Democrats in New York, New Jerseg and Connecticut, under pressure from the national party, are making drastic changes in the process of selecting delegates to the 1980 national convention and insuring the representation of women and minority groups. But Republicans, except for those in Connecticut, have made few changes in their selection procedure.

description: A gold & diamond pendant/brooch

title: Concert Dec. 4 to Honor Britten and Year of Child
description: A concert in honor of the Interna tional Year of the Child and the memory of Benjamin Britten will be held Dec. 4 at 7:30 P.M. at St. Thomas Church, Fifth Avenue and West 53d Street.

title: Tom Hanley, a Confessed Killer, Dies Under Guard in a Hospital
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 24 (UPI) Tom Hanley, onetime Nevada union organizer and confessed killer of Al Bramlet, the culinary union leader, died last night two weeks after testifying as a Government witness in a racketeering trial. He was 63 years old.

description: ART

Laurel's Harness Track Told to Settle Debts
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md. Nov. 24 (AP) Laurel Raceway must settle its debts before the harness track can conduct its 85night meeting next year, the harness board of the Maryland Racing Commission said yesterday.

title: A Correction
description: In an article on foliage viewing at Lake Waramaug [Oct. 14], the telephone number of The Inn at Lake Waramaug was given incorrectly. The correct phone number is 8682168.

title: Scrubby Sagebrush, an Anathema in the West, Is Finally Wanted
description: SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Nov. 24 (AP) Sagebrush grows profusely over the American West, and in some areas the Federal authorities are spraying to get rid of it.

title: Realty News
description: A sixstory office building at 222 South Marginal Road in Fort Lee, N.J., has been sold for more than $8 million.

title: Iona Five Wins, 10787
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 24 (AP)  Kevin Hamilton, a doubtful starter because of an injury, scored 27 points, and Jeff Ruland, recovering from a broken finger, collected 24 points last night to help Iona to a 10787 victory over a touring Mexican basketball team from the University of Guadalajara.

title: Paintings That Hint Of Glass or Tapestry
description: PORT WASHINGTON PAUL WOOD is a prominent presence in the Long Island art world. Not only is he a welllmown Port Washington artist, but also he established an art school that has been in existence for nearly 29 years. Through his family's design consulting firm, he has designed stained glass windows, tapestries and mosaics for synagogues and churches on the Island and elsewhere in the country. He has done commissioned portraits of Long Island personalities and has written books on art.

title: THE MARKETS
description: The continuing crisis in Iran and new outbreaks violence in the Middle East dominated the attention of investors last week. The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 3.93 points to 811.77. The Friday after Thanksgiving provided the week's only winning session.

title: Bolivian Army Rebels Dig In at Barracks in La Paz
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Nov. 24 (Reuters)Rebellious Bolivian Army units were entrenched in the main barracks in La Paz today after they rejected the authority of the Defense Minister and military commanders.

title: American Myopia, Incorporated
description: Overturn any economic rock and you can find evidence of America's dismal economic performance. Since 1960, imports have risen from 5 percent to 11 percent of total national production while manufactured exports have fallen from 25 percent of the world's total to less than 20. Reversing this economic decline will refocused on what Government can do for the private secquire many changes, but most of the suggestions have tor  through tax breaks and research subsidies rather than on what the private sector should be doing for itself.

title: Deaths
description: ASHErnestine Josephle. On November 19 In North Augusta, S.C. Devoted mother of Lee, Bethany, Conn. Memorial service to be held later.

title: A Patagonian Adventure Among the Birds and Beasts
description: At the edge of the small rise I stopped crawling and looked up. On the beach, not more than four yards away, five females and a big bull dozed lazily in the sun, the water licking gently at their flippers. We were in luck, and as I gestured to the group behind me I watched their faces brighten with anticipation. They had never seen wild elephant seals before.

title: Veteran, in Iran Protest, Is Giving Up Citizenship
description: EL PASO, Nov. 24 (UPI)  In protest against what he believes is American inaction in Iran, a disabled Vietnam veteran is giving up his United States citizenship.

title: Mrs. Alexandre Is Honored By Met. Golf Association
description: Cynthia Alexandre, who has devoted much of her adult life to serving women's golf nationally and locally, was designated last week the recipient of the Metropolitan Golf Association's 1979 Distinguished Service Award.

title: Olympic Villages Attract Fewer Tenants
description: Reports from London, Colorado Springs and several European capitals indicate that many worldclass athletes will spend as little time as possible  perhaps no time  in the Olympic Villages at Lake Placid, N.Y., next February and at Moscow in July.

title: DINDIG OUT 100 Hunan Tastes and Parking, Too
description: HUNAN Manor, serving wellprepared homestyle Hunanese dishes, has recently opened in Hartsdale, bringing to seven the number of Chinese restaurants on Central Avenue. We seem to be witnessing the foundation an unincorporated Chinese village of culinary arts, suburban Chinatown where it is possible to taste good examples of dishes from all the major cuisines of China and to find parking besides.

title: Miss Critchley Sets Nuptials
description: Mrs. John Critchley Jr. of Remsenburg, L.I., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Elizabeth Edgar Critchley, to Henry Griswold Haff, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Barse Haff Jr. of Rye, N.Y. Plans have been made for a wedding next July.

title: German Copter Falls Into Rhine
description: WIESBADEN, West Germany, Nov. 24 (Reuters)  A police helicopter plunged into the Rhine River in central West Germany today and three of its crewmen were missing, the police said. A fourth policeman was injured but was rescued and brought ashore on an island in the Rhine near Trebur.

title: Adolescence and Maturity in Plants
description: CONSIDER Hedera helix, the English ivy. It seems that the commonlygrown forms, those with the pointed lobed leaves, are immature forms  juveniles, if you will. While they can be propagated by

title: Illinois Death Penalty Upheld
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Nov. 24 (AP) The Illinois Supreme Court has upheld a provision of the state's 1977 death penalty law that allows prosecutors to initiate a jury hearing into whether death should be imposed after conviction of a capital crime. The ruling Wednesday overturned a trial judge's opinion that the provision gave prosecutors unlimited discretion to trigger deathsentence proceedings. At issue is the conviction , of Ronald Brown, 19 years old, for the fatal shooting, aggravated kidnapping and armed robbery of Charles McGee, 27, in Chicago.

title: Nancy Reynolds Betrothed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John Mitchell Reynolds 3d of Palm Beach, Fla., of the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Sorg Reynolds, to Timothy Channell Davidson.

title: Khomeini Accuses U.S. and Israel Of Attempt to Take Over Mosques
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 24  Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, accusing President Carter of ignoring all human international values, charged today that the United States and Israel were trying to seize two of the most sacred Moslem mosques in the holy cities of Mecca and Medina.

title: White House Panel Keeps Close Watch on Iran Crisis
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24  Every morning since the Iranian crisis began three weeks ago, a small group of senior Carter Administration officials have assembled in the windowless, woodpaneled Situation Room in the basement of the White House.

title: DALLAS ACES AHEAD IN REISINGER BRIDGE
description: CINCINNATI, Nov. 24  The hottest contract bridge team in the country was in the lead tonight in the toughest of all tournament events. The Aces team, which has won two major team championships in the last 12 months, headed 54 squads at the end of the qualifying stage last night in the Reisinger BoardAMatch Team Championship at the American Contract Bridge League Fall Nationals and continued to lead at the halfway stage of the event.

title: Dr. W. F. Kiefer Jr. Weds Melinda Moon
description: At St. Thomas Episcopal Church in Cincinnati last evening, Melinda Messmore Moon was married to Dr. William F. Kiefer Jr. by the Rev. Dr. Robert Gerhard.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: EVEN the most inexperienced of doityourselfers is likely to be familiar with the tool many call the plumber's friend  otherwise known as a force cup or plunger. After trying a chemical drain cleaner, and often even before using a chemical drain opener, this is the tool that the home handyman or handywoman will reach for when a drain gets clogged or starts to act sluggish.

title: Ellen Goldman, C.P.A., Bride of Henry J. Cohen
description: Ellen Joy Goldman and Henry Jon Cohen were married yesterday by Rabbi Maurice Davis at the Harrison (N.Y.) Jewish Community Center.

title: Jazz: Widespread's Solos
description: During the last couple of years, the Widespread Depression Orchestra has been one of the most impressive delvers in an earlier era of jazz primarily because it caught the spirit of a period  the big bands of the 1930's and 40's without being trapped in it. It adapted the bigband arrangements of Duke Ellington, Jimmy Lunceford, Fletcher Henderson, Benny Carter and others to its own ninepiece limitations, but managed to retain, or at least suggest, the full ensembles of the originals. And its soloists, even when they followed the original solos, gave their solos freshness and immediacy by stamping them with their own personalities.

title: HIGHLIGHTS
description: A lot of big deals fell through last week.

title: High Praise for a Plant That Has Everything
description: Lcoking back to the winners in this year's garden, I find that epimediums are high on my list. In fact, I can put a star in front of them. Epimediums are plants you can depend on. They require no coddling, but go on year after year. They slowly increase in size and reliably spread their display of delightful blossoms and durable foliage.

title: Dr. Deborah E. Hammond Bride of Dr. David Emanuel
description: yesterday evening at the home of the bride's parents. Rabbi Emeritus Norbert Rosenthal of Temple Israel in Tulsa performed the ceremony.

title: Dr. Leslie M. Scoutt Is Married to Dr. Joseph G. Garner
description: St. Margaret's Episcopal Church in Washington was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Dr. Leslie Millar Scoutt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Jerrold Scoutt Jr. of Bethesda Md., to Dr. Joseph Glassford Garner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Cleatus E. Garner of Phoenix. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Malcolm Marshall, who was assisted by the Rev. Stephen Arpee.

title: Sarah Hollett Engaged to G. J. Hossfeld 3d
description: The engagement of Sarah Platt Hollett to George John Hossfeld 3d, has been announced by her parents, the Rev. and Mrs. Robert Titus Hollett of Oyster Bay, L.I. Mr. Hossfeld is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hossfeld Jr. of Lloyd Harbor, L.I. The wedding is planned for next June in Christ Episcopal Church in Oyster Bay, of which theprospective bride's father is the rector.

title: POLITICS Democrats Taking A Step Toward 81
description: AGROUP of prominent Democrats have formed a nonprofit association for the express purpose of fostering interest in, and screening candidates for, the 1981 election for Governor.

title: New Golf Rules Are Devised
description: Those sternvisaged governors who control the rules of golf have decided that in some respects players have had it too good and have tightened a few rules, with the changes taking effect Jan. 1. The news is not all bad: A few of the rules have been liberalized. Golfers who have struggled to comprehend what the rulesmakers mean will be delighted to learn some of the language has been clarified.

title: Notes
description: The World of Oz, a New Yorkbased company specializing in small luxury trips, has put together a series of 18day Orient Gourmet adventures with Manila, Bangkok, Penang, Hong Kong and Canton on the itinerary.

title: PostFranco Spain Shows Its Diversity
description: MADRID  One of the accomplishments of the Franco regime was to maintain the fiction that Spain was one nation. In the last four years, the many peoples of Spain  Basques. Catalans. Galicians. Aragonese, Andalusian, Valencianos Castilians and Canary and Balearic islanders  have started expressing their rich and sometimes unsettling diversity.

title: The Saul and Victor Show
description: A blazing marquee would be out of place so far off Broadway, but some of the best theater in New York is playing on Wall Street. The drama involves two bold, often unorthodox, clearly starcrossed operators, both of them voracious corporate acquisitors with a dizzying grasp of financial maneuvering. It is called the Saul and Victor Show.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: FOR a Thursday night at the student cafeteria, seats were unusually easy to find. No one was complaining about long lines or crowded tables. Less than half the regular boarders came for dinner.

title: Rutgers & Newark: Urban Symbiosis
description: NEWARK

title: The Region
description: Hugh L. Carey assured himself dubious footnote award when, in 1976, he became New York's first Governor in more than a century to have a veto overridden by the Legislature. Mr. Carey, it now appears, will be ridden over again.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The recent death of Mamie Eisenhower served as an occasion for recalling her husband's career  one in which she played a key supporting role  and it also focused attention on the various memorials that have been established for Dwight David Eisenhower in the decade since his own death in 1969.

title: Banks See Little Hope On Loans For Houses
description: Thrift institutions are approaching a complete embargo on singlefamily conventional mortgages in New York State and New Jersey, according to bankers and others in the financial community.

title: Citrus Grower Loses Suit Against Rights Workers
description: PHOENIX, Nov. 24  A citrus grower's suit asking that three Arizona civil rights leaders be held in criminal contempt of court for talking to the press about the plight of Mexican farm workers has been dismissed.

title: Khomeini Excites the Arab Masses, Pains Arab Rulers
description: BAHRAIN  Two visitors to this small Arab sheikdom in the Persian Gulf sat in the hotel bar last week discussing the Islamic revolution of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini in nearby Iran. They had spoken for barely 10 minutes when a Yemeni businessman approached them with a warning that this sort of talk can get you in trouble around here. Yet, within minutes, the eavesdropping Yemeni had joined the talk and invited a Jordanian colleague to come along.

title: The Buzz Is There: Is the Beatles' Touch?
description: ELMONT WHEN a band is both appealing and aggressively managed, the casual observer may find it difficult to determine which byproduct  popular response or manufactured promotion  has the upper hand in generating that allimportant wordofmouth reaction sometimes referred to as buzz.

title: Bonn Plays Down Gromyko Warning on U.S. Missiles
description: BONN, Nov. 24  West German officials cautioned today against dramatizing a statement of the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, that a decision by the Western European allies to deploy new American missiles might destroy any chances for widened talks on arms control.

title: Playing the Game
description: Then they're all alone at Naz.ri? Except for the Khautmi men. Will they try to hold it?

title: Leadership Culture in Boston Praised in Contrast to Philadelphia's
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24 (AP) Philadelphians might have more pride today if the Mayflower had sailed up the Delaware in 1620 instead of anchoring at Plymouth Rock, a 12year study suggests.

title: The World
description: If I had to choose between betraying my country and betraying my friend, hope I should have the guts to betray my country. E. M. FORSTER in a 1939 essay.

title: Las Vegas Raises Tacky To a Magnificent Level
description: I never wanted to go to Las Vegas. would like to make that clear at the outset. I appreciate some forms of glitter. An opening night on Broadway, for example, is good glitter, like diamonds. But Las Vegas glitter to me always seemed to mean rhinestones and sequins. Everything I dislike about America, a country of which I am more than passingly fond, I expected to find in Las Vegas  but a threeday visit gave me second thoughts.

title: Late TV Listings
description: 10:30 A.M. (Channel 2) For Our Times: The controversy surrounding the Federal Government's decision to convert the Lake Placid, N.Y., Olympic site into a prison.

title: SATELLITES LASERS PROBE EARTH CRUST
description: A small artificial satellite passes 4,000 miles overhead. From a ground station, in Australia or on a Pacific atoll, in Brazil or along the San Andreas Fault in California, a pulse of intense, sharply focused light issues every second the satellite is within range.

title: 2WAY RADIO SYSTEM TO PROTECT ELDERLY
description: ROCHESTER, Nov. 24 (UPI)  Two hundred elderly people on Rochester's northeast side have been given portable twoway radios as part of an experimental plan designed to curb crimes against the elderly.

title: Food
description: Someone once complained that the United States is becoming an odorless society. Cairo has no such problems. Driving through this andent city, one can almost see the sweet smell of flowers and heavy aroma of mutton, or kofta, wafting from the street vendors carts and stalls.

title: Three Economists Give Their Views on What's Ahead
description: Not rain nor snow nor holiday stays the Government from delivering of economic indicators. Last week's were like many recent signals. They neither confirmed nor denied the coming of recession.

title: New York State Plans a Cash Fuel Grant for Needy
description: New York State announces plans lase week for rash grants of $250 to help welfare families with children pay their heating bills. ether people on welfare would eet 5125. and people who receive Supplemental Security Income would get $150. All this assumes that President Carter will sign a pending bill that would allow such Federal financing.

title: Egon Ronay, Who Panned The Airlines /
description: LONDON  Egon Ronay, Britain's best known publisher of guidebooks, says he could make much more money than he in fact does. We could double our profits with the greatest of ease, declared the 59yearold Hungarian expatriate whose restaurant and hotel guide for 1980 reached across the Atlantic for the first time and panned some United States airlines and rated the New York hotels.

title: Uranium Plan For Lilco Gains
description: THE Long Island Lighting Company's New Mexico uranium supplier has come up with a uranium milltailings disposal plan that state and Federal officials are calling progressive.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Wind and winter sun are the two most devastating enemies of plants in winter. Add to them hungry deer and mice and gardeners have their challenges. And if the thermometer turns unfriendly and drops to low figures for a time, certain plants can be in serious trouble.

title: ART VIEW
description: The American painter Fairfield Porter died a little over four years ago at the age of 68. He was anything but an obscure figure, having been active on the New York scene as both an exhibiting artist and a frequently published critic for many years. He did not lack for admirers, either, among critics, collectors and other artists, several of whom were decisively influenced by his work. Yet in certain quarters  where, for example, the decisions are made about mounting major retro spective exhibitions in New York museums  his special distinction remains, even now, quite unrecognized.

title: DINING OUT Ol for a Menu in Bethel
description: BETHEL SUBSTANTIAL change has come to Bethel recent years, and San Miguel, a Mexican restaurant not quite two years old, is part of the old town's new look.

title: Music Notes: Babar Goes to Washington
description: Afew weeks ago the stage of the Juilliard Theater was filled with elephants, a camel, a monkey and assorted human beings. The circus hadn't come to the auditorium.

title: Backgammon:
description: An International Challenge match sponsored by I.T.T. World Communications was recently held between two strong teams from Europe and the United States. Luigi Villa, current world champion, led the European team, which included Kumar Motakhausses, Beverly Phillips and Serge Lorenzin. The United States was represented by Barclay Cooke, Oswald Jacoby, Lee Genud and Paul Magriel. In an unusual arrangement, the players did not meet facetoface, but played via a highspeed facsimile, relayed by satellite between Geneva ana New York.

title: Giants Aim to Stop Resurgent Redskins
description: The Over the Hill Gang has been replaced by the Gang of 45, but they are still the Washington Redskins and still the Giants most bitter enemies. They will be at the Meadowlands today in what both teams inist will not be a replay of their first meeting this season.

title: House Selling: A Lesson Learned
description: ALMOST 30 years ago, my brother-in-law and I bought  in partnership  a twofamily house in Yonkers. When he died last January, his sister (my wife), was psychologically unprepared to face the absence of her brother next door, so we decided to sell. As a former high school administrator accustomed to dealing with thorny problems on short notice, I decided to restudy the whole question of house selling and buying. Looking over documents and papers relating to the purchase of our home in 1948 yielded little of value, since much of what I looked at in my buying a house folder read like I was seeing it for the first time.
