description: CHUGWATER, Wyo., Nov. 25 (AP)  They hung out the Vacancy sign at the Chugwater Hotel again today, and the Rev. Boyd Crose had plenty of empty pews at the Methodist Church. Nearly all of the 100 motorists who were stranded here for five days by a blizzard had departed.

title: Piano: Alice O'sullivan
description: ALICE WILDERMUTH O'sULLIVAN, who gave a piano recital Saturday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall, has been a church organist since the age of 5, and is music director of First Lutheran Church in Oakland, Calif. Her teachers included Egon Petri, with whom she studied for seven years.

title: Deaths
description: ISAACSONBernard, M.D., Lt. Col, U.S. Army, beloved husband of Sylvia, devoted stepfather of Abraham, Joan, Meg and Norman. Services were held yesterday, November 25.

title: For South Koreans, U.S. Looks Like the Promised Land
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Lee Hong Sik, a radio and television repairman, and Kwon Jung Hee, his wife, picked up their immigrant visas at the American Embassy here in September and prepared to join the hardworking Korean community New Yorkers know so well.

title: Concert: Seraphim Trio
description: THE Seraphim Trio is a brandnew chamber ensemble but its members will be familiar to concertgoers as wellknown soloists in their own right  Edith Peinemann, violinist; Yehuda Hanani, cellist; and Edward Auer, pianist. Like so many performers nowadays, all three have been attracted to the special rewards of making music as a team, and the group's debut concert took place at the 92d Street Y Saturday night.

title: Music: Delos Angeles and de Larrocha
description: THE bond that develops between a great singer such as Victoria de los Angeles and her audience comes as close as this cynical world allows to being an ideal romantic attachment. Flaws  and the Spanish soprano has them nowadays, no question about that  may be recognized, but they are refracted through a kindly, softfocusing glass in such a way that they are perceived as mere specks, almost precious because they belong to the beloved one. Many of her listeners have grown up with the artist and have learned to be tolerant of their own flaws.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: When Mattel Inc. acquired the Western Publishing Company last June, the commercial publishing house became the Californiabased company's secondlargest profit center, after toys. And now Mattel has sent Terrence D. Daniels, one of its top officials, eastward to the Racine, Wis.based subsidiary as chairman and president.

title: Many Mormon Women Feel Torn Between Equal Rights Proposal and Church
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 25 For Mormon feminists, who began organizing in the early 1970's, and for more traditional Mormon women, the proposed equal rights amendment has been a source of Dain and conflict. It has become a source of fear, too, for those who support it, since a Mormon feminist has been accused of apostasy and will soon stand church trial with a possible sentence of excommunication.

title: Article 3 -- No Title
AGING OF LEADERSHIP IS WORRYING PEKING
description: PEKING, Nov. 25  In its proclaimed goal of teaching Vietnam a lesson last winter during their brief border war, China may have learned a lesson too, now appears. Peking's army commanders, many of them veterans of the Long March in the 1930's or the wars with the Chinese Nationalists and the Japanese in the 1940's, are getting too old.

title: Oil Group's Study Shows '79 Profit Above Average
description: Just how great have the oil companies profits been so far this year? Substantially greater than average, according to a compilation prepared by the American Petroleum Institute, the industry's principal trade group.

title: Khomeini v. Shah: What the Record Says
description: On Aug. 18, 1953, a disconsolate Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi and his wife were shopping on the Via Veneto in Rome. They had just fled Iran, where a nationalist Prime Minister, Mohammed Mossadegh, had ignored the Shah's order to resign and won nationalist acclaim for seizing the Britishrun oilfields.

title: CONGRESSMAN VISITS CAPTIVES IN TEHERAN
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 25  An American Congressman on a selfappointed peace mission here said today that he had been permitted to visit the hostages held in the American Embassy by Islamic students demanding that the deposed Shah be returned here for trial.

title: Kurds Declare a Truce In Iran and Offer Aid In a Fight With U.S.
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Monday, Nov. 26 (Reuters)  Iran's rebellious Kurds have announced a truce in their fight against the Government and vowed to join Iranian troops to confront any military action against Iran by the United States.

title: SAUDIS SAY MOSQUE HAS BEEN RETAKEN
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Nov. 25  After a fierce gun battle late yesterday, the Saudi National Guard has succeeded in regaining control over virtually all of the Grand Mosque at Mecca, with the exception of a small section of the basement, according to Saudi and diplomatic sources.

title: Students in Islamabad See A Growing Islamic Uprising
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 25  Mohammed Khaliq Ahme, the president of the Student Union at QuaidiAzam University, explained today why he thought the attack and destruction of the United States Embassy here were justified and correct actions.

title: Libertarians Candidate for 1980, In New York, Urges Budget Cuts
description: If we ever get discouraged, said Ed Clark, the Presidential candidate of the Libertarian Party, we can look at the quality of the Republicans and Democrats.

title: Auto Woodworkers Cancer Rate Is Subject of an Inquiry in Detroit
description: DETROIT, Nov. 25  A Federal investigation has been begun here to determine whether there has been an unusually high incidence of cancer among woodworkers in the automobile industry.

title: Some Landlords Gain P.S.C. Consent to Sell Electricity to Tenants
description: A return to submetering  in which a landlord buys electricity at bulk rates and resells through his own meters to tenants  is being allowed in New York City and most of Westchester County for commercial and industrial buildings, cooperatives and condomiums.

title: Scientists Gather to Preserve Sea Turtles
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP)  The sea turtle, once so abundant that Spanish galleons could navigate in fog by following the sound of migrating herds, is fast becoming extinct.

title: Landrieu and Goldschmidt Stress 80 Politics Before Urban Officials
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 26  If President Carter has been failing, Moon Landrieu, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, told 4,000 of the nation's elected city officials today, it is because he hasn't attended to the political nature of the office but has rather involved himself on a daytoday basis with the fundamental governmental responsibilities of that office.

title: Bankers Trust Reduces Its Prime to 15%
description: The Bankers Trust Company reduced its prime lending rate yesterday to 15 percent from 15 percent and predicted that the move marked the beginning of a downward trend in interest rates.

title: Stage: Magnificent Christmas Spectacular Lights  Up Radio City Music Fall
description: RDIO City Music Hall Entertainment Center calls its holiday show The Magnificent Christmas Spectacular, and while you may quarrel a bit  without passion, really  with magnificent, you will have no trouble at all accepting spectacular. How do you like your Christmas? By Currier & Ives, Clement Moore or maybe the Rockettes? Radio City is doing it all, and giving you a mighty Wurlitzer organ, too.

title: Brennan Hires Clerks, Indicating He'll Stay
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 Associate Justice William J. Brennan Jr. has hired four law clerks for the Supreme Court's 198081 term, indicating that he does not plan to retire at the end of the current in June.

title: Jazz Plight Worries Other N.B.A. Clubs
description: When the National Basketball Association season began Commissioner Larry O'Brien told people in Salt Lake City: We in the N.B.A. will exercise patience, and I hope the people of Salt Lake City will, too. The Jazz are in Salt Lake City to stay. Patience? How much is possible?

title: Television
description: 5:50(5)New Zoo Revue

title: Ice Rink Fumes At Lake Placid Arouse Concern
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Nov. 26  when the air inside the new Olympic field house here was tested recently, it was found to contain carbon monoxide levels that the State of New York and some foreign countries, including the Soviet Union, considered unsafe for active athletes.

title: Spanish Leader Meets Giscard
description: PARIS, Nov. 26 (Reuters)  Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez of Spain met President Valry Giscard d'Estaing of France today and said he was satisfied there was a genuine desire for good relations between their countries.

title: Advertising
description: THERE are three stories concerning Real cigarettes, a lowtar entry from R.J. Reynolds, the country's largest tobacco company.

title: Trenton Democrats Pick Jackman As Assembly Speaker for 2d Term
description: TRENTON, Nov. 26 (AP)  Assembly Speaker Christopher Jackman of Hudson County was elected today by his fellow Democrats to an unprecedented second twoyear term as leader of the lower house.

title: Dollar at 2dear High in Tokyo
description: TOKYO, Nov. 26  The dollar touched a twoyear high of 249.90 yen in foreignexchange trading here today amid reports that Japanese companies are buying expensive oil from Iran. The dollar closed at 249.70 yen.

title: Taxes
description: TAXPAYERS who are reviewing the 1979 performance of their securities portfolios may wish to do some lastminute trading that could save them money.

title: Around the Nation
description: GREENSBORO, N.C., Nov. 26 (AP)  The police department has concluded that it made adequate and proper preparations for the Nov. 3 rally in opposition to the Ku Klux Klan rally in which five demonstrators were fatally shot.

title: S.E.C. Suing Gulf and Western, Charging Impropriety and Fraud
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26  The Securities and Exchange Commission, after a threeandahalfyear investigation, today charged Gulf and Western Industries and its chairman, Charles G. Bluhdorn, with improper financial reporting and other fraudulent courses of conduct.

title: Saudis Confirm Last of Attackers Are Cornered in Mosque Tunnels
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Nov. 26 (AP)  The Saudi Information Minister formally announced today that soldiers had cornered the Iast of the Moslem fanatics who occupied Mecca's Grand Mosque in the mosque's basement.

title: About NewYork
description: You can talk of seasonal change in terms of Jack Frost, due or overdue, of late winters and early summers, but the one season that is rolling in right on schedule is the fifth season that is New York's alone. It's the The Nutcracker season and it starts Saturday.

title: 2 Rookies Share Award
description: In the second tie vote of baseball's continuing season of honors, John Castino of the Minnesota Twins and Alfredo Griffin of the Toronto Blue Jays were named joint winners yesterday as rookie of the year in the American League.

title: Inbreeding Called Peril in Zoos
description: ZOOS and animal parks, heralded as the last hope for many kinds of animals that are becoming rare or extinct in the wild, are being threatened by an increasing rate of animal disease and mortality that results from constant inbreeding of the captive animals, a study of zoo populations has revealed.

title: Events
description: NIGHT AND DAY by Tom Stoppard. Directed by Peter Wood. Starring Maggie Smith. At the ANTA Theater, 245 West52d Street, 6:30.

title: Congressmen Tell of Anger and Frustration on Iran
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26  When Representative Stanley N. Lundine was at home for Thanksgiving in Corning, N.Y., he saw some graffiti at a local college that read Bomb Iran Into the Stone Age. Underneath was a second line, stating, That would be redundant.

title: Article 6 -- No Title
SAFEGUARDS URGED FOR PENSION FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26  A Senate investigations subcommittee recommended broad changes today in the laws and rules governing union pension and trust funds in order to protect such funds from looting by racketeers.

title: Joint Operation Backed For 2 Cincinnati Papers
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP)  The joint operation of The Cincinnati Post and The Cincinnati Enquirer was approved today by Attorney General Benjamin R. Civiletti. Mr. Civiletti, saying that the operation could begin Dec. 6, ruled that The Post was in probable danger of financial failure if the partial merger was blocked.

title: Films of Lubitsch Coming to the Thalia
description: The Thalia Theater, at West 95th Street off Broadway, will run an unusually comprehensive Thursdaynight retrospective on the films of Ernst Lubitsch, beginning this week.

title: But They Say He Won the Primary
description: The Presidentialprimary game has become an expectations game. The winner is the candidate who can best exceed expectations and predictions about his performance, whatever the objective outcome. The importance attached to these preelection projections has become so great that a candidate now runs against an expected percentage of the vote determined largely by popularity polls rather than against other candidates. This is desirable because it gives potentially worthy outsiders a crack at the nomination.

title: Iran to Cut Oil Output Next Year
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 26 Iran will decrease its daily oil production starting next year, the country's Oil Minister said here today, but he declined to say by how much.

title: Utah's Revolving Door
description: June 28 Signed Ben Poquette, center, and Allan Bristow, forward, free agents.

title: JUDGES TO CONSIDER JORDAN PROSECUTOR
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26  Three Federal appellate judges are expected to meet in New York tomorrow to consider

title: Science Watch
description: Warning on Breast Milk

title: turkey's Christians Fear Moslems Fervor
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 26  Turkey's Christians, a minority whose numbers are continuing to decline in this Moslem country, say they are concerned about the wave of extremism in some other Islamic countries and fear a spillover here.

title: Ceausescus Run Rumania With a Tight Family Rule
description: BUCHAREST, Rumania, Nov. 23  At the 12th congress of the Rumanian Communist Party, which ended here today, the unthinkable happened. An 80yearold delegate rose to say that Nicolae Ceausescu, the party chief, was not tackling Rumania's economic problems.

title: New Orders For Steel Are Strong
description: Orders for most steel products have been stronger than expected this fail, although industry executives still predict that there will be a significant decline in shipments in 1980.

title: Deaths
description: LAKEMerrill Millar Armstrong, of East Hampton, L.I., on November 25. Widow of Frederic Lake. Sister of Mrs. Frederick Bruenner, Mrs. Miller Graff, David Millar and John Y. Millar. Internent private. Contributions may be made to The Nature Conservancy, Box 410, Shelter Island, N.Y.11964.

title: Dr. Jacob Hetrick, 84, Led College
description: Dr. Jacob A. W. Hetrick, a former dean and president of the New York Medical College and FlowerFifth Avenue Hospital, died Saturday at a nursing home in Neptune, N.J., following a hip injury in September. He was 84 years old and lived in Brielle, N.J.

title: Thrown Derringer Kills Suspect
description: A derringer allegedly tossed away by a young burglary suspect to avoid a weapons charge went off and killed his compardon yesterday afternoon, according to the police, who said the youth was being held by two policemen when he was shot.

title: Harry N. Abrams, Publisher, Dies; A Pioneer With Quality Art Books
description: Harry N. Abrams, a pioneer in the popularizing and publishing of quality art books, died Sunday night at his home in New York. He was 74 years old.

title: COMMODITIES Futures Prices Swirl Amid Many Influences
description: Futures traders in precious metals responded to an unusually broad range of market influences yesterday. These included indications that interest rates might have peaked, expectations that the latest report on the Consumer Price Index, due today, would show another sharp rise and the strong rebound in the securities markets.

title: Dickens, With Soul, Tunes Up
description: IN a studio three flights up from an auto showroom on West 56th Street, 23 singers are belting out gospel to the tinny notes of a decrepit upright piano. Next door, dancers stomp and leap their way through Afro rhythms while a drum beats like a pulse in the brain. Down the hall, a man cringes from an advancing ghost.

title: The Region
description: MINEOLA, L.I.  The Nassau County District Attorney, Denis Dillon, accused County Executive Francis T. Purcell yesterday of gross insensitivity to the IrishAmerican people for letting a British Army bagpipe band perform in the Nassau Colisuem on Dec. 8. Mr. Dillon asked that future scheduled performances be canceled.

title: GEN. FRANK A ALLEN; SHAEF'S PRESS CHIEF
description: Maj. Gen. Frank A. Allen Jr., who was Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's press chief from September 1944 to July 1945, died last Tuesday at Walter Reed Hospital in Washington. He was 83 years old and lived in Washington.

title: Police Radar Examined Amid Debate
description: WHEN Florida police clocked a speeding banyan tree and a house moving at 28 miles an hour earlier this year, the reports sparked a court hearing and widespread questioning of what had previously been an accepted fact of life behind the wheel  the absolute accuracy of police radar. The hearing did in fact document radar's fallibility: 80 cases based on radar evidence were dismissed and Dade County police are now required to support the arrest of speeders by pacing them.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Obituary 4 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Tougher Windfall Tax Is Rejected by Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26  The Senate rejected today an attempt to substitute the House version of the windfall profits tax bill for its own bill, which would cost the oil industry only about half as much.

title: Judge Censured For Intervention In Weapon Case
description: A Manhattan Criminal Court judge was officially censured yesterday for improperly intervening in a criminal case involving a relative and then lying about the incident when questioned under oath.

title: Official at H.E.W. Resigns
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (UPI) Mary F. Berry, Assistant Secretary for Education at the Department of Health, Eduction and Welfare, today submitted her resignation, effective Jan. 31. Miss Berry, whose position will be abolished once the new Department of Education begins operations next year, joined the present department in 1977.

title: Billions at Stake in Coast Divorce Battle
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 26 (AP)  Theymet in Paris. He was a young Saudi Arabian businessman ready to take a wife. She was a teenage Briton tourins with her mother.

title: A 2China Plan for the Olympics
description: The International Olympic Commit.. tee has approved a resolution that assures China's return to Olympic competition for the first time in 32 years, but leaves Nationalist China's status in doubt.

title: A Landlord in Queens Pleads Guilty to Arson In LongRunning Case
description: Lying on a stretcher in a Queens courtroom with an oxygen mask and medical attendants at his side, a 67yearold landlord ended one of the longest criminal cases in the city yesterday with a surprise plea of guilty.

title: As Winter Nears, Flu Presents New Enigmas
description: PUBLIC health and virus specialists, often puzzled by the behavior of influenza, are especially baffled this year they gird for the annual winter war. Three flu viruses are circulating simultaneously, a profusion of different types that contradicts conventional wisdom.

title: Goldin Complains of Cohn Letter
description: Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin of New York City has asked the city's Department of Investigation to study a letter by the lawyer Roy Cohn that is highly critical of his office and that Mr. Goldin described as threatening in tone.

title: Article 3 -- No Title
description: MARYLAND POLICE BREAK STOLEN GOODS RING: Police officers leading a suspect in a large stolen goods ring into state police headquarters in Pikesvflie, Md. State police and Federal agents, working on an operation called Beartrap II, rounded up 71 suspects. In the undercover investigation, which lasted 17 months, agents bought goods valued at $1.5 million for about $99,000. Suspects in seven states were involved.

title: WALTER KOSLOSKI
description: LONG BRANCH, N.J., Nov. 26 (UPI)  Former State Assemblyman Walter Kosloski, a Democrat who lost his reelection bid this fall, died yesterday at the Monmouth Medical Center. He was 44 years old and had suffered for several months from a kidney infection.

title: Article 1 -- No Title
Throwing Matches in Iran
description: Predictably, some member of the Congress was bound to seek a cheap media ride on Ayatollah Khomeini's flowing coattails. The only surprise is the culprit: George Hansen, an Idaho Republican who is somewhere to the right of the fallen Shah of Iran. Representative Hansen is perhaps best remembered for his recent campaigns to wreck the Panama Canal treaties and to save the Somoza dictatorship in Nicaragua.

title: Carier Receives a Report On Atom Panel's Study
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (UPI)  President Carter today received a report from an advisory panel evaluating the nuclear safety recommendations of his commission on the Three Mile Island accident.

title: Robert Travis Dies at 73; Led G.M.Strike in 1936
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 26 (AP)  Robert Travis, who led a 44day sitdown strike against the General Motors Corporation that resulted in recognition of the United Automobile Workers, has died of cancer. He was 73 years old.

title: Rangers Soetaert Sent to Minors, Too
description: The Rangers goaltending situation got even more curious yesterday.

title: Deportation Proceedings For Iran Students Begin
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 26 (UPI)  Deportation proceedings began today be fore a Federal judge for dozens of Iranian students accused of violating their status.

title: IN THE NATION
description: While the world's attention has been riveted on Iran and the volatile world of Islam, a dangerous amount of tension has also been building up in southern Africa.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: NICE GOING With three personable young musicians at the piano bar of Bridges, the cocktail lounge off the lobby of the Sheraton Center, Seventh Avenue at 53d Street, makes a pleasant dropin spot these afternoons and evenings before or after a midtown show.

title: The Doctor's World
description: THE thud aboard the jumbo jet was startling. A man fell in the aisle near my seat. I responded immediately. By the time I knelt byhis side, he was conscious and sweating profusely. His pulse was weak. He had no pain. He had felt well all day as he worked in New York, but after dinner on the flight to San Francisco, he had suddenly felt queasy. He was walking to the toilet when he collapsed.

title: Floods in Colombia Kill 20
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Nov. 26 (Reuters)  At least 20 people were killed when the Playn and Lebrija rivers flooded three towns in northeastern Colombia last night, civil defense spokesmen said today. Playn, which has a population of 20,000, was hardest hit, with nearly 70 percent of the houses destroyed.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Thick frontal clouds are centered over a low pressure system In the western lake region and extend from western New England and the lower lake region to the Middle Atlantic States. Middle and low level cloudiness covers the upper Middle West and the Northwesl while stratified clouds stretch from the Northern Plains States to the Far West.

title: Soviet Mathematician Is Obscure No More
description: Moscow THE MYSTERY author of a new mathematical theorem that has rocked the world of computer analysis, lives.

title: OBSER VER Such Good Sports
description: It was just another day in the British Secret Service, and it began, as so many days did, with an appointment at Buckingham Palace. Her Majesty was surprised to find that her audience was with Q.

title: Notes on People
description: When the American Film Institute was founded in 1967, its organizers chose as its first fulltime director a man with an intimate knowledge of the movie industry, George Stevens Jr., son of the film director. Mr. Stevens announced his resignation last June, to go into movie production, and yesterday, in choosing his successor, the institute tapped Jean Firstenberg, who calls herself, like Mr. Stevens, a child of the film world.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Charles E. Rickershauser Jr., a lawyer and former California Corporations Commissioner, has been elected the first fulltime chairman of the Pacific Stock Exchange, the country's thirdlargest securities exchange. Mr. Rickershauser, 51 years old, has been serving as interim president and will officially take the new title after a constitutional change for the exchange is approved by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: United Artists East Plans Test of Revival Programs
description: The United Artists East theater, which plays contemporary movies, will feature revivalhouse programs for a special twoweek run, beginning Dec. 5. If this experiment is successful, the theater, at 85th Street and First Avenue, may become a fullfledged revival house next spring.

title: NO SURVIVORS FOUND IN PAKISTANI PLANE
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Nov. 26 (Reuters)  All 156 people aboard a Pakistan International Airlines jetliner, most of them pilgrims returning from Mecca, were killed today when the plane caught fire and crashed shortly after takeoff from Jidda airport, airline officials reported.

title: Concert: Los Angeles Philharmonic
description: EVER since Carlo Maria Giulini became the conductor of the Los Angeles Philharmonic, the orchestra has been coming to New York for an annual series. Los Angeles is proud of its music director. Last night in Carnegie Hall, Mr. Giulini and his cohorts gave the first of three consecutive concerts. Only two works were on the program  the Beethoven Pastoral Symphony and Dvorak's Dymphony No. 7 in D minor.

title: Restaurant in Waldorf Shedding Iranian Ties
description: The owners of Shah Abbas, who spent $2 million decorating their restaurant in the WaldorfAstoria Hotel, have decided that they cannot make a go of it any longer as an Iranian establishment. They informed their 40 employees yesterday that they would be laid off for the next few weeks until the restaurant can reopen under a new name, serving what was described as Mediterranean cuisine.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 27, 1979

title: World Gold
Can 90 Percent Be Most in Need?
description: In the days when the Treasury seemed a horn of plenty, Washington sprinkled urban aid money across nearly every Congressional district in the land. Assistance went even to wealthy suburbs like Westport, Conn., and tiny toy towns like Lone Jack, Mo. (pop. 350), which didn't need it.

title: Industry Spending: Moderate Rise Set
description: An increase in the spending plans of oil companies helped the nation's 1,000 largest manufacturers to record a moderate rise in capital appropriations in the third quarter, the Conference Board announced today.

title: Dr. Harold R. Smart Dead at 87; ExCornell Professor and Author
description: Dr. Harold R. Smart, professor emeritus of philosophy at Cornell University, died last Thursday at St. Francis Hospital in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., at the age of 87. He lived in Poughkeepsie.

title: The Pain of Being a Mormon Feminist
description: STERLING, Va., Nov. 23  Sitting in her cleanlined suburban living room, an hour's ride from Washington, Sonia Johnson, a 43yearold, fifthgeneration Mormon, compared her situation to that of Hester Prenne in Nathaniel Hawthorne's The Scarlet Letter.

title: EARNINGS Associated Dry Goods Profit Up 90.2%
description: The Associated Dry Goods Corportion, which operates Lord & Taylor, 15 other departmentstore chains and a specialtystore division, reported yesterday that its earnings in the third fiscal quarter, ended Nov. 3, rose 90.2 percent from the yearearlier level.

title: Corporate Reports
description: For periods as shown.(N) Indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Nixon Calls Ayatollah An Irrational Leader
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 26 (AP)  Former President Richard M. Nixon said last night that the United States was dealing with an irrational people and an irrational leader in Iran.

title: Punitive Steps Hinted
description: TOKYO, Nov. 26 (AP)  Japan is considering punitive measures against Japanese companies that purchase crude oil from Iran that has been diverted from the United States, officials said today.

title: Market Place
description: I midJuly, the THE Corporation, in announcing that it had purchased 5 percent of the shares of Wylain Inc., said that it might attempt to gain control of the manufacturer cf heating devices and Friedrich airconditioners.

title: Sports Today
description: Knicks vs. Detroit Pistons, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 7:30 P.M. (Television  Manhattan Cable, 7:30 P.M. Radio  WNEW, 7:30 P.M.)

title: Youth Is Held on $500,000 Bond In Attempted Hijacking to Iran
description: EL PASO, Tex., Nov. 26 (AP)  A Massachusetts teenager, released from the Army last month because he had had difficulties in basic training, was ordered held on $500,000 bond today on charges related to an attempted hijacking of a jetliner to Iran.

title: Auto Output Up in Japan
description: TOKYO, Nov. 26 (AP)  Japan's motor vehicle production in October totaled 911,936 units, up 12.4 percent from September and up 15.4 percent from October 1978, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said today.

title: The Case for Diversity At College of Detection
description: A professor at John Jay College of Criminal Justice was conducting a seminar the other day for 20 police officers, Federal agents and corporate security men on the subject of domestic terrorism.

title: Money
description: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 26, 1979

title: Double Danger for the F.B.I. Charter
description: Suddenly, after years of growing agreement that the Federal Bureau of Investigation should be governed by a clear legal charter, the time for Congressional action seems short. If major issues are not settied before the Presidential campaign heats up, the charter will be in double danger. Some legislators will load it with pet provisions. Others, preoccupied with national politics, will be tempted to let it slide.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Iran Tries to Prove Allegations A bout Shah
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 26  In an effort to put pressure on Washington to extradite the deposed Shah, Iran began tonight to publicize some of what it said were the findings of an investigation into the financial dealings of the Shah, his family and associates.

title: BUSINESS
description: TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 27, 1979

title: Obituary 5 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Article 7 -- No Title
description: 76ERS DEFEAT PACERS: Maurice Cheeks of 76ers scoring over Dudley Bradley, left, and Johnny Davis of Indiana in Philadelphia's 113112 victory.

title: Poltier to Direct Comedy, First Film for Columbia
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 26  As the first film on the fouryear contract he signed with Columbia 10 months ago, Sidney Poitier will direct a biting comedy starring Gene Wilder and Richard. Pryor. Tentatively titled Prison Rodeo, the movie  about two entertainers mistakenly imprisoned as bank robbers at a jail where the warden sponsors rodeos  will go into production in February. Mr. Poitier was one of the first black actors to cross the color line as a hero

title: Profit Up 545% At Caesars World
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 26 (UPI)  Aided by the first full quarter's results from operations of its new casino in Atlantic City, Caesars World Inc. reported today that its earnings in the first fiscal quarter, ended Oct. 31, rose 545 percent.

title: Q &
description: Q. At what temperature does frost  form and why?

title: Bank Under Arab Aegis Sues Iran
description: The UBAF Arab American Bank of New York, which is controlled by Arab interests and whose chairman is the Minister of Finance of Iraq, has sued Iran to recover $2 million the bank had lent to that country.

title: Unorthodox Idaho Congressman
description: WASHING TON, Nov. 26  The assessment of official Washington today of Representative George Hansen and his selfappointed peace mission to Iran was only slightly less blunt than that of a Federal judge who declared from the bench four years ago that Mr. Hansen was not necessarily evil but was stupid, surely.

title: Supreme Court Roundup Curb on Abortion Payments for Poor Faces Review
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26  The Supreme Court announced today that would hear arguments on whether it is constitutional for the Federal Government to refuse to pay for abortions for poor women whose doctors believe the procedure to be medically necessary.

title: About Education
description: IN 1975, Isaac Lora sued the New York Board of Education for having placed his child in one of the city's special day schools for the emotionally handicapped. This relatively obscure complaint by a single black parent eventuany set in motion the largest staff retraining program in the history of American public education. By next week, its impact will have been felt in every one of the city's 950 schools. By the end of the year, all 70,000 members of the system's staff, beginning with the Chancellor, will have been reached.

title: Man in AlimonyEquality Decision Back in High Court With New Plea
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26  Husbands are now legal equals in divorce disputes, but the man who won that equality has returned to the Supreme Court with a new grievance.

title: Soviet Foreign Minister Meets Iranian Ambassador in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 26 (AP)  Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union met today with Ambassador Mohammad Mokri of Iran, the Soviet press agency Tass reported.

title: Hong Kong Trade Deficit
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 26 (Reuters) Hong Kong recorded a visible trade deficit equal to about $236 million in United States currency in October compared with September's deficit of about 6119 million and $117 million in October [978, according to provisional government figures released today. Total exports in October rose to $1.42 billion from $1.41 billion in September, while imports rose to $1.65 billion from $1.53 billion the previous month, the Government said.

title: Deaths
description: ABRAMSHarry N. Beloved husband of Nina. Devoted father of Michael and Robert. Dear brother of Betty Tuck and George. Beloved grandfather of Joshua, Daniel, Jordana and Benjamin. Services Tuesday 2pm Central Synagogue, Lexington Ave. at 55th St.

title: Recital. Pedro Firpo
description: PEDRO FIRPO, a pianist from Buenos Aires, played an incomprehensibly bland and thoroughly mediocre recital at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday night. Perhaps he was put off by an audience that interrupted with applause after every movement of Debussy's Suite Bergamasque and Children's Corner Suite, and even between movements of Chopin's Sonata in B minor (Op. 58). Or possibly he was merely out of sorts. In any event, Mr. Firpo rattled through the Debussy without showing much awareness of the poetic fragility of each piece and with little suggestion of this music's stylistic individuality.

title: Bus Pass Sales Set Record
description: HARTFORD, Nov. 26 (AP)  Sales of Connecticut commuter bus passes again have set a record, state officials said today. The economic crunch caused by increasing gasoline prices was cited by Transportation Commissioner Arthur B. Powers as the impetus behind the rise.

title: ABCTV to Introduce 6 Series for Midseason
description: ABCTV yesterday announced midseason changes in its schedule, includine six new primetime series. There will be two comedies, two comedyadventures, a detective drama and an informational magazine program. No dates were announced, but all the changes are to take place early next year, according to Anthony D. Thomopoulos, president of ABC Entertainment.

title: IRAN BIDS U.N. DELAY DEBATE FOR A WEEK
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 26  A spokesman for the Revolutionary Council, Iran's secretive ruling body, said today that it needed to clarify its positions for a Security Council debate and that it had asked the United Nations to delay a proposed meeting for a week.

title: Rider, 17, Is a Top Prospect
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 26  Horse racing enthusiasts maintain that the mettle of a jockey cannot be determined until that rider has been thrown from a horse and returns to ride capably and win. Karen Rogers, a softspoken, frecklefaced, teenager, and one of the leading jockeys at Meadowlands Race Track, took her first spill at the age of 3.

title: Article 2 -- No Title
Storm Raises Roof of Motel
description: Lashing rains and wailing winds that belied another unseasonably mild day slowed air and highway travel, caused scattered power failures, tore off part of a motel roof and reduced scores of umbrellas to junk in the New York metropolitan area vesteray.

title: Obituary 7 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Occidental Dividend Up
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 26 (Reuters)  The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said today that it would increase its annual dividend to $1.50 from $1.25 a share. It said that the board of directors had declared the next quarterly dividend of 37 cents, payable Jan. 15 to holders of record Dec. 10.

title: Bergland to Hear Ideas On the Future of Farms
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (UPI)  Agriculture Secretary Bob Bergland, who has called for a national dialogue on the future of the familyowned farm and rural America, will preside at three hearings this week and listen to Americans ideas.

title: Japanese Return to a Traditional Heating Method
description: TOKYO, Nov. 26  Japan's growing energy crunch, intensified by new threats to vital oil supplies as political turmoil spreads in the Middle East, has caused an increasing number of Japanese to revert to traditional, if less efficient, ways of keeping warm in the cold winter months.

title: NATIONS NOT NAMED Move Called Precautionary  Embassies Plan to Continue Activities
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26  The United States has told its embassies in about 10 Moslem countries to evacuate voluntarily dependents, nonessential diplomats and private businessmen to minimize risks in the aftermath of events in Iran, Pakistan and Saudi Arabia, the State Department said today.

title: Veteran Exposed To Atomic Tests Is Given Benefits
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 26  A former United States Army sergeant who developed cancer years after expnsure to radiation from atomic weapons tests today became the first known veteran to wiry Federal benefits in a case in which the cancer had been diagnosed after the victim left the military.

title: HAITIAN DISSIDENTS FEAR HARSHER LINE
description: PORTAUPRINCE, Haiti, Nov. 25  After protests by the United States and other countries whose diplomats were slapped or beaten along with hundreds of other people at a recent human rights rally, Haiti's Government said this week that it would set up a human rights section in its Department of Foreign Affairs.

title: Abu Dhabi to Cut Output Of Oil 15% Starting in '80
description: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates, Nov. 26  Abu Dhabi will reduce its oil production about 5 percent, or about 75,000 barrels a day, at the beginning of 1980 because of technical difficulties, Mani Said alOtaiba, the Oil Minister of the United Arab Emirates, said today.

title: SelfStyled Leaders Bar Cambodians From Safe Haven
description: SISOPHON DISTRICT, Cambodia, Nov. 26 Selfappointed leaders of more than 400,000 Cambodians camped along the Thai border are preventing them from crossing into Thailand to seek shelter in a huge holding center.

title: Taxi Drivers in Brazil Strike
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Nov. 26 (UPI) Thousands of taxi drivers in Brazil's major cities, including Sao Paulo and Rio de Janeiro, stopped work today to protest a 58 percent increase in gasoline prices, effective today, that raised the price of regular gasoline to $2.70 a gallon.

title: Stage: Van Itallie's Bag Lady, a Soul of Imagination
description: THE title, and only, character in JeanClaude van Itallie's Bag Lady, at the Theater for the New City. is both a migratory bird and a squatter. In common with her sisters who inhabit New York street corners, she carries her household with her, jamming clothes, food and personal mementos into shopping bags.

title: E.E.C. in Talks With Comecon
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 26 (Reuters)  Officials of the European Economic Community and Comecon, the trade organization of the Communist bloc, met here today for talks on a cooperation agreement.

title: Dowell Will Be Host Of Dance Gala Tonight
description: Anthony Dowell, principal dancer with England's Royal Ballet and the American Ballet Theater, will be the host at a gala tonight at b o'clock at the EnglishSpeaking Union, 16 East 69th Street. The event will benefit the

title: Dow Jumps 16.98 in Heavy Turnover
description: Stock prices soared yesterday amid heavy trading in response to signs of easing in shortterm interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average jumped 16.98 points to 828.75, registering its strongest advance in more than two months.

title: INTEREST COSTS DIP, INSPIRING BIG RALLY IN PRICES OF STOCKS
description: Interest rates dropped sharply yesterday amid widening speculation that they have passed their peaks and are now headed downward.

title: Theft Estimate In Mayfair Case Passes $250,000
description: Detectives of the East 67th Street station house yesterday raised estimates of cash and jewelry stolen from safe deposit boxes at the Mayfair Regent Sunday from $100,000 to more than $250,000.

title: Nicaragua Tries Economic Cure
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua  The new revolutionary Government here, apparently still determined to honor the bulk of the foreign debts inherited from the ousted Somoza regime, has now charted a way out of the disastrous financial situation it assumed in midJuly.

title: Why Willie Classen Is in Bellevue Hospital
description: Exhausted even in triumph, Muhammad Ali had remained in his dressing room for about an hour after the Thrills in Manila with Joe Frazier four years ago. When he finally emerged, stiff and sore, Ali mumbled, What you saw tonight was next to death. In boxing, death is always lurking in the next round, sometimes in the next punch. And now a 29yearold Puerto Rican middleweight named

title: MissileBase Solar Power Planned
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP)  The Energy and Defense Departments outlined a joint project today to power a vast missilebase complex with solar and wind power and other renewable energy sources.

title: Seahawks, on Passing of Zorn, Overwhelm Jets by 307
description: SEATTLE, Nov. 26  They did not need trick plays or onside kickoffs or faked punts. All the Seattle Seahawks needed tonight in front of 59,977 fans and a natienal television audience was the generous New York Jets defense.

title: U.S. Inquiry Is Sought By Expatriate Cubans On Systematic Terror
description: A group of CubanAmericans eager to promote a dialogue with the Government of Fidel Castro called on Federal authorities yesterday to investigate a systematic campaign of terror against them by antiCastro terrorists whom they blamed for the shooting death Sunday of Eulalio Jos Negrin.

title: Films to Reflect The New Spain
description: New Spanish Cinema, a film festival reflecting the changed, less restrictive atmosphere of the postFranco years in Spain, will be presented from Jan. 11 to 17 at the Beacon Theater, Broadway and 74th Street. The 16 films will demonstrate that such topics as the church, the army, sexual relations and the Spanish Civil War itself, subject to severe censorship when allowed at all under the Franco regime, may now be treated frankly and often with humor in films.

title: EDUCATION Wrestling With Meaning Of Black English
description: WHAT is black English? A language unto itself, as claimed this past summer by two young lawyers working for a public interest law firm in Michigan? Or a dialect, as asserted by most of the linguists who testified in a Federal case that ran almost a month in the Detroit courtroom of Judge Charles W. Joiner?

title: The U.N. Today
description: Meets at 11 A.M. and 3 P.M. on Palestinian question.

title: Letters
description: So, now we have acid rain [Acid Rain: An Increasing Threat, Nov. 6] among our afflictions  in addition to an energy crisis, a balance of payments deficit and extortion by a religious fanatic. The irony is that the same medicine can cure all of them, plus a number of lesser ills. It's called conservation.

title: Article 4 -- No Title
UV Industries Accepts surprise New Posner did
description: A bidding war for UV Industries between Victor Posner and Saul P. Steinberg  both seeking UV's $306 million in cash assetsended abruptly yesterday with a surprise second bid by Mr. Posner of $518 million and UV's acceptance after about 10 hours of intense deliberation. Directors, it was understood, leaned toward Mr. Posner's offer as early as 1 A.M. yesterday.

title: White House pastry Chef to Leave After a Year
description: Albert Kucnin, who has been the pastry chef at the White House since February, will be leaving that post at the end of January. The Swissborn pastry chef, whose incomparable cakes and desserts earned him his reputation at such New York restaurants as the Four Seasons and Windows on the World, will return to the staff of the Culinary Institute of America in Hyde Park, N.Y.

title: Chicago Bus Crash Injures 31
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 26 (UPI)  A bus crowded with holiday travelers returning from O'Hare International Airport skidded out of control in rain on the Kennedy Expressway and slammed into a concrete retaining wall last night, injuring 31 persons, one critically. The police said that the Continental Air Transport Company bus had swerved out of control in the slippery southbound lanes of the expressway as it rounded a curve.

title: Soviet Buys More U.S. Corn
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP)  The Soviet Union has bought an additional 500,000 metric tons of United States corn for delivery in the coming year, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: An Approach to Difficult Problems
description: Mathematicians disagree as to the ultimate practical value of Leonid Khachiyan's new technique, but concur that in any case it is an important theoretical accomplishment.

title: The Gnostics' Writings
description: In December 1945, near Nag Hammadi in Upper Egypt, an Arab peasant made an astonishing archeological discovery. What he found, hidden in an earthenware jar, were some 52 ancient papyrus texts, including gospels and other secret writings attributed to Jesus and his disciples. The texts contained sayings, poems, myths, philosophical treatises and instructions for mystical practice, all Coptic translations from Greek originals, some dating from the beginning of the Christian Era  the period when the New Testament Gospels themselves were written.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: 21 Bombs Believed Set By the I.R.A Explode In Ulster, Wounding 5
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Nov. 26 (AP)  At least 21 bombs exploded in Belfast and other Northern Ireland centers today in what the police described as a coordinated blitz by Irish Republican Army guerrillas.

title: Koch Is Hopeful Carey Will Join Carter's Support
description: Mayor Koch and Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, both of whom have announced support for President Carter's reelection, said yesterday that they would be surprised if Governor Carey endorsed anyone other than the President for the 1980 election.

title: Jarvis Submits Petitions For New Coast Tax Cut
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 26 (AP)  A new assault on taxation in California by Howard Jarvis, co author of Proposition 13, advanced today as petitions to place another taxcut measure before the state's voters were submitted statewide.

title: Nablus Mayor's Hearing Delayed
description: TEL AVIV, Nov. 26  A judicial hearing for a West Bank Mayor threatened with deportation was put off today amid reports that the Israeli Government was exploring a possible compromise in the case.

title: Protester Guilty Of Trespassing At Indian Point
description: BUCHANAN, N.Y., Nov. 26The first of 150 antinuclear protesters to go on trial here on charges of trespassing at Consolidated Edison's Indian Point power plant last Aug. 5 was found guilty today and then released unconditionally by a Cortland town judge.

title: Obituary 3 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: On Safety Patrol at Nuclear Site
description: SHOREHAM, L.I.  The workers perched on the scaffolds make their own weather inside the nuclear power plant they are building here. Flashes of welders' lightning streak down the walls as red sparks shower through the grids, and blueprints are carried off in the tornadoes whirling out of ventilating fans deep in the core.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Cyanamid Company, Wayne, N.J., a manufacturer of chemicals, drugs and agricultural and consumer products, has elected Paul C. Baker a group vice president, responsible for the consumer products business.

title: City to Get Methane From Refuse
description: New York City entered into a contract yesterday for commercial development of methane gas from its sanitary landfill at Fresh Kills in Staten Island. The gas will be fed into the Brooklyn Union Gas Company's network by March 1982.

title: 3 Different Neighborhoods, 3 New Men's Stores
description: The boom in men's boutiques, which accelerated in the 1960's and slowed down in the 70's as department stores began creating their own designer areas, is under way again. In recent months, shops featuring clothing and accessories for men are again proliferating in all areas of the city. For the most part the new boutiques are indigenous to their neighborhoods.

title: Canadian Doctor to Aid In Shah's Gallstone Case
description: A Canadian radiologist is expected to help remove a gallstone from the deposed Shah, medical sources said yesterday.

title: High Court to Decide Issue of Utility Ads
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26  The Supreme Court expanded its review of the freespeech rights of regulated utilities today by agreeing to decide whether a utility can be prohibited from undertaking promotional advertising to increase uemanu for its product.

title: Five Iranian Students Indicted on Firearms Counts
description: BALTIMORE, Nov. 26  A Federal grand jury today indicted six young Iranians, including five college students who have been held in high bail for 10 days since their arrest at BaltimoreWashington International Airport. The five were held for what Federal agents have described as a bungled plan to smuggle guns to Iran.

title: Canada's Synthetic Fuel: Costs Arouse Concern
description: FORT McMURRAY, Alberta  In this tar sands region, Canadians are developing a synthetic fuels industry like the type many energy specialists expect the United States to adopt. Many, but not all.

title: Focus of Search for Aliens Shifts From Home to Job
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26  Attorney General Benjamin R. Civiletti today ordered immigration officers to focus on employment sites rather than residences when they search for illegal or undocumented aliens.

title: Associated Press
World News Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (UPI)  The State Department said today that a New Zealand observatory had revised its findings about evidence of a nuclear blast in the Southern Hemisphere, and the mystery about a possible atomic bomb test persists.

title: Police Officer Honored at City Hall
description: Police Officer Michael Mullick was joined by son, Kevin, and daughter, Shannon, in a reflective moment at City Hall yesterday after receiving an award from Mayor Koch. Officer Mullick's legs were severed May 31 by a car driven by a drunken driver. Doctors reattached his left leg in a sevenhour operation. Police Commissioner Robert J. McGuire said presentation was a way of emphasizing to him that the entire city is behind him.

title: October Chain Sales Up 6.3%
description: October sales of the nation's leading retail chains were 6.3 percent higher than sales in October 1978, according to data supplied by Chain Stores Age, a trade publication.

title: Dispute Erupts Over Plan for Navy to Build Two $900 Million Destroyers
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26  As the Carter Administration nears its deadline for producing a new military budget, a bitter argument nas aevelopea oernnu one scenes between senior naval officers and civilian budget officials over what warships the Navy should build.

title: Baseball Owners Are Silenced On Player Contract Negotiations
description: Major league baseball's club owners have, according to management sources, have established fines of up to $500,000 for any management person who talks publicly about the negotiations now in progress with the Players Association for the new collectivebargaining agreement.

title: Former S.L.A. Member Tells of the Group's Early Days
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 26  An early member of the Symbionese Liberation Army, Robyn Sue Steiner, who fled while the group was planning the 1979 kidnapping of Patricia Hearst, has emerged from hiding to tell the story of her days with the terrorist group.

title: The City
description: A preliminary city investigation into the snapping of cables of a crowded elevator in a West Side hotel concluded yesterday that the elevator's safety mechanism operated properly in slowing the falling car. Ten passengers on the elevator were treated at hospitals for minor injuries after the accident Saturday.

title: Dr. Charles Stewart, 56, A Professorat Columbia
description: Dr. Charles F. Stewart, a professor of business and international affairs at Columbia University since 1960, died of a heart attack Iast Thursday at his home in Ridgewood, N.J. He was 56 years old.

title: Bridge:
description: CINCINNATI, Nov. 26  An exciting national team championship, matching in tension last month's world championship in Rio de Janiero, ended in the early hours today with two winners.

title: Books of The Times
description: FOR gracious giving this year, I'd suggest ...

title: LANDLORD UNIT SETS RENT LAW PENALTIES
description: The association that represents the owners of 850,000 rentstabilized apartments in New York City said yesterday that it would mete out harsh penalties to landlords who violate rent limits. The association said it was acting in response to a sharp increase in complaints from tenants alleging rent overcharges.

title: A Carter Aide Accuses Oil Companies on Prices
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26  A study by a White House energy aide has charged that the few major American oil companies with access to foreign petroleum supplies have diverted crude oil bought under contract to the higherpriced spot market and have increased markups to other domestic refiners.

title: Prisoner Who Violated Inmates Code Fears Death
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Nov. 26 (AP)  Jim Maslinski said that he could endure no more death threats from fellow inmates, so he fled from prison, married and took a job.

title: Homosexual Foster Children Sent to Lesbian Homes
description: TRENTON, Nov. 26  The New Jersey Department of Human Services said today that in the last four years it had placed five to 10 male and female homosexual teenagers with behavior problems in foster homes headed by lesbians.

title: Mobile Home Fire Kills 4 Boys
description: KIMPER, Ky., Nov. 26 (UPI)  A fire in a mobile home killed four boys in their beds early today. The victims were identified as Gary C. Morley, one year old; his brother, Jason, 2, and Sidney Wayne Casey, 8, and his brother, Fletcher, 9. A teenager who was looking after them escaped unhurt. Deputy Coroner Jerry Bee said the fire apparently started in the kitchen, but no cause was determined.

title: Patriotic Front Ignores Deadline On Rhodesia CeaseFire Demand
description: LONDON, Nov. 26 (Reuters)  The leaders of the Patriotic Front guerrilla alliance ignored a deadline set for today by the British chairman of the Zimbabwe Rhodesia conference for a ceasefire agreement but further meetings between the sides were planned.

title: Giants' Taylor Earns Start Against Dallas
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 26  Billy Taylor and Emery Moorehead, two football players who developed a friendship in the hardship of a professional training camp, were hoping that some day they could be the starting backfield for the Giants.

title: Officials Bemoan State of Queens Zoo
description: Unfazed by stormy weather, community and state representatives made a walking tour yesterday of the Queens Zoo to protest what they perceive as its deterioration and insufficient financing.

title: O.A.S. Opposes Iranian Action
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (UPI)  The Organization of American States today urged Iran to order the release of the 49 Americans in the United States Embassy in Teheran.

title: U.S. ASKS PARTIAL EVACUATION OF CITIZENS IN MOSLEM LANDS; U.N. ARGUES OVER IRANSESSION
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 26  The Security Council put off until tomorrow the urgent meeting requested by Secretary General Kurt Waldheim and aimed at helping free the hostages in the American Embassy in Teheran.

title: City May Cut Back on Filling Jobs To Save $11 Million in Fiscal Year
description: Mayor Koch's administration is considering filling fewer vacant jobs than anticipated in the last six months of this fiscal year to save $11 million.

title: Chase Sets 15% Prime; Most Banks Stay at 15%
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank announced yesterday that it had lowered its prime lending rate by half a percentage point to 15 percent from the record level of 15 percent.

title: Court Places Two Bengals In FirstOffender Program
description: BURLINGTON, Ky., Nov. 27 (AP) Two Cincinnati Bengal football players accused of evading payment of airport parking bills were placed in a special court program for first offenders today.

title: Children's Clothes From All Ages
description: CENE from April 1830, Outdoor Games: A spacious lawn with house and dog in the background. A child plays with hoop. Two boys are in skeleton suits with tops buttoned onto trousers for onepiece effect. A girl is in a cotton print dress with drop shoulders, puffedout sleeves, a raised waist and a full skirt.

title: Corporate Reports
description: For periods as shown.(N) Indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchangeand (O) over-the-counter.

title: Fires Sweep Central Australia
description: ALICE SPRINGS, Australia, Nov. 27 (Reuters)  Bush fires, mostly started by lightning and covering thousands of square miles, are sweeping out of control across central Australia, fire authorities said today. Pilots flying over the Tanami Desert Wildlife Sanctuary north of here reported a blaze covering some 300 square miles.

title: AnheuserBusch Offering Catalogue
description: AnheuserBusch Inc., the nation's largest brewer, announced yesterday that it would enter the directmail marketing business by offering a catalogue of merchandise bearing the emblems of its beer brands.

title: Feeding the Unborn: Some Diet Wisdom For MotherstoBe
description: THERE is probably no time in life when good nutrition is more crucial to your future than when you can least control what you eat  before you are born. Your grandmother was right: a pregnant woman is indeed eating for two. But what she eats is even more important than how much.

title: 4 Drown as Cars Fall Into a Creek
description: At least four men, including a worldclass American bobsledder, were killed Monday night when a road collapsed and sent their vehicles into a rainswollen stream about 20 miles east of Lake Placid, N.Y. The bobsledder, Dr. Thomas F. Tanneberger, 30, was a candidate for the United States bobsled team in the upcoming Olympics. Rescue workers were searching for a fifth man still missing and presumed dead. Article, page B2.

title: CBS First in TV Ratings As ABC Drops to Third
description: Stunned by two strong movies on the rival networks Sunday night, one of the heaviest viewing nights of the season, ABCTV finished third in the Nielsen ratings last week, its poorest competitive showing since July of last year.

title: Iran Aide Says Gromyko Supports the Revolution
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 27  Ambassador Mohammed Mokri of Iran said today that Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko had expressed moral support for the Iranian revolution in a twohour meeting yesterday and had not brought up the issue of the American hostages.

title: Curb on Selling Feathers Upheld
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27  In Washington, as in nature, birds of a feather flock together.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS Going Into Labor
description: ARDMORE, Ireland  Ever since anyone under the age of 50 can remember, it has seemed to many expert observers everywhere that the British Labor Party was about either to fall apart or blow up. The fact that it has not happened yet is no proof that it never will. The English lord in Ernest Hemingway's novel The Sun Also Rises, when asked how he came to go bankrupt, answered two ways  first gradually and then suddenly. The same can happen to an institution.

title: Bavaria's Return of 2 Czech Escapees Stirs Storm
description: BONN, Nov. 27  Franz Josef Strauss, Bavaria's Minister President, a conservative candidate to become West German Chancellor and a politician known for his antiCommunist views, was forced onto the defense this week because of a disclosure that two Czechoslovaks seekine asylum had been deported.

title: Body of a Woman Dead for Years Found in Her Family's Apartment
description: The police yesterday found the body of a woman whose corpse had been kept in a sealed bedroom in her Bronx apartment by her son and grandson. The grandson told the authorities that the woman had died in January 1976 at the age of 86, according to the police.

title: Nets Win, 11893; Newlin Scores 35
description: MILWAUKEE, Nov. 27  Even with a I5point lead, 8570, at the end of the  third quarter of tonight's game against the Milwaukee Bucks, the New Jersey Nets did not let up  they had squandered too many similar leads in the final period in recent weeks.

title: Nablus Mayor Bars Any Compromise With Israelis
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 27  Bassam al Shaka, the Palestinian Mayor of Nablus who is in prison pending his deportation from the occupied West Bank, said today that he would not compromise with the Israeli Government as a way of softening the punishment directed against him.

title: TV: Two Hootenannies
description: IN honor of hogkillin time and sweeps month, CBS is presenting backtoback hootenannies tonight. From 9 to 10 o'clock, there's The Unbroken Circle, a salute to the late Maybelle Carter, the matriarch of the performing clan. Kenny Rogers and the American Cowboy will be seen from 10 to 11.

title: Oil Group Revises Inventory Figures
description: The American Petroleum Institute said yesterday that a computer error caused it to underestimate supplies of heating oil, gasoline and other petroleum products by several million barrels in its weekly tally last week.

title: Careers
description: FAMILYOWNED businesses abound in this country, totaling about 10 million. They employ about 44 million people and their sales volume reaches $1 trillion, according to a trade association called the National Family Business Council.

title: Chess:
description: For some years, in the opinion of Labs Portisch's rivals, that Hungarian grandmaster has not felt comfortable in unclear tactical battles in which he cannot make use of his fine logical positional play. However, a significant sprinkling of his recent games contradict this judgment.

title: Wine Talk
description: MARCELLO sat before the fireplace of his house in Tuscany in the hills above Florence, dipping pieces of lightly toasted bread into a saucer of fresh, warm olive oil and passing them to his guests. He was talking about Chianti, the great wine of the region, and he was telling how proud he was of his 1974 riserva, a fullbodied red that promised to be one of his best. It was aging in oak casks and would remain there for at least three years to merit the riserva designation that would set it apart as superior to most other Chiantis.

title: Private Lives
description: THE phone rang. It was a fancy new phone, salmoncolored, like a skinned squirrel, with push buttons on its belly and an extension cord instead of a tail. She could walk around the apartment with her phone, her pet. She could talk to them, whoever they were, while rummaging in the refrigerator for a stalk of celery or curled on the window seat, looking down at the stumps of people on the avenue, with burning leaves in her mouth. Every telephone needs a princess.

title: Article 4 -- No Title
Plan for South Street Market Leaves a Wake of Dissension
description: The Square Rigger Bar goes to sleep early, down on Front Street near the East River, but it comes to sociable, individualistic life several times a day.

title: Now a Word About the Malpeque
description: The Belon is all very well, and everyone who enjoys oysters will welcome any addition to the brief list of oysters available in New York. (In better times the list went on and on: Rappahannocks, Saddle Rocks, Goose Creeks, Narragansetts, Lvnnhavens, Buzzards Bays.)

title: British Air Fares Rise
description: LONDON, Nov. 27 (Reuters)  Britain's Civil Aviation Authority said today that it had granted air fare increases of 10 percent for British Airways, Air Anglia, British Caledonian, British Island Airways, British Midland and DanAir. It said the increases, effective next Monday, were to cover rising costs, including fuel.

title: Gulf Lease Sale Draws $1.9 Billion
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 27 (AP)  A Federal sale of sea bottom oildrilling leases in the Gulf of Mexico, expected to be routine, drew $1.9 billion in high bids today.

title: Best Buys
description: WHEN planning the December budget, consumers had best prepare for the worst. Food costs continue to rise, and although some food items  such as pork and poultry, eggs, nuts and grains  are now quite plentiful, price increases on other staple foods will wipe out any anticipated savings.

title: Transcript of Khomeini's Attack
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27  Following is a transcript of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's statement today on the Security Council and the American hostages. It was broadcast in Persian by Teheran radio and monitored and translated by the United States Foreign Broadcast Information Service.

title: Shopping Tips for Newcomers
description: Shopping tips for newcomers and native New Yorkers alike:

title: Real Estate
description: THE industrialized waterfront of Staten Island along the Kill van KuH opposite Bayonne is usually associated with shipping and shipyards. Over the years a Bethlehem Steel shipyard has come and gone. The Howland Hook terminal for containerized shipping holds forth in Mariner's Harbor.

title: A Decision on G.M. engines Reversed by Appeals Court
description: The New York Court of Appeals reversed a lower court yesterday and said General Motors did not necessarily have to make payments to thousands of unknowing New York residents who purchased 1977 model cars with substitute engines. It was a significant victory for G.M.

title: Antuofermo to Battle Odds, Toi
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 27  The signs are pasted everywhere, on the men'sroom door, elevators and even the dressing room of Vito Antuofermo, the only middleweight boxing champion this world has.

title: US. STEEL IS CLOSING 15 PLANTS, WITH CUT OF 13,000 EMPLOYEES
description: The United States Steel Corporation announced yesterday that it was closing 15 plants and mills in eight states. About 13,000 production and whitecollar workers will lose their jobs.

title: TV RATINGS
description: Following are the top 15 national television shows of the past week (Monday, Nov. 19, to Sunday, Nov. 25), listed according to their rank In the ratings cornpiled by the A.C. Nielsen Company. A rating is a percentage of the total number of United States households with television sets.

title: New Head of Japan Bank
description: TOKYO, Nov. 27 (AP)  Haruo Mayekawa, the deputy governor of the Bank of Japan, was chosen by the Government today to be governor of the central bank. He will succeed Teiichiro Morinaga, who will step down when his fiveyear term expires next month. A spokesman for Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira said that Satoshi Sumita, former president of Japan's ExportImport Bank, was named to take the deputy governorship of the central bank. The appointment of the two officials will be effective Dec. 17 following Cabinet approval, the spokesman said.

title: Economic Scene
description: RESTRICTIVE monetary and fiscal policy in the United States, aimed at bringing down the rate of inflation and defending the dollar, has not been blown off course by the Iranian crisis.

title: Rally by Knicks Subdues Pistons
description: As Ray Williams and Michael Ray Richardson go, so go the Knicks. The young backcourt combination that scores, rebounds, piles up assists and makes steals  and sometimes makes crucial mistakes  came on strong in the late stages of the game last night and led the Knicks to a 116114 overtime victory over the Detroit Pistons at Madison Square Garden.

title: What the U.N. Will Expose
description: This may be the week in which the United Nations finally demonstrates whether it has become merely a place or still functions as an institution. Secretary General Waldheim has summoned the Security Council to consider a grave threat to the peace. In fact, there is no threat so long as the United States cares more for its hostages than for retribution. The greater danger is that the United Nations will be exposed as utterly helpless, unable to speak even for the most elementary ingredient of diplomacy: the safety of diplomats.

title: Experts Tie Teton Darn Collapse to Poor Filler Soil
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27  Soil that was unusually susceptible to erosion was used to fill the earthen core of the Teton Dam in Idaho and was an aggravating factor causing the dam's collapse in 1976, a panel of experts has concluded.

title: Ohira Says He'll Fight Corruption
description: TOKYO, Nov. 27  Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira, in a policy speech at the opening of a new session of Parliament today, pledged his Government to an attack on official corruption and other malfeasances by Japanese in high places that have brought widespread criticism.

title: Market Place
description: INVESTORS paying heavy taxes who seek high yields with safety may wish to consider a new issue of Housing and Urban Development project notes.

title: Blind Cairo Sheik Rallies Poor With Fiery Islamic Creed
description: CAIRO Nov. 27  At noon on a recent Friday in Cairo's decaying central district of Hadayik elQuba, a blind man wearing a white skullcap and gownlike blue galabia stepped before a microphone at the Ein elHayat Mosque and lamented the inequities of contemporary Egvpt.

title: IRAN SHOWS PAPERS IN BANKING INQUIRY
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 27  More than $6 million was transferred out of Iran into secret numbered bank accounts in Switzerland and elsewhere by members of the Shah's family months before he was deposed in January, according to Iranian bank documents.

title: Desertions and Disrepair Said to Hit Iran's Army
description: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini has ordered the mobilization of a vast civilian force to do the work of the Imperial Iranian Armed Forces, sapped by desertions, disrepair and indiscipline.

title: Dept. of Education Nominee Opposes Federal Rule
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP)  Judge Shirley M. Hufstedler of the Federal appellate court, nominated as Secretary of the new Department of Education, testified today that she would work to minimize Federal disruption and domination of the nation's schools.

title: Soviet Union to Comply
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 27  Officials of the Soviet Olympic Committee said today they would go along with the International Olympic Committee's decision to let both China and Taiwan participate separately in the Moscow Olympics in July 1980.

title: Manson Again Denied Parole in Tate Slayings
description: VACAVILLE, Calif., Nov. 27 (UPI)  Charles Manson, mastermind of the 1969 murders of Sharon Tate, the actress, and eight other persons, was again denied parole today.

title: Gallstone Is Removed From Shah, Raising Chance of Early Departure
description: A gallstone in the bile duct of Mohammed Riza Pahlevi has been removed and officials at New York HospitalCornell Medical Center said yesterday that, barring complications, the deposed Shah of Iran should be able to leave the hospital and return to Mexico within a week.

title: VLADIMIR YURSHA
description: Vladimir Yursha, vice president and assistant to the president of the Gulf and Western Natural Resources Group, a division of Gulf and Western Industries of New York, died of a heart attack Monday on a flight from Newark to Nashville. He was 52 years old and lived in Hazlet, N.J.

title: 2 Senators Would Add Chrysler Aid Conditions
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27  Prospects for emergency Federal loan guarantees for the Chrysler Corporation worsened today as two key Senators said that they would not support an aid package unless it contained a wage freeze for Chrysler workers and hefty increases in private aid for the company.

title: Pressure on the Slopes
description: A mile or more below Killington Peak, the swaying chariots of a double chairlift floated upward toward the top of the mountain as quietly as a line of red balloons. Every second or third chair on the lift, one of 17 servicing the 72 interconnecting trails of the fivemountain complex, had a skier in it. But only a few of the

title: The U.N. Today
Olympic Conditions Rejected by Taiwan
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Nov. 27  Taiwan refused today to accept the conditions set by the International Olympic Cornmittee for Taiwan's participation in the Olympic Games next year and officials said the country would follow through on a lawsuit already filed seeking a reversal of the decision.

title: Prices Increase 0.8% in a Month In City's Region
description: Consumer prices in the New York area continued their steady upward climb last month, rising eighttenths of 1 percent in October after an unusually sharp surge the month before. The United States Bu reau of Labor Statistics, which reported the figures yesterday, said the October increase matched the average monthly rise of the first half of the year.

title: The Difficult Endive a Star Among Rare Vegetables
description: LEUVEN, BELGIUM

title: Landrieu Offers Plan to Preserve Vitality of Cities
description: Moon Landrieu, United States Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, presented a program yesterday aimed at strengthening urban centers, such as New York City, and called for urban support of President Carter's reelection.

title: EXMAYOR CAVANAGH OF DETROIT IS DEAD
description: DETROIT, Nov. 27  Jerome P. Cavanagh, who rose to national prominence as Mayor of Detroit in the 1960's, died today in Lexington, Ky., of an apparent heart attack. He was 51 years old.

title: X9.9 Billion Trimmed From Windfall Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27  President Carter lost a major round in his fight to obtain a substantial windfall profits tax on the oil industry when the Senate voted today to cut $9.9 billion more in revenue from a bill he already regarded as unsatisfactory.

title: Harness Driver Suspended After Losing an Appeal
description: EAST WINDSOR TOWNSHIP, N.J., Nov. 27  Lew Williams of Secaucus, the nation's most prominent black harness driver, lost an appeal today and was suspended for 30 days by the State Racing Commission for possession of the prohibited medications tenuate and valium. The ban begins Jan. 11, the opening night of the Meadowlands 1980 meet.

title: Last Licks Closing; Has It a Future?
description: LAST LICKS, the play by Frank Gilroy that opened at the Longacre on Nov. 20, will close next Sunday after 25 performances. Devour the Snow, the play by Abe Polsky that opened at the John Golden on Nov. 7, closed after only six performances. Both plays had their adherents among the critics, even though there was small possibility that either play would be a boxoffice success. However, the producers of Last Licks, who had also produced Devour the Snow, decided to let it run for a while, offering tickets to all performances this week at halfprice. The decision to keep Last Licks open was made, at least in part, because of theater economics.

title: Patriots Facing Jinx In Key Miami Game
description: In the nine years that Don Shula has been coach of the Dolphins, the New England Patriots have never beaten his team in Miami. The Patriots hope to end that slump when they play the Dolphins in Miami tomorrow night, with first place at stake in the Eastern Division of the American Football Conference.

title: Concert: Giulini's Vienna
description: NO matter how it might be considered, the Los Angeles Philharmonic's concert at Carnegie Hall last night could hardly be called runof themill. For

title: Bobsledder and 3 Others Killed in Washout
description: ELIZABETHTOWN, N.Y., Nov. 27 Four men, including a world class American bobsledder, were killed last night during torrential rains when three vehicles plunged 25 feet off a washedout country road into a swollen creek near here, about 20 miles east of Lake Placid. A fifth man was stilt missing tomgnt and presumed drowned. Two other men, who hoped to get on the United States bobsled team in the upcoming Olympics, survived the accident and were reported in good condition, authorities said.

title: Mecca Attack: U.S. Setback?; Trend to Conservatism Would Mean Less Oil
description: KUWAIT, Nov. 27  With the takeover of the Grand Mosque in Mecca apparently about ended, attention is turning to the lessons of that event for Saudi Arabia. In the view of almost everyone, the memory of Mecca will not be principally

title: 2 Saboteurs Jailed for 2 Years
description: SURRY, Va., Nov. 27 (AP)  Two former employees of a nuclear power plant who said they sabotaged the plant to show that it was unsafe were sentenced today to two years in prison. Judge Ligon Jones of Surry County Circuit Court refused to reduce the sentences a jury recommended for William Kuykendall, 26 years old, of Newport News, and James Merrill, 24, of Hampton. They were found guilty Oct. 16 of pouring sodium hydroxide on 62 fuel rod assemblies at the Surry nuclear plant.

title: New Haven Closing Was Expected
