description: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 27  The closing of the U.S. Steel Works here had been expected for two or three months by the 400 or so employees of the cable fabricating plant that has been a major industrial employer in New Haven since the turn of the century. Like many of

title: DISCOVERIES
description: Even if their tiny eyes didn't flash on and off, the insect pins made by a pair of Dutchmen who describe themselves as electronic craftsmen would be attractive jewelry. The dragonflies have wings made of translucent plastic and legs of silver wire, while a silvery beetle has a body fashioned of a computer part. But what makes them particularly amusing are their flashing eyes, powered by a small battery (the kind used in wristwatches or hearing aids). The insect pins are $160 each at Mythology, 370 Columbus Avenue (78th Street), which also has some less intricate blinking tie tacks at $20 and $25.

title: House Votes, 321 to 63, to Allow Congress to Veto F.T.C. Rulings
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27  By a 5to1 margin the House passed a bill today that would restrict the Federal Trade Commission by subjecting its rulings to a Congressional veto.

title: Study Hails Hypertension Drugs
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP)  A nationwide study involving 11,000 people proves that deaths associated with high blood pressure can be drastically reduced with comprehensive treatment, the National Institutes of Health announced today.

title: Toscanini Tribute Set From NBC's Studio 8H
description: NBC's historic Studio 8H, from 1937 to 1954 the site of Arturo Toscanini's broadcast concerts with the NBC Symphony Orchestra, will be the scene of a televised tribute to the conductor on Wednesday, Jan. 9, at 9:30 P.M.

title: Power Is Knocked Out In Five Western States
description: A power loss from a 700megawatt generator at the Grand Coulee Dam triggered a widespread power failure in five Western states yesterday, knocking out electricity for a few minutes in some spots and up to several hours in others.

title: Entertainment Events
description: GAYANE, ballet by Aram Khachaturian, directed by Horace King; performed by the Ballet Company of Riga, Latvia; with Me Ripa Symphony Orchestra, at the Murray Hill Theater, 160 East 3Eth Street.

title: News Summary
description: WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 28, 1979

title: TV: Liv Ullmann in Cocteau Drama
description: JEAN COCTEAU'S The Human Voice is a oneact play in search of a bravura performance, and that is what it gets, from Liv Ullmann tonight at 9 on WNETTV, Channel 13. Originally produced for stage presentation, this version was directed by Jos Quintero. The dramatic line of The Human

title: Herbert Lombard, 89; A Researcher on Cancer
description: BOSTON, Nov. 27 (AP)  Dr. Herbert K. Lombard, a cancer researcher who was one of the first to link the disease to smoking, died Sunday at Pondville State Hospital, a cancertreatment hospital that he helped found. He was 89 years old.

title: Look Who's Pushing Inflation Now
description: Judged by deeds, not words, the Carter Administration seems to favor still more inflation. Despite the current 12 percent rate, the Treasury Department has ordered a 5 percent increase in the price of steel imported during the first quarter of 1980. Behind that protective barrier the prices of domestic steel will rise.

title: U.S. ACTS TO CREATE PRIVATE SECTOR JOBS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP)  The Carter Administration announced today a new program aimed at creating 80,000 permanent jobs for the hardcore unemployed in private business with the help of Federal funds.

title: CREDIT MARKETS In terest Ra tes Con tin ue to Drop
description: Interest rates yesterday dropped for the fourth market session in a row.

title: Letters
description: Your Nov. 11 editorial Kennedy: Upside Down on Energy, offering the litmus test for the 1980 Presidential campaign, repeats, as if by rote, the oil industry's creed that decontrols, higher prices and higher profits are the only ingredients capable of offering relief from our dependence upon OPEC. The only choice, you add, is who gets the gravy.

title: Lanier Carries On Despite Pistons' Decline
description: When Bob Lanier failed to make the National Basketball Association Eastern Conference allstar team last February, a furor was set off in Detroit, where the game was played. The fans couldn't understand why Lanier's talents had been snubbed. The Pistons star center had averaged 24.2 points and 9.2 rebounds at the time the selections were made.

title: Rhodesian Talks at New Impasse as Guerrillas Balk
description: LONDON, Nov. 27  The negotiations on the future of Zimbabwe Rhodesia have reached an impasse that could negate most of the farreaching agreements achieved during the last 11 weeks, senior participants said tonight.

title: U.N. Gets Written Iranian Pledge BaniSadr Will Arrive on Saturday
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 27  The Security Council received a written promise today that Iran's Acting Foreign Minister would arrive Saturday for a Council meeting.

title: Court Hears Dispute on Aid to Minority Contractors
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27  The Supreme Court heard arguments today in an affirmative action case that raises some of the constitutional questions left unanswered by the decisions in the Bakke and Weber cases of the last two years.

title: State Senate Overrides 2 Vetoes By Carey of Bills for Heating Aid
description: ALBANY, Nov. 27  The State Senate, after less than an hour of debate, overwhelmingly overrode today Governor Carey's vetoes of two bills to help the elderly and the working poor pay their winter heating bills.

title: Kitchen Equipment
description: THE most common problem in cooking a roast is the drymeat blight, which usually strikes following errors of omission. Two frequent omissions are a failure to truss or to use a thermometer. Another one, and it is at least as important as the first two, is the failure to baste adequately.

title: Davidson: Instincts Are Missing
description: From the start of the season he knew that something was wrong. Pucks were sliding past the best goaltender in last season's Stanley Cup playoffs with alarming frequency. He had once

title: The Region
description: HACKENSACK, N.J.  A $2.175 million cash settlement was made yesterday in a suit by a 40yearold salesman who suffered permanent brain damage when his car was struck in the rear by a trailer truck at a traffic light in South Brunswick, N.J., in June 1977.

title: Around the Nation
description: CARSON CITY, Nev., Nov. 27 (AP)  Thousands of items contaminated by radiation, from a cement mixer to small gauges, were stolen from a nuclear waste dump, an inspector from the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said today.

title: Here's How to Be Your Very Own BestSeller List
description: If to publish is to make public, then you can publish  if you're not too ambitious or greedy  without publishers. In Dublin you can recite your novel or epic in a public, not publishing house and, assured of an audience that watches your lips even if it doesn't listen, feel no urge to write it down. If you wish to write it down, you can employ a scrivener, as Chaucer did (he was called Adam, ours is called Xerox), and distribute copies to your friends or on street corners. Or you can do what I myself recently did in Rome  say what you have to say in four lines of verse and stick your holograph under the bust of Pasquino just off the Piazza Navone  hence pasquinade.

title: Letters
description: No Conflict of Interests

title: Recital: Berman in 2 Distinct Modes
description: IN the three years since his American dbut, Lazar Berman has managed to attain such a beatified status that everything he does is greeted with delight by his public. In fact, however, the Soviet pianist, like all other musicians, plays some works extremely well and others not well at all. Last night at the 92d Street Y, for example, Mr. Berman had pounded through half his program in fairly stolid and blunt fashion before this listener could take much pleasure in his performance.

title: Money
description: TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 27, 1979

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The St. Joe Zinc Company, a division of the St. Joe Minerals Corporation, said that it had decided to close permanently its zinc smelter in Monaca, Pa., at the end of the year.

title: Article 2 -- No Title
Energy Stocky Drop
description: Energy issues tumbled yesterday after some Wall Street analysts said the group appeared vulnerable in the wake of recent sharp gains. Elsewhere, stock prices generally moved higher, although leading market averages displayed small declines.

title: Santa Fe Raises Dividend
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 27 (Reuters)Santa Fe Industries said today that its directors had increased the quarterly dividend to 65 cents from 60 cents a share, payable March 1 to holders of record Jan. 21.

title: Chicago Airport Plan Grounded After Mayor Jilts the President
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27The script for President Carter's longawaited production of Airport, a political romance, has been sent back to the White House for a rewrite job. The female lead, Mayor Jane M. Byrne of Chicago, backed out of her role, citing other commitments.

title: Carter's Press Session Is on TV Tonight at 9
description: President Carter will hold a news conference tonight that will be televised live at 9 P.M. on CBS, NBC, ABC and WNET, channels 2, 4, 7 and 13 in New York. It will also be broadcast live on two local radio stations, WCBSAM and WINS.

title: Mozart: The Philomusica Offers Divertimento in D
description: LONG, long ago, before there was Muzak and before the selfreversing tape recorder was even imagined, living perform- ers had to be employed to drown out conversation at social gatherings. This was an important function, because most people had little to say anyway and could pretend to be absorbed in the sounds. Thus the concept of an audience for serious music grew. In time composers were being asked to write pieces that would not only fill entire evenings but also could be listened to, should anyone decide to do so. Mozart's divertimentos and cassations are perhaps the finest examples of this exalted kind of background music.

title: AYATOLLAH ATTACKS U.N. COUNCIL SESSION AS PART OF U.S. PLAN
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 27  Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, apparently crushing immediate hope for diplomatic efforts to gain the release of the American hostages here, today attacked plans for a session of the United Nations Security Council because he said the outcome had been dictated by the United States.

title: Colombia Says 62 Died in Flood
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Nov. 27 (UPI) Civil Defense officials announced today that 62 bodies had been recovered from the mud and wreckage left after the Playonero River burst its banks Sunday and swept through the small towns of El Playen and Lebrija, 200 miles northeast of Bogota.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Times yesterday about the New Spanish Cinema film festival at the Beacon Theater gave the dates incorrectly. They are Jan. 11 to Jan. 27.

title: Engine Problems Plague Advanced Air Force Jets
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP)  The Air Force said today that nearly 100 of its most advanced fighter planes would be sitting on the ground without engines by next summer because of persistent engine problems.

title: The City
description: A Federal grand jury charged three men yesterday with defrauding the Government four years ago when they were meal suppliers in a federally financed summer lunch program for needy children in Brooklyn.

title: EARNINGS
description: Operations of the HewlettPackard Company in the fourth fiscal quarter ended Oct. 31 resulted in an 7.7 percent earnings gain on a sales rise of 31 percent, according to yesterday's report of the precision electronic equipment producer. Annual profits climbed 32.7 percent and sales, 35.8 percent.

title: Gingerbread Visions Come True
description: CHAPPAQUA, N.Y. My father knew silence meant mischief. As children, if we were out of sight and quiet for more than a few minutes, his voice would suddenly bellow, Whatever you're doing, stop it at once!

title: Miller, ExMiners Head, Suffers Second Heart Attack in 2 Weeks
description: CHARLESTON, W.Va., Nov. 27 (UPI) Arnold R. Miller, the fanner president of the United Mine Workers, has suffered his second heart attack in two weeks, a spokesman at Charleston Memorial Hospital said today.

title: 5 Agent Orange Manufacturers Are Sued on Behalf of Veterans
description: BOSTON, Nov. 27 (UPI)  A Federal class action suit has been filed on behalf of Massachusetts veterans who suffered health problems allegedly due to exposure to Agent Orange, a defoliant used by the United States in the Vietnam war.

title: Jersey Is Urged to Set Up HazardousWaste Panel
description: TRENTON, Nov. 27  Saying that improper handling of a yearly average of 4 million to 5 million tons of hazardous waste poses an imminent threat to health in New Jersey, a special Dovernor's commission has proposed the creation of a staterun corporation to oversee disposal.

title: Stage: Woody Guthrie
description: WOODY GUTHRIE, a oneman show paying tribute to the celebrated American balladeer that opened at the Cherry Lane Theater on Monday, is a mixed blessing. Tom Taylor, who plays Mr. Guthrie and developed the show, doesn't look much like the Oklahomaborn protest singer, songwriter and folk hero. His rather thin singing is even closer to common speech than Mr. Guthrie's singing was  rather too close for comfort. But his interest in and sympathy for Mr. Guthrie seem to be deep and genuine, and he's quite a riveting performer, making up in commitment and feeling for the material much of what he lacks in technical skills.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: PRINT AND IMPRINT The annual book bazaar is being held today through Friday at the Mercantile Library, 17 East 47th Street, a quiet midtown sanctuary that offers free Hour With the Author lectures. Collectors and holiday shoppers will find hardcover volumes and paperbacks ranging from library duplicates to current fiction and art books, at reduced prices. Hours are 9 A.M. to 5 P.M.

title: Topics
description: The White House has lost its pastry chef, the WaldorfAstoria has lost its Iranian restaurant and France has lost its snaileating champion. The first apparently succumbed to the difficulty of getting fresh, unpasteurized cream through the Secret Service. The second seems a casualty of the Iranian crisis. The third O.D.'d on his specialty, snails. All three show how the pampered palate can go wrong.

title: Article 1 -- No Title
description: NEW WAVE OF BOMBINGS IN BELFAST: Part of the Chester Park Hotel was in ruins yesterday after a bomb explosion Monday night. The provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army claimed responsibility for about 20 bombings overnight throughout the province. No one was killed, but at least two persons were hospitalized.

title: Octobers Prices, Led by Housing, Increased by 1% Costs in Region Continued Steady Upward Trend
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27  Consumer prices rose by 1 percent last month, mainly reflecting the sharpest rise in housing costs in three decades after austerity moves on Oct. 6 by the Federal Reserve System, the Government reported today.

title: Jury Awards $860,000 In Jet's Lack of Pressure
description: A jury awarded more than $860,000 last night to 23 passengers who were on an Eastern Airlines jumbo jet in September that the passengers said was improperly pressurized.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: IT has long been my contention that if home cooks exercised a little foresight, they could save themselves time and money. Essentially, this would include the basic preparation and freezing of such stocks as chicken, beef and fish. For example, if you found an especially good buy on chicken parts (necks, backbones, wings and soon), you would benefit by buying them and throwing them into a stock pot with a little water and a few vegetables to make the basis for countless stews and sauces. You might ask your fish dealer to throw in a few fish bones and, preferably, fish heads along with your purchase. These, too, should be cooked, strained and frozen for future use. You should clearly label these various stocks.

title: Camp
description: When it is time for dinner, the men march single file into the dining room, singing camp songs. They gather at tables of eight and wait for the bugle to blow mess. After the last notes, they eat.

title: Kosygin's Deputy, 74, Raised to Full Politburo Status
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 27  With Aleksei N. Kosygin, the 75yearold Prime Minister, absent and ailing, the Soviet leadership promoted his 74yearold deputy, Nikolai A. Tikhonov, to full membership in the Communist Party's ruling Politburo today. Mr. Tikhonov is regarded as a close political associate of Leonid I. Brezhney, the party chief.

title: Advertising
description: THE country's largest maker of cigarettes, R.J. Reynolds Tobacco, announced yesterday that was switching two of its major brands, Winston and Camel, in January. The former, which billed $29.3 million last year, according to Leading National Advertisers, is returning to the William Esty Company, the agency that introduced it, while Camel, billing $23.5 million is going from Esty to Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn.

title: Israel Says Arabs Abuse U.N. s Efforts for Peace
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 27 (UPI)  Israel accused Arab countries today of exploiting United Nations efforts to achieve a Middle East peace and with attempting to obscure the inseparable bond between the Jewish people and Israel.

title: Business Records
description: Petition Filed by

title: POPE'S TURKISH VISIT GETS EXTRA SECURITY
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 27  The Turkish Government has ordered extraordinary security measures for the arrival tomorrow of Pope John Paul II for a threeday visit to this Islamic country.

title: Panel Proposes Broad Changes in Education and Job Preparation
description: A series of sweeping changes in schooling and job preparation to give young people, particularly those not bound for  college, more options in the critical years from 16 to 21, was proposed yesterday by the Carnegie Council on Policy Studies in Higher Education.

title: Dividends
description: STOCK

title: Q&A
description: Q. My husband is on a lowcalorie diet and does not drink regular milk. I always buy him skimmed milk (sometimes sold as skim milk) or lowfat milk (sometimes sold as nonfat milk). Is there a difference?

title: Senseless Suffering in Southeast Asia
description: There seems to be no end to the depravities that compound human suffering in Southeast Asia.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: BONN, Nov. 27The dollar fell to its lowest level in nearly two months against major Continental currencies in active trading today, as declining American interest rates, worries about inflation in the United States and continued tension in Iran set off waves of dollar selline.

title: Judge Reverses His Order Fora 2Jury Murder Trial
description: A State Supreme Court justice reversed himself yesterday and dropped the idea of holding a single trial with two juries for two men accused of a murder. He acted after the prosecutor changed his mind and withdrew his approval of the twojury procedure.

title: Nuclear Power Training Unit Set
description: NEWARK, Nov. 27 (AP)  The Public Service Electric and Gas Company announced today planned to build a $20 million training center in West Deptford for employees who will work in control rooms of the companys Salem and Hope Creek nuclear power generating stations.

title: U.S. Postmaster Reports Surplus, First in 34 Years
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27  The United States Postal Service announced today that it had a surplus of $469,863,000 in the fiscal year ended Sept. 30, the first in 34 years. But the Postmaster General warned that inflation would submerge the agency in red ink again this fiscal year.

title: Obituary 1 -- No Title
description: MARCEL L'HERBIER

title: IU Stockholders to Get Shares in Shipping Unit
description: The IU International Corporation, diversified transportation and utility company, voted overwhelmingly yesterday to distribute shares of the company's GotaasLarsen shipping subsidiary to stockholders. 1 ne spinout would isolate the heavy losses of GotaasLarsen from the rest of the company and help make IU stock more attractive, markets analysts said.

title: Theater: Stoppard's Night and Day
description: THERE are two Maggie Smiths in Tom Stoppard's Night And Day, the public Maggie and the private Maggie, and I'm going to confess to a partiality for the private Maggie right off.

title: Film: Khachaturian's Ballet 'Gayane':The Cast
description: IF you remember the old juke-box favorite "Saber Dance," you might actually want to see where it comes from, the Soviet ballet "Gayan."Created to Aram Khachaturian's music in 1942, "Gayan" is one of the staples of the Soviet and Eastern European ballet repertory. Oddly, it has never been seen here, although Margot Fonteyn and the Hungarian dancer Viktor Rona once danced at the White House in a ladylike and gentlemanly pas de deux from one of the many re-choreographed versions of the original production.The new filmed version, which opens today at the Murray Hill Theater, is on the wilder side. American-produced, by the See Theater Network, it has many aspects to recommend it.The dancers are from Latvia's Riga Opera and Ballet Theater. Mikhail Baryshnikov and Aleksandr Godunov started their ballet training at that company's school and, as Mr. Baryshnikov says, the Riga Ballet is a good company. Since it has never performed in the United States, this "Gayan" offers Americans a first glimpse of its dancers. The choreographer, Boris Eifman, is also new here, although his name is familiar when contemporary young Soviet choreographers come under discussion.The combined result is a ballet film of interest to ballet lovers and anybody who likes a good show. Yet, despite Mr. Eifman's valiant efforts, he is restricted by the required Soviet format of the ballet's origins  the incorporated folk elements of the music and its reliance upon a moral conclusion.The first version was created in Perm, where the Kirov Ballet had been evacuated during World War II. Nina Asimova worked with a scenario involving a spy who parachutes into a collective farm in Armenia. In 1954, Vassily Vainonen choreographed the best-known version for the Bolshoi with a new scenario, about a love quadrangle in which Gayan  the mountain girl in the Caucusus  stands by a lover who is ostracized by the community because he has betrayed a rival.Mr. Eifman has created his own narrative, concentrating on a love story within the framework of a village revolt. Gayan is the girl in the Caucusus loved by both Giko and Armen. Armen leads the revolt against the local tyrant, Machak and wins Gayan's hand. Her heart nonetheless belongs to Giko, torn between his love for Gayan and loyalty to his father, ???ak. The stylized folk dancers are ???oven into the narrative as part of ???ion, and this includes the famous Saber Dance, in which Armen and Giko now duel over Gayan.Mr. Eifman has provided some fine examples of vigorous masculine dancing and the real sparks that fly during the Saber Dance will remind American audiences of the exciting Georgian men's dances that have been seen here. The men in the Riga Ballet have all the energy and passion one could demand, even clashing their swords against their shields in unison during the curtain calls.This "Gayan" is, then, a film of a stage performance in the Riga Opera House  danced especially for the American production team. It has some of the defects of a filmed stage performance, but there has also been an effort to zoom in on the right people at the right dramatic moments. In this respect, Mr. Eifman's choreography looks best in the various pas de deux that sum up the human drama upon which he concentrates.Larisa Tuisova's fluidity makes for a very womanly Gayan and Genadi Gorbanyev has a youthful exuberance as Armen. Maris Koristin treats the grotesqueries of Machak's choreography persuasively and Aleksandr Rumyantsev, most impressive of all, has the right dramatic power.

title: Nixon Says U.S. Unity Is Key to Fate of Hostages
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 27 (AP)  Former President Richard M. Nixon says that he thinks the American hostages being held in Iran will be released if the nation stands firmly behind President Carter in his efforts to resolve the situation.

title: NevadaCalifornia Dispute Near High Court Action
description: RENO, Nev., Nov. 27 (AP)  Hundred, of California landowners could find the titles to their property thrown into question if the United States Supreme Court were to decide in favor of Nevada in a border dispute, according to documents filed in the case.

title: U.S. Upheld on Prosecuting Bribery
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27  The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that violators of state laws against commercial bribery can also be prosecuted by the Federal Government under a 1961 anticrime statute.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Airlines Attack Easing of Rules
description: MANILA, Nov. 27 (Reuters)  Calls by the United States for world governments to deregulate international airline service came under attack today at the start of the 35th annual meeting here of the International Air Transport Association.

title: Orthodoxy of the East, With a Proud History, Is Religion for Millions
description: The Eastern Orthodox churches, a fellowship of 15 independent church bodies around the world, assert the doctrine that they represent the unbroken, undivided Church of Christ. Tracing their tradition to the earliest Christian communities, the Orthodox consider the Roman Catholic, or Western, branch of the church a depar ture from authentic teaching on several matters including the Catholic claim that the Pope can exercise infallibilty on church teachings.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: TransAtlantic

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE At Macy's Meeting, Topic Is Succession
description: In its first formal announcement about plans for successors to its two principal officers, R.H. Macy & Company said yesterday that Donald B. Smiley, chairman and chief executive officer, and Herbert L. Seegal, president, would retire next July 31 at the age of 65. Published reports last January indicated that these moves would probably occur at that time, the end of the big retailing company's 1980 fiscal year.

title: Civiletti, Citing Rule of Law, Urges Restraint Toward Iranians in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP)  Attorney General Benjamin R. Civiletti urged Americans today to behave with restraint and not discriminate against Iranians despite our justifiable anger at the takeover of the United States Embassy in Teheran and the holding of 49 American hostages at the embassy.

title: Kuwaitis Plan to Cut Oil Output
description: KUWAIT, Nov. 27  Kuwait plans to reduce its output of crude oil as soon as is practical, probably next year, a high Government official here said today.

title: All the World Is Their (Belon) Oyster
description: THE temperature was in the 20's and a light wind was blowing one recent morning as the oyster farmers tended their stock on floating docks jutting out into the chill waters of the Damariscotta River where it spills into the Atlantic Ocean.

title: New Yorkers,etc.
description: THE acceptances read like a who's who of that fancy and fashionable international world that makes Manhattan glitter. William Paley, Diana Vreeland, Franco Zefferelli, Mary McFadden, Sam Spiegel, Count Rudi Crespi and his countess, Consuelo, Pyrma and John Pell,

title: WASHINGTON;As Moscow Sees Us
description: MOSCOW  Officials in Moscow express concern and even anxiety over the decline in U.S.Soviet relations, but the Iranian affair doesn't seem to have made much of a stir here. Soviet spokesmen agree it is an awkward situation but certainly do not agree with Secretary General Waldheim of the United Nations that the confrontation in Teheran is the most serious threat to world peace since the Cuban missile crisis of 1962.

title: 7 Go on Trial in Seoul Next Week for Slaying of Park
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 27  The former South Korean intelligence chief and six other men were formally accused today of the assassination of President Park Chung Hee and were ordered to stand trial before a military court next week.

title: French to Purchase Allied Chemical Unit
description: PARIS, Nov. 27 (Reuters)  Groupe Routiere Colas, a French construction company, said today that it would sign an agreement tomorrow to buy the road construction materials division of the Allied Chemical Corporation.

title: Persian Gulf Countries Fear a Violent Reaction if U.S. Acts Against Iran
description: BAHRAIN, Nov. 27  Governments of the countries that share the waters of the Persian Gulf with Iran are becoming increasingly anxious about the Iranian crisis involving American hostages and the possibility of a strong American action.

title: World News Briefs
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Nov. 27 (UPI)  Nicaraguan officials said today that city workers building a recreation center in downtown Managua had found the mutilated bodies of about 30 people.

title: Jets Coach Explains, Punter Apologizes
description: In the wake of the New York Jets nationally televised trouncing in Seattle Monday night, Coach Walt Michaels, in his fashion, explained yesterday his theory of criticism and indicated why ne had singled out Chuck Ramsey, his punter, after the loss to the Seahawks.

title: Benton to Acquire Manning, Selvage
description: At a news conference today at the Plaza Hotel, Benton & Bowles, the 14thlargest American ad agency worldwide, is expected to announce that it is acquiring Manning, Selvage & Lee, the country's seventhlargest public relations firm.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: New U.S. Law to Help Pay for Heating
description: About 1.5 million poor and elderly families in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut became eligible for Federal funds to help them with their heating costs this winter under a law signed by President Carter yesterday. The law provides $1.35 billion for such programs across the nation.

title: Red Sox Sign Lockwood, Extend Contract of Evans
description: BOSTON, Nov. 27 (AP) The Boston Red Sox brought home a former local schoolboy star today and also assured a veteran that he would remain with the team. The Red Sox signed Skip Lockwood, the righthanded relief pitcher formerly with the Mets, as a free agent, and they rewarded Dwight Evans, the rightfielder, with a new multiyear contract.

title: Protesters Accuse Nepal Police
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, Nov. 27 (AP)  ProMarxist students and farmers demonstrated here today, accusing the police in the town of Dhankuta of having shot to death 12 opponents of the Government in the last two weeks.

title: Bridge:
description: For a player accustomed to team play or to rubber bridge, there could hardly be anything less earthshaking than a partscore deal that is clearly eoine to make one or two overtricks.But It was the 10th trick in an obvious contract of two spades that decided the Reisinger playoff in Cincinnati Sunday night at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals, and had a major impact on the 1981 world team championship to be played in Rye, N.Y.

title: Lillian Diamond Stern Dies at 76; Long Active in Brooklyn Schools
description: Lillian Diamond Stern, an early leader in student guidance in New York City schools and the wife of the writer Philip Van Doren Stern, died Monday in Sarasota, Fla. She was 76 years old and had lived in Sarasota since 1971.

title: Manila Joins GATT
description: GENEVA, Nov. 27  The Philippines signed an accord today with the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade to become the 85th member of the world tradesupervisory agency on Jan. 1. Mexico and Colombia are also scheduled to join GATT, which was created in 1948 to regulate world trade.

description: Carter Hawley Hale Stores, which operates BergdorfGoodman, Wanamaker and NeimanMarcus among other department and speciality stores, reported an 19.6 percent increase in earnings for the 13 weeks to Nov. 3 on a sales gain of 17 percent, Philip M. Hawley, president, reported yesterday.

description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 27 (AP)  Fifteen times the normal amount of fluoridation was mistakenly allowed into the city's water system, contaminating a kidney machine at a clinic where one patient later died and seven others became ill, health officials have reported.

description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 27 (AP) Victor Galindez, the lightheavyweight champion, refused to make his weight public today at the weighin for his title defense Friday against Marvin Johnson. He would not step on the scales until he was sure no reporters could see the results.

Would you know where to get the rare fish, special cut of meat or unusual pastry shell needed to make your family a meal like the ones they used to get back home?

title: U.S. ASKS AMERICANS TO AVOID 11 NATIONS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27  The United States urged all Americans today to avoid nonessential travel to 11 Middle East or Moslem countries where American Embassy staffs and dependents are now being voluntarily reduced for security reasons.

description: NIJMEGEN, the Netherlands, Nov. 27 (Reuters)  Thirty Roman Catholic theologians from all over the world today criticized the Vatican's secrecy in investigating their colleagues.

title: Minority Youths Find Gold in Film, TVand Disks
description: AMERICA loves winners, said Ossie Davis, the actor and playwright. Whether that's right or wrong is beside the point. The point is: How do we minority people turn losers into winners?

title: Bank of Italy: A Test of Strength
description: ROMEItaly's central bank, which has followed its own course through a succession of weak governments and a highly charged political atmosphere, now confronts a weakening economy with its independence under question.

title: Meeting on Federal Policy Hears Appeals to Save the Family Farm
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., Nov. 27 (UPI)  Northeastern farmers today opened the first in a series of hearings on Federal agricultural policy with a unanimous, sometimes impassioned, plea for preservation of the family farm.

title: Senators Shown How to Steal Car
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP)  A Senate panel today dramatized the highly profitable crime of automobile theft by having a masked criminal tell how easy it was to steal cars. The criminal, released from prison to testify under police guard, said that he had become a car thief because it was very easy, and there was big money in it.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 28, 1979

title: Japan Acts To Brake Yen's Slide
description: TOKYO, Wednesday, Nov. 28 (UPI)  The Japanese Government and the Bank of Japan announced a program yesterday to check the yen's depreciation against other major currencies, and in early trading this morning the yen was stronger. The dollar retreated for the first time in five sessions.

title: Airline Pilots March Protests Requirement For Retirement at 60
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27  Commercial airline pilots boasting a total of four and a half million hours of flying experience staged a march on the Capitol today, urging a moratorium on a Federal rule requiring them to retire at the age of 60.

title: World Gold
description: TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 27, 1979

title: Letters
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: Evolutionary Equal Time
description: There is progress, of a sort, to report from the Florida Legislature. For years, the evolution of local legal thinking about how Creation is taught seemed to be proceeding almost as slowly as Darwin's kind. The Scopes monkey trial occurred 54 years ago, yet every so often a county judge somewhere still rises upagainst teaching evilution and demands that local teachers rely on the Bible instead. Now, Joe Carlucci and Tom Bush, Florida legislators, have proposed their own version. They are not trying to forbid teaching evolution; they want equal time. They say public schools should also have to teach scientific creationism, a theory close to the Bible.

title: Soviet Pushes Gold Coin
description: With the price of gold rising, the Soviet Union has stepped up its production of the chervonets, a small gold coin that it sells to private buyers.

title: Italian Politician Jailed in France
description: PARIS, Nov. 28 (Reuters) A military court has jailed the Frenchborn secretary of the Italian Radical Party, Jean Fabr, for one month for evading conscription. Mr. Fabr, a French citizen, was arrested in Paris last month while attending a meeting of French and Italian Radical Party officials.

title: Japan's Export Of Vehicles Up
description: TOKYO, Nov. 28 (AP)  Japan exported 410,269 motor vehicles in October, 2.8 percent more than in the previous month and 32.4 percent more than in October 1978, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said today.

title: Banks Urge Iran Action
description: Banks in the United States have warned European and Japanese banks that if they fail to take strong action to safeguard their loans to Iran, they cannot expect to share in the proceeds of any distribution of Iranian assets seized by American banks, according to financial sources.

title: A Delicate Performance
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28  His tone was stern, even angry at moments. He spoke with resolute determination. But President Carter was restrained and conciliatory in his news conference last night, still emphasizing the peaceful pathof diplomacy rather than force of arms to free American hostages in Iran, refusing to set deadlines for their release or to be lured into ultimatums.

title: Michael J. Bradley Is Dead at 82
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28 (AP)  Michael J. Bradley, a former Representative who once served as chairman of the Democratic City Committee, died yesterday at his home here. He was 82 years old.

title: Events Today
description: CANTERBURY TALES, a musical based on Chaucer stories; book by Martin Starkle and Nevi!! Coghill; music by Richard Hill and John Hawkins; lyrics by NevlII Coghill; directed by Robert Johanson, at the Equity Library Theater, 103d Street and Riverside Drive, 8.

title: Flying Backward in the Senate
description: Senators Cannon of Nevada and Stevens of Alaska are waging an effective battle to dilute Federal rules designed to lower the noise of jet airplanes. Three years ago, after exhaustive study of data from the airlines and other interested groups, the TransportationDepartment issued new noise standards that were to be met in stages by 1985. But now the Senate has overwhelmingly voted to exempt most planes and to allow more time to refit or replace others. A parliamentary maneuver by Senator Cannon may soon force the House to take up this issue as well.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP)  The House refused today to let Southern states use a banned pesticide, suspected of causing cancer, as a weapon against the fire ant.

title: DEPENDENTS START MIDEAST EVACUATION
description: BAHRAIN, Nov. 28  A quiet evacuation of American dependents has begun throughout the Persian Gulf region from countries designated by the United States as potential scenes of antiAmerican riots by Islamic zealots.

title: Advertising
description: A COMMON method of compensation for media buying services known as the splitsavings system was denounced yesterday by Walter Staab, president of the SFM Media Service Corporation. He spoke in Kansas City, Mo., but he had time before he left to drop a few negative comments in New York City.

title: Msgr. John K. Sharp Dies at 87
description: Msgr. John Kean Sharp, who since his retirement has assisted at St. Louis de Montfort Church in Sound Beach, L.I., died Tuesday at St. Charles Hospital in Port Jefferson, L.I., after a long illness. He was 87 years old.

title: ESSAY Tightening Henry's Belt
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28  Henry Kissinger evidently did not like being portrayed as a pessimist at a crucial moment. In Richard Nixon's memoirs, in a downbeat moment after Hanoi's spring offensive in 1972 threatened theMoscow summit, Nixon quoted himself as saying, And then we're defeated, and wrote this about Henry's response: Then we will just have to tighten our belts, Kissinger replied glumly.

title: 100 MORE ARRESTED BY KOREAN MILITARY
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 28  Martial law authorities arrested 100 people, mainly Christian students, here last night in the second mass arrest in four days, according to official sources today.

title: We're Better Off Than We Think
description: When the Consumer Price Index shows October prices continued marching upward at 1 percent a month, does that mean the average American's cost of living increased again by 1 percent?

title: Miller Calls Arabs Worried About U.S. War Threat
description: LONDON, Nov. 28 Winding up a fiveday tour of three key Persian Gulf countries, Secretary of the Treasury G. William Miller said today that the leaders with whom he met were extremely worried that the United States might useforce against Iran in connection with the American hostages being held there.

title: U.S. SELLS BOOKLETS ON APLANT SECURITY
description: Government documents written to help nuclear plant operators test their security systems, but potentially usefui to saboteur, are available to the general public.

title: Suffolk County Adopts A Policy on Residency
description: RIVERHEAD, L.I., Nov. 28 (AP)The Suffolk County Legislature today unanimously adopted a law that would require all new county employees to live in Suffolk County. County officialssaid the law would actually amount to a formalization of a current, informal policy that insures that most county jobs go to county residents.

title: Governor Wants Mortgage Rates Raised to 12%
description: Governor Carey proposed yesterday that the Legislature increase the maximum interest rate on home mortgages by two percentage points, to 12 percent, to ease the problem that prospective homeowners are having in getting loans. He made the proposal privately to Democratic legislative leaders and asked them to consider a special session before January to approve it.

title: Blue Bell Plans to Offer $28 a Share for Jantzen
description: Blue Bell Inc. has announced that subsidiary, Blue Bell Holdings, intends to offer $28 a share for all the outstanding stock of Jantzen Inc., a leading name in men's and women's swimwear. The offer would total about $47.5 million in cash.

title: ABROAD AT HOME Our Goals In The Crisis
description: BOSTON, Nov. 28  What are the basic objectives that the United States should be trying to achieve in the Iranian crisis? It is a question we scarcely consider, so compelling are the emotions of the day. But we must try to take a longer view, for profound interests are at stake and it may be a long struggle.

title: Simon &
description: Erwin A. Glikes, publisher of Harper & Row's tradebook division, has been named publisher of Simon & Schuster's tradebook division. He succeeds Richard E. Snyder, who has given up that post but who will remain president and chief executive of Simon & Schuster.

title: For Me, Double Anguish
description: A friend who returned from Iran last week told me of the silent thousands back home who oppose the Ayatollah Khomeini and who live in mortal terror from one day to the next. In America, a different terror has spread tocountless Iranian students like me regardless of whether they are sympathetic, apolitical or actively opposed to recent developments in Iran.

description: COPENHAGEN, Nov. 28  Like the burst of sunlight with which August Bournonville filled his ballets in the 19th century, this week's Boumonville Centenary Festival by the Royal Danish Ballet has picked up with a bounce characteristic of the Danish choreographer's own style.

title: Business Records
description: Wednesday, Nov. 28, 1979

title: A Shrewd Compromise for Chrysler
description: As outlined by the White House, the Federal loan guarantee program for Chrysler is a cheap ride. Neither Chrysler's stockholders nor its employees would be asked to make major sacrifices. But two members of the Senate Banking Committee  Richard Lugar, aconservative Republican from Indiana, and Paul Tsongas, a liberal Democrat from Massachusetts  have a better idea. They suggest a bailout program that would require those who stand to lose the most from Chrysler's demise to bear most of the burden of the rescue. That is the least the public should demand as the price of taxpayer support.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article in The Living Section yesterday misstated the location of Upper Volta. It should have said Upper Volta is an independent country in West Africa.

description: Antiques and Collectors Exposition, Madison Square Garden, 33d Street and Seventh Avenue.

title: F.C.C. Rejects Network Pleas on Carter's TV Time
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28  The Federal Communications Commission today rejected appeals by the television networks and reaffirmed its finding that they had acted unreasonably in refusing a request by President Carter's reelection cornmittee to buy 30 minutes of prime time to announce his candidacy for a second term next week.

title: 75 Whooping Cranes in Texas
description: AUSTWELL, Tex., Nov. 28 (UPI) Seventyfive whooping cranes have arrived to winter at the Aransas Wildlife Reguge. We're still hoping for some more, a spokesman for the Refuge said yesterday. We hope to get about 81 if all of them come back. The cranes, once plentiful in the United States, have dwindled in number to about 120.

description: A rumor swept Wall Street yesterday that the International Business Machines Corporation and the Justice Department were about to settle the mammoth antitrust lawsuit against the company. I.B.M. shares rose $1.25 to $65.75 on the news, as 522,000 shares changed hands, making the computer manufacturer the most actively traded Big Board issue.

description: AKRON, Ohio, Nov. 28 (Reuters) Coastal Industries increased its quarterly dividend today to 10 cents a share from 7 cents, payable Dec. 14 to shareholders of record Dec. 7.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28  The deputy chairman of Ronald Reagan's campaign committee, Michael K. Deaver, resigned Monday to return to his public relations company.

title: Many Democrats in Congress Delay Choice in KennedyCarter Contest
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28  Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Chicago Democratic organization's man in Washington, has been a delegate to every Democratic National Convention since 1956. He will not be going to the convention in New York City next August, however, because, even though his organization is supporting Senator Edward M. Kennedy, he does not want to be slated as backing either President Carter or Mr. Kennedy.

title: Q &
description: Q.I have installed fiberglass insula tion over my ceiling, but not enough heat is getting through to help melt snow on the roof. The snow tends to accumulate along the eaves. When it does melt, it forms an ice dam along the edge of the roof, forcing water up under the shingles that then leaks down the walls on the inside. I have heard that there are heating cables available, but these are not approved by Underwriters Laboratories. Also, can you tell me if the cable would generate enough heat to be a hazard for the roof shingles?  M.A.S., East Hampton, L.I.

title: Report to Harvard Urges Changes In School's Black Studies Program
description: Ten years after Harvard University, amid great turmoil, established an AfroAmerican Studies Department, a confidential report to the university administration asserts that the program has been crippled by persistent basic problems, and urges that it be changed to a degreegranting academic committee.

The Rangers rookie goaltender, who made his first start in the National Hockey League last night,against the Minnesota North Stars at Madison Square Garden, had a 43 lead until 17 minutes 11 seconds of the final period when Glen Sharpley fired a slapshot from the right point.

description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Nov. 28 (AP) This village of 2,700 persons was without power for seven hours today as the local electric company upgraded its system for the 1980 Winter Olympics. Power was restored about 4:15 P.M., or about 10 minutes before sunset.

title: South African Seized in Salvador
description: SAN SALVADOR, Nov. 28 (UPI)  A group of armed men surrounded South Africa's Ambassador to El Salvador today as he left the embassy here, forced him into the back of a truck and drove off, witnesses said.

title: Books: Actors on Tour
description: MEL ARRIGHI, a writer who was once an actor, has written a quietly absorbing novel about a touring company that is performing Much Ado About Nothing under the leadership of that famed acting couple, the Glynns, a husbandandwife team that has for years won the plaudits of audiences.

title: Workers Call U.S. Steel Greedy
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28  Officials the United Steelworkers union, angered and dismayed by the United States Steel Corporation's announcement that it planned to close 15 plants employing 13,000 workers, charged today that the move reflected company mismanagement and greed.

title: Toll of Iran Earthquake Put at 16 Dead, 23 Hurt
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 28 (Reuters)  A powerful earthquake that struck northeastern Iran yesterday killed 16 people and injured 23, officials here said today.

title: Dodgers Sutcliffe Is League's Top Rookie
description: It didn't even look like I would make the club, Rick Sutcliffe of the Los Angeles Dodgers said yesterday, remembering the unpromising days of last spring. The Dodgers had a lot of name pitchers down in spring training. But, fortunately for me, there were a lot of sore arms.

title: Minister Jailed for Arson Is Facing 2d Trial in Same Connecticut Case
description: A Baptist minister serving a 20year prison sentence for his role in what the Federal Bureau of Investigation has called the biggest case of arson it has investigated  a fire in 1975 at a rubber factory in Shelton, Conn.  faces another trial in connection with that fire. He could receive 30 more years.

title: Transcript of the President's News Conference on Crisis Over Hostages in Iran
description: For the last 24 days our nation's concern has been focused on our fellow Americans being held hostage in Iran. We have welcomed some of them home to their families and their friends. Butwe will not rest nor deviate from our efforts until all have been freed from their imprisonment and their abuse.

title: Despite Abuse, Hudson Remains A River of Life;
description: It is as pleasant a land as one can tread upon, Henry Hudson noted 340 years ago this fall when he ventured ashore after coming upon the majestic river that was eventually to be named after him.

title: Girl Impaled on Fence After Rooftop Plunge
description: A 16yearold New Jersey girl fell five floors from a Manhattan roof early yesterday and was impaled on the spikes of a metal fence. She was listed in satisfactory condition last night inBellevue Hospital after four hours of surgery to remove portions of the spikes from her chest and right armpit.

title: Chapter Two to Close Dec. 9
description: After two years and ??57 performances, Neil Simon's Chapter Two will end its Broadway run on Dec. 9 at the Eugene O'Neill Theater. Directedby Herbert Ross, the play opened on Broadway on Dec. 4, 1977, at the Imperial Theater, with Judd Hirsch and Anita Gillette. After its last performance, the Eugene O'Neill will close for renovation in preparation for Mr. Simon's new play, I Ought to Be in Pictures, starring Tony Curtis. It is scheduled to open in March.

title: Diplomatic Impasse
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28  The quick rise and abrupt fall of Abolhassan BaniSadr as Iran's Foreign Minister pointed up today the increasing difficulty of finding a diplomatic solution to the Iranian crisis that meets the demands of bothAyatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's militant Iranians and President Carter's equally resolute Administration.

title: U.S. Informs Yemen of Concern About Purchase of Soviet Arms
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (Reuters) The United States today criticized Yemen for ordering Soviet arms after buying nearly $500 million worth of weapons from the United States earlier this year.

title: Home Improvement; The old floor: Reviving luster (or recreating)
description: OVER the past decade more and more homeowners and apartment dwellers have become interested in real hardwood flooring, once the hallmark of every fine house. They are uncovering old wood floors that were been covered with carpeting or tile for years, then sanding and refinishing the wood to its original luster.

title: Stock Offer Is Planned By Chrysler
description: DETROIT, Nov. 28 (AP)  The Chrysler Corporation announced today that it was planning to offer a new issue of preferred stock to parties having a particular interest in the company, such as its suppliers and dealers.

title: Feld Ballet to Make Debut In Washington on Dec. 25
description: The Eliot Feld Ballet will make its Washington debut at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts on Christmas Day. The company will appear through Dec. 30 in place of the American Ballet Theater, which canceled its fourweek season because of lockout against its dancers.

title: Housing Slump Foreseen
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28  Housing industry analysts and a senior Federal official predicted today that home building is headed for a slump in 1980, with housing starts falling at least 20 percent from the 1979 average annual rate.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: The price of gold climbed above the $400anounce mark yesterday, pushed by a continuing silver price spiral, according to dealers, while the dollar closed generally lower in quiet trading on the world's currency markets.

title: TV CHIEF GETS POST Ghotbzadeh Says Decision Has Not Been Made on Role in U.N. Debate
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 28  Abolhassan BaniSadr, wouldbe architect of negotiations for the release of the hostages in the captive American Embassy, was dismissed tonight as Acting Foreign Minister.

title: Cabaret: Warren Songs In Lullaby of Broadway
description: HARRY WARREN, who composed Lullaby of Broadway, also wrote 249 other songs, including 42d Street, for musicals at four major Hollywood film studios during the 1930's and 40's. Those two songs are theend pieces of a chronological review of Mr. Warren's career through Depression, war and Warner Bros. musicals called Lullaby of Broadway, which opened Tuesday evening at Boltax, 22 Wooster Street.

title: Woman Wielding a Hunting Knife Subdued in Kennedy Senate Office
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28  A woman waving a fiveinch hunting knife and shouting loudly burst into the reception area of Senator Edward M. Kennedy's Capitol Hill office today and was seized by Secret Service agents after a brief struggle in which one agent was slightly wounded in the hand.

title: Lax for a Day, Judge Chided
description: ALBANY, Nov. 28  When he was elected judge of the City Court in Olean in 1977, Anthony J. De Rose said he would dismiss charges against the first defendant to appear before him.

title: The Region
description: NEWARK A prosecutor in Federal Court told jurors yesterday that Robert Notte, the former executive director of the Newark Redevelopment and Housing Authority, and Nathan Kabot, former controller of the authority, had conspired to force people doing business with the agency to pay them thousands of dollars in kickbacks.

title: Jetliner Crash Delays Bid To Retrace Byrd's Flight
description: Next to Adm. Richard E. Byrd's flights over the North Pole and across the Atlantic, it was his most ambitious venture. Fifty years ago today, he took off in a skiequipped Ford Trimotor in a bold attempt to fly 1,600 miles from his base at Little America to the South Pole and back.

title: Mondale Announces Expansion Of Health Aid for Brooklyn Poor
description: Vice President Mondale announced yesterday an expanded Federal plan to aid hospitals in the BedfordStuyvesant and Crown Heights sections of Brooklyn. The program, which amends an earlier proposal, involves a threeyear Federalcommitment to a $30 million program of health care for the poor in the two areas.

title: World News Briefs
description: PEKING, Nov. 28 (Reuters)  Members of the Chinese Parliament have voiced strong criticism of the socalled Democracy Wall here.

title: Wistful Reflections Of a Divorced Man
description: F OR me, my friend said, divorce is like a more profound form of marriage. It even has its honeymoon. Now that I no longer live with my wife, I'm crazy about her. I can see how beautiful, howintelligent, how intuitive and sexy she is. The whole sequence is reversed: after the honeymoon, we'll begin our engagement. We'll be engaged, she and I, till death do us part.

title: Design Notebook
description: NOT the least of the pleasures of the extraordinary environment of Disneyland in California and Walt Disney World in Florida are the rather bouncy, delicate evocations or smalltown American main streets with which both theme parks begin. The ability of these Main Streets to serve as easy transitions from the outside world to the somewhat imaginary worlds of theme parks comes from a number of factors. These Main Streets are clean, they are brightly colored and they are fanciful in their details.

title: 2 Saboteurs Jailed for 2 Years
description: SURRY, Va., Nov. 27 (AP)  Two former employees of a nuclear power plant who said they sabotaged the plant to show that it was unsafe were sentenced Tuesday to two years in prison. Judge LigonJones of Surry County Circuit Court refused to reduce the sentences a jury recommended for William Kuykendall, 26 years old, of Newport News, and James Merrill, 24, of Hampton. They were found guilty Oct. 16 of pouring sodium hydroxide on 62 fuel rod assemblies at the Surry nuclear plant.

title: Market Place
description: WHEN leading banks chopped fractions off the prime rate this week, reducing this key corporate lending rate below the record 15 percent, many analysts were quick to argue that the long rise in interest rates had finally peaked.

title: Wilkinson Dropped As Cardinals Coach
description: Bud Wilkinson was dismissed yesterJay as coach of the St. Louis Cardinals after rejecting frontoffice suggestions that he start his backup quarterback next Sunday in place of Jim Hart.

title: Landslide Kills 8 in Malaysia
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Nov. 28 (UPI)  A landslide buried a clinic being used as a flood relief center in the village of Kuala Balah, north of here, today. Initial reports placed the death toll at eight.

title: Carter Accepting Substantial Rise In Arms Budget
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28  The Carter Administration, under the prodding of Senator Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia, and former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, has agreed to a substantial increase in its budget request for military spending over the next five years, Government officials said today.

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 29, 1979

title: Technology
description: LIKE still waters, the hot brine of geothermal energy usually runs deep, and is often expensive to recover. For years, geothermal energy most commonly water trapped beneath the earth's surface that is heated by molten rock material called magma  has been a tempting, if largely untapped, curiosity of the energy world.

title: GARDENING
description: SPRING begins in the fall, but gardeners on rooftops and balconies rarely realize it. While enjoying the kalaidescope of leaves, it's too easy for the city gardener to forget that his terrace trees and shrubs are only going to sleep, notdying. Essential garden chores still remain. Even as the gray of winter approaches, life goes on beneath the soil and both food and water will be needed.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Interest rates, after declining for four consecutive market sessions, rose yesterday as traders and investors apparently decided that the recovery in fixedincome security prices had moved too far in too short a time.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: The New York Times/John Sotomayor

title: Obituary 3  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Philharmonic Gets Help
description: Sidney Harth, associate conductor and concertmaster of the Los Angeles Philharmonic Orchestra from 1973 to last year, will be named guest concertmaster of the New York Philharmonic. Rodney Friend, who has been the Philharmonic's concertmaster since September 1976, will leave the orchestra on Dec. 22 to become concertmaster of the BBC Symphony in London.

title: Music: Clannad, Irish Traditionalists
description: IT'S not every day that a group of Irish traditional musicians arrives in New York armed with rave notices from Rolling Stone  Ireland's finest traditional band  and numerous American dailies, aswell as from folkmusic circles. But Clannad, which has been together 10 years now, is no ordinary Irish band. The group is very traditional in that it performs authentic folk material, much of it sung in Gaelic. But the instrumentation and arrangements betray influences from rock and jazz, and the group carries its own sound man, who's an integral part of its presentations.

title: Benitez: A Champion And an Underdog
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 28  Wilfred Benitez's father writes an article in Ring magazine saying his son cannot beat Sugar Ray Leonard here Friday night.

title: Iran Sues Shah and Wife for $56 Billion in New York
description: The Government of Iran filed suit in Manhattan yesterday against Shah Mohammed Rizzi Pahlevi and his wife, Farah, asking $56.5 billion in damages and the immediate creation of a trust to assume control of all their assets.

title: Landry to Start for Colts
description: The Jets return to Shea Stadium Sunday against the Baltimore Colts, who will continue to have Greg Landry at quarterback instead of Bert Jones. Coach Ted Marchibroda says he does not think in terms of employing Jones any more this season. The star quarterback has an injured shoulder.

title: Iran Share In Krupp Is Frozen
description: BONN, Nov. 28  The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York has sharply stepped up the financial conflict between Iran and United States banks by moving to attach Iran's holdings in two major West German companies.

title: FrenchChinese Accord
description: PARIS, Nov. 28 (AP)  The French Association of Building Contractors said today that it had signed a preliminary agreement with the Chinese State Construction Company for Chinese laborers to be used on French companies construction contracts outside France and China. The Chinese recently made a similar deal with Italy.

title: New Life for U.S. Classics
description: With a grant of $1.8 million from the National Endowment for the Humanities and the Ford Foundation, a nonprofit company has been formed to publish moderately priced editions of the complete or significant works of American writers, it was announced yesterday.

title: The U.N. Today
Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Governor Finds A Method to Get CarFumes Tests
description: The inspections, designed to meet Federal clean air standards and prevent the cutoff of millions of dollars in Federal aid, would begin in 1981, according to state and Federal officials.

title: Bridge:
description: If six topranked players are in the same contract and just one of them fails, it may be interesting to inquire why  especially if the lead is of little importance and the contract appears easy against any defense.

title: U.S. Budget for 80 Clears Congress After House Rejects Cuts by G.O.P.
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28  The Federal Government finally got a budget today, almost two months after the start of the fiscal year 1980.

title: Chiang Ching Dancers To Perform at Henry St.
description: The Chiang Ching Dance Company will appear at the Louis Abrons Arts for Living Center at Henry Street Settlement, 466 Grand Street, from next Thursday through Sunday, Dec. 9. Works by guest choreographers will include Soliloquy of a Bhiksuni.choreographed by the late Joyce Trisler and based on a scene from a 16thcentury Chinese drama; Stuart Hodes's Orison, based on Greek mythology, and Interpretation, conceived and directed by Miss Ching with choreography by Rodney Griffin, Rael Lamb, Jaclynn Villamil and members of the Ching company.

title: Synthetic Fuel Aid Bid
description: BOCA RATON, Fla., Nov. 28  Clifton C. Garvin Jr., chairman of the Exxon Corporation, called today for the Government to provide modest economic incentives to help private industry develop synthetic fuels. He termed synthetic fuels the best hope for a successful transition to the age of nondepletable energy.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SUNSHINE ERA Jerome Kern fans who have done some scholarly digging know of the Princess Shows, a group of musicals that made Broadway history from 1915 to 1920 for deftly interweaving plot and music. The old Princess Theater at the Avenue of the Americas and West 39th Street is long gone, but not some of Kern's most charming songs, such as Till the Clouds Roll By.

title: Notes on People
description: At an auction at Christie's in New York, John Castellani had eyes for one item only  a fourvolume set of the Earl of Chesterfield's letters of advice to his son.

title: Safety of Sex During Pregnancy Questioned in Study
description: A study of more than 26,000 pregnancies has cast serious doubt on the longpresumed safety of sexual intercourse during pregnancy.

title: Bigger Oil Tax Wins Test Vote
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28  Supporters of a stronger windfall profits tax on the oil industry won a tentative victory in the Senate today when a test vote indicated they might be able to add $22.5 billion to its revenue total.

title: Stones Reinstated By A.A.U.
description: Dwight Stones, a twotime Olympic bronze medalist and former worldrecord holder in the high jump, ww. reinstated last night by the Amateui Athletic Union.

title: Black Images Films To Open Friday
description: The Harlem Cultural Council's Black Images on Film series will open tomorrow at 7:30 P.M. at the Symphony Space Theater, Broadway and 95th Street, with Scar of Shame, 1928 silent film starring Lucia Lynn Moses and Harry Henderson and produced by the Colored Players Film Corporation of Philadelphia.

title: A Painter of Intimate Portraits of Pets
description: SHE'S been called a nave artist. Sophisticated naive, corrected Mimi Vang Olsen, New York animal fancier who started painting 10 years ago. I'm aportrait painter. She has done people and families but recently has concentrated on pets. They're intimate portraits of specific pets, said Mrs. Vang Olsen. I interview the animal in its own surroundings, to discover its personality  and where it likes to sit, or stand. A series of photographs is taken, because animals can't pose, said Mrs. Vang Olsen, who then works out the composition in her studio. It will hang over the mantelpiece, if it's good, she said. If not, I guess it will hang somewhere else. The oil paintings (usually 30 by 35 inches) are about $2,500 each, depending on the number of animals and the size. Mrs. Vang Olsen can be reached at 8897255.

title: New Tempo of Nets Too Fast for Pistons
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Nov. 28  The New Jersey Nets 9889 victory over the Detroit Pistons tonight was not as convincing as their rout of the Milwaukee Bucks by 25 points last night. but it was enough to convince Coach Kevin Loughery that his gamble on remaking the team's image is beginning to pay off.

title: Productivity Down for a 3d Quarter
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP)  The productivity of American business and workers declined for a third consecutive quarter from July through September, the first time that has happened since 1974, the Government said today.

title: The Coach From the Mines
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 28  Among the souvenir footballs and the plaques and the photos in Walt Michaels's big oakpaneled office in the Jets training complex, a framed painting of a coal miner hangs prominently on one wall. The hard, dirtsmudged face peers out from under a miner's headlamp and below it, on a small gold plate, is engraved :

title: Record Growth For Money Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP)Sales of moneymarket funds totaled $14.2 billion in October, surpassing the previous record of $10.5 billion in August, the Investment Company Institute reported today.

title: World Gold
description: WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 28, 1979

title: I.B.M. Helps Push Market Up
description: Precious metal stocks and International Business Machines led the market yesterday to a modest advance. Trading was active but below the heavy pace of the two previous sessions.

title: Oil Decontrol Backed
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28  Two economists said in a study made public today that price controls on oil were costing Americans more than $3 billion a year because they fostered excessive demand, discouraged domestic production and involved the Government and private industry in red tape.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: United Press International

title: Delay of Month Is Likely in Start Of Fuel Bill Aid
description: It will be about a month before the new statefinanced program for grants of $100 to $200 to help New York State's nearpoor with heating bills can be put into operation, Barbara Blum, State Commissioner of Social Services, said yesterday.

title: E1 Quneitra, WarRazed Golan City, a Memorial to Strife
description: EL QUNEITRA, Syria  A damp wind descending from the Golan Heights whistles through the bell towers of a damaged church. From the surrounding devastation rise fragments of a mosque's minaret, a razed hospital, a movie theater. The street has a halfdozen lifeless buildings.

title: Why Not Gifts for a Child's Room?
description: WHEN buying Christmas presents for children, it is a temptation to select the latest toys and gadgets. But parents could make one of the gifts a special addition for a child's room  a super bunk bed, perhaps, a desk, a place to store toys, an easel or an indoor swing. Children love their possessions and while they might not think of asking for furnishings, a child's room is his own secure kingdom and these gifts can be enjoyed for years.

title: Classen Dies 5 Days After Knockout at Forum
description: Willie Classen, who was battered through the ropes at the Felt Forum of Madison Square Garden last Friday in his 24th professional bout, died yesterday evening at Bellevue Hospital without regaining consciousness. He was 29 years old.

title: ;Mrs. Gandhi Seen Making Gains
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 28  Former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi appears to be steadily gaining popular support for January's elections and is being buttressed by defections of highlevel officials from her opponents parties.

title: Joseph Lese, Apartment Builder In 1920's and 30's, Is Dead at 91
description: Joseph J. Lese, a New York City real estate developer and a founding member of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies, died yesterday at his winter home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 91 years old.

title: 257 BELIEVED KILLED AS A DC10 CRASHES ON ANTARCTIC PEAK
description: McMURDO STATION, Antarctica, Thursday, Nov. 29  A New Zealand DC10 on a sightseeing flight over Antarctica crashed into a 12,400foot mountain near here yesterday, apparently killing all 257 persons aboard. Twenty of the passengers were from the United States.

title: Johannesburg Retains Pool Ban
description: JOHANNESBURG, Nov. 28 (Reuters) The Johannesburg City Council has rejected a request for its whitesonly municipal swimming pools to be opened to all races. The request was made last night by the opposition Progressive Federal Party.

title: Stage: Deadwood Dick
description: IT doesn't take a theatergoer more than a glance at the title and subtitle of Deadwood Dick, Legend of the West or They Went Thataway, now running at the Carter Theater, 250 West 43d Street, to gather that it is a spoof of old westerns and thecliches that surrounded them: the fastest gun in the West ; the faithful Indian (faithful to the white man, that is); the desperado who is wax in the hands of the fair sex.

title: Giscard, on TV, Calls Any Hostage Taking Totally Unacceptable
description: PARIS, Nov. 28  President Valry Giscard d'Estaing, in an hourlong nationwide television interview last night, made the strongest statement yet by a French official on the plight of the American hostages in Teheran.

title: Little Progress Marks Meeting On Rent Laws
description: The setting was different yesterday, but the cast of participants and their ideas were familiar and so was the outcome  much argument, little agreement.

title: Bank Cites Iran Payment
description: TOKYO, Nov. 28 (AP)  Sumitomo Bank Ltd., a major Japanese commercial bank, said today that Iran had paid, in dollars, the interest and part of the principal of a $50 million syndicated loan.

title: The Subway Token That Rides Lapels
description: IF you've survived 333 days worth of subway commuting and think that you'll hold up for the remaining 32 days of the year, then you'll probably agree that you deserve a medal for your mettle. What bettertime to reward yourself than now, during the Christmas season? And what metal could be a bettersuited plaudit for your lapel than a genuine subway token?

title: Dutch Bank Rate Up
description: AMSTERDAM, Nov. 28 (Reuters)The rate charged by the Dutch central bank on loans to commercial banks will be raised to 9.5 percent from 8.5 percent, effective tomorrow, the central bank said today.

title: Carter Attends Prayer Breakfast
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP)  President Carter today paid a rare visit to the Capitol to attend a prayer breakfast with a group of senators. Presidents have rarely visited the Capitol except to address joint sessions of Congress.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: ELEANOR PINKHAM

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Bache Halsey Stuart Shields Inc., the securities firm, has named John Hennigan, Manny Korman, Edwin Payne, John Wei and George Wunsch senior vice presidents.

title: U.S. Export Controls: Dispute in Soviet Case
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28  A bitter dispute within the Commerce Department is being aired in Congress. The dispute is over the way American export control regulations have been administered in connection with a giant Soviet truck factory on the Kama River in Siberia, newly built with American technology.

title: Employees Bid For a Rail Line
description: SPOKANE, Wash., Nov. 28 (UPI)Customers and employees of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul & Pacific Railroad proposed yesterday to buy line of the bankrupt railroad that runs between Louisville, Ky., and Seattle.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Sarabande in D minor, Handel; Fantasia, Purcell; El pelele, Granados; Trio Sonata No. 2, Sammartini; Polonaise for Violin and Chamber Orchesrtra, Schubert.

title: Venezuela Pushing Untapped Heavy Oil
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 28  As Americans prepare for possible winter shortages of the oil used to heat homes, run industry and power electric generating plants, Venezuela is pushing ahead with a program to make this South American republic one of the world's top exporters of such fuels well into the next century.

title: KEY GOODS IN SOVIET FALL SHORT OF GOAL
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 28  The Soviet Gov: ernment acknowledged today that there were shortfalls in production plans fore coal, oil, steel and agriculture in 1979 and announced lower growth rates in 1980 for consumer goods, heavy industry and food supplies.

title: $100,000 in Birth Pills Missing
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 28 (UPI)  Twentythree thousand packets of birth control pills valued at more than $100,000 were found to be missing in the Chicago Health Department's sixmonth audit. The pills, known as Orval, were missing from the department's central warehouse, Terry Hocin, Deputy Health Commissioner, I said yesterday.

title: Senate Unit Votes to Narrow Law Against Soliciting Criminal Acts
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP)  The Senate Judiciary Committee voted today to narrow proposed legislation against trying to persuade a person to commit a crime.

title: Warners to Market 20 Films on Tapes
description: Warner Bros. announced yesterday that it would sell video cassette recordings of 20 of its films, including Superman, The Exorcist and All the President's Men, through its consumer videotape division, WCI Home Video.

title: Paraguay President in Argentina
description: BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 28 (Reuters) President Alfredo Stroessner of Paraguay arrived today on a twoday official visit. He was met at the Buenos Aires airport by President Jorge Rafael Videla, with whom he will have talks.

title: Supreme Court Rejects City Plea On School Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28  New York City failed today in its bid before the Supreme Court to obtain $3.5 million in special school aid for which the Federal Government had found the city schools ineligible two years ago.

title: Veterans' Benefits Are Raised
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP)  President Carter has signed legislation raising by 9.9 percent the benefits for 2.5 million disabled veterans and survivors of veterans, it was announced today. The increase is retroactive to Oct. 1.

title: A Rose for Frederic Forrest
description: LOS ANGELES THERE are four or five pinup postcards of nude women on the bedroom wall. They cover the small holes Frederic Forrest kicked and punched through the plaster when he last got drunk, four months ago. The large holes are stuffed with newspaper.

title: The Saudi Oil Bargain: Who Is Benefiting?; Economic Analysis
description: By all appearances, industry analysts say, oil consumers and the big oil companies are sharing the benefit of bargain oil from Saudi Arabia.

title: Nuclear Waste Dump In Washington Is Open
description: OLYMPIA, Wash., Nov. 28 (AP)  The lowlevel nuclear waste dump at Hanford, one of only three in the nation, was reopened yesterday after being closed for six weeks for safety violations, the state energy director, Jack Wood. said.

title: Army Is Told to Upgrade Many Discharges
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP)  A Federal judge ordered the Army today to upgrade the less than honorable discharges of thousands of Vietnamera servicemen who were ousted for drug use.

title: $1 Million Theft An Inside Job, Authorities Say
description: Federal and state authorities in New Jersey said yesterday that they believed that the disappearance of about $1 million in cash and checks from an Edison bank over the weekend was an inside job.

title: 2 Youths With Knives Rob Stein and Fiance
description: Andrew J. Stein, the Manhattan Borough President, was robbed of $100 by two youths with knives last night as he and his fiance were walking his dog at the edge of Central Park.

title: STRESSES DIPLOMACY But He Speaks of Possible Actions Once Present Effort Is Exhausted
