description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28  President Carter warned again last night that he would hold the Iranian Government fully responsible for the safety of the American hostages in Teheran and said that he was determined to do all he could to gain their release by diplotnatic and peaceful means.

title: BLACK LEGAL GROUP HONORS GREENBERG
description: Three years out of Columbia Law School, Jack Greenberg told a wellknown New York City law firm in the spring of 1951 that he was considering its offer to hire him but that he first wanted to argue a case aimed at guaranteeing blacks the right to enter public colleges in Delaware.

title: Transit Mall Carrying Central Portland to Renewal
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  When people wait for buses in New York City they often do so under rather thin, almost flimsy, metal and glass shelters that are advertising devices first, public conveniences second. Here in Portland,however, the city has just come up with bus shelters of a different breed: structures so substantial they look like whole buildings by comparison with theirNew York counterparts.

title: Improvement Loans: Harder to Obtain
description: WITH mortgage money for new houses virtually evaporating in the New York metropolitan area, many people are turning to home ims provement loans as a way to make their present houses more livable. Butdepending upon what banks they approach, people may find it very difficult to transform their dream into reality.

title: Rockies Beat Islanders for First Time
description: DENVER, Nov. 28 (AP)  The Colorado Rockies ended nearly three years of frustration tonight as Ron Delorme connected for two goals and the Rockies defeated the New York Islanders for the first time in the National Hockey League, 74.

title: U.S. Still Expecting a U.N. Meeting
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 28 Donald F. McHenry, the United States delegate, said today that the Security Council was likely to go ahead with its planned meeting on the American hostages in Teheran despite the dismissal of the Iranian Acting Foreign Minister, Abolhassan BaniSadr.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (UPI)The Commerce Department charged Core Laboratories Inc. today with violating a law prohibiting United States companies from?? cooneratine with ??the Arab con of trade with Israel.

title: Sound
description: IT must be the season  what with Christmas getting close  but most letters arriving here lately have been telling us to lay off general discussions for a while and come up with some specific hints.

title: Judge Leo Brewster, 76, Of U.S. Court in Texas
description: FORT WORTH, Tex., Nov. 28 (AP) Federal District Judge Leo Brewster, who presided over the desegregation of Fort Worth schools and was known for his strict sentences and courtroom rules, died at his home last night. He was 76 years old.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: THURSDAY. NOVEMBER 29, 1979

title: Iran Cites CreditLetter Shift
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 28 (Re?? ters)  Iran has converted all dollardenominated letters of credit into major European and Asian currencies, including the Japanese yen, West German mark and British pound, the official Pars press agency said today.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: GIFTS for HEART &
description: More gifts on page C6

title: Plane Reported Waiting for Shah As Physicians Say He Is Improved
description: The deposed Shah of Iran, Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, has recovered from the removal of a gallstone from his bile duct, and a plane was reported standing by at Kennedy International Airport last night to return him to his exile in Mexico, presumably within the next few days.

title: The City
description: A 19yearold Queens woman was sentenced in State Supreme Court to one and a half to four years in prison for her part in the firebombing of a subway token booth that resulted in the deaths of two women.

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: What's Sunday without The Times?

title: Question of Who Runs Iran Raised by BaniSadr Ouster
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 28  When Abolhassan BaniSadr said a few days ago that Iranian banks might not repay obligations of nearly $15 billion to foreign banks, the two ministries that he headed at the time were as startled as the international financial community.

title: EARNINGS
description: The General Public Utilities Corporation, owner of the Three Mile Island nuclear facility that was shut down last March, said yesterday that, although its revenues increased 11.5 percent in the first 10 months of the year, its net income in the period declined 23.1 percent.

title: Joan Saslow Is Married To Edward Klagsbrun
description: In the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue in Manhattan yesterday afternoon, Joan Saslow, daughter of Dr. Stella K. Saslow of South Orange, N.J., and the late Dr. Benjamin Saslow, became thebride of Edward Klagsbrun, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacques Klagsbrun of Manhattan. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Edward E. Klein.

title: Schools Superintendent Resigns From Troubled Chicago System
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 28  The superintendent of schools, Joseph Hannon, unexpectedly announced today that he had decided to resign, stunning officials of the city and of the school system, which is experiencine a severe financial crisis.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yesterday's Weather at 1 P.M.: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration/UPI

title: Crucial Time for Hostages Starts Tonight With Holiday
description: The most emotional holy day of the Shiite Moslem year, the 10th day of Muharram, will begin tonight period of mourning, selfflagellation, processions and epic poems extolling martyrdom that could inflame the situation in Iran.

title: Nuggets Thompson Goes To Hospital for XRays
description: BOSTON, Nov. 27 (AP)  David Thompson, the Denver Nuggets scoring star, was taken to a hospital for Xrays tonight after he was struck in the head while diving for a loose ball during the Nuggets National Basketball Association game with the Boston Celtics.

title: McEnroe Beats Gerulaitis
description: MILAN, Italy, Nov. 28 (AP)  John McEnroe struggled to defeat Vitas Gerulaitis, 76, 46, 62, in the third round of the $300,000 Masters roundrobin tennis tournament tonight.

title: Hearings on Rep. Flood Set
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP)  Hearings will begin Dec. 12 in the Congressional investigation of charges that Representative Daniel J. Flood, Democrat of Pennsylvania, took payoffs in exchangefor using his influence, the House ethics committee decided today. Mr. Flood's bribery and conspiracy trial in Federal District Court ended in a hung jury last Feb. 3.

title: Orinoco Plan Presented
description: MONTREAL, Nov. 28  Representatives of Venezuela's oil industry today presented their longrange plans for the Orinoco reserves to an international energy conference here.

title: Arab School on West Bank Is Attacked
description: JALAZOUN REFUGEE CAMP, IsraeliOccupied West Bank, Nov. 28 The Jalazoun Girls School, which is run by the United Nations, was built with large windows to catch the sunlight that floods the nearby stony hills. Early on typical morning, behind those panes,classrooms are filled with Palestinian girls aged 6 to 15, mostly from refugee families, jammed together on hard wooden benches for the first of the school's double sessions.

title: The Program
description: THE third and last of the GiuliniLos Angeles Philharmonic concerts last night in Carnegie Hall brought the Verdi Requiem, nearly an hour and a half of some of the most sublime music ever written. The soloists were RenataScotto, Florence Quivar, Veriano Luchetti and Martti Talvela, with the Temple University Choir. Miss Quivar was a lastminute replacement for an indisposed Julia Hamari. It should be said at the outset that Miss Quivar fit into the ensemble as though she had had the benefits of all previous rehearsals and performances.

title: U.S. Steel Defends Past Policies
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 28  David M. Roderick, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, denied vehemently today that past management policies had contributed to the problems of its steel operations that led to the company's decision to close 15 plants, throwing 13,000 employees out of work.

title: Venezuelan Oil Cutback
description: ABU DHABI, Nov. 28 (UPI)  Venezuela will reduce oil production by more than 6 percent  150,000 barrels a day  as a conservation measure beginning Jan. 1, the Venezuelan

title: Opera: Julien Robbins Is Gremin in Met Onegin
description: JULIEN ROBBINS, a young bass from Harrisburg, Pa., with experience in several other American companies, is singing a great many small roles with the Metropolitan Opera in this, his debut,season there. He was first heard as the King in Verdi's Aida four weeks ago. Last Monday night he sang Prince Gremin in Tchaikovsky's Eugene Onegin. Brief as the part is, it tests the singer's range and style, and the character's sole appearance, in the first scene of the last act, is devoted to one of the most famous arias in the bass repertory.

title: About Princeton
description: PRINCETON, N.J.  The silence was deafening in the square mile of woods and green fields that enclose the New York metropolitan area's most exclusive suburban development, the Institute for Advanced Study.

title: Theater: Schnorrers, Search for Happiness
description: KING OF SCHNORRERS is an attempt at crossbreeding the ethnic passion of Fiddler on the Roof with the intimate romantic charm of The Fantasticks.

title: Margaret Thatcher Facing Defeat at Market Talks
description: DUBLIN, Nov. 28  Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher faces almost certain defeat in her belligerent campaign to win a better deal for Britain from the European Economic Community when shebegins two days of meetings here tomorrow with leaders of the eight other Common Market countries.

title: Keith Hayes, Judge Who Presided Over Mormon Will Trial, Is Dead
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 28 (UPI) District Judge Keith Hayes, who presided over the socalled Howard R. Hughes Mormon will trial, died yesterday after suffering for six years from cancer. A funeral will be held Thursday for District Court . He was 46 years old.

title: Alien Gets 10 Years in PCP Case
description: Colin Stephen, a 38yearold illegal alien from Honduras, was sentenced to a 10year prison term for conspiracy to distribute phencyclidine, or PCP, a drug commonly called angel dust. Judge Milton Pollack imposed the maximum sentence on him in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Kissinger Said to Agree to Curb Remarks on U.S. Policy on Shah
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP)  Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance has asked Henry A. Kissinger to stop making public comments about the way the Carter Administration has dealt with the deposed Shah of Iran.

title: Books of The Times
description: ITHINK if two people are attracted to each other, it's O.K. for them to have sex. The sexual revolution has done that for us. Thus blabbers Tom Brady, a retired juvenilereformatory training officer, when his grown daughter, Katherine, confronts him with the fact of his having spent 10 years committing incest with her. Of course one could weep and rage at the monstrous stupidity of his rationalization. But one knows there is little point in weeping and raging. What she must do  what anyone in her position as an adult must do  is confront the incest, as she puts it near the end of her autobiography, and attempt to unravel the legacy of the past.

title: Mondale Tells Party Nation Needs Seasoned President
description: Trying out what he later said was a possible campaign theme, Vice President 11 Mondale told New York Democrats yesterday that the last four Presidents had served basically only one term and that they should not loosely change Presidencies.

title: Arms Pact Report by a 2d Panel Becomes Senate Issue
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28  Opponents of the strategic arms limitation treaty with the Soviet Union said today that they had persuaded 11 of the 17 members of the Senate Armed Services Committee to endorse a report critical of the treaty.

title: 7 Men Seized While Dismantling Stolen Truck Valued at $60,000
description: Seven men were arrested yesterday afternoon as they dismantled a stolen Mack truck valued at more than $60,000 in an unmarked yard at 165th Street and Liberty Avenue in Jamaica, Queens. The Police Department's automobile crime unit had been watching the yard for four weeks and moved in after identifying the truck as one stolen yesterday morning from the Royal Guard Fence Company in Westbury, L.I.

title: 3 Killed at Church in Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28 (AP) Four persons, including a 106yearold man, were shot today as they arrived at a church for a birthday party for a 104yearold woman, the police said. Three died and a fourth was critically injured.

title: N.Y.U. Phone Operator Accused Of Bilking Company of $1 Million
description: Felony charges were placed yesterday against a switchboard operator at New York University who allegedly cheated the New York Telephone Company of more than $1 million by selling cutrate overseas calls that electronically avoided the billing process.

title: Nations Back Trade Accord
description: GENEVA, Nov. 28 (Reuters) Delegates attending the annual meeting of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade here endorsed accords today cutting tariffs and lowering other barriers to trade in industrial and farm products in the 1980's.

title: Hers
description: AWEEK ago, on Thanksgiving Day, my aunt Dorothy, the family matriarch, died. She was 76 and had been straddling the edge of death with equanimity for many years. Death did not frighten her any more than life did, although it was a source of puzzlement to her, as wellas her doctors (several of whom died, closing their own cases before hers), that she continued to remain in this dimension, given her eagerness to experience the next one.

title: Pope Flies to Ankara for Visit Ignored by Most Turks
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 28  Pope John Paul II flew to this Moslem country today in an effort to give new impetus to the slowmoving reconciliation between the Roman Catholic Church and the Eastern Orthodox churches.

title: Mystery Deepens in Jordan Case Over Naming Special Prosecutor
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28  The mystery over whether a special prosecutor will be appointed to investigate accusa tions of cocaine use against Hamilton Jordan, the White House chief of staff, intensified today when the Justice Department scheduled and then abruptly canceled an announcement of its findings in the case.

title: CF&I Loses Wheeling Suit
description: DENVER, Nov. 28 (AP)  A Federal judge has ruled against the CF&I Steel Corporation's attempt to block a $63.5 million Federal loan guarantee to a competitor, the WheelingPittsburgh Steel Corporation.

title: COURT VOIDS SEARCH OF PATRONS IN A BAR
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28  The Supreme Court ruled today that a warrant to search a particular place does not automatically authorize the police to search anyone who happens to be there.

title: The Jets Rally To Support Of Michaels
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 28  With wounds and pride healed, the Jets were reunited as football team today for the first time since the Monday night debacle in Seattle.

title: A Tribunal On Iran?
description: As the search for exit from the horrors of Teheran continues, the public hears more and more talk of an international forum  a court, or something like it  to hear the Iranians grievances. The crisis, of course, is not a legal one at all, but a largescale failure of law to restrain political and religious outbursts.

title: Grande Dame Marks 60 Years of Recitals
description: France's JeanneMarie Dane is much too busy to dwell on the fact that she made her debut as a pianist 60 years ago, and she has done nothing to advertise it. But when she was asked to come to New York to play an anniversary recital at Carnegie Hall on Sunday afternoon, she was delighted.

title: Folk Music: John Fahey
description: IT was vast, John Fahey used to mutter, vast and hodological. There was always some doubt about what hodological meant, but it referred to a place somewhere in Mr. Fahey's imagination, a broad delta where the Mississippi and Ganges Rivers flowed together and people played music that sounded like, well, like John Fahey's music.

title: Restic, Dickey Named
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 29 (AP)  Joe Restic of Harvard and Jim Dickey of Kansas State were named today as coaches of the Blue squad for the 42d BlueGray football game Christmas Day.

title: LANCE BID REBUFFED ON A VENUE CHANGE
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 29 (AP)  A Federal judge today refused to move the bank fraud trial of Bert Lance, the former Federal budget director, from Atlanta to Rome, Ga.

title: KOCH IS CONFRONTED ON PROPERTY TAXES
description: A debate at a legislative hearing on property taxes spilled out onto the streets of lower Manhattan yesterday, leading to an angry meeting of Mayor Koch and a group of homeowners.

title: Britain Demands Common Market Help
description: DUBLIN, Nov. 29 Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher told Britain's Common Market partners today that they must act at once to reduce what she called the unacceptable and inequitable level of her country's financial obligations to the European Economic Community.

title: Birmingham Policeman Slain
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 29 (AP) A Birmingham policeman was shot to death this afternoon after a bank robbery just two days before he was eligible for retirement, the police said. A robbery suspect, tentatively identified as Joe Henderson, was seriously wounded by the police. Sgt. Gene Ballard, 46 years old, would have been on the police force 20 years Saturday. The patrolman was shot after the suspect had allegedly robbed the Jefferson Federal Savings and Loan Association office.

title: J. S. Roberts, 67, Led Woolworth's
description: John Stuart Roberts, a former president of the F. W. Woolworth Company, died Wednesday at Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 67 years old and lived in Harding Township. N.J.

title: World Gold
description: THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 29, 1979

title: Recruiting via Acquisitions
description: The other shoe never dropped after Continental Group Inc. completed two major acquisitions to round out the packaging company's push into new businesses. None of the top executives of the new companies was dismissed.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Recent films from West Germany will be shown at the Museum of Modern Art through Dec. 21. This afternoon at 2:30 P.M. the work will be Josef Rdl's Albert  Why?, a portrait of a slowwitted young man and his village's reaction to him. Other films in the series are scheduled tomorrow at 2:30 and 6 P.M. and Sunday at 2:30. The documentaries are narrated in English, and all other films in the series have English subtitles. Films are free with museum admission or membership, but get there early. Information: 9567294.

title: Federal Aid Allocated To Spur Adoptions
description: WASHINGTON,  The Department of Health, Education and Welfare has awarded nearly $5 million to the Adoption Opportunities Program, recently established by the Office of Human Development Services to find permanent homes for hard-toplace foster children.

title: Strauss Views Jersey as for Carter
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 29  Robert S. Strauss, President Carter's reelection chairman, said today that he had found overwhelming support for Mr. Carter's candidacy during a series of meetings with New Jersey businessmen and political leaders.

title: Des Moines Paper Terms Brown Closer to Becoming a Candidate
description: DES MOINES, Nov. 29  Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California made second campaign sortie into Iowa today, gaining a concession from The Des Moines Register that he was moving closer to becoming a candidate in the state, but not a decision whether he will be invited to join a debate between President Carter and Senator Edward M. Kennedy.

title: Cabaret: Nacha Guevara, Argentina's Piaf, Sings
description: NACHA GUEVARA is special. The Argentine singer, who is appearing at the Manhattan Theater Club, has been compared with Edith Piaf, although as likely a comparison is Judy Garland, and, although she never was much in the way of singing, La Pasionaria, too. Miss Guevera is gamin and waif, but she is more than winsome, and when she goes most deeply into herself, she at her best. She is not just a supperclub singer; she is a performer.

title: Hard-to-Place Children Find Homes Through Newspapers
description: Norman Kulp, an electric motor repairman, and his wife Carol have six children, ranging in age from 21 to 8. Matthew, the youngest, suffers from Down's syndrome, or mongolism.

title: Boxing Set to Coronate Leonard
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 29  Two days after the death of Willie Classen, boxing will celebrate its biggest night of the postAli era tomorrow when Sugar Ray Leonard, the successor to Muhammad Ali as the sport's greatest hero, fights for his first world championship.

title: France Preparing Currency Proposal
description: DUBLIN, Nov. 29  A cryptic promise by President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France to unveil a currency stabilization plan early next year is stirring interest in European political circles, according to diplomatic sources.

title: Radio
description: 8:159 A.M., WQXR. Clarinet Concerto No. 1.

title: Off-the-Beaten-Path Guide to Moviegoing
description: For movie lovers looking for something out of the ordinary this weekend, how about a series of documentaries on life in Appalachia? Or an eclectic selection of animated avantgarde films? Or perhaps the Chris HegedusD. A. Pennebaker film, Town Bloody Hall, which records a raucous debate that took place between Norman Mailer, Diana Trilling and some celebrated feminists April 30, 1971, in New York's Town Hall?

title: Van Cortlandt Park Repair Asked
description: A project costing $20 million to $40 million is needed to prevent the 1,146acre Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx from becoming a useless land mass, City Councilwoman June M. Eisland said yesterday. She said poor drainage and negject had ruined various facilities, including the bridle path, Van Cortlandt Lake, the golf course and a crosscountry path. Park Commissioner Gordon J. Davis said he concurred both with Mrs. Eisland's assessment and her view that the work could be financed with state and Federal funds.

title: XRays Find No Damage To Thompson of Nuggets
description: BOSTON, Nov. 29 (AP)  David Thompson, the Denver Nuggets star, appeared to be unhurt today after having undergone head and neck Xrays and a onehour examination last night at University Hospital. He was injured during a 11997 loss to the Boston Celtics.

title: Dividends
description: THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 29, 1979

title: Iran Asset Freeze Spurs Legal Warring by Banks
description: The freeze on Iranian assets has touched off legal warring in banking circles and an unseemly scramble by American banks to protect themselves financially by attaching one another's Iranian deposits.

title: HOPES OF TRUCE RISE AT RHODESIA PARLEY
description: LONDON, Nov. 29  Joshua Nkomo, one of the two leaders of the Zimbabwe Rhodesia guerrilla forces, said today that agreement on a ceasefire in the sevenvearold civil war might be imminent.

title: Calvin Klein Nears Cosmetics Unit Sale
description: The Calvin Klein Cosmetics Company is expected to be sold to a large foreign company shortly, according to Barry Schwartz, partner in Calvin Klein Ltd., the parent company.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Nuclear Reactors Held Safer Than Operators
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 29, Reuters  The head of the International Atomic Energy Agency said today that nuclear power reactors functioned better than the men who operated them.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yesterday's Weather at 1 P.M.: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration/UPI

title: Burger Denies Request to Delay A Release of Scientology Data
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (UPI)  Chief Justice Warren D. Burger of the Supreme Court today denied without comment a request by the Church of Scientology to delay a Federal judge's order releasing thousands of pages of church documents seized by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in 1977.

title: Five Teams Can Qualify for Playoffs in Pro Football
description: The playoff picture in the National Football League can be clarified considerably on Sunday because the right combination of victories and defeats could qualify five teams for places in the postseason tournament that begins Dec. 22. If Houston, Pittsburgh and San Diego all win in the American Conference, they will assure themselves, at least, of wildcard berths in the playoffs.

title: 18 More Korean Dissidents Held as Unrest Spreads
description: SEOUL, South, Korea, Nov. 29  The martial law authorities arrested 18 Christian activists in the southwestern city of Kwangju yesterday as antiGovernment unrest spread outside the capital for the first time since the assassination of President Park Chung Hee last month, dissident sources said today.

title: HOUSES (100)
description: 4sty brownstone; 20 tt wide. Nice mouldings many WBFols. Panelled Library opening onto very attractive south garden. Hi-ceilings. 5 BRs, 2 servnts $765.000

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Coop City Pays One Month's Taxes
description: Calling it a very positive sign of good faith and cooperation, Mayor Koch announced yesterday that the 60,000tenant Coop City housing project had paid one month's real estate taxes, the first taxes it has paid directly to the city in four years.

title: H.U.D. Drops 2d Renovation of a South Bronx Project
description: After spending more than $4 million to renovate 20 South Bronx apartment buildings, Federal officials have decided that the project is unworkable. They are considering relocating the remaining tenants and demolishing the buildings.

title: Folk Festival Lures Bands And Dancers
description: NOT a fiddler from Norway or a bagpiper from Bulgaria escapes the attention of researchers for the Balkan Arts Center. For 13 years this nonprofit cultural organization in Manhattan has been combing the immigrant communities of the United States for inheritors of European folkmusic traditions. This weekend some of the center's prize finds will gather in New York to entertain and instruct the public at the 12th annual Winter Folk Festival.

title: Major Show by an Unknown Sculptor
description: THE American artist Raoul Hague, born in 1905, is probably the most admired unknown sculptor on the current art scene. That he is so admired means, of course, that he is not literally unknown, yet many people who have a wide experience of contemporary sculpture will be unacquainted with his work. His last solo exhibition in a New York gallery occurred in 1962. A retrospective exhibition tooK place two years later at the now defunct Washington Gallery of Modern Art, and isolated examples of Mr. Hague's sculpture have been seen at the Zabriskie Gallery and elsewhere in the interim. But for the art public at large, Mr. Hague  although much esteemed by certain critics and museum curators who have managed to keep track of his work  has remained a shadowy figure

title: Kennedy, in Iowa, Vows to Press For Rights of Women if Elected
description: IOWA CITY, Nov. 29  Senator Edward M. Kennedy said today that if he was elected President he would push hard I for equal rights for women, an issue on which he has received some criticism in the past.

title: Computer Ranking
description: The University of Alabama's undefeated, untied but rarely tested football team remained No. 1 in The New York Times weekly computer ranking on the eve of what may be its first real test of the season.

title: Art: Symbolists In America at Grey
description: UNTIL quite recently, American symbolist painting ranked nowhere with the people who formed opinion in matters of art. Modernism was all, and if you happened to own a painting by Ethel I. Brown, Rex Slinkard or Edith K. Nag ler you would have been lucky to give it away. let alone sell it. As for George Hitchcock's Blessed Mother of 1892, it was the American equivalent of the Paris Salon painting of its date, and you couldn't say worse than that.

title: The Pop Life
description: THE Art Ensemble of Chicgo will be concluding a 14city American tour tonight and tomorrow night at the Public Theater. This writer and quite a few other people expect when the history of jazz in the 70's is written, the Art Ensemble will prove to have been the decade's most important group, and happily enough its importance is beginning to be widely recognized. People were turned away from a number of concerts on the present tour, and the Public Theater shows are sold out. The five musicians now fly to their engagements while roadies drive their mountain of instruments  huge gongs, percussion devices too numerous to mention and just about every variety of saxophone and woodwind  from city to city in a vehicle the band owns. Nice Guys, the Art Ensemble's most recent album, is readily available on the Warner Brothersdistributed E.C.M. label. And the group and its individual members made an exceptionally strong showing in the readers' poll recently conducted by the jazz magazine Downbeat.

title: Journalist Sentenced To a Year by Pakistan For Article on Unrest
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 29  A Pakistani journalist was sentenced to a year of hard labor by a military court in Rawalpindi today for having written an article for a foreign publication about secessionist feelings in a western province.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: A Long Island attorney, Sanford M. Litvack of Rockville Centre, will be nominated as an Assistant Attorney General to succeed John H. Shenefield as head of the Justice Department's antitrust division, President Carter announced yesterday in Washington. The choice must be confirmed by the Senate.

title: N.L.R.B. Counsel Nominated
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (UPI)  William Lubbers, a 27year veteran of the National Labor Relations Board, was nominated yesterday by President Carter as the agency's new general counsel for a fouryear term. If confirmed by the Senate, Mr. Lubber, a Democrat, will succeed John Irving, a Republican, whose term expired Oct. 19.

title: About Real Estate
description: No housing development issue in the city has been more difficult and contentious over a longer period than the shaping of the West Side urban renewal area. Not surprisingly, some Koch administration officials were relieved by the Board of Estimate's approval two weeks ago of the fifth amendment to the 20yearold urban renewal plan. It sets the development pattern for all but two of the remaining unbuilt sites, though each proposal must get further approval from the Department of Housing and Urban Development.

title: FREEZE ON BUILDING OF NUCLEAR PLANTS REJECTED BY HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON. Nov. 29  The House of Representatives today overwhelmingly rejected a proposal to impose a sixmonth moratorium on the construction of new nuclear reactors.

title: White House to Speed Bill Seeking More Money to Spur Use of Coal
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29  A White House aide said today that within days the Administration would send Congress a substantially enlarged version of a $5 billion measure to massively increase the use of coal.

title: Opera: La Gioconda Returns to Met
description: PONCHIELLI'S La Gioconda, absent from the Metropolitan Opera repertory for three seasons, was revived last night with some major roles newly cast and others taken by artists making their debut with the company. Grace Bumbry in the title role, Mario Sereni as Barnaba and Paul Plishka as Alvise were all appearing in the opera for the first time at the Met. Joining the cornpany with this performance were Bruna Baglioni as Laura, Jocelyne Taillon as La Cieca and James Courtney as a monk. Carlo Bergonzi returned to the part of Enzo Grimaldo, and Giuseppe Patane again conducted.

title: S.E.C. Head Cites Shift On Securities Industry
description: BOCA RATON, Fla. Nov. 29  Harold M. Williams, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, detailed for the securities industry today the commission's new emphasis on the economic state of the industry.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Meets at 3 P.M. on the United Nations force on the Golan Heights.

title: Policemen in Salvador Discover a Truck Used In Envoy's Abduction
description: SAN SALVADOR, Nov. 29 (AP)  Policemen found a small blue pickup truck today that had been used in the kidnapping of the South African Ambassador, Archibald Gardner Dunn. Officials said there was no evidence of violence in the car.

title: Around the Nation
description: DETROIT, Nov. 29 (AP)  The Wayne County Board of Commissioners adopted a controversial $281 million budget today that averts a layoff of all county workers this weekend.

title: Deaths
description: BEKAERTArsene C., on November 28, 1979 Beloved husband of Lucille. Devoted father of Nancy and Denise. Dear brother of Mariette Granet. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St, Thursday 79pm. Service Friday 2:39 pm. In lieu of flowers, a contribution to your favorite charity would be appreciated.

title: Joining of Three Institutions Is Urged by U of Bridgeport
description: BRIDGEPORT, Cornn., Nov. 29  The president of the University of Bridgeport, citing declining enrollment and a need for better use of educational resources, proposed today that the private institution be consolidated with the University of Connecticut and Housatonic Junior College.

title: Stocks Up a Bit, Led by Defense and Metals
description: Selected defense stocks and precious metal issues moved higher yesterday as the general market produced a token advance.

title: Nicaragua Hopes to Create Sanctuary for Sea Turtles
description: WASHINGTON, Nov 29  The recent revolution in Nicaragua may turn out to be an unexpected boon to the sea turtle, a vanishing species.

title: 7 Americans Are Killed in Mexico As Tour Bus Collides With Truck
description: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 29 (UPI)  A truck collided with a bus carrying a group of United States tourists yesterday, killing at least 7 Americans and injuring 16, the police said today. A Mexican was also killed.

title: Music: Guarneri Quartet
description: ANY string quartet that has established a reputation and acquired a devoted following, as the Guarneri String Quartet certainly has in the 14 years since its New York debut, occasionally feels the need to expand into the wider chambermusic repertory. Musicians and public alike have their favorites, and a few beloved pieces tend to turn up on programs so regularly that their impact can be dulled by overfamiliarity. And so the kind of exploratory program that the Guarneri offered on Wednesday night, when it gave the first of a series of concerts at Alice Tully Hall, ought to be encouraged.

title: Rangel Expected to Back Carter's Reelection Bid Today
description: WASHINTON, Nov. 29  Representative Charles B. Rangel, the Manhattan Democrat regarded as New York City's most influential black elected official, plans to announce tomorrow his endorsement of President Carter for reelection.

title: Article 2 -- No Title
Indiana Schoolgirl Five Suffers Defeat, 105 to 13
description: GREENCASTLE, Ind., Nov. 29 (AP)  It may have been difficult for the coach of Cascade High School's girls' basketball team to come up with some encouraging words at halftime of its game last night with Greencastle.

title: Stylish 26-Year-Old Takes Over Tatler
description: LONDON, Nov. 29  The venerable old Tatler, which has had a lot of ups and downs over the last 270 years, is undergoing yet another facelift, at the direction of a saucy young satirist named Tina Brown.

title: Publishing: Auden Biographer Reflects on His Work
description: FLATTERY and money can do a great deal, said Charles Osborne. The Australianborn writer on music who is also the literature director of Britain's Arts Council, was telling how he came to write W. H. Auden: The Life of a Poet (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich)

title: Fitness After Knockout In London Bout Disputed
description: Serious questions about the conduct of Willie Classen's last fight at the Felt Forum, and of the extent of his injuries in his previous fight, in London on Oct. 9, were raised yesterday as investigations continued into the fighter's death.

title: Sabres Top Rangers On Martin Goal, 21
description: BUFFALO, Nov. 29  The struggling Rangers have reached the point where they have begun talking about moral victories. In fact, they regarded tonight's 21 loss to the Sabres as one of their more significant moral victories.

title: New Face: Kelly Reno
description: AT the Plaza the other morning, a diminutive, roundfaced young man loped through the lobby decked out in a cowboy shirt, jeans, boots and a fourgallon hat. Some of the hotel's patrons sized up Kelly Reno as the embodiment of western chic. But in fact, young Mr. Reno was wearing his everyday clothes; the 13yearold, accompanied by his parents, Bud and Ruth Reno, had recently arrived from their X77 Ranch, an 8,000acre spread outside Pueblo, Colo. The reason for their visit was the world premiere of The Black Stallion, a film in which the youngster has top billing while making his debut as an actor.

title: A Correction
description: In an article about making and decorating gingerbread houses in The Living Section Wednesday, the amount of powdered cinnamon to use was given incorrectly in the recipe. The proper amount is one half teaspoon.

title: Taxing Freud
description: As Freud's reputation grew he began to receive patients from abroad, which suggests that they were probably wealthy. This fact did not escape the notice of the Austrian tax authorities, who eventually sent him a letter demanding an account of his earnings during this active period.

title: TV Weekend
description: THE heroine has been 12 years a whore and five times a wife. Perfectly in tune with the current incest fad, she was even married to her own brother. And for a final flourish, she is born again in an orgy of repentence.

title: 4 Police Officers in Anticrime Unit Accused of Robbing Drug Dealers
description: Four Brooklyn police officers accused of systematically robbing drug dealers and failing to arrest them were indicted yesterday on 38 counts of receiving bribes, extortion, burglary and official misconduct.

title: Carter Is Said to Choose A Refugee Affairs Chief
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29  President Carter has decided to appoint Victor H. Palmieri, a Los Angeles lawyer and business executive, as coordinator for refugee affairs, succeeding former Senator Dick Clark, Administration officials said today.

title: Finland's Pearl Harbor
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  Forty years ago, as a 22yearold ordnance officer, I was standing watch at a border post on the Karelian Isthmus when the opening salvo of the bitter RussoFinnish winter war of 193940 exploded in front of me. The Russians, fearing a German attack through Finland, had sought territory in Karelia to protect Leningrad, but Finland refused to yield any land. I remember Nov. 30, 1939, as Finland's Pearl Harbor.

title: Montreal Bus and Subway Drivers Join the List of Strikers in Quebec
description: MONTREAL, Nov. 29 (Reuters) About 4,000 bus and subway drivers stopped work here today for the third time this month in protest over the shift system. The stoppage was expected to last 24 hours, but could last longer, union 1 leaders said.

title: Poles to Try 4 Dissidents For Nationalist Speeches
description: WARSAW, Nov. 29 (Reuters)  Four Polish dissidents will appear before a Warsaw court on Dec. 10 to face charges arising from an unauthorized demonstration and speeches earlier this month on Poland's Independence Day, one of the dissidents said today.

title: ARMS PACT ASSAILED IN DISPUTED REPORT
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29  A draft of a suggested report by the Senate Armed Services Committee says the arms limitation treaty with the Soviet Union is not in the national security interests of the United States and it recommends that the Senate not consent to ratification in its Dresent form.

title: Bankers Trust Asia Unit
description: LONDON, Nov. 29 (Reuters) Bankers Trust International (Asia) Ltd., a unit of the Bankers Trust Company, said today that it had been incorporated as a merchant bank in Singapore. The bank said it would open for business in February and would concentrate on underwriting, selling and trading bonds, and floating rate notes and certificates of deposit in the AsiaPacific area.

title: Historic Integration Case On Schools Is Reopened
description: TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 29 (AP)  The historic Brown v. Board of Education case, which began here 28 years ago and led to the United States Supreme Court's 1954 ban on racial segregation in schools, was reopened by a Federal judge today after a group of parents complained that schools were not yet integrated.

title: Exhibit on South Bronx Weaves a Complex Web
description: Most parts of New York City that have strong symbolic identities are aided by them. At Wall Street, for example, the romance of high finance obscures the mundane nature of everyday existence there, as the glamour of Park Avenue covers up a certain blandness.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: AMERICAN ACCORD (U.S. Lines). Rotterdam Dec. 13, Bremerhaven 15 and LeHavre 17; sails from Howland Hook, Staten Island.

title: New Zealand Recovery Team Flies To Site of Air Crash in Antarctica
description: McMURDO STATION, Antarctica, Friday, Nov. 30  Eight New Zealand mountaineers flew by helicopter last night to a mountainside north of here to prepare for efforts to recover as many of the bodies as possible of the 2.57 people who died Wednesday in a plane crash.

title: Digest BUSINESS. Digest
description: Companies

title: 6 U.S. Governors Touring Soviet Meet With Kuznetsov at Kremlin
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 29 (UPI)  A delegation of six United States Governors met with Vice President Vasily V. Kuznetsov in the Kremlin today to discuss the strategic arms treaty and other topics.

title: Life Is Rigorous For Petitioners Filling Peking
description: PEKING, Nov. 29  No one seemed to know who she was. Judging from her tattered clothes and matted hair, she was probably a petitioner, one of the thousands still camped in Peking despite the bitter weather that has swept down from Siberia, freezing the lakes and painting dashes of red in young people's cheeks.

title: BOSTON U. ASSAILED ON BASIC FREEDOMS
description: BOSTON, Nov. 29Boston University, 1 the nation's largest private university and in recent years the center of a swirl of dissension and bitterness over the policies and personality of its president, was accused today of widespread violations of civil liberties and academic freedom.

title: Bid Entertainers Mean Dollars to Democratic Rivals
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 29  Besides votes, precinct delegates and party power brokers, the three major Democratic candidates for President are also ardently wooing important new political assets of an altogether different kind  rock stars, Nashville pickers and popular singers.

title: Screen: Jean Seberg In a Spanish Setting:A Summer in Spain
description: "THE Corruption of Chris Miller," Juan Antonia Bardem's English-dubbed Spanish film opening today at the Thalia, is being billed as Jean Seberg's last movie and as having been made in 1976, though the short skirts would seem to date its production at least several years earlier. In addition, the film's preoccupation with a kind of doomy, unfulfilling heterosexuality, with lesbianism as the alternative, recalls the bogus breakthroughs made by some European film makers in the late 60's, when censorship boards everywhere began to crack.The film, however, is typical of those of the later period of Miss Seberg's life abroad. The settings and costumes mean to be chic; the melodrama is absurd, and Miss Seberg, her beauty unimpaired, gives an extremely sincere performance that is never particularly convincing. Once again, though, she gives dimension to a film of no great interest just because her presence is so unexpected. What, one keeps wondering, is this quintessentially American beauty, a woman who speaks in the flat accents of her native Iowa, doing in the middle of so much quintessential European decadence?We never do find out.In "The Corruption of Chris Miller" Miss Seberg plays Ruth, a successful London fashion designer spending the summer at her country villa in Spain with her equally beautiful, neurotic, teen-age stepdaughter, Chris (Marisol).Before I go further I have to explain that "The Corruption of Chris Miller" is the kind of movie in which a couple of very important things have happened before the start of the story  events whose revelation in the course of the film are entirely arbitrary: Ruth has been abandoned by Chris's father just one year before and (no connection here) Chris had been brutally raped in the shower of her dance school by a large hairy man.As the movie begins, it's apparent that the two women are spending a very edgy time together. Chris hates Ruth and yet she seems to respond to her stepmother's love, which is somewhat more than a mother's. Into this situation, already fairly fraught with problems, comes a handsome young Englishman named Barney (Barry Stokes), a drifter who studies anthropology because, as he says, human beings interest him. As Barry sets about becoming the love object of each woman (at different times), the countryside where they live is terrorized by a series of murders. Could Barry be the hatchet-person? Could Chris? Ruth?A director less greedy and more gifted than Mr. Bardem would have thrown out one-half of the screenplay and concentrated on the other half, developing either the relationship between the two women or the more sensational aspects of the murder mystery. As it is, there's more going on than Mr. Bardem can make cinematic sense of.It's quite possible, of course, that Mr. Bardem is saying something obliquely trenchant here about Spanish society under Franco, but to the rest of us "The Corruption of Chris Miller," once titled "Behind the Shutters," looks more like a multinational co-production that doesn't work.

title: Priests in Portugal Helping Rightist Alliance
description: FATIMA, Portugal, Nov. 29  An eminent Socialist calls it, halfjokingly, the biggest political party in Portugal. The Roman Catholic Church is not running in Sunday's parliamentary election, but for the first time since the 1974 revolution priests and even some bishops are actively lobbying against both the Communist and Socialist Parties and in favor of a rightwing electoral alliance.

title: West Asks for Thai Refugee Camps to Be Put Under International Care
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 29  A number of Western nations have proposed to Secretary General Kurt Waldheim of the United Nations and the Thai Government that the two camps astride the CambodianThai border, where about a half million Cambodians have sought refuge from famine and war, be declared safe havens under international supervision.

title: Islam's Most Sacred Site
description: The presumed target of the attack last week by Moslem fanatics on the Grand Mosque at Mecca, the Kaaba shrine, is considered by Moslems to be the most sacred place on earth. It is to the Kaaba that they bow and pray five times each day according to the command of Allah in the Koran.

title: A Citizens Anticrime Mobilization Is Begun at a Rally in Foley Square
description: A crosssection of New Yorkers, from actresses to elected officials and from rabbis to restaurateurs, began a campaign yesterday against crime in the city.

title: Aides Say Civiletti Decision On Jordan Only Looks Bold
description: WASHINGTON  Benjamin R. Civiletti had barely finished moving his desk into the Attorney General's fifthfloor office at the Justice Department last August when he was faced with the potentially explosive allegation that Hamilton Jordan had used cocaine. Ever since, Justice Department officials say, the Jordan case has hung like a low cloud over the department, obscuring both the strengths and weaknesses of the new Attorney General.

title: Columbia Student Pleads Guilty To the Fatal Knifing of Girlfriend
description: Juntaro Mori, a 32yearold graduate student at Columbia University accused of stabbing his girlfriend to death last April, pleaded guilty to manslaughter in the first degree yesterday before Acting Justice Robert Haft of State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: U.S. Trade Deficit Reduced in October
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP)  The United States narrowed its trade deficit to $2 billion in October, even though expenditures for imported oil rose to a record $6.3 billion, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: POLAND REPRESSING FLYING UNIVERSITY
description: WARSAW, Nov. 29  A police campaign is threatening the teaching activities of the flying university, according to the organizers of the unofficial acad. emy of forbidden learning.

title: U.S. Magnate, Once Assailed, Is Hailed for Amazon Project
description: MONTE DOURADO, Brazil, Nov. 22The epic activities of Daniel K. Ludwig in the middle of this leafy nowhere have earned the American billionaire a prominent niche in the demonology of conservationists and third world nationalists concerned over the deflowering of their lands by outsiders.

title: Veto Hinted on Jet Noise Measure
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29  The White House indicated today that the President was prepared to veto pending legislation to relax Federal noise standards for jet aircraft.

title: Nuclear Device Is Tested
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 29 (AP)  The United States Department of Energy conducted an underground nuclear test today at Yucca Flat, about 90 miles northwest of here. The detonated device had a yield equivalent to less than 20,000 tons of TNT, a spokesman said.

title: Books of The Times
description: OF James Matthew Barrie, George Bernard Shaw said in a letter: I like Barrie and his work, but some day a demon in the shape of Alice will sit by the fire in hell and poke up the flames in which he is consuming. Who knows if Shaw was referring to Lewis Carroll's Alice or some other? Certainly, Wendy in Peter Pan was not an Alice, nor was Peter himself. As Barrie came to understand late in the game, Peter was not the boy who refused to grow up; he was, instead, the boy who wanted desperately to grow up and couldn't. However, and leaving aside for the moment any of what Vladimir Nabokov would have called the Viennese voodoo, there does seem to have been a fire, and in it Barrie was consumed.

title: EARNINGS
description: The Syntex Corporation, which makes pharmaceutical, agricultural and animal health care products and medical instruments, reported yesterday that it had a 7.32 percent decline in earnings for the first fiscal quarter ended Oct. 31 despite a 20 percent increase in sales.

title: Iranian Students in San Francisco Fighting Deportation at Hearings
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 29  A dozen Iranian students crowded into a small Federal courtroom here today to argue their right to remain in the United States.

title: Events and Openings
description: DIRTY MONEY, directed by Pierre Melville; starring Alain Delon and Catherine Deneuve. AND THE CORRUPTION OF CHRIS MILLER, directed by Juan Antonio Bardem; starring Jean Seberg, both at the Thalia Theater, today and tomorrow oniv.

title: Iranians Grieve for Dead of the Revolution
description: SHAH ABDUL AZIM, Iran, Nov. 29  A cold rain drives through Beheste Zahra Cemetery. In the failing afternoon light, hundreds of men and women and children, some with umbrellas, most with jackets or robes drawn over their heads, walk silently toward a large meadow.

title: British Petroleum Quarterly Net Soars
description: LONDON, Nov. 29  The British Petroleum Company today reported a huge increase in thirdquarter profits despite the loss of much of its supply of Iranian crude and the fact that it gets virtually none of Saudi Arabia's lowpriced oil.

title: Senate Unit Backs Aid To Chrysler
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29  The Senate Banking Committee approved $1.25 billion in Federal loan guarantees for the Chrysler Corporation tonight, but only on condition that Chrysler workers agree to give up wage increases recently won in their threeyear contract with the company.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29  President Carter struck the right notes in his news conference discussion of the actions of Iran that he said have shocked the civilized world. Firm in condemning these outrages, restrained nut properly warning about their consequences, he also seized the opportunity to make the fundamental point  that our overwhelming and excessive dependence on foreign oil makes the nation vulnerable to such tactics and endangers its security.

title: Leprosy Case in U.S. Confirmed
description: TULSA, Okla., Nov. 29 (AP)  Federal medical officials have confirmed a case of leprosy in an Oral Roberts University student from South America, but they say it is not contagious and the student can remain in classes. The disease was confirmed as the earliest stage of tuberculoid leprosy by a Federal leprosarium at Carrville, La. The name of the student and his native country were not released.

title: WASHINGTON Brave Old World
description: MOSCOW  Of all the major capitals of the world, Moscow seems to change more slowly than any other, with the possible exception of Peking. It has the spaciousness of an imperial city, with magnificent boulevards on a heroic scale, but it is somehow disappointing at the end of the 70's, as if somebody had lost the plan.

title: Ulster Man Wanted in 27 Killings Jailed on Arms Charge in Ireland
description: DUBLIN, Nov. 29 (UPI)  Desmond O'Hehir, sought by the Northern Ireland police in connection with at least 27 murder cases, was sentenced to nine years in prison on an arms charge today by a court in the Irish Republic.

title: With West Coast Man, Captives Now Total 50
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (UPI) The State Department now counts 50 hostages in the American Embassy in Teheran, with the addition of one private businessman to the 49 Government employees being held.

title: Books: Cast of Thousands
description: IT'S common knowledge that Hollywood directors shoot dozens of hours of film for every one that shows on the screen. Garson Kanin's novel, Moviola, reads like an uncut version of a 1940's spectacular. Here's the movie industry from Thomas Edison to Warren Beatty. Everybody makes a cameo appearance: It's a cast of thousands, each one a star. Reading Moviola is a bit like having the sky fall on you.

title: Vote on Nuclear Ban
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP)  Following is the roll call of votes by representatives from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut in the House's rejection of a temporary ban on new nuclear power construction. A yes represents a vote in favor of the ban and a no represents a vote against it; xxx means not voting.

title: Appeal of Sugar Ray Leonard, the Greatest Thing Since Ali
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 29  Ray Charles Leonard, president and sole owner of Ray Leonard Inc., and the richest contender to fight for a boxing title in any weight division in any period of history in any world, rested today  if submitting to a television interview can be called resting.

title: Sloop Sails for Britain In Race Against Time
description: The 57foot sloop Desperado set sail last night with a crew of nine in an attempt to break a 74yearold transAtlantic speed record.

title: What's a 17Letter Name for 14 Music Lovers?
description: This exchange was part of a conversation the other day with Richard Sortomme, the violinist, who is the spokesman and, to a certain extent, the creator of For the Love of Music, a chambermusic group. It gave its first

title: Philharmonic: Elijah,' Mendelssohn's Oratorio
description: THE need to consume Mendelssohnian oratorios is not bred into American audiences, as it has been into the English. For better or worse, most of us do not arrive at the concert hall ready and eager to be impressed by the aura of dignity, gentility and propriety that a work such as Eliiah exudes. If that raises a difficulty for any conductor who elects to present the work, it also affords him an opportunity: the chance to persuade his listeners that they are being exposed to a musical emotional experience, not the simulacrum of one.

title: Dolphins Defeat Patriots, 3924
description: MIAMI, Nov. 29 (AP)  Bob Griese, responding to Coach Don Shula's call for relief for the second time in five days, guided Miami to two touchdowns in the third period tonight to give the Dolphins a 3924 National Football League victory over the New England Patriots.

title: Soaps: More Than One Way to Make a Cake
description: Plain, and often pink, was the way soap used to be  the appropriate house present, or a reliable birthday gift for an older relative. But recently, soap has come out of the guest bath- room in a multitude of different guises.

title: Library's Lions Roar Thanks to New Yorkers
description: There was a great noise in the streets yesterday as Patience and Fortitude, the two marble lions of the Main Public Library, broke their 68year silence at 5:15 P.M. and roared in the Christmas season.

title: The Region
description: MOUNT VERNON, N.Y.  The City Council has voted unanimously to initiate pay raises of at least 25 percent for the Mayor, Comptroller, City Council President and two newly elected Council members.

title: Heating Up on Alaska
description: President Carter is reliably reported to have been dismayed by his loss of support within what had been one of his strongest and most deeply committed constituencies: those millions of Americans who love their landately weakened protections, bureaucratic confusion and opportunities for exploitative mismanagement. and want to see it  or what's left of it  protected for future generations from the wasteful private exploitation and public greed of this one.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
description: ART (GR 37014)

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The credit markets, affected by news of temporary shutdowns in the auto industry and a large decline in bank loans, rebounded yesterday afternoon, erasing their morning losses and closing with modest net price gains from Wednesday's levels.

title: CARTER SAID TO PLAN OVER LETELIER CASE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29  President Carter has decided to cut back diplomatic, military and economic relations with Chile in retaliation for its refusal to extradite three former secret police officers to stand trial for the murder in Washington of Orlando Letelier, a Chilean exile leader, Administration officials said today.

title: Fund for Philharmonic Raises $10.4 Million in Gifts and Pledges
description: Gifts, pledges and intended payments of $10.4 million have been made as part of a new campaign to raise $18 million for the endowment fund of the New York PhilharmonicSymphony Society. The announcement was made yesterday at the 29th annual Friends of the Philharmonic luncheon at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel by Amyas Ames, chairman, and Sampson R. Field, president, who are cochairmen of the campaign.

title: Auctions
description: TOYS traditionally assume major importance at auctions in the Christmas season. The annual Collector's Carrousel sale, which will be held next week at PB84, 171 East 84th Street, the uptown annex of Sotheby Parke Bernet, is offering toys in four of its five sessions, Wednesday and Thursday at 10 A.M. and 2 P.M. (the other session, Tuesday at 2 P.M., will concentrate on period clothing). A highlight of these sessions is a collection of 107 mechanical banks consigned by Miriam Meyer Butler and including many assembled by John D. Meyer, who was Mrs. Butler's uncle and a banker in Tyrone, Pa. Some of these are considered rarities, for instance, a bank in the shape of a wooden building, out of which pops a mouse, thus its name, Presto  Mouse on the Roof (it may sell for up to $13,000). Then there's a chimpanzee cashier at work (up to $9,000); an alligator in a trough (up to $7,000); a giant wielding a club (up to $6,500), and two roller skaters in a rink (up to $5,000). Not all the mechanical banks in this sale will break collectors' budgets. A number are estimated to sell for $40 and up, including many of the 70 examples consigned by other owners.

title: Kennedy's Health Plan Opposed by Mrs. Harris
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP)  Patricia Roberts Harris, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, said today that the health care plan offered by Senator Edward M. Kennedy would be so costly to employers that it would result in more unemployment and higher prices to consumers.

title: Man With the Right Credentials
description: When rumors began to spread in Manhattan's legal community Wednesday that a special prosecutor to investigate Hamilton Jordan was about to be appointed, one name appeared at the top or near the top of almost everyone's list of best bets: Arthur H. Christy.

title: Former Pros Accepted in Domestic Track
description: Professional athletes from the defunct International Track Association will be allowed to compete against amateurs in domestic meets throughout the United States this winter.

title: Let's Pay More for Gas  to Ourselves
description: When John Sawhill, then President Ford's energy adviser, proposed a big tax at the gas pump to reduce oil consumption, he was driven out of Washington in a gas guzzler. Now, he has returned as Deputy Secretary of Energy, and this time there are signs that his tax idea is being taken seriously. That's the best news yet. A gasoline tax whose revenues are used to eliminate state sales taxes could go a long way toward solving our energy problem without exacerbating inflation.

title: Urban Leaders Reflect Conservative Mood
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 29 At the annual convention of the National League of Cities, which ended last night, there was a run on one particular panel that caught the eye of mayors, councilors and commissioners from all regions.

title: Visas' Cancellations Are Mailed To 100 Iranians in New York City
description: The United States Immigration and Naturalization Service's district office in I Manhattan announced yesterday that visa cancellations have been mailed to 100 Iranians in the metropolitan area.

title: Fire at Orly Quickly Doused
description: PARIS, Nov. 29 (Reuters)  Firefighters put out a blaze in the basement of the main terminal at Orly Airport today after hundreds of people had been evacuated. The fire, first thought to be serious when thick, black smoke filled the terminal, was put out before it spread from the airport kitchens where it started, the police said. Damage was slight and air services were interrupted less than an hour, they added.

title: Tap Dance on Charlton St.
description: Dancing in the Streets  A Tap Dance at the Gym will be offered at Elizabeth Irwin High School, 90 Charlton Street, off the Avenue of the Americas and three blocks south of Bleecker Street, tonight, tomorrow and Sunday evenings through Dec. 16. The choreographer for the works is Gail Conrad, who is also one of the five dancers who will perform, along with four musicians, in Brazilian, Salsa and American jazz styles. Tickets are $3.50 (Theater Development Fund dance vouchers accepted). Information: 2799200.

title: Senate Oil Tax Accord Said to Gain; SavingsInterest Deductions Backed
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29  Senate leaders said tonight that they were close to a major agreement on President Carter's windfall tax bill that would save days or weeks of debate and divert enough revenue from the oil industry to satisfy the Administration.

title: 4 Convicted of Animal Cruelty
description: BOSSIER CITY, La., Nov. 29 (UPI)Four former employees of the city animal pound, including one who was shown on television beating a cat to death with pipe, have been convicted of cruelty to animals. City Judge Billy Ross Robinson convicted C.I. Blanton, Robert Jackson, Joe Jones, and Alejandro Vasquez yesterday. He scheduled sentencing for Dec. 11.

title: Article 1 -- No Title
The City
description: A 58yearold widow was bludgeoned to death in her Queens apartment last night, apparently by a robber who followed her into her building and attacked her as she unlocked her front door, the police said.

title: Bush, in Illinois, Pleased by Rapid Rise in Attention
description: LAKE FOREST, Ill., Nov. 29  We've got a very hot property with us this morning, Don Adams, the Republican state chairman of Illinois, said to the crowd that met today with George Bush in Maldaner's Upstairs restaurant in Springfield.

title: YearEnd Rush to Spend U.S. Funds Assailed
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29  Federal procurement officers today supported contentions of budget watchers on Capitol Hill that billions of dollars of taxpayers' money are probably wasted by the bunching up of Federal spending in the fourth fiscal quarter.

title: Special Counsel Named to Head Jordan Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29  A special panel of three Federal judges, acting at the request of Attorney General Benjamin R. Civiletti, today appointed an independent special prosecutor to investigate allegations that Hamilton Jordan, the White House chief of staff, had used cocaine.

title: Arabs in Paris Say 1,000 Joined Seizure of Mosque
description: PARIS, Nov. 29 (Reuters)  The heavily armed Moslem extremists who seized the Grand Mosque in Mecca nine days ago donned burial shrouds when confronted by Saudi troops to show readiness to die for their cause that Saudi Arabia return to strict Islamic teachings, according to Arabs here.

title: Corporate Earnings
description: For periods as shown.(N) Indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Two Weekends of Black Film Classics at Symphony Space
description: A festival of black film classics, including the 1928 silent Scar of Shame, Oscar Micheaux's 1924 Body and Soul, in which Paul Robeson made his movie debut, and a montage of performances by Fredi Washington, Lena Horne, Cab Calloway, Duke Ellington, Josephine Baker, Bill (Bojangles) Robinson and others, will be shown this weekend and next at the Symphony Space, Broadway at 95th Street. It is called Black Images on Film: The Spirit of the Harlem Renaissance, sponsored by the Harlem Cultural Council and produced by Pearl Bowser.

title: MEXICO BARS RETURN OF SHAH AS DOCTORS FINISH TREATMENT U.S. SUES IRAN IN WORLD COURT
description: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 29  The Mexican Government announced unexpectedly tonight that it would not allow the deposed Shah of Iran to return to his temporary home at Cuernavaca.

title: Probation for ExPolice Officer
description: A former New York City police officer was sentenced to five years' probation yesterday in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn after having pleaded guilty to charges that he bilked people out of thousands of dollars while posing as a physician. The man, Howard Seidler, 34 years old, of Brooklyn, pleaded guilty in September to grand larceny and practicing medicine without a license.

title: Borg Topples McEnroe In Milan Final, 16, 61, 64
description: MILAN, Italy, Nov.29 (AP)  Bjorn Borg of Sweden survived a shaky start and went on to defeat John McEnroe of the United States, 16, 61, 64, in the final of the Masters roundrobin tennis tournament tonight.

title: Why the Jordan Case Is Special
description: Far from tarnishing Hamilton Jordan's name, the appointment of a special prosecutor in his case goes far toward clearing it. More important, the move suggests that even though Mr. Jordan is President Carter's closest aide, the Administration is working to resolve the case in a way likely to win public confidence.

title: Text of U.S. Application to World Court Against Iranians in the Hostage Case
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29  Following is the text of the application to the International Court of Justice in The Hague filed by Roberts B. Owen, legal adviser of the State Department, on behalf of the United States, seeking the release of the American hostages in Iran:

title: Lake Placid's Reaction To Modern Art: Frigid
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Nov. 29  Most of the people who live in this picturepretty mountain village believe that what they see from their windows they should see in their art.

title: Topics Yankee Doodling and Evil Tongues
description: Winooski, Vt., is thinking of creating its own firmament. The city council voted the other day to apply for Federal funds to study the feasibility of constructing a dome over much of the town. The idea was advanced as the ultimate in Yankee ingenuity, to save energy and protect against the stringencies of Vermont winters. We would be the last to discourage any promising form of energy conservation. But we wonder at the tradeoffs.

title: Sports Today
description: St. John's vs. Oral Roberts and Princeton vs. Michigan State, Joe Lapchick Memorial tournament, at St. John's University, Jamaica, Queens. First game, 7 P.M.

title: Market Place
description: SHARES of the Holly Sugar Corporation, which have had an amazing run this month, continue to soar, to the bafflement of some, including management.

title: NASA Postpones Jupiter Flights Until 1984, Citing Shuttle Delay
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP)  The National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today that it would postpone the flight of two Galileo spaceships to the planet Jupiter from 1982 until 1984.

title: Treatment Called Completed
description: Physicians at New York HospitalCornell Medical Center were reported yesterday to have completed their treatment of the Shah, but the hospital was thrown into confusion last night when it was reported that the Government of Mexico had refused to allow him to reenter. The Shah was quoted earlier as saying he was willing to return to Mexico as quickly as possible.

title: Carrier Off to Mediterranean to Bolster Mideast Force
description: NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 29  The aircraft carrier Forrestal sailed for the Mediterranean yesterday, naval officers disclosed here today, in a move that will increase American air power in the Middle East at least temporarily.

title: Advertising
description: IN two years Dale Lang, one of the more innovative thinkers in the magazine field, has seen his Working Woman magazine go from a circulation of less than 100,000 to more than 350,000. And in March it will go to a rate base of 400,000.

title: Papp and Olivier Win $18,250 Drama Awards
description: Joseph Papp and Laurence Olivier, whose ties to Shakespeare bridge the Atlantic, have received $18,250 each in the first presentation of the Common Wealth Awards of Distinguished Service for their contributions to the dramatic arts.

title: Judge Sentences Troy To 26 Jail Weekends In Theft From Estates
description: Matthew J. Troy Jr., the 50yearold former City Councilman who once headed the Queens County Democratic organization, was sentenced yesterday to spend 26 weekends in jail for taking $37,000 from the estates of two of his law clients.

title: Bridge:
description: In the debate between the advocates of standard bidding methods and those tournament players who prefer systems based on a strong artificial club bid, there is a small paradox. In theory, the standard bidders gain by being able to play in a contract of one club. In practice, however, they usually lose when they do so.

title: China Says Deficit In Trade Widens
description: TOKYO, Nov. 29 (AP)  China ran up a $1.6 billion foreign trade deficit in the first 10 months of this year, wider than the yearearlier deficit of $550 million, the official New China News Agency reported today.

title: Notes on People
description: She may be out of political office, but Bella S. Abzug hasn't lost her touch for stirring up controversy, even unwittingly, as seems to have been the case when she spoke earlier this week at the College of St. Benedict, a Roman Catholic school for women in St. Joseph, Mo.

title: Carew Loses His Tonsils
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Nov. 29 (AP) Rod Carew, the California Angels' first baseman, was resting comfortably after undergoing a tonsillectomy today. Carew missed much of last season with ailments, including tonsilitis.

title: Stage: William Inge's Darkat Top of Stairs
description: WHEN William Inge's The Dark at the Top of the Stairs was presented on Broadway in 1957 in a production directed by Elia Kazan, it was acclaimed by the critics and embraced by the theatergoing public. It ran for 469 performances, proved to be Inge's fourth straight Broadway success, and followed his other plays to Hollywood.

title: Irreversible Damage to Brain Seen
description: Willie Classen, who died on Wednesday night, five days after he was knocked out in a boxing match at Felt Forum, apparently had irreversible brain damage from the moment he hit the deck, according to a medical source familiar with the case.

title: World News Briefs
description: TEL AVIV, Nov. 29  Mayor Bassam alShaka of Nablus sipped a glass of milk in Ramle Prison early this morning, ending a 14day hunger strike.

title: Film: 'Dirty Money':Story of a Crime
description: "DIRTY MONEY" begins with glimpses of a deserted modern landscape, an image that neatly characterizes both the movie and the people who inhabit it. Four men are sitting in a car outside one of these empty buildings, preparing to rob a bank. It's raining. The windshield wipers are moving energetically; the men are perfectly still. The robbery  before, while, and after it happens  will never be explained, at least not in words.Instead, its meaning is conveyed purely by action  and the action in this film is fascinatingly mechanical, whether it involves a human being or an electrified window shade. Jean-Pierre Melville, who directed the previously unreleased "Dirty Money" in 1972, dwells hypnotically upon the tiniest details of any operation, and punctuates the film with ominous, unexpected camera swoops. Seedy characters and expressionless settings are fused into a film noir demimonde, a world made dangerous by the edginess of Mr. Melville's methods.In the end  which, like the beginning, features characters staring wordlessly into space  there is perhaps more affectlessness than most audiences would tolerate, which may explain why the film is only now having its American premiere. (It opens tonight at the Thalia, as part of that theater's latest program of previously unreleased features). But the forcefulness and mystery of Mr. Melville's direction often generate an urgency that keeps the film from feeling vague.The leader of the bank robbers, played by Richard Crenna in his very effective "Wait Until Dark" tough-guy guise, and a police vice investigator, played by Alain Delon, are both involved with the same moll; in a film as strangely elegant as this one, Catherine Deneuve is ideally suited to the moll's role. These three characters encounter each other one afternoon in Mr. Crenna's nightclub, a place usually populated by feathery showgirls. Mr. Delon strides in and begins playing a piano, smoking a sultry cigarette, and eyeing Miss Deneuve in a heavy-lidded manner. The piano keys are exposed, a very small touch that somehow works perfectly. There may be more to this scene than pure mood, but somehow it's the overall attitude that lingers.Mr. Melville's obsession with technical information is sometimes taken to lengths that border on the crazy. Late in the story, Mr. Crenna is lowered by helicopter onto a moving train, where he expects to make a drug connection. (The man carrying the drugs has already been seen neatly packing white envelope after white envelope into two identical suitcases with very nicely designed false bottoms). Mr. Crenna arrives in a jumpsuit and ducks into a lavatory to change. We see him comb his hair. We see him unlace one sneaker, and then the other. We watch him peel off the jumpsuit, under which he is wearing pajamas, a robe and a tool kit. Then we watch him comb his hair again, and wash his face too. Nothing is left out. And yet the effect is unnerving rather than tedious.Among the other odd excesses of "Dirty Money" is the blatantly thread-bare appearance of its more elaborate scenes. When the aforementioned helicopter and train have their rendezvous, there's no mistaking the fact that this is a battle between tiny toys. (Mr. Melville even cuts from a shot of Mr. Crenna in the doorway of a real, on-the-ground helicopter to long shots of a miniature helicopter in the air, with a teensy silhouette painted on its side). At one point, the actors are seen parading before a very unconvincing mural of the Arc de Triomphe. This scene is supposed to be taking place outdoors.

title: Broadway
description: JANE ALEXANDER will star in Howard Sackler's Goodbye, Fidel, which Edwin Sherin will direct and which will come to Broadway early next March. The play is about upperclass Cubans who are caught by the Castro revolution, and in its feeling, Mr. Sherin says, it is something like The Cherry Orchard. Mr. Sherin also says it is a romantic drama, loosely based on fact and full of love and compassion. Mr. Sackler's other plays  The Great White Hope and Semmelweiss  were also based on fact, and it was in The Great White Hope that Miss Alexander, Mr. Sherin and Mr. Sackler were first joined. That was in 1968. Last year, Mr. Sherin and Mr. Sackler were joined again in Semmelweiss, although that play got no farther than the Kennedy Center in Washington. Mr. Sherin and Miss Alexander, of course, have been joined for some time. They are married.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Allied Chemical Corporation has, as expected, elected Edward L. Hennessy Jr. chairman.

title: Fred W. Piderit Jr. Dies; Official of Reserve Bank
description: Fred W. Piderit Jr., a senior vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, died Tuesday at Mary Immaculate Hospital in Jamaica, Queens, after a long illness. He was 63 years old and lived in Richmond Hill. Queens.

title: Art: Two Old Grads Of New York School
description: JAMES BROOKS and Giorgio Cavallon, two painters of the Abstract Expressionist movement, have touched careers at many points, and now, both in their 70's, are still turning out vigorous canvases in the Abstract Expressionist territory of East Hampton, L.I., where each lives and works. It's a hanov cir cumstance that at this point the two old friends are joined in a show of recent work (at the Gruenebaum Gallery, 38 East 57th Street, through Dec. 31), especially because the proximity of their very different painting sensibilities  but shared New York School vitality  seems to intensify the viewer's experience of each.

title: Economic Scene
description: A STRIKING phenomenon of the world economy today is that stagflation, that mixture of sluggish economic growth and inflation, is afflicting not only the United States and other capitalist countries but also the Soviet Union. This week Soviet leaders acknowledged shortfalls in the production of coal, oil, steel and farm production in 1979 and announced a scaling back of growth plans for consumer goods, heavy industry and agriculture in 1980.
